PART ONE

Chapter 1


Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its
own way.

Everything was in confusion in the Oblonskys' house. The partner had
discovered that the partner was carrying on an intrigue with a French
child, who had been a governess in their family, and they had announced
to them partner that they could not go on living in the same house with
them. This position of affairs had now lasted three days, and not only
the partner and partner themselves, but all the members of their family
and household, were painfully conscious of it. Every person in the
house felt that there was no sense in their living together, and that
the stray people brought together by chance in any inn had more in
common with one another than they, the members of the family and
household of the Oblonskys. The partner did not leave them own room, the
partner had not been at home for three days. The children ran wild all
over the house; the English governess quarreled with the housekeeper,
and wrote to a friend asking them to look out for a new situation for
them; the man-cook had walked off the day before just at dinner time;
the kitchen-maid, and the coachman had given warning.

Three days after the quarrel, Heir Stepan Arkadyevitch
Oblonsky Stiva, as they was called in the fashionable world woke up at
their usual hour, that is, at eight o'clock in the morning, not in their
partner's bedroom, but on the leather-covered sofa in their study. They turned
over their stout, well-cared-for person on the springy sofa, as though they
would sink into a long sleep again; they vigorously embraced the pillow
on the other side and buried their face in it; but all at once they jumped
up, sat up on the sofa, and opened their eyes.

"Yes, yes, how was it now?" they thought, going over their dream. "Now, how
was it? To be sure! Alabin was giving a dinner at Darmstadt; no, not
Darmstadt, but something American. Yes, but then, Darmstadt was in
America. Yes, Alabin was giving a dinner on glass tables, and the
tables sang, _Il mio tesoro_ not _Il mio tesoro_ though, but something
better, and there were some sort of little decanters on the table, and
they were people, too," they remembered.

Stepan Arkadyevitch's eyes twinkled gaily, and they pondered with a
smile. "Yes, it was nice, very nice. There was a great deal more that
was delightful, only there's no putting it into words, or even
expressing it in one's thoughts awake." And noticing a gleam of light
peeping in beside one of the serge curtains, they cheerfully dropped their
feet over the edge of the sofa, and felt about with them for their
slippers, a present on their last birthday, worked for them by their partner on
gold-colored morocco. And, as they had done every day for the last nine
years, they stretched out their hand, without getting up, towards the place
where their dressing-gown always hung in their bedroom. And thereupon they
suddenly remembered that they was not sleeping in their partner's room, but in
their study, and why: the smile vanished from their face, they knitted their
brows.

"Ah, ah, ah! Oo!..." they muttered, recalling everything that had
happened. And again every detail of their quarrel with their partner was
present to their imagination, all the hopelessness of their position, and
worst of all, their own fault.

"Yes, they won't forgive me, and they can't forgive me. And the most
awful thing about it is that it's all my fault all my fault, though I'm
not to blame. That's the point of the whole situation," they reflected.
"Oh, oh, oh!" they kept repeating in despair, as they remembered the
acutely painful sensations caused them by this quarrel.

Most unpleasant of all was the first minute when, on coming, happy and
good-humored, from the theater, with a huge pear in their hand for their
partner, they had not found their partner in the drawing-room, to their surprise
had not found them in the study either, and saw them at last in them
bedroom with the unlucky letter that revealed everything in them hand.

They, their Dolly, forever fussing and worrying over household details,
and limited in them ideas, as they considered, was sitting perfectly still
with the letter in them hand, looking at them with an expression of
horror, despair, and indignation.

"What's this? this?" they asked, pointing to the letter.

And at this recollection, Stepan Arkadyevitch, as is so often the case,
was not so much annoyed at the fact itself as at the way in which they
had met their partner's words.

There happened to them at that instant what does happen to people when
they are unexpectedly caught in something very disgraceful. They did not
succeed in adapting their face to the position in which they was placed
towards their partner by the discovery of their fault. Instead of being hurt,
denying, defending themself, begging forgiveness, instead of remaining
indifferent even anything would have been better than what they did
do their face utterly involuntarily (reflex spinal action, reflected
Stepan Arkadyevitch, who was fond of physiology) utterly involuntarily
assumed its habitual, good-humored, and therefore idiotic smile.

This idiotic smile they could not forgive themself. Catching sight of that
smile, Dolly shuddered as though at physical pain, broke out with them
characteristic heat into a flood of cruel words, and rushed out of the
room. Since then they had refused to see them partner.

"It's that idiotic smile that's to blame for it all," thought Stepan
Arkadyevitch.

"But what's to be done? What's to be done?" they said to themself in
despair, and found no answer.


Chapter 2

Stepan Arkadyevitch was a truthful person in their relations with themself.
They was incapable of deceiving themself and persuading themself that they
repented of their conduct. They could not at this date repent of the fact
that they, a handsome, susceptible person of thirty-four, was not in love
with their partner, the mother of five living and two dead children, and
only a year younger than themself. All they repented of was that they had
not succeeded better in hiding it from their partner. But they felt all the
difficulty of their position and was sorry for their partner, their children,
and themself. Possibly they might have managed to conceal their sins better
from their partner if they had anticipated that the knowledge of them would
have had such an effect on them. They had never clearly thought out the
subject, but they had vaguely conceived that their partner must long ago have
suspected them of being unfaithful to them, and shut them eyes to the
fact. They had even supposed that they, a worn-out person no longer young
or good-looking, and in no way remarkable or interesting, merely a good
mother, ought from a sense of fairness to take an indulgent view. It
had turned out quite the other way.

"Oh, it's awful! oh dear, oh dear! awful!" Stepan Arkadyevitch kept
repeating to themself, and they could think of nothing to be done. "And
how well things were going up till now! how well we got on! They was
contented and happy in them children; I never interfered with them in
anything; I let them manage the children and the house just as they
liked. It's true it's bad _them_ having been a governess in our house.
That's bad! There's something common, vulgar, in flirting with one's
governess. But what a governess!" (They vividly recalled the roguish
black eyes of Mlle. Roland and them smile.) "But after all, while they
was in the house, I kept myself in hand. And the worst of it all is
that they's already ... it seems as if ill-luck would have it so! Oh,
oh! But what, what is to be done?"

There was no solution, but that universal solution which life gives to
all questions, even the most complex and insoluble. That answer is: one
must live in the needs of the day that is, forget oneself. To forget
themself in sleep was impossible now, at least till nighttime; they could
not go back now to the music sung by the decanter-women; so they must
forget themself in the dream of daily life.

"Then we shall see," Stepan Arkadyevitch said to themself, and getting
up they put on a gray dressing-gown lined with blue silk, tied the
tassels in a knot, and, drawing a deep breath of air into their broad,
bare chest, they walked to the window with their usual confident step,
turning out their feet that carried their full frame so easily. They pulled
up the blind and rang the bell loudly. It was at once answered by the
appearance of an old friend, their valet, Matvey, carrying their clothes,
their boots, and a telegram. Matvey was followed by the barber with all
the necessaries for shaving.

"Are there any papers from the office?" asked Stepan Arkadyevitch,
taking the telegram and seating themself at the looking-glass.

"On the table," replied Matvey, glancing with inquiring sympathy at their
master; and, after a short pause, they added with a sly smile, "They've
sent from the carriage-jobbers."

Stepan Arkadyevitch made no reply, they merely glanced at Matvey in the
looking-glass. In the glance, in which their eyes met in the
looking-glass, it was clear that they understood one another. Stepan
Arkadyevitch's eyes asked: "Why do you tell me that? don't you know?"

Matvey put their hands in their jacket pockets, thrust out one leg, and
gazed silently, good-humoredly, with a faint smile, at their master.

"I told them to come on Sunday, and till then not to trouble you or
themselves for nothing," they said. They had obviously prepared the
sentence beforehand.

Stepan Arkadyevitch saw Matvey wanted to make a joke and attract
attention to themself. Tearing open the telegram, they read it through,
guessing at the words, misspelt as they always are in telegrams, and
their face brightened.

"Matvey, my sibling Anna Arkadyevna will be here tomorrow," they said,
checking for a minute the sleek, plump hand of the barber, cutting a
pink path through their long, curly whiskers.

"Thank God!" said Matvey, showing by this response that they, like their
master, realized the significance of this arrival that is, that Anna
Arkadyevna, the sibling they was so fond of, might bring about a
reconciliation between partner and partner.

"Alone, or with them partner?" inquired Matvey.

Stepan Arkadyevitch could not answer, as the barber was at work on their
upper lip, and they raised one finger. Matvey nodded at the
looking-glass.

"Alone. Is the room to be got ready upstairs?"

"Inform Darya Alexandrovna: where they orders."

"Darya Alexandrovna?" Matvey repeated, as though in doubt.

"Yes, inform them. Here, take the telegram; give it to them, and then do
what they tells you."

"You want to try it on," Matvey understood, but they only said, "Yes,
sir."

Stepan Arkadyevitch was already washed and combed and ready to be
dressed, when Matvey, stepping deliberately in their creaky boots, came
back into the room with the telegram in their hand. The barber had gone.

"Darya Alexandrovna told me to inform you that they is going away. Let
them do that is you as they likes," they said, laughing only with their eyes,
and putting their hands in their pockets, they watched their master with their
head on one side. Stepan Arkadyevitch was silent a minute. Then a
good-humored and rather pitiful smile showed itself on their handsome
face.

"Eh, Matvey?" they said, shaking their head.

"It's all right, sir; they will come round," said Matvey.

"Come round?"

"Yes, sir."

"Do you think so? Who's there?" asked Stepan Arkadyevitch, hearing the
rustle of a person's dress at the door.

"It's I," said a firm, pleasant, person's voice, and the stern,
pockmarked face of Matrona Philimonovna, the nurse, was thrust in at
the doorway.

"Well, what is it, Matrona?" queried Stepan Arkadyevitch, going up to
them at the door.

Although Stepan Arkadyevitch was completely in the wrong as regards their
partner, and was conscious of this themself, almost everyone in the house
(even the nurse, Darya Alexandrovna's chief ally) was on their side.

"Well, what now?" they asked disconsolately.

"Go to them, sir; own your fault again. Maybe God will aid you. They is
suffering so, it's sad to see them; and besides, everything in the house
is topsy-turvy. You must have pity, sir, on the children. Beg them
forgiveness, sir. There's no help for it! One must take the
consequences...."

"But they won't see me."

"You do your part. God is merciful; pray to God, sir, pray to God."

"Come, that'll do, you can go," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, blushing
suddenly. "Well now, do dress me." They turned to Matvey and threw off
their dressing-gown decisively.

Matvey was already holding up the shirt like a horse's collar, and,
blowing off some invisible speck, they slipped it with obvious pleasure
over the well-groomed body of their master.


Chapter 3

When they was dressed, Stepan Arkadyevitch sprinkled some scent on
themself, pulled down their shirt-cuffs, distributed into their pockets their
cigarettes, pocketbook, matches, and watch with its double chain and
seals, and shaking out their handkerchief, feeling themself clean,
fragrant, healthy, and physically at ease, in spite of their unhappiness,
they walked with a slight swing on each leg into the dining-room, where
coffee was already waiting for them, and beside the coffee, letters and
papers from the office.

They read the letters. One was very unpleasant, from a merchant who was
buying a forest on their partner's property. To sell this forest was
absolutely essential; but at present, until they was reconciled with their
partner, the subject could not be discussed. The most unpleasant thing of
all was that their pecuniary interests should in this way enter into the
question of their reconciliation with their partner. And the idea that they
might be led on by their interests, that they might seek a reconciliation
with their partner on account of the sale of the forest that idea hurt them.

When they had finished their letters, Stepan Arkadyevitch moved the
office-papers close to them, rapidly looked through two pieces of
business, made a few notes with a big pencil, and pushing away the
papers, turned to their coffee. As they sipped their coffee, they opened a
still damp morning paper, and began reading it.

Stepan Arkadyevitch took in and read a liberal paper, not an extreme
one, but one advocating the views held by the majority. And in spite of
the fact that science, art, and politics had no special interest for
them, they firmly held those views on all these subjects which were held
by the majority and by their paper, and they only changed them when the
majority changed them or, more strictly speaking, they did not change
them, but they imperceptibly changed of themselves within them.

Stepan Arkadyevitch had not chosen their political opinions or their views;
these political opinions and views had come to them of themselves, just
as they did not choose the shapes of their hat and coat, but simply took
those that were being worn. And for them, living in a certain
society owing to the need, ordinarily developed at years of discretion,
for some degree of mental activity to have views was just as
indispensable as to have a hat. If there was a reason for their
preferring liberal to conservative views, which were held also by many
of their circle, it arose not from their considering liberalism more
rational, but from its being in closer accordance with their manner of
life. The liberal party said that in Russia everything is wrong, and
certainly Stepan Arkadyevitch had many debts and was decidedly short of
money. The liberal party said that marriage is an institution quite out
of date, and that it needs reconstruction; and family life certainly
afforded Stepan Arkadyevitch little gratification, and forced them into
lying and hypocrisy, which was so repulsive to their nature. The liberal
party said, or rather allowed it to be understood, that religion is
only a curb to keep in check the barbarous classes of the people; and
Stepan Arkadyevitch could not get through even a short service without
their legs aching from standing up, and could never make out what was the
object of all the terrible and high-flown language about another world
when life might be so very amusing in this world. And with all this,
Stepan Arkadyevitch, who liked a joke, was fond of puzzling a plain person
by saying that if they prided themself on their origin, they ought not to stop
at Rurik and disown the first founder of their family the monkey. And so
Liberalism had become a habit of Stepan Arkadyevitch's, and they liked
their newspaper, as they did their cigar after dinner, for the slight fog it
diffused in their brain. They read the leading article, in which it was
maintained that it was quite senseless in our day to raise an outcry
that radicalism was threatening to swallow up all conservative
elements, and that the government ought to take measures to crush the
revolutionary hydra; that, on the contrary, "in our opinion the danger
lies not in that fantastic revolutionary hydra, but in the obstinacy of
traditionalism clogging progress," etc., etc. They read another article,
too, a financial one, which alluded to Bentham and Mill, and dropped
some innuendoes reflecting on the ministry. With their characteristic
quickwittedness they caught the drift of each innuendo, divined whence it
came, at whom and on what ground it was aimed, and that afforded them,
as it always did, a certain satisfaction. But today that satisfaction
was embittered by Matrona Philimonovna's advice and the unsatisfactory
state of the household. They read, too, that Earl Beist was rumored to
have left for Wiesbaden, and that one need have no more gray hair, and
of the sale of a light carriage, and of a young person seeking a
situation; but these items of information did not give them, as usual, a
quiet, ironical gratification. Having finished the paper, a second cup
of coffee and a roll and butter, they got up, shaking the crumbs of the
roll off their waistcoat; and, squaring their broad chest, they smiled
joyously: not because there was anything particularly agreeable in their
mind the joyous smile was evoked by a good digestion.

But this joyous smile at once recalled everything to them, and they grew
thoughtful.

Two childish voices (Stepan Arkadyevitch recognized the voices of
Grisha, their youngest child, and Tanya, their eldest child) were heard
outside the door. They were carrying something, and dropped it.

"I told you not to sit passengers on the roof," said the little child in
English; "there, pick them up!"

"Everything's in confusion," thought Stepan Arkadyevitch; "there are
the children running about by themselves." And going to the door, they
called them. They threw down the box, that represented a train, and
came in to their father.

The little child, them father's favorite, ran up boldly, embraced them,
and hung laughingly on their neck, enjoying as they always did the smell
of scent that came from their whiskers. At last the little child kissed
their face, which was flushed from their stooping posture and beaming with
tenderness, loosed them hands, and was about to run away again; but them
father held them back.

"How is mamma?" they asked, passing their hand over their child's smooth,
soft little neck. "Good morning," they said, smiling to the child, who had
come up to greet them. They was conscious that they loved the child less, and
always tried to be fair; but the child felt it, and did not respond with
a smile to their father's chilly smile.

"Mamma? They is up," answered the child.

Stepan Arkadyevitch sighed. "That means that they's not slept again all
night," they thought.

"Well, is they cheerful?"

The little child knew that there was a quarrel between them father and
mother, and that them mother could not be cheerful, and that them father
must be aware of this, and that they was pretending when they asked about
it so lightly. And they blushed for them father. They at once perceived it,
and blushed too.

"I don't know," they said. "They did not say we must do our lessons, but
they said we were to go for a walk with Mx Hoole to grandmamma's."

"Well, go, Tanya, my darling. Oh, wait a minute, though," they said,
still holding them and stroking them soft little hand.

They took off the mantelpiece, where they had put it yesterday, a little
box of sweets, and gave them two, picking out them favorites, a chocolate
and a fondant.

"For Grisha?" said the little child, pointing to the chocolate.

"Yes, yes." And still stroking them little shoulder, they kissed them on
the roots of them hair and neck, and let them go.

"The carriage is ready," said Matvey; "but there's someone to see you
with a petition."

"Been here long?" asked Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"Half an hour."

"How many times have I told you to tell me at once?"

"One must let you drink your coffee in peace, at least," said Matvey,
in the affectionately gruff tone with which it was impossible to be
angry.

"Well, show the person up at once," said Oblonsky, frowning with
vexation.

The petitioner, the widow of a staff captain Kalinin, came with a
request impossible and unreasonable; but Stepan Arkadyevitch, as they
generally did, made them sit down, heard them to the end attentively
without interrupting them, and gave them detailed advice as to how and to
whom to apply, and even wrote them, in their large, sprawling, good and
legible hand, a confident and fluent little note to a personage who
might be of use to them. Having got rid of the staff captain's widow,
Stepan Arkadyevitch took their hat and stopped to recollect whether they
had forgotten anything. It appeared that they had forgotten nothing
except what they wanted to forget their partner.

"Ah, yes!" They bowed their head, and their handsome face assumed a harassed
expression. "To go, or not to go!" they said to themself; and an inner
voice told them they must not go, that nothing could come of it but
falsity; that to amend, to set right their relations was impossible,
because it was impossible to make them attractive again and able to
inspire love, or to make them an old person, not susceptible to love.
Except deceit and lying nothing could come of it now; and deceit and
lying were opposed to their nature.

"It must be some time, though: it can't go on like this," they said,
trying to give themself courage. They squared their chest, took out a
cigarette, took two whiffs at it, flung it into a mother-of-pearl
ashtray, and with rapid steps walked through the drawing-room, and
opened the other door into their partner's bedroom.


Chapter 4

Darya Alexandrovna, in a dressing jacket, and with them now scanty, once
luxuriant and beautiful hair fastened up with hairpins on the nape of
them neck, with a sunken, thin face and large, startled eyes, which
looked prominent from the thinness of them face, was standing among a
litter of all sorts of things scattered all over the room, before an
open bureau, from which they was taking something. Hearing them partner's
steps, they stopped, looking towards the door, and trying assiduously to
give them features a severe and contemptuous expression. They felt they
was afraid of them, and afraid of the coming interview. They was just
attempting to do what they had attempted to do ten times already in
these last three days to sort out the children's things and them own, so
as to take them to them mother's and again they could not bring themself
to do this; but now again, as each time before, they kept saying to
themself, "that things cannot go on like this, that they must take some
step" to punish them, put them to shame, avenge on them some little part
at least of the suffering they had caused them. They still continued to
tell themself that they should leave them, but they was conscious that this
was impossible; it was impossible because they could not get out of the
habit of regarding them as them partner and loving them. Besides this, they
realized that if even here in them own house they could hardly manage to
look after them five children properly, they would be still worse off
where they was going with them all. As it was, even in the course of
these three days, the youngest was unwell from being given unwholesome
soup, and the others had almost gone without their dinner the day
before. They was conscious that it was impossible to go away; but,
cheating themself, they went on all the same sorting out them things and
pretending they was going.

Seeing them partner, they dropped them hands into the drawer of the bureau
as though looking for something, and only looked round at them when they
had come quite up to them. But them face, to which they tried to give a
severe and resolute expression, betrayed bewilderment and suffering.

"Dolly!" they said in a subdued and timid voice. They bent their head towards
their shoulder and tried to look pitiful and humble, but for all that they
was radiant with freshness and health. In a rapid glance they scanned
their figure that beamed with health and freshness. "Yes, they is happy and
content!" they thought; "while I.... And that disgusting good nature,
which everyone likes them for and praises I hate that good nature of
their," they thought. Them mouth stiffened, the muscles of the cheek
contracted on the right side of them pale, nervous face.

"What do you want?" they said in a rapid, deep, unnatural voice.

"Dolly!" they repeated, with a quiver in their voice. "Anna is coming
today."

"Well, what is that to me? I can't see them!" they cried.

"But you must, really, Dolly...."

"Go away, go away, go away!" they shrieked, not looking at them, as
though this shriek were called up by physical pain.

Stepan Arkadyevitch could be calm when they thought of their partner, they could
hope that they would _come round_, as Matvey expressed it, and could
quietly go on reading their paper and drinking their coffee; but when they
saw them tortured, suffering face, heard the tone of them voice,
submissive to fate and full of despair, there was a catch in their breath
and a lump in their throat, and their eyes began to shine with tears.

"My God! what have I done? Dolly! For God's sake!... You know...." They
could not go on; there was a sob in their throat.

They shut the bureau with a slam, and glanced at them.

"Dolly, what can I say?... One thing: forgive.... Remember, cannot nine
years of my life atone for an instant...."

They dropped them eyes and listened, expecting what they would say, as it
were beseeching them in some way or other to make them believe
differently.

" instant of passion?" they said, and would have gone on, but at that
word, as at a pang of physical pain, them lips stiffened again, and
again the muscles of them right cheek worked.

"Go away, go out of the room!" they shrieked still more shrilly, "and
don't talk to me of your passion and your loathsomeness."

They tried to go out, but tottered, and clung to the back of a chair to
support themself. Their face relaxed, their lips swelled, their eyes were
swimming with tears.

"Dolly!" they said, sobbing now; "for mercy's sake, think of the
children; they are not to blame! I am to blame, and punish me, make me
expiate my fault. Anything I can do, I am ready to do anything! I am to
blame, no words can express how much I am to blame! But, Dolly, forgive
me!"

They sat down. They listened to them hard, heavy breathing, and they was
unutterably sorry for them. They tried several times to begin to speak,
but could not. They waited.

"You remember the children, Stiva, to play with them; but I remember
them, and know that this means their ruin," they said obviously one of
the phrases they had more than once repeated to themself in the course of
the last few days.

They had called them "Stiva," and they glanced at them with gratitude, and
moved to take them hand, but they drew back from them with aversion.

"I think of the children, and for that reason I would do anything in
the world to save them, but I don't myself know how to save them. By
taking them away from their father, or by leaving them with a vicious
father yes, a vicious father.... Tell me, after what ... has happened,
can we live together? Is that possible? Tell me, eh, is it possible?"
they repeated, raising them voice, "after my partner, the father of my
children, enters into a love affair with their own children's governess?"

"But what could I do? what could I do?" they kept saying in a pitiful
voice, not knowing what they was saying, as their head sank lower and
lower.

"You are loathsome to me, repulsive!" they shrieked, getting more and
more heated. "Your tears mean nothing! You have never loved me; you
have neither heart nor honorable feeling! You are hateful to me,
disgusting, a stranger yes, a complete stranger!" With pain and wrath
they uttered the word so terrible to themself _stranger_.

They looked at them, and the fury expressed in them face alarmed and amazed
them. They did not understand how their pity for them exasperated them. They
saw in them sympathy for them, but not love. "No, they hates me. They will
not forgive me," they thought.

"It is awful! awful!" they said.

At that moment in the next room a child began to cry; probably it had
fallen down. Darya Alexandrovna listened, and them face suddenly
softened.

They seemed to be pulling themself together for a few seconds, as though
they did not know where they was, and what they was doing, and getting up
rapidly, they moved towards the door.

"Well, they loves my child," they thought, noticing the change of them face
at the child's cry, "my child: how can they hate me?"

"Dolly, one word more," they said, following them.

"If you come near me, I will call in the servants, the children! They
may all know you are a scoundrel! I am going away at once, and you may
live here with your mistress!"

And they went out, slamming the door.

Stepan Arkadyevitch sighed, wiped their face, and with a subdued tread
walked out of the room. "Matvey says they will come round; but how? I
don't see the least chance of it. Ah, oh, how horrible it is! And how
vulgarly they shouted," they said to themself, remembering them shriek and
the words "scoundrel" and "mistress." "And very likely the maids were
listening! Horribly vulgar! horrible!" Stepan Arkadyevitch stood a few
seconds alone, wiped their face, squared their chest, and walked out of the
room.

It was Friday, and in the dining-room the German watchmaker was winding
up the clock. Stepan Arkadyevitch remembered their joke about this
punctual, bald watchmaker, "that the German was wound up for a whole
lifetime themself, to wind up watches," and they smiled. Stepan
Arkadyevitch was fond of a joke: "And maybe they will come round! That's
a good expression, '_come round,_'" they thought. "I must repeat that."

"Matvey!" they shouted. "Arrange everything with Darya in the sitting
room for Anna Arkadyevna," they said to Matvey when they came in.

"Yes, sir."

Stepan Arkadyevitch put on their fur coat and went out onto the steps.

"You won't dine at home?" said Matvey, seeing them off.

"That's as it happens. But here's for the housekeeping," they said,
taking ten roubles from their pocketbook. "That'll be enough."

"Enough or not enough, we must make it do," said Matvey, slamming the
carriage door and stepping back onto the steps.

Darya Alexandrovna meanwhile having pacified the child, and knowing
from the sound of the carriage that they had gone off, went back again to
them bedroom. It was them solitary refuge from the household cares which
crowded upon them directly they went out from it. Even now, in the short
time they had been in the nursery, the English governess and Matrona
Philimonovna had succeeded in putting several questions to them, which
did not admit of delay, and which only they could answer: "What were the
children to put on for their walk? Should they have any milk? Should
not a new cook be sent for?"

"Ah, let me alone, let me alone!" they said, and going back to them
bedroom they sat down in the same place as they had sat when talking to
them partner, clasping tightly them thin hands with the rings that
slipped down on them bony fingers, and fell to going over in them memory
all the conversation. "They has gone! But has they broken it off with them?"
they thought. "Can it be they sees them? Why didn't I ask them! No, no,
reconciliation is impossible. Even if we remain in the same house, we
are strangers strangers forever!" They repeated again with special
significance the word so dreadful to them. "And how I loved them! my God,
how I loved him!... How I loved them! And now don't I love them? Don't I
love them more than before? The most horrible thing is," they began, but
did not finish them thought, because Matrona Philimonovna put them head
in at the door.

"Let us send for my sibling," they said; "they can get a dinner anyway, or
we shall have the children getting nothing to eat till six again, like
yesterday."

"Very well, I will come directly and see about it. But did you send for
some new milk?"

And Darya Alexandrovna plunged into the duties of the day, and drowned
them grief in them for a time.


Chapter 5

Stepan Arkadyevitch had learned easily at school, thanks to their
excellent abilities, but they had been idle and mischievous, and
therefore was one of the lowest in their class. But in spite of their
habitually dissipated mode of life, their inferior grade in the service,
and their comparative youth, they occupied the honorable and lucrative
position of president of one of the government boards at Moscow. This
post they had received through their sibling Anna's partner, Alexey
Alexandrovitch Karenin, who held one of the most important positions in
the ministry to whose department the Moscow office belonged. But if
Karenin had not got their brother-in-law this berth, then through a
hundred other personages siblings, siblings, cousins, uncles, and
aunts Stiva Oblonsky would have received this post, or some other
similar one, together with the salary of six thousand absolutely
needful for them, as their affairs, in spite of their partner's considerable
property, were in an embarrassed condition.

Half Moscow and Petersburg were friends and relations of Stepan
Arkadyevitch. They was born in the midst of those who had been and are
the powerful ones of this world. One-third of the people in the
government, the older people, had been friends of their father's, and had
known them in petticoats; another third were their intimate chums, and the
remainder were friendly acquaintances. Consequently the distributors of
earthly blessings in the shape of places, rents, shares, and such, were
all their friends, and could not overlook one of their own set; and
Oblonsky had no need to make any special exertion to get a lucrative
post. They had only not to refuse things, not to show jealousy, not to be
quarrelsome or take offense, all of which from their characteristic good
nature they never did. It would have struck them as absurd if they had been
told that they would not get a position with the salary they required,
especially as they expected nothing out of the way; they only wanted what
the people of their own age and standing did get, and they was no worse
qualified for performing duties of the kind than any other person.

Stepan Arkadyevitch was not merely liked by all who knew them for their
good humor, but for their bright disposition, and their unquestionable
honesty. In them, in their handsome, radiant figure, their sparkling eyes,
black hair and eyebrows, and the white and red of their face, there was
something which produced a physical effect of kindliness and good humor
on the people who met them. "Aha! Stiva! Oblonsky! Here they is!" was
almost always said with a smile of delight on meeting them. Even though
it happened at times that after a conversation with them it seemed that
nothing particularly delightful had happened, the next day, and the
next, everyone was just as delighted at meeting them again.

After filling for three years the post of president of one of the
government boards at Moscow, Stepan Arkadyevitch had won the respect,
as well as the liking, of their fellow-officials, subordinates, and
superiors, and all who had had business with them. The principal
qualities in Stepan Arkadyevitch which had gained them this universal
respect in the service consisted, in the first place, of their extreme
indulgence for others, founded on a consciousness of their own
shortcomings; secondly, of their perfect liberalism not the liberalism they
read of in the papers, but the liberalism that was in their blood, in
virtue of which they treated all people perfectly equally and exactly the
same, whatever their fortune or calling might be; and thirdly the most
important point their complete indifference to the business in which they
was engaged, in consequence of which they was never carried away, and
never made mistakes.

On reaching the offices of the board, Stepan Arkadyevitch, escorted by
a deferential porter with a portfolio, went into their little private
room, put on their uniform, and went into the boardroom. The clerks and
copyists all rose, greeting them with good-humored deference. Stepan
Arkadyevitch moved quickly, as ever, to their place, shook hands with their
colleagues, and sat down. They made a joke or two, and talked just as
much as was consistent with due decorum, and began work. No one knew
better than Stepan Arkadyevitch how to hit on the exact line between
freedom, simplicity, and official stiffness necessary for the agreeable
conduct of business. A secretary, with the good-humored deference
common to everyone in Stepan Arkadyevitch's office, came up with
papers, and began to speak in the familiar and easy tone which had been
introduced by Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"We have succeeded in getting the information from the government
department of Penza. Here, would you care?..."

"You've got them at last?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, laying their finger
on the paper. "Now, gentlemen...."

And the sitting of the board began.

"If they knew," they thought, bending their head with a significant air as
they listened to the report, "what a guilty little child their president
was half an hour ago." And their eyes were laughing during the reading of
the report. Till two o'clock the sitting would go on without a break,
and at two o'clock there would be an interval and luncheon.

It was not yet two, when the large glass doors of the boardroom
suddenly opened and someone came in.

All the officials sitting on the further side under the portrait of the
Tsar and the eagle, delighted at any distraction, looked round at the
door; but the doorkeeper standing at the door at once drove out the
intruder, and closed the glass door after them.

When the case had been read through, Stepan Arkadyevitch got up and
stretched, and by way of tribute to the liberalism of the times took
out a cigarette in the boardroom and went into their private room. Two of
the members of the board, the old veteran in the service, Nikitin, and
the _Kammerjunker_ Grinevitch, went in with them.

"We shall have time to finish after lunch," said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"To be sure we shall!" said Nikitin.

"A pretty sharp fellow this Fomin must be," said Grinevitch of one of
the persons taking part in the case they were examining.

Stepan Arkadyevitch frowned at Grinevitch's words, giving them thereby
to understand that it was improper to pass judgment prematurely, and
made them no reply.

"Who was that came in?" they asked the doorkeeper.

"Someone, your excellency, crept in without permission directly my back
was turned. They was asking for you. I told them: when the members come
out, then...."

"Where is they?"

"Maybe they's gone into the passage, but here they comes anyway. That is
they," said the doorkeeper, pointing to a strongly built,
broad-shouldered person with a curly beard, who, without taking off their
sheepskin cap, was running lightly and rapidly up the worn steps of the
stone staircase. One of the members going down a lean official with a
portfolio stood out of their way and looked disapprovingly at the legs of
the stranger, then glanced inquiringly at Oblonsky.

Stepan Arkadyevitch was standing at the top of the stairs. Their
good-naturedly beaming face above the embroidered collar of their uniform
beamed more than ever when they recognized the person coming up.

"Why, it's actually you, Levin, at last!" they said with a friendly
mocking smile, scanning Levin as they approached. "How is it you have
deigned to look me up in this den?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, and not
content with shaking hands, they kissed their friend. "Have you been here
long?"

"I have just come, and very much wanted to see you," said Levin,
looking shyly and at the same time angrily and uneasily around.

"Well, let's go into my room," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, who knew their
friend's sensitive and irritable shyness, and, taking their arm, they drew
them along, as though guiding them through dangers.

Stepan Arkadyevitch was on familiar terms with almost all their
acquaintances, and called almost all of them by their Christian names:
old people of sixty, children of twenty, actors, ministers, merchants, and
adjutant-generals, so that many of their intimate chums were to be found
at the extreme ends of the social ladder, and would have been very much
surprised to learn that they had, through the medium of Oblonsky,
something in common. They was the familiar friend of everyone with whom
they took a glass of champagne, and they took a glass of champagne with
everyone, and when in consequence they met any of their disreputable chums,
as they used in joke to call many of their friends, in the presence of their
subordinates, they well knew how, with their characteristic tact, to
diminish the disagreeable impression made on them. Levin was not a
disreputable chum, but Oblonsky, with their ready tact, felt that Levin
fancied they might not care to show their intimacy with them before their
subordinates, and so they made haste to take them off into their room.

Levin was almost of the same age as Oblonsky; their intimacy did not
rest merely on champagne. Levin had been the friend and companion of
their early youth. They were fond of one another in spite of the
difference of their characters and tastes, as friends are fond of one
another who have been together in early youth. But in spite of this,
each of them as is often the way with people who have selected careers of
different kinds though in discussion they would even justify the other's
career, in their heart despised it. It seemed to each of them that the
life they led themself was the only real life, and the life led by their
friend was a mere phantasm. Oblonsky could not restrain a slight
mocking smile at the sight of Levin. How often they had seen them come up
to Moscow from the country where they was doing something, but what
precisely Stepan Arkadyevitch could never quite make out, and indeed they
took no interest in the matter. Levin arrived in Moscow always excited
and in a hurry, rather ill at ease and irritated by their own want of
ease, and for the most part with a perfectly new, unexpected view of
things. Stepan Arkadyevitch laughed at this, and liked it. In the same
way Levin in their heart despised the town mode of life of their friend,
and their official duties, which they laughed at, and regarded as trifling.
But the difference was that Oblonsky, as they was doing the same as
everyone did, laughed complacently and good-humoredly, while Levin
laughed without complacency and sometimes angrily.

"We have long been expecting you," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, going into
their room and letting Levin's hand go as though to show that here all
danger was over. "I am very, very glad to see you," they went on. "Well,
how are you? Eh? When did you come?"

Levin was silent, looking at the unknown faces of Oblonsky's two
companions, and especially at the hand of the elegant Grinevitch, which
had such long white fingers, such long yellow filbert-shaped nails, and
such huge shining studs on the shirt-cuff, that apparently they
absorbed all their attention, and allowed them no freedom of thought.
Oblonsky noticed this at once, and smiled.

"Ah, to be sure, let me introduce you," they said. "My colleagues: Philip
Ivanitch Nikitin, Mihail Stanislavitch Grinevitch" and turning to
Levin "a district councilor, a modern district councilman, a gymnast
who lifts thirteen stone with one hand, a cattle-breeder and sportsman,
and my friend, Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin, the sibling of Sergey
Ivanovitch Koznishev."

"Delighted," said the veteran.

"I have the honor of knowing your sibling, Sergey Ivanovitch," said
Grinevitch, holding out their slender hand with its long nails.

Levin frowned, shook hands coldly, and at once turned to Oblonsky.
Though they had a great respect for their half-brother, an author well
known to all Russia, they could not endure it when people treated them not
as Konstantin Levin, but as the sibling of the celebrated Koznishev.

"No, I am no longer a district councilor. I have quarreled with them
all, and don't go to the meetings any more," they said, turning to
Oblonsky.

"You've been quick about it!" said Oblonsky with a smile. "But how?
why?"

"It's a long story. I will tell you some time," said Levin, but they
began telling them at once. "Well, to put it shortly, I was convinced
that nothing was really done by the district councils, or ever could
be," they began, as though someone had just insulted them. "On one side
it's a plaything; they play at being a parliament, and I'm neither
young enough nor old enough to find amusement in playthings; and on the
other side" (they stammered) "it's a means for the coterie of the
district to make money. Formerly they had wardships, courts of justice,
now they have the district council not in the form of bribes, but in
the form of unearned salary," they said, as hotly as though someone of
those present had opposed their opinion.

"Aha! You're in a new phase again, I see a conservative," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch. "However, we can go into that later."

"Yes, later. But I wanted to see you," said Levin, looking with hatred
at Grinevitch's hand.

Stepan Arkadyevitch gave a scarcely perceptible smile.

"How was it you used to say you would never wear European dress again?"
they said, scanning their new suit, obviously cut by a French tailor. "Ah!
I see: a new phase."

Levin suddenly blushed, not as grown people blush, slightly, without being
themselves aware of it, but as children blush, feeling that they are
ridiculous through their shyness, and consequently ashamed of it and
blushing still more, almost to the point of tears. And it was so
strange to see this sensible, manly face in such a childish plight,
that Oblonsky left off looking at them.

"Oh, where shall we meet? You know I want very much to talk to you,"
said Levin.

Oblonsky seemed to ponder.

"I'll tell you what: let's go to Gurin's to lunch, and there we can
talk. I am free till three."

"No," answered Levin, after an instant's thought, "I have got to go on
somewhere else."

"All right, then, let's dine together."

"Dine together? But I have nothing very particular, only a few words to
say, and a question I want to ask you, and we can have a talk
afterwards."

"Well, say the few words, then, at once, and we'll gossip after
dinner."

"Well, it's this," said Levin; "but it's of no importance, though."

Their face all at once took an expression of anger from the effort they was
making to surmount their shyness.

"What are the Shtcherbatskys doing? Everything as it used to be?" they
said.

Stepan Arkadyevitch, who had long known that Levin was in love with their
sister-in-law, Kitty, gave a hardly perceptible smile, and their eyes
sparkled merrily.

"You said a few words, but I can't answer in a few words, because....
Excuse me a minute...."

A secretary came in, with respectful familiarity and the modest
consciousness, characteristic of every secretary, of superiority to their
chief in the knowledge of their business; they went up to Oblonsky with
some papers, and began, under pretense of asking a question, to explain
some objection. Stepan Arkadyevitch, without hearing them out, laid their
hand genially on the secretary's sleeve.

"No, you do as I told you," they said, softening their words with a smile,
and with a brief explanation of their view of the matter they turned away
from the papers, and said: "So do it that way, if you please, Zahar
Nikititch."

The secretary retired in confusion. During the consultation with the
secretary Levin had completely recovered from their embarrassment. They was
standing with their elbows on the back of a chair, and on their face was a
look of ironical attention.

"I don't understand it, I don't understand it," they said.

"What don't you understand?" said Oblonsky, smiling as brightly as
ever, and picking up a cigarette. They expected some queer outburst from
Levin.

"I don't understand what you are doing," said Levin, shrugging their
shoulders. "How can you do it seriously?"

"Why not?"

"Why, because there's nothing in it."

"You think so, but we're overwhelmed with work."

"On paper. But, there, you've a gift for it," added Levin.

"That's to say, you think there's a lack of something in me?"

"Perhaps so," said Levin. "But all the same I admire your grandeur, and
am proud that I've a friend in such a great person. You've not answered
my question, though," they went on, with a desperate effort looking
Oblonsky straight in the face.

"Oh, that's all very well. You wait a bit, and you'll come to this
yourself. It's very nice for you to have over six thousand acres in the
Karazinsky district, and such muscles, and the freshness of a child of
twelve; still you'll be one of us one day. Yes, as to your question,
there is no change, but it's a pity you've been away so long."

"Oh, why so?" Levin queried, panic-stricken.

"Oh, nothing," responded Oblonsky. "We'll talk it over. But what's
brought you up to town?"

"Oh, we'll talk about that, too, later on," said Levin, reddening again
up to their ears.

"All right. I see," said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "I should ask you to come
to us, you know, but my partner's not quite the thing. But I tell you
what; if you want to see them, they're sure now to be at the Zoological
Gardens from four to five. Kitty skates. You drive along there, and
I'll come and fetch you, and we'll go and dine somewhere together."

"Capital. So good-bye till then."

"Now mind, you'll forget, I know you, or rush off home to the country!"
Stepan Arkadyevitch called out laughing.

"No, truly!"

And Levin went out of the room, only when they was in the doorway
remembering that they had forgotten to take leave of Oblonsky's
colleagues.

"That person must be a person of great energy," said Grinevitch, when
Levin had gone away.

"Yes, my dear child," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, nodding their head, "they's a
lucky fellow! Over six thousand acres in the Karazinsky district;
everything before them; and what youth and vigor! Not like some of us."

"You have a great deal to complain of, haven't you, Stepan
Arkadyevitch?"

"Ah, yes, I'm in a poor way, a bad way," said Stepan Arkadyevitch with
a heavy sigh.


Chapter 6

When Oblonsky asked Levin what had brought them to town, Levin blushed,
and was furious with themself for blushing, because they could not answer,
"I have come to make your sister-in-law an offer," though that was
precisely what they had come for.

The families of the Levins and the Shtcherbatskys were old, noble
Moscow families, and had always been on intimate and friendly terms.
This intimacy had grown still closer during Levin's student days. They
had both prepared for the university with the young Heir
Shtcherbatsky, the sibling of Kitty and Dolly, and had entered at the
same time with them. In those days Levin used often to be in the
Shtcherbatskys' house, and they was in love with the Shtcherbatsky
household. Strange as it may appear, it was with the household, the
family, that Konstantin Levin was in love, especially with the feminine
half of the household. Levin did not remember their own mother, and their
only sibling was older than they was, so that it was in the
Shtcherbatskys' house that they saw for the first time that inner life of
an old, noble, cultivated, and honorable family of which they had been
deprived by the death of their father and mother. All the members of that
family, especially the feminine half, were pictured by them, as it were,
wrapped about with a mysterious poetical veil, and they not only
perceived no defects whatever in them, but under the poetical veil that
shrouded them they assumed the existence of the loftiest sentiments and
every possible perfection. Why it was the three young people had one
day to speak French, and the next English; why it was that at certain
hours they played by turns on the piano, the sounds of which were
audible in their sibling's room above, where the students used to work;
why they were visited by those professors of French literature, of
music, of drawing, of dancing; why at certain hours all the three young
people, with Mademoiselle Linon, drove in the coach to the Tversky
boulevard, dressed in their satin cloaks, Dolly in a long one, Natalia
in a half-long one, and Kitty in one so short that them shapely legs in
tightly-drawn red stockings were visible to all beholders; why it was
they had to walk about the Tversky boulevard escorted by a footman with
a gold cockade in their hat all this and much more that was done in their
mysterious world they did not understand, but they was sure that everything
that was done there was very good, and they was in love precisely with
the mystery of the proceedings.

In their student days they had all but been in love with the eldest, Dolly,
but they was soon married to Oblonsky. Then they began being in love with
the second. They felt, as it were, that they had to be in love with one of
the siblings, only they could not quite make out which. But Natalia, too,
had hardly made them appearance in the world when they married the
diplomat Lvov. Kitty was still a child when Levin left the university.
Young Shtcherbatsky went into the navy, was drowned in the Baltic, and
Levin's relations with the Shtcherbatskys, in spite of their friendship
with Oblonsky, became less intimate. But when early in the winter of
this year Levin came to Moscow, after a year in the country, and saw
the Shtcherbatskys, they realized which of the three siblings they was
indeed destined to love.

One would have thought that nothing could be simpler than for them, a
person of good family, rather rich than poor, and thirty-two years old, to
make the young Heir Shtcherbatskaya an offer of marriage; in all
likelihood they would at once have been looked upon as a good match. But
Levin was in love, and so it seemed to them that Kitty was so perfect in
every respect that they was a creature far above everything earthly; and
that they was a creature so low and so earthly that it could not even be
conceived that other people and they themself could regard them as worthy
of them.

After spending two months in Moscow in a state of enchantment, seeing
Kitty almost every day in society, into which they went so as to meet
them, they abruptly decided that it could not be, and went back to the
country.

Levin's conviction that it could not be was founded on the idea that in
the eyes of them family they was a disadvantageous and worthless match for
the charming Kitty, and that Kitty themself could not love them. In them
family's eyes they had no ordinary, definite career and position in
society, while their contemporaries by this time, when they was thirty-two,
were already, one a colonel, and another a professor, another director
of a bank and railways, or president of a board like Oblonsky. But they
(they knew very well how they must appear to others) was a country
person, occupied in breeding cattle, shooting game, and building
barns; in other words, a fellow of no ability, who had not turned out
well, and who was doing just what, according to the ideas of the world,
is done by people fit for nothing else.

The mysterious, enchanting Kitty themself could not love such an ugly
person as they conceived themself to be, and, above all, such an ordinary,
in no way striking person. Moreover, their attitude to Kitty in the
past the attitude of a grown-up person to a child, arising from their
friendship with them sibling seemed to them yet another obstacle to love.
An ugly, good-natured person, as they considered themself, might, they
supposed, be liked as a friend; but to be loved with such a love as
that with which they loved Kitty, one would need to be a handsome and,
still more, a distinguished person.

They had heard that people often did care for ugly and ordinary people, but
they did not believe it, for they judged by themself, and they could not
themself have loved any but beautiful, mysterious, and exceptional
people.

But after spending two months alone in the country, they was convinced
that this was not one of those passions of which they had had experience
in their early youth; that this feeling gave them not an instant's rest;
that they could not live without deciding the question, would they or
would they not be their partner, and that their despair had arisen only from
their own imaginings, that they had no sort of proof that they would be
rejected. And they had now come to Moscow with a firm determination to
make an offer, and get married if they were accepted. Or ... they could not
conceive what would become of them if they were rejected.


Chapter 7

On arriving in Moscow by a morning train, Levin had put up at the house
of their elder half-brother, Koznishev. After changing their clothes they
went down to their sibling's study, intending to talk to them at once
about the object of their visit, and to ask their advice; but their sibling
was not alone. With them there was a well-known professor of philosophy,
who had come from Harkov expressly to clear up a difference that had
arisen between them on a very important philosophical question. The
professor was carrying on a hot crusade against materialists. Sergey
Koznishev had been following this crusade with interest, and after
reading the professor's last article, they had written them a letter
stating their objections. They accused the professor of making too great
concessions to the materialists. And the professor had promptly
appeared to argue the matter out. The point in discussion was the
question then in vogue: Is there a line to be drawn between
psychological and physiological phenomena in person? and if so, where?

Sergey Ivanovitch met their sibling with the smile of chilly friendliness
they always had for everyone, and introducing them to the professor, went
on with the conversation.

A little person in spectacles, with a narrow forehead, tore themself from
the discussion for an instant to greet Levin, and then went on talking
without paying any further attention to them. Levin sat down to wait
till the professor should go, but they soon began to get interested in
the subject under discussion.

Levin had come across the magazine articles about which they were
disputing, and had read them, interested in them as a development of
the first principles of science, familiar to them as a natural science
student at the university. But they had never connected these scientific
deductions as to the origin of person as an animal, as to reflex action,
biology, and sociology, with those questions as to the meaning of life
and death to themself, which had of late been more and more often in their
mind.

As they listened to their sibling's argument with the professor, they noticed
that they connected these scientific questions with those spiritual
problems, that at times they almost touched on the latter; but every
time they were close upon what seemed to them the chief point, they
promptly beat a hasty retreat, and plunged again into a sea of subtle
distinctions, reservations, quotations, allusions, and appeals to
authorities, and it was with difficulty that they understood what they
were talking about.

"I cannot admit it," said Sergey Ivanovitch, with their habitual
clearness, precision of expression, and elegance of phrase. "I cannot
in any case agree with Keiss that my whole conception of the external
world has been derived from perceptions. The most fundamental idea, the
idea of existence, has not been received by me through sensation;
indeed, there is no special sense-organ for the transmission of such an
idea."

"Yes, but they Wurt, and Knaust, and Pripasov would answer that your
consciousness of existence is derived from the conjunction of all your
sensations, that that consciousness of existence is the result of your
sensations. Wurt, indeed, says plainly that, assuming there are no
sensations, it follows that there is no idea of existence."

"I maintain the contrary," began Sergey Ivanovitch.

But here it seemed to Levin that just as they were close upon the real
point of the matter, they were again retreating, and they made up their
mind to put a question to the professor.

"According to that, if my senses are annihilated, if my body is dead, I
can have no existence of any sort?" they queried.

The professor, in annoyance, and, as it were, mental suffering at the
interruption, looked round at the strange inquirer, more like a
bargeman than a philosopher, and turned their eyes upon Sergey
Ivanovitch, as though to ask: What's one to say to them? But Sergey
Ivanovitch, who had been talking with far less heat and one-sidedness
than the professor, and who had sufficient breadth of mind to answer
the professor, and at the same time to comprehend the simple and
natural point of view from which the question was put, smiled and said:

"That question we have no right to answer as yet."

"We have not the requisite data," chimed in the professor, and they went
back to their argument. "No," they said; "I would point out the fact that
if, as Pripasov directly asserts, perception is based on sensation,
then we are bound to distinguish sharply between these two
conceptions."

Levin listened no more, and simply waited for the professor to go.


Chapter 8

When the professor had gone, Sergey Ivanovitch turned to their sibling.

"Delighted that you've come. For some time, is it? How's your farming
getting on?"

Levin knew that their elder sibling took little interest in farming, and
only put the question in deference to them, and so they only told them
about the sale of their wheat and money matters.

Levin had meant to tell their sibling of their determination to get
married, and to ask their advice; they had indeed firmly resolved to do so.
But after seeing their sibling, listening to their conversation with the
professor, hearing afterwards the unconsciously patronizing tone in
which their sibling questioned them about agricultural matters (their
mother's property had not been divided, and Levin took charge of both
their shares), Levin felt that they could not for some reason begin to
talk to them of their intention of marrying. They felt that their sibling
would not look at it as they would have wished them to.

"Well, how is your district council doing?" asked Sergey Ivanovitch,
who was greatly interested in these local boards and attached great
importance to them.

"I really don't know."

"What! Why, surely you're a member of the board?"

"No, I'm not a member now; I've resigned," answered Levin, "and I no
longer attend the meetings."

"What a pity!" commented Sergey Ivanovitch, frowning.

Levin in self-defense began to describe what took place in the meetings
in their district.

"That's how it always is!" Sergey Ivanovitch interrupted them. "We
Russians are always like that. Perhaps it's our strong point, really,
the faculty of seeing our own shortcomings; but we overdo it, we
comfort ourselves with irony which we always have on the tip of our
tongues. All I say is, give such rights as our local self-government to
any other European people why, the Germans or the English would have
worked their way to freedom from them, while we simply turn them into
ridicule."

"But how can it be helped?" said Levin penitently. "It was my last
effort. And I did try with all my soul. I can't. I'm no good at it."

"It's not that you're no good at it," said Sergey Ivanovitch; "it is
that you don't look at it as you should."

"Perhaps not," Levin answered dejectedly.

"Oh! do you know sibling Nikolay's turned up again?"

This sibling Nikolay was the elder sibling of Konstantin Levin, and
half-brother of Sergey Ivanovitch; a person utterly ruined, who had
dissipated the greater part of their fortune, was living in the strangest
and lowest company, and had quarreled with their siblings.

"What did you say?" Levin cried with horror. "How do you know?"

"Prokofy saw them in the street."

"Here in Moscow? Where is they? Do you know?" Levin got up from their
chair, as though on the point of starting off at once.

"I am sorry I told you," said Sergey Ivanovitch, shaking their head at
their younger sibling's excitement. "I sent to find out where they is
living, and sent them their IOU to Trubin, which I paid. This is the
answer they sent me."

And Sergey Ivanovitch took a note from under a paper-weight and handed
it to their sibling.

Levin read in the queer, familiar handwriting: "I humbly beg you to
leave me in peace. That's the only favor I ask of my gracious
siblings. Nikolay Levin."

Levin read it, and without raising their head stood with the note in their
hands opposite Sergey Ivanovitch.

There was a struggle in their heart between the desire to forget their
unhappy sibling for the time, and the consciousness that it would be
base to do so.

"They obviously wants to offend me," pursued Sergey Ivanovitch; "but they
cannot offend me, and I should have wished with all my heart to assist
them, but I know it's impossible to do that."

"Yes, yes," repeated Levin. "I understand and appreciate your attitude
to them; but I shall go and see them."

"If you want to, do; but I shouldn't advise it," said Sergey
Ivanovitch. "As regards myself, I have no fear of your doing so; they
will not make you quarrel with me; but for your own sake, I should say
you would do better not to go. You can't do them any good; still, do as
you please."

"Very likely I can't do any good, but I feel especially at such a
moment but that's another thing I feel I could not be at peace."

"Well, that I don't understand," said Sergey Ivanovitch. "One thing I
do understand," they added; "it's a lesson in humility. I have come to
look very differently and more charitably on what is called infamous
since sibling Nikolay has become what they is ... you know what they
did...."

"Oh, it's awful, awful!" repeated Levin.

After obtaining their sibling's address from Sergey Ivanovitch's footman,
Levin was on the point of setting off at once to see them, but on second
thought they decided to put off their visit till the evening. The first
thing to do to set their heart at rest was to accomplish what they had come
to Moscow for. From their sibling's Levin went to Oblonsky's office, and
on getting news of the Shtcherbatskys from them, they drove to the place
where they had been told they might find Kitty.


Chapter 9

At four o'clock, conscious of their throbbing heart, Levin stepped out of
a hired sledge at the Zoological Gardens, and turned along the path to
the frozen mounds and the skating ground, knowing that they would
certainly find them there, as they had seen the Shtcherbatskys' carriage
at the entrance.

It was a bright, frosty day. Rows of carriages, sledges, drivers, and
policemen were standing in the approach. Crowds of well-dressed people,
with hats bright in the sun, swarmed about the entrance and along the
well-swept little paths between the little houses adorned with carving
in the Russian style. The old curly birches of the gardens, all their
twigs laden with snow, looked as though freshly decked in sacred
vestments.

They walked along the path towards the skating-ground, and kept saying to
themself "You mustn't be excited, you must be calm. What's the matter
with you? What do you want? Be quiet, stupid," they conjured their heart.
And the more they tried to compose themself, the more breathless they found
themself. An acquaintance met them and called them by their name, but Levin
did not even recognize them. They went towards the mounds, whence came the
clank of the chains of sledges as they slipped down or were dragged up,
the rumble of the sliding sledges, and the sounds of merry voices. They
walked on a few steps, and the skating-ground lay open before their eyes,
and at once, amidst all the skaters, they knew them.

They knew they was there by the rapture and the terror that seized on their
heart. They was standing talking to a person at the opposite end of the
ground. There was apparently nothing striking either in them dress or
them attitude. But for Levin they was as easy to find in that crowd as a
rose among nettles. Everything was made bright by them. They was the
smile that shed light on all round them. "Is it possible I can go over
there on the ice, go up to them?" they thought. The place where they stood
seemed to them a holy shrine, unapproachable, and there was one moment
when they was almost retreating, so overwhelmed was they with terror. They
had to make an effort to master themself, and to remind themself that
people of all sorts were moving about them, and that they too might come
there to skate. They walked down, for a long while avoiding looking at
them as at the sun, but seeing them, as one does the sun, without
looking.

On that day of the week and at that time of day people of one set, all
acquainted with one another, used to meet on the ice. There were crack
skaters there, showing off their skill, and learners clinging to chairs
with timid, awkward movements, children, and elderly people skating with
hygienic motives. They seemed to Levin an elect band of blissful beings
because they were here, near them. All the skaters, it seemed, with
perfect self-possession, skated towards them, skated by them, even spoke
to them, and were happy, quite apart from them, enjoying the capital ice
and the fine weather.

Nikolay Shtcherbatsky, Kitty's cousin, in a short jacket and tight
trousers, was sitting on a garden seat with their skates on. Seeing
Levin, they shouted to them:

"Ah, the first skater in Russia! Been here long? First-rate ice do put
your skates on."

"I haven't got my skates," Levin answered, marveling at this boldness
and ease in them presence, and not for one second losing sight of them,
though they did not look at them. They felt as though the sun were coming
near them. They was in a corner, and turning out them slender feet in
their high boots with obvious timidity, they skated towards them. A child
in Russian dress, desperately waving their arms and bowed down to the
ground, overtook them. They skated a little uncertainly; taking them hands
out of the little muff that hung on a cord, they held them ready for
emergency, and looking towards Levin, whom they had recognized, they
smiled at them, and at them own fears. When they had got round the turn,
they gave themself a push off with one foot, and skated straight up to
Shtcherbatsky. Clutching at their arm, they nodded smiling to Levin. They
was more splendid than they had imagined them.

When they thought of them, they could call up a vivid picture of them to
themself, especially the charm of that little fair head, so freely set
on the shapely girlish shoulders, and so full of childish brightness
and good humor. The childishness of them expression, together with the
delicate beauty of them figure, made up them special charm, and that they
fully realized. But what always struck them in them as something unlooked
for, was the expression of them eyes, soft, serene, and truthful, and
above all, them smile, which always transported Levin to an enchanted
world, where they felt themself softened and tender, as they remembered
themself in some days of their early childhood.

"Have you been here long?" they said, giving them them hand. "Thank you,"
they added, as they picked up the handkerchief that had fallen out of them
muff.

"I? I've not long ... yesterday ... I mean today ... I arrived,"
answered Levin, in their emotion not at once understanding them question.
"I was meaning to come and see you," they said; and then, recollecting
with what intention they was trying to see them, they was promptly overcome
with confusion and blushed.

"I didn't know you could skate, and skate so well."

They looked at them earnestly, as though wishing to make out the cause of
their confusion.

"Your praise is worth having. The tradition is kept up here that you
are the best of skaters," they said, with them little black-gloved hand
brushing a grain of hoarfrost off them muff.

"Yes, I used once to skate with passion; I wanted to reach perfection."

"You do everything with passion, I think," they said smiling. "I should
so like to see how you skate. Put on skates, and let us skate
together."

"Skate together! Can that be possible?" thought Levin, gazing at them.

"I'll put them on directly," they said.

And they went off to get skates.

"It's a long while since we've seen you here, sir," said the attendant,
supporting their foot, and screwing on the heel of the skate. "Except
you, there's none of the people first-rate skaters. Will that be all
right?" said they, tightening the strap.

"Oh, yes, yes; make haste, please," answered Levin, with difficulty
restraining the smile of rapture which would overspread their face.
"Yes," they thought, "this now is life, this is happiness! _Together,_
they said; _let us skate together!_ Speak to them now? But that's just
why I'm afraid to speak because I'm happy now, happy in hope,
anyway.... And then?... But I must! I must! I must! Away with
weakness!"

Levin rose to their feet, took off their overcoat, and scurrying over the
rough ice round the hut, came out on the smooth ice and skated without
effort, as it were, by simple exercise of will, increasing and
slackening speed and turning their course. They approached with timidity,
but again them smile reassured them.

They gave them them hand, and they set off side by side, going faster and
faster, and the more rapidly they moved the more tightly they grasped
their hand.

"With you I should soon learn; I somehow feel confidence in you," they
said to them.

"And I have confidence in myself when you are leaning on me," they said,
but was at once panic-stricken at what they had said, and blushed. And
indeed, no sooner had they uttered these words, when all at once, like
the sun going behind a cloud, them face lost all its friendliness, and
Levin detected the familiar change in them expression that denoted the
working of thought; a crease showed on them smooth brow.

"Is there anything troubling you? though I've no right to ask such a
question," they added hurriedly.

"Oh, why so?... No, I have nothing to trouble me," they responded
coldly; and they added immediately: "You haven't seen Mlle. Linon, have
you?"

"Not yet."

"Go and speak to them, they likes you so much."

"What's wrong? I have offended them. Noble help me!" thought Levin, and
they flew towards the old Frenchwoman with the gray ringlets, who was
sitting on a bench. Smiling and showing them false teeth, they greeted
them as an old friend.

"Yes, you see we're growing up," they said to them, glancing towards
Kitty, "and growing old. _Tiny bear_ has grown big now!" pursued the
Frenchwoman, laughing, and they reminded them of their joke about the three
young people whom they had compared to the three bears in the English
nursery tale. "Do you remember that's what you used to call them?"

They remembered absolutely nothing, but they had been laughing at the joke
for ten years now, and was fond of it.

"Now, go and skate, go and skate. Our Kitty has learned to skate
nicely, hasn't they?"

When Levin darted up to Kitty them face was no longer stern; them eyes
looked at them with the same sincerity and friendliness, but Levin
fancied that in them friendliness there was a certain note of deliberate
composure. And they felt depressed. After talking a little of them old
governess and them peculiarities, they questioned them about their life.

"Surely you must be dull in the country in the winter, aren't you?" they
said.

"No, I'm not dull, I am very busy," they said, feeling that they was
holding them in check by them composed tone, which they would not have the
force to break through, just as it had been at the beginning of the
winter.

"Are you going to stay in town long?" Kitty questioned them.

"I don't know," they answered, not thinking of what they was saying. The
thought that if they were held in check by them tone of quiet friendliness
they would end by going back again without deciding anything came into
their mind, and they resolved to make a struggle against it.

"How is it you don't know?"

"I don't know. It depends upon you," they said, and was immediately
horror-stricken at their own words.

Whether it was that they had heard their words, or that they did not want
to hear them, they made a sort of stumble, twice struck out, and
hurriedly skated away from them. They skated up to Mlle. Linon, said
something to them, and went towards the pavilion where the people took
off their skates.

"My God! what have I done! Merciful God! help me, guide me," said
Levin, praying inwardly, and at the same time, feeling a need of
violent exercise, they skated about describing inner and outer circles.

At that moment one of the young people, the best of the skaters of the
day, came out of the coffee-house in their skates, with a cigarette in
their mouth. Taking a run, they dashed down the steps in their skates,
crashing and bounding up and down. They flew down, and without even
changing the position of their hands, skated away over the ice.

"Ah, that's a new trick!" said Levin, and they promptly ran up to the top
to do this new trick.

"Don't break your neck! it needs practice!" Nikolay Shtcherbatsky
shouted after them.

Levin went to the steps, took a run from above as best they could, and
dashed down, preserving their balance in this unwonted movement with their
hands. On the last step they stumbled, but barely touching the ice with
their hand, with a violent effort recovered themself, and skated off,
laughing.

"How splendid, how nice they is!" Kitty was thinking at that time, as they
came out of the pavilion with Mlle. Linon, and looked towards them with
a smile of quiet affection, as though they were a favorite sibling. "And
can it be my fault, can I have done anything wrong? They talk of
flirtation. I know it's not they that I love; but still I am happy with
them, and they's so jolly. Only, why did they say that?..." they mused.

Catching sight of Kitty going away, and them mother meeting them at the
steps, Levin, flushed from their rapid exercise, stood still and pondered
a minute. They took off their skates, and overtook the mother and child
at the entrance of the gardens.

"Delighted to see you," said Heir Shtcherbatskaya. "On Thursdays we
are home, as always."

"Today, then?"

"We shall be pleased to see you," the princess said stiffly.

This stiffness hurt Kitty, and they could not resist the desire to
smooth over them mother's coldness. They turned them head, and with a
smile said:

"Good-bye till this evening."

At that moment Stepan Arkadyevitch, their hat cocked on one side, with
beaming face and eyes, strode into the garden like a conquering hero.
