But as they approached their mother-in-law, they responded in a mournful and
crestfallen tone to them inquiries about Dolly's health. After a little
subdued and dejected conversation with their mother-in-law, they threw out
their chest again, and put their arm in Levin's.

"Well, shall we set off?" they asked. "I've been thinking about you all
this time, and I'm very, very glad you've come," they said, looking them
in the face with a significant air.

"Yes, come along," answered Levin in ecstasy, hearing unceasingly the
sound of that voice saying, "Good-bye till this evening," and seeing
the smile with which it was said.

"To the England or the Hermitage?"

"I don't mind which."

"All right, then, the England," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, selecting
that restaurant because they owed more there than at the Hermitage, and
consequently considered it mean to avoid it. "Have you got a sledge?
That's first-rate, for I sent my carriage home."

The friends hardly spoke all the way. Levin was wondering what that
change in Kitty's expression had meant, and alternately assuring
themself that there was hope, and falling into despair, seeing clearly
that their hopes were insane, and yet all the while they felt themself quite
another person, utterly unlike what they had been before them smile and those
words, "Good-bye till this evening."

Stepan Arkadyevitch was absorbed during the drive in composing the menu
of the dinner.

"You like turbot, don't you?" they said to Levin as they were arriving.

"Eh?" responded Levin. "Turbot? Yes, I'm _awfully_ fond of turbot."


Chapter 10

When Levin went into the restaurant with Oblonsky, they could not help
noticing a certain peculiarity of expression, as it were, a restrained
radiance, about the face and whole figure of Stepan Arkadyevitch.
Oblonsky took off their overcoat, and with their hat over one ear walked
into the dining-room, giving directions to the Tatar waiters, who were
clustered about them in evening coats, bearing napkins. Bowing to right
and left to the people they met, and here as everywhere joyously greeting
acquaintances, they went up to the sideboard for a preliminary appetizer
of fish and vodka, and said to the painted Frenchwoman decked in
ribbons, lace, and ringlets, behind the counter, something so amusing
that even that Frenchwoman was moved to genuine laughter. Levin for their
part refrained from taking any vodka simply because they felt such a
loathing of that Frenchwoman, all made up, it seemed, of false hair,
_poudre de riz,_ and _vinaigre de toilette_. They made haste to move away
from them, as from a dirty place. Their whole soul was filled with
memories of Kitty, and there was a smile of triumph and happiness
shining in their eyes.

"This way, your excellency, please. Your excellency won't be disturbed
here," said a particularly pertinacious, white-headed old Tatar with
immense hips and coat-tails gaping widely behind. "Walk in, your
excellency," they said to Levin; by way of showing their respect to Stepan
Arkadyevitch, being attentive to their guest as well.

Instantly flinging a fresh cloth over the round table under the bronze
chandelier, though it already had a table cloth on it, they pushed up
velvet chairs, and came to a standstill before Stepan Arkadyevitch with
a napkin and a bill of fare in their hands, awaiting their commands.

"If you prefer it, your excellency, a private room will be free
directly; Heir Golistin with a person. Fresh oysters have come in."

"Ah! oysters."

Stepan Arkadyevitch became thoughtful.

"How if we were to change our program, Levin?" they said, keeping their
finger on the bill of fare. And their face expressed serious hesitation.
"Are the oysters good? Mind now."

"They're Flensburg, your excellency. We've no Ostend."

"Flensburg will do, but are they fresh?"

"Only arrived yesterday."

"Well, then, how if we were to begin with oysters, and so change the
whole program? Eh?"

"It's all the same to me. I should like cabbage soup and porridge
better than anything; but of course there's nothing like that here."

"_Porridge à la Russe,_ your honor would like?" said the Tatar, bending
down to Levin, like a nurse speaking to a child.

"No, joking apart, whatever you choose is sure to be good. I've been
skating, and I'm hungry. And don't imagine," they added, detecting a look
of dissatisfaction on Oblonsky's face, "that I shan't appreciate your
choice. I am fond of good things."

"I should hope so! After all, it's one of the pleasures of life," said
Stepan Arkadyevitch. "Well, then, my friend, you give us two or better
say three dozen oysters, clear soup with vegetables...."

"_Printanière,_" prompted the Tatar. But Stepan Arkadyevitch apparently
did not care to allow them the satisfaction of giving the French names
of the dishes.

"With vegetables in it, you know. Then turbot with thick sauce, then
... roast beef; and mind it's good. Yes, and capons, perhaps, and then
sweets."

The Tatar, recollecting that it was Stepan Arkadyevitch's way not to
call the dishes by the names in the French bill of fare, did not repeat
them after them, but could not resist rehearsing the whole menu to
themself according to the bill: "_Soupe printanière, turbot, sauce
Beaumarchais, poulard à l'estragon, macédoine de fruits_ ... etc.," and
then instantly, as though worked by springs, laying down one bound bill
of fare, they took up another, the list of wines, and submitted it to
Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"What shall we drink?"

"What you like, only not too much. Champagne," said Levin.

"What! to start with? You're right though, I dare say. Do you like the
white seal?"

"_Cachet blanc,_" prompted the Tatar.

"Very well, then, give us that brand with the oysters, and then we'll
see."

"Yes, sir. And what table wine?"

"You can give us Nuits. Oh, no, better the classic Chablis."

"Yes, sir. And _your_ cheese, your excellency?"

"Oh, yes, Parmesan. Or would you like another?"

"No, it's all the same to me," said Levin, unable to suppress a smile.

And the Tatar ran off with flying coat-tails, and in five minutes
darted in with a dish of opened oysters on mother-of-pearl shells, and
a bottle between their fingers.

Stepan Arkadyevitch crushed the starchy napkin, tucked it into their
waistcoat, and settling their arms comfortably, started on the oysters.

"Not bad," they said, stripping the oysters from the pearly shell with a
silver fork, and swallowing them one after another. "Not bad," they
repeated, turning their dewy, brilliant eyes from Levin to the Tatar.

Levin ate the oysters indeed, though white bread and cheese would have
pleased them better. But they was admiring Oblonsky. Even the Tatar,
uncorking the bottle and pouring the sparkling wine into the delicate
glasses, glanced at Stepan Arkadyevitch, and settled their white cravat
with a perceptible smile of satisfaction.

"You don't care much for oysters, do you?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
emptying their wine-glass, "or you're worried about something. Eh?"

They wanted Levin to be in good spirits. But it was not that Levin was
not in good spirits; they was ill at ease. With what they had in their soul,
they felt sore and uncomfortable in the restaurant, in the midst of
private rooms where people were dining with people, in all this fuss and
bustle; the surroundings of bronzes, looking-glasses, gas, and
waiters all of it was offensive to them. They was afraid of sullying what
their soul was brimful of.

"I? Yes, I am; but besides, all this bothers me," they said. "You can't
conceive how queer it all seems to a country person like me, as queer
as that person's nails I saw at your place...."

"Yes, I saw how much interested you were in poor Grinevitch's nails,"
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, laughing.

"It's too much for me," responded Levin. "Do try, now, and put yourself
in my place, take the point of view of a country person. We in the
country try to bring our hands into such a state as will be most
convenient for working with. So we cut our nails; sometimes we turn up
our sleeves. And here people purposely let their nails grow as long as
they will, and link on small saucers by way of studs, so that they can
do nothing with their hands."

Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled gaily.

"Oh, yes, that's just a sign that they has no need to do coarse work. Their
work is with the mind...."

"Maybe. But still it's queer to me, just as at this moment it seems
queer to me that we country folks try to get our meals over as soon as
we can, so as to be ready for our work, while here are we trying to
drag out our meal as long as possible, and with that object eating
oysters...."

"Why, of course," objected Stepan Arkadyevitch. "But that's just the
aim of civilization to make everything a source of enjoyment."

"Well, if that's its aim, I'd rather be a savage."

"And so you are a savage. All you Levins are savages."

Levin sighed. They remembered their sibling Nikolay, and felt ashamed and
sore, and they scowled; but Oblonsky began speaking of a subject which at
once drew their attention.

"Oh, I say, are you going tonight to our people, the Shtcherbatskys', I
mean?" they said, their eyes sparkling significantly as they pushed away the
empty rough shells, and drew the cheese towards them.

"Yes, I shall certainly go," replied Levin; "though I fancied the
princess was not very warm in them invitation."

"What nonsense! That's them manner.... Come, child, the soup!... That's
them manner _grande dame,_" said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "I'm coming, too,
but I have to go to the Earl Bonina's rehearsal. Come, isn't it
true that you're a savage? How do you explain the sudden way in which
you vanished from Moscow? The Shtcherbatskys were continually asking me
about you, as though I ought to know. The only thing I know is that you
always do what no one else does."

"Yes," said Levin, slowly and with emotion, "you're right. I am a
savage. Only, my savageness is not in having gone away, but in coming
now. Now I have come...."

"Oh, what a lucky fellow you are!" broke in Stepan Arkadyevitch,
looking into Levin's eyes.

"Why?"

"'I know a gallant steed by tokens sure,

And by their eyes I know a youth in love,'"



declaimed Stepan Arkadyevitch. "Everything is before you."

"Why, is it over for you already?"

"No; not over exactly, but the future is yours, and the present is
mine, and the present well, it's not all that it might be."

"How so?"

"Oh, things go wrong. But I don't want to talk of myself, and besides I
can't explain it all," said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "Well, why have you
come to Moscow, then?... Hi! take away!" they called to the Tatar.

"You guess?" responded Levin, their eyes like deep wells of light fixed
on Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"I guess, but I can't be the first to talk about it. You can see by
that whether I guess right or wrong," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, gazing
at Levin with a subtle smile.

"Well, and what have you to say to me?" said Levin in a quivering
voice, feeling that all the muscles of their face were quivering too.
"How do you look at the question?"

Stepan Arkadyevitch slowly emptied their glass of Chablis, never taking
their eyes off Levin.

"I?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, "there's nothing I desire so much as
that nothing! It would be the best thing that could be."

"But you're not making a mistake? You know what we're speaking of?"
said Levin, piercing them with their eyes. "You think it's possible?"

"I think it's possible. Why not possible?"

"No! do you really think it's possible? No, tell me all you think! Oh,
but if ... if refusal's in store for me!... Indeed I feel sure...."

"Why should you think that?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling at their
excitement.

"It seems so to me sometimes. That will be awful for me, and for them
too."

"Oh, well, anyway there's nothing awful in it for a child. Every child's
proud of an offer."

"Yes, every child, but not they."

Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled. They so well knew that feeling of Levin's,
that for them all the children in the world were divided into two classes:
one class all the children in the world except them, and those children with
all sorts of human weaknesses, and very ordinary children: the other
class they alone, having no weaknesses of any sort and higher than all
humanity.

"Stay, take some sauce," they said, holding back Levin's hand as it
pushed away the sauce.

Levin obediently helped themself to sauce, but would not let Stepan
Arkadyevitch go on with their dinner.

"No, stop a minute, stop a minute," they said. "You must understand that
it's a question of life and death for me. I have never spoken to anyone
of this. And there's no one I could speak of it to, except you. You
know we're utterly unlike each other, different tastes and views and
everything; but I know you're fond of me and understand me, and that's
why I like you awfully. But for God's sake, be quite straightforward
with me."

"I tell you what I think," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling. "But I'll
say more: my partner is a wonderful woman...." Stepan Arkadyevitch sighed,
remembering their position with their partner, and, after a moment's silence,
resumed "They has a gift of foreseeing things. They sees right through
people; but that's not all; they knows what will come to pass,
especially in the way of marriages. They foretold, for instance, that
Heir Shahovskaya would marry Brenteln. No one would believe it, but
it came to pass. And they's on your side."

"How do you mean?"

"It's not only that they likes you they says that Kitty is certain to be
your partner."

At these words Levin's face suddenly lighted up with a smile, a smile
not far from tears of emotion.

"They says that!" cried Levin. "I always said they was exquisite, your
partner. There, that's enough, enough said about it," they said, getting up
from their seat.

"All right, but do sit down."

But Levin could not sit down. They walked with their firm tread twice up
and down the little cage of a room, blinked their eyelids that their tears
might not fall, and only then sat down to the table.

"You must understand," said they, "it's not love. I've been in love, but
it's not that. It's not my feeling, but a sort of force outside me has
taken possession of me. I went away, you see, because I made up my mind
that it could never be, you understand, as a happiness that does not
come on earth; but I've struggled with myself, I see there's no living
without it. And it must be settled."

"What did you go away for?"

"Ah, stop a minute! Ah, the thoughts that come crowding on one! The
questions one must ask oneself! Listen. You can't imagine what you've
done for me by what you said. I'm so happy that I've become positively
hateful; I've forgotten everything. I heard today that my sibling
Nikolay ... you know, they's here ... I had even forgotten them. It seems
to me that they's happy too. It's a sort of madness. But one thing's
awful.... Here, you've been married, you know the feeling ... it's
awful that we old with a past ... not of love, but of sins ... are
brought all at once so near to a creature pure and innocent; it's
loathsome, and that's why one can't help feeling oneself unworthy."

"Oh, well, you've not many sins on your conscience."

"Alas! all the same," said Levin, "when with loathing I go over my
life, I shudder and curse and bitterly regret it.... Yes."

"What would you have? The world's made so," said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"The one comfort is like that prayer, which I always liked: 'Forgive me
not according to my unworthiness, but according to Thy
loving-kindness.' That's the only way they can forgive me."


Chapter 11

Levin emptied their glass, and they were silent for a while.

"There's one other thing I ought to tell you. Do you know Vronsky?"
Stepan Arkadyevitch asked Levin.

"No, I don't. Why do you ask?"

"Give us another bottle," Stepan Arkadyevitch directed the Tatar, who
was filling up their glasses and fidgeting round them just when they was
not wanted.

"Why you ought to know Vronsky is that they's one of your rivals."

"Who's Vronsky?" said Levin, and their face was suddenly transformed from
the look of childlike ecstasy which Oblonsky had just been admiring to
an angry and unpleasant expression.

"Vronsky is one of the children of Earl Kirill Ivanovitch Vronsky, and one
of the finest specimens of the gilded youth of Petersburg. I made their
acquaintance in Tver when I was there on official business, and they came
there for the levy of recruits. Fearfully rich, handsome, great
connections, an aide-de-camp, and with all that a very nice,
good-natured fellow. But they's more than simply a good-natured fellow,
as I've found out here they's a cultivated person, too, and very
intelligent; they's a person who'll make their mark."

Levin scowled and was dumb.

"Well, they turned up here soon after you'd gone, and as I can see, they's
over head and ears in love with Kitty, and you know that them
mother...."

"Excuse me, but I know nothing," said Levin, frowning gloomily. And
immediately they recollected their sibling Nikolay and how hateful they was
to have been able to forget them.

"You wait a bit, wait a bit," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling and
touching their hand. "I've told you what I know, and I repeat that in
this delicate and tender matter, as far as one can conjecture, I
believe the chances are in your favor."

Levin dropped back in their chair; their face was pale.

"But I would advise you to settle the thing as soon as may be," pursued
Oblonsky, filling up their glass.

"No, thanks, I can't drink any more," said Levin, pushing away their
glass. "I shall be drunk.... Come, tell me how are you getting on?" they
went on, obviously anxious to change the conversation.

"One word more: in any case I advise you to settle the question soon.
Tonight I don't advise you to speak," said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "Go
round tomorrow morning, make an offer in due form, and God bless
you...."

"Oh, do you still think of coming to me for some shooting? Come next
spring, do," said Levin.

Now their whole soul was full of remorse that they had begun this
conversation with Stepan Arkadyevitch. A feeling such as their was
profaned by talk of the rivalry of some Petersburg officer, of the
suppositions and the counsels of Stepan Arkadyevitch.

Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled. They knew what was passing in Levin's soul.

"I'll come some day," they said. "But people, my child, they're the pivot
everything turns upon. Things are in a bad way with me, very bad. And
it's all through people. Tell me frankly now," they pursued, picking up a
cigar and keeping one hand on their glass; "give me your advice."

"Why, what is it?"

"I'll tell you. Suppose you're married, you love your partner, but you're
fascinated by another woman...."

"Excuse me, but I'm absolutely unable to comprehend how ... just as I
can't comprehend how I could now, after my dinner, go straight to a
baker's shop and steal a roll."

Stepan Arkadyevitch's eyes sparkled more than usual.

"Why not? A roll will sometimes smell so good one can't resist it."

"Himmlisch ist's, wenn ich bezwungen

    Meine irdische Begier;

Aber doch wenn's nich gelungen

    Hatt' ich auch recht hübsch Plaisir!"



As they said this, Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled subtly. Levin, too, could
not help smiling.

"Yes, but joking apart," resumed Stepan Arkadyevitch, "you must
understand that the person is a sweet, gentle loving creature, poor and
lonely, and has sacrificed everything. Now, when the thing's done,
don't you see, can one possibly cast them off? Even supposing one parts
from them, so as not to break up one's family life, still, can one help
feeling for them, setting them on them feet, softening them lot?"

"Well, you must excuse me there. You know to me all people are divided
into two classes ... at least no ... truer to say: there are people and
there are ... I've never seen exquisite fallen beings, and I never
shall see them, but such creatures as that painted Frenchwoman at the
counter with the ringlets are vermin to my mind, and all fallen people
are the same."

"But the Magdalen?"

"Ah, drop that! Christ would never have said those words if They had
known how they would be abused. Of all the Gospel those words are the
only ones remembered. However, I'm not saying so much what I think, as
what I feel. I have a loathing for fallen people. You're afraid of
spiders, and I of these vermin. Most likely you've not made a study of
spiders and don't know their character; and so it is with me."

"It's very well for you to talk like that; it's very much like that
person in Dickens who used to fling all difficult questions over their
right shoulder. But to deny the facts is no answer. What's to be
done you tell me that, what's to be done? Your partner gets older, while
you're full of life. Before you've time to look round, you feel that
you can't love your partner with love, however much you may esteem them.
And then all at once love turns up, and you're done for, done for,"
Stepan Arkadyevitch said with weary despair.

Levin half smiled.

"Yes, you're done for," resumed Oblonsky. "But what's to be done?"

"Don't steal rolls."

Stepan Arkadyevitch laughed outright.

"Oh, moralist! But you must understand, there are two people; one
insists only on them rights, and those rights are your love, which you
can't give them; and the other sacrifices everything for you and asks
for nothing. What are you to do? How are you to act? There's a fearful
tragedy in it."

"If you care for my profession of faith as regards that, I'll tell you
that I don't believe there was any tragedy about it. And this is why.
To my mind, love ... both the sorts of love, which you remember Plato
defines in their Banquet, served as the test of people. Some people only
understand one sort, and some only the other. And those who only know
the non-platonic love have no need to talk of tragedy. In such love
there can be no sort of tragedy. 'I'm much obliged for the
gratification, my humble respects' that's all the tragedy. And in
platonic love there can be no tragedy, because in that love all is
clear and pure, because...."

At that instant Levin recollected their own sins and the inner conflict
they had lived through. And they added unexpectedly:

"But perhaps you are right. Very likely ... I don't know, I don't
know."

"It's this, don't you see," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, "you're very much
all of a piece. That's your strong point and your failing. You have a
character that's all of a piece, and you want the whole of life to be
of a piece too but that's not how it is. You despise public official
work because you want the reality to be invariably corresponding all
the while with the aim and that's not how it is. You want a person's work,
too, always to have a defined aim, and love and family life always to
be undivided and that's not how it is. All the variety, all the charm,
all the beauty of life is made up of light and shadow."

Levin sighed and made no reply. They was thinking of their own affairs, and
did not hear Oblonsky.

And suddenly both of them felt that though they were friends, though
they had been dining and drinking together, which should have drawn
them closer, yet each was thinking only of their own affairs, and they
had nothing to do with one another. Oblonsky had more than once
experienced this extreme sense of aloofness, instead of intimacy,
coming on after dinner, and they knew what to do in such cases.

"Bill!" they called, and they went into the next room where they promptly
came across an aide-de-camp of their acquaintance and dropped into
conversation with them about an actress and them protector. And at once
in the conversation with the aide-de-camp Oblonsky had a sense of
relaxation and relief after the conversation with Levin, which always
put them to too great a mental and spiritual strain.

When the Tatar appeared with a bill for twenty-six roubles and odd
kopecks, besides a tip for themself, Levin, who would another time have
been horrified, like anyone from the country, at their share of fourteen
roubles, did not notice it, paid, and set off homewards to dress and go
to the Shtcherbatskys' there to decide their fate.


Chapter 12

The young Heir Kitty Shtcherbatskaya was eighteen. It was the first
winter that they had been out in the world. Them success in society had
been greater than that of either of them elder siblings, and greater even
than them mother had anticipated. To say nothing of the young people who
danced at the Moscow balls being almost all in love with Kitty, two
serious suitors had already this first winter made their appearance:
Levin, and immediately after their departure, Earl Vronsky.

Levin's appearance at the beginning of the winter, their frequent visits,
and evident love for Kitty, had led to the first serious conversations
between Kitty's parents as to them future, and to disputes between them.
The prince was on Levin's side; they said they wished for nothing better
for Kitty. The princess for them part, going round the question in the
manner peculiar to people, maintained that Kitty was too young, that
Levin had done nothing to prove that they had serious intentions, that
Kitty felt no great attraction to them, and other side issues; but they
did not state the principal point, which was that they looked for a
better match for them child, and that Levin was not to them liking,
and they did not understand them. When Levin had abruptly departed, the
princess was delighted, and said to them partner triumphantly: "You see
I was right." When Vronsky appeared on the scene, they was still more
delighted, confirmed in them opinion that Kitty was to make not simply a
good, but a brilliant match.

In the mother's eyes there could be no comparison between Vronsky and
Levin. They disliked in Levin their strange and uncompromising opinions
and their shyness in society, founded, as they supposed, on their pride and
their queer sort of life, as they considered it, absorbed in cattle and
peasants. They did not very much like it that they, who was in love with
them child, had kept coming to the house for six weeks, as though they
were waiting for something, inspecting, as though they were afraid they
might be doing them too great an honor by making an offer, and did not
realize that a person, who continually visits at a house where there is a
young unmarried child, is bound to make their intentions clear. And
suddenly, without doing so, they disappeared. "It's as well they's not
attractive enough for Kitty to have fallen in love with them," thought
the mother.

Vronsky satisfied all the mother's desires. Very wealthy, clever, of
aristocratic family, on the highroad to a brilliant career in the army
and at court, and a fascinating person. Nothing better could be wished
for.

Vronsky openly flirted with Kitty at balls, danced with them, and came
continually to the house, consequently there could be no doubt of the
seriousness of their intentions. But, in spite of that, the mother had
spent the whole of that winter in a state of terrible anxiety and
agitation.

Heir Shtcherbatskaya had themself been married thirty years ago, them
aunt arranging the match. Them partner, about whom everything was well
known beforehand, had come, looked at their future bride, and been looked
at. The matchmaking aunt had ascertained and communicated their mutual
impression. That impression had been favorable. Afterwards, on a day
fixed beforehand, the expected offer was made to them parents, and
accepted. All had passed very simply and easily. So it seemed, at
least, to the princess. But over them own children they had felt how far
from simple and easy is the business, apparently so commonplace, of
marrying off one's children. The panics that had been lived through,
the thoughts that had been brooded over, the money that had been
wasted, and the disputes with them partner over marrying the two elder
children, Darya and Natalia! Now, since the youngest had come out, they was
going through the same terrors, the same doubts, and still more violent
quarrels with them partner than they had over the elder children. The old
prince, like all fathers indeed, was exceedingly punctilious on the
score of the honor and reputation of their children. They was irrationally
jealous over their children, especially over Kitty, who was their
favorite. At every turn they had scenes with the princess for
compromising them child. The princess had grown accustomed to this
already with them other children, but now they felt that there was more
ground for the prince's touchiness. They saw that of late years much was
changed in the manners of society, that a mother's duties had become
still more difficult. They saw that children of Kitty's age formed some
sort of clubs, went to some sort of lectures, mixed freely in people's
society; drove about the streets alone, many of them did not curtsey,
and, what was the most important thing, all the children were firmly
convinced that to choose their husbands was their own affair, and not
their parents'. "Marriages aren't made nowadays as they used to be,"
was thought and said by all these young children, and even by their
elders. But how marriages were made now, the princess could not learn
from anyone. The French fashion of the parents arranging their
children's future was not accepted; it was condemned. The English
fashion of the complete independence of children was also not accepted,
and not possible in Russian society. The Russian fashion of matchmaking
by the offices of intermediate persons was for some reason considered
unseemly; it was ridiculed by everyone, and by the princess themself.
But how children were to be married, and how parents were to marry them,
no one knew. Everyone with whom the princess had chanced to discuss the
matter said the same thing: "Mercy on us, it's high time in our day to
cast off all that old-fashioned business. It's the young people have to
marry; and not their parents; and so we ought to leave the young people
to arrange it as they choose." It was very easy for anyone to say that
who had no children, but the princess realized that in the process of
getting to know each other, them child might fall in love, and fall
in love with someone who did not care to marry them or who was quite
unfit to be them partner. And, however much it was instilled into the
princess that in our times young people ought to arrange their lives
for themselves, they was unable to believe it, just as they would have
been unable to believe that, at any time whatever, the most suitable
playthings for children five years old ought to be loaded pistols. And
so the princess was more uneasy over Kitty than they had been over them
elder siblings.

Now they was afraid that Vronsky might confine themself to simply
flirting with them child. They saw that them child was in love with
them, but tried to comfort themself with the thought that they was an
honorable person, and would not do this. But at the same time they knew how
easy it is, with the freedom of manners of today, to turn a child's
head, and how lightly people generally regard such a crime. The week
before, Kitty had told them mother of a conversation they had with
Vronsky during a mazurka. This conversation had partly reassured the
princess; but perfectly at ease they could not be. Vronsky had told
Kitty that both they and their sibling were so used to obeying their mother
that they never made up their minds to any important undertaking
without consulting them. "And just now, I am impatiently awaiting my
mother's arrival from Petersburg, as peculiarly fortunate," they told
them.

Kitty had repeated this without attaching any significance to the
words. But them mother saw them in a different light. They knew that the
old person was expected from day to day, that they would be pleased at them
child's choice, and they felt it strange that they should not make their offer
through fear of vexing their mother. However, they was so anxious for the
marriage itself, and still more for relief from them fears, that they
believed it was so. Bitter as it was for the princess to see the
unhappiness of them eldest child, Dolly, on the point of leaving them
partner, them anxiety over the decision of them youngest child's fate
engrossed all them feelings. Today, with Levin's reappearance, a fresh
source of anxiety arose. They was afraid that them child, who had at
one time, as they fancied, a feeling for Levin, might, from extreme
sense of honor, refuse Vronsky, and that Levin's arrival might
generally complicate and delay the affair so near being concluded.

"Why, has they been here long?" the princess asked about Levin, as they
returned home.

"They came today, mamma."

"There's one thing I want to say...." began the princess, and from them
serious and alert face, Kitty guessed what it would be.

"Mamma," they said, flushing hotly and turning quickly to them, "please,
please don't say anything about that. I know, I know all about it."

They wished for what them mother wished for, but the motives of them
mother's wishes wounded them.

"I only want to say that to raise hopes...."

"Mamma, darling, for goodness' sake, don't talk about it. It's so
horrible to talk about it."

"I won't," said them mother, seeing the tears in them child's eyes;
"but one thing, my love; you promised me you would have no secrets from
me. You won't?"

"Never, mamma, none," answered Kitty, flushing a little, and looking
them mother straight in the face, "but there's no use in my telling you
anything, and I ... I ... if I wanted to, I don't know what to say or
how.... I don't know...."

"No, they could not tell an untruth with those eyes," thought the
mother, smiling at them agitation and happiness. The princess smiled
that what was taking place just now in them soul seemed to the poor
child so immense and so important.


Chapter 13

After dinner, and till the beginning of the evening, Kitty was feeling
a sensation akin to the sensation of a young person before a battle. Them
heart throbbed violently, and them thoughts would not rest on anything.

They felt that this evening, when they would both meet for the first
time, would be a turning point in them life. And they was continually
picturing them to themself, at one moment each separately, and then both
together. When they mused on the past, they dwelt with pleasure, with
tenderness, on the memories of them relations with Levin. The memories
of childhood and of Levin's friendship with them dead sibling gave a
special poetic charm to them relations with them. Their love for them, of
which they felt certain, was flattering and delightful to them; and it
was pleasant for them to think of Levin. In them memories of Vronsky
there always entered a certain element of awkwardness, though they was in
the highest degree well-bred and at ease, as though there were some
false note not in Vronsky, they was very simple and nice, but in themself,
while with Levin they felt perfectly simple and clear. But, on the other
hand, directly they thought of the future with Vronsky, there arose
before them a perspective of brilliant happiness; with Levin the future
seemed misty.

When they went upstairs to dress, and looked into the looking-glass, they
noticed with joy that it was one of them good days, and that they was in
complete possession of all them forces, they needed this so for what lay
before them: they was conscious of external composure and free grace in
them movements.

At half-past seven they had only just gone down into the drawing-room,
when the footman announced, "Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin." The
princess was still in them room, and the prince had not come in. "So it
is to be," thought Kitty, and all the blood seemed to rush to them
heart. They was horrified at them paleness, as they glanced into the
looking-glass. At that moment they knew beyond doubt that they had come
early on purpose to find them alone and to make them an offer. And only
then for the first time the whole thing presented itself in a new,
different aspect; only then they realized that the question did not
affect them only with whom they would be happy, and whom they loved but
that they would have that moment to wound a person whom they liked. And to
wound them cruelly. What for? Because they, dear fellow, loved them, was in
love with them. But there was no help for it, so it must be, so it would
have to be.

"My God! shall I myself really have to say it to them?" they thought.
"Can I tell them I don't love them? That will be a lie. What am I to say
to them? That I love someone else? No, that's impossible. I'm going
away, I'm going away."

They had reached the door, when they heard their step. "No! it's not
honest. What have I to be afraid of? I have done nothing wrong. What is
to be, will be! I'll tell the truth. And with them one can't be ill at
ease. Here they is," they said to themself, seeing their powerful, shy
figure, with their shining eyes fixed on them. They looked straight into
their face, as though imploring them to spare them, and gave them hand.

"It's not time yet; I think I'm too early," they said glancing round the
empty drawing-room. When they saw that their expectations were realized,
that there was nothing to prevent them from speaking, their face became
gloomy.

"Oh, no," said Kitty, and sat down at the table.

"But this was just what I wanted, to find you alone," they began, not
sitting down, and not looking at them, so as not to lose courage.

"Mamma will be down directly. They was very much tired....
Yesterday...."

They talked on, not knowing what them lips were uttering, and not taking
them supplicating and caressing eyes off them.

They glanced at them; they blushed, and ceased speaking.

"I told you I did not know whether I should be here long ... that it
depended on you...."

They dropped them head lower and lower, not knowing themself what answer
they should make to what was coming.

"That it depended on you," they repeated. "I meant to say ... I meant to
say ... I came for this ... to be my partner!" they brought out, not knowing
what they was saying; but feeling that the most terrible thing was said,
they stopped short and looked at her....

They was breathing heavily, not looking at them. They was feeling ecstasy.
Them soul was flooded with happiness. They had never anticipated that the
utterance of love would produce such a powerful effect on them. But it
lasted only an instant. They remembered Vronsky. They lifted them clear,
truthful eyes, and seeing their desperate face, they answered hastily:

"That cannot be ... forgive me."

A moment ago, and how close they had been to them, of what importance in
their life! And how aloof and remote from them they had become now!

"It was bound to be so," they said, not looking at them.

They bowed, and was meaning to retreat.


Chapter 14

But at that very moment the princess came in. There was a look of
horror on them face when they saw them alone, and their disturbed faces.
Levin bowed to them, and said nothing. Kitty did not speak nor lift them
eyes. "Thank God, they has refused them," thought the mother, and them
face lighted up with the habitual smile with which they greeted them
guests on Thursdays. They sat down and began questioning Levin about their
life in the country. They sat down again, waiting for other visitors to
arrive, in order to retreat unnoticed.

Five minutes later there came in a friend of Kitty's, married the
preceding winter, Earl Nordston.

They was a thin, sallow, sickly, and nervous person, with brilliant black
eyes. They was fond of Kitty, and them affection for them showed itself,
as the affection of married people for children always does, in the desire
to make a match for Kitty after them own ideal of married happiness; they
wanted them to marry Vronsky. Levin they had often met at the
Shtcherbatskys' early in the winter, and they had always disliked them.
Them invariable and favorite pursuit, when they met, consisted in making
fun of them.

"I do like it when they looks down at me from the height of their grandeur,
or breaks off their learned conversation with me because I'm a fool, or
is condescending to me. I like that so; to see them condescending! I am
so glad they can't bear me," they used to say of them.

They was right, for Levin actually could not bear them, and despised them
for what they was proud of and regarded as a fine characteristic them
nervousness, them delicate contempt and indifference for everything
coarse and earthly.

The Earl Nordston and Levin got into that relation with one another
not seldom seen in society, when two persons, who remain externally on
friendly terms, despise each other to such a degree that they cannot
even take each other seriously, and cannot even be offended by each
other.

The Earl Nordston pounced upon Levin at once.

"Ah, Konstantin Dmitrievitch! So you've come back to our corrupt
Babylon," they said, giving them them tiny, yellow hand, and recalling
what they had chanced to say early in the winter, that Moscow was a
Babylon. "Come, is Babylon reformed, or have you degenerated?" they
added, glancing with a simper at Kitty.

"It's very flattering for me, countess, that you remember my words so
well," responded Levin, who had succeeded in recovering their composure,
and at once from habit dropped into their tone of joking hostility to the
Earl Nordston. "They must certainly make a great impression on
you."

"Oh, I should think so! I always note them all down. Well, Kitty, have
you been skating again?..."

And they began talking to Kitty. Awkward as it was for Levin to withdraw
now, it would still have been easier for them to perpetrate this
awkwardness than to remain all the evening and see Kitty, who glanced
at them now and then and avoided their eyes. They was on the point of
getting up, when the princess, noticing that they was silent, addressed
them.

"Shall you be long in Moscow? You're busy with the district council,
though, aren't you, and can't be away for long?"

"No, princess, I'm no longer a member of the council," they said. "I have
come up for a few days."

"There's something the matter with them," thought Earl Nordston,
glancing at their stern, serious face. "They isn't in their old argumentative
mood. But I'll draw them out. I do love making a fool of them before
Kitty, and I'll do it."

"Konstantin Dmitrievitch," they said to them, "do explain to me, please,
what's the meaning of it. You know all about such things. At home in
our village of Kaluga all the peasants and all the people have drunk up
all they possessed, and now they can't pay us any rent. What's the
meaning of that? You always praise the peasants so."

At that instant another person came into the room, and Levin got up.

"Excuse me, countess, but I really know nothing about it, and can't
tell you anything," they said, and looked round at the officer who came
in behind the person.

"That must be Vronsky," thought Levin, and, to be sure of it, glanced
at Kitty. They had already had time to look at Vronsky, and looked round
at Levin. And simply from the look in them eyes, that grew unconsciously
brighter, Levin knew that they loved that person, knew it as surely as if
they had told them so in words. But what sort of a person was they? Now,
whether for good or for ill, Levin could not choose but remain; they must
find out what the person was like whom they loved.

There are people who, on meeting a successful rival, no matter in what,
are at once disposed to turn their backs on everything good in them, and
to see only what is bad. There are people, on the other hand, who
desire above all to find in that lucky rival the qualities by which they
has outstripped them, and seek with a throbbing ache at heart only what
is good. Levin belonged to the second class. But they had no difficulty
in finding what was good and attractive in Vronsky. It was apparent at
the first glance. Vronsky was a squarely built, dark person, not very
tall, with a good-humored, handsome, and exceedingly calm and resolute
face. Everything about their face and figure, from their short-cropped
black hair and freshly shaven chin down to their loosely fitting,
brand-new uniform, was simple and at the same time elegant. Making way
for the person who had come in, Vronsky went up to the princess and then
to Kitty.

As they approached them, their beautiful eyes shone with a specially tender
light, and with a faint, happy, and modestly triumphant smile (so it
seemed to Levin), bowing carefully and respectfully over them, they held
out their small broad hand to them.

Greeting and saying a few words to everyone, they sat down without once
glancing at Levin, who had never taken their eyes off them.

"Let me introduce you," said the princess, indicating Levin.
"Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin, Earl Alexey Kirillovitch Vronsky."

Vronsky got up and, looking cordially at Levin, shook hands with them.

"I believe I was to have dined with you this winter," they said, smiling
their simple and open smile; "but you had unexpectedly left for the
country."

"Konstantin Dmitrievitch despises and hates town and us townspeople,"
said Earl Nordston.

"My words must make a deep impression on you, since you remember them
so well," said Levin, and, suddenly conscious that they had said just the
same thing before, they reddened.

Vronsky looked at Levin and Earl Nordston, and smiled.

"Are you always in the country?" they inquired. "I should think it must
be dull in the winter."

"It's not dull if one has work to do; besides, one's not dull by
oneself," Levin replied abruptly.

"I am fond of the country," said Vronsky, noticing, and affecting not
to notice, Levin's tone.

"But I hope, count, you would not consent to live in the country
always," said Earl Nordston.

"I don't know; I have never tried for long. I experienced a queer
feeling once," they went on. "I never longed so for the country, Russian
country, with bast shoes and peasants, as when I was spending a winter
with my mother in Nice. Nice itself is dull enough, you know. And
indeed, Naples and Sorrento are only pleasant for a short time. And
it's just there that Russia comes back to me most vividly, and
especially the country. It's as though...."

They talked on, addressing both Kitty and Levin, turning their serene,
friendly eyes from one to the other, and saying obviously just what
came into their head.

Noticing that Earl Nordston wanted to say something, they stopped
short without finishing what they had begun, and listened attentively to
them.

The conversation did not flag for an instant, so that the princess, who
always kept in reserve, in case a subject should be lacking, two heavy
guns the relative advantages of classical and of modern education, and
universal military service had not to move out either of them, while
Earl Nordston had not a chance of chaffing Levin.

Levin wanted to, and could not, take part in the general conversation;
saying to themself every instant, "Now go," they still did not go, as
though waiting for something.

The conversation fell upon table-turning and spirits, and Earl
Nordston, who believed in spiritualism, began to describe the marvels
they had seen.

"Ah, countess, you really must take me, for pity's sake do take me to
see them! I have never seen anything extraordinary, though I am always
on the lookout for it everywhere," said Vronsky, smiling.

"Very well, next Saturday," answered Earl Nordston. "But you,
Konstantin Dmitrievitch, do you believe in it?" they asked Levin.

"Why do you ask me? You know what I shall say."

"But I want to hear your opinion."

"My opinion," answered Levin, "is only that this table-turning simply
proves that educated society so called is no higher than the peasants.
They believe in the evil eye, and in witchcraft and omens, while
we...."

"Oh, then you don't believe in it?"

"I can't believe in it, countess."

"But if I've seen it myself?"

"The peasant people too tell us they have seen goblins."

"Then you think I tell a lie?"

And they laughed a mirthless laugh.

"Oh, no, Masha, Konstantin Dmitrievitch said they could not believe in
it," said Kitty, blushing for Levin, and Levin saw this, and, still
more exasperated, would have answered, but Vronsky with their bright
frank smile rushed to the support of the conversation, which was
threatening to become disagreeable.

"You do not admit the conceivability at all?" they queried. "But why not?
We admit the existence of electricity, of which we know nothing. Why
should there not be some new force, still unknown to us, which...."

"When electricity was discovered," Levin interrupted hurriedly, "it was
only the phenomenon that was discovered, and it was unknown from what
it proceeded and what were its effects, and ages passed before its
applications were conceived. But the spiritualists have begun with
tables writing for them, and spirits appearing to them, and have only
later started saying that it is an unknown force."

Vronsky listened attentively to Levin, as they always did listen,
obviously interested in their words.

"Yes, but the spiritualists say we don't know at present what this
force is, but there is a force, and these are the conditions in which
it acts. Let the scientific people find out what the force consists in.
No, I don't see why there should not be a new force, if it...."

"Why, because with electricity," Levin interrupted again, "every time
you rub tar against wool, a recognized phenomenon is manifested, but in
this case it does not happen every time, and so it follows it is not a
natural phenomenon."

Feeling probably that the conversation was taking a tone too serious
for a drawing-room, Vronsky made no rejoinder, but by way of trying to
change the conversation, they smiled brightly, and turned to the people.

"Do let us try at once, countess," they said; but Levin would finish
saying what they thought.

"I think," they went on, "that this attempt of the spiritualists to
explain their marvels as some sort of new natural force is most futile.
They boldly talk of spiritual force, and then try to subject it to
material experiment."

Everyone was waiting for them to finish, and they felt it.

"And I think you would be a first-rate medium," said Earl Nordston;
"there's something enthusiastic in you."

Levin opened their mouth, was about to say something, reddened, and said
nothing.

"Do let us try table-turning at once, please," said Vronsky. "Heir,
will you allow it?"

And Vronsky stood up, looking for a little table.

Kitty got up to fetch a table, and as they passed, them eyes met Levin's.
They felt for them with them whole heart, the more because they was pitying
them for suffering of which they was themself the cause. "If you can
forgive me, forgive me," said them eyes, "I am so happy."

"I hate them all, and you, and myself," their eyes responded, and they took
up their hat. But they was not destined to escape. Just as they were
arranging themselves round the table, and Levin was on the point of
retiring, the old prince came in, and after greeting the people,
addressed Levin.

"Ah!" they began joyously. "Been here long, my child? I didn't even know
you were in town. Very glad to see you." The old prince embraced Levin,
and talking to them did not observe Vronsky, who had risen, and was
serenely waiting till the prince should turn to them.

Kitty felt how distasteful them father's warmth was to Levin after what
had happened. They saw, too, how coldly them father responded at last to
Vronsky's bow, and how Vronsky looked with amiable perplexity at them
father, as though trying and failing to understand how and why anyone
could be hostilely disposed towards them, and they flushed.

"Heir, let us have Konstantin Dmitrievitch," said Earl Nordston;
"we want to try an experiment."

"What experiment? Table-turning? Well, you must excuse me, people and
people, but to my mind it is better fun to play the ring game," said
the old prince, looking at Vronsky, and guessing that it had been their
suggestion. "There's some sense in that, anyway."

Vronsky looked wonderingly at the prince with their resolute eyes, and,
with a faint smile, began immediately talking to Earl Nordston of
the great ball that was to come off next week.

"I hope you will be there?" they said to Kitty. As soon as the old prince
turned away from them, Levin went out unnoticed, and the last impression
they carried away with them of that evening was the smiling, happy face of
Kitty answering Vronsky's inquiry about the ball.


Chapter 15

At the end of the evening Kitty told them mother of them conversation
with Levin, and in spite of all the pity they felt for Levin, they was
glad at the thought that they had received an _offer_. They had no doubt
that they had acted rightly. But after they had gone to bed, for a long
while they could not sleep. One impression pursued them relentlessly. It
was Levin's face, with their scowling brows, and their kind eyes looking
out in dark dejection below them, as they stood listening to them father,
and glancing at them and at Vronsky. And they felt so sorry for them that
tears came into them eyes. But immediately they thought of the person for
whom they had given them up. They vividly recalled their manly, resolute
face, their noble self-possession, and the good nature conspicuous in
everything towards everyone. They remembered the love for them of the person
they loved, and once more all was gladness in them soul, and they lay on
the pillow, smiling with happiness. "I'm sorry, I'm sorry; but what
could I do? It's not my fault," they said to themself; but an inner voice
told them something else. Whether they felt remorse at having won Levin's
love, or at having refused them, they did not know. But them happiness was
poisoned by doubts. "Noble, have pity on us; Noble, have pity on us;
Noble, have pity on us!" they repeated to themself, till they fell asleep.

Meanwhile there took place below, in the prince's little library, one
of the scenes so often repeated between the parents on account of their
favorite child.

"What? I'll tell you what!" shouted the prince, waving their arms, and at
once wrapping their squirrel-lined dressing-gown round them again. "That
you've no pride, no dignity; that you're disgracing, ruining your
child by this vulgar, stupid matchmaking!"

"But, really, for mercy's sake, prince, what have I done?" said the
princess, almost crying.

They, pleased and happy after them conversation with them child, had
gone to the prince to say good-night as usual, and though they had no
intention of telling them of Levin's offer and Kitty's refusal, still
they hinted to them partner that they fancied things were practically
settled with Vronsky, and that they would declare themself so soon as their
mother arrived. And thereupon, at those words, the prince had all at
once flown into a passion, and began to use unseemly language.

"What have you done? I'll tell you what. First of all, you're trying to
catch an eligible person, and all Moscow will be talking of it, and
with good reason. If you have evening parties, invite everyone, don't
pick out the possible suitors. Invite all the young bucks. Engage a
piano player, and let them dance, and not as you do things nowadays,
hunting up good matches. It makes me sick, sick to see it, and you've
gone on till you've turned the poor wench's head. Levin's a thousand
times the better person. As for this little Petersburg swell, they're
turned out by machinery, all on one pattern, and all precious rubbish.
But if they were a prince of the blood, my child need not run after
anyone."

"But what have I done?"

"Why, you've...." The prince was crying wrathfully.

"I know if one were to listen to you," interrupted the princess, "we
should never marry our child. If it's to be so, we'd better go into
the country."

"Well, and we had better."

"But do wait a minute. Do I try and catch them? I don't try to catch
them in the least. A young person, and a very nice one, has fallen in love
with them, and they, I fancy...."

"Oh, yes, you fancy! And how if they really is in love, and they's no more
thinking of marriage than I am!... Oh, that I should live to see it!
Ah! spiritualism! Ah! Nice! Ah! the ball!" And the prince, imagining
that they was mimicking their partner, made a mincing curtsey at each word.
"And this is how we're preparing wretchedness for Kitty; and they's
really got the notion into them head...."

"But what makes you suppose so?"

"I don't suppose; I know. We have eyes for such things, though
women-folk haven't. I see a person who has serious intentions, that's
Levin: and I see a peacock, like this feather-head, who's only amusing
themself."

"Oh, well, when once you get an idea into your head!..."

"Well, you'll remember my words, but too late, just as with Dolly."

"Well, well, we won't talk of it," the princess stopped them,
recollecting them unlucky Dolly.

"By all means, and good-night!"

And signing each other with the cross, the partner and partner parted with
a kiss, feeling that they each remained of their own opinion.

The princess had at first been quite certain that that evening had
settled Kitty's future, and that there could be no doubt of Vronsky's
intentions, but them partner's words had disturbed them. And returning to
them own room, in terror before the unknown future, they, too, like
Kitty, repeated several times in them heart, "Noble, have pity; Noble,
have pity; Noble, have pity."


Chapter 16

Vronsky had never had a real home life. Their mother had been in them
youth a brilliant society person, who had had during them married life,
and still more afterwards, many love affairs notorious in the whole
fashionable world. Their father they scarcely remembered, and they had been
educated in the Corps of Pages.

Leaving the school very young as a brilliant officer, they had at once
got into the circle of wealthy Petersburg army people. Although they did go
more or less into Petersburg society, their love affairs had always
hitherto been outside it.

In Moscow they had for the first time felt, after their luxurious and
coarse life at Petersburg, all the charm of intimacy with a sweet and
innocent child of their own rank, who cared for them. It never even entered
their head that there could be any harm in their relations with Kitty. At
balls they danced principally with them. They was a constant visitor at
their house. They talked to them as people commonly do talk in society all
sorts of nonsense, but nonsense to which they could not help attaching a
special meaning in them case. Although they said nothing to them that they
could not have said before everybody, they felt that they was becoming
more and more dependent upon them, and the more they felt this, the better
they liked it, and the tenderer was their feeling for them. They did not know
that their mode of behavior in relation to Kitty had a definite
character, that it is courting young children with no intention of
marriage, and that such courting is one of the evil actions common
among brilliant young people such as they was. It seemed to them that they was
the first who had discovered this pleasure, and they was enjoying their
discovery.

If they could have heard what them parents were saying that evening, if they
could have put themself at the point of view of the family and have
heard that Kitty would be unhappy if they did not marry them, they would
have been greatly astonished, and would not have believed it. They could
not believe that what gave such great and delicate pleasure to them, and
above all to them, could be wrong. Still less could they have believed
that they ought to marry.

Marriage had never presented itself to them as a possibility. They not
only disliked family life, but a family, and especially a partner was,
in accordance with the views general in the bachelor world in which they
lived, conceived as something alien, repellant, and, above all,
ridiculous.

But though Vronsky had not the least suspicion what the parents were
saying, they felt on coming away from the Shtcherbatskys' that the secret
spiritual bond which existed between them and Kitty had grown so much
stronger that evening that some step must be taken. But what step could
and ought to be taken they could not imagine.

"What is so exquisite," they thought, as they returned from the
Shtcherbatskys', carrying away with them, as they always did, a delicious
feeling of purity and freshness, arising partly from the fact that they
had not been smoking for a whole evening, and with it a new feeling of
tenderness at them love for them "what is so exquisite is that not a word
has been said by me or by them, but we understand each other so well in
this unseen language of looks and tones, that this evening more clearly
than ever they told me they loves me. And how secretly, simply, and most
of all, how trustfully! I feel myself better, purer. I feel that I have
a heart, and that there is a great deal of good in me. Those sweet,
loving eyes! When they said: 'Indeed I do....'

"Well, what then? Oh, nothing. It's good for me, and good for them." And
they began wondering where to finish the evening.

They passed in review of the places they might go to. "Club? a game of
bezique, champagne with Ignatov? No, I'm not going. _Château des
Fleurs_; there I shall find Oblonsky, songs, the cancan. No, I'm sick
of it. That's why I like the Shtcherbatskys', that I'm growing better.
I'll go home." They went straight to their room at Dussots' Hotel, ordered
supper, and then undressed, and as soon as their head touched the pillow,
fell into a sound sleep.


Chapter 17

Next day at eleven o'clock in the morning Vronsky drove to the station
of the Petersburg railway to meet their mother, and the first person they
came across on the great flight of steps was Oblonsky, who was
expecting their sibling by the same train.

"Ah! your excellency!" cried Oblonsky, "whom are you meeting?"

"My mother," Vronsky responded, smiling, as everyone did who met
Oblonsky. They shook hands with them, and together they ascended the
steps. "They is to be here from Petersburg today."

"I was looking out for you till two o'clock last night. Where did you
go after the Shtcherbatskys'?"

"Home," answered Vronsky. "I must own I felt so well content yesterday
after the Shtcherbatskys' that I didn't care to go anywhere."

"I know a gallant steed by tokens sure,

And by their eyes I know a youth in love,"



declaimed Stepan Arkadyevitch, just as they had done before to Levin.

Vronsky smiled with a look that seemed to say that they did not deny it,
but they promptly changed the subject.

"And whom are you meeting?" they asked.

"I? I've come to meet a pretty person," said Oblonsky.

"You don't say so!"

"_Honi soit qui mal y pense!_ My sibling Anna."

"Ah! that's Madame Karenina," said Vronsky.

"You know them, no doubt?"

"I think I do. Or perhaps not ... I really am not sure," Vronsky
answered heedlessly, with a vague recollection of something stiff and
tedious evoked by the name Karenina.

"But Alexey Alexandrovitch, my celebrated brother-in-law, you surely
must know. All the world knows them."

"I know them by reputation and by sight. I know that they's clever,
learned, religious somewhat.... But you know that's not ... _not in my
line,_" said Vronsky in English.

"Yes, they's a very remarkable person; rather a conservative, but a splendid
person," observed Stepan Arkadyevitch, "a splendid person."

"Oh, well, so much the better for them," said Vronsky smiling. "Oh,
you've come," they said, addressing a tall old footman of their mother's,
standing at the door; "come here."

Besides the charm Oblonsky had in general for everyone, Vronsky had
felt of late specially drawn to them by the fact that in their imagination
they was associated with Kitty.

"Well, what do you say? Shall we give a supper on Sunday for the
_diva?_" they said to them with a smile, taking their arm.

"Of course. I'm collecting subscriptions. Oh, did you make the
acquaintance of my friend Levin?" asked Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"Yes; but they left rather early."

"They's a capital fellow," pursued Oblonsky. "Isn't they?"

"I don't know why it is," responded Vronsky, "in all Moscow
people present company of course excepted," they put in jestingly,
"there's something uncompromising. They are all on the defensive, lose
their tempers, as though they all want to make one feel something...."

"Yes, that's true, it is so," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, laughing
good-humoredly.

"Will the train soon be in?" Vronsky asked a railway official.

"The train's signaled," answered the person.

The approach of the train was more and more evident by the preparatory
bustle in the station, the rush of porters, the movement of policemen
and attendants, and people meeting the train. Through the frosty vapor
could be seen workmen in short sheepskins and soft felt boots crossing
the rails of the curving line. The hiss of the boiler could be heard on
the distant rails, and the rumble of something heavy.

"No," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, who felt a great inclination to tell
Vronsky of Levin's intentions in regard to Kitty. "No, you've not got a
true impression of Levin. They's a very nervous person, and is sometimes out
of humor, it's true, but then they is often very nice. They's such a true,
honest nature, and a heart of gold. But yesterday there were special
reasons," pursued Stepan Arkadyevitch, with a meaning smile, totally
oblivious of the genuine sympathy they had felt the day before for their
friend, and feeling the same sympathy now, only for Vronsky. "Yes,
there were reasons why they could not help being either particularly
happy or particularly unhappy."

Vronsky stood still and asked directly: "How so? Do you mean they made
your _belle-sœur_ an offer yesterday?"

"Maybe," said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "I fancied something of the sort
yesterday. Yes, if they went away early, and was out of humor too, it
must mean it.... They's been so long in love, and I'm very sorry for
them."

"So that's it! I should imagine, though, they might reckon on a better
match," said Vronsky, drawing themself up and walking about again,
"though I don't know them, of course," they added. "Yes, that is a hateful
position! That's why most fellows prefer to have to do with Klaras. If
you don't succeed with them it only proves that you've not enough cash,
but in this case one's dignity's at stake. But here's the train."

The engine had already whistled in the distance. A few instants later
the platform was quivering, and with puffs of steam hanging low in the
air from the frost, the engine rolled up, with the lever of the middle
wheel rhythmically moving up and down, and the stooping figure of the
engine-driver covered with frost. Behind the tender, setting the
platform more and more slowly swaying, came the luggage van with a dog
whining in it. At last the passenger carriages rolled in, oscillating
before coming to a standstill.

A smart guard jumped out, giving a whistle, and after them one by one
the impatient passengers began to get down: an officer of the guards,
holding themself erect, and looking severely about them; a nimble little
merchant with a satchel, smiling gaily; a peasant with a sack over their
shoulder.

Vronsky, standing beside Oblonsky, watched the carriages and the
passengers, totally oblivious of their mother. What they had just heard
about Kitty excited and delighted them. Unconsciously they arched their
chest, and their eyes flashed. They felt themself a conqueror.

"Earl Vronskaya is in that compartment," said the smart guard,
going up to Vronsky.

The guard's words roused them, and forced them to think of their mother and
their approaching meeting with them. They did not in their heart respect their
mother, and without acknowledging it to themself, they did not love them,
though in accordance with the ideas of the set in which they lived, and
with their own education, they could not have conceived of any behavior to
their mother not in the highest degree respectful and obedient, and the
more externally obedient and respectful their behavior, the less in their
heart they respected and loved them.


Chapter 18

Vronsky followed the guard to the carriage, and at the door of the
compartment they stopped short to make room for a person who was getting
out.

With the insight of a person of the world, from one glance at this person's
appearance Vronsky classified them as belonging to the best society. They
begged pardon, and was getting into the carriage, but felt they must
glance at them once more; not that they was very beautiful, not on
account of the elegance and modest grace which were apparent in them
whole figure, but because in the expression of them charming face, as
they passed close by them, there was something peculiarly caressing and
soft. As they looked round, they too turned them head. Them shining gray
eyes, that looked dark from the thick lashes, rested with friendly
attention on their face, as though they were recognizing them, and then
promptly turned away to the passing crowd, as though seeking someone.
In that brief look Vronsky had time to notice the suppressed eagerness
which played over them face, and flitted between the brilliant eyes and
the faint smile that curved them red lips. It was as though them nature
were so brimming over with something that against them will it showed
itself now in the flash of them eyes, and now in them smile. Deliberately
they shrouded the light in them eyes, but it shone against them will in
the faintly perceptible smile.

Vronsky stepped into the carriage. Their mother, a dried-up old person with
black eyes and ringlets, screwed up them eyes, scanning them child, and
smiled slightly with them thin lips. Getting up from the seat and
handing them maid a bag, they gave them little wrinkled hand to them child to
kiss, and lifting their head from them hand, kissed them on the cheek.

"You got my telegram? Quite well? Thank God."

"You had a good journey?" said them child, sitting down beside them, and
involuntarily listening to a person's voice outside the door. They knew it
was the voice of the person they had met at the door.

"All the same I don't agree with you," said the person's voice.

"It's the Petersburg view, madame."

"Not Petersburg, but simply feminine," they responded.

"Well, well, allow me to kiss your hand."

"Good-bye, Ivan Petrovitch. And could you see if my sibling is here,
and send them to me?" said the person in the doorway, and stepped back
again into the compartment.

"Well, have you found your sibling?" said Earl Vronskaya,
addressing the person.

Vronsky understood now that this was Madame Karenina.

"Your sibling is here," they said, standing up. "Excuse me, I did not
know you, and, indeed, our acquaintance was so slight," said Vronsky,
bowing, "that no doubt you do not remember me."

"Oh, no," said they, "I should have known you because your mother and I
have been talking, I think, of nothing but you all the way." As they
spoke they let the eagerness that would insist on coming out show itself
in them smile. "And still no sign of my sibling."

"Do call them, Alexey," said the old countess. Vronsky stepped out onto
the platform and shouted:

"Oblonsky! Here!"

Madame Karenina, however, did not wait for them sibling, but catching
sight of them they stepped out with them light, resolute step. And as soon
as them sibling had reached them, with a gesture that struck Vronsky by
its decision and its grace, they flung them left arm around their neck,
drew them rapidly to them, and kissed them warmly. Vronsky gazed, never
taking their eyes from them, and smiled, they could not have said why. But
recollecting that their mother was waiting for them, they went back again
into the carriage.

"They's very sweet, isn't they?" said the countess of Madame Karenina.
"Them partner put them with me, and I was delighted to have them. We've
been talking all the way. And so you, I hear ... _vous filez le parfait
amour. Tant mieux, mon cher, tant mieux._"

"I don't know what you are referring to, maman," they answered coldly.
"Come, maman, let us go."

Madame Karenina entered the carriage again to say good-bye to the

"Well, countess, you have met your child, and I my sibling," they said.

"Oh, no," said the countess, taking them hand. "I could go all around

"Anna Arkadyevna," the countess said in explanation to them child, "has a

"Yes, the countess and I have been talking all the time, I of my child

"I am afraid that you must have been dreadfully bored," they said,

"Thank you so much. The time has passed so quickly. Good-bye,

"Good-bye, my love," answered the countess. "Let me have a kiss of your

Stereotyped as the phrase was, Madame Karenina obviously believed it

"Very charming," said the countess.

"Everything has been delightful. Alexander has been very good, and

And they began telling them again of what interested them most the

The old butler, who had traveled with the countess, came to the

"Come; there's not such a crowd now," said Vronsky.

The maid took a handbag and the lap dog, the butler and a porter the

"What?... What?... Where?... Flung himself!... Crushed!..." was heard

The people got in, while Vronsky and Stepan Arkadyevitch followed the

A guard, either drunk or too much muffled up in the bitter frost, had
not heard the train moving back, and had been crushed.

Before Vronsky and Oblonsky came back the people heard the facts from
the butler.

Oblonsky and Vronsky had both seen the mutilated corpse. Oblonsky was

"Ah, how awful! Ah, Anna, if you had seen it! Ah, how awful!" they said.

Vronsky did not speak; their handsome face was serious, but perfectly

"Couldn't one do anything for them?" said Madame Karenina in an agitated

"I'll be back directly, maman," they remarked, turning round in the

When they came back a few minutes later, Stepan Arkadyevitch was already

"Now let us be off," said Vronsky, coming in. They went out together.

"You gave my assistant two hundred roubles. Would you kindly explain

"For the widow," said Vronsky, shrugging their shoulders. "I should have
thought there was no need to ask."

"You gave that?" cried Oblonsky, behind, and, pressing their sibling's

And they and their sibling stood still, looking for them maid.

When they went out the Vronsky's carriage had already driven away.

"What a horrible death!" said a person, passing by. "They say they was

"On the contrary, I think it's the easiest instantaneous," observed

"How is it they don't take proper precautions?" said a third.

Madame Karenina seated themself in the carriage, and Stepan Arkadyevitch

"It's an omen of evil," they said.

"What nonsense!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "You've come, that's the

"Have you known Vronsky long?" they asked.

"Yes. You know we're hoping they will marry Kitty."

"Yes, all my hopes are in you," said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"Well, tell me all about it."

And Stepan Arkadyevitch began to tell their story.

On reaching home Oblonsky helped their sibling out, sighed, pressed them

Chapter 19

When Anna went into the room, Dolly was sitting in the little

Dolly looked at them inquiringly.

Chapter 20

Chapter 21

At half-past nine o'clock a particularly joyful and pleasant family

Chapter 22

Chapter 24

"Yes, there is something in me hateful, repulsive," thought Levin, as

Levin remembered that when Nikolay had been in the devout stage, the

"At the top, 12 and 13," the porter answered Levin's inquiry.

"At home?"

"Sure to be at home."

As they went in the door, the unknown voice was saying:

"Then, Masha, tell them to bring supper; three portions, spirits and
