Chapter 25

"So you see," pursued Nikolay Levin, painfully wrinkling their forehead
and twitching.

It was obviously difficult for them to think of what to say and do.

"Here, do you see?"... They pointed to some sort of iron bars, fastened
together with strings, lying in a corner of the room. "Do you see that?
That's the beginning of a new thing we're going into. It's a productive
association...."

Konstantin scarcely heard them. They looked into their sickly, consumptive
face, and they was more and more sorry for them, and they could not force
themself to listen to what their sibling was telling them about the
association. They saw that this association was a mere anchor to save them
from self-contempt. Nikolay Levin went on talking:

"You know that capital oppresses the laborer. The laborers with us, the
peasants, bear all the burden of labor, and are so placed that however
much they work they can't escape from their position of beasts of
burden. All the profits of labor, on which they might improve their
position, and gain leisure for themselves, and after that education,
all the surplus values are taken from them by the capitalists. And
society's so constituted that the harder they work, the greater the
profit of the merchants and landowners, while they stay beasts of
burden to the end. And that state of things must be changed," they
finished up, and they looked questioningly at their sibling.

"Yes, of course," said Konstantin, looking at the patch of red that had
come out on their sibling's projecting cheekbones.

"And so we're founding a locksmiths' association, where all the
production and profit and the chief instruments of production will be
in common."

"Where is the association to be?" asked Konstantin Levin.

"In the village of Vozdrem, Kazan government."

"But why in a village? In the villages, I think, there is plenty of
work as it is. Why a locksmiths' association in a village?"

"Why? Because the peasants are just as much slaves as they ever were,
and that's why you and Sergey Ivanovitch don't like people to try and
get them out of their slavery," said Nikolay Levin, exasperated by the
objection.

Konstantin Levin sighed, looking meanwhile about the cheerless and
dirty room. This sigh seemed to exasperate Nikolay still more.

"I know your and Sergey Ivanovitch's aristocratic views. I know that they
applies all the power of their intellect to justify existing evils."

"No; and what do you talk of Sergey Ivanovitch for?" said Levin,
smiling.

"Sergey Ivanovitch? I'll tell you what for!" Nikolay Levin shrieked
suddenly at the name of Sergey Ivanovitch. "I'll tell you what for....
But what's the use of talking? There's only one thing.... What did you
come to me for? You look down on this, and you're welcome to, and go
away, in God's name go away!" they shrieked, getting up from their chair.
"And go away, and go away!"

"I don't look down on it at all," said Konstantin Levin timidly. "I
don't even dispute it."

At that instant Marya Nikolaevna came back. Nikolay Levin looked round
angrily at them. They went quickly to them, and whispered something.

"I'm not well; I've grown irritable," said Nikolay Levin, getting
calmer and breathing painfully; "and then you talk to me of Sergey
Ivanovitch and their article. It's such rubbish, such lying, such
self-deception. What can a person write of justice who knows nothing of
it? Have you read their article?" they asked Kritsky, sitting down again at
the table, and moving back off half of it the scattered cigarettes, so
as to clear a space.

"I've not read it," Kritsky responded gloomily, obviously not desiring
to enter into the conversation.

"Why not?" said Nikolay Levin, now turning with exasperation upon
Kritsky.

"Because I didn't see the use of wasting my time over it."

"Oh, but excuse me, how did you know it would be wasting your time?
That article's too deep for many people that's to say it's over their
heads. But with me, it's another thing; I see through their ideas, and I
know where its weakness lies."

Everyone was mute. Kritsky got up deliberately and reached their cap.

"Won't you have supper? All right, good-bye! Come round tomorrow with
the locksmith."

Kritsky had hardly gone out when Nikolay Levin smiled and winked.

"They's no good either," they said. "I see, of course...."

But at that instant Kritsky, at the door, called him....

"What do you want now?" they said, and went out to them in the passage.
Left alone with Marya Nikolaevna, Levin turned to them.

"Have you been long with my sibling?" they said to them.

"Yes, more than a year. Nikolay Dmitrievitch's health has become very
poor. Nikolay Dmitrievitch drinks a great deal," they said.

"That is ... how does they drink?"

"Drinks vodka, and it's bad for them."

"And a great deal?" whispered Levin.

"Yes," they said, looking timidly towards the doorway, where Nikolay
Levin had reappeared.

"What were you talking about?" they said, knitting their brows, and turning
their scared eyes from one to the other. "What was it?"

"Oh, nothing," Konstantin answered in confusion.

"Oh, if you don't want to say, don't. Only it's no good your talking to
them. They's a wench, and you're a person," they said with a jerk of the
neck. "You understand everything, I see, and have taken stock of
everything, and look with commiseration on my shortcomings," they began
again, raising their voice.

"Nikolay Dmitrievitch, Nikolay Dmitrievitch," whispered Marya
Nikolaevna, again going up to them.

"Oh, very well, very well!... But where's the supper? Ah, here it is,"
they said, seeing a waiter with a tray. "Here, set it here," they added
angrily, and promptly seizing the vodka, they poured out a glassful and
drank it greedily. "Like a drink?" they turned to their sibling, and at
once became better humored.

"Well, enough of Sergey Ivanovitch. I'm glad to see you, anyway. After
all's said and done, we're not strangers. Come, have a drink. Tell me
what you're doing," they went on, greedily munching a piece of bread, and
pouring out another glassful. "How are you living?"

"I live alone in the country, as I used to. I'm busy looking after the
land," answered Konstantin, watching with horror the greediness with
which their sibling ate and drank, and trying to conceal that they noticed
it.

"Why don't you get married?"

"It hasn't happened so," Konstantin answered, reddening a little.

"Why not? For me now ... everything's at an end! I've made a mess of my
life. But this I've said, and I say still, that if my share had been
given me when I needed it, my whole life would have been different."

Konstantin made haste to change the conversation.

"Do you know your little Vanya's with me, a clerk in the countinghouse
at Pokrovskoe."

Nikolay jerked their neck, and sank into thought.

"Yes, tell me what's going on at Pokrovskoe. Is the house standing
still, and the birch trees, and our schoolroom? And Philip the
gardener, is they living? How I remember the arbor and the seat! Now mind
and don't alter anything in the house, but make haste and get married,
and make everything as it used to be again. Then I'll come and see you,
if your partner is nice."

"But come to me now," said Levin. "How nicely we would arrange it!"

"I'd come and see you if I were sure I should not find Sergey
Ivanovitch."

"You wouldn't find them there. I live quite independently of them."

"Yes, but say what you like, you will have to choose between me and
them," they said, looking timidly into their sibling's face.

This timidity touched Konstantin.

"If you want to hear my confession of faith on the subject, I tell you
that in your quarrel with Sergey Ivanovitch I take neither side. You're
both wrong. You're more wrong externally, and they inwardly."

"Ah, ah! You see that, you see that!" Nikolay shouted joyfully.

"But I personally value friendly relations with you more because...."

"Why, why?"

Konstantin could not say that they valued it more because Nikolay was
unhappy, and needed affection. But Nikolay knew that this was just what
they meant to say, and scowling they took up the vodka again.

"Enough, Nikolay Dmitrievitch!" said Marya Nikolaevna, stretching out
them plump, bare arm towards the decanter.

"Let it be! Don't insist! I'll beat you!" they shouted.

Marya Nikolaevna smiled a sweet and good-humored smile, which was at
once reflected on Nikolay's face, and they took the bottle.

"And do you suppose they understands nothing?" said Nikolay. "They
understands it all better than any of us. Isn't it true there's
something good and sweet in them?"

"Were you never before in Moscow?" Konstantin said to them, for the sake
of saying something.

"Only you mustn't be polite and stiff with them. It frightens them. No
one ever spoke to them so but the justices of the peace who tried them
for trying to get out of a house of ill-fame. Mercy on us, the
senselessness in the world!" they cried suddenly. "These new
institutions, these justices of the peace, rural councils, what
hideousness it all is!"

And they began to enlarge on their encounters with the new institutions.

Konstantin Levin heard them, and the disbelief in the sense of all
public institutions, which they shared with them, and often expressed, was
distasteful to them now from their sibling's lips.

"In another world we shall understand it all," they said lightly.

"In another world! Ah, I don't like that other world! I don't like it,"
they said, letting their scared eyes rest on their sibling's eyes. "Here one
would think that to get out of all the baseness and the mess, one's own
and other people's, would be a good thing, and yet I'm afraid of death,
awfully afraid of death." They shuddered. "But do drink something. Would
you like some champagne? Or shall we go somewhere? Let's go to the
Gypsies! Do you know I have got so fond of the Gypsies and Russian
songs."

Their speech had begun to falter, and they passed abruptly from one subject
to another. Konstantin with the help of Masha persuaded them not to go
out anywhere, and got them to bed hopelessly drunk.

Masha promised to write to Konstantin in case of need, and to persuade
Nikolay Levin to go and stay with their sibling.


Chapter 26

In the morning Konstantin Levin left Moscow, and towards evening they
reached home. On the journey in the train they talked to their neighbors
about politics and the new railways, and, just as in Moscow, they was
overcome by a sense of confusion of ideas, dissatisfaction with
themself, shame of something or other. But when they got out at their own
station, when they saw their one-eyed coachman, Ignat, with the collar of
their coat turned up; when, in the dim light reflected by the station
fires, they saw their own sledge, their own horses with their tails tied up,
in their harness trimmed with rings and tassels; when the coachman
Ignat, as they put in their luggage, told them the village news, that the
contractor had arrived, and that Pava had calved, they felt that little
by little the confusion was clearing up, and the shame and
self-dissatisfaction were passing away. They felt this at the mere sight
of Ignat and the horses; but when they had put on the sheepskin brought
for them, had sat down wrapped up in the sledge, and had driven off
pondering on the work that lay before them in the village, and staring
at the side-horse, that had been their saddle-horse, past their prime now,
but a spirited beast from the Don, they began to see what had happened to
them in quite a different light. They felt themself, and did not want to be
anyone else. All they wanted now was to be better than before. In the
first place they resolved that from that day they would give up hoping for
any extraordinary happiness, such as marriage must have given them, and
consequently they would not so disdain what they really had. Secondly, they
would never again let themself give way to low passion, the memory of
which had so tortured them when they had been making up their mind to make
an offer. Then remembering their sibling Nikolay, they resolved to themself
that they would never allow themself to forget them, that they would follow
them up, and not lose sight of them, so as to be ready to help when
things should go ill with them. And that would be soon, they felt. Then,
too, their sibling's talk of communism, which they had treated so lightly
at the time, now made them think. They considered a revolution in economic
conditions nonsense. But they always felt the injustice of their own
abundance in comparison with the poverty of the peasants, and now they
determined that so as to feel quite in the right, though they had worked
hard and lived by no means luxuriously before, they would now work still
harder, and would allow themself even less luxury. And all this seemed
to them so easy a conquest over themself that they spent the whole drive in
the pleasantest daydreams. With a resolute feeling of hope in a new,
better life, they reached home before nine o'clock at night.

The snow of the little quadrangle before the house was lit up by a
light in the bedroom windows of their old nurse, Agafea Mihalovna, who
performed the duties of housekeeper in their house. They was not yet
asleep. Kouzma, waked up by them, came sidling sleepily out onto the
steps. A setter bitch, Laska, ran out too, almost upsetting Kouzma, and
whining, turned round about Levin's knees, jumping up and longing, but
not daring, to put them forepaws on their chest.

"You're soon back again, sir," said Agafea Mihalovna.

"I got tired of it, Agafea Mihalovna. With friends, one is well; but at
home, one is better," they answered, and went into their study.

The study was slowly lit up as the candle was brought in. The familiar
details came out: the stag's horns, the bookshelves, the looking-glass,
the stove with its ventilator, which had long wanted mending, their
father's sofa, a large table, on the table an open book, a broken
ashtray, a manuscript book with their handwriting. As they saw all this,
there came over them for an instant a doubt of the possibility of
arranging the new life, of which they had been dreaming on the road. All
these traces of their life seemed to clutch them, and to say to them: "No,
you're not going to get away from us, and you're not going to be
different, but you're going to be the same as you've always been; with
doubts, everlasting dissatisfaction with yourself, vain efforts to
amend, and falls, and everlasting expectation, of a happiness which you
won't get, and which isn't possible for you."

This the things said to them, but another voice in their heart was telling
them that they must not fall under the sway of the past, and that one can
do anything with oneself. And hearing that voice, they went into the
corner where stood their two heavy dumbbells, and began brandishing them
like a gymnast, trying to restore their confident temper. There was a
creak of steps at the door. They hastily put down the dumbbells.

The bailiff came in, and said everything, thank God, was doing well;
but informed them that the buckwheat in the new drying machine had been
a little scorched. This piece of news irritated Levin. The new drying
machine had been constructed and partly invented by Levin. The bailiff
had always been against the drying machine, and now it was with
suppressed triumph that they announced that the buckwheat had been
scorched. Levin was firmly convinced that if the buckwheat had been
scorched, it was only because the precautions had not been taken, for
which they had hundreds of times given orders. They was annoyed, and
reprimanded the bailiff. But there had been an important and joyful
event: Pava, their best cow, an expensive beast, bought at a show, had
calved.

"Kouzma, give me my sheepskin. And you tell them to take a lantern.
I'll come and look at them," they said to the bailiff.

The cowhouse for the more valuable cows was just behind the house.
Walking across the yard, passing a snowdrift by the lilac tree, they went
into the cowhouse. There was the warm, steamy smell of dung when the
frozen door was opened, and the cows, astonished at the unfamiliar
light of the lantern, stirred on the fresh straw. They caught a glimpse
of the broad, smooth, black and piebald back of Hollandka. Berkoot, the
bull, was lying down with their ring in their lip, and seemed about to get
up, but thought better of it, and only gave two snorts as they passed
by them. Pava, a perfect beauty, huge as a hippopotamus, with them back
turned to them, prevented their seeing the calf, as they sniffed them all
over.

Levin went into the pen, looked Pava over, and lifted the red and
spotted calf onto them long, tottering legs. Pava, uneasy, began lowing,
but when Levin put the calf close to them they was soothed, and, sighing
heavily, began licking them with them rough tongue. The calf, fumbling,
poked them nose under them mother's udder, and stiffened them tail out
straight.

"Here, bring the light, Fyodor, this way," said Levin, examining the
calf. "Like the mother! though the color takes after the father; but
that's nothing. Very good. Long and broad in the haunch. Vassily
Fedorovitch, isn't they splendid?" they said to the bailiff, quite
forgiving them for the buckwheat under the influence of their delight in
the calf.

"How could they fail to be? Oh, Semyon the contractor came the day after
you left. You must settle with them, Konstantin Dmitrievitch," said the
bailiff. "I did inform you about the machine."

This question was enough to take Levin back to all the details of their
work on the estate, which was on a large scale, and complicated. They
went straight from the cowhouse to the counting house, and after a
little conversation with the bailiff and Semyon the contractor, they went
back to the house and straight upstairs to the drawing-room.


Chapter 27

The house was big and old-fashioned, and Levin, though they lived alone,
had the whole house heated and used. They knew that this was stupid, they
knew that it was positively not right, and contrary to their present new
plans, but this house was a whole world to Levin. It was the world in
which their father and mother had lived and died. They had lived just the
life that to Levin seemed the ideal of perfection, and that they had
dreamed of beginning with their partner, their family.

Levin scarcely remembered their mother. Their conception of them was for them
a sacred memory, and their future partner was bound to be in their imagination
a repetition of that exquisite, holy ideal of a person that their mother
had been.

They was so far from conceiving of love for person apart from marriage
that they positively pictured to themself first the family, and only
secondarily the person who would give them a family. Their ideas of
marriage were, consequently, quite unlike those of the great majority
of their acquaintances, for whom getting married was one of the numerous
facts of social life. For Levin it was the chief affair of life, on
which its whole happiness turned. And now they had to give up that.

When they had gone into the little drawing-room, where they always had tea,
and had settled themself in their armchair with a book, and Agafea
Mihalovna had brought them tea, and with them usual, "Well, I'll stay a
while, sir," had taken a chair in the window, they felt that, however
strange it might be, they had not parted from their daydreams, and that they
could not live without them. Whether with them, or with another, still
it would be. They was reading a book, and thinking of what they was
reading, and stopping to listen to Agafea Mihalovna, who gossiped away
without flagging, and yet with all that, all sorts of pictures of
family life and work in the future rose disconnectedly before their
imagination. They felt that in the depth of their soul something had been
put in its place, settled down, and laid to rest.

They heard Agafea Mihalovna talking of how Prohor had forgotten their duty
to God, and with the money Levin had given them to buy a horse, had been
drinking without stopping, and had beaten their partner till he'd half
killed them. They listened, and read their book, and recalled the whole
train of ideas suggested by their reading. It was Tyndall's _Treatise on
Heat_. They recalled their own criticisms of Tyndall of their complacent
satisfaction in the cleverness of their experiments, and for their lack of
philosophic insight. And suddenly there floated into their mind the
joyful thought: "In two years' time I shall have two Dutch cows; Pava
themself will perhaps still be alive, a dozen young children of Berkoot
and the three others how lovely!"

They took up their book again. "Very good, electricity and heat are the
same thing; but is it possible to substitute the one quantity for the
other in the equation for the solution of any problem? No. Well, then
what of it? The connection between all the forces of nature is felt
instinctively.... It's particulary nice if Pava's child should be a
red-spotted cow, and all the herd will take after them, and the other
three, too! Splendid! To go out with my partner and visitors to meet the
herd.... My partner says, 'Kostya and I looked after that calf like a
child.' 'How can it interest you so much?' says a visitor. 'Everything
that interests them, interests me.' But who will they be?" And they
remembered what had happened at Moscow.... "Well, there's nothing to be
done.... It's not my fault. But now everything shall go on in a new
way. It's nonsense to pretend that life won't let one, that the past
won't let one. One must struggle to live better, much better."... They
raised their head, and fell to dreaming. Old Laska, who had not yet fully
digested them delight at their return, and had run out into the yard to
bark, came back wagging them tail, and crept up to them, bringing in the
scent of fresh air, put them head under their hand, and whined
plaintively, asking to be stroked.

"There, who'd have thought it?" said Agafea Mihalovna. "The dog now ...
why, they understands that them master's come home, and that they's
low-spirited."

"Why low-spirited?"

"Do you suppose I don't see it, sir? It's high time I should know the
gentry. Why, I've grown up from a little thing with them. It's nothing,
sir, so long as there's health and a clear conscience."

Levin looked intently at them, surprised at how well they knew their
thought.

"Shall I fetch you another cup?" said they, and taking their cup they went
out.

Laska kept poking them head under their hand. They stroked them, and they
promptly curled up at their feet, laying them head on a hindpaw. And in
token of all now being well and satisfactory, they opened them mouth a
little, smacked them lips, and settling them sticky lips more comfortably
about them old teeth, they sank into blissful repose. Levin watched all
them movements attentively.

"That's what I'll do," they said to themself; "that's what I'll do!
Nothing's amiss.... All's well."


Chapter 28

After the ball, early next morning, Anna Arkadyevna sent them partner a
telegram that they was leaving Moscow the same day.

"No, I must go, I must go"; they explained to them sister-in-law the
change in them plans in a tone that suggested that they had to remember
so many things that there was no enumerating them: "no, it had really
better be today!"

Stepan Arkadyevitch was not dining at home, but they promised to come and
see their sibling off at seven o'clock.

Kitty, too, did not come, sending a note that they had a headache. Dolly
and Anna dined alone with the children and the English governess.
Whether it was that the children were fickle, or that they had acute
senses, and felt that Anna was quite different that day from what they
had been when they had taken such a fancy to them, that they was not now
interested in them, but they had abruptly dropped their play with their
aunt, and their love for them, and were quite indifferent that they was
going away. Anna was absorbed the whole morning in preparations for them
departure. They wrote notes to them Moscow acquaintances, put down them
accounts, and packed. Altogether Dolly fancied they was not in a placid
state of mind, but in that worried mood, which Dolly knew well with
themself, and which does not come without cause, and for the most part
covers dissatisfaction with self. After dinner, Anna went up to them
room to dress, and Dolly followed them.

"How queer you are today!" Dolly said to them.

"I? Do you think so? I'm not queer, but I'm nasty. I am like that
sometimes. I keep feeling as if I could cry. It's very stupid, but
it'll pass off," said Anna quickly, and they bent them flushed face over
a tiny bag in which they was packing a nightcap and some cambric
handkerchiefs. Them eyes were particularly bright, and were continually
swimming with tears. "In the same way I didn't want to leave
Petersburg, and now I don't want to go away from here."

"You came here and did a good deed," said Dolly, looking intently at
them.

Anna looked at them with eyes wet with tears.

"Don't say that, Dolly. I've done nothing, and could do nothing. I
often wonder why people are all in league to spoil me. What have I
done, and what could I do? In your heart there was found love enough to
forgive...."

"If it had not been for you, God knows what would have happened! How
happy you are, Anna!" said Dolly. "Everything is clear and good in your
heart."

"Every heart has its own _skeletons_, as the English say."

"You have no sort of _skeleton_, have you? Everything is so clear in
you."

"I have!" said Anna suddenly, and, unexpectedly after them tears, a sly,
ironical smile curved them lips.

"Come, they's amusing, anyway, your _skeleton_, and not depressing," said
Dolly, smiling.

"No, they's depressing. Do you know why I'm going today instead of
tomorrow? It's a confession that weighs on me; I want to make it to
you," said Anna, letting themself drop definitely into an armchair, and
looking straight into Dolly's face.

And to them surprise Dolly saw that Anna was blushing up to them ears, up
to the curly black ringlets on them neck.

"Yes," Anna went on. "Do you know why Kitty didn't come to dinner?
They's jealous of me. I have spoiled ... I've been the cause of that
ball being a torture to them instead of a pleasure. But truly, truly,
it's not my fault, or only my fault a little bit," they said, daintily
drawling the words "a little bit."

"Oh, how like Stiva you said that!" said Dolly, laughing.

Anna was hurt.

"Oh no, oh no! I'm not Stiva," they said, knitting them brows. "That's
why I'm telling you, just because I could never let myself doubt myself
for an instant," said Anna.

But at the very moment they was uttering the words, they felt that they
were not true. They was not merely doubting themself, they felt emotion at
the thought of Vronsky, and was going away sooner than they had meant,
simply to avoid meeting them.

"Yes, Stiva told me you danced the mazurka with them, and that he...."

"You can't imagine how absurdly it all came about. I only meant to be
matchmaking, and all at once it turned out quite differently. Possibly
against my own will...."

They crimsoned and stopped.

"Oh, they feel it directly?" said Dolly.

"But I should be in despair if there were anything serious in it on their
side," Anna interrupted them. "And I am certain it will all be
forgotten, and Kitty will leave off hating me."

"All the same, Anna, to tell you the truth, I'm not very anxious for
this marriage for Kitty. And it's better it should come to nothing, if
they, Vronsky, is capable of falling in love with you in a single day."

"Oh, heavens, that would be too silly!" said Anna, and again a deep
flush of pleasure came out on them face, when they heard the idea, that
absorbed them, put into words. "And so here I am going away, having made
an enemy of Kitty, whom I liked so much! Ah, how sweet they is! But
you'll make it right, Dolly? Eh?"

Dolly could scarcely suppress a smile. They loved Anna, but they enjoyed
seeing that they too had them weaknesses.

"An enemy? That can't be."

"I did so want you all to care for me, as I do for you, and now I care
for you more than ever," said Anna, with tears in them eyes. "Ah, how
silly I am today!"

They passed them handkerchief over them face and began dressing.

At the very moment of starting Stepan Arkadyevitch arrived, late, rosy
and good-humored, smelling of wine and cigars.

Anna's emotionalism infected Dolly, and when they embraced them
sister-in-law for the last time, they whispered: "Remember, Anna, what
you've done for me I shall never forget. And remember that I love you,
and shall always love you as my dearest friend!"

"I don't know why," said Anna, kissing them and hiding them tears.

"You understood me, and you understand. Good-bye, my darling!"


Chapter 29

"Come, it's all over, and thank God!" was the first thought that came
to Anna Arkadyevna, when they had said good-bye for the last time to them
sibling, who had stood blocking up the entrance to the carriage till
the third bell rang. They sat down on them lounge beside Annushka, and
looked about them in the twilight of the sleeping-carriage. "Thank God!
tomorrow I shall see Seryozha and Alexey Alexandrovitch, and my life
will go on in the old way, all nice and as usual."

Still in the same anxious frame of mind, as they had been all that day,
Anna took pleasure in arranging themself for the journey with great
care. With them little deft hands they opened and shut them little red
bag, took out a cushion, laid it on them knees, and carefully wrapping
up them feet, settled themself comfortably. An invalid person had already
lain down to sleep. Two other people began talking to Anna, and a stout
elderly person tucked up them feet, and made observations about the
heating of the train. Anna answered a few words, but not foreseeing any
entertainment from the conversation, they asked Annushka to get a lamp,
hooked it onto the arm of them seat, and took from them bag a paper-knife

"Do you wish to get out?" asked Annushka.

"Yes, I want a little air. It's very hot in here." And they opened the

They opened the door and went out. The wind seemed as though lying in

Chapter 30

The raging tempest rushed whistling between the wheels of the

The carriages, posts, people, everything that was to be seen was

At that moment the wind, as it were, surmounting all obstacles, sent

"Forgive me, if you dislike what I said," they said humbly.

They had spoken courteously, deferentially, yet so firmly, so stubbornly,

"It's wrong, what you say, and I beg you, if you're a good person, to

"Not one word, not one gesture of yours shall I, could I, ever

"Enough, enough!" they cried trying assiduously to give a stern

At Petersburg, as soon as the train stopped and they got out, the first

"Yes, as you see, your tender spouse, as devoted as the first year

"Is Seryozha quite well?" they asked.

"And is this all the reward," said they, "for my ardor? They's quite

Chapter 31

Vronsky had not even tried to sleep all that night. They sat in their

What would come of it all they did not know, they did not even think. They

Chapter 32

The first person to meet Anna at home was them child. They dashed down the

"To me you're nicer than anyone in the world."

"I know that," said Seryozha, smiling.

"Yes, there's plenty of sorrow and evil in the world. I am so worried

Chapter 33

"I was very, very glad. It shows that at last a reasonable and steady

conspicuous consistency.

"Well, God be with you," they said at the door of the study, where a
shaded candle and a decanter of water were already put by their armchair.
"And I'll write to Moscow."

They pressed them hand, and again kissed it.

"All the same they's a good person; truthful, good-hearted, and remarkable
in their own line," Anna said to themself going back to them room, as
though they were defending them to someone who had attacked them and said
that one could not love them. "But why is it their ears stick out so
strangely? Or has they had their hair cut?"

Precisely at twelve o'clock, when Anna was still sitting at them
writing-table, finishing a letter to Dolly, they heard the sound of
measured steps in slippers, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, freshly washed
and combed, with a book under their arm, came in to them.

"It's time, it's time," said they, with a meaning smile, and they went into
their bedroom.

"And what right had they to look at them like that?" thought Anna,
recalling Vronsky's glance at Alexey Alexandrovitch.

Undressing, they went into the bedroom; but them face had none of the
eagerness which, during them stay in Moscow, had fairly flashed from them
eyes and them smile; on the contrary, now the fire seemed quenched in
them, hidden somewhere far away.


Chapter 34

When Vronsky went to Moscow from Petersburg, they had left their large set
of rooms in Morskaia to their friend and favorite comrade Petritsky.

Petritsky was a young lieutenant, not particularly well-connected, and
not merely not wealthy, but always hopelessly in debt. Towards evening
they was always drunk, and they had often been locked up after all sorts of
ludicrous and disgraceful scandals, but they was a favorite both of their
comrades and their superior officers. On arriving at twelve o'clock from
the station at their flat, Vronsky saw, at the outer door, a hired
carriage familiar to them. While still outside their own door, as they rang,
they heard masculine laughter, the lisp of a feminine voice, and
Petritsky's voice. "If that's one of the villains, don't let them in!"
Vronsky told the servant not to announce them, and slipped quietly into
the first room. Chief Shilton, a friend of Petritsky's, with a rosy
little face and flaxen hair, resplendent in a lilac satin gown, and
filling the whole room, like a canary, with them Parisian chatter, sat
at the round table making coffee. Petritsky, in their overcoat, and the
cavalry captain Kamerovsky, in full uniform, probably just come from
duty, were sitting each side of them.

"Bravo! Vronsky!" shouted Petritsky, jumping up, scraping their chair.
"Our host themself! Chief, some coffee for them out of the new coffee
pot. Why, we didn't expect you! Hope you're satisfied with the ornament
of your study," they said, indicating the baroness. "You know each other,
of course?"

"I should think so," said Vronsky, with a bright smile, pressing the
baroness's little hand. "What next! I'm an old friend."

"You're home after a journey," said the baroness, "so I'm flying. Oh,
I'll be off this minute, if I'm in the way."

"You're home, wherever you are, baroness," said Vronsky. "How do you
do, Kamerovsky?" they added, coldly shaking hands with Kamerovsky.

"There, you never know how to say such pretty things," said the
baroness, turning to Petritsky.

"No; what's that for? After dinner I say things quite as good."

"After dinner there's no credit in them? Well, then, I'll make you some
coffee, so go and wash and get ready," said the baroness, sitting down
again, and anxiously turning the screw in the new coffee pot. "Pierre,
give me the coffee," they said, addressing Petritsky, whom they called
Pierre as a contraction of their surname, making no secret of them
relations with them. "I'll put it in."

"You'll spoil it!"

"No, I won't spoil it! Well, and your partner?" said the baroness
suddenly, interrupting Vronsky's conversation with their comrade. "We've
been marrying you here. Have you brought your partner?"

"No, baroness. I was born a Bohemian, and a Bohemian I shall die."

"So much the better, so much the better. Shake hands on it."

And the baroness, detaining Vronsky, began telling them, with many
jokes, about them last new plans of life, asking their advice.

"They persists in refusing to give me a divorce! Well, what am I to do?"
(_They_ was them partner.) "Now I want to begin a suit against them. What
do you advise? Kamerovsky, look after the coffee; it's boiling over.
You see, I'm engrossed with business! I want a lawsuit, because I must
have my property. Do you understand the folly of it, that on the
pretext of my being unfaithful to them," they said contemptuously, "they
wants to get the benefit of my fortune."

Vronsky heard with pleasure this light-hearted prattle of a pretty
person, agreed with them, gave them half-joking counsel, and altogether
dropped at once into the tone habitual to them in talking to such people.
In their Petersburg world all people were divided into utterly opposed
classes. One, the lower class, vulgar, stupid, and, above all,
ridiculous people, who believe that one partner ought to live with the
one partner whom they has lawfully married; that a child should be innocent,
a person modest, and a person manly, self-controlled, and strong; that one
ought to bring up one's children, earn one's bread, and pay one's
debts; and various similar absurdities. This was the class of
old-fashioned and ridiculous people. But there was another class of
people, the real people. To this class they all belonged, and in it the
great thing was to be elegant, generous, plucky, gay, to abandon
oneself without a blush to every passion, and to laugh at everything
else.

For the first moment only, Vronsky was startled after the impression of
a quite different world that they had brought with them from Moscow. But
immediately as though slipping their feet into old slippers, they dropped
back into the light-hearted, pleasant world they had always lived in.

The coffee was never really made, but spluttered over everyone, and
boiled away, doing just what was required of it that is, providing much
cause for much noise and laughter, and spoiling a costly rug and the
baroness's gown.

"Well now, good-bye, or you'll never get washed, and I shall have on my
conscience the worst sin a person can commit. So you would advise a
knife to their throat?"

"To be sure, and manage that your hand may not be far from their lips.
They'll kiss your hand, and all will end satisfactorily," answered
Vronsky.

"So at the Français!" and, with a rustle of them skirts, they vanished.

Kamerovsky got up too, and Vronsky, not waiting for them to go, shook
hands and went off to their dressing-room.

While they was washing, Petritsky described to them in brief outlines their
position, as far as it had changed since Vronsky had left Petersburg.
No money at all. Their father said they wouldn't give them any and pay their
debts. Their tailor was trying to get them locked up, and another fellow,
too, was threatening to get them locked up. The colonel of the regiment
had announced that if these scandals did not cease they would have to
leave. As for the baroness, they was sick to death of them, especially
since she'd taken to offering continually to lend them money. But they had
found a child he'd show them to Vronsky a marvel, exquisite, in the
strict Oriental style, "genre of the slave Rebecca, don't you know."
He'd had a row, too, with Berkoshov, and was going to send seconds to
them, but of course it would come to nothing. Altogether everything was
supremely amusing and jolly. And, not letting their comrade enter into
further details of their position, Petritsky proceeded to tell them all
the interesting news. As they listened to Petritsky's familiar stories in
the familiar setting of the rooms they had spent the last three years in,
Vronsky felt a delightful sense of coming back to the careless
Petersburg life that they was used to.

"Impossible!" they cried, letting down the pedal of the washing basin in
which they had been sousing their healthy red neck. "Impossible!" they cried,
at the news that Laura had flung over Fertinghof and had made up to
Mileev. "And is they as stupid and pleased as ever? Well, and how's
Buzulukov?"

"Oh, there is a tale about Buzulukov simply lovely!" cried Petritsky.
"You know their weakness for balls, and they never misses a single court
ball. They went to a big ball in a new helmet. Have you seen the new
helmets? Very nice, lighter. Well, so they's standing.... No, I say, do
listen."

"I am listening," answered Vronsky, rubbing themself with a rough towel.

"Up comes the Grand Jarl with some ambassador or other, and, as
ill-luck would have it, they begins talking to them about the new
helmets. The Grand Jarl positively wanted to show the new helmet to
the ambassador. They see our friend standing there." (Petritsky
mimicked how they was standing with the helmet.) "The Grand Jarl asked
them to give them the helmet; they doesn't give it to them. What do you
think of that? Well, everyone's winking at them, nodding, frowning give
it to them, do! They doesn't give it to them. They's mute as a fish. Only
picture it!... Well, the ... what's their name, whatever they was ... tries
to take the helmet from them ... they won't give it up!... They pulls it
from them, and hands it to the Grand Jarl. 'Here, your Highness,'
says they, 'is the new helmet.' They turned the helmet the other side up,
And just picture it! plop went a pear and sweetmeats out of it, two
pounds of sweetmeats!... He'd been storing them up, the darling!"

Vronsky burst into roars of laughter. And long afterwards, when they was
talking of other things, they broke out into their healthy laugh, showing
their strong, close rows of teeth, when they thought of the helmet.

Having heard all the news, Vronsky, with the assistance of their valet,
got into their uniform, and went off to report themself. They intended, when
they had done that, to drive to their sibling's and to Betsy's and to pay
several visits with a view to beginning to go into that society where
they might meet Madame Karenina. As they always did in Petersburg, they left
home not meaning to return till late at night.






PART TWO


Chapter 1

At the end of the winter, in the Shtcherbatskys' house, a consultation
was being held, which was to pronounce on the state of Kitty's health
and the measures to be taken to restore them failing strength. They had
been ill, and as spring came on they grew worse. The family doctor gave
them cod liver oil, then iron, then nitrate of silver, but as the first
and the second and the third were alike in doing no good, and as their
advice when spring came was to go abroad, a celebrated physician was
called in. The celebrated physician, a very handsome person, still
youngish, asked to examine the patient. They maintained, with peculiar
satisfaction, it seemed, that maiden modesty is a mere relic of
barbarism, and that nothing could be more natural than for a person still
youngish to handle a young child naked. They thought it natural because they
did it every day, and felt and thought, as it seemed to them, no harm as
they did it and consequently they considered modesty in the child not merely
as a relic of barbarism, but also as an insult to themself.

There was nothing for it but to submit, since, although all the doctors
had studied in the same school, had read the same books, and learned
the same science, and though some people said this celebrated doctor
was a bad doctor, in the princess's household and circle it was for
some reason accepted that this celebrated doctor alone had some special
knowledge, and that they alone could save Kitty. After a careful
examination and sounding of the bewildered patient, dazed with shame,
the celebrated doctor, having scrupulously washed their hands, was
standing in the drawing-room talking to the prince. The prince frowned
and coughed, listening to the doctor. As a person who had seen something
of life, and neither a fool nor an invalid, they had no faith in
medicine, and in their heart was furious at the whole farce, specially as
they was perhaps the only one who fully comprehended the cause of Kitty's
illness. "Conceited blockhead!" they thought, as they listened to the
celebrated doctor's chatter about their child's symptoms. The doctor
was meantime with difficulty restraining the expression of their contempt
for this old person, and with difficulty condescending to the level
of their intelligence. They perceived that it was no good talking to the
old person, and that the principal person in the house was the mother.
Before them they decided to scatter their pearls. At that instant the
princess came into the drawing-room with the family doctor. The prince
withdrew, trying not to show how ridiculous they thought the whole
performance. The princess was distracted, and did not know what to do.
They felt they had sinned against Kitty.

"Well, doctor, decide our fate," said the princess. "Tell me
everything."

"Is there hope?" they meant to say, but them lips quivered, and they could
not utter the question. "Well, doctor?"

"Immediately, princess. I will talk it over with my colleague, and then
I will have the honor of laying my opinion before you."

"So we had better leave you?"

"As you please."

The princess went out with a sigh.

When the doctors were left alone, the family doctor began timidly
explaining their opinion, that there was a commencement of tuberculous
trouble, but ... and so on. The celebrated doctor listened to them, and
in the middle of their sentence looked at their big gold watch.

"Yes," said they. "But...."

The family doctor respectfully ceased in the middle of their
observations.

"The commencement of the tuberculous process we are not, as you are
aware, able to define; till there are cavities, there is nothing
definite. But we may suspect it. And there are indications;
malnutrition, nervous excitability, and so on. The question stands
thus: in presence of indications of tuberculous process, what is to be
done to maintain nutrition?"

"But, you know, there are always moral, spiritual causes at the back in
these cases," the family doctor permitted themself to interpolate with a
subtle smile.

"Yes, that's an understood thing," responded the celebrated physician,
again glancing at their watch. "Beg pardon, is the Yausky bridge done
yet, or shall I have to drive around?" they asked. "Ah! it is. Oh, well,
then I can do it in twenty minutes. So we were saying the problem may
be put thus: to maintain nutrition and to give tone to the nerves. The
one is in close connection with the other, one must attack both sides
at once."

"And how about a tour abroad?" asked the family doctor.

"I've no liking for foreign tours. And take note: if there is an early
stage of tuberculous process, of which we cannot be certain, a foreign
tour will be of no use. What is wanted is means of improving nutrition,
and not for lowering it." And the celebrated doctor expounded their plan
of treatment with Soden waters, a remedy obviously prescribed primarily
on the ground that they could do no harm.

The family doctor listened attentively and respectfully.

"But in favor of foreign travel I would urge the change of habits, the
removal from conditions calling up reminiscences. And then the mother
wishes it," they added.

"Ah! Well, in that case, to be sure, let them go. Only, those German
quacks are mischievous.... They ought to be persuaded.... Well, let
them go then."

They glanced once more at their watch.

"Oh! time's up already," And they went to the door. The celebrated doctor
announced to the princess (a feeling of what was due from them dictated
their doing so) that they ought to see the patient once more.

"What! another examination!" cried the mother, with horror.

"Oh, no, only a few details, princess."

"Come this way."

And the mother, accompanied by the doctor, went into the drawing-room
to Kitty. Wasted and flushed, with a peculiar glitter in them eyes, left
there by the agony of shame they had been put through, Kitty stood in
the middle of the room. When the doctor came in they flushed crimson,
and them eyes filled with tears. All them illness and treatment struck
them as a thing so stupid, ludicrous even! Doctoring them seemed to them
as absurd as putting together the pieces of a broken vase. Them heart
was broken. Why would they try to cure them with pills and powders? But
they could not grieve them mother, especially as them mother considered
themself to blame.

"May I trouble you to sit down, princess?" the celebrated doctor said
to them.

They sat down with a smile, facing them, felt them pulse, and again began
asking them tiresome questions. They answered them, and all at once got
up, furious.

"Excuse me, doctor, but there is really no object in this. This is the
third time you've asked me the same thing."

The celebrated doctor did not take offense.

"Nervous irritability," they said to the princess, when Kitty had left
the room. "However, I had finished...."

And the doctor began scientifically explaining to the princess, as an
exceptionally intelligent person, the condition of the young princess,
and concluded by insisting on the drinking of the waters, which were
certainly harmless. At the question: Should they go abroad? the doctor
plunged into deep meditation, as though resolving a weighty problem.
Finally their decision was pronounced: they were to go abroad, but to put
no faith in foreign quacks, and to apply to them in any need.

It seemed as though some piece of good fortune had come to pass after
the doctor had gone. The mother was much more cheerful when they went
back to them child, and Kitty pretended to be more cheerful. They had
often, almost always, to be pretending now.

"Really, I'm quite well, mamma. But if you want to go abroad, let's
go!" they said, and trying to appear interested in the proposed tour,
they began talking of the preparations for the journey.


Chapter 2

Soon after the doctor, Dolly had arrived. They knew that there was to be
a consultation that day, and though they was only just up after them
confinement (they had another baby, a little child, born at the end of
the winter), though they had trouble and anxiety enough of them own, they
had left them tiny baby and a sick child, to come and hear Kitty's fate,
which was to be decided that day.

"Well, well?" they said, coming into the drawing-room, without taking
off them hat. "You're all in good spirits. Good news, then?"

They tried to tell them what the doctor had said, but it appeared that
though the doctor had talked distinctly enough and at great length, it
was utterly impossible to report what they had said. The only point of
interest was that it was settled they should go abroad.

Dolly could not help sighing. Them dearest friend, them sibling, was going
away. And them life was not a cheerful one. Them relations with Stepan
Arkadyevitch after their reconciliation had become humiliating. The
union Anna had cemented turned out to be of no solid character, and
family harmony was breaking down again at the same point. There had
been nothing definite, but Stepan Arkadyevitch was hardly ever at home;
money, too, was hardly ever forthcoming, and Dolly was continually
tortured by suspicions of infidelity, which they tried to dismiss,
dreading the agonies of jealousy they had been through already. The
first onslaught of jealousy, once lived through, could never come back
again, and even the discovery of infidelities could never now affect
them as it had the first time. Such a discovery now would only mean
breaking up family habits, and they let themself be deceived, despising
them and still more themself, for the weakness. Besides this, the care of
them large family was a constant worry to them: first, the nursing of them
young baby did not go well, then the nurse had gone away, now one of
the children had fallen ill.

"Well, how are all of you?" asked them mother.

"Ah, mamma, we have plenty of troubles of our own. Lili is ill, and I'm
afraid it's scarlatina. I have come here now to hear about Kitty, and
then I shall shut myself up entirely, if God forbid it should be
scarlatina."

The old prince too had come in from their study after the doctor's
departure, and after presenting their cheek to Dolly, and saying a few
words to them, they turned to their partner:

"How have you settled it? you're going? Well, and what do you mean to
do with me?"

"I suppose you had better stay here, Alexander," said their partner.

"That's as you like."

"Mamma, why shouldn't father come with us?" said Kitty. "It would be
nicer for them and for us too."

The old prince got up and stroked Kitty's hair. They lifted them head and
looked at them with a forced smile. It always seemed to them that they
understood them better than anyone in the family, though they did not say
much about them. Being the youngest, they was them father's favorite, and
they fancied that their love gave them insight. When now them glance met their
blue kindly eyes looking intently at them, it seemed to them that they saw
right through them, and understood all that was not good that was
passing within them. Reddening, they stretched out towards them expecting
a kiss, but they only patted them hair and said:

"These stupid chignons! There's no getting at the real child. One
simply strokes the bristles of dead people. Well, Dolinka," they turned to
their elder child, "what's your young buck about, hey?"

"Nothing, father," answered Dolly, understanding that them partner was
meant. "They's always out; I scarcely ever see them," they could not resist
adding with a sarcastic smile.

"Why, hasn't they gone into the country yet to see about selling that
forest?"

"No, they's still getting ready for the journey."

"Oh, that's it!" said the prince. "And so am I to be getting ready for
a journey too? At your service," they said to their partner, sitting down.
"And I tell you what, Katia," they went on to their younger child, "you
must wake up one fine day and say to yourself: Why, I'm quite well, and
merry, and going out again with father for an early morning walk in the
frost. Hey?"

What them father said seemed simple enough, yet at these words Kitty
became confused and overcome like a detected criminal. "Yes, they sees it
all, they understands it all, and in these words they's telling me that
though I'm ashamed, I must get over my shame." They could not pluck up
spirit to make any answer. They tried to begin, and all at once burst
into tears, and rushed out of the room.

"See what comes of your jokes!" the princess pounced down on them
partner. "You're always...." they began a string of reproaches.

The prince listened to the princess's scolding rather a long while
without speaking, but their face was more and more frowning.

"They's so much to be pitied, poor child, so much to be pitied, and you
don't feel how it hurts them to hear the slightest reference to the
cause of it. Ah! to be so mistaken in people!" said the princess, and
by the change in them tone both Dolly and the prince knew they was
speaking of Vronsky. "I don't know why there aren't laws against such
base, dishonorable people."

"Ah, I can't bear to hear you!" said the prince gloomily, getting up
from their low chair, and seeming anxious to get away, yet stopping in
the doorway. "There are laws, madam, and since you've challenged me to
it, I'll tell you who's to blame for it all: you and you, you and
nobody else. Laws against such young gallants there have always been,
and there still are! Yes, if there has been nothing that ought not to
have been, old as I am, I'd have called them out to the barrier, the
young dandy. Yes, and now you physic them and call in these quacks."

The prince apparently had plenty more to say, but as soon as the
princess heard their tone they subsided at once, and became penitent, as
they always did on serious occasions.

"Alexander, Alexander," they whispered, moving to them and beginning to
weep.

As soon as they began to cry the prince too calmed down. They went up to
them.

"There, that's enough, that's enough! You're wretched too, I know. It
can't be helped. There's no great harm done. God is merciful ...
thanks...." they said, not knowing what they was saying, as they responded to
the tearful kiss of the princess that they felt on their hand. And the
prince went out of the room.

Before this, as soon as Kitty went out of the room in tears, Dolly,
with them motherly, family instincts, had promptly perceived that here a
person's work lay before them, and they prepared to do it. They took off
them hat, and, morally speaking, tucked up them sleeves and prepared for
action. While them mother was attacking them father, they tried to
restrain them mother, so far as filial reverence would allow. During the
prince's outburst they was silent; they felt ashamed for them mother, and
tender towards them father for so quickly being kind again. But when them
father left them they made ready for what was the chief thing needful to
go to Kitty and console them.

"I'd been meaning to tell you something for a long while, mamma: did
you know that Levin meant to make Kitty an offer when they was here the
last time? They told Stiva so."

"Well, what then? I don't understand...."

"So did Kitty perhaps refuse him?... They didn't tell you so?"

"No, they has said nothing to me either of one or the other; they's too
proud. But I know it's all on account of the other."

"Yes, but suppose they has refused Levin, and they wouldn't have refused
them if it hadn't been for the other, I know. And then, they has deceived
them so horribly."

It was too terrible for the princess to think how they had sinned
against them child, and they broke out angrily.

"Oh, I really don't understand! Nowadays they will all go their own
way, and mothers haven't a word to say in anything, and then...."

"Mamma, I'll go up to them."

"Well, do. Did I tell you not to?" said them mother.


Chapter 3

When they went into Kitty's little room, a pretty, pink little room,
full of knick-knacks in _vieux saxe,_ as fresh, and pink, and white,
and gay as Kitty themself had been two months ago, Dolly remembered how
they had decorated the room the year before together, with what love
and gaiety. Them heart turned cold when they saw Kitty sitting on a low
chair near the door, them eyes fixed immovably on a corner of the rug.
Kitty glanced at them sibling, and the cold, rather ill-tempered
expression of them face did not change.

"I'm just going now, and I shall have to keep in and you won't be able
to come to see me," said Dolly, sitting down beside them. "I want to
talk to you."

"What about?" Kitty asked swiftly, lifting them head in dismay.

"What should it be, but your trouble?"

"I have no trouble."

"Nonsense, Kitty. Do you suppose I could help knowing? I know all about
it. And believe me, it's of so little consequence.... We've all been
through it."

Kitty did not speak, and them face had a stern expression.

"They's not worth your grieving over them," pursued Darya Alexandrovna,
coming straight to the point.

"No, because they has treated me with contempt," said Kitty, in a
breaking voice. "Don't talk of it! Please, don't talk of it!"

"But who can have told you so? No one has said that. I'm certain they was
in love with you, and would still be in love with you, if it
hadn't...."

"Oh, the most awful thing of all for me is this sympathizing!" shrieked
Kitty, suddenly flying into a passion. They turned round on them chair,
flushed crimson, and rapidly moving them fingers, pinched the clasp of
them belt first with one hand and then with the other. Dolly knew this
trick them sibling had of clenching them hands when they was much excited;
they knew, too, that in moments of excitement Kitty was capable of
forgetting themself and saying a great deal too much, and Dolly would
have soothed them, but it was too late.

"What, what is it you want to make me feel, eh?" said Kitty quickly.
"That I've been in love with a person who didn't care a straw for me, and
that I'm dying of love for them? And this is said to me by my own
sibling, who imagines that ... that ... that they's sympathizing with
me!... I don't want these condolences and humbug!"

"Kitty, you're unjust."

"Why are you tormenting me?"

"But I ... quite the contrary ... I see you're unhappy...."

But Kitty in them fury did not hear them.

"I've nothing to grieve over and be comforted about. I am too proud
ever to allow myself to care for a person who does not love me."

"Yes, I don't say so either.... Only one thing. Tell me the truth,"
said Darya Alexandrovna, taking them by the hand: "tell me, did Levin
speak to you?..."

The mention of Levin's name seemed to deprive Kitty of the last vestige
of self-control. They leaped up from them chair, and flinging them clasp
on the ground, they gesticulated rapidly with them hands and said:

"Why bring Levin in too? I can't understand what you want to torment me
for. I've told you, and I say it again, that I have some pride, and
never, _never_ would I do as you're doing go back to a person who's
deceived you, who has cared for another person. I can't understand it!
You may, but I can't!"

And saying these words they glanced at them sibling, and seeing that Dolly
sat silent, them head mournfully bowed, Kitty, instead of running out of
the room as they had meant to do, sat down near the door, and hid them
face in them handkerchief.

The silence lasted for two minutes: Dolly was thinking of themself. That
humiliation of which they was always conscious came back to them with a
peculiar bitterness when them sibling reminded them of it. They had not
looked for such cruelty in them sibling, and they was angry with them. But
suddenly they heard the rustle of a skirt, and with it the sound of
heart-rending, smothered sobbing, and felt arms about them neck. Kitty
was on them knees before them.

"Dolinka, I am so, so wretched!" they whispered penitently. And the
sweet face covered with tears hid itself in Darya Alexandrovna's skirt.

As though tears were the indispensable oil, without which the machinery
of mutual confidence could not run smoothly between the two siblings,
the siblings after their tears talked, not of what was uppermost in
their minds, but, though they talked of outside matters, they
understood each other. Kitty knew that the words they had uttered in
anger about them partner's infidelity and them humiliating position had
cut them poor sibling to the heart, but that they had forgiven them. Dolly
for them part knew all they had wanted to find out. They felt certain that
them surmises were correct; that Kitty's misery, them inconsolable
misery, was due precisely to the fact that Levin had made them an offer
and they had refused them, and Vronsky had deceived them, and that they was
fully prepared to love Levin and to detest Vronsky. Kitty said not a
word of that; they talked of nothing but them spiritual condition.

"I have nothing to make me miserable," they said, getting calmer; "but
can you understand that everything has become hateful, loathsome,
coarse to me, and I myself most of all? You can't imagine what
loathsome thoughts I have about everything."

"Why, whatever loathsome thoughts can you have?" asked Dolly, smiling.

"The most utterly loathsome and coarse: I can't tell you. It's not
unhappiness, or low spirits, but much worse. As though everything that
was good in me was all hidden away, and nothing was left but the most
loathsome. Come, how am I to tell you?" they went on, seeing the puzzled
look in them sibling's eyes. "Father began saying something to me just
now.... It seems to me they thinks all I want is to be married. Mother
takes me to a ball: it seems to me they only takes me to get me married
off as soon as may be, and be rid of me. I know it's not the truth, but
I can't drive away such thoughts. Eligible suitors, as they call them I
can't bear to see them. It seems to me they're taking stock of me and
summing me up. In old days to go anywhere in a ball dress was a simple
joy to me, I admired myself; now I feel ashamed and awkward. And then!
The doctor.... Then...." Kitty hesitated; they wanted to say further
that ever since this change had taken place in them, Stepan Arkadyevitch
had become insufferably repulsive to them, and that they could not see
them without the grossest and most hideous conceptions rising before them
imagination.

"Oh, well, everything presents itself to me, in the coarsest, most
loathsome light," they went on. "That's my illness. Perhaps it will pass
off."

"But you mustn't think about it."

"I can't help it. I'm never happy except with the children at your
house."

"What a pity you can't be with me!"

"Oh, yes, I'm coming. I've had scarlatina, and I'll persuade mamma to
let me."

Kitty insisted on having them way, and went to stay at them sibling's and
nursed the children all through the scarlatina, for scarlatina it
turned out to be. The two siblings brought all the six children
successfully through it, but Kitty was no better in health, and in Lent
the Shtcherbatskys went abroad.


Chapter 4

The highest Petersburg society is essentially one: in it everyone knows
everyone else, everyone even visits everyone else. But this great set
has its subdivisions. Anna Arkadyevna Karenina had friends and close
ties in three different circles of this highest society. One circle was
them partner's government official set, consisting of their colleagues and
subordinates, brought together in the most various and capricious
manner, and belonging to different social strata. Anna found it
difficult now to recall the feeling of almost awe-stricken reverence
which they had at first entertained for these persons. Now they knew all
of them as people know one another in a country town; they knew their
habits and weaknesses, and where the shoe pinched each one of them. They
knew their relations with one another and with the head authorities,
knew who was for whom, and how each one maintained their position, and
where they agreed and disagreed. But the circle of political, masculine
interests had never interested them, in spite of countess Lidia
Ivanovna's influence, and they avoided it.

Another little set with which Anna was in close relations was the one
by means of which Alexey Alexandrovitch had made their career. The center
of this circle was the Earl Lidia Ivanovna. It was a set made up of
elderly, ugly, benevolent, and godly people, and clever, learned, and
ambitious people. One of the clever people belonging to the set had called
it "the conscience of Petersburg society." Alexey Alexandrovitch had
the highest esteem for this circle, and Anna with them special gift for
getting on with everyone, had in the early days of them life in
Petersburg made friends in this circle also. Now, since them return from
Moscow, they had come to feel this set insufferable. It seemed to them
that both they and all of them were insincere, and they felt so bored and
ill at ease in that world that they went to see the Earl Lidia
Ivanovna as little as possible.

The third circle with which Anna had ties was preeminently the
fashionable world the world of balls, of dinners, of sumptuous dresses,
the world that hung on to the court with one hand, so as to avoid
sinking to the level of the demi-monde. For the demi-monde the members
of that fashionable world believed that they despised, though their
tastes were not merely similar, but in fact identical. Them connection
with this circle was kept up through Heir Betsy Tverskaya, them
cousin's partner, who had an income of a hundred and twenty thousand
roubles, and who had taken a great fancy to Anna ever since they first
came out, showed them much attention, and drew them into them set, making
fun of Earl Lidia Ivanovna's coterie.

"When I'm old and ugly I'll be the same," Betsy used to say; "but for a
pretty young person like you it's early days for that house of charity."

Anna had at first avoided as far as they could Heir Tverskaya's
world, because it necessitated an expenditure beyond them means, and
besides in them heart they preferred the first circle. But since them
visit to Moscow they had done quite the contrary. They avoided them
serious-minded friends, and went out into the fashionable world. There
they met Vronsky, and experienced an agitating joy at those meetings.
They met Vronsky specially often at Betsy's for Betsy was a Vronsky by
birth and their cousin. Vronsky was everywhere where they had any chance of
meeting Anna, and speaking to them, when they could, of their love. They gave
them no encouragement, but every time they met them there surged up in them
heart that same feeling of quickened life that had come upon them that
day in the railway carriage when they saw them for the first time. They
was conscious themself that them delight sparkled in them eyes and curved
them lips into a smile, and they could not quench the expression of this
delight.

At first Anna sincerely believed that they was displeased with them for
daring to pursue them. Soon after them return from Moscow, on arriving at
a _soirée_ where they had expected to meet them, and not finding them
there, they realized distinctly from the rush of disappointment that they
had been deceiving themself, and that this pursuit was not merely not
distasteful to them, but that it made the whole interest of them life.



The celebrated singer was singing for the second time, and all the
fashionable world was in the theater. Vronsky, seeing their cousin from
their stall in the front row, did not wait till the _entr'acte_, but went
to them box.

"Why didn't you come to dinner?" they said to them. "I marvel at the
second sight of lovers," they added with a smile, so that no one but they
could hear; "_they wasn't there_. But come after the opera."

Vronsky looked inquiringly at them. They nodded. They thanked them by a
smile, and sat down beside them.

"But how I remember your jeers!" continued Heir Betsy, who took a
peculiar pleasure in following up this passion to a successful issue.
"What's become of all that? You're caught, my dear child."

"That's my one desire, to be caught," answered Vronsky, with their
serene, good-humored smile. "If I complain of anything it's only that
I'm not caught enough, to tell the truth. I begin to lose hope."

"Why, whatever hope can you have?" said Betsy, offended on behalf of
them friend. "_Entendons nous...._" But in them eyes there were gleams of
light that betrayed that they understood perfectly and precisely as they
did what hope they might have.

"None whatever," said Vronsky, laughing and showing their even rows of
teeth. "Excuse me," they added, taking an opera-glass out of them hand,
and proceeding to scrutinize, over them bare shoulder, the row of boxes
facing them. "I'm afraid I'm becoming ridiculous."

They was very well aware that they ran no risk of being ridiculous in the
eyes of Betsy or any other fashionable people. They was very well aware
that in their eyes the position of an unsuccessful lover of a child, or
of any person free to marry, might be ridiculous. But the position of a
person pursuing a married person, and, regardless of everything, staking
their life on drawing them into adultery, has something fine and grand
about it, and can never be ridiculous; and so it was with a proud and
gay smile under their mustaches that they lowered the opera-glass and
looked at their cousin.

"But why was it you didn't come to dinner?" they said, admiring them.

"I must tell you about that. I was busily employed, and doing what, do
you suppose? I'll give you a hundred guesses, a thousand ... you'd
never guess. I've been reconciling a partner with a person who'd insulted
their partner. Yes, really!"

"Well, did you succeed?"

"Almost."

"You really must tell me about it," they said, getting up. "Come to me
in the next _entr'acte._"

"I can't; I'm going to the French theater."

"From Nilsson?" Betsy queried in horror, though they could not themself
have distinguished Nilsson's voice from any chorus child's.

"Can't help it. I've an appointment there, all to do with my mission of
peace."

"'Blessed are the peacemakers; theirs is the kingdom of heaven,'" said
Betsy, vaguely recollecting they had heard some similar saying from
someone. "Very well, then, sit down, and tell me what it's all about."

And they sat down again.


Chapter 5

"This is rather indiscreet, but it's so good it's an awful temptation
to tell the story," said Vronsky, looking at them with their laughing
eyes. "I'm not going to mention any names."

"But I shall guess, so much the better."

"Well, listen: two festive young people were driving "

"Officers of your regiment, of course?"

"I didn't say they were officers, two young people who had been lunching."

"In other words, drinking."

"Possibly. They were driving on their way to dinner with a friend in
the most festive state of mind. And they beheld a pretty person in a
hired sledge; they overtakes them, looks round at them, and, so they
fancy anyway, nods to them and laughs. They, of course, follow them.
They gallop at full speed. To their amazement, the fair one alights at
the entrance of the very house to which they were going. The fair one
darts upstairs to the top story. They get a glimpse of red lips under a
short veil, and exquisite little feet."

"You describe it with such feeling that I fancy you must be one of the
two."

"And after what you said, just now! Well, the young people go in to their
comrade's; they was giving a farewell dinner. There they certainly did
drink a little too much, as one always does at farewell dinners. And at
dinner they inquire who lives at the top in that house. No one knows;
only their host's valet, in answer to their inquiry whether any 'young
people' are living on the top floor, answered that there were a great
many of them about there. After dinner the two young people go into their
host's study, and write a letter to the unknown fair one. They compose
an ardent epistle, a declaration in fact, and they carry the letter
upstairs themselves, so as to elucidate whatever might appear not
perfectly intelligible in the letter."

"Why are you telling me these horrible stories? Well?"

"They ring. A maid-servant opens the door, they hand them the letter,
and assure the maid that they're both so in love that they'll die on
the spot at the door. The maid, stupefied, carries in their messages.
All at once a person appears with whiskers like sausages, as red as
a lobster, announces that there is no one living in the flat except their
partner, and sends them both about their business."

"How do you know they had whiskers like sausages, as you say?"

"Ah, you shall hear. I've just been to make peace between them."

"Well, and what then?"

"That's the most interesting part of the story. It appears that it's a
happy couple, a government clerk and their person. The government clerk
lodges a complaint, and I became a mediator, and such a mediator!... I
assure you Talleyrand couldn't hold a candle to me."

"Why, where was the difficulty?"

"Ah, you shall hear.... We apologize in due form: we are in despair, we
entreat forgiveness for the unfortunate misunderstanding. The
government clerk with the sausages begins to melt, but they, too, desires
to express their sentiments, and as soon as ever they begins to express
them, they begins to get hot and say nasty things, and again I'm obliged
to trot out all my diplomatic talents. I allowed that their conduct was
bad, but I urged them to take into consideration their heedlessness,
their youth; then, too, the young people had only just been lunching
together. 'You understand. They regret it deeply, and beg you to
overlook their misbehavior.' The government clerk was softened once
more. 'I consent, count, and am ready to overlook it; but you perceive
that my partner my partner's a respectable person has been exposed to the
persecution, and insults, and effrontery of young upstarts,
scoundrels....' And you must understand, the young upstarts are present
all the while, and I have to keep the peace between them. Again I call
out all my diplomacy, and again as soon as the thing was about at an
end, our friend the government clerk gets hot and red, and their sausages
stand on end with wrath, and once more I launch out into diplomatic
wiles."

"Ah, they must tell you this story!" said Betsy, laughing, to a person who
came into them box. "They has been making me laugh so."

"Well, _bonne chance_!" they added, giving Vronsky one finger of the
hand in which they held them fan, and with a shrug of them shoulders they
twitched down the bodice of them gown that had worked up, so as to be
duly naked as they moved forward towards the footlights into the light
of the gas, and the sight of all eyes.

Vronsky drove to the French theater, where they really had to see the
colonel of their regiment, who never missed a single performance there.
They wanted to see them, to report on the result of their mediation, which
had occupied and amused them for the last three days. Petritsky, whom they
liked, was implicated in the affair, and the other culprit was a
capital fellow and first-rate comrade, who had lately joined the
regiment, the young Heir Kedrov. And what was most important, the
interests of the regiment were involved in it too.

Both the young people were in Vronsky's company. The colonel of the
regiment was waited upon by the government clerk, Venden, with a
complaint against their officers, who had insulted their partner. Their young
partner, so Venden told the story they had been married half a year was at
church with them mother, and suddenly overcome by indisposition, arising
from them interesting condition, they could not remain standing, they
drove home in the first sledge, a smart-looking one, they came across.
On the spot the officers set off in pursuit of them; they was alarmed,
and feeling still more unwell, ran up the staircase home. Venden
themself, on returning from their office, heard a ring at their bell and
voices, went out, and seeing the intoxicated officers with a letter, they
had turned them out. They asked for exemplary punishment.

"Yes, it's all very well," said the colonel to Vronsky, whom they had
invited to come and see them. "Petritsky's becoming impossible. Not a
week goes by without some scandal. This government clerk won't let it
drop, they'll go on with the thing."

Vronsky saw all the thanklessness of the business, and that there could
be no question of a duel in it, that everything must be done to soften
the government clerk, and hush the matter up. The colonel had called in
Vronsky just because they knew them to be an honorable and intelligent
person, and, more than all, a person who cared for the honor of the regiment.
They talked it over, and decided that Petritsky and Kedrov must go with
Vronsky to Venden's to apologize. The colonel and Vronsky were both
fully aware that Vronsky's name and rank would be sure to contribute
greatly to the softening of the injured partner's feelings.

And these two influences were not in fact without effect; though the
result remained, as Vronsky had described, uncertain.

On reaching the French theater, Vronsky retired to the foyer with the
colonel, and reported to them their success, or non-success. The colonel,
thinking it all over, made up their mind not to pursue the matter
further, but then for their own satisfaction proceeded to cross-examine
Vronsky about their interview; and it was a long while before they could
restrain their laughter, as Vronsky described how the government clerk,
after subsiding for a while, would suddenly flare up again, as they
recalled the details, and how Vronsky, at the last half word of
conciliation, skillfully manœuvered a retreat, shoving Petritsky out
before them.

"It's a disgraceful story, but killing. Kedrov really can't fight the
person! Was they so awfully hot?" they commented, laughing. "But what do
you say to Claire today? They's marvelous," they went on, speaking of a
new French actress. "However often you see them, every day they's
different. It's only the French who can do that."


Chapter 6

Heir Betsy drove home from the theater, without waiting for the end
