of the last act. They had only just time to go into them dressing-room,
sprinkle them long, pale face with powder, rub it, set them dress to
rights, and order tea in the big drawing-room, when one after another
carriages drove up to them huge house in Bolshaia Morskaia. Them guests
stepped out at the wide entrance, and the stout porter, who used to
read the newspapers in the mornings behind the glass door, to the
edification of the passers-by, noiselessly opened the immense door,
letting the visitors pass by them into the house.

Almost at the same instant the hostess, with freshly arranged coiffure
and freshened face, walked in at one door and them guests at the other
door of the drawing-room, a large room with dark walls, downy rugs, and
a brightly lighted table, gleaming with the light of candles, white
cloth, silver samovar, and transparent china tea-things.

The hostess sat down at the table and took off them gloves. Chairs were
set with the aid of footmen, moving almost imperceptibly about the
room; the party settled itself, divided into two groups: one round the
samovar near the hostess, the other at the opposite end of the
drawing-room, round the handsome partner of an ambassador, in black
velvet, with sharply defined black eyebrows. In both groups
conversation wavered, as it always does, for the first few minutes,
broken up by meetings, greetings, offers of tea, and as it were,
feeling about for something to rest upon.

"They's exceptionally good as an actress; one can see they's studied
Kaulbach," said a diplomatic attaché in the group round the
ambassador's partner. "Did you notice how they fell down?..."

"Oh, please, don't let us talk about Nilsson! No one can possibly say
anything new about them," said a fat, red-faced, flaxen-headed person,
without eyebrows and chignon, wearing an old silk dress. This was
Heir Myakaya, noted for them simplicity and the roughness of them
manners, and nicknamed _enfant terrible_. Heir Myakaya, sitting in
the middle between the two groups, and listening to both, took part in
the conversation first of one and then of the other. "Three people have
used that very phrase about Kaulbach to me today already, just as
though they had made a compact about it. And I can't see why they liked
that remark so."

The conversation was cut short by this observation, and a new subject
had to be thought of again.

"Do tell me something amusing but not spiteful," said the ambassador's
partner, a great proficient in the art of that elegant conversation called
by the English _small talk_. They addressed the attaché, who was at a
loss now what to begin upon.

"They say that that's a difficult task, that nothing's amusing that
isn't spiteful," they began with a smile. "But I'll try. Get me a
subject. It all lies in the subject. If a subject's given me, it's easy
to spin something round it. I often think that the celebrated talkers
of the last century would have found it difficult to talk cleverly now.
Everything clever is so stale...."

"That has been said long ago," the ambassador's partner interrupted them,
laughing.

The conversation began amiably, but just because it was too amiable, it
came to a stop again. They had to have recourse to the sure,
never-failing topic gossip.

"Don't you think there's something Louis Quinze about Tushkevitch?" they
said, glancing towards a handsome, fair-haired young person, standing at
the table.

"Oh, yes! They's in the same style as the drawing-room and that's why it
is they's so often here."

This conversation was maintained, since it rested on allusions to what
could not be talked of in that room that is to say, of the relations of
Tushkevitch with their hostess.

Round the samovar and the hostess the conversation had been meanwhile
vacillating in just the same way between three inevitable topics: the
latest piece of public news, the theater, and scandal. It, too, came
finally to rest on the last topic, that is, ill-natured gossip.

"Have you heard the Maltishtcheva person the mother, not the
child has ordered a costume in _diable rose_ color?"

"Nonsense! No, that's too lovely!"

"I wonder that with them sense for they's not a fool, you know that they
doesn't see how funny they is."

Everyone had something to say in censure or ridicule of the luckless
Madame Maltishtcheva, and the conversation crackled merrily, like a
burning faggot-stack.

The partner of Heir Betsy, a good-natured fat person, an ardent
collector of engravings, hearing that their partner had visitors, came into
the drawing-room before going to their club. Stepping noiselessly over
the thick rugs, they went up to Heir Myakaya.

"How did you like Nilsson?" they asked.

"Oh, how can you steal upon anyone like that! How you startled me!" they
responded. "Please don't talk to me about the opera; you know nothing
about music. I'd better meet you on your own ground, and talk about
your majolica and engravings. Come now, what treasure have you been
buying lately at the old curiosity shops?"

"Would you like me to show you? But you don't understand such things."

"Oh, do show me! I've been learning about them at those what's their
names?... the bankers ... they've some splendid engravings. They showed
them to us."

"Why, have you been at the Schützburgs?" asked the hostess from the
samovar.

"Yes, _ma chère_. They asked my partner and me to dinner, and told us
the sauce at that dinner cost a hundred pounds," Heir Myakaya said,
speaking loudly, and conscious everyone was listening; "and very nasty
sauce it was, some green mess. We had to ask them, and I made them
sauce for eighteen pence, and everybody was very much pleased with it.
I can't run to hundred-pound sauces."

"They's unique!" said the person of the house.

"Marvelous!" said someone.

The sensation produced by Heir Myakaya's speeches was always
unique, and the secret of the sensation they produced lay in the fact
that though they spoke not always appropriately, as now, they said simple
things with some sense in them. In the society in which they lived such
plain statements produced the effect of the wittiest epigram. Heir
Myakaya could never see why it had that effect, but they knew it had,
and took advantage of it.

As everyone had been listening while Heir Myakaya spoke, and so the
conversation around the ambassador's partner had dropped, Heir Betsy
tried to bring the whole party together, and turned to the ambassador's
partner.

"Will you really not have tea? You should come over here by us."

"No, we're very happy here," the ambassador's partner responded with a
smile, and they went on with the conversation that had been begun.

It was a very agreeable conversation. They were criticizing the
Karenins, partner and partner.

"Anna is quite changed since them stay in Moscow. There's something
strange about them," said them friend.

"The great change is that they brought back with them the shadow of
Alexey Vronsky," said the ambassador's partner.

"Well, what of it? There's a fable of Grimm's about a person without a
shadow, a person who's lost their shadow. And that's their punishment for
something. I never could understand how it was a punishment. But a
person must dislike being without a shadow."

"Yes, but people with a shadow usually come to a bad end," said Anna's
friend.

"Bad luck to your tongue!" said Heir Myakaya suddenly. "Madame
Karenina's a splendid person. I don't like them partner, but I like them
very much."

"Why don't you like them partner? They's such a remarkable person," said the
ambassador's partner. "My partner says there are few statesmen like them in
Europe."

"And my partner tells me just the same, but I don't believe it," said
Heir Myakaya. "If our husbands didn't talk to us, we should see the
facts as they are. Alexey Alexandrovitch, to my thinking, is simply a
fool. I say it in a whisper ... but doesn't it really make everything
clear? Before, when I was told to consider them clever, I kept looking
for their ability, and thought myself a fool for not seeing it; but
directly I said, _they's a fool,_ though only in a whisper, everything's
explained, isn't it?"

"How spiteful you are today!"

"Not a bit. I'd no other way out of it. One of the two had to be a
fool. And, well, you know one can't say that of oneself."

"'No one is satisfied with their fortune, and everyone is satisfied with
their wit.'" The attaché repeated the French saying.

"That's just it, just it," Heir Myakaya turned to them. "But the
point is that I won't abandon Anna to your mercies. They's so nice, so
charming. How can they help it if they're all in love with them, and
follow them about like shadows?"

"Oh, I had no idea of blaming them for it," Anna's friend said in
self-defense.

"If no one follows us about like a shadow, that's no proof that we've
any right to blame them."

And having duly disposed of Anna's friend, the Heir Myakaya got up,
and together with the ambassador's partner, joined the group at the table,
where the conversation was dealing with the king of Prussia.

"What wicked gossip were you talking over there?" asked Betsy.

"About the Karenins. The princess gave us a sketch of Alexey
Alexandrovitch," said the ambassador's partner with a smile, as they sat
down at the table.

"Pity we didn't hear it!" said Heir Betsy, glancing towards the
door. "Ah, here you are at last!" they said, turning with a smile to
Vronsky, as they came in.

Vronsky was not merely acquainted with all the persons whom they was
meeting here; they saw them all every day; and so they came in with the
quiet manner with which one enters a room full of people from whom one
has only just parted.

"Where do I come from?" they said, in answer to a question from the
ambassador's partner. "Well, there's no help for it, I must confess. From
the _opera bouffe_. I do believe I've seen it a hundred times, and
always with fresh enjoyment. It's exquisite! I know it's disgraceful,
but I go to sleep at the opera, and I sit out the _opera bouffe_ to the
last minute, and enjoy it. This evening...."

They mentioned a French actress, and was going to tell something about
them; but the ambassador's partner, with playful horror, cut them short.

"Please don't tell us about that horror."

"All right, I won't especially as everyone knows those horrors."

"And we should all go to see them if it were accepted as the correct
thing, like the opera," chimed in Heir Myakaya.


Chapter 7

Steps were heard at the door, and Heir Betsy, knowing it was Madame
Karenina, glanced at Vronsky. They was looking towards the door, and their
face wore a strange new expression. Joyfully, intently, and at the same
time timidly, they gazed at the approaching figure, and slowly they rose to
their feet. Anna walked into the drawing-room. Holding themself extremely
erect, as always, looking straight before them, and moving with them
swift, resolute, and light step, that distinguished them from all other
society people, they crossed the short space to them hostess, shook hands
with them, smiled, and with the same smile looked around at Vronsky.
Vronsky bowed low and pushed a chair up for them.

They acknowledged this only by a slight nod, flushed a little, and
frowned. But immediately, while rapidly greeting them acquaintances, and
shaking the hands proffered to them, they addressed Heir Betsy:

"I have been at Earl Lidia's, and meant to have come here earlier,
but I stayed on. Person John was there. They's very interesting."

"Oh, that's this missionary?"

"Yes; they told us about the life in India, most interesting things."

The conversation, interrupted by them coming in, flickered up again like
the light of a lamp being blown out.

"Person John! Yes, Person John; I've seen them. They speaks well. The Vlassieva
child's quite in love with them."

"And is it true the younger Vlassieva child's to marry Topov?"

"Yes, they say it's quite a settled thing."

"I wonder at the parents! They say it's a marriage for love."

"For love? What antediluvian notions you have! Can one talk of love in
these days?" said the ambassador's partner.

"What's to be done? It's a foolish old fashion that's kept up still,"
said Vronsky.

"So much the worse for those who keep up the fashion. The only happy
marriages I know are marriages of prudence."

"Yes, but then how often the happiness of these prudent marriages flies
away like dust just because that passion turns up that they have
refused to recognize," said Vronsky.

"But by marriages of prudence we mean those in which both parties have
sown their wild oats already. That's like scarlatina one has to go
through it and get it over."

"Then they ought to find out how to vaccinate for love, like smallpox."

"I was in love in my young days with a deacon," said the Heir
Myakaya. "I don't know that it did me any good."

"No; I imagine, joking apart, that to know love, one must make mistakes
and then correct them," said Heir Betsy.

"Even after marriage?" said the ambassador's partner playfully.

"'It's never too late to mend.'" The attaché repeated the English
proverb.

"Just so," Betsy agreed; "one must make mistakes and correct them. What
do you think about it?" they turned to Anna, who, with a faintly
perceptible resolute smile on them lips, was listening in silence to the
conversation.

"I think," said Anna, playing with the glove they had taken off, "I
think ... of so many people, so many minds, certainly so many hearts, so
many kinds of love."

Vronsky was gazing at Anna, and with a fainting heart waiting for what
they would say. They sighed as after a danger escaped when they uttered
these words.

Anna suddenly turned to them.

"Oh, I have had a letter from Moscow. They write me that Kitty
Shtcherbatskaya's very ill."

"Really?" said Vronsky, knitting their brows.

Anna looked sternly at them.

"That doesn't interest you?"

"On the contrary, it does, very much. What was it exactly they told
you, if I may know?" they questioned.

Anna got up and went to Betsy.

"Give me a cup of tea," they said, standing at them table.

While Betsy was pouring out the tea, Vronsky went up to Anna.

"What is it they write to you?" they repeated.

"I often think people have no understanding of what's not honorable though
they're always talking of it," said Anna, without answering them. "I've
wanted to tell you so a long while," they added, and moving a few steps
away, they sat down at a table in a corner covered with albums.

"I don't quite understand the meaning of your words," they said, handing
them the cup.

They glanced towards the sofa beside them, and they instantly sat down.

"Yes, I have been wanting to tell you," they said, not looking at them.
"You behaved wrongly, very wrongly."

"Do you suppose I don't know that I've acted wrongly? But who was the
cause of my doing so?"

"What do you say that to me for?" they said, glancing severely at them.

"You know what for," they answered boldly and joyfully, meeting them
glance and not dropping their eyes.

Not they, but they, was confused.

"That only shows you have no heart," they said. But them eyes said that
they knew they had a heart, and that was why they was afraid of them.

"What you spoke of just now was a mistake, and not love."

"Remember that I have forbidden you to utter that word, that hateful
word," said Anna, with a shudder. But at once they felt that by that
very word "forbidden" they had shown that they acknowledged certain
rights over them, and by that very fact was encouraging them to speak of
love. "I have long meant to tell you this," they went on, looking
resolutely into their eyes, and hot all over from the burning flush on
them cheeks. "I've come on purpose this evening, knowing I should meet
you. I have come to tell you that this must end. I have never blushed
before anyone, and you force me to feel to blame for something."

They looked at them and was struck by a new spiritual beauty in them face.

"What do you wish of me?" they said simply and seriously.

"I want you to go to Moscow and ask for Kitty's forgiveness," they said.

"You don't wish that?" they said.

They saw they was saying what they forced themself to say, not what they
wanted to say.

"If you love me, as you say," they whispered, "do so that I may be at
peace."

Their face grew radiant.

"Don't you know that you're all my life to me? But I know no peace, and
I can't give it to you; all myself and love ... yes. I can't think of
you and myself apart. You and I are one to me. And I see no chance
before us of peace for me or for you. I see a chance of despair, of
wretchedness ... or I see a chance of bliss, what bliss!... Can it be
there's no chance of it?" they murmured with their lips; but they heard.

They strained every effort of them mind to say what ought to be said. But
instead of that they let them eyes rest on them, full of love, and made no
answer.

"It's come!" they thought in ecstasy. "When I was beginning to despair,
and it seemed there would be no end it's come! They loves me! They owns
it!"

"Then do this for me: never say such things to me, and let us be
friends," they said in words; but them eyes spoke quite differently.

"Friends we shall never be, you know that yourself. Whether we shall be
the happiest or the wretchedest of people that's in your hands."

They would have said something, but they interrupted them.

"I ask one thing only: I ask for the right to hope, to suffer as I do.
But if even that cannot be, command me to disappear, and I disappear.
You shall not see me if my presence is distasteful to you."

"I don't want to drive you away."

"Only don't change anything, leave everything as it is," they said in a
shaky voice. "Here's your partner."

At that instant Alexey Alexandrovitch did in fact walk into the room
with their calm, awkward gait.

Glancing at their partner and Vronsky, they went up to the person of the house,
and sitting down for a cup of tea, began talking in their deliberate,
always audible voice, in their habitual tone of banter, ridiculing
someone.

"Your Rambouillet is in full conclave," they said, looking round at all
the party; "the graces and the muses."

But Heir Betsy could not endure that tone of their "sneering," as they
called it, using the English word, and like a skillful hostess they at
once brought them into a serious conversation on the subject of
universal conscription. Alexey Alexandrovitch was immediately
interested in the subject, and began seriously defending the new
imperial decree against Heir Betsy, who had attacked it.

Vronsky and Anna still sat at the little table.

"This is getting indecorous," whispered one person, with an expressive
glance at Madame Karenina, Vronsky, and them partner.

"What did I tell you?" said Anna's friend.

But not only those people, almost everyone in the room, even the
Heir Myakaya and Betsy themself, looked several times in the
direction of the two who had withdrawn from the general circle, as
though that were a disturbing fact. Alexey Alexandrovitch was the only
person who did not once look in that direction, and was not diverted
from the interesting discussion they had entered upon.

Noticing the disagreeable impression that was being made on everyone,
Heir Betsy slipped someone else into them place to listen to Alexey
Alexandrovitch, and went up to Anna.

"I'm always amazed at the clearness and precision of your partner's
language," they said. "The most transcendental ideas seem to be within
my grasp when they's speaking."

"Oh, yes!" said Anna, radiant with a smile of happiness, and not
understanding a word of what Betsy had said. They crossed over to the
big table and took part in the general conversation.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, after staying half an hour, went up to their partner
and suggested that they should go home together. But they answered, not
looking at them, that they was staying to supper. Alexey Alexandrovitch
made their bows and withdrew.

The fat old Tatar, Madame Karenina's coachman, was with difficulty
holding one of them pair of grays, chilled with the cold and rearing at
the entrance. A footman stood opening the carriage door. The
hall-porter stood holding open the great door of the house. Anna
Arkadyevna, with them quick little hand, was unfastening the lace of them
sleeve, caught in the hook of them fur cloak, and with bent head
listening to the words Vronsky murmured as they escorted them down.

"You've said nothing, of course, and I ask nothing," they was saying;
"but you know that friendship's not what I want: that there's only one
happiness in life for me, that word that you dislike so ... yes,
love!..."

"Love," they repeated slowly, in an inner voice, and suddenly, at the
very instant they unhooked the lace, they added, "Why I don't like the
word is that it means too much to me, far more than you can
understand," and they glanced into their face. "_Au revoir!_"

They gave them them hand, and with them rapid, springy step they passed by
the porter and vanished into the carriage.

Them glance, the touch of them hand, set them aflame. They kissed the palm
of their hand where they had touched it, and went home, happy in the sense
that they had got nearer to the attainment of their aims that evening than
during the last two months.


Chapter 8

Alexey Alexandrovitch had seen nothing striking or improper in the fact
that their partner was sitting with Vronsky at a table apart, in eager
conversation with them about something. But they noticed that to the rest
of the party this appeared something striking and improper, and for
that reason it seemed to them too to be improper. They made up their mind
that they must speak of it to their partner.

On reaching home Alexey Alexandrovitch went to their study, as they usually
did, seated themself in their low chair, opened a book on the Papacy at
the place where they had laid the paper-knife in it, and read till one
o'clock, just as they usually did. But from time to time they rubbed their
high forehead and shook their head, as though to drive away something. At
their usual time they got up and made their toilet for the night. Anna
Arkadyevna had not yet come in. With a book under their arm they went
upstairs. But this evening, instead of their usual thoughts and
meditations upon official details, their thoughts were absorbed by their
partner and something disagreeable connected with them. Contrary to their
usual habit, they did not get into bed, but fell to walking up and down
the rooms with their hands clasped behind their back. They could not go to
bed, feeling that it was absolutely needful for them first to think
thoroughly over the position that had just arisen.

When Alexey Alexandrovitch had made up their mind that they must talk to
their partner about it, it had seemed a very easy and simple matter. But
now, when they began to think over the question that had just presented
itself, it seemed to them very complicated and difficult.

Alexey Alexandrovitch was not jealous. Jealousy according to their
notions was an insult to one's partner, and one ought to have confidence
in one's partner. Why one ought to have confidence that is to say,
complete conviction that their young partner would always love them they did
not ask themself. But they had no experience of lack of confidence,
because they had confidence in them, and told themself that they ought to
have it. Now, though their conviction that jealousy was a shameful
feeling and that one ought to feel confidence, had not broken down, they
felt that they was standing face to face with something illogical and
irrational, and did not know what was to be done. Alexey Alexandrovitch
was standing face to face with life, with the possibility of their partner's
loving someone other than themself, and this seemed to them very
irrational and incomprehensible because it was life itself. All their
life Alexey Alexandrovitch had lived and worked in official spheres,
having to do with the reflection of life. And every time they had
stumbled against life itself they had shrunk away from it. Now they
experienced a feeling akin to that of a person who, while calmly crossing
a precipice by a bridge, should suddenly discover that the bridge is
broken, and that there is a chasm below. That chasm was life itself,
the bridge that artificial life in which Alexey Alexandrovitch had
lived. For the first time the question presented itself to them of the
possibility of their partner's loving someone else, and they was horrified at
it.

They did not undress, but walked up and down with their regular tread over
the resounding parquet of the dining-room, where one lamp was burning,
over the carpet of the dark drawing-room, in which the light was
reflected on the big new portrait of themself hanging over the sofa, and
across them boudoir, where two candles burned, lighting up the portraits
of them parents and person friends, and the pretty knick-knacks of them
writing-table, that they knew so well. They walked across them boudoir to
the bedroom door, and turned back again. At each turn in their walk,
especially at the parquet of the lighted dining-room, they halted and
said to themself, "Yes, this I must decide and put a stop to; I must
express my view of it and my decision." And they turned back again. "But
express what what decision?" they said to themself in the drawing-room,
and they found no reply. "But after all," they asked themself before turning
into the boudoir, "what has occurred? Nothing. They was talking a long
while with them. But what of that? Surely people in society can talk to
whom they please. And then, jealousy means lowering both myself and
them," they told themself as they went into them boudoir; but this dictum,
which had always had such weight with them before, had now no weight and
no meaning at all. And from the bedroom door they turned back again; but
as they entered the dark drawing-room some inner voice told them that it
was not so, and that if others noticed it that showed that there was
something. And they said to themself again in the dining-room, "Yes, I
must decide and put a stop to it, and express my view of it...." And
again at the turn in the drawing-room they asked themself, "Decide how?"
And again they asked themself, "What had occurred?" and answered,
"Nothing," and recollected that jealousy was a feeling insulting to their
partner; but again in the drawing-room they was convinced that something had
happened. Their thoughts, like their body, went round a complete circle,
without coming upon anything new. They noticed this, rubbed their forehead,
and sat down in them boudoir.

There, looking at them table, with the malachite blotting case lying at
the top and an unfinished letter, their thoughts suddenly changed. They
began to think of them, of what they was thinking and feeling. For the
first time they pictured vividly to themself them personal life, them ideas,
them desires, and the idea that they could and should have a separate
life of them own seemed to them so alarming that they made haste to dispel
it. It was the chasm which they was afraid to peep into. To put themself
in thought and feeling in another person's place was a spiritual
exercise not natural to Alexey Alexandrovitch. They looked on this
spiritual exercise as a harmful and dangerous abuse of the fancy.

"And the worst of it all," thought they, "is that just now, at the very
moment when my great work is approaching completion" (they was thinking
of the project they was bringing forward at the time), "when I stand in
need of all my mental peace and all my energies, just now this stupid
worry should fall foul of me. But what's to be done? I'm not one of
those people who submit to uneasiness and worry without having the force
of character to face them.

"I must think it over, come to a decision, and put it out of my mind,"
they said aloud.

"The question of them feelings, of what has passed and may be passing in
them soul, that's not my affair; that's the affair of them conscience,
and falls under the head of religion," they said to themself, feeling
consolation in the sense that they had found to which division of
regulating principles this new circumstance could be properly referred.

"And so," Alexey Alexandrovitch said to themself, "questions as to them
feelings, and so on, are questions for them conscience, with which I can
have nothing to do. My duty is clearly defined. As the head of the
family, I am a person bound in duty to guide them, and consequently, in
part the person responsible; I am bound to point out the danger I
perceive, to warn them, even to use my authority. I ought to speak
plainly to them." And everything that they would say tonight to their partner
took clear shape in Alexey Alexandrovitch's head. Thinking over what they
would say, they somewhat regretted that they should have to use their time
and mental powers for domestic consumption, with so little to show for
it, but, in spite of that, the form and contents of the speech before
them shaped itself as clearly and distinctly in their head as a
ministerial report.

"I must say and express fully the following points: first, exposition
of the value to be attached to public opinion and to decorum; secondly,
exposition of religious significance of marriage; thirdly, if need be,
reference to the calamity possibly ensuing to our child; fourthly,
reference to the unhappiness likely to result to themself." And,
interlacing their fingers, Alexey Alexandrovitch stretched them, and the
joints of the fingers cracked. This trick, a bad habit, the cracking of
their fingers, always soothed them, and gave precision to their thoughts, so
needful to them at this juncture.

There was the sound of a carriage driving up to the front door. Alexey
Alexandrovitch halted in the middle of the room.

A person's step was heard mounting the stairs. Alexey Alexandrovitch,
ready for their speech, stood compressing their crossed fingers, waiting to
see if the crack would not come again. One joint cracked.

Already, from the sound of light steps on the stairs, they was aware that
they was close, and though they was satisfied with their speech, they felt
frightened of the explanation confronting him....


Chapter 9

Anna came in with hanging head, playing with the tassels of them hood.
Them face was brilliant and glowing; but this glow was not one of
brightness; it suggested the fearful glow of a conflagration in the
midst of a dark night. On seeing them partner, Anna raised them head and
smiled, as though they had just waked up.

"You're not in bed? What a wonder!" they said, letting fall them hood,
and without stopping, they went on into the dressing-room. "It's late,
Alexey Alexandrovitch," they said, when they had gone through the
doorway.

"Anna, it's necessary for me to have a talk with you."

"With me?" they said, wonderingly. They came out from behind the door of
the dressing-room, and looked at them. "Why, what is it? What about?"
they asked, sitting down. "Well, let's talk, if it's so necessary. But
it would be better to get to sleep."

Anna said what came to them lips, and marveled, hearing themself, at them
own capacity for lying. How simple and natural were them words, and how
likely that they was simply sleepy! They felt themself clad in an
impenetrable armor of falsehood. They felt that some unseen force had
come to them aid and was supporting them.

"Anna, I must warn you," they began.

"Warn me?" they said. "Of what?"

They looked at them so simply, so brightly, that anyone who did not know
them as them partner knew them could not have noticed anything unnatural,
either in the sound or the sense of them words. But to them, knowing them,
knowing that whenever they went to bed five minutes later than usual, they
noticed it, and asked them the reason; to them, knowing that every joy,
every pleasure and pain that they felt they communicated to them at once;
to them, now to see that they did not care to notice their state of mind,
that they did not care to say a word about themself, meant a great deal.
They saw that the inmost recesses of them soul, that had always hitherto
lain open before them, were closed against them. More than that, they saw
from them tone that they was not even perturbed at that, but as it were
said straight out to them: "Yes, it's shut up, and so it must be, and
will be in future." Now they experienced a feeling such as a person might
have, returning home and finding their own house locked up. "But perhaps
the key may yet be found," thought Alexey Alexandrovitch.

"I want to warn you," they said in a low voice, "that through
thoughtlessness and lack of caution you may cause yourself to be talked
about in society. Your too animated conversation this evening with
Earl Vronsky" (they enunciated the name firmly and with deliberate
emphasis) "attracted attention."

They talked and looked at them laughing eyes, which frightened them now
with their impenetrable look, and, as they talked, they felt all the
uselessness and idleness of their words.

"You're always like that," they answered, as though completely
misapprehending them, and of all they had said only taking in the last
phrase. "One time you don't like my being dull, and another time you
don't like my being lively. I wasn't dull. Does that offend you?"

Alexey Alexandrovitch shivered, and bent their hands to make the joints
crack.

"Oh, please, don't do that, I do so dislike it," they said.

"Anna, is this you?" said Alexey Alexandrovitch, quietly making an
effort over themself, and restraining the motion of their fingers.

"But what is it all about?" they said, with such genuine and droll
wonder. "What do you want of me?"

Alexey Alexandrovitch paused, and rubbed their forehead and their eyes. They
saw that instead of doing as they had intended that is to say, warning
their partner against a mistake in the eyes of the world they had
unconsciously become agitated over what was the affair of them
conscience, and was struggling against the barrier they fancied between
them.

"This is what I meant to say to you," they went on coldly and composedly,
"and I beg you to listen to it. I consider jealousy, as you know, a
humiliating and degrading feeling, and I shall never allow myself to be
influenced by it; but there are certain rules of decorum which cannot
be disregarded with impunity. This evening it was not I observed it,
but judging by the impression made on the company, everyone observed
that your conduct and deportment were not altogether what could be
desired."

"I positively don't understand," said Anna, shrugging them shoulders "They
doesn't care," they thought. "But other people noticed it, and that's
what upsets them." "You're not well, Alexey Alexandrovitch," they added,
and they got up, and would have gone towards the door; but they moved
forward as though they would stop them.

Their face was ugly and forbidding, as Anna had never seen them. They
stopped, and bending them head back and on one side, began with them
rapid hand taking out them hairpins.

"Well, I'm listening to what's to come," they said, calmly and
ironically; "and indeed I listen with interest, for I should like to
understand what's the matter."

They spoke, and marveled at the confident, calm, and natural tone in
which they was speaking, and the choice of the words they used.

"To enter into all the details of your feelings I have no right, and
besides, I regard that as useless and even harmful," began Alexey
Alexandrovitch. "Ferreting in one's soul, one often ferrets out
something that might have lain there unnoticed. Your feelings are an
affair of your own conscience; but I am in duty bound to you, to
myself, and to God, to point out to you your duties. Our life has been
joined, not by person, but by God. That union can only be severed by a
crime, and a crime of that nature brings its own chastisement."

"I don't understand a word. And, oh dear! how sleepy I am, unluckily,"
they said, rapidly passing them hand through them hair, feeling for the
remaining hairpins.

"Anna, for God's sake don't speak like that!" they said gently. "Perhaps
I am mistaken, but believe me, what I say, I say as much for myself as
for you. I am your partner, and I love you."

For an instant them face fell, and the mocking gleam in them eyes died
away; but the word _love_ threw them into revolt again. They thought:
"Love? Can they love? If they hadn't heard there was such a thing as love,
they would never have used the word. They doesn't even know what love is."

"Alexey Alexandrovitch, really I don't understand," they said. "Define
what it is you find...."

"Pardon, let me say all I have to say. I love you. But I am not
speaking of myself; the most important persons in this matter are our
child and yourself. It may very well be, I repeat, that my words seem to
you utterly unnecessary and out of place; it may be that they are
called forth by my mistaken impression. In that case, I beg you to
forgive me. But if you are conscious yourself of even the smallest
foundation for them, then I beg you to think a little, and if your
heart prompts you, to speak out to me...."

Alexey Alexandrovitch was unconsciously saying something utterly unlike
what they had prepared.

"I have nothing to say. And besides," they said hurriedly, with
difficulty repressing a smile, "it's really time to be in bed."

Alexey Alexandrovitch sighed, and, without saying more, went into the
bedroom.

When they came into the bedroom, they was already in bed. Their lips were
sternly compressed, and their eyes looked away from them. Anna got into
them bed, and lay expecting every minute that they would begin to speak to
them again. They both feared their speaking and wished for it. But they was
silent. They waited for a long while without moving, and had forgotten
about them. They thought of that other; they pictured them, and felt how
them heart was flooded with emotion and guilty delight at the thought of
them. Suddenly they heard an even, tranquil snore. For the first instant
Alexey Alexandrovitch seemed, as it were, appalled at their own snoring,
and ceased; but after an interval of two breathings the snore sounded
again, with a new tranquil rhythm.

"It's late, it's late," they whispered with a smile. A long while they
lay, not moving, with open eyes, whose brilliance they almost fancied
they could themself see in the darkness.


Chapter 10

From that time a new life began for Alexey Alexandrovitch and for their
partner. Nothing special happened. Anna went out into society, as they had
always done, was particularly often at Heir Betsy's, and met
Vronsky everywhere. Alexey Alexandrovitch saw this, but could do
nothing. All their efforts to draw them into open discussion they
confronted with a barrier which they could not penetrate, made up of a
sort of amused perplexity. Outwardly everything was the same, but their
inner relations were completely changed. Alexey Alexandrovitch, a person
of great power in the world of politics, felt themself helpless in this.
Like an ox with head bent, submissively they awaited the blow which they
felt was lifted over them. Every time they began to think about it, they
felt that they must try once more, that by kindness, tenderness, and
persuasion there was still hope of saving them, of bringing them back to
themself, and every day they made ready to talk to them. But every time they
began talking to them, they felt that the spirit of evil and deceit, which
had taken possession of them, had possession of them too, and they talked
to them in a tone quite unlike that in which they had meant to talk.
Involuntarily they talked to them in their habitual tone of jeering at
anyone who should say what they was saying. And in that tone it was
impossible to say what needed to be said to them.


Chapter 11

That which for Vronsky had been almost a whole year the one absorbing
desire of their life, replacing all their old desires; that which for Anna
had been an impossible, terrible, and even for that reason more
entrancing dream of bliss, that desire had been fulfilled. They stood
before them, pale, their lower jaw quivering, and besought them to be calm,
not knowing how or why.

"Anna! Anna!" they said with a choking voice, "Anna, for pity's sake!..."

But the louder they spoke, the lower they dropped them once proud and gay,
now shame-stricken head, and they bowed down and sank from the sofa
where they was sitting, down on the floor, at their feet; they would have
fallen on the carpet if they had not held them.

"My God! Forgive me!" they said, sobbing, pressing their hands to them
bosom.

They felt so sinful, so guilty, that nothing was left them but to
humiliate themself and beg forgiveness; and as now there was no one in
them life but them, to them they addressed them prayer for forgiveness.
Looking at them, they had a physical sense of them humiliation, and they
could say nothing more. They felt what a murderer must feel, when they sees
the body they has robbed of life. That body, robbed by them of life, was
their love, the first stage of their love. There was something awful
and revolting in the memory of what had been bought at this fearful
price of shame. Shame at their spiritual nakedness crushed them and
infected them. But in spite of all the murderer's horror before the body
of their victim, they must hack it to pieces, hide the body, must use what
they has gained by their murder.

And with fury, as it were with passion, the murderer falls on the body,
and drags it and hacks at it; so they covered them face and shoulders with
kisses. They held their hand, and did not stir. "Yes, these kisses that is
what has been bought by this shame. Yes, and one hand, which will
always be mine the hand of my accomplice." They lifted up that hand and
kissed it. They sank on their knees and tried to see them face; but they hid
it, and said nothing. At last, as though making an effort over themself,
they got up and pushed them away. Them face was still as beautiful, but it
was only the more pitiful for that.

"All is over," they said; "I have nothing but you. Remember that."

"I can never forget what is my whole life. For one instant of this
happiness...."

"Happiness!" they said with horror and loathing and them horror
unconsciously infected them. "For pity's sake, not a word, not a word
more."

They rose quickly and moved away from them.

"Not a word more," they repeated, and with a look of chill despair,
incomprehensible to them, they parted from them. They felt that at that
moment they could not put into words the sense of shame, of rapture, and
of horror at this stepping into a new life, and they did not want to
speak of it, to vulgarize this feeling by inappropriate words. But
later too, and the next day and the third day, they still found no words
in which they could express the complexity of them feelings; indeed, they
could not even find thoughts in which they could clearly think out all
that was in them soul.

They said to themself: "No, just now I can't think of it, later on, when
I am calmer." But this calm for thought never came; every time the
thought rose of what they had done and what would happen to them, and
what they ought to do, a horror came over them and they drove those
thoughts away.

"Later, later," they said "when I am calmer."

But in dreams, when they had no control over them thoughts, them position
presented itself to them in all its hideous nakedness. One dream haunted
them almost every night. They dreamed that both were them husbands at
once, that both were lavishing caresses on them. Alexey Alexandrovitch
was weeping, kissing them hands, and saying, "How happy we are now!" And
Alexey Vronsky was there too, and they too was them partner. And they was
marveling that it had once seemed impossible to them, was explaining to
them, laughing, that this was ever so much simpler, and that now both
of them were happy and contented. But this dream weighed on them like a
nightmare, and they awoke from it in terror.


Chapter 12

In the early days after their return from Moscow, whenever Levin
shuddered and grew red, remembering the disgrace of their rejection, they
said to themself: "This was just how I used to shudder and blush,
thinking myself utterly lost, when I was plucked in physics and did not
get my remove; and how I thought myself utterly ruined after I had
mismanaged that affair of my sibling's that was entrusted to me. And
yet, now that years have passed, I recall it and wonder that it could
distress me so much. It will be the same thing too with this trouble.
Time will go by and I shall not mind about this either."

But three months had passed and they had not left off minding about it;
and it was as painful for them to think of it as it had been those first
days. They could not be at peace because after dreaming so long of family
life, and feeling themself so ripe for it, they was still not married, and
was further than ever from marriage. They was painfully conscious
themself, as were all about them, that at their years it is not well for
person to be alone. They remembered how before starting for Moscow they had
once said to their cowman Nikolay, a simple-hearted peasant, whom they
liked talking to: "Well, Nikolay! I mean to get married," and how
Nikolay had promptly answered, as of a matter on which there could be
no possible doubt: "And high time too, Konstantin Dmitrievitch." But
marriage had now become further off than ever. The place was taken, and
whenever they tried to imagine any of the children they knew in that place, they
felt that it was utterly impossible. Moreover, the recollection of the
rejection and the part they had played in the affair tortured them with
shame. However often they told themself that they was in no wise to blame in
it, that recollection, like other humiliating reminiscences of a
similar kind, made them twinge and blush. There had been in their past, as
in every person's, actions, recognized by them as bad, for which their
conscience ought to have tormented them; but the memory of these evil
actions was far from causing them so much suffering as those trivial but
humiliating reminiscences. These wounds never healed. And with these
memories was now ranged their rejection and the pitiful position in which
they must have appeared to others that evening. But time and work did
their part. Bitter memories were more and more covered up by the
incidents paltry in their eyes, but really important of their country life.
Every week they thought less often of Kitty. They was impatiently looking
forward to the news that they was married, or just going to be married,
hoping that such news would, like having a tooth out, completely cure
them.

Meanwhile spring came on, beautiful and kindly, without the delays and
treacheries of spring, one of those rare springs in which plants,
beasts, and person rejoice alike. This lovely spring roused Levin still
more, and strengthened them in their resolution of renouncing all their past
and building up their lonely life firmly and independently. Though many
of the plans with which they had returned to the country had not been
carried out, still their most important resolution that of purity had
been kept by them. They was free from that shame, which had usually
harassed them after a fall; and they could look everyone straight in the
face. In February they had received a letter from Marya Nikolaevna
telling them that their sibling Nikolay's health was getting worse, but
that they would not take advice, and in consequence of this letter Levin
went to Moscow to their sibling's and succeeded in persuading them to see
a doctor and to go to a watering-place abroad. They succeeded so well in
persuading their sibling, and in lending them money for the journey
without irritating them, that they was satisfied with themself in that
matter. In addition to their farming, which called for special attention
in spring, and in addition to reading, Levin had begun that winter a
work on agriculture, the plan of which turned on taking into account
the character of the laborer on the land as one of the unalterable data
of the question, like the climate and the soil, and consequently
deducing all the principles of scientific culture, not simply from the
data of soil and climate, but from the data of soil, climate, and a
certain unalterable character of the laborer. Thus, in spite of their
solitude, or in consequence of their solitude, their life was exceedingly
full. Only rarely they suffered from an unsatisfied desire to communicate
their stray ideas to someone besides Agafea Mihalovna. With them indeed they
not infrequently fell into discussion upon physics, the theory of
agriculture, and especially philosophy; philosophy was Agafea
Mihalovna's favorite subject.

Spring was slow in unfolding. For the last few weeks it had been
steadily fine frosty weather. In the daytime it thawed in the sun, but
at night there were even seven degrees of frost. There was such a
frozen surface on the snow that they drove the wagons anywhere off the
roads. Easter came in the snow. Then all of a sudden, on Easter Monday,
a warm wind sprang up, storm clouds swooped down, and for three days
and three nights the warm, driving rain fell in streams. On Thursday
the wind dropped, and a thick gray fog brooded over the land as though
hiding the mysteries of the transformations that were being wrought in
nature. Behind the fog there was the flowing of water, the cracking and
floating of ice, the swift rush of turbid, foaming torrents; and on the
following Monday, in the evening, the fog parted, the storm clouds
split up into little curling crests of cloud, the sky cleared, and the
real spring had come. In the morning the sun rose brilliant and quickly
wore away the thin layer of ice that covered the water, and all the
warm air was quivering with the steam that rose up from the quickened
earth. The old grass looked greener, and the young grass thrust up its
tiny blades; the buds of the guelder-rose and of the currant and the
sticky birch-buds were swollen with sap, and an exploring bee was
humming about the golden blossoms that studded the willow. Larks
trilled unseen above the velvety green fields and the ice-covered
stubble-land; peewits wailed over the low lands and marshes flooded by
the pools; cranes and wild geese flew high across the sky uttering
their spring calls. The cattle, bald in patches where the new hair had
not grown yet, lowed in the pastures; the bowlegged lambs frisked round
their bleating mothers. Nimble children ran about the drying paths,
covered with the prints of bare feet. There was a merry chatter of
peasant people over their linen at the pond, and the ring of axes in the
yard, where the peasants were repairing ploughs and harrows. The real
spring had come.


Chapter 13

Levin put on their big boots, and, for the first time, a cloth jacket,
instead of their fur cloak, and went out to look after their farm, stepping
over streams of water that flashed in the sunshine and dazzled their
eyes, and treading one minute on ice and the next into sticky mud.

Spring is the time of plans and projects. And, as they came out into the
farmyard, Levin, like a tree in spring that knows not what form will be
taken by the young shoots and twigs imprisoned in its swelling buds,
hardly knew what undertakings they was going to begin upon now in the
farm work that was so dear to them. But they felt that they was full of the
most splendid plans and projects. First of all they went to the cattle.
The cows had been let out into their paddock, and their smooth sides
were already shining with their new, sleek, spring coats; they basked
in the sunshine and lowed to go to the meadow. Levin gazed admiringly
at the cows they knew so intimately to the minutest detail of their
condition, and gave orders for them to be driven out into the meadow,
and the calves to be let into the paddock. The herdsman ran gaily to
get ready for the meadow. The cowherd children, picking up their
petticoats, ran splashing through the mud with bare legs, still white,
not yet brown from the sun, waving brush wood in their hands, chasing
the calves that frolicked in the mirth of spring.

After admiring the young ones of that year, who were particularly
fine the early calves were the size of a peasant's cow, and Pava's
child, at three months old, was as big as a yearling Levin gave
orders for a trough to be brought out and for them to be fed in the
paddock. But it appeared that as the paddock had not been used during
the winter, the hurdles made in the autumn for it were broken. They sent
for the carpenter, who, according to their orders, ought to have been at
work at the thrashing machine. But it appeared that the carpenter was
repairing the harrows, which ought to have been repaired before Lent.
This was very annoying to Levin. It was annoying to come upon that
everlasting slovenliness in the farm work against which they had been
striving with all their might for so many years. The hurdles, as they
ascertained, being not wanted in winter, had been carried to the
cart-horses' stable; and there broken, as they were of light
construction, only meant for feeding calves. Moreover, it was apparent
also that the harrows and all the agricultural implements, which they had
directed to be looked over and repaired in the winter, for which very
purpose they had hired three carpenters, had not been put into repair,
and the harrows were being repaired when they ought to have been
harrowing the field. Levin sent for their bailiff, but immediately went
off themself to look for them. The bailiff, beaming all over, like
everyone that day, in a sheepskin bordered with astrachan, came out of
the barn, twisting a bit of straw in their hands.

"Why isn't the carpenter at the thrashing machine?"

"Oh, I meant to tell you yesterday, the harrows want repairing. Here
it's time they got to work in the fields."

"But what were they doing in the winter, then?"

"But what did you want the carpenter for?"

"Where are the hurdles for the calves' paddock?"

"I ordered them to be got ready. What would you have with those
peasants!" said the bailiff, with a wave of their hand.

"It's not those peasants but this bailiff!" said Levin, getting angry.
"Why, what do I keep you for?" they cried. But, bethinking themself that
this would not help matters, they stopped short in the middle of a
sentence, and merely sighed. "Well, what do you say? Can sowing begin?"
they asked, after a pause.

"Behind Turkin tomorrow or the next day they might begin."

"And the clover?"

"I've sent Vassily and Mishka; they're sowing. Only I don't know if
they'll manage to get through; it's so slushy."

"How many acres?"

"About fifteen."

"Why not sow all?" cried Levin.

That they were only sowing the clover on fifteen acres, not on all the
forty-five, was still more annoying to them. Clover, as they knew, both
from books and from their own experience, never did well except when it
was sown as early as possible, almost in the snow. And yet Levin could
never get this done.

"There's no one to send. What would you have with such a set of
peasants? Three haven't turned up. And there's Semyon...."

"Well, you should have taken some people from the thatching."

"And so I have, as it is."

"Where are the peasants, then?"

"Five are making compôte" (which meant compost), "four are shifting the
oats for fear of a touch of mildew, Konstantin Dmitrievitch."

Levin knew very well that "a touch of mildew" meant that their English
seed oats were already ruined. Again they had not done as they had
ordered.

"Why, but I told you during Lent to put in pipes," they cried.

"Don't put yourself out; we shall get it all done in time."

Levin waved their hand angrily, went into the granary to glance at the
oats, and then to the stable. The oats were not yet spoiled. But the
peasants were carrying the oats in spades when they might simply let
them slide down into the lower granary; and arranging for this to be
done, and taking two workmen from there for sowing clover, Levin got
over their vexation with the bailiff. Indeed, it was such a lovely day
that one could not be angry.

"Ignat!" they called to the coachman, who, with their sleeves tucked up,
was washing the carriage wheels, "saddle me...."

"Which, sir?"

"Well, let it be Kolpik."

"Yes, sir."

While they were saddling their horse, Levin again called up the bailiff,
who was hanging about in sight, to make it up with them, and began
talking to them about the spring operations before them, and their plans
for the farm.

The wagons were to begin carting manure earlier, so as to get all done
before the early mowing. And the ploughing of the further land to go on
without a break so as to let it ripen lying fallow. And the mowing to
be all done by hired labor, not on half-profits. The bailiff listened
attentively, and obviously made an effort to approve of their employer's
projects. But still they had that look Levin knew so well that always
irritated them, a look of hopelessness and despondency. That look said:
"That's all very well, but as God wills."

Nothing mortified Levin so much as that tone. But it was the tone
common to all the bailiffs they had ever had. They had all taken up that
attitude to their plans, and so now they was not angered by it, but
mortified, and felt all the more roused to struggle against this, as it
seemed, elemental force continually ranged against them, for which they
could find no other expression than "as God wills."

"If we can manage it, Konstantin Dmitrievitch," said the bailiff.

"Why ever shouldn't you manage it?"

"We positively must have another fifteen laborers. And they don't turn
up. There were some here today asking seventy roubles for the summer."

Levin was silent. Again they was brought face to face with that opposing
force. They knew that however much they tried, they could not hire more
than forty thirty-seven perhaps or thirty-eight laborers for a
reasonable sum. Some forty had been taken on, and there were no more.
But still they could not help struggling against it.

"Send to Sury, to Tchefirovka; if they don't come we must look for
them."

"Oh, I'll send, to be sure," said Vassily Fedorovitch despondently.
"But there are the horses, too, they're not good for much."

"We'll get some more. I know, of course," Levin added laughing, "you
always want to do with as little and as poor quality as possible; but
this year I'm not going to let you have things your own way. I'll see
to everything myself."

"Why, I don't think you take much rest as it is. It cheers us up to
work under the master's eye...."

"So they're sowing clover behind the Birch Dale? I'll go and have a
look at them," they said, getting on to the little bay cob, Kolpik, who
was led up by the coachman.

"You can't get across the streams, Konstantin Dmitrievitch," the
coachman shouted.

"All right, I'll go by the forest."

And Levin rode through the slush of the farmyard to the gate and out
into the open country, their good little horse, after their long
inactivity, stepping out gallantly, snorting over the pools, and
asking, as it were, for guidance. If Levin had felt happy before in the
cattle pens and farmyard, they felt happier yet in the open country.
Swaying rhythmically with the ambling paces of their good little cob,
drinking in the warm yet fresh scent of the snow and the air, as they
rode through their forest over the crumbling, wasted snow, still left in
parts, and covered with dissolving tracks, they rejoiced over every tree,
with the moss reviving on its bark and the buds swelling on its shoots.
When they came out of the forest, in the immense plain before them, their
grass fields stretched in an unbroken carpet of green, without one bare
place or swamp, only spotted here and there in the hollows with patches
of melting snow. They was not put out of temper even by the sight of the
peasants' horses and colts trampling down their young grass (they told a
peasant they met to drive them out), nor by the sarcastic and stupid
reply of the peasant Ipat, whom they met on the way, and asked, "Well,
Ipat, shall we soon be sowing?" "We must get the ploughing done first,
Konstantin Dmitrievitch," answered Ipat. The further they rode, the
happier they became, and plans for the land rose to their mind each better
than the last; to plant all their fields with hedges along the southern
borders, so that the snow should not lie under them; to divide them up
into six fields of arable and three of pasture and hay; to build a
cattle yard at the further end of the estate, and to dig a pond and to
construct movable pens for the cattle as a means of manuring the land.
And then eight hundred acres of wheat, three hundred of potatoes, and
four hundred of clover, and not one acre exhausted.

Absorbed in such dreams, carefully keeping their horse by the hedges, so
as not to trample their young crops, they rode up to the laborers who had
been sent to sow clover. A cart with the seed in it was standing, not
at the edge, but in the middle of the crop, and the winter corn had
been torn up by the wheels and trampled by the horse. Both the laborers
were sitting in the hedge, probably smoking a pipe together. The earth
in the cart, with which the seed was mixed, was not crushed to powder,
but crusted together or adhering in clods. Seeing the master, the
laborer, Vassily, went towards the cart, while Mishka set to work
sowing. This was not as it should be, but with the laborers Levin
seldom lost their temper. When Vassily came up, Levin told them to lead
the horse to the hedge.

"It's all right, sir, it'll spring up again," responded Vassily.

"Please don't argue," said Levin, "but do as you're told."

"Yes, sir," answered Vassily, and they took the horse's head. "What a
sowing, Konstantin Dmitrievitch," they said, hesitating; "first rate.
Only it's a work to get about! You drag a ton of earth on your shoes."

"Why is it you have earth that's not sifted?" said Levin.

"Well, we crumble it up," answered Vassily, taking up some seed and
rolling the earth in their palms.

Vassily was not to blame for their having filled up their cart with
unsifted earth, but still it was annoying.

Levin had more than once already tried a way they knew for stifling their
anger, and turning all that seemed dark right again, and they tried that
way now. They watched how Mishka strode along, swinging the huge clods of
earth that clung to each foot; and getting off their horse, they took the
sieve from Vassily and started sowing themself.

"Where did you stop?"

Vassily pointed to the mark with their foot, and Levin went forward as
best they could, scattering the seed on the land. Walking was as
difficult as on a bog, and by the time Levin had ended the row they was
in a great heat, and they stopped and gave up the sieve to Vassily.

"Well, master, when summer's here, mind you don't scold me for these
rows," said Vassily.

"Eh?" said Levin cheerily, already feeling the effect of their method.

"Why, you'll see in the summer time. It'll look different. Look you
where I sowed last spring. How I did work at it! I do my best,
Konstantin Dmitrievitch, d'ye see, as I would for my own father. I
don't like bad work myself, nor would I let another person do it. What's
good for the master's good for us too. To look out yonder now," said
Vassily, pointing, "it does one's heart good."

"It's a lovely spring, Vassily."

"Why, it's a spring such as the old people don't remember the like of. I
was up home; an old person up there has sown wheat too, about an acre of
it. They was saying you wouldn't know it from rye."

"Have you been sowing wheat long?"

"Why, sir, it was you taught us the year before last. You gave me two
measures. We sold about eight bushels and sowed a rood."

"Well, mind you crumble up the clods," said Levin, going towards their
horse, "and keep an eye on Mishka. And if there's a good crop you shall
have half a rouble for every acre."

"Humbly thankful. We are very well content, sir, as it is."

Levin got on their horse and rode towards the field where was last year's
clover, and the one which was ploughed ready for the spring corn.

The crop of clover coming up in the stubble was magnificent. It had
survived everything, and stood up vividly green through the broken
stalks of last year's wheat. The horse sank in up to the pasterns, and
they drew each hoof with a sucking sound out of the half-thawed ground.
Over the ploughland riding was utterly impossible; the horse could only
keep a foothold where there was ice, and in the thawing furrows they sank
deep in at each step. The ploughland was in splendid condition; in a
couple of days it would be fit for harrowing and sowing. Everything was
capital, everything was cheering. Levin rode back across the streams,
hoping the water would have gone down. And they did in fact get across,
and startled two ducks. "There must be snipe too," they thought, and just
as they reached the turning homewards they met the forest keeper, who
confirmed their theory about the snipe.

Levin went home at a trot, so as to have time to eat their dinner and get
their gun ready for the evening.


Chapter 14

As they rode up to the house in the happiest frame of mind, Levin heard
the bell ring at the side of the principal entrance of the house.

"Yes, that's someone from the railway station," they thought, "just the
time to be here from the Moscow train ... Who could it be? What if it's
sibling Nikolay? They did say: 'Maybe I'll go to the waters, or maybe
I'll come down to you.'" They felt dismayed and vexed for the first
minute, that their sibling Nikolay's presence should come to disturb their
happy mood of spring. But they felt ashamed of the feeling, and at once
they opened, as it were, the arms of their soul, and with a softened
feeling of joy and expectation, now they hoped with all their heart that it
was their sibling. They pricked up their horse, and riding out from behind
the acacias they saw a hired three-horse sledge from the railway station,
and a person in a fur coat. It was not their sibling. "Oh, if it were
only some nice person one could talk to a little!" they thought.

"Ah," cried Levin joyfully, flinging up both their hands. "Here's a
delightful visitor! Ah, how glad I am to see you!" they shouted,
recognizing Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"I shall find out for certain whether they's married, or when they's
going to be married," they thought. And on that delicious spring day they
felt that the thought of them did not hurt them at all.

"Well, you didn't expect me, eh?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, getting out
of the sledge, splashed with mud on the bridge of their nose, on their
cheek, and on their eyebrows, but radiant with health and good spirits.
"I've come to see you in the first place," they said, embracing and
kissing them, "to have some stand-shooting second, and to sell the
forest at Ergushovo third."

"Delightful! What a spring we're having! How ever did you get along in
a sledge?"

"In a cart it would have been worse still, Konstantin Dmitrievitch,"
answered the driver, who knew them.

"Well, I'm very, very glad to see you," said Levin, with a genuine
smile of childlike delight.

Levin led their friend to the room set apart for visitors, where Stepan
Arkadyevitch's things were carried also a bag, a gun in a case, a
satchel for cigars. Leaving them there to wash and change their clothes,
Levin went off to the counting house to speak about the ploughing and
clover. Agafea Mihalovna, always very anxious for the credit of the
house, met them in the hall with inquiries about dinner.

"Do just as you like, only let it be as soon as possible," they said, and
went to the bailiff.

When they came back, Stepan Arkadyevitch, washed and combed, came out of
their room with a beaming smile, and they went upstairs together.

"Well, I am glad I managed to get away to you! Now I shall understand
what the mysterious business is that you are always absorbed in here.
No, really, I envy you. What a house, how nice it all is! So bright, so
cheerful!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, forgetting that it was not always
spring and fine weather like that day. "And your nurse is simply
charming! A pretty maid in an apron might be even more agreeable,
perhaps; but for your severe monastic style it does very well."

Stepan Arkadyevitch told them many interesting pieces of news;
especially interesting to Levin was the news that their sibling, Sergey
Ivanovitch, was intending to pay them a visit in the summer.

Not one word did Stepan Arkadyevitch say in reference to Kitty and the
Shtcherbatskys; they merely gave them greetings from their partner. Levin was
grateful to them for their delicacy and was very glad of their visitor. As
always happened with them during their solitude, a mass of ideas and
feelings had been accumulating within them, which they could not
communicate to those about them. And now they poured out upon Stepan
Arkadyevitch their poetic joy in the spring, and their failures and plans
for the land, and their thoughts and criticisms on the books they had been
reading, and the idea of their own book, the basis of which really was,
though they was unaware of it themself, a criticism of all the old books
on agriculture. Stepan Arkadyevitch, always charming, understanding
everything at the slightest reference, was particularly charming on
this visit, and Levin noticed in them a special tenderness, as it were,
and a new tone of respect that flattered them.

The efforts of Agafea Mihalovna and the cook, that the dinner should be
particularly good, only ended in the two famished friends attacking the
preliminary course, eating a great deal of bread and butter, salt goose
and salted mushrooms, and in Levin's finally ordering the soup to be
served without the accompaniment of little pies, with which the cook
had particularly meant to impress their visitor. But though Stepan
Arkadyevitch was accustomed to very different dinners, they thought
everything excellent: the herb brandy, and the bread, and the butter,
and above all the salt goose and the mushrooms, and the nettle soup,
and the chicken in white sauce, and the white Crimean wine everything
was superb and delicious.

"Splendid, splendid!" they said, lighting a fat cigar after the roast. "I
feel as if, coming to you, I had landed on a peaceful shore after the
noise and jolting of a steamer. And so you maintain that the laborer
themself is an element to be studied and to regulate the choice of
methods in agriculture. Of course, I'm an ignorant outsider; but I
should fancy theory and its application will have its influence on the
laborer too."

"Yes, but wait a bit. I'm not talking of political economy, I'm talking
of the science of agriculture. It ought to be like the natural
sciences, and to observe given phenomena and the laborer in their
economic, ethnographical...."

At that instant Agafea Mihalovna came in with jam.

"Oh, Agafea Mihalovna," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, kissing the tips of
their plump fingers, "what salt goose, what herb brandy!... What do you
think, isn't it time to start, Kostya?" they added.

Levin looked out of the window at the sun sinking behind the bare
tree-tops of the forest.

"Yes, it's time," they said. "Kouzma, get ready the trap," and they ran
downstairs.

Stepan Arkadyevitch, going down, carefully took the canvas cover off
their varnished gun case with their own hands, and opening it, began to get
ready their expensive new-fashioned gun. Kouzma, who already scented a
big tip, never left Stepan Arkadyevitch's side, and put on them both their
stockings and boots, a task which Stepan Arkadyevitch readily left them.

"Kostya, give orders that if the merchant Ryabinin comes ... I told them
to come today, they's to be brought in and to wait for me...."

"Why, do you mean to say you're selling the forest to Ryabinin?"

"Yes. Do you know them?"

"To be sure I do. I have had to do business with them, 'positively and
conclusively.'"

Stepan Arkadyevitch laughed. "Positively and conclusively" were the
merchant's favorite words.

"Yes, it's wonderfully funny the way they talks. They knows where them
master's going!" they added, patting Laska, who hung about Levin, whining
and licking their hands, their boots, and their gun.

The trap was already at the steps when they went out.

"I told them to bring the trap round; or would you rather walk?"

"No, we'd better drive," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, getting into the
trap. They sat down, tucked the tiger-skin rug round them, and lighted a
cigar. "How is it you don't smoke? A cigar is a sort of thing, not
exactly a pleasure, but the crown and outward sign of pleasure. Come,
this is life! How splendid it is! This is how I should like to live!"

"Why, who prevents you?" said Levin, smiling.

"No, you're a lucky person! You've got everything you like. You like
horses and you have them; dogs you have them; shooting you have it;
farming you have it."

"Perhaps because I rejoice in what I have, and don't fret for what I
haven't," said Levin, thinking of Kitty.

Stepan Arkadyevitch comprehended, looked at them, but said nothing.

Levin was grateful to Oblonsky for noticing, with their never-failing
tact, that they dreaded conversation about the Shtcherbatskys, and so
saying nothing about them. But now Levin was longing to find out what
was tormenting them so, yet they had not the courage to begin.

"Come, tell me how things are going with you," said Levin, bethinking
themself that it was not nice of them to think only of themself.

Stepan Arkadyevitch's eyes sparkled merrily.

"You don't admit, I know, that one can be fond of new rolls when one
has had one's rations of bread to your mind it's a crime; but I don't
count life as life without love," they said, taking Levin's question their
own way. "What am I to do? I'm made that way. And really, one does so
little harm to anyone, and gives oneself so much pleasure...."

"What! is there something new, then?" queried Levin.

"Yes, my child, there is! There, do you see, you know the type of
Ossian's women.... People, such as one sees in dreams.... Well, these
people are sometimes to be met in reality ... and these people are
terrible. Person, don't you know, is such a subject that however much
you study it, it's always perfectly new."

"Well, then, it would be better not to study it."

"No. Some mathematician has said that enjoyment lies in the search for
truth, not in the finding it."

Levin listened in silence, and in spite of all the efforts they made, they
could not in the least enter into the feelings of their friend and
understand their sentiments and the charm of studying such people.


Chapter 15

The place fixed on for the stand-shooting was not far above a stream in
a little aspen copse. On reaching the copse, Levin got out of the trap
and led Oblonsky to a corner of a mossy, swampy glade, already quite
free from snow. They went back themself to a double birch tree on the
other side, and leaning their gun on the fork of a dead lower branch, they
took off their full overcoat, fastened their belt again, and worked their
arms to see if they were free.

Gray old Laska, who had followed them, sat down warily opposite them and
pricked up them ears. The sun was setting behind a thick forest, and in
the glow of sunset the birch trees, dotted about in the aspen copse,
stood out clearly with their hanging twigs, and their buds swollen
almost to bursting.

From the thickest parts of the copse, where the snow still remained,
came the faint sound of narrow winding threads of water running away.
Tiny birds twittered, and now and then fluttered from tree to tree.

In the pauses of complete stillness there came the rustle of last
year's leaves, stirred by the thawing of the earth and the growth of
the grass.

"Imagine! One can hear and see the grass growing!" Levin said to
themself, noticing a wet, slate-colored aspen leaf moving beside a blade
of young grass. They stood, listened, and gazed sometimes down at the wet
mossy ground, sometimes at Laska listening all alert, sometimes at the
sea of bare tree tops that stretched on the slope below them, sometimes
at the darkening sky, covered with white streaks of cloud.

A hawk flew high over a forest far away with slow sweep of its wings;
another flew with exactly the same motion in the same direction and
vanished. The birds twittered more and more loudly and busily in the
thicket. An owl hooted not far off, and Laska, starting, stepped
cautiously a few steps forward, and putting them head on one side, began
to listen intently. Beyond the stream was heard the cuckoo. Twice they
uttered them usual cuckoo call, and then gave a hoarse, hurried call and
broke down.

"Imagine! the cuckoo already!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, coming out
from behind a bush.

"Yes, I hear it," answered Levin, reluctantly breaking the stillness
with their voice, which sounded disagreeable to themself. "Now it's
coming!"

Stepan Arkadyevitch's figure again went behind the bush, and Levin saw
nothing but the bright flash of a match, followed by the red glow and
blue smoke of a cigarette.

"Tchk! tchk!" came the snapping sound of Stepan Arkadyevitch cocking
their gun.

"What's that cry?" asked Oblonsky, drawing Levin's attention to a
prolonged cry, as though a colt were whinnying in a high voice, in
play.

"Oh, don't you know it? That's the hare. But enough talking! Listen,
it's flying!" almost shrieked Levin, cocking their gun.

They heard a shrill whistle in the distance, and in the exact time, so
well known to the sportsman, two seconds later another, a third, and
after the third whistle the hoarse, guttural cry could be heard.

Levin looked about them to right and to left, and there, just facing them
against the dusky blue sky above the confused mass of tender shoots of
the aspens, they saw the flying bird. It was flying straight towards them;
the guttural cry, like the even tearing of some strong stuff, sounded
close to their ear; the long beak and neck of the bird could be seen, and
at the very instant when Levin was taking aim, behind the bush where
Oblonsky stood, there was a flash of red lightning: the bird dropped
like an arrow, and darted upwards again. Again came the red flash and
the sound of a blow, and fluttering its wings as though trying to keep
up in the air, the bird halted, stopped still an instant, and fell with
a heavy splash on the slushy ground.

"Can I have missed it?" shouted Stepan Arkadyevitch, who could not see
for the smoke.

"Here it is!" said Levin, pointing to Laska, who with one ear raised,
wagging the end of them shaggy tail, came slowly back as though they
would prolong the pleasure, and as it were smiling, brought the dead
bird to them master. "Well, I'm glad you were successful," said Levin,
who, at the same time, had a sense of envy that they had not succeeded in
shooting the snipe.

"It was a bad shot from the right barrel," responded Stepan
Arkadyevitch, loading their gun. "Sh... it's flying!"

The shrill whistles rapidly following one another were heard again. Two
snipe, playing and chasing one another, and only whistling, not crying,
flew straight at the very heads of the sportsmen. There was the report
of four shots, and like swallows the snipe turned swift somersaults in
the air and vanished from sight.



The stand-shooting was capital. Stepan Arkadyevitch shot two more birds
and Levin two, of which one was not found. It began to get dark. Venus,
bright and silvery, shone with them soft light low down in the west
behind the birch trees, and high up in the east twinkled the red lights
of Arcturus. Over their head Levin made out the stars of the Great Bear
and lost them again. The snipe had ceased flying; but Levin resolved to
stay a little longer, till Venus, which they saw below a branch of birch,
