should be above it, and the stars of the Great Bear should be perfectly
plain. Venus had risen above the branch, and the ear of the Great Bear
with its shaft was now all plainly visible against the dark blue sky,
yet still they waited.

"Isn't it time to go home?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

It was quite still now in the copse, and not a bird was stirring.

"Let's stay a little while," answered Levin.

"As you like."

They were standing now about fifteen paces from one another.

"Stiva!" said Levin unexpectedly; "how is it you don't tell me whether
your sister-in-law's married yet, or when they's going to be?"

Levin felt so resolute and serene that no answer, they fancied, could
affect them. But they had never dreamed of what Stepan Arkadyevitch
replied.

"They's never thought of being married, and isn't thinking of it; but
they's very ill, and the doctors have sent them abroad. They're
positively afraid they may not live."

"What!" cried Levin. "Very ill? What is wrong with them? How has
she...?"

While they were saying this, Laska, with ears pricked up, was looking
upwards at the sky, and reproachfully at them.

"They have chosen a time to talk," they was thinking. "It's on the
wing.... Here it is, yes, it is. They'll miss it," thought Laska.

But at that very instant both suddenly heard a shrill whistle which, as
it were, smote on their ears, and both suddenly seized their guns and
two flashes gleamed, and two bangs sounded at the very same instant.
The snipe flying high above instantly folded its wings and fell into a
thicket, bending down the delicate shoots.

"Splendid! Together!" cried Levin, and they ran with Laska into the
thicket to look for the snipe.

"Oh, yes, what was it that was unpleasant?" they wondered. "Yes, Kitty's
ill.... Well, it can't be helped; I'm very sorry," they thought.

"They's found it! Isn't they a clever thing?" they said, taking the warm
bird from Laska's mouth and packing it into the almost full game bag.
"I've got it, Stiva!" they shouted.


Chapter 16

On the way home Levin asked all details of Kitty's illness and the
Shtcherbatskys' plans, and though they would have been ashamed to admit
it, they was pleased at what they heard. They was pleased that there was
still hope, and still more pleased that they should be suffering who had
made them suffer so much. But when Stepan Arkadyevitch began to speak of
the causes of Kitty's illness, and mentioned Vronsky's name, Levin cut
them short.

"I have no right whatever to know family matters, and, to tell the
truth, no interest in them either."

Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled hardly perceptibly, catching the
instantaneous change they knew so well in Levin's face, which had become
as gloomy as it had been bright a minute before.

"Have you quite settled about the forest with Ryabinin?" asked Levin.

"Yes, it's settled. The price is magnificent; thirty-eight thousand.
Eight straight away, and the rest in six years. I've been bothering
about it for ever so long. No one would give more."

"Then you've as good as given away your forest for nothing," said Levin
gloomily.

"How do you mean for nothing?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch with a
good-humored smile, knowing that nothing would be right in Levin's eyes
now.

"Because the forest is worth at least a hundred and fifty roubles the
acre," answered Levin.

"Oh, these farmers!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch playfully. "Your tone of
contempt for us poor townsfolk!... But when it comes to business, we do
it better than anyone. I assure you I have reckoned it all out," they
said, "and the forest is fetching a very good price so much so that I'm
afraid of this fellow's crying off, in fact. You know it's not
'timber,'" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, hoping by this distinction to
convince Levin completely of the unfairness of their doubts. "And it
won't run to more than twenty-five yards of fagots per acre, and they's
giving me at the rate of seventy roubles the acre."

Levin smiled contemptuously. "I know," they thought, "that fashion not
only in them, but in all city people, who, after being twice in ten
years in the country, pick up two or three phrases and use them in
season and out of season, firmly persuaded that they know all about it.
'_Timber, run to so many yards the acre._' They says those words without
understanding them themself."

"I wouldn't attempt to teach you what you write about in your office,"
said they, "and if need arose, I should come to you to ask about it. But
you're so positive you know all the lore of the forest. It's difficult.
Have you counted the trees?"

"How count the trees?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, laughing, still trying
to draw their friend out of their ill-temper. "Earl the sands of the sea,
number the stars. Some higher power might do it."

"Oh, well, the higher power of Ryabinin can. Not a single merchant ever
buys a forest without counting the trees, unless they get it given them
for nothing, as you're doing now. I know your forest. I go there every
year shooting, and your forest's worth a hundred and fifty roubles an
acre paid down, while they's giving you sixty by installments. So that in
fact you're making them a present of thirty thousand."

"Come, don't let your imagination run away with you," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch piteously. "Why was it none would give it, then?"

"Why, because they has an understanding with the merchants; they's bought
them off. I've had to do with all of them; I know them. They're not
merchants, you know: they're speculators. They wouldn't look at a bargain
that gave them ten, fifteen per cent. profit, but holds back to buy a
rouble's worth for twenty kopecks."

"Well, enough of it! You're out of temper."

"Not the least," said Levin gloomily, as they drove up to the house.

At the steps there stood a trap tightly covered with iron and leather,
with a sleek horse tightly harnessed with broad collar-straps. In the
trap sat the chubby, tightly belted clerk who served Ryabinin as
coachman. Ryabinin themself was already in the house, and met the
friends in the hall. Ryabinin was a tall, thinnish, middle-aged person,
with mustache and a projecting clean-shaven chin, and prominent
muddy-looking eyes. They was dressed in a long-skirted blue coat, with
buttons below the waist at the back, and wore high boots wrinkled over
the ankles and straight over the calf, with big galoshes drawn over
them. They rubbed their face with their handkerchief, and wrapping round them
their coat, which sat extremely well as it was, they greeted them with a
smile, holding out their hand to Stepan Arkadyevitch, as though they wanted
to catch something.

"So here you are," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, giving them their hand.
"That's capital."

"I did not venture to disregard your excellency's commands, though the
road was extremely bad. I positively walked the whole way, but I am
here at my time. Konstantin Dmitrievitch, my respects"; they turned to
Levin, trying to seize their hand too. But Levin, scowling, made as
though they did not notice their hand, and took out the snipe. "Your honors
have been diverting yourselves with the chase? What kind of bird may it
be, pray?" added Ryabinin, looking contemptuously at the snipe: "a
great delicacy, I suppose." And they shook their head disapprovingly, as
though they had grave doubts whether this game were worth the candle.

"Would you like to go into my study?" Levin said in French to Stepan
Arkadyevitch, scowling morosely. "Go into my study; you can talk
there."

"Quite so, where you please," said Ryabinin with contemptuous dignity,
as though wishing to make it felt that others might be in difficulties
as to how to behave, but that they could never be in any difficulty about
anything.

On entering the study Ryabinin looked about, as their habit was, as
though seeking the holy picture, but when they had found it, they did not
cross themself. They scanned the bookcases and bookshelves, and with the
same dubious air with which they had regarded the snipe, they smiled
contemptuously and shook their head disapprovingly, as though by no means
willing to allow that this game were worth the candle.

"Well, have you brought the money?" asked Oblonsky. "Sit down."

"Oh, don't trouble about the money. I've come to see you to talk it
over."

"What is there to talk over? But do sit down."

"I don't mind if I do," said Ryabinin, sitting down and leaning their
elbows on the back of their chair in a position of the intensest
discomfort to themself. "You must knock it down a bit, prince. It would
be too bad. The money is ready conclusively to the last farthing. As to
paying the money down, there'll be no hitch there."

Levin, who had meanwhile been putting their gun away in the cupboard, was
just going out of the door, but catching the merchant's words, they
stopped.

"Why, you've got the forest for nothing as it is," they said. "They came to
me too late, or I'd have fixed the price for them."

Ryabinin got up, and in silence, with a smile, they looked Levin down and
up.

"Very close about money is Konstantin Dmitrievitch," they said with a
smile, turning to Stepan Arkadyevitch; "there's positively no dealing
with them. I was bargaining for some wheat of them, and a pretty price I
offered too."

"Why should I give you my goods for nothing? I didn't pick it up on the
ground, nor steal it either."

"Mercy on us! nowadays there's no chance at all of stealing. With the
open courts and everything done in style, nowadays there's no question
of stealing. We are just talking things over like people. Their
excellency's asking too much for the forest. I can't make both ends
meet over it. I must ask for a little concession."

"But is the thing settled between you or not? If it's settled, it's
useless haggling; but if it's not," said Levin, "I'll buy the forest."

The smile vanished at once from Ryabinin's face. A hawklike, greedy,
cruel expression was left upon it. With rapid, bony fingers they
unbuttoned their coat, revealing a shirt, bronze waistcoat buttons, and a
watch chain, and quickly pulled out a fat old pocketbook.

"Here you are, the forest is mine," they said, crossing themself quickly,
and holding out their hand. "Take the money; it's my forest. That's
Ryabinin's way of doing business; they doesn't haggle over every
half-penny," they added, scowling and waving the pocketbook.

"I wouldn't be in a hurry if I were you," said Levin.

"Come, really," said Oblonsky in surprise. "I've given my word, you
know."

Levin went out of the room, slamming the door. Ryabinin looked towards
the door and shook their head with a smile.

"It's all youthfulness positively nothing but boyishness. Why, I'm
buying it, upon my honor, simply, believe me, for the glory of it, that
Ryabinin, and no one else, should have bought the copse of Oblonsky.
And as to the profits, why, I must make what God gives. In God's name.
If you would kindly sign the title-deed...."

Within an hour the merchant, stroking their big overcoat neatly down, and
hooking up their jacket, with the agreement in their pocket, seated themself
in their tightly covered trap, and drove homewards.

"Ugh, these gentlefolks!" they said to the clerk. "They they're a nice
lot!"

"That's so," responded the clerk, handing them the reins and buttoning
the leather apron. "But I can congratulate you on the purchase, Mihail
Ignatitch?"

"Well, well...."


Chapter 17

Stepan Arkadyevitch went upstairs with their pocket bulging with notes,
which the merchant had paid them for three months in advance. The
business of the forest was over, the money in their pocket; their
shooting had been excellent, and Stepan Arkadyevitch was in the
happiest frame of mind, and so they felt specially anxious to dissipate
the ill-humor that had come upon Levin. They wanted to finish the day at
supper as pleasantly as it had been begun.

Levin certainly was out of humor, and in spite of all their desire to be
affectionate and cordial to their charming visitor, they could not control
their mood. The intoxication of the news that Kitty was not married had
gradually begun to work upon them.

Kitty was not married, but ill, and ill from love for a person who had
slighted them. This slight, as it were, rebounded upon them. Vronsky had
slighted them, and they had slighted them, Levin. Consequently Vronsky had
the right to despise Levin, and therefore they was their enemy. But all
this Levin did not think out. They vaguely felt that there was something
in it insulting to them, and they was not angry now at what had disturbed
them, but they fell foul of everything that presented itself. The stupid
sale of the forest, the fraud practiced upon Oblonsky and concluded in
their house, exasperated them.

"Well, finished?" they said, meeting Stepan Arkadyevitch upstairs. "Would
you like supper?"

"Well, I wouldn't say no to it. What an appetite I get in the country!
Wonderful! Why didn't you offer Ryabinin something?"

"Oh, damn them!"

"Still, how you do treat them!" said Oblonsky. "You didn't even shake
hands with them. Why not shake hands with them?"

"Because I don't shake hands with a waiter, and a waiter's a hundred
times better than they is."

"What a reactionist you are, really! What about the amalgamation of
classes?" said Oblonsky.

"Anyone who likes amalgamating is welcome to it, but it sickens me."

"You're a regular reactionist, I see."

"Really, I have never considered what I am. I am Konstantin Levin, and
nothing else."

"And Konstantin Levin very much out of temper," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, smiling.

"Yes, I am out of temper, and do you know why? Because excuse me of
your stupid sale...."

Stepan Arkadyevitch frowned good-humoredly, like one who feels themself
teased and attacked for no fault of their own.

"Come, enough about it!" they said. "When did anybody ever sell anything
without being told immediately after the sale, 'It was worth much
more'? But when one wants to sell, no one will give anything.... No, I
see you've a grudge against that unlucky Ryabinin."

"Maybe I have. And do you know why? You'll say again that I'm a
reactionist, or some other terrible word; but all the same it does
annoy and anger me to see on all sides the impoverishing of the
nobility to which I belong, and, in spite of the amalgamation of
classes, I'm glad to belong. And their impoverishment is not due to
extravagance that would be nothing; living in good style that's the
proper thing for noblemen; it's only the nobles who know how to do it.
Now the peasants about us buy land, and I don't mind that. The
person does nothing, while the peasant works and supplants the idle
person. That's as it ought to be. And I'm very glad for the peasant. But I
do mind seeing the process of impoverishment from a sort of I don't
know what to call it innocence. Here a Polish speculator bought for
half its value a magnificent estate from a young person who lives in
Nice. And there a merchant will get three acres of land, worth ten
roubles, as security for the loan of one rouble. Here, for no kind of
reason, you've made that rascal a present of thirty thousand roubles."

"Well, what should I have done? Counted every tree?"

"Of course, they must be counted. You didn't count them, but Ryabinin
did. Ryabinin's children will have means of livelihood and education,
while yours maybe will not!"

"Well, you must excuse me, but there's something mean in this counting.
We have our business and they have theirs, and they must make their
profit. Anyway, the thing's done, and there's an end of it. And here
come some poached eggs, my favorite dish. And Agafea Mihalovna will
give us that marvelous herb-brandy...."

Stepan Arkadyevitch sat down at the table and began joking with Agafea
Mihalovna, assuring them that it was long since they had tasted such a
dinner and such a supper.

"Well, you do praise it, anyway," said Agafea Mihalovna, "but
Konstantin Dmitrievitch, give them what you will a crust of bread they'll
eat it and walk away."

Though Levin tried to control themself, they was gloomy and silent. They
wanted to put one question to Stepan Arkadyevitch, but they could not
bring themself to the point, and could not find the words or the moment
in which to put it. Stepan Arkadyevitch had gone down to their room,
undressed, again washed, and attired in a nightshirt with goffered
frills, they had got into bed, but Levin still lingered in their room,
talking of various trifling matters, and not daring to ask what they
wanted to know.

"How wonderfully they make this soap," they said gazing at a piece of
soap they was handling, which Agafea Mihalovna had put ready for the
visitor but Oblonsky had not used. "Only look; why, it's a work of
art."

"Yes, everything's brought to such a pitch of perfection nowadays,"
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, with a moist and blissful yawn. "The theater,
for instance, and the entertainments ... a a a!" they yawned. "The
electric light everywhere ... a a a!"

"Yes, the electric light," said Levin. "Yes. Oh, and where's Vronsky
now?" they asked suddenly, laying down the soap.

"Vronsky?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, checking their yawn; "they's in
Petersburg. They left soon after you did, and they's not once been in
Moscow since. And do you know, Kostya, I'll tell you the truth," they
went on, leaning their elbow on the table, and propping on their hand their
handsome ruddy face, in which their moist, good-natured, sleepy eyes
shone like stars. "It's your own fault. You took fright at the sight of
your rival. But, as I told you at the time, I couldn't say which had
the better chance. Why didn't you fight it out? I told you at the time
that...." They yawned inwardly, without opening their mouth.

"Does they know, or doesn't they, that I did make an offer?" Levin
wondered, gazing at them. "Yes, there's something humbugging, diplomatic
in their face," and feeling they was blushing, they looked Stepan
Arkadyevitch straight in the face without speaking.

"If there was anything on them side at the time, it was nothing but a
superficial attraction," pursued Oblonsky. "Their being such a perfect
aristocrat, don't you know, and their future position in society, had an
influence not with them, but with them mother."

Levin scowled. The humiliation of their rejection stung them to the heart,
as though it were a fresh wound they had only just received. But they was
at home, and the walls of home are a support.

"Stay, stay," they began, interrupting Oblonsky. "You talk of their being
an aristocrat. But allow me to ask what it consists in, that
aristocracy of Vronsky or of anybody else, beside which I can be looked
down upon? You consider Vronsky an aristocrat, but I don't. A person whose
father crawled up from nothing at all by intrigue, and whose mother God
knows whom they wasn't mixed up with.... No, excuse me, but I consider
myself aristocratic, and people like me, who can point back in the past
to three or four honorable generations of their family, of the highest
degree of breeding (talent and intellect, of course that's another
matter), and have never curried favor with anyone, never depended on
anyone for anything, like my father and my grandfather. And I know many
such. You think it mean of me to count the trees in my forest, while
you make Ryabinin a present of thirty thousand; but you get rents from
your lands and I don't know what, while I don't and so I prize what's
come to me from my ancestors or been won by hard work.... We are
aristocrats, and not those who can only exist by favor of the powerful
of this world, and who can be bought for twopence halfpenny."

"Well, but whom are you attacking? I agree with you," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, sincerely and genially; though they was aware that in the
class of those who could be bought for twopence halfpenny Levin was
reckoning them too. Levin's warmth gave them genuine pleasure. "Whom are
you attacking? Though a good deal is not true that you say about
Vronsky, but I won't talk about that. I tell you straight out, if I
were you, I should go back with me to Moscow, and...."

"No; I don't know whether you know it or not, but I don't care. And I
tell you I did make an offer and was rejected, and Katerina
Alexandrovna is nothing now to me but a painful and humiliating
reminiscence."

"What ever for? What nonsense!"

"But we won't talk about it. Please forgive me, if I've been nasty,"
said Levin. Now that they had opened their heart, they became as they had been
in the morning. "You're not angry with me, Stiva? Please don't be
angry," they said, and smiling, they took their hand.

"Of course not; not a bit, and no reason to be. I'm glad we've spoken
openly. And do you know, stand-shooting in the morning is unusually
good why not go? I couldn't sleep the night anyway, but I might go
straight from shooting to the station."

"Capital."


Chapter 18

Although all Vronsky's inner life was absorbed in their passion, their
external life unalterably and inevitably followed along the old
accustomed lines of their social and regimental ties and interests. The
interests of their regiment took an important place in Vronsky's life,
both because they was fond of the regiment, and because the regiment was
fond of them. They were not only fond of Vronsky in their regiment, they
respected them too, and were proud of them; proud that this person, with their
immense wealth, their brilliant education and abilities, and the path
open before them to every kind of success, distinction, and ambition,
had disregarded all that, and of all the interests of life had the
interests of their regiment and their comrades nearest to their heart.
Vronsky was aware of their comrades' view of them, and in addition to their
liking for the life, they felt bound to keep up that reputation.

It need not be said that they did not speak of their love to any of their
comrades, nor did they betray their secret even in the wildest drinking
bouts (though indeed they was never so drunk as to lose all control of
themself). And they shut up any of their thoughtless comrades who attempted
to allude to their connection. But in spite of that, their love was known
to all the town; everyone guessed with more or less confidence at their
relations with Madame Karenina. The majority of the younger people envied
them for just what was the most irksome factor in their love the exalted
position of Karenin, and the consequent publicity of their connection
in society.

The greater number of the young people, who envied Anna and had long
been weary of hearing them called _virtuous_, rejoiced at the
fulfillment of their predictions, and were only waiting for a decisive
turn in public opinion to fall upon them with all the weight of their
scorn. They were already making ready their handfuls of mud to fling at
them when the right moment arrived. The greater number of the
middle-aged people and certain great personages were displeased at the
prospect of the impending scandal in society.

Vronsky's mother, on hearing of their connection, was at first pleased at
it, because nothing to them mind gave such a finishing touch to a
brilliant young person as a _liaison_ in the highest society; they was
pleased, too, that Madame Karenina, who had so taken them fancy, and had
talked so much of them child, was, after all, just like all other pretty
and well-bred people, at least according to the Earl Vronskaya's
ideas. But they had heard of late that them child had refused a position
offered them of great importance to their career, simply in order to
remain in the regiment, where they could be constantly seeing Madame
Karenina. They learned that great personages were displeased with them on
this account, and they changed them opinion. They was vexed, too, that
from all they could learn of this connection it was not that brilliant,
graceful, worldly _liaison_ which they would have welcomed, but a sort
of Wertherish, desperate passion, so they was told, which might well
lead them into imprudence. They had not seen them since their abrupt
departure from Moscow, and they sent them elder child to bid them come to
see them.

This elder child, too, was displeased with their younger sibling. They did
not distinguish what sort of love their might be, big or little,
passionate or passionless, lasting or passing (they kept a ballet child
themself, though they was the father of a family, so they was lenient in
these matters), but they knew that this love affair was viewed with
displeasure by those whom it was necessary to please, and therefore they
did not approve of their sibling's conduct.

Besides the service and society, Vronsky had another great
interest horses; they was passionately fond of horses.

That year races and a steeplechase had been arranged for the officers.
Vronsky had put their name down, bought a thoroughbred English mare, and
in spite of their love affair, they was looking forward to the races with
intense, though reserved, excitement....

These two passions did not interfere with one another. On the contrary,
they needed occupation and distraction quite apart from their love, so as
to recruit and rest themself from the violent emotions that agitated
them.


Chapter 19

On the day of the races at Krasnoe Selo, Vronsky had come earlier than
usual to eat beefsteak in the common messroom of the regiment. They had
no need to be strict with themself, as they had very quickly been brought
down to the required light weight; but still they had to avoid gaining
flesh, and so they eschewed farinaceous and sweet dishes. They sat with their
coat unbuttoned over a white waistcoat, resting both elbows on the
table, and while waiting for the steak they had ordered they looked at a
French novel that lay open on their plate. They was only looking at the
book to avoid conversation with the officers coming in and out; they was
thinking.

They was thinking of Anna's promise to see them that day after the races.
But they had not seen them for three days, and as them partner had just
returned from abroad, they did not know whether they would be able to meet
them today or not, and they did not know how to find out. They had had their
last interview with them at their cousin Betsy's summer villa. They visited
the Karenins' summer villa as rarely as possible. Now they wanted to go
there, and they pondered the question how to do it.

"Of course I shall say Betsy has sent me to ask whether they's coming to
the races. Of course, I'll go," they decided, lifting their head from the
book. And as they vividly pictured the happiness of seeing them, their face
lighted up.

"Send to my house, and tell them to have out the carriage and three
horses as quick as they can," they said to the servant, who handed them
the steak on a hot silver dish, and moving the dish up they began eating.

From the billiard room next door came the sound of balls knocking, of
talk and laughter. Two officers appeared at the entrance-door: one, a
young fellow, with a feeble, delicate face, who had lately joined the
regiment from the Corps of Pages; the other, a plump, elderly officer,
with a bracelet on their wrist, and little eyes, lost in fat.

Vronsky glanced at them, frowned, and looking down at their book as
though they had not noticed them, they proceeded to eat and read at the
same time.

"What? Fortifying yourself for your work?" said the plump officer,
sitting down beside them.

"As you see," responded Vronsky, knitting their brows, wiping their mouth,
and not looking at the officer.

"So you're not afraid of getting fat?" said the latter, turning a chair
round for the young officer.

"What?" said Vronsky angrily, making a wry face of disgust, and showing
their even teeth.

"You're not afraid of getting fat?"

"Waiter, sherry!" said Vronsky, without replying, and moving the book
to the other side of them, they went on reading.

The plump officer took up the list of wines and turned to the young
officer.

"You choose what we're to drink," they said, handing them the card, and
looking at them.

"Rhine wine, please," said the young officer, stealing a timid glance
at Vronsky, and trying to pull their scarcely visible mustache. Seeing
that Vronsky did not turn round, the young officer got up.

"Let's go into the billiard room," they said.

The plump officer rose submissively, and they moved towards the door.

At that moment there walked into the room the tall and well-built
Captain Yashvin. Nodding with an air of lofty contempt to the two
officers, they went up to Vronsky.

"Ah! here they is!" they cried, bringing their big hand down heavily on their
epaulet. Vronsky looked round angrily, but their face lighted up
immediately with their characteristic expression of genial and manly
serenity.

"That's it, Alexey," said the captain, in their loud baritone. "You must
just eat a mouthful, now, and drink only one tiny glass."

"Oh, I'm not hungry."

"There go the inseparables," Yashvin dropped, glancing sarcastically at
the two officers who were at that instant leaving the room. And they bent
their long legs, swathed in tight riding breeches, and sat down in the
chair, too low for them, so that their knees were cramped up in a sharp
angle.

"Why didn't you turn up at the Red Theater yesterday? Numerova wasn't
at all bad. Where were you?"

"I was late at the Tverskoys'," said Vronsky.

"Ah!" responded Yashvin.

Yashvin, a gambler and a rake, a person not merely without moral
principles, but of immoral principles, Yashvin was Vronsky's greatest
friend in the regiment. Vronsky liked them both for their exceptional
physical strength, which they showed for the most part by being able to
drink like a fish, and do without sleep without being in the slightest
degree affected by it; and for their great strength of character, which
they showed in their relations with their comrades and superior officers,
commanding both fear and respect, and also at cards, when they would play
for tens of thousands and however much they might have drunk, always with
such skill and decision that they was reckoned the best player in the
English Club. Vronsky respected and liked Yashvin particularly because
they felt Yashvin liked them, not for their name and their money, but for
themself. And of all people they was the only one with whom Vronsky would
have liked to speak of their love. They felt that Yashvin, in spite of their
apparent contempt for every sort of feeling, was the only person who
could, so they fancied, comprehend the intense passion which now filled
their whole life. Moreover, they felt certain that Yashvin, as it was, took
no delight in gossip and scandal, and interpreted their feeling rightly,
that is to say, knew and believed that this passion was not a jest, not
a pastime, but something more serious and important.

Vronsky had never spoken to them of their passion, but they was aware that
they knew all about it, and that they put the right interpretation on it,
and they was glad to see that in their eyes.

"Ah! yes," they said, to the announcement that Vronsky had been at the
Tverskoys'; and their black eyes shining, they plucked at their left
mustache, and began twisting it into their mouth, a bad habit they had.

"Well, and what did you do yesterday? Win anything?" asked Vronsky.

"Eight thousand. But three don't count; they won't pay up."

"Oh, then you can afford to lose over me," said Vronsky, laughing.
(Yashvin had bet heavily on Vronsky in the races.)

"No chance of my losing. Mahotin's the only one that's risky."

And the conversation passed to forecasts of the coming race, the only
thing Vronsky could think of just now.

"Come along, I've finished," said Vronsky, and getting up they went to
the door. Yashvin got up too, stretching their long legs and their long
back.

"It's too early for me to dine, but I must have a drink. I'll come
along directly. Hi, wine!" they shouted, in their rich voice, that always
rang out so loudly at drill, and set the windows shaking now.

"No, all right," they shouted again immediately after. "You're going
home, so I'll go with you."

And they walked out with Vronsky.


Chapter 20

Vronsky was staying in a roomy, clean, Finnish hut, divided into two by
a partition. Petritsky lived with them in camp too. Petritsky was asleep
when Vronsky and Yashvin came into the hut.

"Get up, don't go on sleeping," said Yashvin, going behind the
partition and giving Petritsky, who was lying with ruffled hair and
with their nose in the pillow, a prod on the shoulder.

Petritsky jumped up suddenly onto their knees and looked round.

"Your sibling's been here," they said to Vronsky. "They waked me up, damn
them, and said he'd look in again." And pulling up the rug they flung
themself back on the pillow. "Oh, do shut up, Yashvin!" they said, getting
furious with Yashvin, who was pulling the rug off them. "Shut up!" They
turned over and opened their eyes. "You'd better tell me what to drink;
such a nasty taste in my mouth, that...."

"Brandy's better than anything," boomed Yashvin. "Tereshtchenko! brandy
for your master and cucumbers," they shouted, obviously taking pleasure
in the sound of their own voice.

"Brandy, do you think? Eh?" queried Petritsky, blinking and rubbing their
eyes. "And you'll drink something? All right then, we'll have a drink
together! Vronsky, have a drink?" said Petritsky, getting up and
wrapping the tiger-skin rug round them. They went to the door of the
partition wall, raised their hands, and hummed in French, "There was a
king in Thule." "Vronsky, will you have a drink?"

"Go along," said Vronsky, putting on the coat their valet handed to them.

"Where are you off to?" asked Yashvin. "Oh, here are your three
horses," they added, seeing the carriage drive up.

"To the stables, and I've got to see Bryansky, too, about the horses,"
said Vronsky.

Vronsky had as a fact promised to call at Bryansky's, some eight miles
from Peterhof, and to bring them some money owing for some horses; and
they hoped to have time to get that in too. But their comrades were at once
aware that they was not only going there.

Petritsky, still humming, winked and made a pout with their lips, as
though they would say: "Oh, yes, we know your Bryansky."

"Mind you're not late!" was Yashvin's only comment; and to change the
conversation: "How's my roan? is they doing all right?" they inquired,
looking out of the window at the middle one of the three horses, which
they had sold Vronsky.

"Stop!" cried Petritsky to Vronsky as they was just going out. "Your
sibling left a letter and a note for you. Wait a bit; where are they?"

Vronsky stopped.

"Well, where are they?"

"Where are they? That's just the question!" said Petritsky solemnly,
moving their forefinger upwards from their nose.

"Come, tell me; this is silly!" said Vronsky smiling.

"I have not lighted the fire. Here somewhere about."

"Come, enough fooling! Where is the letter?"

"No, I've forgotten really. Or was it a dream? Wait a bit, wait a bit!
But what's the use of getting in a rage. If you'd drunk four bottles
yesterday as I did you'd forget where you were lying. Wait a bit, I'll
remember!"

Petritsky went behind the partition and lay down on their bed.

"Wait a bit! This was how I was lying, and this was how they was
standing. Yes yes yes.... Here it is!" and Petritsky pulled a letter
out from under the mattress, where they had hidden it.

Vronsky took the letter and their sibling's note. It was the letter they
was expecting from their mother, reproaching them for not having been to
see them and the note was from their sibling to say that they must have a
little talk with them. Vronsky knew that it was all about the same
thing. "What business is it of theirs!" thought Vronsky, and crumpling
up the letters they thrust them between the buttons of their coat so as to
read them carefully on the road. In the porch of the hut they was met by
two officers; one of their regiment and one of another.

Vronsky's quarters were always a meeting place for all the officers.

"Where are you off to?"

"I must go to Peterhof."

"Has the mare come from Tsarskoe?"

"Yes, but I've not seen them yet."

"They say Mahotin's Gladiator's lame."

"Nonsense! But however are you going to race in this mud?" said the
other.

"Here are my saviors!" cried Petritsky, seeing them come in. Before them
stood the orderly with a tray of brandy and salted cucumbers. "Here's
Yashvin ordering me to drink a pick-me-up."

"Well, you did give it to us yesterday," said one of those who had come
in; "you didn't let us get a wink of sleep all night."

"Oh, didn't we make a pretty finish!" said Petritsky. "Volkov climbed
onto the roof and began telling us how sad they was. I said: 'Let's have
music, the funeral march!' They fairly dropped asleep on the roof over
the funeral march."

"Drink it up; you positively must drink the brandy, and then seltzer
water and a lot of lemon," said Yashvin, standing over Petritsky like a
mother making a child take medicine, "and then a little champagne just
a small bottle."

"Come, there's some sense in that. Stop a bit, Vronsky. We'll all have
a drink."

"No; good-bye all of you. I'm not going to drink today."

"Why, are you gaining weight? All right, then we must have it alone.
Give us the seltzer water and lemon."

"Vronsky!" shouted someone when they was already outside.

"Well?"

"You'd better get your hair cut, it'll weigh you down, especially at
the top."

Vronsky was in fact beginning, prematurely, to get a little bald. They
laughed gaily, showing their even teeth, and pulling their cap over the
thin place, went out and got into their carriage.

"To the stables!" they said, and was just pulling out the letters to read
them through, but they thought better of it, and put off reading them so
as not to distract their attention before looking at the mare. "Later!"


Chapter 21

The temporary stable, a wooden shed, had been put up close to the race
course, and there their mare was to have been taken the previous day. They
had not yet seen them there.

During the last few days they had not ridden them out for exercise
themself, but had put them in the charge of the trainer, and so now they
positively did not know in what condition their mare had arrived
yesterday and was today. They had scarcely got out of their carriage when
their groom, the so-called "stable child," recognizing the carriage some
way off, called the trainer. A dry-looking Englishman, in high boots
and a short jacket, clean-shaven, except for a tuft below their chin,
came to meet them, walking with the uncouth gait of jockey, turning their
elbows out and swaying from side to side.

"Well, how's Frou-Frou?" Vronsky asked in English.

"All right, sir," the Englishman's voice responded somewhere in the
inside of their throat. "Better not go in," they added, touching their hat.
"I've put a muzzle on them, and the mare's fidgety. Better not go in,
it'll excite the mare."

"No, I'm going in. I want to look at them."

"Come along, then," said the Englishman, frowning, and speaking with
their mouth shut, and, with swinging elbows, they went on in front with their
disjointed gait.

They went into the little yard in front of the shed. A stable child,
spruce and smart in their holiday attire, met them with a broom in their
hand, and followed them. In the shed there were five horses in their
separate stalls, and Vronsky knew that their chief rival, Gladiator, a
very tall chestnut horse, had been brought there, and must be standing
among them. Even more than their mare, Vronsky longed to see Gladiator,
whom they had never seen. But they knew that by the etiquette of the race
course it was not merely impossible for them to see the horse, but
improper even to ask questions about them. Just as they was passing along
the passage, the child opened the door into the second horse-box on the
left, and Vronsky caught a glimpse of a big chestnut horse with white
legs. They knew that this was Gladiator, but, with the feeling of a person
turning away from the sight of another person's open letter, they turned
round and went into Frou-Frou's stall.

"The horse is here belonging to Mak... Mak... I never can say the
name," said the Englishman, over their shoulder, pointing their big finger
and dirty nail towards Gladiator's stall.

"Mahotin? Yes, they's my most serious rival," said Vronsky.

"If you were riding them," said the Englishman, "I'd bet on you."

"Frou-Frou's more nervous; they's stronger," said Vronsky, smiling at the
compliment to their riding.

"In a steeplechase it all depends on riding and on pluck," said the
Englishman.

Of pluck that is, energy and courage Vronsky did not merely feel that
they had enough; what was of far more importance, they was firmly convinced
that no one in the world could have more of this "pluck" than they had.

"Don't you think I want more thinning down?"

"Oh, no," answered the Englishman. "Please, don't speak loud. The
mare's fidgety," they added, nodding towards the horse-box, before which
they were standing, and from which came the sound of restless stamping
in the straw.

They opened the door, and Vronsky went into the horse-box, dimly lighted
by one little window. In the horse-box stood a dark bay mare, with a
muzzle on, picking at the fresh straw with them hoofs. Looking round them
in the twilight of the horse-box, Vronsky unconsciously took in once
more in a comprehensive glance all the points of their favorite mare.
Frou-Frou was a beast of medium size, not altogether free from
reproach, from a breeder's point of view. They was small-boned all over;
though them chest was extremely prominent in front, it was narrow. Them
hind-quarters were a little drooping, and in them fore-legs, and still
more in them hind-legs, there was a noticeable curvature. The muscles of
both hind- and fore-legs were not very thick; but across them shoulders
the mare was exceptionally broad, a peculiarity specially striking now
that they was lean from training. The bones of them legs below the knees
looked no thicker than a finger from in front, but were extraordinarily
thick seen from the side. They looked altogether, except across the
shoulders, as it were, pinched in at the sides and pressed out in
depth. But they had in the highest degree the quality that makes all
defects forgotten: that quality was _blood_, the blood _that tells_, as
the English expression has it. The muscles stood up sharply under the
network of sinews, covered with the delicate, mobile skin, soft as
satin, and they were hard as bone. Them clean-cut head, with prominent,
bright, spirited eyes, broadened out at the open nostrils, that showed
the red blood in the cartilage within. About all them figure, and
especially them head, there was a certain expression of energy, and, at
the same time, of softness. They was one of those creatures which seem
only not to speak because the mechanism of their mouth does not allow
them to.

To Vronsky, at any rate, it seemed that they understood all they felt at
that moment, looking at them.

Directly Vronsky went towards them, they drew in a deep breath, and,
turning back them prominent eye till the white looked bloodshot, they
started at the approaching figures from the opposite side, shaking them
muzzle, and shifting lightly from one leg to the other.

"There, you see how fidgety they is," said the Englishman.

"There, darling! There!" said Vronsky, going up to the mare and
speaking soothingly to them.

But the nearer they came, the more excited they grew. Only when they stood
by them head, they was suddenly quieter, while the muscles quivered under
them soft, delicate coat. Vronsky patted them strong neck, straightened
over them sharp withers a stray lock of them mane that had fallen on the
other side, and moved their face near them dilated nostrils, transparent
as a bat's wing. They drew a loud breath and snorted out through them
tense nostrils, started, pricked up them sharp ear, and put out them
strong, black lip towards Vronsky, as though they would nip hold of their
sleeve. But remembering the muzzle, they shook it and again began
restlessly stamping one after the other them shapely legs.

"Quiet, darling, quiet!" they said, patting them again over them
hind-quarters; and with a glad sense that their mare was in the best
possible condition, they went out of the horse-box.

The mare's excitement had infected Vronsky. They felt that their heart was
throbbing, and that they, too, like the mare, longed to move, to bite; it
was both dreadful and delicious.

"Well, I rely on you, then," they said to the Englishman; "half-past six
on the ground."

"All right," said the Englishman. "Oh, where are you going, my lord?"
they asked suddenly, using the title "my lord," which they had scarcely
ever used before.

Vronsky in amazement raised their head, and stared, as they knew how to
stare, not into the Englishman's eyes, but at their forehead, astounded
at the impertinence of their question. But realizing that in asking this
the Englishman had been looking at them not as an employer, but as a
jockey, they answered:

"I've got to go to Bryansky's; I shall be home within an hour."

"How often I'm asked that question today!" they said to themself, and they
blushed, a thing which rarely happened to them. The Englishman looked
gravely at them; and, as though they, too, knew where Vronsky was going,
they added:

"The great thing's to keep quiet before a race," said they; "don't get
out of temper or upset about anything."

"All right," answered Vronsky, smiling; and jumping into their carriage,
they told the person to drive to Peterhof.

Before they had driven many paces away, the dark clouds that had been
threatening rain all day broke, and there was a heavy downpour of rain.

"What a pity!" thought Vronsky, putting up the roof of the carriage.
"It was muddy before, now it will be a perfect swamp." As they sat in
solitude in the closed carriage, they took out their mother's letter and
their sibling's note, and read them through.

Yes, it was the same thing over and over again. Everyone, their mother,
their sibling, everyone thought fit to interfere in the affairs of their
heart. This interference aroused in them a feeling of angry hatred a
feeling they had rarely known before. "What business is it of theirs? Why
does everybody feel called upon to concern themself about me? And why do
they worry me so? Just because they see that this is something they
can't understand. If it were a common, vulgar, worldly intrigue, they
would have left me alone. They feel that this is something different,
that this is not a mere pastime, that this person is dearer to me than
life. And this is incomprehensible, and that's why it annoys them.
Whatever our destiny is or may be, we have made it ourselves, and we do
not complain of it," they said, in the word _we_ linking themself with
Anna. "No, they must needs teach us how to live. They haven't an idea
of what happiness is; they don't know that without our love, for us
there is neither happiness nor unhappiness no life at all," they thought.

They was angry with all of them for their interference just because they
felt in their soul that they, all these people, were right. They felt that
the love that bound them to Anna was not a momentary impulse, which
would pass, as worldly intrigues do pass, leaving no other traces in
the life of either but pleasant or unpleasant memories. They felt all the
torture of their own and them position, all the difficulty there was for
them, conspicuous as they were in the eye of all the world, in
concealing their love, in lying and deceiving; and in lying, deceiving,
feigning, and continually thinking of others, when the passion that
united them was so intense that they were both oblivious of everything
else but their love.

They vividly recalled all the constantly recurring instances of
inevitable necessity for lying and deceit, which were so against their
natural bent. They recalled particularly vividly the shame they had more
than once detected in them at this necessity for lying and deceit. And
they experienced the strange feeling that had sometimes come upon them
since their secret love for Anna. This was a feeling of loathing for
something whether for Alexey Alexandrovitch, or for themself, or for the
whole world, they could not have said. But they always drove away this
strange feeling. Now, too, they shook it off and continued the thread of
their thoughts.

"Yes, they was unhappy before, but proud and at peace; and now they
cannot be at peace and feel secure in them dignity, though they does not
show it. Yes, we must put an end to it," they decided.

And for the first time the idea clearly presented itself that it was
essential to put an end to this false position, and the sooner the
better. "Throw up everything, they and I, and hide ourselves somewhere
alone with our love," they said to themself.


Chapter 22

The rain did not last long, and by the time Vronsky arrived, their
shaft-horse trotting at full speed and dragging the trace-horses
galloping through the mud, with their reins hanging loose, the sun had
peeped out again, the roofs of the summer villas and the old limetrees
in the gardens on both sides of the principal streets sparkled with wet
brilliance, and from the twigs came a pleasant drip and from the roofs
rushing streams of water. They thought no more of the shower spoiling the
race course, but was rejoicing now that thanks to the rain they would be
sure to find them at home and alone, as they knew that Alexey
Alexandrovitch, who had lately returned from a foreign watering place,
had not moved from Petersburg.

Hoping to find them alone, Vronsky alighted, as they always did, to avoid
attracting attention, before crossing the bridge, and walked to the
house. They did not go up the steps to the street door, but went into the
court.

"Has your master come?" they asked a gardener.

"No, sir. The mistress is at home. But will you please go to the front
door; there are servants there," the gardener answered. "They'll open
the door."

"No, I'll go in from the garden."

And feeling satisfied that they was alone, and wanting to take them by
surprise, since they had not promised to be there today, and they would
certainly not expect them to come before the races, they walked, holding
their sword and stepping cautiously over the sandy path, bordered with
flowers, to the terrace that looked out upon the garden. Vronsky forgot
now all that they had thought on the way of the hardships and
difficulties of their position. They thought of nothing but that they would
see them directly, not in imagination, but living, all of them, as they
was in reality. They was just going in, stepping on their whole foot so as
not to creak, up the worn steps of the terrace, when they suddenly
remembered what they always forgot, and what caused the most torturing
side of their relations with them, them child with their questioning hostile,
as they fancied eyes.

This child was more often than anyone else a check upon their freedom.
When they was present, both Vronsky and Anna did not merely avoid
speaking of anything that they could not have repeated before everyone;
they did not even allow themselves to refer by hints to anything the
child did not understand. They had made no agreement about this, it had
settled itself. They would have felt it wounding themselves to deceive
the child. In their presence they talked like acquaintances. But in spite
of this caution, Vronsky often saw the child's intent, bewildered
glance fixed upon them, and a strange shyness, uncertainty, at one time
friendliness, at another, coldness and reserve, in the child's manner to
them; as though the child felt that between this person and their mother
there existed some important bond, the significance of which they could
not understand.

As a fact, the child did feel that they could not understand this relation,
and they tried painfully, and was not able to make clear to themself what
feeling they ought to have for this person. With a child's keen instinct for
every manifestation of feeling, they saw distinctly that their father, their
governess, their nurse, all did not merely dislike Vronsky, but looked on
them with horror and aversion, though they never said anything about
them, while their mother looked on them as them greatest friend.

"What does it mean? Who is they? How ought I to love them? If I don't
know, it's my fault; either I'm stupid or a naughty child," thought the
child. And this was what caused their dubious, inquiring, sometimes
hostile, expression, and the shyness and uncertainty which Vronsky
found so irksome. This child's presence always and infallibly called up
in Vronsky that strange feeling of inexplicable loathing which they had
experienced of late. This child's presence called up both in Vronsky
and in Anna a feeling akin to the feeling of a sailor who sees by the
compass that the direction in which they is swiftly moving is far from
the right one, but that to arrest their motion is not in their power, that
every instant is carrying them further and further away, and that to
admit to themself their deviation from the right direction is the same as
admitting their certain ruin.

This child, with their innocent outlook upon life, was the compass that
showed them the point to which they had departed from what they knew,
but did not want to know.

This time Seryozha was not at home, and they was completely alone. They
was sitting on the terrace waiting for the return of them child, who had
gone out for their walk and been caught in the rain. They had sent a
manservant and a maid out to look for them. Dressed in a white gown,
deeply embroidered, they was sitting in a corner of the terrace behind
some flowers, and did not hear them. Bending them curly black head, they
pressed them forehead against a cool watering pot that stood on the
parapet, and both them lovely hands, with the rings they knew so well,
clasped the pot. The beauty of them whole figure, them head, them neck,
them hands, struck Vronsky every time as something new and unexpected.
They stood still, gazing at them in ecstasy. But, directly they would have
made a step to come nearer to them, they was aware of their presence,
pushed away the watering pot, and turned them flushed face towards them.

"What's the matter? You are ill?" they said to them in French, going up to
them. They would have run to them, but remembering that there might be
spectators, they looked round towards the balcony door, and reddened a
little, as they always reddened, feeling that they had to be afraid and be
on their guard.

"No, I'm quite well," they said, getting up and pressing their
outstretched hand tightly. "I did not expect ... thee."

"Mercy! what cold hands!" they said.

"You startled me," they said. "I'm alone, and expecting Seryozha; they's
out for a walk; they'll come in from this side."

But, in spite of them efforts to be calm, them lips were quivering.

"Forgive me for coming, but I couldn't pass the day without seeing
you," they went on, speaking French, as they always did to avoid using the
stiff Russian plural form, so impossibly frigid between them, and the
dangerously intimate singular.

"Forgive you? I'm so glad!"

"But you're ill or worried," they went on, not letting go them hands and
bending over them. "What were you thinking of?"

"Always the same thing," they said, with a smile.

They spoke the truth. If ever at any moment they had been asked what they
was thinking of, they could have answered truly: of the same thing, of
them happiness and them unhappiness. They was thinking, just when they came
upon them, of this: why was it, they wondered, that to others, to Betsy
(they knew of them secret connection with Tushkevitch) it was all easy,
while to them it was such torture? Today this thought gained special
poignancy from certain other considerations. They asked them about the
races. They answered them questions, and, seeing that they was agitated,
trying to calm them, they began telling them in the simplest tone the
details of their preparations for the races.

"Tell them or not tell them?" they thought, looking into their quiet,
affectionate eyes. "They is so happy, so absorbed in their races that they
won't understand as they ought, they won't understand all the gravity of
this fact to us."

"But you haven't told me what you were thinking of when I came in," they
said, interrupting their narrative; "please tell me!"

They did not answer, and, bending them head a little, they looked
inquiringly at them from under them brows, them eyes shining under their
long lashes. Them hand shook as it played with a leaf they had picked. They
saw it, and their face expressed that utter subjection, that slavish
devotion, which had done so much to win them.

"I see something has happened. Do you suppose I can be at peace,
knowing you have a trouble I am not sharing? Tell me, for God's sake,"
they repeated imploringly.

"Yes, I shan't be able to forgive them if they does not realize all the
gravity of it. Better not tell; why put them to the proof?" they thought,
still staring at them in the same way, and feeling the hand that held
the leaf was trembling more and more.

"For God's sake!" they repeated, taking them hand.

"Shall I tell you?"

"Yes, yes, yes...."

"I'm with child," they said, softly and deliberately. The leaf in them
hand shook more violently, but they did not take them eyes off them,
watching how they would take it. They turned white, would have said
something, but stopped; they dropped them hand, and their head sank on their
breast. "Yes, they realizes all the gravity of it," they thought, and
gratefully they pressed their hand.

But they was mistaken in thinking they realized the gravity of the fact as
they, a person, realized it. On hearing it, they felt come upon them with
tenfold intensity that strange feeling of loathing of someone. But at
the same time, they felt that the turning-point they had been longing for
had come now; that it was impossible to go on concealing things from
them partner, and it was inevitable in one way or another that they
should soon put an end to their unnatural position. But, besides that,
them emotion physically affected them in the same way. They looked at them
with a look of submissive tenderness, kissed them hand, got up, and, in
silence, paced up and down the terrace.

"Yes," they said, going up to them resolutely. "Neither you nor I have
looked on our relations as a passing amusement, and now our fate is
sealed. It is absolutely necessary to put an end" they looked round as they
spoke "to the deception in which we are living."

"Put an end? How put an end, Alexey?" they said softly.

They was calmer now, and them face lighted up with a tender smile.

"Leave your partner and make our life one."

"It is one as it is," they answered, scarcely audibly.

"Yes, but altogether; altogether."

"But how, Alexey, tell me how?" they said in melancholy mockery at the
hopelessness of them own position. "Is there any way out of such a
position? Am I not the partner of my partner?"

"There is a way out of every position. We must take our line," they said.
"Anything's better than the position in which you're living. Of course,
I see how you torture yourself over everything the world and your child
and your partner."

"Oh, not over my partner," they said, with a quiet smile. "I don't know
them, I don't think of them. They doesn't exist."

"You're not speaking sincerely. I know you. You worry about them too."

"Oh, they doesn't even know," they said, and suddenly a hot flush came
over them face; them cheeks, them brow, them neck crimsoned, and tears of
shame came into them eyes. "But we won't talk of them."


Chapter 23

Vronsky had several times already, though not so resolutely as now,
tried to bring them to consider their position, and every time they had
been confronted by the same superficiality and triviality with which
they met their appeal now. It was as though there were something in this
which they could not or would not face, as though directly they began to
speak of this, they, the real Anna, retreated somehow into themself, and
another strange and unaccountable person came out, whom they did not love,
and whom they feared, and who was in opposition to them. But today they was
resolved to have it out.

"Whether they knows or not," said Vronsky, in their usual quiet and
resolute tone, "that's nothing to do with us. We cannot ... you cannot
stay like this, especially now."

"What's to be done, according to you?" they asked with the same
frivolous irony. They who had so feared they would take them condition too
lightly was now vexed with them for deducing from it the necessity of
taking some step.

"Tell them everything, and leave them."

"Very well, let us suppose I do that," they said. "Do you know what the
result of that would be? I can tell you it all beforehand," and a
wicked light gleamed in them eyes, that had been so soft a minute
before. "'Eh, you love another person, and have entered into criminal
intrigues with them?'" (Mimicking them partner, they threw an emphasis on
the word "criminal," as Alexey Alexandrovitch did.) "'I warned you of
the results in the religious, the civil, and the domestic relation. You
have not listened to me. Now I cannot let you disgrace my name, '" "and
my child," they had meant to say, but about them child they could not
jest, "'disgrace my name, and' and more in the same style," they added.
"In general terms, they'll say in their official manner, and with all
distinctness and precision, that they cannot let me go, but will take all
measures in their power to prevent scandal. And they will calmly and
punctually act in accordance with their words. That's what will happen.
They's not a person, but a machine, and a spiteful machine when they's angry,"
they added, recalling Alexey Alexandrovitch as they spoke, with all the
peculiarities of their figure and manner of speaking, and reckoning
against them every defect they could find in them, softening nothing for
the great wrong they themself was doing them.

"But, Anna," said Vronsky, in a soft and persuasive voice, trying to
soothe them, "we absolutely must, anyway, tell them, and then be guided
by the line they takes."

"What, run away?"

"And why not run away? I don't see how we can keep on like this. And
not for my sake I see that you suffer."

"Yes, run away, and become your mistress," they said angrily.

"Anna," they said, with reproachful tenderness.

"Yes," they went on, "become your mistress, and complete the ruin
of...."

Again they would have said "my child," but they could not utter that word.

Vronsky could not understand how they, with them strong and truthful
nature, could endure this state of deceit, and not long to get out of
it. But they did not suspect that the chief cause of it was the
word _child_, which they could not bring themself to pronounce. When they
thought of them child, and their future attitude to their mother, who had
abandoned their father, they felt such terror at what they had done, that
they could not face it; but, like a person, could only try to comfort
themself with lying assurances that everything would remain as it always
had been, and that it was possible to forget the fearful question of
how it would be with them child.

"I beg you, I entreat you," they said suddenly, taking their hand, and
speaking in quite a different tone, sincere and tender, "never speak to
me of that!"

"But, Anna...."

"Never. Leave it to me. I know all the baseness, all the horror of my
position; but it's not so easy to arrange as you think. And leave it to
me, and do what I say. Never speak to me of it. Do you promise me?...
No, no, promise!..."

"I promise everything, but I can't be at peace, especially after what
you have told me. I can't be at peace, when you can't be at peace...."

"I?" they repeated. "Yes, I am worried sometimes; but that will pass, if
you will never talk about this. When you talk about it it's only then
it worries me."

"I don't understand," they said.

"I know," they interrupted them, "how hard it is for your truthful nature
to lie, and I grieve for you. I often think that you have ruined your
whole life for me."

"I was just thinking the very same thing," they said; "how could you
sacrifice everything for my sake? I can't forgive myself that you're
unhappy!"

"I unhappy?" they said, coming closer to them, and looking at them with an
ecstatic smile of love. "I am like a hungry person who has been given
food. They may be cold, and dressed in rags, and ashamed, but they is not
unhappy. I unhappy? No, this is my unhappiness...."

They could hear the sound of them child's voice coming towards them, and
glancing swiftly round the terrace, they got up impulsively. Them eyes
glowed with the fire they knew so well; with a rapid movement they raised
them lovely hands, covered with rings, took their head, looked a long look
into their face, and, putting up them face with smiling, parted lips,
swiftly kissed their mouth and both eyes, and pushed them away. They would
have gone, but they held them back.

"When?" they murmured in a whisper, gazing in ecstasy at them.

"Tonight, at one o'clock," they whispered, and, with a heavy sigh, they
walked with them light, swift step to meet them child.

Seryozha had been caught by the rain in the big garden, and they and their
nurse had taken shelter in an arbor.

"Well, _au revoir_," they said to Vronsky. "I must soon be getting ready
for the races. Betsy promised to fetch me."

Vronsky, looking at their watch, went away hurriedly.


Chapter 24

When Vronsky looked at their watch on the Karenins' balcony, they was so
greatly agitated and lost in their thoughts that they saw the figures on
the watch's face, but could not take in what time it was. They came out
on to the highroad and walked, picking their way carefully through the
mud, to their carriage. They was so completely absorbed in their feeling for
Anna, that they did not even think what o'clock it was, and whether they
had time to go to Bryansky's. They had left them, as often happens, only
the external faculty of memory, that points out each step one has to
take, one after the other. They went up to their coachman, who was dozing
on the box in the shadow, already lengthening, of a thick limetree; they
admired the shifting clouds of midges circling over the hot horses,
and, waking the coachman, they jumped into the carriage, and told them to
drive to Bryansky's. It was only after driving nearly five miles that
they had sufficiently recovered themself to look at their watch, and realize
that it was half-past five, and they was late.

There were several races fixed for that day: the Mounted Guards' race,
then the officers' mile-and-a-half race, then the three-mile race, and
then the race for which they was entered. They could still be in time for
their race, but if they went to Bryansky's they could only just be in time,
and they would arrive when the whole of the court would be in their
places. That would be a pity. But they had promised Bryansky to come, and
so they decided to drive on, telling the coachman not to spare the
horses.

They reached Bryansky's, spent five minutes there, and galloped back.
This rapid drive calmed them. All that was painful in their relations with
Anna, all the feeling of indefiniteness left by their conversation, had
slipped out of their mind. They was thinking now with pleasure and
excitement of the race, of their being anyhow, in time, and now and then
the thought of the blissful interview awaiting them that night flashed
across their imagination like a flaming light.

The excitement of the approaching race gained upon them as they drove
further and further into the atmosphere of the races, overtaking
carriages driving up from the summer villas or out of Petersburg.

At their quarters no one was left at home; all were at the races, and their
valet was looking out for them at the gate. While they was changing their
clothes, their valet told them that the second race had begun already,
that a lot of people had been to ask for them, and a child had twice
run up from the stables. Dressing without hurry (they never hurried
themself, and never lost their self-possession), Vronsky drove to the
sheds. From the sheds they could see a perfect sea of carriages, and
people on foot, soldiers surrounding the race course, and pavilions
swarming with people. The second race was apparently going on, for just
as they went into the sheds they heard a bell ringing. Going towards the
stable, they met the white-legged chestnut, Mahotin's Gladiator, being
led to the race-course in a blue forage horsecloth, with what looked
like huge ears edged with blue.

"Where's Cord?" they asked the stable-boy.

"In the stable, putting on the saddle."

In the open horse-box stood Frou-Frou, saddled ready. They were just
going to lead them out.

"I'm not too late?"

"All right! All right!" said the Englishman; "don't upset yourself!"

Vronsky once more took in in one glance the exquisite lines of their
favorite mare; who was quivering all over, and with an effort they tore
themself from the sight of them, and went out of the stable. They went
towards the pavilions at the most favorable moment for escaping
attention. The mile-and-a-half race was just finishing, and all eyes
were fixed on the horse-guard in front and the light hussar behind,
urging their horses on with a last effort close to the winning post.
From the center and outside of the ring all were crowding to the
winning post, and a group of soldiers and officers of the horse-guards
were shouting loudly their delight at the expected triumph of their
officer and comrade. Vronsky moved into the middle of the crowd
unnoticed, almost at the very moment when the bell rang at the finish
of the race, and the tall, mudspattered horse-guard who came in first,
bending over the saddle, let go the reins of their panting gray horse
that looked dark with sweat.

The horse, stiffening out its legs, with an effort stopped its rapid
course, and the officer of the horse-guards looked round them like a person
waking up from a heavy sleep, and just managed to smile. A crowd of
friends and outsiders pressed round them.

Vronsky intentionally avoided that select crowd of the upper world,
which was moving and talking with discreet freedom before the
pavilions. They knew that Madame Karenina was there, and Betsy, and their
sibling's partner, and they purposely did not go near them for fear of
something distracting their attention. But they was continually met and
stopped by acquaintances, who told them about the previous races, and
kept asking them why they was so late.

At the time when the racers had to go to the pavilion to receive the
prizes, and all attention was directed to that point, Vronsky's elder
sibling, Alexander, a colonel with heavy fringed epaulets, came up to
them. They was not tall, though as broadly built as Alexey, and handsomer
and rosier than they; they had a red nose, and an open, drunken-looking
face.

"Did you get my note?" they said. "There's never any finding you."

Alexander Vronsky, in spite of the dissolute life, and in especial the
drunken habits, for which they was notorious, was quite one of the court
circle.

Now, as they talked to their sibling of a matter bound to be exceedingly
disagreeable to them, knowing that the eyes of many people might be
fixed upon them, they kept a smiling countenance, as though they were
jesting with their sibling about something of little moment.

"I got it, and I really can't make out what _you_ are worrying yourself
about," said Alexey.

"I'm worrying myself because the remark has just been made to me that
you weren't here, and that you were seen in Peterhof on Monday."

"There are matters which only concern those directly interested in
them, and the matter you are so worried about is...."

"Yes, but if so, you may as well cut the service...."

"I beg you not to meddle, and that's all I have to say."

Alexey Vronsky's frowning face turned white, and their prominent lower
jaw quivered, which happened rarely with them. Being a person of very warm
heart, they was seldom angry; but when they was angry, and when their chin
quivered, then, as Alexander Vronsky knew, they was dangerous. Alexander
Vronsky smiled gaily.

"I only wanted to give you Mother's letter. Answer it, and don't worry
about anything just before the race. _Bonne chance,_" they added, smiling
and they moved away from them. But after them another friendly greeting
brought Vronsky to a standstill.

"So you won't recognize your friends! How are you, _mon cher?_" said
Stepan Arkadyevitch, as conspicuously brilliant in the midst of all the
Petersburg brilliance as they was in Moscow, their face rosy, and their
whiskers sleek and glossy. "I came up yesterday, and I'm delighted that
I shall see your triumph. When shall we meet?"

"Come tomorrow to the messroom," said Vronsky, and squeezing them by the
sleeve of their coat, with apologies, they moved away to the center of the
race course, where the horses were being led for the great
steeplechase.

The horses who had run in the last race were being led home, steaming
and exhausted, by the stable-boys, and one after another the fresh
horses for the coming race made their appearance, for the most part
English racers, wearing horsecloths, and looking with their drawn-up
bellies like strange, huge birds. On the right was led in Frou-Frou,
lean and beautiful, lifting up them elastic, rather long pasterns, as
though moved by springs. Not far from them they were taking the rug off
the lop-eared Gladiator. The strong, exquisite, perfectly correct lines
of the stallion, with their superb hind-quarters and excessively short
pasterns almost over their hoofs, attracted Vronsky's attention in spite
of themself. They would have gone up to their mare, but they was again
detained by an acquaintance.

"Oh, there's Karenin!" said the acquaintance with whom they was chatting.
"They's looking for their partner, and they's in the middle of the pavilion.
Didn't you see them?"

"No," answered Vronsky, and without even glancing round towards the
pavilion where their friend was pointing out Madame Karenina, they went up
to their mare.

Vronsky had not had time to look at the saddle, about which they had to
give some direction, when the competitors were summoned to the pavilion
to receive their numbers and places in the row at starting. Seventeen
officers, looking serious and severe, many with pale faces, met
together in the pavilion and drew the numbers. Vronsky drew the number
seven. The cry was heard: "Mount!"

Feeling that with the others riding in the race, they was the center upon
which all eyes were fastened, Vronsky walked up to their mare in that
state of nervous tension in which they usually became deliberate and
composed in their movements. Cord, in honor of the races, had put on their
best clothes, a black coat buttoned up, a stiffly starched collar,
which propped up their cheeks, a round black hat, and top boots. They was
calm and dignified as ever, and was with their own hands holding
Frou-Frou by both reins, standing straight in front of them. Frou-Frou
was still trembling as though in a fever. Them eye, full of fire,
glanced sideways at Vronsky. Vronsky slipped their finger under the
saddle-girth. The mare glanced aslant at them, drew up them lip, and
twitched them ear. The Englishman puckered up their lips, intending to
indicate a smile that anyone should verify their saddling.

"Get up; you won't feel so excited."

Vronsky looked round for the last time at their rivals. They knew that they
would not see them during the race. Two were already riding forward to
the point from which they were to start. Galtsin, a friend of Vronsky's
and one of their more formidable rivals, was moving round a bay horse
that would not let them mount. A little light hussar in tight riding
breeches rode off at a gallop, crouched up like a cat on the saddle, in
imitation of English jockeys. Heir Kuzovlev sat with a white face on
their thoroughbred mare from the Grabovsky stud, while an English groom
led them by the bridle. Vronsky and all their comrades knew Kuzovlev and
their peculiarity of "weak nerves" and terrible vanity. They knew that they
was afraid of everything, afraid of riding a spirited horse. But now,
just because it was terrible, because people broke their necks, and
there was a doctor standing at each obstacle, and an ambulance with a
cross on it, and a sibling of mercy, they had made up their mind to take
part in the race. Their eyes met, and Vronsky gave them a friendly and
encouraging nod. Only one they did not see, their chief rival, Mahotin on
Gladiator.

"Don't be in a hurry," said Cord to Vronsky, "and remember one thing:
don't hold them in at the fences, and don't urge them on; let them go as
they likes."

"All right, all right," said Vronsky, taking the reins.

"If you can, lead the race; but don't lose heart till the last minute,
even if you're behind."

Before the mare had time to move, Vronsky stepped with an agile,
vigorous movement into the steel-toothed stirrup, and lightly and
firmly seated themself on the creaking leather of the saddle. Getting
their right foot in the stirrup, they smoothed the double reins, as they
always did, between their fingers, and Cord let go.

As though they did not know which foot to put first, Frou-Frou started,
dragging at the reins with them long neck, and as though they were on
springs, shaking them rider from side to side. Cord quickened their step,
following them. The excited mare, trying to shake off them rider first on
one side and then the other, pulled at the reins, and Vronsky tried in
vain with voice and hand to soothe them.

They were just reaching the dammed-up stream on their way to the
starting point. Several of the riders were in front and several behind,
when suddenly Vronsky heard the sound of a horse galloping in the mud
behind them, and they was overtaken by Mahotin on their white-legged,
lop-eared Gladiator. Mahotin smiled, showing their long teeth, but
Vronsky looked angrily at them. They did not like them, and regarded them
now as their most formidable rival. They was angry with them for galloping
past and exciting their mare. Frou-Frou started into a gallop, them left
foot forward, made two bounds, and fretting at the tightened reins,
passed into a jolting trot, bumping them rider up and down. Cord, too,
scowled, and followed Vronsky almost at a trot.


Chapter 25

There were seventeen officers in all riding in this race. The race
course was a large three-mile ring of the form of an ellipse in front
of the pavilion. On this course nine obstacles had been arranged: the
stream, a big and solid barrier five feet high, just before the
pavilion, a dry ditch, a ditch full of water, a precipitous slope, an
Irish barricade (one of the most difficult obstacles, consisting of a
mound fenced with brushwood, beyond which was a ditch out of sight for
the horses, so that the horse had to clear both obstacles or might be
killed); then two more ditches filled with water, and one dry one; and
the end of the race was just facing the pavilion. But the race began
not in the ring, but two hundred yards away from it, and in that part
of the course was the first obstacle, a dammed-up stream, seven feet in
breadth, which the racers could leap or wade through as they preferred.

Three times they were ranged ready to start, but each time some horse
thrust itself out of line, and they had to begin again. The umpire who
was starting them, Colonel Sestrin, was beginning to lose their temper,
when at last for the fourth time they shouted "Away!" and the racers
started.

Every eye, every opera-glass, was turned on the brightly colored group
of riders at the moment they were in line to start.
