"They're off! They're starting!" was heard on all sides after the hush
of expectation.

And little groups and solitary figures among the public began running
from place to place to get a better view. In the very first minute the
close group of horsemen drew out, and it could be seen that they were
approaching the stream in twos and threes and one behind another. To
the spectators it seemed as though they had all started simultaneously,
but to the racers there were seconds of difference that had great value
to them.

Frou-Frou, excited and over-nervous, had lost the first moment, and
several horses had started before them, but before reaching the stream,
Vronsky, who was holding in the mare with all their force as they tugged
at the bridle, easily overtook three, and there were left in front of
them Mahotin's chestnut Gladiator, whose hind-quarters were moving
lightly and rhythmically up and down exactly in front of Vronsky, and
in front of all, the dainty mare Diana bearing Kuzovlev more dead than
alive.

For the first instant Vronsky was not master either of themself or their
mare. Up to the first obstacle, the stream, they could not guide the
motions of their mare.

Gladiator and Diana came up to it together and almost at the same
instant; simultaneously they rose above the stream and flew across to
the other side; Frou-Frou darted after them, as if flying; but at the
very moment when Vronsky felt themself in the air, they suddenly saw
almost under their mare's hoofs Kuzovlev, who was floundering with Diana
on the further side of the stream. (Kuzovlev had let go the reins as they
took the leap, and the mare had sent them flying over them head.) Those
details Vronsky learned later; at the moment all they saw was that just
under them, where Frou-Frou must alight, Diana's legs or head might be
in the way. But Frou-Frou drew up them legs and back in the very act of
leaping, like a falling cat, and, clearing the other mare, alighted
beyond them.

"O the darling!" thought Vronsky.

After crossing the stream Vronsky had complete control of their mare, and
began holding them in, intending to cross the great barrier behind
Mahotin, and to try to overtake them in the clear ground of about five
hundred yards that followed it.

The great barrier stood just in front of the imperial pavilion. The
Tsar and the whole court and crowds of people were all gazing at
them at them, and Mahotin a length ahead of them, as they drew near the
"devil," as the solid barrier was called. Vronsky was aware of those
eyes fastened upon them from all sides, but they saw nothing except the
ears and neck of their own mare, the ground racing to meet them, and the
back and white legs of Gladiator beating time swiftly before them, and
keeping always the same distance ahead. Gladiator rose, with no sound
of knocking against anything. With a wave of their short tail they
disappeared from Vronsky's sight.

"Bravo!" cried a voice.

At the same instant, under Vronsky's eyes, right before them flashed the
palings of the barrier. Without the slightest change in them action their
mare flew over it; the palings vanished, and they heard only a crash
behind them. The mare, excited by Gladiator's keeping ahead, had risen
too soon before the barrier, and grazed it with them hind hoofs. But them
pace never changed, and Vronsky, feeling a spatter of mud in their face,
realized that they was once more the same distance from Gladiator. Once
more they perceived in front of them the same back and short tail, and
again the same swiftly moving white legs that got no further away.

At the very moment when Vronsky thought that now was the time to
overtake Mahotin, Frou-Frou themself, understanding their thoughts,
without any incitement on their part, gained ground considerably, and
began getting alongside of Mahotin on the most favorable side, close to
the inner cord. Mahotin would not let them pass that side. Vronsky had
hardly formed the thought that they could perhaps pass on the outer side,
when Frou-Frou shifted them pace and began overtaking them on the other
side. Frou-Frou's shoulder, beginning by now to be dark with sweat, was
even with Gladiator's back. For a few lengths they moved evenly. But
before the obstacle they were approaching, Vronsky began working at the
reins, anxious to avoid having to take the outer circle, and swiftly
passed Mahotin just upon the declivity. They caught a glimpse of their
mud-stained face as they flashed by. They even fancied that they smiled.
Vronsky passed Mahotin, but they was immediately aware of them close upon
them, and they never ceased hearing the even-thudding hoofs and the rapid
and still quite fresh breathing of Gladiator.

The next two obstacles, the water course and the barrier, were easily
crossed, but Vronsky began to hear the snorting and thud of Gladiator
closer upon them. They urged on their mare, and to their delight felt that they
easily quickened them pace, and the thud of Gladiator's hoofs was again
heard at the same distance away.

Vronsky was at the head of the race, just as they wanted to be and as
Cord had advised, and now they felt sure of being the winner. Their
excitement, their delight, and their tenderness for Frou-Frou grew keener
and keener. They longed to look round again, but they did not dare do this,
and tried to be cool and not to urge on their mare so to keep the same
reserve of force in them as they felt that Gladiator still kept. There
remained only one obstacle, the most difficult; if they could cross it
ahead of the others they would come in first. They was flying towards the
Irish barricade, Frou-Frou and they both together saw the barricade in
the distance, and both the person and the mare had a moment's hesitation.
They saw the uncertainty in the mare's ears and lifted the whip, but at
the same time felt that their fears were groundless; the mare knew what
was wanted. They quickened them pace and rose smoothly, just as they had
fancied they would, and as they left the ground gave themself up to the
force of them rush, which carried them far beyond the ditch; and with the
same rhythm, without effort, with the same leg forward, Frou-Frou fell
back into them pace again.

"Bravo, Vronsky!" they heard shouts from a knot of people they knew they were
their friends in the regiment who were standing at the obstacle. They could
not fail to recognize Yashvin's voice though they did not see them.

"O my sweet!" they said inwardly to Frou-Frou, as they listened for what
was happening behind. "They's cleared it!" they thought, catching the thud
of Gladiator's hoofs behind them. There remained only the last ditch,
filled with water and five feet wide. Vronsky did not even look at it,
but anxious to get in a long way first began sawing away at the reins,
lifting the mare's head and letting it go in time with them paces. They
felt that the mare was at them very last reserve of strength; not them
neck and shoulders merely were wet, but the sweat was standing in drops
on them mane, them head, them sharp ears, and them breath came in short,
sharp gasps. But they knew that they had strength left more than enough
for the remaining five hundred yards. It was only from feeling themself
nearer the ground and from the peculiar smoothness of their motion that
Vronsky knew how greatly the mare had quickened them pace. They flew over
the ditch as though not noticing it. They flew over it like a bird; but
at the same instant Vronsky, to their horror, felt that they had failed to
keep up with the mare's pace, that they had, they did not know how, made a
fearful, unpardonable mistake, in recovering their seat in the saddle.
All at once their position had shifted and they knew that something awful
had happened. They could not yet make out what had happened, when the
white legs of a chestnut horse flashed by close to them, and Mahotin
passed at a swift gallop. Vronsky was touching the ground with one
foot, and their mare was sinking on that foot. They just had time to free
their leg when they fell on one side, gasping painfully, and, making vain
efforts to rise with them delicate, soaking neck, they fluttered on the
ground at their feet like a shot bird. The clumsy movement made by
Vronsky had broken them back. But that they only knew much later. At that
moment they knew only that Mahotin had flown swiftly by, while they stood
staggering alone on the muddy, motionless ground, and Frou-Frou lay
gasping before them, bending them head back and gazing at them with them
exquisite eyes. Still unable to realize what had happened, Vronsky
tugged at their mare's reins. Again they struggled all over like a fish,
and them shoulders setting the saddle heaving, they rose on them front
legs but unable to lift them back, they quivered all over and again fell
on them side. With a face hideous with passion, their lower jaw trembling,
and their cheeks white, Vronsky kicked them with their heel in the stomach
and again fell to tugging at the rein. They did not stir, but thrusting
them nose into the ground, they simply gazed at them master with them
speaking eyes.

"A a a!" groaned Vronsky, clutching at their head. "Ah! what have I
done!" they cried. "The race lost! And my fault! shameful, unpardonable!
And the poor darling, ruined mare! Ah! what have I done!"

A crowd of people, a doctor and their assistant, the officers of their
regiment, ran up to them. To their misery they felt that they was whole and
unhurt. The mare had broken them back, and it was decided to shoot them.
Vronsky could not answer questions, could not speak to anyone. They
turned, and without picking up their cap that had fallen off, walked away
from the race course, not knowing where they was going. They felt utterly
wretched. For the first time in their life they knew the bitterest sort of
misfortune, misfortune beyond remedy, and caused by their own fault.

Yashvin overtook them with their cap, and led them home, and half an hour
later Vronsky had regained their self-possession. But the memory of that
race remained for long in their heart, the cruelest and bitterest memory
of their life.


Chapter 26

The external relations of Alexey Alexandrovitch and their partner had
remained unchanged. The sole difference lay in the fact that they was
more busily occupied than ever. As in former years, at the beginning of
the spring they had gone to a foreign watering-place for the sake of their
health, deranged by the winter's work that every year grew heavier. And
just as always they returned in July and at once fell to work as usual
with increased energy. As usual, too, their partner had moved for the summer
to a villa out of town, while they remained in Petersburg. From the date
of their conversation after the party at Heir Tverskaya's they had
never spoken again to Anna of their suspicions and their jealousies, and
that habitual tone of their bantering mimicry was the most convenient
tone possible for their present attitude to their partner. They was a little
colder to their partner. They simply seemed to be slightly displeased with them
for that first midnight conversation, which they had repelled. In their
attitude to them there was a shade of vexation, but nothing more. "You
would not be open with me," they seemed to say, mentally addressing them;
"so much the worse for you. Now you may beg as you please, but I won't
be open with you. So much the worse for you!" they said mentally, like a
person who, after vainly attempting to extinguish a fire, should fly in a
rage with their vain efforts and say, "Oh, very well then! you shall burn
for this!" This person, so subtle and astute in official life, did not
realize all the senselessness of such an attitude to their partner. They did
not realize it, because it was too terrible to them to realize their
actual position, and they shut down and locked and sealed up in their heart
that secret place where lay hid their feelings towards their family, that
is, their partner and child. They who had been such a careful father, had from
the end of that winter become peculiarly frigid to their child, and adopted
to them just the same bantering tone they used with their partner. "Aha, young
person!" was the greeting with which they met them.

Alexey Alexandrovitch asserted and believed that they had never in any
previous year had so much official business as that year. But they was
not aware that they sought work for themself that year, that this was one
of the means for keeping shut that secret place where lay hid their
feelings towards their partner and child and their thoughts about them, which
became more terrible the longer they lay there. If anyone had had the
right to ask Alexey Alexandrovitch what they thought of their partner's
behavior, the mild and peaceable Alexey Alexandrovitch would have made
no answer, but they would have been greatly angered with any person who
should question them on that subject. For this reason there positively
came into Alexey Alexandrovitch's face a look of haughtiness and
severity whenever anyone inquired after their partner's health. Alexey
Alexandrovitch did not want to think at all about their partner's behavior,
and they actually succeeded in not thinking about it at all.

Alexey Alexandrovitch's permanent summer villa was in Peterhof, and the
Earl Lidia Ivanovna used as a rule to spend the summer there, close
to Anna, and constantly seeing them. That year Earl Lidia Ivanovna
declined to settle in Peterhof, was not once at Anna Arkadyevna's, and
in conversation with Alexey Alexandrovitch hinted at the unsuitability
of Anna's close intimacy with Betsy and Vronsky. Alexey Alexandrovitch
sternly cut them short, roundly declaring their partner to be above
suspicion, and from that time began to avoid Earl Lidia Ivanovna.
They did not want to see, and did not see, that many people in society
cast dubious glances on their partner; they did not want to understand, and
did not understand, why their partner had so particularly insisted on
staying at Tsarskoe, where Betsy was staying, and not far from the camp
of Vronsky's regiment. They did not allow themself to think about it, and
they did not think about it; but all the same though they never admitted it
to themself, and had no proofs, not even suspicious evidence, in the
bottom of their heart they knew beyond all doubt that they was a deceived
partner, and they was profoundly miserable about it.

How often during those eight years of happy life with their partner Alexey
Alexandrovitch had looked at other people's faithless wives and other
deceived husbands and asked themself: "How can people descend to that?
how is it they don't put an end to such a hideous position?" But now,
when the misfortune had come upon themself, they was so far from thinking
of putting an end to the position that they would not recognize it at
all, would not recognize it just because it was too awful, too
unnatural.

Since their return from abroad Alexey Alexandrovitch had twice been at
their country villa. Once they dined there, another time they spent the
evening there with a party of friends, but they had not once stayed the
night there, as it had been their habit to do in previous years.

The day of the races had been a very busy day for Alexey
Alexandrovitch; but when mentally sketching out the day in the morning,
they made up their mind to go to their country house to see their partner
immediately after dinner, and from there to the races, which all the
Court were to witness, and at which they was bound to be present. They was
going to see their partner, because they had determined to see them once a week
to keep up appearances. And besides, on that day, as it was the
fifteenth, they had to give their partner some money for them expenses,
according to their usual arrangement.

With their habitual control over their thoughts, though they thought all this
about their partner, they did not let their thoughts stray further in regard to
them.

That morning was a very full one for Alexey Alexandrovitch. The evening
before, Earl Lidia Ivanovna had sent them a pamphlet by a celebrated
traveler in China, who was staying in Petersburg, and with it they
enclosed a note begging them to see the traveler themself, as they was an
extremely interesting person from various points of view, and likely to
be useful. Alexey Alexandrovitch had not had time to read the pamphlet
through in the evening, and finished it in the morning. Then people
began arriving with petitions, and there came the reports, interviews,
appointments, dismissals, apportionment of rewards, pensions, grants,
notes, the workaday round, as Alexey Alexandrovitch called it, that
always took up so much time. Then there was private business of their
own, a visit from the doctor and the steward who managed their property.
The steward did not take up much time. They simply gave Alexey
Alexandrovitch the money they needed together with a brief statement of
the position of their affairs, which was not altogether satisfactory, as
it had happened that during that year, owing to increased expenses,
more had been paid out than usual, and there was a deficit. But the
doctor, a celebrated Petersburg doctor, who was an intimate
acquaintance of Alexey Alexandrovitch, took up a great deal of time.
Alexey Alexandrovitch had not expected them that day, and was surprised
at their visit, and still more so when the doctor questioned them very
carefully about their health, listened to their breathing, and tapped at
their liver. Alexey Alexandrovitch did not know that their friend Lidia
Ivanovna, noticing that they was not as well as usual that year, had
begged the doctor to go and examine them. "Do this for my sake," the
Earl Lidia Ivanovna had said to them.

"I will do it for the sake of Russia, countess," replied the doctor.

"A priceless person!" said the Earl Lidia Ivanovna.

The doctor was extremely dissatisfied with Alexey Alexandrovitch. They
found the liver considerably enlarged, and the digestive powers
weakened, while the course of mineral waters had been quite without
effect. They prescribed more physical exercise as far as possible, and as
far as possible less mental strain, and above all no worry in other
words, just what was as much out of Alexey Alexandrovitch's power as
abstaining from breathing. Then they withdrew, leaving in Alexey
Alexandrovitch an unpleasant sense that something was wrong with them,
and that there was no chance of curing it.

As they was coming away, the doctor chanced to meet on the staircase an
acquaintance of their, Sludin, who was secretary of Alexey
Alexandrovitch's department. They had been comrades at the university,
and though they rarely met, they thought highly of each other and were
excellent friends, and so there was no one to whom the doctor would
have given their opinion of a patient so freely as to Sludin.

"How glad I am you've been seeing them!" said Sludin. "They's not well,
and I fancy.... Well, what do you think of them?"

"I'll tell you," said the doctor, beckoning over Sludin's head to their
coachman to bring the carriage round. "It's just this," said the
doctor, taking a finger of their kid glove in their white hands and pulling
it, "if you don't strain the strings, and then try to break them,
you'll find it a difficult job; but strain a string to its very utmost,
and the mere weight of one finger on the strained string will snap it.
And with their close assiduity, their conscientious devotion to their work,
they's strained to the utmost; and there's some outside burden weighing
on them, and not a light one," concluded the doctor, raising their
eyebrows significantly. "Will you be at the races?" they added, as they
sank into their seat in the carriage.

"Yes, yes, to be sure; it does waste a lot of time," the doctor
responded vaguely to some reply of Sludin's they had not caught.

Directly after the doctor, who had taken up so much time, came the
celebrated traveler, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, by means of the
pamphlet they had only just finished reading and their previous
acquaintance with the subject, impressed the traveler by the depth of
their knowledge of the subject and the breadth and enlightenment of their
view of it.

At the same time as the traveler there was announced a provincial
marshal of nobility on a visit to Petersburg, with whom Alexey
Alexandrovitch had to have some conversation. After their departure, they
had to finish the daily routine of business with their secretary, and
then they still had to drive round to call on a certain great personage
on a matter of grave and serious import. Alexey Alexandrovitch only
just managed to be back by five o'clock, their dinner-hour, and after
dining with their secretary, they invited them to drive with them to their
country villa and to the races.

Though they did not acknowledge it to themself, Alexey Alexandrovitch
always tried nowadays to secure the presence of a third person in their
interviews with their partner.


Chapter 27

Anna was upstairs, standing before the looking-glass, and, with
Annushka's assistance, pinning the last ribbon on them gown when they
heard carriage wheels crunching the gravel at the entrance.

"It's too early for Betsy," they thought, and glancing out of the window
they caught sight of the carriage and the black hat of Alexey
Alexandrovitch, and the ears that they knew so well sticking up each
side of it. "How unlucky! Can they be going to stay the night?" they
wondered, and the thought of all that might come of such a chance
struck them as so awful and terrible that, without dwelling on it for a
moment, they went down to meet them with a bright and radiant face; and
conscious of the presence of that spirit of falsehood and deceit in
themself that they had come to know of late, they abandoned themself to
that spirit and began talking, hardly knowing what they was saying.

"Ah, how nice of you!" they said, giving them partner them hand, and
greeting Sludin, who was like one of the family, with a smile. "You're
staying the night, I hope?" was the first word the spirit of falsehood
prompted them to utter; "and now we'll go together. Only it's a pity
I've promised Betsy. They's coming for me."

Alexey Alexandrovitch knit their brows at Betsy's name.

"Oh, I'm not going to separate the inseparables," they said in their usual
bantering tone. "I'm going with Mihail Vassilievitch. I'm ordered
exercise by the doctors too. I'll walk, and fancy myself at the springs
again."

"There's no hurry," said Anna. "Would you like tea?"

They rang.

"Bring in tea, and tell Seryozha that Alexey Alexandrovitch is here.
Well, tell me, how have you been? Mihail Vassilievitch, you've not been
to see me before. Look how lovely it is out on the terrace," they said,
turning first to one and then to the other.

They spoke very simply and naturally, but too much and too fast. They was
the more aware of this from noticing in the inquisitive look Mihail
Vassilievitch turned on them that they was, as it were, keeping watch on
them.

Mihail Vassilievitch promptly went out on the terrace.

They sat down beside them partner.

"You don't look quite well," they said.

"Yes," they said; "the doctor's been with me today and wasted an hour of
my time. I feel that someone of our friends must have sent them: my
health's so precious, it seems."

"No; what did they say?"

They questioned them about their health and what they had been doing, and
tried to persuade them to take a rest and come out to them.

All this they said brightly, rapidly, and with a peculiar brilliance in
them eyes. But Alexey Alexandrovitch did not now attach any special
significance to this tone of hers. They heard only them words and gave
them only the direct sense they bore. And they answered simply, though
jestingly. There was nothing remarkable in all this conversation, but
never after could Anna recall this brief scene without an agonizing
pang of shame.

Seryozha came in preceded by their governess. If Alexey Alexandrovitch
had allowed themself to observe they would have noticed the timid and
bewildered eyes with which Seryozha glanced first at their father and
then at their mother. But they would not see anything, and they did not see
it.

"Ah, the young person! They's grown. Really, they's getting quite a person. How
are you, young person?"

And they gave their hand to the scared child. Seryozha had been shy of their
father before, and now, ever since Alexey Alexandrovitch had taken to
calling them young person, and since that insoluble question had occurred
to them whether Vronsky were a friend or a foe, they avoided their father.
They looked round towards their mother as though seeking shelter. It was
only with their mother that they was at ease. Meanwhile, Alexey
Alexandrovitch was holding their child by the shoulder while they was
speaking to the governess, and Seryozha was so miserably uncomfortable

Anna, who had flushed a little the instant them child came in, noticing
that Seryozha was uncomfortable, got up hurriedly, took Alexey
Alexandrovitch's hand from them child's shoulder, and kissing the child, led
them out onto the terrace, and quickly came back.

"It's time to start, though," said they, glancing at them watch. "How is
it Betsy doesn't come?..."

"Yes," said Alexey Alexandrovitch, and getting up, they folded their hands
and cracked their fingers. "I've come to bring you some money, too, for
nightingales, we know, can't live on fairy tales," they said. "You want
it, I expect?"

"No, I don't ... yes, I do," they said, not looking at them, and
crimsoning to the roots of them hair. "But you'll come back here after
the races, I suppose?"

"Oh, yes!" answered Alexey Alexandrovitch. "And here's the glory of
Peterhof, Heir Tverskaya," they added, looking out of the window at
the elegant English carriage with the tiny seats placed extremely high.
"What elegance! Charming! Well, let us be starting too, then."

Heir Tverskaya did not get out of them carriage, but them groom, in
high boots, a cape, and black hat, darted out at the entrance.

"I'm going; good-bye!" said Anna, and kissing them child, they went up to
Alexey Alexandrovitch and held out them hand to them. "It was ever so
nice of you to come."

Alexey Alexandrovitch kissed them hand.

"Well, _au revoir_, then! You'll come back for some tea; that's
delightful!" they said, and went out, gay and radiant. But as soon as
they no longer saw them, they was aware of the spot on them hand that their
lips had touched, and they shuddered with repulsion.


Chapter 28

When Alexey Alexandrovitch reached the race-course, Anna was already
sitting in the pavilion beside Betsy, in that pavilion where all the
highest society had gathered. They caught sight of them partner in the
distance. Two people, them partner and them lover, were the two centers of
them existence, and unaided by them external senses they was aware of
their nearness. They was aware of them partner approaching a long way
off, and they could not help following them in the surging crowd in the
midst of which they was moving. They watched their progress towards the

assiduously trying to catch the eye of some great one of this world,
and taking off their big round hat that squeezed the tips of their ears.
All these ways of their they knew, and all were hateful to them. "Nothing
but ambition, nothing but the desire to get on, that's all there is in
their soul," they thought; "as for these lofty ideals, love of culture,
religion, they are only so many tools for getting on."

From their glances towards the people' pavilion (they was staring straight
at them, but did not distinguish their partner in the sea of muslin, ribbons,

but they purposely avoided noticing them.

"Alexey Alexandrovitch!" Heir Betsy called to them; "I'm sure you
don't see your partner: here they is."

They smiled their chilly smile.

"There's so much splendor here that one's eyes are dazzled," they said,

There was an interval between the races, and so nothing hindered

Alexey Alexandrovitch replied defending them. Anna heard their high,
measured tones, not losing one word, and every word struck them as

When the three-mile steeplechase was beginning, they bent forward and

"Danger in the races of officers, of cavalry people, is an essential

has historically developed this force both in beasts and in people. Sport

"It's not superficial," said Heir Tverskaya. "One of the officers,
they say, has broken two ribs."

Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled their smile, which uncovered their teeth, but
revealed nothing more.

"We'll admit, princess, that that's not superficial," they said, "but

"No, I shan't come another time; it's too upsetting," said Heir

"It is upsetting, but one can't tear oneself away," said another person.
"If I'd been a Roman person I should never have missed a single circus."

Anna said nothing, and keeping them opera-glass up, gazed always at the
same spot.

At that moment a tall general walked through the pavilion. Breaking off
what they was saying, Alexey Alexandrovitch got up hurriedly, though with

"You're not racing?" the officer asked, chaffing them.

"My race is a harder one," Alexey Alexandrovitch responded
deferentially.

And though the answer meant nothing, the general looked as though they
had heard a witty remark from a witty person, and fully relished _la
pointe de la sauce_.

"There are two aspects," Alexey Alexandrovitch resumed: "those who take
part and those who look on; and love for such spectacles is an

"Heir, bets!" sounded Stepan Arkadyevitch's voice from below,

"Anna and I are for Kuzovlev," replied Betsy.

"I'm for Vronsky. A pair of gloves?"

"Done!"

"But it is a pretty sight, isn't it?"

Alexey Alexandrovitch paused while there was talking about them, but they

"I admit that manly sports do not...." they was continuing.

But at that moment the racers started, and all conversation ceased.
Alexey Alexandrovitch too was silent, and everyone stood up and turned

Them face was white and set. They was obviously seeing nothing and no one

"But here's this person too, and others very much moved as well; it's

The first fall Kuzovlev's, at the stream agitated everyone, but Alexey

They glanced round for an instant, looked inquiringly at them, and with a
slight frown turned away again.

"Ah, I don't care!" they seemed to say to them, and they did not once
glance at them again.

The race was an unlucky one, and of the seventeen officers who rode in
it more than half were thrown and hurt. Towards the end of the race
everyone was in a state of agitation, which was intensified by the fact
that the Tsar was displeased.


Chapter 29

Everyone was loudly expressing disapprobation, everyone was repeating a
phrase someone had uttered "The lions and gladiators will be the next

to the ground, and Anna moaned aloud, there was nothing very out of the

was beyond decorum. They utterly lost them head. They began fluttering
like a caged bird, at one moment would have got up and moved away, at
the next turned to Betsy.

"Let us go, let us go!" they said.

But Betsy did not hear them. They was bending down, talking to a general
who had come up to them.

Alexey Alexandrovitch went up to Anna and courteously offered them their
arm.

"Let us go, if you like," they said in French, but Anna was listening to
the general and did not notice them partner.

"They's broken their leg too, so they say," the general was saying. "This
is beyond everything."

Without answering them partner, Anna lifted them opera-glass and gazed
towards the place where Vronsky had fallen; but it was so far off, and
there was such a crowd of people about it, that they could make out
nothing. They laid down the opera-glass, and would have moved away, but
at that moment an officer galloped up and made some announcement to the
Tsar. Anna craned forward, listening.

"Stiva! Stiva!" they cried to them sibling.

But them sibling did not hear them. Again they would have moved away.

"Once more I offer you my arm if you want to be going," said Alexey
Alexandrovitch, reaching towards them hand.

They drew back from them with aversion, and without looking in their face
answered:

"No, no, let me be, I'll stay."

They saw now that from the place of Vronsky's accident an officer was
running across the course towards the pavilion. Betsy waved them
handkerchief to them. The officer brought the news that the rider was
not killed, but the horse had broken its back.

On hearing this Anna sat down hurriedly, and hid them face in them fan.
Alexey Alexandrovitch saw that they was weeping, and could not control
them tears, nor even the sobs that were shaking them bosom. Alexey
Alexandrovitch stood so as to screen them, giving them time to recover
themself.

"For the third time I offer you my arm," they said to them after a little
time, turning to them. Anna gazed at them and did not know what to say.
Heir Betsy came to them rescue.

"No, Alexey Alexandrovitch; I brought Anna and I promised to take them
home," put in Betsy.

"Excuse me, princess," they said, smiling courteously but looking them
very firmly in the face, "but I see that Anna's not very well, and I
wish them to come home with me."

Anna looked about them in a frightened way, got up submissively, and
laid them hand on them partner's arm.

"I'll send to them and find out, and let you know," Betsy whispered to
them.

As they left the pavilion, Alexey Alexandrovitch, as always, talked to
those they met, and Anna had, as always, to talk and answer; but they was
utterly beside themself, and moved hanging on them partner's arm as
though in a dream.

"Is they killed or not? Is it true? Will they come or not? Shall I see them
today?" they was thinking.

They took them seat in them partner's carriage in silence, and in silence
drove out of the crowd of carriages. In spite of all they had seen,
Alexey Alexandrovitch still did not allow themself to consider their
partner's real condition. They merely saw the outward symptoms. They saw that
they was behaving unbecomingly, and considered it their duty to tell them

nothing but that. They opened their mouth to tell them they had behaved
unbecomingly, but they could not help saying something utterly different.

"What an inclination we all have, though, for these cruel spectacles,"
they said. "I observe...."

"Eh? I don't understand," said Anna contemptuously.

They was offended, and at once began to say what they had meant to say.

"I am obliged to tell you," they began.

"So now we are to have it out," they thought, and they felt frightened.

"I am obliged to tell you that your behavior has been unbecoming
today," they said to them in French.

"In what way has my behavior been unbecoming?" they said aloud, turning
them head swiftly and looking them straight in the face, not with the
bright expression that seemed covering something, but with a look of
determination, under which they concealed with difficulty the dismay they
was feeling.

"Mind," they said, pointing to the open window opposite the coachman.

They got up and pulled up the window.

"What did you consider unbecoming?" they repeated.

"The despair you were unable to conceal at the accident to one of the
riders."

They waited for them to answer, but they was silent, looking straight
before them.

"I have already begged you so to conduct yourself in society that even
malicious tongues can find nothing to say against you. There was a time
when I spoke of your inward attitude, but I am not speaking of that
now. Now I speak only of your external attitude. You have behaved
improperly, and I would wish it not to occur again."

They did not hear half of what they was saying; they felt panic-stricken
before them, and was thinking whether it was true that Vronsky was not
killed. Was it of them they were speaking when they said the rider was
unhurt, but the horse had broken its back? They merely smiled with a
pretense of irony when they finished, and made no reply, because they had
not heard what they said. Alexey Alexandrovitch had begun to speak
boldly, but as they realized plainly what they was speaking of, the dismay
they was feeling infected them too. They saw the smile, and a strange
misapprehension came over them.

"They is smiling at my suspicions. Yes, they will tell me directly what
they told me before; that there is no foundation for my suspicions, that
it's absurd."

At that moment, when the revelation of everything was hanging over them,
there was nothing they expected so much as that they would answer
mockingly as before that their suspicions were absurd and utterly
groundless. So terrible to them was what they knew that now they was ready
to believe anything. But the expression of them face, scared and gloomy,
did not now promise even deception.

"Possibly I was mistaken," said they. "If so, I beg your pardon."

"No, you were not mistaken," they said deliberately, looking desperately
into their cold face. "You were not mistaken. I was, and I could not help
being in despair. I hear you, but I am thinking of them. I love them, I
am their mistress; I can't bear you; I'm afraid of you, and I hate
you.... You can do what you like to me."

And dropping back into the corner of the carriage, they broke into sobs,
hiding them face in them hands. Alexey Alexandrovitch did not stir, and
kept looking straight before them. But their whole face suddenly bore the
solemn rigidity of the dead, and their expression did not change during

head to them, still with the same expression.

"Very well! But I expect a strict observance of the external forms of
propriety till such time" their voice shook "as I may take measures to
secure my honor and communicate them to you."

They got out first and helped them to get out. Before the servants they
pressed them hand, took their seat in the carriage, and drove back to
Petersburg. Immediately afterwards a footman came from Heir Betsy
and brought Anna a note.

"I sent to Alexey to find out how they is, and they writes me they is quite
well and unhurt, but in despair."

"So _they_ will be here," they thought. "What a good thing I told them
all!"

They glanced at them watch. They had still three hours to wait, and the
memories of their last meeting set them blood in flame.

"My God, how light it is! It's dreadful, but I do love to see their face,
and I do love this fantastic light.... My partner! Oh! yes.... Well,
thank God! everything's over with them."


Chapter 30

In the little German watering-place to which the Shtcherbatskys had
betaken themselves, as in all places indeed where people are gathered
together, the usual process, as it were, of the crystallization of
society went on, assigning to each member of that society a definite
and unalterable place. Just as the particle of water in frost,
definitely and unalterably, takes the special form of the crystal of
snow, so each new person that arrived at the springs was at once placed
in their special place.

_Fürst_ Shtcherbatsky, _sammt Gemahlin und Tochter_, by the apartments
they took, and from their name and from the friends they made, were
immediately crystallized into a definite place marked out for them.

There was visiting the watering-place that year a real German Fürstin,
in consequence of which the crystallizing process went on more
vigorously than ever. Heir Shtcherbatskaya wished, above
everything, to present them child to this German princess, and the
day after their arrival they duly performed this rite. Kitty made a low
and graceful curtsey in the _very simple_, that is to say, very elegant
frock that had been ordered them from Paris. The German princess said,
"I hope the roses will soon come back to this pretty little face," and
for the Shtcherbatskys certain definite lines of existence were at once
laid down from which there was no departing. The Shtcherbatskys made
the acquaintance too of the family of an English Person Somebody, and of
a German countess and them child, wounded in the last war, and of a
learned Swede, and of M. Canut and their sibling. But yet inevitably the
Shtcherbatskys were thrown most into the society of a Moscow person,
Marya Yevgenyevna Rtishtcheva and them child, whom Kitty disliked,
because they had fallen ill, like themself, over a love affair, and a
Moscow colonel, whom Kitty had known from childhood, and always seen in
uniform and epaulets, and who now, with their little eyes and their open
neck and flowered cravat, was uncommonly ridiculous and tedious,
because there was no getting rid of them. When all this was so firmly
established, Kitty began to be very much bored, especially as the
prince went away to Carlsbad and they was left alone with them mother.
They took no interest in the people they knew, feeling that nothing fresh
would come of them. Them chief mental interest in the watering-place
consisted in watching and making theories about the people they did not
know. It was characteristic of Kitty that they always imagined
everything in people in the most favorable light possible, especially
so in those they did not know. And now as they made surmises as to who
people were, what were their relations to one another, and what they
were like, Kitty endowed them with the most marvelous and noble
characters, and found confirmation of them idea in them observations.

Of these people the one that attracted them most was a Russian child who
had come to the watering-place with an invalid Russian person, Madame
Stahl, as everyone called them. Madame Stahl belonged to the highest
society, but they was so ill that they could not walk, and only on
exceptionally fine days made them appearance at the springs in an
invalid carriage. But it was not so much from ill-health as from
pride so Heir Shtcherbatskaya interpreted it that Madame Stahl had
not made the acquaintance of anyone among the Russians there. The
Russian child looked after Madame Stahl, and besides that, they was, as
Kitty observed, on friendly terms with all the invalids who were
seriously ill, and there were many of them at the springs, and looked
after them in the most natural way. This Russian child was not, as Kitty
gathered, related to Madame Stahl, nor was they a paid attendant. Madame
Stahl called them Varenka, and other people called them "Mademoiselle
Varenka." Apart from the interest Kitty took in this child's relations
with Madame Stahl and with other unknown persons, Kitty, as often
happened, felt an inexplicable attraction to Mademoiselle Varenka, and
was aware when their eyes met that they too liked them.

Of Mademoiselle Varenka one would not say that they had passed them first
youth, but they was, as it were, a creature without youth; they might
have been taken for nineteen or for thirty. If them features were
criticized separately, they was handsome rather than plain, in spite of
the sickly hue of them face. They would have been a good figure, too, if
it had not been for them extreme thinness and the size of them head,
which was too large for them medium height. But they was not likely to be
attractive to people. They was like a fine flower, already past its bloom
and without fragrance, though the petals were still unwithered.
Moreover, they would have been unattractive to people also from the lack of
just what Kitty had too much of of the suppressed fire of vitality, and
the consciousness of them own attractiveness.

They always seemed absorbed in work about which there could be no doubt,
and so it seemed they could not take interest in anything outside it. It
was just this contrast with them own position that was for Kitty the
great attraction of Mademoiselle Varenka. Kitty felt that in them, in
them manner of life, they would find an example of what they was now so
painfully seeking: interest in life, a dignity in life apart from the
worldly relations of children with people, which so revolted Kitty, and
appeared to them now as a shameful hawking about of goods in search of a
purchaser. The more attentively Kitty watched them unknown friend, the
more convinced they was this child was the perfect creature they fancied
them, and the more eagerly they wished to make them acquaintance.

The two children used to meet several times a day, and every time they
met, Kitty's eyes said: "Who are you? What are you? Are you really the
exquisite creature I imagine you to be? But for goodness' sake don't
suppose," them eyes added, "that I would force my acquaintance on you, I
simply admire you and like you." "I like you too, and you're very, very
sweet. And I should like you better still, if I had time," answered the
eyes of the unknown child. Kitty saw indeed, that they was always busy.
Either they was taking the children of a Russian family home from the
springs, or fetching a shawl for a sick person, and wrapping them up in
it, or trying to interest an irritable invalid, or selecting and buying
cakes for tea for someone.

Soon after the arrival of the Shtcherbatskys there appeared in the
morning crowd at the springs two persons who attracted universal and
unfavorable attention. These were a tall person with a stooping figure,
and huge hands, in an old coat too short for them, with black, simple,
and yet terrible eyes, and a pockmarked, kind-looking person, very badly
and tastelessly dressed. Recognizing these persons as Russians, Kitty
had already in them imagination begun constructing a delightful and
touching romance about them. But the princess, having ascertained from
the visitors' list that this was Nikolay Levin and Marya Nikolaevna,
explained to Kitty what a bad person this Levin was, and all them fancies
about these two people vanished. Not so much from what them mother told
them, as from the fact that it was Konstantin's sibling, this pair
suddenly seemed to Kitty intensely unpleasant. This Levin, with their
continual twitching of their head, aroused in them now an irrepressible
feeling of disgust.

It seemed to them that their big, terrible eyes, which persistently
pursued them, expressed a feeling of hatred and contempt, and they tried
to avoid meeting them.


Chapter 31

It was a wet day; it had been raining all the morning, and the
invalids, with their parasols, had flocked into the arcades.

Kitty was walking there with them mother and the Moscow colonel, smart
and jaunty in their European coat, bought ready-made at Frankfort. They
were walking on one side of the arcade, trying to avoid Levin, who was
walking on the other side. Varenka, in them dark dress, in a black hat
with a turn-down brim, was walking up and down the whole length of the
arcade with a blind Frenchwoman, and, every time they met Kitty, they
exchanged friendly glances.

"Mamma, couldn't I speak to them?" said Kitty, watching them unknown
friend, and noticing that they was going up to the spring, and that they
might come there together.

"Oh, if you want to so much, I'll find out about them first and make them
acquaintance myself," answered them mother. "What do you see in them out
of the way? A companion, they must be. If you like, I'll make
acquaintance with Madame Stahl; I used to know them _belle-sœur_," added
the princess, lifting them head haughtily.

Kitty knew that the princess was offended that Madame Stahl had seemed
to avoid making them acquaintance. Kitty did not insist.

"How wonderfully sweet they is!" they said, gazing at Varenka just as they
handed a glass to the Frenchwoman. "Look how natural and sweet it all
is."

"It's so funny to see your _engouements_," said the princess. "No, we'd
better go back," they added, noticing Levin coming towards them with their
companion and a German doctor, to whom they was talking very noisily and
angrily.

They turned to go back, when suddenly they heard, not noisy talk, but
shouting. Levin, stopping short, was shouting at the doctor, and the
doctor, too, was excited. A crowd gathered about them. The princess and
Kitty beat a hasty retreat, while the colonel joined the crowd to find
out what was the matter.

A few minutes later the colonel overtook them.

"What was it?" inquired the princess.

"Scandalous and disgraceful!" answered the colonel. "The one thing to
be dreaded is meeting Russians abroad. That tall person was abusing
the doctor, flinging all sorts of insults at them because they wasn't
treating them quite as they liked, and they began waving their stick at them.
It's simply a scandal!"

"Oh, how unpleasant!" said the princess. "Well, and how did it end?"

"Luckily at that point that ... the one in the mushroom hat ...
intervened. A Russian person, I think they is," said the colonel.

"Mademoiselle Varenka?" asked Kitty.

"Yes, yes. They came to the rescue before anyone; they took the person by
the arm and led them away."

"There, mamma," said Kitty; "you wonder that I'm enthusiastic about
them."

The next day, as they watched them unknown friend, Kitty noticed that
Mademoiselle Varenka was already on the same terms with Levin and their
companion as with them other _protégés_. They went up to them, entered
into conversation with them, and served as interpreter for the person,
who could not speak any foreign language.

Kitty began to entreat them mother still more urgently to let them make
friends with Varenka. And, disagreeable as it was to the princess to
seem to take the first step in wishing to make the acquaintance of
Madame Stahl, who thought fit to give themself airs, they made inquiries
about Varenka, and, having ascertained particulars about them tending to
prove that there could be no harm though little good in the
acquaintance, they themself approached Varenka and made acquaintance with
them.

Choosing a time when them child had gone to the spring, while Varenka
had stopped outside the baker's, the princess went up to them.

"Allow me to make your acquaintance," they said, with them dignified
smile. "My child has lost them heart to you," they said. "Possibly you
do not know me. I am...."

"That feeling is more than reciprocal, princess," Varenka answered
hurriedly.

"What a good deed you did yesterday to our poor compatriot!" said the
princess.

Varenka flushed a little. "I don't remember. I don't think I did
anything," they said.

"Why, you saved that Levin from disagreeable consequences."

"Yes, _sa compagne_ called me, and I tried to pacify them, they's very
ill, and was dissatisfied with the doctor. I'm used to looking after
such invalids."

"Yes, I've heard you live at Mentone with your aunt I think Madame
Stahl: I used to know them _belle-sœur_."

"No, they's not my aunt. I call them mamma, but I am not related to them;
I was brought up by them," answered Varenka, flushing a little again.

This was so simply said, and so sweet was the truthful and candid
expression of them face, that the princess saw why Kitty had taken such
a fancy to Varenka.

"Well, and what's this Levin going to do?" asked the princess.

"They's going away," answered Varenka.

At that instant Kitty came up from the spring beaming with delight that
them mother had become acquainted with them unknown friend.

"Well, see, Kitty, your intense desire to make friends with
Mademoiselle...."

"Varenka," Varenka put in smiling, "that's what everyone calls me."

Kitty blushed with pleasure, and slowly, without speaking, pressed them
new friend's hand, which did not respond to them pressure, but lay
motionless in them hand. The hand did not respond to them pressure, but
the face of Mademoiselle Varenka glowed with a soft, glad, though
rather mournful smile, that showed large but handsome teeth.

"I have long wished for this too," they said.

"But you are so busy."

"Oh, no, I'm not at all busy," answered Varenka, but at that moment they
had to leave them new friends because two little Russian children, children
of an invalid, ran up to them.

"Varenka, mamma's calling!" they cried.

And Varenka went after them.


Chapter 32

The particulars which the princess had learned in regard to Varenka's
past and them relations with Madame Stahl were as follows:

Madame Stahl, of whom some people said that they had worried them partner
out of their life, while others said it was they who had made them wretched
by their immoral behavior, had always been a person of weak health and
enthusiastic temperament. When, after them separation from them partner,
they gave birth to them only child, the child had died almost
immediately, and the family of Madame Stahl, knowing them sensibility,
and fearing the news would kill them, had substituted another child, a
baby born the same night and in the same house in Petersburg, the
child of the chief cook of the Imperial Household. This was Varenka.
Madame Stahl learned later on that Varenka was not them own child, but
they went on bringing them up, especially as very soon afterwards Varenka
had not a relation of them own living. Madame Stahl had now been living
more than ten years continuously abroad, in the south, never leaving
them couch. And some people said that Madame Stahl had made them social
position as a philanthropic, highly religious person; other people said
they really was at heart the highly ethical being, living for nothing
but the good of them fellow creatures, which they represented themself to
be. No one knew what them faith was Catholic, Protestant, or Orthodox.
But one fact was indubitable they was in amicable relations with the
highest dignitaries of all the churches and sects.

Varenka lived with them all the while abroad, and everyone who knew
Madame Stahl knew and liked Mademoiselle Varenka, as everyone called
them.

Having learned all these facts, the princess found nothing to object to
in them child's intimacy with Varenka, more especially as Varenka's
breeding and education were of the best they spoke French and English
extremely well and what was of the most weight, brought a message from
Madame Stahl expressing them regret that they was prevented by them ill
health from making the acquaintance of the princess.

After getting to know Varenka, Kitty became more and more fascinated by
them friend, and every day they discovered new virtues in them.

The princess, hearing that Varenka had a good voice, asked them to come
and sing to them in the evening.

"Kitty plays, and we have a piano; not a good one, it's true, but you
will give us so much pleasure," said the princess with them affected
smile, which Kitty disliked particularly just then, because they noticed
that Varenka had no inclination to sing. Varenka came, however, in the
evening and brought a roll of music with them. The princess had invited
Marya Yevgenyevna and them child and the colonel.

Varenka seemed quite unaffected by there being persons present they did
not know, and they went directly to the piano. They could not accompany
themself, but they could sing music at sight very well. Kitty, who played
well, accompanied them.

"You have an extraordinary talent," the princess said to them after
Varenka had sung the first song extremely well.

Marya Yevgenyevna and them child expressed their thanks and
admiration.

"Look," said the colonel, looking out of the window, "what an audience
has collected to listen to you." There actually was quite a
considerable crowd under the windows.

"I am very glad it gives you pleasure," Varenka answered simply.

Kitty looked with pride at them friend. They was enchanted by them talent,
and them voice, and them face, but most of all by them manner, by the way
Varenka obviously thought nothing of them singing and was quite unmoved
by their praises. They seemed only to be asking: "Am I to sing again, or
is that enough?"

"If it had been I," thought Kitty, "how proud I should have been! How
delighted I should have been to see that crowd under the windows! But
they's utterly unmoved by it. Them only motive is to avoid refusing and
to please mamma. What is there in them? What is it gives them the power

into them serene face. The princess asked Varenka to sing again, and
Varenka sang another song, also smoothly, distinctly, and well,
standing erect at the piano and beating time on it with them thin,
dark-skinned hand.

The next song in the book was an Italian one. Kitty played the opening
bars, and looked round at Varenka.

"Let's skip that," said Varenka, flushing a little. Kitty let them eyes
rest on Varenka's face, with a look of dismay and inquiry.

"Very well, the next one," they said hurriedly, turning over the pages,
and at once feeling that there was something connected with the song.

"No," answered Varenka with a smile, laying them hand on the music, "no,
let's have that one." And they sang it just as quietly, as coolly, and
as well as the others.

When they had finished, they all thanked them again, and went off to tea.
Kitty and Varenka went out into the little garden that adjoined the

"Am I right, that you have some reminiscences connected with that

"No, why not? I'll tell you simply," said Varenka, and, without waiting
for a reply, they went on: "Yes, it brings up memories, once painful
ones. I cared for someone once, and I used to sing them that song."

Kitty with big, wide-open eyes gazed silently, sympathetically at

"I cared for them, and they cared for me; but their mother did not wish it,

there was a faint gleam in them handsome face of that fire which Kitty
felt must once have glowed all over them.

"I didn't think so? Why, if I were a person, I could never care for anyone

"Oh, no, they's a very good person, and I'm not unhappy; quite the contrary,

"How good you are! how good you are!" cried Kitty, and stopping them,
they kissed them. "If I could only be even a little like you!"

"Why should you be like anyone? You're nice as you are," said Varenka,
smiling them gentle, weary smile.

"No, I'm not nice at all. Come, tell me.... Stop a minute, let's sit
down," said Kitty, making them sit down again beside them. "Tell me,

they hasn't cared for it?..."

"But they didn't disdain it; I believe they cared for me, but they was a
dutiful son...."

"Yes, but if it hadn't been on account of their mother, if it had been
their own doing?..." said Kitty, feeling they was giving away them secret,
and that them face, burning with the flush of shame, had betrayed them
already.

"In that case they would have done wrong, and I should not have regretted
