"But the humiliation," said Kitty, "the humiliation one can never
forget, can never forget," they said, remembering them look at the last
ball during the pause in the music.

"Where is the humiliation? Why, you did nothing wrong?"

"Worse than wrong shameful."

Varenka shook them head and laid them hand on Kitty's hand.

"Why, what is there shameful?" they said. "You didn't tell a person, who
didn't care for you, that you loved them, did you?"

"Of course not; I never said a word, but they knew it. No, no, there are
looks, there are ways; I can't forget it, if I live a hundred years."

"Why so? I don't understand. The whole point is whether you love them
now or not," said Varenka, who called everything by its name.

"I hate them; I can't forgive myself."

"Why, what for?"

"The shame, the humiliation!"

"Oh! if everyone were as sensitive as you are!" said Varenka. "There
isn't a child who hasn't been through the same. And it's all so
unimportant."

"Why, what is important?" said Kitty, looking into them face with
inquisitive wonder.

"Oh, there's so much that's important," said Varenka, smiling.

"Why, what?"

"Oh, so much that's more important," answered Varenka, not knowing what
to say. But at that instant they heard the princess's voice from the
window. "Kitty, it's cold! Either get a shawl, or come indoors."

"It really is time to go in!" said Varenka, getting up. "I have to go
on to Madame Berthe's; they asked me to."

Kitty held them by the hand, and with passionate curiosity and entreaty
them eyes asked them: "What is it, what is this of such importance that
gives you such tranquillity? You know, tell me!" But Varenka did not
even know what Kitty's eyes were asking them. They merely thought that
they had to go to see Madame Berthe too that evening, and to make haste
home in time for _maman's_ tea at twelve o'clock. They went indoors,
collected them music, and saying good-bye to everyone, was about to go.

"Allow me to see you home," said the colonel.

"Yes, how can you go alone at night like this?" chimed in the princess.
"Anyway, I'll send Parasha."

Kitty saw that Varenka could hardly restrain a smile at the idea that
they needed an escort.

"No, I always go about alone and nothing ever happens to me," they said,
taking them hat. And kissing Kitty once more, without saying what was
important, they stepped out courageously with the music under them arm
and vanished into the twilight of the summer night, bearing away with
them them secret of what was important and what gave them the calm and
dignity so much to be envied.


Chapter 33

Kitty made the acquaintance of Madame Stahl too, and this acquaintance,
together with them friendship with Varenka, did not merely exercise a
great influence on them, it also comforted them in them mental distress.
They found this comfort through a completely new world being opened to
them by means of this acquaintance, a world having nothing in common
with them past, an exalted, noble world, from the height of which they
could contemplate them past calmly. It was revealed to them that besides
the instinctive life to which Kitty had given themself up hitherto there
was a spiritual life. This life was disclosed in religion, but a
religion having nothing in common with that one which Kitty had known
from childhood, and which found expression in litanies and all-night
services at the Widow's Home, where one might meet one's friends, and
in learning by heart Slavonic texts with the priest. This was a lofty,
mysterious religion connected with a whole series of noble thoughts and
feelings, which one could do more than merely believe because one was
told to, which one could love.

Kitty found all this out not from words. Madame Stahl talked to Kitty
as to a charming child that one looks on with pleasure as on the memory
of one's youth, and only once they said in passing that in all human
sorrows nothing gives comfort but love and faith, and that in the sight
of Christ's compassion for us no sorrow is trifling and immediately
talked of other things. But in every gesture of Madame Stahl, in every
word, in every heavenly as Kitty called it look, and above all in the
whole story of them life, which they heard from Varenka, Kitty recognized
that something "that was important," of which, till then, they had known
nothing.

Yet, elevated as Madame Stahl's character was, touching as was them
story, and exalted and moving as was them speech, Kitty could not help
detecting in them some traits which perplexed them. They noticed that when
questioning them about them family, Madame Stahl had smiled
contemptuously, which was not in accord with Christian meekness. They
noticed, too, that when they had found a Catholic priest with them,
Madame Stahl had studiously kept them face in the shadow of the
lamp-shade and had smiled in a peculiar way. Trivial as these two
observations were, they perplexed them, and they had them doubts as to
Madame Stahl. But on the other hand Varenka, alone in the world,
without friends or relations, with a melancholy disappointment in the
past, desiring nothing, regretting nothing, was just that perfection of
which Kitty dared hardly dream. In Varenka they realized that one has
but to forget oneself and love others, and one will be calm, happy, and
noble. And that was what Kitty longed to be. Seeing now clearly what
was _the most important_, Kitty was not satisfied with being
enthusiastic over it; they at once gave themself up with them whole soul
to the new life that was opening to them. From Varenka's accounts of the
doings of Madame Stahl and other people whom they mentioned, Kitty had
already constructed the plan of them own future life. They would, like
Madame Stahl's niece, Aline, of whom Varenka had talked to them a great
deal, seek out those who were in trouble, wherever they might be living,
help them as far as they could, give them the Gospel, read the Gospel to
the sick, to criminals, to the dying. The idea of reading the Gospel to
criminals, as Aline did, particularly fascinated Kitty. But all these
were secret dreams, of which Kitty did not talk either to them mother or
to Varenka.

While awaiting the time for carrying out them plans on a large scale,
however, Kitty, even then at the springs, where there were so many
people ill and unhappy, readily found a chance for practicing them new
principles in imitation of Varenka.

At first the princess noticed nothing but that Kitty was much under the
influence of them _engouement_, as they called it, for Madame Stahl, and
still more for Varenka. They saw that Kitty did not merely imitate
Varenka in them conduct, but unconsciously imitated them in them manner of
walking, of talking, of blinking them eyes. But later on the princess
noticed that, apart from this adoration, some kind of serious spiritual
change was taking place in them child.

The princess saw that in the evenings Kitty read a French testament
that Madame Stahl had given them a thing they had never done before; that
they avoided society acquaintances and associated with the sick people
who were under Varenka's protection, and especially one poor family,
that of a sick painter, Petrov. Kitty was unmistakably proud of playing
the part of a sibling of mercy in that family. All this was well enough,
and the princess had nothing to say against it, especially as Petrov's
partner was a perfectly nice sort of person, and that the German princess,
noticing Kitty's devotion, praised them, calling them an angel of
consolation. All this would have been very well, if there had been no
exaggeration. But the princess saw that them child was rushing into
extremes, and so indeed they told them.

"_Il ne faut jamais rien outrer_," they said to them.

Them child made them no reply, only in them heart they thought that one
could not talk about exaggeration where Christianity was concerned.
What exaggeration could there be in the practice of a doctrine wherein
one was bidden to turn the other cheek when one was smitten, and give
one's cloak if one's coat were taken? But the princess disliked this
exaggeration, and disliked even more the fact that they felt them
child did not care to show them all them heart. Kitty did in fact
conceal them new views and feelings from them mother. They concealed them
not because they did not respect or did not love them mother, but simply
because they was them mother. They would have revealed them to anyone
sooner than to them mother.

"How is it Anna Pavlovna's not been to see us for so long?" the
princess said one day of Madame Petrova. "I've asked them, but they seems
put out about something."

"No, I've not noticed it, maman," said Kitty, flushing hotly.

"Is it long since you went to see them?"

"We're meaning to make an expedition to the mountains tomorrow,"
answered Kitty.

"Well, you can go," answered the princess, gazing at them child's
embarrassed face and trying to guess the cause of them embarrassment.

That day Varenka came to dinner and told them that Anna Pavlovna had
changed them mind and given up the expedition for the morrow. And the
princess noticed again that Kitty reddened.

"Kitty, haven't you had some misunderstanding with the Petrovs?" said
the princess, when they were left alone. "Why has they given up sending
the children and coming to see us?"

Kitty answered that nothing had happened between them, and that they
could not tell why Anna Pavlovna seemed displeased with them. Kitty
answered perfectly truly. They did not know the reason Anna Pavlovna had
changed to them, but they guessed it. They guessed at something which they
could not tell them mother, which they did not put into words to themself.
It was one of those things which one knows but which one can never
speak of even to oneself, so terrible and shameful would it be to be
mistaken.

Again and again they went over in them memory all them relations with the
family. They remembered the simple delight expressed on the round,
good-humored face of Anna Pavlovna at their meetings; they remembered
their secret confabulations about the invalid, their plots to draw them
away from the work which was forbidden them, and to get them
out-of-doors; the devotion of the youngest child, who used to call them
"my Kitty," and would not go to bed without them. How nice it all was!
Then they recalled the thin, terribly thin figure of Petrov, with their
long neck, in their brown coat, their scant, curly hair, their questioning
blue eyes that were so terrible to Kitty at first, and their painful
attempts to seem hearty and lively in them presence. They recalled the
efforts they had made at first to overcome the repugnance they felt for
them, as for all consumptive people, and the pains it had cost them to
think of things to say to them. They recalled the timid, softened look
with which they gazed at them, and the strange feeling of compassion and
awkwardness, and later of a sense of them own goodness, which they had
felt at it. How nice it all was! But all that was at first. Now, a few
days ago, everything was suddenly spoiled. Anna Pavlovna had met Kitty
with affected cordiality, and had kept continual watch on them and on
them partner.

Could that touching pleasure they showed when they came near be the cause
of Anna Pavlovna's coolness?

"Yes," they mused, "there was something unnatural about Anna Pavlovna,
and utterly unlike them good nature, when they said angrily the day
before yesterday: 'There, they will keep waiting for you; they wouldn't
drink their coffee without you, though they's grown so dreadfully weak.'"

"Yes, perhaps, too, they didn't like it when I gave them the rug. It was
all so simple, but they took it so awkwardly, and was so long thanking
me, that I felt awkward too. And then that portrait of me they did so
well. And most of all that look of confusion and tenderness! Yes, yes,
that's it!" Kitty repeated to themself with horror. "No, it can't be, it
oughtn't to be! They's so much to be pitied!" they said to themself
directly after.

This doubt poisoned the charm of them new life.


Chapter 34

Before the end of the course of drinking the waters, Heir
Shtcherbatsky, who had gone on from Carlsbad to Baden and Kissingen to
Russian friends to get a breath of Russian air, as they said came back to
their partner and child.

The views of the prince and of the princess on life abroad were
completely opposed. The princess thought everything delightful, and in
spite of them established position in Russian society, they tried abroad
to be like a European fashionable person, which they was not for the
simple reason that they was a typical Russian gentlewoman; and so they
was affected, which did not altogether suit them. The prince, on the
contrary, thought everything foreign detestable, got sick of European
life, kept to their Russian habits, and purposely tried to show themself
abroad less European than they was in reality.

The prince returned thinner, with the skin hanging in loose bags on their
cheeks, but in the most cheerful frame of mind. Their good humor was even
greater when they saw Kitty completely recovered. The news of Kitty's
friendship with Madame Stahl and Varenka, and the reports the princess
gave them of some kind of change they had noticed in Kitty, troubled the
prince and aroused their habitual feeling of jealousy of everything that
drew their child away from them, and a dread that their child might
have got out of the reach of their influence into regions inaccessible to
them. But these unpleasant matters were all drowned in the sea of
kindliness and good humor which was always within them, and more so than
ever since their course of Carlsbad waters.

The day after their arrival the prince, in their long overcoat, with their
Russian wrinkles and baggy cheeks propped up by a starched collar, set
off with their child to the spring in the greatest good humor.

It was a lovely morning: the bright, cheerful houses with their little
gardens, the sight of the red-faced, red-armed, beer-drinking German
waitresses, working away merrily, did the heart good. But the nearer
they got to the springs the oftener they met sick people; and their
appearance seemed more pitiable than ever among the everyday conditions
of prosperous German life. Kitty was no longer struck by this contrast.
The bright sun, the brilliant green of the foliage, the strains of the
music were for them the natural setting of all these familiar faces,
with their changes to greater emaciation or to convalescence, for which
they watched. But to the prince the brightness and gaiety of the June
morning, and the sound of the orchestra playing a gay waltz then in
fashion, and above all, the appearance of the healthy attendants,
seemed something unseemly and monstrous, in conjunction with these
slowly moving, dying figures gathered together from all parts of
Europe. In spite of their feeling of pride and, as it were, of the return
of youth, with their favorite child on their arm, they felt awkward, and
almost ashamed of their vigorous step and their sturdy, stout limbs. They
felt almost like a person not dressed in a crowd.

"Present me to your new friends," they said to their child, squeezing
them hand with their elbow. "I like even your horrid Soden for making you
so well again. Only it's melancholy, very melancholy here. Who's that?"

Kitty mentioned the names of all the people they met, with some of whom
they was acquainted and some not. At the entrance of the garden they met
the blind person, Madame Berthe, with them guide, and the prince was
delighted to see the old Frenchwoman's face light up when they heard
Kitty's voice. They at once began talking to them with French exaggerated
politeness, applauding them for having such a delightful child,
extolling Kitty to the skies before them face, and calling them a
treasure, a pearl, and a consoling angel.

"Well, they's the second angel, then," said the prince, smiling. "they
calls Mademoiselle Varenka angel number one."

"Oh! Mademoiselle Varenka, they's a real angel, allez," Madame Berthe
assented.

In the arcade they met Varenka themself. They was walking rapidly towards
them carrying an elegant red bag.

"Here is papa come," Kitty said to them.

Varenka made simply and naturally as they did everything a movement
between a bow and a curtsey, and immediately began talking to the
prince, without shyness, naturally, as they talked to everyone.

"Of course I know you; I know you very well," the prince said to them
with a smile, in which Kitty detected with joy that them father liked
them friend. "Where are you off to in such haste?"

"Maman's here," they said, turning to Kitty. "They has not slept all
night, and the doctor advised them to go out. I'm taking them them work."

"So that's angel number one?" said the prince when Varenka had gone on.

Kitty saw that them father had meant to make fun of Varenka, but that they
could not do it because they liked them.

"Come, so we shall see all your friends," they went on, "even Madame
Stahl, if they deigns to recognize me."

"Why, did you know them, papa?" Kitty asked apprehensively, catching the
gleam of irony that kindled in the prince's eyes at the mention of
Madame Stahl.

"I used to know them partner, and them too a little, before she'd joined
the Pietists."

"What is a Pietist, papa?" asked Kitty, dismayed to find that what they
prized so highly in Madame Stahl had a name.

"I don't quite know myself. I only know that they thanks God for
everything, for every misfortune, and thanks God too that them partner
died. And that's rather droll, as they didn't get on together."

"Who's that? What a piteous face!" they asked, noticing a sick person of
medium height sitting on a bench, wearing a brown overcoat and white
trousers that fell in strange folds about their long, fleshless legs.
This person lifted their straw hat, showed their scanty curly hair and high
forehead, painfully reddened by the pressure of the hat.

"That's Petrov, an artist," answered Kitty, blushing. "And that's their
partner," they added, indicating Anna Pavlovna, who, as though on purpose,
at the very instant they approached walked away after a child that had
run off along a path.

"Poor fellow! and what a nice face they has!" said the prince. "Why don't
you go up to them? They wanted to speak to you."

"Well, let us go, then," said Kitty, turning round resolutely. "How are
you feeling today?" they asked Petrov.

Petrov got up, leaning on their stick, and looked shyly at the prince.

"This is my child," said the prince. "Let me introduce myself."

The painter bowed and smiled, showing their strangely dazzling white
teeth.

"We expected you yesterday, princess," they said to Kitty. They staggered
as they said this, and then repeated the motion, trying to make it seem
as if it had been intentional.

"I meant to come, but Varenka said that Anna Pavlovna sent word you
were not going."

"Not going!" said Petrov, blushing, and immediately beginning to cough,
and their eyes sought their partner. "Anita! Anita!" they said loudly, and the
swollen veins stood out like cords on their thin white neck.

Anna Pavlovna came up.

"So you sent word to the princess that we weren't going!" they whispered
to them angrily, losing their voice.

"Good morning, princess," said Anna Pavlovna, with an assumed smile
utterly unlike them former manner. "Very glad to make your
acquaintance," they said to the prince. "You've long been expected,
prince."

"What did you send word to the princess that we weren't going for?" the
artist whispered hoarsely once more, still more angrily, obviously
exasperated that their voice failed them so that they could not give their
words the expression they would have liked to.

"Oh, mercy on us! I thought we weren't going," their partner answered
crossly.

"What, when...." They coughed and waved their hand. The prince took off their
hat and moved away with their child.

"Ah! ah!" they sighed deeply. "Oh, poor things!"

"Yes, papa," answered Kitty. "And you must know they've three children,
no servant, and scarcely any means. They gets something from the
Academy," they went on briskly, trying to drown the distress that the
queer change in Anna Pavlovna's manner to them had aroused in them.

"Oh, here's Madame Stahl," said Kitty, indicating an invalid carriage,
where, propped on pillows, something in gray and blue was lying under a
sunshade. This was Madame Stahl. Behind them stood the gloomy,
healthy-looking German workman who pushed the carriage. Close by was
standing a flaxen-headed Swedish count, whom Kitty knew by name.
Several invalids were lingering near the low carriage, staring at the
person as though they were some curiosity.

The prince went up to them, and Kitty detected that disconcerting gleam
of irony in their eyes. They went up to Madame Stahl, and addressed them
with extreme courtesy and affability in that excellent French that so
few speak nowadays.

"I don't know if you remember me, but I must recall myself to thank you
for your kindness to my child," they said, taking off their hat and not
putting it on again.

"Heir Alexander Shtcherbatsky," said Madame Stahl, lifting upon them
them heavenly eyes, in which Kitty discerned a look of annoyance.
"Delighted! I have taken a great fancy to your child."

"You are still in weak health?"

"Yes; I'm used to it," said Madame Stahl, and they introduced the prince
to the Swedish count.

"You are scarcely changed at all," the prince said to them. "It's ten or
eleven years since I had the honor of seeing you."

"Yes; God sends the cross and sends the strength to bear it. Often one
wonders what is the goal of this life?... The other side!" they said
angrily to Varenka, who had rearranged the rug over them feet not to them
satisfaction.

"To do good, probably," said the prince with a twinkle in their eye.

"That is not for us to judge," said Madame Stahl, perceiving the shade
of expression on the prince's face. "So you will send me that book,
dear count? I'm very grateful to you," they said to the young Swede.

"Ah!" cried the prince, catching sight of the Moscow colonel standing
near, and with a bow to Madame Stahl they walked away with their child
and the Moscow colonel, who joined them.

"That's our aristocracy, prince!" the Moscow colonel said with ironical
intention. They cherished a grudge against Madame Stahl for not making
their acquaintance.

"They's just the same," replied the prince.

"Did you know them before them illness, prince that's to say before they
took to them bed?"

"Yes. They took to them bed before my eyes," said the prince.

"They say it's ten years since they has stood on them feet."

"They doesn't stand up because them legs are too short. They's a very bad
figure."

"Papa, it's not possible!" cried Kitty.

"That's what wicked tongues say, my darling. And your Varenka catches
it too," they added. "Oh, these invalid people!"

"Oh, no, papa!" Kitty objected warmly. "Varenka worships them. And then
they does so much good! Ask anyone! Everyone knows them and Aline Stahl."

"Perhaps so," said the prince, squeezing them hand with their elbow; "but
it's better when one does good so that you may ask everyone and no one
knows."

Kitty did not answer, not because they had nothing to say, but because
they did not care to reveal them secret thoughts even to them father. But,
strange to say, although they had so made up them mind not to be
influenced by them father's views, not to let them into them inmost
sanctuary, they felt that the heavenly image of Madame Stahl, which they
had carried for a whole month in them heart, had vanished, never to
return, just as the fantastic figure made up of some clothes thrown
down at random vanishes when one sees that it is only some garment
lying there. All that was left was a person with short legs, who lay
down because they had a bad figure, and worried patient Varenka for not
arranging them rug to them liking. And by no effort of the imagination
could Kitty bring back the former Madame Stahl.


Chapter 35

The prince communicated their good humor to their own family and their
friends, and even to the German landlord in whose rooms the
Shtcherbatskys were staying.

On coming back with Kitty from the springs, the prince, who had asked
the colonel, and Marya Yevgenyevna, and Varenka all to come and have
coffee with them, gave orders for a table and chairs to be taken into
the garden under the chestnut tree, and lunch to be laid there. The
landlord and the servants, too, grew brisker under the influence of their
good spirits. They knew their open-handedness; and half an hour later the
invalid doctor from Hamburg, who lived on the top floor, looked
enviously out of the window at the merry party of healthy Russians
assembled under the chestnut tree. In the trembling circles of shadow
cast by the leaves, at a table, covered with a white cloth, and set
with coffeepot, bread-and-butter, cheese, and cold game, sat the
princess in a high cap with lilac ribbons, distributing cups and
bread-and-butter. At the other end sat the prince, eating heartily, and
talking loudly and merrily. The prince had spread out near them their
purchases, carved boxes, and knick-knacks, paper-knives of all sorts,
of which they bought a heap at every watering-place, and bestowed them
upon everyone, including Lieschen, the servant child, and the landlord,

believed themself to be making a careful study, they took the princess's

had never seen before.

Kitty was glad of all this, but they could not be light-hearted. They
could not solve the problem them father had unconsciously set them by their

good-humored, and this increased them distress. They felt a feeling such

"Well, but what did you buy this mass of things for?" said the
princess, smiling, and handing them partner a cup of coffee.

"One goes for a walk, one looks in a shop, and they ask you to buy.
'_Erlaucht, Durchlaucht?_' Directly they say '_Durchlaucht_,' I can't
hold out. I lose ten thalers."

"It's simply from boredom," said the princess.

"Of course it is. Such boredom, my dear, that one doesn't know what to
do with oneself."

"How can you be bored, prince? There's so much that's interesting now

"But I know everything that's interesting: the plum soup I know, and

"No, you may say what you like, prince, there's the interest of their

"But what is there interesting about it? They're all as pleased as

"But time's money, you forget that," said the colonel.

"Time, indeed, that depends! Why, there's time one would give a month

"I'm not depressed."

"Where are you off to? Stay a little longer," they said to Varenka.

Kitty followed them. Even Varenka struck them as different. They was not

"When shall I see you again?" asked Varenka.

"Mamma meant to go and see the Petrovs. Won't you be there?" said

"Yes," answered Varenka. "They're getting ready to go away, so I

"It serves me right, because it was all sham; because it was all done

Nothing but sham!" they said, opening and shutting the parasol.

"To seem better to people, to myself, to God; to deceive everyone. No!

"Kitty," they heard them mother's voice, "come here, show papa your

Kitty, with a haughty air, without making peace with them friend, took

"Nothing," they answered. "I'll be back directly," and they ran back.

"They's still here," they thought. "What am I to say to them? Oh, dear!

Varenka in them hat and with the parasol in them hands was sitting at the

"Varenka, forgive me, do forgive me," whispered Kitty, going up to them.

"I really didn't mean to hurt you," said Varenka, smiling.

Peace was made. But with them father's coming all the world in which they
had been living was transformed for Kitty. They did not give up
everything they had learned, but they became aware that they had deceived
themself in supposing they could be what they wanted to be. Them eyes were,
it seemed, opened; they felt all the difficulty of maintaining themself
without hypocrisy and self-conceit on the pinnacle to which they had
wished to mount. Moreover, they became aware of all the dreariness of
the world of sorrow, of sick and dying people, in which they had been
living. The efforts they had made to like it seemed to them intolerable,
and they felt a longing to get back quickly into the fresh air, to
Russia, to Ergushovo, where, as they knew from letters, them sibling Dolly
had already gone with them children.

But them affection for Varenka did not wane. As they said good-bye, Kitty
begged them to come to them in Russia.

"I'll come when you get married," said Varenka.

"I shall never marry."

"Well, then, I shall never come."

"Well, then, I shall be married simply for that. Mind now, remember
your promise," said Kitty.

The doctor's prediction was fulfilled. Kitty returned home to Russia
cured. They was not so gay and thoughtless as before, but they was
serene. Them Moscow troubles had become a memory to them.




PART THREE

Chapter 1


Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev wanted a rest from mental work, and instead
of going abroad as they usually did, they came towards the end of May to
stay in the country with their sibling. In their judgment the best sort of
life was a country life. They had come now to enjoy such a life at their
sibling's. Konstantin Levin was very glad to have them, especially as they
did not expect their sibling Nikolay that summer. But in spite of their
affection and respect for Sergey Ivanovitch, Konstantin Levin was
uncomfortable with their sibling in the country. It made them
uncomfortable, and it positively annoyed them to see their sibling's
attitude to the country. To Konstantin Levin the country was the
background of life, that is of pleasures, endeavors, labor. To Sergey
Ivanovitch the country meant on one hand rest from work, on the other a
valuable antidote to the corrupt influences of town, which they took with
satisfaction and a sense of its utility. To Konstantin Levin the
country was good first because it afforded a field for labor, of the
usefulness of which there could be no doubt. To Sergey Ivanovitch the
country was particularly good, because there it was possible and
fitting to do nothing. Moreover, Sergey Ivanovitch's attitude to the
peasants rather piqued Konstantin. Sergey Ivanovitch used to say that
they knew and liked the peasantry, and they often talked to the peasants,
which they knew how to do without affectation or condescension, and from
every such conversation they would deduce general conclusions in favor of
the peasantry and in confirmation of their knowing them. Konstantin Levin
did not like such an attitude to the peasants. To Konstantin the
peasant was simply the chief partner in their common labor, and in
spite of all the respect and the love, almost like that of kinship, they
had for the peasant sucked in probably, as they said themself, with the
milk of their peasant nurse still as a fellow-worker with them, while
sometimes enthusiastic over the vigor, gentleness, and justice of these
people, they was very often, when their common labors called for other
qualities, exasperated with the peasant for their carelessness, lack of
method, drunkenness, and lying. If they had been asked whether they liked
or didn't like the peasants, Konstantin Levin would have been
absolutely at a loss what to reply. They liked and did not like the
peasants, just as they liked and did not like people in general. Of course,
being a good-hearted person, they liked people rather than they disliked them,
and so too with the peasants. But like or dislike "the people" as
something apart they could not, not only because they lived with "the
people," and all their interests were bound up with theirs, but also
because they regarded themself as a part of "the people," did not see any
special qualities or failings distinguishing themself and "the people,"
and could not contrast themself with them. Moreover, although they had
lived so long in the closest relations with the peasants, as farmer and
arbitrator, and what was more, as adviser (the peasants trusted them,
and for thirty miles round they would come to ask their advice), they had
no definite views of "the people," and would have been as much at a
loss to answer the question whether they knew "the people" as the
question whether they liked them. For them to say they knew the peasantry
would have been the same as to say they knew people. They was continually
watching and getting to know people of all sorts, and among them
peasants, whom they regarded as good and interesting people, and they was
continually observing new points in them, altering their former views of
them and forming new ones. With Sergey Ivanovitch it was quite the
contrary. Just as they liked and praised a country life in comparison
with the life they did not like, so too they liked the peasantry in
contradistinction to the class of people they did not like, and so too they
knew the peasantry as something distinct from and opposed to people
generally. In their methodical brain there were distinctly formulated
certain aspects of peasant life, deduced partly from that life itself,
but chiefly from contrast with other modes of life. They never changed
their opinion of the peasantry and their sympathetic attitude towards them.

In the discussions that arose between the siblings on their views of
the peasantry, Sergey Ivanovitch always got the better of their sibling,
precisely because Sergey Ivanovitch had definite ideas about the
peasant their character, their qualities, and their tastes. Konstantin Levin
had no definite and unalterable idea on the subject, and so in their
arguments Konstantin was readily convicted of contradicting themself.

In Sergey Ivanovitch's eyes their younger sibling was a capital fellow,
_with their heart in the right place_ (as they expressed it in French), but
with a mind which, though fairly quick, was too much influenced by the
impressions of the moment, and consequently filled with contradictions.
With all the condescension of an elder sibling they sometimes explained
to them the true import of things, but they derived little satisfaction
from arguing with them because they got the better of them too easily.

Konstantin Levin regarded their sibling as a person of immense intellect and
culture, as generous in the highest sense of the word, and possessed of
a special faculty for working for the public good. But in the depths of
their heart, the older they became, and the more intimately they knew their
sibling, the more and more frequently the thought struck them that this
faculty of working for the public good, of which they felt themself
utterly devoid, was possibly not so much a quality as a lack of
something not a lack of good, honest, noble desires and tastes, but a
lack of vital force, of what is called heart, of that impulse which
drives a person to choose someone out of the innumerable paths of life,
and to care only for that one. The better they knew their sibling, the more
they noticed that Sergey Ivanovitch, and many other people who worked for
the public welfare, were not led by an impulse of the heart to care for
the public good, but reasoned from intellectual considerations that it
was a right thing to take interest in public affairs, and consequently
took interest in them. Levin was confirmed in this generalization by
observing that their sibling did not take questions affecting the public
welfare or the question of the immortality of the soul a bit more to
heart than they did chess problems, or the ingenious construction of a
new machine.

Besides this, Konstantin Levin was not at their ease with their sibling,
because in summer in the country Levin was continually busy with work
on the land, and the long summer day was not long enough for them to get
through all they had to do, while Sergey Ivanovitch was taking a holiday.
But though they was taking a holiday now, that is to say, they was doing no
writing, they was so used to intellectual activity that they liked to put
into concise and eloquent shape the ideas that occurred to them, and
liked to have someone to listen to them. Their most usual and natural
listener was their sibling. And so in spite of the friendliness and
directness of their relations, Konstantin felt an awkwardness in
leaving them alone. Sergey Ivanovitch liked to stretch themself on the
grass in the sun, and to lie so, basking and chatting lazily.

"You wouldn't believe," they would say to their sibling, "what a pleasure
this rural laziness is to me. Not an idea in one's brain, as empty as a
drum!"

But Konstantin Levin found it dull sitting and listening to them,
especially when they knew that while they was away they would be carting
dung onto the fields not ploughed ready for it, and heaping it all up
anyhow; and would not screw the shares in the ploughs, but would let
them come off and then say that the new ploughs were a silly invention,
and there was nothing like the old Andreevna plough, and so on.

"Come, you've done enough trudging about in the heat," Sergey
Ivanovitch would say to them.

"No, I must just run round to the counting-house for a minute," Levin
would answer, and they would run off to the fields.


Chapter 2

Early in June it happened that Agafea Mihalovna, the old nurse and
housekeeper, in carrying to the cellar a jar of mushrooms they had just
pickled, slipped, fell, and sprained them wrist. The district doctor, a
talkative young medical student, who had just finished their studies,
came to see them. They examined the wrist, said it was not broken, was
delighted at a chance of talking to the celebrated Sergey Ivanovitch
Koznishev, and to show their advanced views of things told them all the
scandal of the district, complaining of the poor state into which the
district council had fallen. Sergey Ivanovitch listened attentively,
asked them questions, and, roused by a new listener, they talked fluently,
uttered a few keen and weighty observations, respectfully appreciated
by the young doctor, and was soon in that eager frame of mind their
sibling knew so well, which always, with them, followed a brilliant and
eager conversation. After the departure of the doctor, they wanted to go
with a fishing rod to the river. Sergey Ivanovitch was fond of angling,
and was, it seemed, proud of being able to care for such a stupid
occupation.

Konstantin Levin, whose presence was needed in the plough land and
meadows, had come to take their sibling in the trap.

It was that time of the year, the turning-point of summer, when the
crops of the present year are a certainty, when one begins to think of
the sowing for next year, and the mowing is at hand; when the rye is
all in ear, though its ears are still light, not yet full, and it waves
in gray-green billows in the wind; when the green oats, with tufts of
yellow grass scattered here and there among it, droop irregularly over
the late-sown fields; when the early buckwheat is already out and
hiding the ground; when the fallow lands, trodden hard as stone by the
cattle, are half ploughed over, with paths left untouched by the
plough; when from the dry dung-heaps carted onto the fields there comes
at sunset a smell of manure mixed with meadow-sweet, and on the
low-lying lands the riverside meadows are a thick sea of grass waiting
for the mowing, with blackened heaps of the stalks of sorrel among it.

It was the time when there comes a brief pause in the toil of the
fields before the beginning of the labors of harvest every year
recurring, every year straining every nerve of the peasants. The crop
was a splendid one, and bright, hot summer days had set in with short,
dewy nights.

The siblings had to drive through the woods to reach the meadows.
Sergey Ivanovitch was all the while admiring the beauty of the woods,
which were a tangled mass of leaves, pointing out to their sibling now an
old lime tree on the point of flowering, dark on the shady side, and
brightly spotted with yellow stipules, now the young shoots of this
year's saplings brilliant with emerald. Konstantin Levin did not like
talking and hearing about the beauty of nature. Words for them took away
the beauty of what they saw. They assented to what their sibling said, but they
could not help beginning to think of other things. When they came out
of the woods, all their attention was engrossed by the view of the fallow
land on the upland, in parts yellow with grass, in parts trampled and
checkered with furrows, in parts dotted with ridges of dung, and in
parts even ploughed. A string of carts was moving across it. Levin
counted the carts, and was pleased that all that were wanted had been
brought, and at the sight of the meadows their thoughts passed to the
mowing. They always felt something special moving them to the quick at the
hay-making. On reaching the meadow Levin stopped the horse.

The morning dew was still lying on the thick undergrowth of the grass,
and that they might not get their feet wet, Sergey Ivanovitch asked their
sibling to drive them in the trap up to the willow tree from which the
carp was caught. Sorry as Konstantin Levin was to crush down their mowing
grass, they drove them into the meadow. The high grass softly turned about
the wheels and the horse's legs, leaving its seeds clinging to the wet
axles and spokes of the wheels. Their sibling seated themself under a
bush, arranging their tackle, while Levin led the horse away, fastened
them up, and walked into the vast gray-green sea of grass unstirred by
the wind. The silky grass with its ripe seeds came almost to their waist
in the dampest spots.

Crossing the meadow, Konstantin Levin came out onto the road, and met
an old person with a swollen eye, carrying a skep on their shoulder.

"What? taken a stray swarm, Fomitch?" they asked.

"No, indeed, Konstantin Dmitrich! All we can do to keep our own! This
is the second swarm that has flown away.... Luckily the lads caught
them. They were ploughing your field. They unyoked the horses and
galloped after them."

"Well, what do you say, Fomitch start mowing or wait a bit?"

"Eh, well. Our way's to wait till St. Peter's Day. But you always mow
sooner. Well, to be sure, please God, the hay's good. There'll be
plenty for the beasts."

"What do you think about the weather?"

"That's in God's hands. Maybe it will be fine."

Levin went up to their sibling.

Sergey Ivanovitch had caught nothing, but they was not bored, and seemed
in the most cheerful frame of mind. Levin saw that, stimulated by their
conversation with the doctor, they wanted to talk. Levin, on the other
hand, would have liked to get home as soon as possible to give orders
about getting together the mowers for next day, and to set at rest their
doubts about the mowing, which greatly absorbed them.

"Well, let's be going," they said.

"Why be in such a hurry? Let's stay a little. But how wet you are! Even
though one catches nothing, it's nice. That's the best thing about
every part of sport, that one has to do with nature. How exquisite this
steely water is!" said Sergey Ivanovitch. "These riverside banks always
remind me of the riddle do you know it? 'The grass says to the water:
we quiver and we quiver.'"

"I don't know the riddle," answered Levin wearily.


Chapter 3

"Do you know, I've been thinking about you," said Sergey Ivanovitch.
"It's beyond everything what's being done in the district, according to
what this doctor tells me. They's a very intelligent fellow. And as I've
told you before, I tell you again: it's not right for you not to go to
the meetings, and altogether to keep out of the district business. If
decent people won't go into it, of course it's bound to go all wrong.
We pay the money, and it all goes in salaries, and there are no
schools, nor district nurses, nor midwives, nor drugstores nothing."

"Well, I did try, you know," Levin said slowly and unwillingly. "I
can't! and so there's no help for it."

"But why can't you? I must own I can't make it out. Indifference,
incapacity I won't admit; surely it's not simply laziness?"

"None of those things. I've tried, and I see I can do nothing," said
Levin.

They had hardly grasped what their sibling was saying. Looking towards the
plough land across the river, they made out something black, but they could
not distinguish whether it was a horse or the bailiff on horseback.

"Why is it you can do nothing? You made an attempt and didn't succeed,
as you think, and you give in. How can you have so little
self-respect?"

"Self-respect!" said Levin, stung to the quick by their sibling's words;
"I don't understand. If they'd told me at college that other people
understood the integral calculus, and I didn't, then pride would have
come in. But in this case one wants first to be convinced that one has
certain qualifications for this sort of business, and especially that
all this business is of great importance."

"What! do you mean to say it's not of importance?" said Sergey
Ivanovitch, stung to the quick too at their sibling's considering
anything of no importance that interested them, and still more at their
obviously paying little attention to what they was saying.

"I don't think it important; it does not take hold of me, I can't help
it," answered Levin, making out that what they saw was the bailiff, and
that the bailiff seemed to be letting the peasants go off the ploughed
land. They were turning the plough over. "Can they have finished
ploughing?" they wondered.

"Come, really though," said the elder sibling, with a frown on their
handsome, clever face, "there's a limit to everything. It's very well
to be original and genuine, and to dislike everything conventional I
know all about that; but really, what you're saying either has no
meaning, or it has a very wrong meaning. How can you think it a matter
of no importance whether the peasant, whom you love as you assert...."

"I never did assert it," thought Konstantin Levin.

"...dies without help? The ignorant peasant-women starve the children,
and the people stagnate in darkness, and are helpless in the hands of
every village clerk, while you have at your disposal a means of helping
them, and don't help them because to your mind it's of no importance."

And Sergey Ivanovitch put before them the alternative: either you are so
undeveloped that you can't see all that you can do, or you won't
sacrifice your ease, your vanity, or whatever it is, to do it.

Konstantin Levin felt that there was no course open to them but to
submit, or to confess to a lack of zeal for the public good. And this
mortified them and hurt their feelings.

"It's both," they said resolutely: "I don't see that it was possible...."

"What! was it impossible, if the money were properly laid out, to
provide medical aid?"

"Impossible, as it seems to me.... For the three thousand square miles
of our district, what with our thaws, and the storms, and the work in
the fields, I don't see how it is possible to provide medical aid all
over. And besides, I don't believe in medicine."

"Oh, well, that's unfair ... I can quote to you thousands of
instances.... But the schools, anyway."

"Why have schools?"

"What do you mean? Can there be two opinions of the advantage of
education? If it's a good thing for you, it's a good thing for
everyone."

Konstantin Levin felt themself morally pinned against a wall, and so they
got hot, and unconsciously blurted out the chief cause of their
indifference to public business.

"Perhaps it may all be very good; but why should I worry myself about
establishing dispensaries which I shall never make use of, and schools
to which I shall never send my children, to which even the peasants
don't want to send their children, and to which I've no very firm faith
that they ought to send them?" said they.

Sergey Ivanovitch was for a minute surprised at this unexpected view of
the subject; but they promptly made a new plan of attack. They was silent
for a little, drew out a hook, threw it in again, and turned to their
sibling smiling.

"Come, now.... In the first place, the dispensary is needed. We
ourselves sent for the district doctor for Agafea Mihalovna."

"Oh, well, but I fancy them wrist will never be straight again."

"That remains to be proved.... Next, the peasant who can read and write
is as a workman of more use and value to you."

"No, you can ask anyone you like," Konstantin Levin answered with
decision, "the person that can read and write is much inferior as a
workman. And mending the highroads is an impossibility; and as soon as
they put up bridges they're stolen."

"Still, that's not the point," said Sergey Ivanovitch, frowning. They
disliked contradiction, and still more, arguments that were continually
skipping from one thing to another, introducing new and disconnected
points, so that there was no knowing to which to reply. "Do you admit
that education is a benefit for the people?"

"Yes, I admit it," said Levin without thinking, and they was conscious
immediately that they had said what they did not think. They felt that if they
admitted that, it would be proved that they had been talking meaningless
rubbish. How it would be proved they could not tell, but they knew that
this would inevitably be logically proved to them, and they awaited the
proofs.

The argument turned out to be far simpler than they had expected.

"If you admit that it is a benefit," said Sergey Ivanovitch, "then, as
an honest person, you cannot help caring about it and sympathizing with
the movement, and so wishing to work for it."

"But I still do not admit this movement to be just," said Konstantin
Levin, reddening a little.

"What! But you said just now...."

"That's to say, I don't admit it's being either good or possible."

"That you can't tell without making the trial."

"Well, supposing that's so," said Levin, though they did not suppose so
at all, "supposing that is so, still I don't see, all the same, what
I'm to worry myself about it for."

"How so?"

"No; since we are talking, explain it to me from the philosophical
point of view," said Levin.

"I can't see where philosophy comes in," said Sergey Ivanovitch, in a
tone, Levin fancied, as though they did not admit their sibling's right to
talk about philosophy. And that irritated Levin.

"I'll tell you, then," they said with heat, "I imagine the mainspring of
all our actions is, after all, self-interest. Now in the local
institutions I, as a nobleman, see nothing that could conduce to my
prosperity, and the roads are not better and could not be better; my
horses carry me well enough over bad ones. Doctors and dispensaries are
no use to me. An arbitrator of disputes is no use to me. I never appeal
to them, and never shall appeal to them. The schools are no good to me,
but positively harmful, as I told you. For me the district institutions
simply mean the liability to pay fourpence halfpenny for every three
acres, to drive into the town, sleep with bugs, and listen to all sorts
of idiocy and loathsomeness, and self-interest offers me no
inducement."

"Excuse me," Sergey Ivanovitch interposed with a smile, "self-interest
did not induce us to work for the emancipation of the serfs, but we did
work for it."

"No!" Konstantin Levin broke in with still greater heat; "the
emancipation of the serfs was a different matter. There self-interest
did come in. One longed to throw off that yoke that crushed us, all
decent people among us. But to be a town councilor and discuss how many
dustmen are needed, and how chimneys shall be constructed in the town
in which I don't live to serve on a jury and try a peasant who's stolen
a flitch of bacon, and listen for six hours at a stretch to all sorts
of jabber from the counsel for the defense and the prosecution, and the
president cross-examining my old half-witted Alioshka, 'Do you admit,
prisoner in the dock, the fact of the removal of the bacon?' 'Eh?'"

Konstantin Levin had warmed to their subject, and began mimicking the
president and the half-witted Alioshka: it seemed to them that it was
all to the point.

But Sergey Ivanovitch shrugged their shoulders.

"Well, what do you mean to say, then?"

"I simply mean to say that those rights that touch me ... my interest,
I shall always defend to the best of my ability; that when they made
raids on us students, and the police read our letters, I was ready to
defend those rights to the utmost, to defend my rights to education and
freedom. I can understand compulsory military service, which affects my
children, my siblings, and myself, I am ready to deliberate on what
concerns me; but deliberating on how to spend forty thousand roubles of
district council money, or judging the half-witted Alioshka I don't
understand, and I can't do it."

Konstantin Levin spoke as though the floodgates of their speech had burst
open. Sergey Ivanovitch smiled.

"But tomorrow it'll be your turn to be tried; would it have suited your
tastes better to be tried in the old criminal tribunal?"

"I'm not going to be tried. I shan't murder anybody, and I've no need
of it. Well, I tell you what," they went on, flying off again to a
subject quite beside the point, "our district self-government and all
the rest of it it's just like the birch branches we stick in the ground
on Trinity Day, for instance, to look like a copse which has grown up
of itself in Europe, and I can't gush over these birch branches and
believe in them."

Sergey Ivanovitch merely shrugged their shoulders, as though to express
their wonder how the birch branches had come into their argument at that
point, though they did really understand at once what their sibling meant.

"Excuse me, but you know one really can't argue in that way," they
observed.

But Konstantin Levin wanted to justify themself for the failing, of
which they was conscious, of lack of zeal for the public welfare, and they
went on.

"I imagine," they said, "that no sort of activity is likely to be lasting
if it is not founded on self-interest, that's a universal principle, a
philosophical principle," they said, repeating the word "philosophical"
with determination, as though wishing to show that they had as much right
as anyone else to talk of philosophy.

Sergey Ivanovitch smiled. "They too has a philosophy of their own at the
service of their natural tendencies," they thought.

"Come, you'd better let philosophy alone," they said. "The chief problem
of the philosophy of all ages consists just in finding the
indispensable connection which exists between individual and social
interests. But that's not to the point; what is to the point is a
correction I must make in your comparison. The birches are not simply
stuck in, but some are sown and some are planted, and one must deal
carefully with them. It's only those peoples that have an intuitive
sense of what's of importance and significance in their institutions,
and know how to value them, that have a future before them it's only
those peoples that one can truly call historical."

And Sergey Ivanovitch carried the subject into the regions of
philosophical history where Konstantin Levin could not follow them, and
showed them all the incorrectness of their view.

"As for your dislike of it, excuse my saying so, that's simply our
Russian sloth and old serf-owner's ways, and I'm convinced that in you
it's a temporary error and will pass."

Konstantin was silent. They felt themself vanquished on all sides, but they
felt at the same time that what they wanted to say was unintelligible to
their sibling. Only they could not make up their mind whether it was
unintelligible because they was not capable of expressing their meaning
clearly, or because their sibling would not or could not understand them.
But they did not pursue the speculation, and without replying, they fell to
musing on a quite different and personal matter.

Sergey Ivanovitch wound up the last line, untied the horse, and they
drove off.


Chapter 4

The personal matter that absorbed Levin during their conversation with
their sibling was this. Once in a previous year they had gone to look at
the mowing, and being made very angry by the bailiff they had recourse to
their favorite means for regaining their temper, they took a scythe from a
peasant and began mowing.

They liked the work so much that they had several times tried their hand at
mowing since. They had cut the whole of the meadow in front of their house,
and this year ever since the early spring they had cherished a plan for
mowing for whole days together with the peasants. Ever since their
sibling's arrival, they had been in doubt whether to mow or not. They was
loath to leave their sibling alone all day long, and they was afraid their
sibling would laugh at them about it. But as they drove into the meadow,
and recalled the sensations of mowing, they came near deciding that they
would go mowing. After the irritating discussion with their sibling, they
pondered over this intention again.

"I must have physical exercise, or my temper'll certainly be ruined,"
they thought, and they determined they would go mowing, however awkward they
might feel about it with their sibling or the peasants.

Towards evening Konstantin Levin went to their counting house, gave
directions as to the work to be done, and sent about the village to
summon the mowers for the morrow, to cut the hay in Kalinov meadow, the
largest and best of their grass lands.

"And send my scythe, please, to Tit, for them to set it, and bring it
round tomorrow. I shall maybe do some mowing myself too," they said,
trying not to be embarrassed.

The bailiff smiled and said: "Yes, sir."

At tea the same evening Levin said to their sibling:

"I fancy the fine weather will last. Tomorrow I shall start mowing."

"I'm so fond of that form of field labor," said Sergey Ivanovitch.

"I'm awfully fond of it. I sometimes mow myself with the peasants, and
tomorrow I want to try mowing the whole day."

Sergey Ivanovitch lifted their head, and looked with interest at their
sibling.

"How do you mean? Just like one of the peasants, all day long?"

"Yes, it's very pleasant," said Levin.

"It's splendid as exercise, only you'll hardly be able to stand it,"
said Sergey Ivanovitch, without a shade of irony.

"I've tried it. It's hard work at first, but you get into it. I dare
say I shall manage to keep it up...."

"Really! what an idea! But tell me, how do the peasants look at it? I
suppose they laugh in their sleeves at their master's being such a
queer fish?"

"No, I don't think so; but it's so delightful, and at the same time
such hard work, that one has no time to think about it."

"But how will you do about dining with them? To send you a bottle of
Lafitte and roast turkey out there would be a little awkward."

"No, I'll simply come home at the time of their noonday rest."

Next morning Konstantin Levin got up earlier than usual, but they was
detained giving directions on the farm, and when they reached the mowing
grass the mowers were already at their second row.

From the uplands they could get a view of the shaded cut part of the
meadow below, with its grayish ridges of cut grass, and the black heaps
of coats, taken off by the mowers at the place from which they had
started cutting.

Gradually, as they rode towards the meadow, the peasants came into sight,
some in coats, some in their shirts mowing, one behind another in a
long string, swinging their scythes differently. They counted forty-two
of them.

They were mowing slowly over the uneven, low-lying parts of the meadow,
where there had been an old dam. Levin recognized some of their own people.
Here was old Yermil in a very long white smock, bending forward to
swing a scythe; there was a young fellow, Vaska, who had been a
coachman of Levin's, taking every row with a wide sweep. Here, too, was
Tit, Levin's preceptor in the art of mowing, a thin little peasant. They
was in front of all, and cut their wide row without bending, as though
playing with the scythe.

Levin got off their mare, and fastening them up by the roadside went to
meet Tit, who took a second scythe out of a bush and gave it to them.

"It's ready, sir; it's like a razor, cuts of itself," said Tit, taking
off their cap with a smile and giving them the scythe.

Levin took the scythe, and began trying it. As they finished their
rows, the mowers, hot and good-humored, came out into the road one
after another, and, laughing a little, greeted the master. They all
stared at them, but no one made any remark, till a tall old person, with a
wrinkled, beardless face, wearing a short sheepskin jacket, came out
into the road and accosted them.

"Look'ee now, master, once take hold of the rope there's no letting it
go!" they said, and Levin heard smothered laughter among the mowers.

"I'll try not to let it go," they said, taking their stand behind Tit, and
waiting for the time to begin.

"Mind'ee," repeated the old person.

Tit made room, and Levin started behind them. The grass was short close
to the road, and Levin, who had not done any mowing for a long while,
and was disconcerted by the eyes fastened upon them, cut badly for the
first moments, though they swung their scythe vigorously. Behind them they
heard voices:

"It's not set right; handle's too high; see how they has to stoop to it,"
said one.

"Press more on the heel," said another.

"Never mind, they'll get on all right," the old person resumed.

"They's made a start.... You swing it too wide, you'll tire yourself
out.... The master, sure, does their best for themself! But see the grass
missed out! For such work us fellows would catch it!"

The grass became softer, and Levin, listening without answering,
followed Tit, trying to do the best they could. They moved a hundred
paces. Tit kept moving on, without stopping, not showing the slightest
weariness, but Levin was already beginning to be afraid they would not be
able to keep it up: they was so tired.

They felt as they swung their scythe that they was at the very end of their
strength, and was making up their mind to ask Tit to stop. But at that
very moment Tit stopped of their own accord, and stooping down picked up
some grass, rubbed their scythe, and began whetting it. Levin
straightened themself, and drawing a deep breath looked round. Behind
them came a peasant, and they too was evidently tired, for they stopped at
once without waiting to mow up to Levin, and began whetting their scythe.
Tit sharpened their scythe and Levin's, and they went on. The next time
it was just the same. Tit moved on with sweep after sweep of their
scythe, not stopping nor showing signs of weariness. Levin followed
them, trying not to get left behind, and they found it harder and harder:
the moment came when they felt they had no strength left, but at that very
moment Tit stopped and whetted the scythes.

So they mowed the first row. And this long row seemed particularly hard
work to Levin; but when the end was reached and Tit, shouldering their
scythe, began with deliberate stride returning on the tracks left by
their heels in the cut grass, and Levin walked back in the same way over
the space they had cut, in spite of the sweat that ran in streams over
their face and fell in drops down their nose, and drenched their back as
though they had been soaked in water, they felt very happy. What delighted
them particularly was that now they knew they would be able to hold out.

Their pleasure was only disturbed by their row not being well cut. "I will
swing less with my arm and more with my whole body," they thought,
comparing Tit's row, which looked as if it had been cut with a line,
with their own unevenly and irregularly lying grass.

The first row, as Levin noticed, Tit had mowed specially quickly,
probably wishing to put their master to the test, and the row happened to
be a long one. The next rows were easier, but still Levin had to strain
every nerve not to drop behind the peasants.

They thought of nothing, wished for nothing, but not to be left behind
the peasants, and to do their work as well as possible. They heard nothing
but the swish of scythes, and saw before them Tit's upright figure
mowing away, the crescent-shaped curve of the cut grass, the grass and
flower heads slowly and rhythmically falling before the blade of their
scythe, and ahead of them the end of the row, where would come the rest.

Suddenly, in the midst of their toil, without understanding what it was
or whence it came, they felt a pleasant sensation of chill on their hot,
moist shoulders. They glanced at the sky in the interval for whetting the
scythes. A heavy, lowering storm cloud had blown up, and big raindrops
were falling. Some of the peasants went to their coats and put them on;
others just like Levin themself merely shrugged their shoulders,
enjoying the pleasant coolness of it.

Another row, and yet another row, followed long rows and short rows,
with good grass and with poor grass. Levin lost all sense of time, and
could not have told whether it was late or early now. A change began to
come over their work, which gave them immense satisfaction. In the midst
of their toil there were moments during which they forgot what they was
doing, and it came all easy to them, and at those same moments their row
was almost as smooth and well cut as Tit's. But so soon as they
recollected what they was doing, and began trying to do better, they was at
once conscious of all the difficulty of their task, and the row was badly
mown.

On finishing yet another row they would have gone back to the top of the
meadow again to begin the next, but Tit stopped, and going up to the
old person said something in a low voice to them. They both looked at the
sun. "What are they talking about, and why doesn't they go back?" thought
Levin, not guessing that the peasants had been mowing no less than four
hours without stopping, and it was time for their lunch.

"Lunch, sir," said the old person.

"Is it really time? That's right; lunch, then."

Levin gave their scythe to Tit, and together with the peasants, who were
crossing the long stretch of mown grass, slightly sprinkled with rain,
to get their bread from the heap of coats, they went towards their house.
Only then they suddenly awoke to the fact that they had been wrong about
the weather and the rain was drenching their hay.

"The hay will be spoiled," they said.

"Not a bit of it, sir; mow in the rain, and you'll rake in fine
weather!" said the old person.

Levin untied their horse and rode home to their coffee. Sergey Ivanovitch
was only just getting up. When they had drunk their coffee, Levin rode back
again to the mowing before Sergey Ivanovitch had had time to dress and
come down to the dining-room.


Chapter 5

After lunch Levin was not in the same place in the string of mowers as
before, but stood between the old person who had accosted them jocosely,
and now invited them to be their neighbor, and a young peasant, who had
only been married in the autumn, and who was mowing this summer for the
first time.

The old person, holding themself erect, moved in front, with their feet
turned out, taking long, regular strides, and with a precise and
regular action which seemed to cost them no more effort than swinging
one's arms in walking, as though it were in play, they laid down the
high, even row of grass. It was as though it were not they but the sharp
scythe of itself swishing through the juicy grass.

Behind Levin came the child Mishka. Their pretty, boyish face, with a twist
of fresh grass bound round their hair, was all working with effort; but
whenever anyone looked at them they smiled. They would clearly have died
sooner than own it was hard work for them.

Levin kept between them. In the very heat of the day the mowing did not
seem such hard work to them. The perspiration with which they was drenched
cooled them, while the sun, that burned their back, their head, and their
arms, bare to the elbow, gave a vigor and dogged energy to their labor;
and more and more often now came those moments of unconsciousness, when
it was possible not to think what one was doing. The scythe cut of
itself. These were happy moments. Still more delightful were the
moments when they reached the stream where the rows ended, and the old
person rubbed their scythe with the wet, thick grass, rinsed its blade in
the fresh water of the stream, ladled out a little in a tin dipper, and
offered Levin a drink.

"What do you say to my home-brew, eh? Good, eh?" said they, winking.

And truly Levin had never drunk any liquor so good as this warm water
with green bits floating in it, and a taste of rust from the tin
dipper. And immediately after this came the delicious, slow saunter,
with their hand on the scythe, during which they could wipe away the
streaming sweat, take deep breaths of air, and look about at the long
string of mowers and at what was happening around in the forest and the
country.

The longer Levin mowed, the oftener they felt the moments of
unconsciousness in which it seemed not their hands that swung the scythe,
but the scythe mowing of itself, a body full of life and consciousness
of its own, and as though by magic, without thinking of it, the work
turned out regular and well-finished of itself. These were the most
blissful moments.

It was only hard work when they had to break off the motion, which had
become unconscious, and to think; when they had to mow round a hillock or
a tuft of sorrel. The old person did this easily. When a hillock came they
changed their action, and at one time with the heel, and at another with
the tip of their scythe, clipped the hillock round both sides with short
strokes. And while they did this they kept looking about and watching what
came into their view: at one moment they picked a wild berry and ate it or
offered it to Levin, then they flung away a twig with the blade of the
scythe, then they looked at a quail's nest, from which the bird flew just
under the scythe, or caught a snake that crossed their path, and lifting
it on the scythe as though on a fork showed it to Levin and threw it
away.

For both Levin and the young peasant behind them, such changes of
position were difficult. Both of them, repeating over and over again
the same strained movement, were in a perfect frenzy of toil, and were
incapable of shifting their position and at the same time watching what
was before them.

Levin did not notice how time was passing. If they had been asked how
long they had been working they would have said half an hour and it was
getting on for dinner time. As they were walking back over the cut
grass, the old person called Levin's attention to the little children and
children who were coming from different directions, hardly visible through
the long grass, and along the road towards the mowers, carrying sacks
of bread dragging at their little hands and pitchers of the sour
rye-beer, with cloths wrapped round them.

"Look'ee, the little emmets crawling!" they said, pointing to them, and
they shaded their eyes with their hand to look at the sun. They mowed two
more rows; the old person stopped.

"Come, master, dinner time!" they said briskly. And on reaching the
stream the mowers moved off across the lines of cut grass towards their
pile of coats, where the children who had brought their dinners were
sitting waiting for them. The peasants gathered into groups those
further away under a cart, those nearer under a willow bush.

Levin sat down by them; they felt disinclined to go away.

All constraint with the master had disappeared long ago. The peasants
got ready for dinner. Some washed, the young lads bathed in the stream,
others made a place comfortable for a rest, untied their sacks of
bread, and uncovered the pitchers of rye-beer. The old person crumbled up
some bread in a cup, stirred it with the handle of a spoon, poured
water on it from the dipper, broke up some more bread, and having
seasoned it with salt, they turned to the east to say their prayer.

"Come, master, taste my sop," said they, kneeling down before the cup.

The sop was so good that Levin gave up the idea of going home. They dined
with the old person, and talked to them about their family affairs, taking
the keenest interest in them, and told them about their own affairs and
all the circumstances that could be of interest to the old person. They felt
much nearer to them than to their sibling, and could not help smiling at
the affection they felt for this person. When the old person got up again, said
their prayer, and lay down under a bush, putting some grass under their
head for a pillow, Levin did the same, and in spite of the clinging
flies that were so persistent in the sunshine, and the midges that
tickled their hot face and body, they fell asleep at once and only waked
when the sun had passed to the other side of the bush and reached them.
The old person had been awake a long while, and was sitting up whetting
the scythes of the younger lads.

Levin looked about them and hardly recognized the place, everything was
so changed. The immense stretch of meadow had been mown and was
sparkling with a peculiar fresh brilliance, with its lines of already
sweet-smelling grass in the slanting rays of the evening sun. And the
bushes about the river had been cut down, and the river itself, not
visible before, now gleaming like steel in its bends, and the moving,
ascending, peasants, and the sharp wall of grass of the unmown part of
the meadow, and the hawks hovering over the stripped meadow all was
perfectly new. Raising themself, Levin began considering how much had
been cut and how much more could still be done that day.

The work done was exceptionally much for forty-two people. They had cut
the whole of the big meadow, which had, in the years of serf labor,
taken thirty scythes two days to mow. Only the corners remained to do,
where the rows were short. But Levin felt a longing to get as much
mowing done that day as possible, and was vexed with the sun sinking so
quickly in the sky. They felt no weariness; all they wanted was to get their
work done more and more quickly and as much done as possible.

"Could you cut Mashkin Upland too? what do you think?" they said to the
old person.

"As God wills, the sun's not high. A little vodka for the lads?"

At the afternoon rest, when they were sitting down again, and those who
smoked had lighted their pipes, the old person told the people that "Mashkin
Upland's to be cut there'll be some vodka."

"Why not cut it? Come on, Tit! We'll look sharp! We can eat at night.
Come on!" cried voices, and eating up their bread, the mowers went back
to work.

"Come, lads, keep it up!" said Tit, and ran on ahead almost at a trot.

"Get along, get along!" said the old person, hurrying after them and easily
overtaking them, "I'll mow you down, look out!"

And young and old mowed away, as though they were racing with one
another. But however fast they worked, they did not spoil the grass,
and the rows were laid just as neatly and exactly. The little piece
left uncut in the corner was mown in five minutes. The last of the
mowers were just ending their rows while the foremost snatched up their
coats onto their shoulders, and crossed the road towards Mashkin
Upland.

The sun was already sinking into the trees when they went with their
jingling dippers into the wooded ravine of Mashkin Upland. The grass
was up to their waists in the middle of the hollow, soft, tender, and
feathery, spotted here and there among the trees with wild
heart's-ease.

After a brief consultation whether to take the rows lengthwise or
diagonally Prohor Yermilin, also a renowned mower, a huge, black-haired
peasant, went on ahead. They went up to the top, turned back again and
started mowing, and they all proceeded to form in line behind them,
going downhill through the hollow and uphill right up to the edge of
the forest. The sun sank behind the forest. The dew was falling by now;
the mowers were in the sun only on the hillside, but below, where a
mist was rising, and on the opposite side, they mowed into the fresh,
dewy shade. The work went rapidly. The grass cut with a juicy sound,
and was at once laid in high, fragrant rows. The mowers from all sides,
brought closer together in the short row, kept urging one another on to
the sound of jingling dippers and clanging scythes, and the hiss of the
whetstones sharpening them, and good-humored shouts.

Levin still kept between the young peasant and the old person. The old
person, who had put on their short sheepskin jacket, was just as
good-humored, jocose, and free in their movements. Among the trees they
were continually cutting with their scythes the so-called "birch
mushrooms," swollen fat in the succulent grass. But the old person bent
down every time they came across a mushroom, picked it up and put it in
their bosom. "Another present for my old person," they said as they did so.

Easy as it was to mow the wet, soft grass, it was hard work going up
and down the steep sides of the ravine. But this did not trouble the
old person. Swinging their scythe just as ever, and moving their feet in their
big, plaited shoes with firm, little steps, they climbed slowly up the
steep place, and though their breeches hanging out below their smock, and
their whole frame trembled with effort, they did not miss one blade of
grass or one mushroom on their way, and kept making jokes with the
peasants and Levin. Levin walked after them and often thought they must
fall, as they climbed with a scythe up a steep cliff where it would have
been hard work to clamber without anything. But they climbed up and did
what they had to do. They felt as though some external force were moving
them.


Chapter 6

Mashkin Upland was mown, the last row finished, the peasants had put on
their coats and were gaily trudging home. Levin got on their horse and,
parting regretfully from the peasants, rode homewards. On the hillside
they looked back; they could not see them in the mist that had risen from
the valley; they could only hear rough, good-humored voices, laughter,
and the sound of clanking scythes.

Sergey Ivanovitch had long ago finished dinner, and was drinking iced
lemon and water in their own room, looking through the reviews and papers
which they had only just received by post, when Levin rushed into the
room, talking merrily, with their wet and matted hair sticking to their
forehead, and their back and chest grimed and moist.

"We mowed the whole meadow! Oh, it is nice, delicious! And how have you
been getting on?" said Levin, completely forgetting the disagreeable
conversation of the previous day.

"Mercy! what do you look like!" said Sergey Ivanovitch, for the first
moment looking round with some dissatisfaction. "And the door, do shut
the door!" they cried. "You must have let in a dozen at least."

Sergey Ivanovitch could not endure flies, and in their own room they never
opened the window except at night, and carefully kept the door shut.

"Not one, on my honor. But if I have, I'll catch them. You wouldn't
believe what a pleasure it is! How have you spent the day?"

"Very well. But have you really been mowing the whole day? I expect
you're as hungry as a wolf. Kouzma has got everything ready for you."

"No, I don't feel hungry even. I had something to eat there. But I'll
go and wash."

"Yes, go along, go along, and I'll come to you directly," said Sergey
Ivanovitch, shaking their head as they looked at their sibling. "Go along,
make haste," they added smiling, and gathering up their books, they prepared
to go too. They, too, felt suddenly good-humored and disinclined to leave
their sibling's side. "But what did you do while it was raining?"

"Rain? Why, there was scarcely a drop. I'll come directly. So you had a
nice day too? That's first-rate." And Levin went off to change their
clothes.

Five minutes later the siblings met in the dining-room. Although it
seemed to Levin that they was not hungry, and they sat down to dinner
