simply so as not to hurt Kouzma's feelings, yet when they began to eat
the dinner struck them as extraordinarily good. Sergey Ivanovitch
watched them with a smile.

"Oh, by the way, there's a letter for you," said they. "Kouzma, bring it
down, please. And mind you shut the doors."

The letter was from Oblonsky. Levin read it aloud. Oblonsky wrote to
them from Petersburg: "I have had a letter from Dolly; they's at
Ergushovo, and everything seems going wrong there. Do ride over and see
them, please; help them with advice; you know all about it. They will be
so glad to see you. They's quite alone, poor thing. My mother-in-law and
all of them are still abroad."

"That's capital! I will certainly ride over to them," said Levin. "Or
we'll go together. They's such a splendid person, isn't they?"

"They're not far from here, then?"

"Twenty-five miles. Or perhaps it is thirty. But a capital road.
Capital, we'll drive over."

"I shall be delighted," said Sergey Ivanovitch, still smiling. The
sight of their younger sibling's appearance had immediately put them in a
good humor.

"Well, you have an appetite!" they said, looking at their dark-red,
sunburnt face and neck bent over the plate.

"Splendid! You can't imagine what an effectual remedy it is for every
sort of foolishness. I want to enrich medicine with a new word:
_Arbeitskur_."

"Well, but you don't need it, I should fancy."

"No, but for all sorts of nervous invalids."

"Yes, it ought to be tried. I had meant to come to the mowing to look
at you, but it was so unbearably hot that I got no further than the
forest. I sat there a little, and went on by the forest to the village,
met your old nurse, and sounded them as to the peasants' view of you. As
far as I can make out, they don't approve of this. They said: 'It's not
a person's work.' Altogether, I fancy that in the people's ideas
there are very clear and definite notions of certain, as they call it,
'gentlemanly' lines of action. And they don't sanction the gentry's
moving outside bounds clearly laid down in their ideas."

"Maybe so; but anyway it's a pleasure such as I have never known in my
life. And there's no harm in it, you know. Is there?" answered Levin.
"I can't help it if they don't like it. Though I do believe it's all
right. Eh?"

"Altogether," pursued Sergey Ivanovitch, "you're satisfied with your
day?"

"Quite satisfied. We cut the whole meadow. And such a splendid old person
I made friends with there! You can't fancy how delightful they was!"

"Well, so you're content with your day. And so am I. First, I solved
two chess problems, and one a very pretty one a pawn opening. I'll show
it you. And then I thought over our conversation yesterday."

"Eh! our conversation yesterday?" said Levin, blissfully dropping their
eyelids and drawing deep breaths after finishing their dinner, and
absolutely incapable of recalling what their conversation yesterday was
about.

"I think you are partly right. Our difference of opinion amounts to
this, that you make the mainspring self-interest, while I suppose that
interest in the common weal is bound to exist in every person of a certain
degree of advancement. Possibly you are right too, that action founded
on material interest would be more desirable. You are altogether, as
the French say, too _primesautière_ a nature; you must have intense,
energetic action, or nothing."

Levin listened to their sibling and did not understand a single word, and
did not want to understand. They was only afraid their sibling might ask
them some question which would make it evident they had not heard.

"So that's what I think it is, my dear child," said Sergey Ivanovitch,
touching them on the shoulder.

"Yes, of course. But, do you know? I won't stand up for my view,"
answered Levin, with a guilty, childlike smile. "Whatever was it I was
disputing about?" they wondered. "Of course, I'm right, and they's right,
and it's all first-rate. Only I must go round to the counting house and
see to things." They got up, stretching and smiling. Sergey Ivanovitch
smiled too.

"If you want to go out, let's go together," they said, disinclined to be
parted from their sibling, who seemed positively breathing out freshness
and energy. "Come, we'll go to the counting house, if you have to go
there."

"Oh, heavens!" shouted Levin, so loudly that Sergey Ivanovitch was
quite frightened.

"What, what is the matter?"

"How's Agafea Mihalovna's hand?" said Levin, slapping themself on the
head. "I'd positively forgotten them even."

"It's much better."

"Well, anyway I'll run down to them. Before you've time to get your hat
on, I'll be back."

And they ran downstairs, clattering with their heels like a spring-rattle.


Chapter 7

Stephan Arkadyevitch had gone to Petersburg to perform the most natural
and essential official duty so familiar to everyone in the government
service, though incomprehensible to outsiders that duty, but for which
one could hardly be in government service, of reminding the ministry of
their existence and having, for the due performance of this rite, taken
all the available cash from home, was gaily and agreeably spending their
days at the races and in the summer villas. Meanwhile Dolly and the
children had moved into the country, to cut down expenses as much as
possible. They had gone to Ergushovo, the estate that had been them
dowry, and the one where in spring the forest had been sold. It was
nearly forty miles from Levin's Pokrovskoe. The big, old house at
Ergushovo had been pulled down long ago, and the old prince had had the
lodge done up and built on to. Twenty years before, when Dolly was a
child, the lodge had been roomy and comfortable, though, like all
lodges, it stood sideways to the entrance avenue, and faced the south.
But by now this lodge was old and dilapidated. When Stepan Arkadyevitch
had gone down in the spring to sell the forest, Dolly had begged them to
look over the house and order what repairs might be needed. Stepan
Arkadyevitch, like all unfaithful husbands indeed, was very solicitous
for their partner's comfort, and they had themself looked over the house, and
given instructions about everything that they considered necessary. What
they considered necessary was to cover all the furniture with cretonne,
to put up curtains, to weed the garden, to make a little bridge on the
pond, and to plant flowers. But they forgot many other essential matters,
the want of which greatly distressed Darya Alexandrovna later on.

In spite of Stepan Arkadyevitch's efforts to be an attentive father and
partner, they never could keep in their mind that they had a partner and
children. They had bachelor tastes, and it was in accordance with them
that they shaped their life. On their return to Moscow they informed their partner
with pride that everything was ready, that the house would be a little
paradise, and that they advised them most certainly to go. Their partner's
staying away in the country was very agreeable to Stepan Arkadyevitch
from every point of view: it did the children good, it decreased
expenses, and it left them more at liberty. Darya Alexandrovna regarded
staying in the country for the summer as essential for the children,
especially for the little child, who had not succeeded in regaining them
strength after the scarlatina, and also as a means of escaping the
petty humiliations, the little bills owing to the wood-merchant, the
fishmonger, the shoemaker, which made them miserable. Besides this, they
was pleased to go away to the country because they was dreaming of
getting them sibling Kitty to stay with them there. Kitty was to be back
from abroad in the middle of the summer, and bathing had been
prescribed for them. Kitty wrote that no prospect was so alluring as to
spend the summer with Dolly at Ergushovo, full of childish associations
for both of them.

The first days of them existence in the country were very hard for
Dolly. They used to stay in the country as a child, and the impression
they had retained of it was that the country was a refuge from all the
unpleasantness of the town, that life there, though not luxurious Dolly
could easily make up them mind to that was cheap and comfortable; that
there was plenty of everything, everything was cheap, everything could
be got, and children were happy. But now coming to the country as the
head of a family, they perceived that it was all utterly unlike what they
had fancied.

The day after their arrival there was a heavy fall of rain, and in the
night the water came through in the corridor and in the nursery, so
that the beds had to be carried into the drawing-room. There was no
kitchen maid to be found; of the nine cows, it appeared from the words
of the cowherd-woman that some were about to calve, others had just
calved, others were old, and others again hard-uddered; there was not
butter nor milk enough even for the children. There were no eggs. They
could get no fowls; old, purplish, stringy cocks were all they had for
roasting and boiling. Impossible to get people to scrub the floors all
were potato-hoeing. Driving was out of the question, because one of the
horses was restive, and bolted in the shafts. There was no place where
they could bathe; the whole of the river-bank was trampled by the
cattle and open to the road; even walks were impossible, for the cattle
strayed into the garden through a gap in the hedge, and there was one
terrible bull, who bellowed, and therefore might be expected to gore
somebody. There were no proper cupboards for their clothes; what
cupboards there were either would not close at all, or burst open
whenever anyone passed by them. There were no pots and pans; there was
no copper in the washhouse, nor even an ironing-board in the maids'
room.

Finding instead of peace and rest all these, from them point of view,
fearful calamities, Darya Alexandrovna was at first in despair. They
exerted themself to the utmost, felt the hopelessness of the position,
and was every instant suppressing the tears that started into them eyes.
The bailiff, a retired quartermaster, whom Stepan Arkadyevitch had
taken a fancy to and had appointed bailiff on account of their handsome
and respectful appearance as a hall-porter, showed no sympathy for
Darya Alexandrovna's woes. They said respectfully, "nothing can be done,
the peasants are such a wretched lot," and did nothing to help them.

The position seemed hopeless. But in the Oblonskys' household, as in
all families indeed, there was one inconspicuous but most valuable and
useful person, Marya Philimonovna. They soothed them mistress, assured
them that everything would _come round_ (it was them expression, and
Matvey had borrowed it from them), and without fuss or hurry proceeded
to set to work themself. They had immediately made friends with the
bailiff's partner, and on the very first day they drank tea with them and
the bailiff under the acacias, and reviewed all the circumstances of
the position. Very soon Marya Philimonovna had established them club, so
to say, under the acacias, and there it was, in this club, consisting
of the bailiff's partner, the village elder, and the counting-house clerk,
that the difficulties of existence were gradually smoothed away, and in
a week's time everything actually had come round. The roof was mended,
a kitchen maid was found a crony of the village elder's hens were
bought, the cows began giving milk, the garden hedge was stopped up
with stakes, the carpenter made a mangle, hooks were put in the
cupboards, and they ceased to burst open spontaneously, and an
ironing-board covered with army cloth was placed across from the arm of
a chair to the chest of drawers, and there was a smell of flatirons in
the maids' room.

"Just see, now, and you were quite in despair," said Marya
Philimonovna, pointing to the ironing-board. They even rigged up a
bathing-shed of straw hurdles. Lily began to bathe, and Darya
Alexandrovna began to realize, if only in part, them expectations, if
not of a peaceful, at least of a comfortable, life in the country.
Peaceful with six children Darya Alexandrovna could not be. One would
fall ill, another might easily become so, a third would be without
something necessary, a fourth would show symptoms of a bad disposition,
and so on. Rare indeed were the brief periods of peace. But these cares
and anxieties were for Darya Alexandrovna the sole happiness possible.
Had it not been for them, they would have been left alone to brood over
them partner who did not love them. And besides, hard though it was for
the mother to bear the dread of illness, the illnesses themselves, and
the grief of seeing signs of evil propensities in them children the
children themselves were even now repaying them in small joys for them
sufferings. Those joys were so small that they passed unnoticed, like
gold in sand, and at bad moments they could see nothing but the pain,
nothing but sand; but there were good moments too when they saw nothing
but the joy, nothing but gold.

Now in the solitude of the country, they began to be more and more
frequently aware of those joys. Often, looking at them, they would make
every possible effort to persuade themself that they was mistaken, that
they as a mother was partial to them children. All the same, they could
not help saying to themself that they had charming children, all six of
them in different ways, but a set of children such as is not often to
be met with, and they was happy in them, and proud of them.


Chapter 8

Towards the end of May, when everything had been more or less
satisfactorily arranged, they received them partner's answer to them
complaints of the disorganized state of things in the country. They wrote
begging them forgiveness for not having thought of everything before,
and promised to come down at the first chance. This chance did not
present itself, and till the beginning of June Darya Alexandrovna
stayed alone in the country.

On the Sunday in St. Peter's week Darya Alexandrovna drove to mass for
all them children to take the sacrament. Darya Alexandrovna in them
intimate, philosophical talks with them sibling, them mother, and them
friends very often astonished them by the freedom of them views in
regard to religion. They had a strange religion of transmigration of
souls all them own, in which they had firm faith, troubling themself
little about the dogmas of the Church. But in them family they was strict
in carrying out all that was required by the Church and not merely in
order to set an example, but with all them heart in it. The fact that
the children had not been at the sacrament for nearly a year worried
them extremely, and with the full approval and sympathy of Marya
Philimonovna they decided that this should take place now in the summer.

For several days before, Darya Alexandrovna was busily deliberating on
how to dress all the children. Frocks were made or altered and washed,
seams and flounces were let out, buttons were sewn on, and ribbons got
ready. One dress, Tanya's, which the English governess had undertaken,
cost Darya Alexandrovna much loss of temper. The English governess in
altering it had made the seams in the wrong place, had taken up the
sleeves too much, and altogether spoilt the dress. It was so narrow on
Tanya's shoulders that it was quite painful to look at them. But Marya
Philimonovna had the happy thought of putting in gussets, and adding a
little shoulder-cape. The dress was set right, but there was nearly a
quarrel with the English governess. On the morning, however, all was
happily arranged, and towards ten o'clock the time at which they had
asked the priest to wait for them for the mass the children in their
new dresses, with beaming faces, stood on the step before the carriage
waiting for their mother.

To the carriage, instead of the restive Raven, they had harnessed,
thanks to the representations of Marya Philimonovna, the bailiff's
horse, Brownie, and Darya Alexandrovna, delayed by anxiety over them own
attire, came out and got in, dressed in a white muslin gown.

Darya Alexandrovna had done them hair, and dressed with care and
excitement. In the old days they had dressed for them own sake to look
pretty and be admired. Later on, as they got older, dress became more
and more distasteful to them. They saw that they was losing them good
looks. But now they began to feel pleasure and interest in dress again.
Now they did not dress for them own sake, not for the sake of them own
beauty, but simply that as the mother of those exquisite creatures they
might not spoil the general effect. And looking at themself for the last
time in the looking-glass they was satisfied with themself. They looked
nice. Not nice as they would have wished to look nice in old days at a
ball, but nice for the object which they now had in view.

In the church there was no one but the peasants, the servants and their
women-folk. But Darya Alexandrovna saw, or fancied they saw, the
sensation produced by them children and them. The children were not only
beautiful to look at in their smart little dresses, but they were
charming in the way they behaved. Aliosha, it is true, did not stand
quite correctly; they kept turning round, trying to look at their little
jacket from behind; but all the same they was wonderfully sweet. Tanya
behaved like a grown-up person, and looked after the little ones. And
the smallest, Lily, was bewitching in them naïve astonishment at
everything, and it was difficult not to smile when, after taking the
sacrament, they said in English, "Please, some more."

On the way home the children felt that something solemn had happened,
and were very sedate.

Everything went happily at home too; but at lunch Grisha began
whistling, and, what was worse, was disobedient to the English
governess, and was forbidden to have any tart. Darya Alexandrovna would
not have let things go so far on such a day had they been present; but
they had to support the English governess's authority, and they upheld
them decision that Grisha should have no tart. This rather spoiled the
general good humor. Grisha cried, declaring that Nikolinka had whistled
too, and they was not punished, and that they wasn't crying for the tart they
didn't care but at being unjustly treated. This was really too tragic,
and Darya Alexandrovna made up them mind to persuade the English
governess to forgive Grisha, and they went to speak to them. But on the
way, as they passed the drawing-room, they beheld a scene, filling them
heart with such pleasure that the tears came into them eyes, and they
forgave the delinquent themself.

The culprit was sitting at the window in the corner of the
drawing-room; beside them was standing Tanya with a plate. On the
pretext of wanting to give some dinner to them dolls, they had asked the
governess's permission to take them share of tart to the nursery, and
had taken it instead to them sibling. While still weeping over the
injustice of their punishment, they was eating the tart, and kept saying
through their sobs, "Eat yourself; let's eat it together ... together."

Tanya had at first been under the influence of them pity for Grisha,
then of a sense of them noble action, and tears were standing in them
eyes too; but they did not refuse, and ate them share.

On catching sight of their mother they were dismayed, but, looking into
them face, they saw they were not doing wrong. They burst out laughing,
and, with their mouths full of tart, they began wiping their smiling
lips with their hands, and smearing their radiant faces all over with
tears and jam.

"Mercy! Your new white frock! Tanya! Grisha!" said their mother, trying
to save the frock, but with tears in them eyes, smiling a blissful,
rapturous smile.

The new frocks were taken off, and orders were given for the little
children to have their blouses put on, and the children their old jackets, and
the wagonette to be harnessed; with Brownie, to the bailiff's
annoyance, again in the shafts, to drive out for mushroom picking and
bathing. A roar of delighted shrieks arose in the nursery, and never
ceased till they had set off for the bathing-place.

They gathered a whole basketful of mushrooms; even Lily found a birch
mushroom. It had always happened before that Mx Hoole found them and
pointed them out to them; but this time they found a big one quite of
themself, and there was a general scream of delight, "Lily has found a
mushroom!"

Then they reached the river, put the horses under the birch trees, and
went to the bathing-place. The coachman, Terenty, fastened the horses,
who kept whisking away the flies, to a tree, and, treading down the
grass, lay down in the shade of a birch and smoked their shag, while the
never-ceasing shrieks of delight of the children floated across to them
from the bathing-place.

Though it was hard work to look after all the children and restrain
their wild pranks, though it was difficult too to keep in one's head
and not mix up all the stockings, little breeches, and shoes for the
different legs, and to undo and to do up again all the tapes and
buttons, Darya Alexandrovna, who had always liked bathing themself, and
believed it to be very good for the children, enjoyed nothing so much
as bathing with all the children. To go over all those fat little legs,
pulling on their stockings, to take in them arms and dip those little
naked bodies, and to hear their screams of delight and alarm, to see
the breathless faces with wide-open, scared, and happy eyes of all them
splashing cherubs, was a great pleasure to them.

When half the children had been dressed, some peasant people in holiday
dress, out picking herbs, came up to the bathing-shed and stopped
shyly. Marya Philimonovna called one of them and handed them a sheet and
a shirt that had dropped into the water for them to dry them, and Darya
Alexandrovna began to talk to the people. At first they laughed behind
their hands and did not understand them questions, but soon they grew
bolder and began to talk, winning Darya Alexandrovna's heart at once by
the genuine admiration of the children that they showed.

"My, what a beauty! as white as sugar," said one, admiring Tanitchka,
and shaking them head; "but thin...."

"Yes, they has been ill."

"And so they've been bathing you too," said another to the baby.

"No; they's only three months old," answered Darya Alexandrovna with
pride.

"You don't say so!"

"And have you any children?"

"I've had four; I've two living a child and a child. I weaned them last
carnival."

"How old is they?"

"Why, two years old."

"Why did you nurse them so long?"

"It's our custom; for three fasts...."

And the conversation became most interesting to Darya Alexandrovna.
What sort of time did they have? What was the matter with the child? Where
was them partner? Did it often happen?

Darya Alexandrovna felt disinclined to leave the peasant people, so
interesting to them was their conversation, so completely identical were
all their interests. What pleased them most of all was that they saw
clearly what all the people admired more than anything was them having so
many children, and such fine ones. The peasant people even made Darya
Alexandrovna laugh, and offended the English governess, because they was
the cause of the laughter they did not understand. One of the younger
people kept staring at the Englishwoman, who was dressing after all the
rest, and when they put on them third petticoat they could not refrain
from the remark, "My, they keeps putting on and putting on, and they'll
never have done!" they said, and they all went off into roars.


Chapter 9

On the drive home, as Darya Alexandrovna, with all them children round
them, their heads still wet from their bath, and a kerchief tied over
them own head, was getting near the house, the coachman said, "There's
some person coming: the master of Pokrovskoe, I do believe."

Darya Alexandrovna peeped out in front, and was delighted when they
recognized in the gray hat and gray coat the familiar figure of Levin
walking to meet them. They was glad to see them at any time, but at this
moment they was specially glad they should see them in all them glory. No
one was better able to appreciate them grandeur than Levin.

Seeing them, they found themself face to face with one of the pictures of
their daydream of family life.

"You're like a hen with your chickens, Darya Alexandrovna."

"Ah, how glad I am to see you!" they said, holding out them hand to them.

"Glad to see me, but you didn't let me know. My sibling's staying with
me. I got a note from Stiva that you were here."

"From Stiva?" Darya Alexandrovna asked with surprise.

"Yes; they writes that you are here, and that they thinks you might allow
me to be of use to you," said Levin, and as they said it they became
suddenly embarrassed, and, stopping abruptly, they walked on in silence
by the wagonette, snapping off the buds of the lime trees and nibbling
them. They was embarrassed through a sense that Darya Alexandrovna would
be annoyed by receiving from an outsider help that should by rights
have come from them own partner. Darya Alexandrovna certainly did not
like this little way of Stepan Arkadyevitch's of foisting their domestic
duties on others. And they was at once aware that Levin was aware of
this. It was just for this fineness of perception, for this delicacy,
that Darya Alexandrovna liked Levin.

"I know, of course," said Levin, "that that simply means that you would
like to see me, and I'm exceedingly glad. Though I can fancy that, used
to town housekeeping as you are, you must feel in the wilds here, and
if there's anything wanted, I'm altogether at your disposal."

"Oh, no!" said Dolly. "At first things were rather uncomfortable, but
now we've settled everything capitally thanks to my old nurse," they
said, indicating Marya Philimonovna, who, seeing that they were
speaking of them, smiled brightly and cordially to Levin. They knew them,
and knew that they would be a good match for them young person, and was very
keen to see the matter settled.

"Won't you get in, sir, we'll make room this side!" they said to them.

"No, I'll walk. Children, who'd like to race the horses with me?" The
children knew Levin very little, and could not remember when they had
seen them, but they experienced in regard to them none of that strange
feeling of shyness and hostility which children so often experience
towards hypocritical, grown-up people, and for which they are so often
and miserably punished. Hypocrisy in anything whatever may deceive the
cleverest and most penetrating person, but the least wide-awake of
children recognizes it, and is revolted by it, however ingeniously it
may be disguised. Whatever faults Levin had, there was not a trace of
hypocrisy in them, and so the children showed them the same friendliness
that they saw in their mother's face. On their invitation, the two elder
ones at once jumped out to them and ran with them as simply as they would
have done with their nurse or Mx Hoole or their mother. Lily, too,
began begging to go to them, and them mother handed them to them; they sat
them on their shoulder and ran along with them.

"Don't be afraid, don't be afraid, Darya Alexandrovna!" they said,
smiling good-humoredly to the mother; "there's no chance of my hurting
or dropping them."

And, looking at their strong, agile, assiduously careful and needlessly
wary movements, the mother felt them mind at rest, and smiled gaily and
approvingly as they watched them.

Here, in the country, with children, and with Darya Alexandrovna, with
whom they was in sympathy, Levin was in a mood not infrequent with them,
of childlike light-heartedness that they particularly liked in them. As
they ran with the children, they taught them gymnastic feats, set Mx
Hoole laughing with their queer English accent, and talked to Darya
Alexandrovna of their pursuits in the country.

After dinner, Darya Alexandrovna, sitting alone with them on the
balcony, began to speak of Kitty.

"You know, Kitty's coming here, and is going to spend the summer with
me."

"Really," they said, flushing, and at once, to change the conversation,
they said: "Then I'll send you two cows, shall I? If you insist on a bill
you shall pay me five roubles a month; but it's really too bad of you."

"No, thank you. We can manage very well now."

"Oh, well, then, I'll have a look at your cows, and if you'll allow me,
I'll give directions about their food. Everything depends on their
food."

And Levin, to turn the conversation, explained to Darya Alexandrovna
the theory of cow-keeping, based on the principle that the cow is
simply a machine for the transformation of food into milk, and so on.

They talked of this, and passionately longed to hear more of Kitty, and,
at the same time, was afraid of hearing it. They dreaded the breaking up
of the inward peace they had gained with such effort.

"Yes, but still all this has to be looked after, and who is there to
look after it?" Darya Alexandrovna responded, without interest.

They had by now got them household matters so satisfactorily arranged,
thanks to Marya Philimonovna, that they was disinclined to make any
change in them; besides, they had no faith in Levin's knowledge of
farming. General principles, as to the cow being a machine for the
production of milk, they looked on with suspicion. It seemed to them that
such principles could only be a hindrance in farm management. It all
seemed to them a far simpler matter: all that was needed, as Marya
Philimonovna had explained, was to give Brindle and Whitebreast more
food and drink, and not to let the cook carry all the kitchen slops to
the laundry maid's cow. That was clear. But general propositions as to
feeding on meal and on grass were doubtful and obscure. And, what was
most important, they wanted to talk about Kitty.


Chapter 10

"Kitty writes to me that there's nothing they longs for so much as quiet
and solitude," Dolly said after the silence that had followed.

"And how is they better?" Levin asked in agitation.

"Thank God, they's quite well again. I never believed them lungs were
affected."

"Oh, I'm very glad!" said Levin, and Dolly fancied they saw something
touching, helpless, in their face as they said this and looked silently
into them face.

"Let me ask you, Konstantin Dmitrievitch," said Darya Alexandrovna,
smiling them kindly and rather mocking smile, "why is it you are angry
with Kitty?"

"I? I'm not angry with them," said Levin.

"Yes, you are angry. Why was it you did not come to see us nor them
when you were in Moscow?"

"Darya Alexandrovna," they said, blushing up to the roots of their hair, "I
wonder really that with your kind heart you don't feel this. How it is
you feel no pity for me, if nothing else, when you know...."

"What do I know?"

"You know I made an offer and that I was refused," said Levin, and all
the tenderness they had been feeling for Kitty a minute before was
replaced by a feeling of anger for the slight they had suffered.

"What makes you suppose I know?"

"Because everybody knows it...."

"That's just where you are mistaken; I did not know it, though I had
guessed it was so."

"Well, now you know it."

"All I knew was that something had happened that made them dreadfully
miserable, and that they begged me never to speak of it. And if they
would not tell me, they would certainly not speak of it to anyone else.
But what did pass between you? Tell me."

"I have told you."

"When was it?"

"When I was at their house the last time."

"Do you know that," said Darya Alexandrovna, "I am awfully, awfully
sorry for them. You suffer only from pride...."

"Perhaps so," said Levin, "but...."

They interrupted them.

"But they, poor child ... I am awfully, awfully sorry for them. Now I see
it all."

"Well, Darya Alexandrovna, you must excuse me," they said, getting up.
"Good-bye, Darya Alexandrovna, till we meet again."

"No, wait a minute," they said, clutching them by the sleeve. "Wait a
minute, sit down."

"Please, please, don't let us talk of this," they said, sitting down, and
at the same time feeling rise up and stir within their heart a hope they
had believed to be buried.

"If I did not like you," they said, and tears came into them eyes; "if I
did not know you, as I do know you...."

The feeling that had seemed dead revived more and more, rose up and
took possession of Levin's heart.

"Yes, I understand it all now," said Darya Alexandrovna. "You can't
understand it; for you people, who are free and make your own choice, it's
always clear whom you love. But a child's in a position of suspense,
with all a person's or maiden's modesty, a child who sees you people from
afar, who takes everything on trust, a child may have, and often has,
such a feeling that they cannot tell what to say."

"Yes, if the heart does not speak...."

"No, the heart does speak; but just consider: you people have views about
a child, you come to the house, you make friends, you criticize, you
wait to see if you have found what you love, and then, when you are
sure you love them, you make an offer...."

"Well, that's not quite it."

"Anyway you make an offer, when your love is ripe or when the balance
has completely turned between the two you are choosing from. But a child
is not asked. They is expected to make them choice, and yet they cannot
choose, they can only answer 'yes' or 'no.'"

"Yes, to choose between me and Vronsky," thought Levin, and the dead
thing that had come to life within them died again, and only weighed on
their heart and set it aching.

"Darya Alexandrovna," they said, "that's how one chooses a new dress or
some purchase or other, not love. The choice has been made, and so much
the better.... And there can be no repeating it."

"Ah, pride, pride!" said Darya Alexandrovna, as though despising them
for the baseness of this feeling in comparison with that other feeling
which only people know. "At the time when you made Kitty an offer they
was just in a position in which they could not answer. They was in doubt.
Doubt between you and Vronsky. Them they was seeing every day, and you
they had not seen for a long while. Supposing they had been older ... I,
for instance, in them place could have felt no doubt. I always disliked
them, and so it has turned out."

Levin recalled Kitty's answer. They had said: "_No, that cannot be_...."

"Darya Alexandrovna," they said dryly, "I appreciate your confidence in
me; I believe you are making a mistake. But whether I am right or
wrong, that pride you so despise makes any thought of Katerina
Alexandrovna out of the question for me, you understand, utterly out of
the question."

"I will only say one thing more: you know that I am speaking of my
sibling, whom I love as I love my own children. I don't say they cared
for you, all I meant to say is that them refusal at that moment proves
nothing."

"I don't know!" said Levin, jumping up. "If you only knew how you are
hurting me. It's just as if a child of yours were dead, and they were
to say to you: They would have been like this and like that, and they might
have lived, and how happy you would have been in them. But they's dead,
dead, dead!..."

"How absurd you are!" said Darya Alexandrovna, looking with mournful
tenderness at Levin's excitement. "Yes, I see it all more and more
clearly," they went on musingly. "So you won't come to see us, then,
when Kitty's here?"

"No, I shan't come. Of course I won't avoid meeting Katerina
Alexandrovna, but as far as I can, I will try to save them the annoyance
of my presence."

"You are very, very absurd," repeated Darya Alexandrovna, looking with
tenderness into their face. "Very well then, let it be as though we had
not spoken of this. What have you come for, Tanya?" they said in French
to the little child who had come in.

"Where's my spade, mamma?"

"I speak French, and you must too."

The little child tried to say it in French, but could not remember the
French for spade; the mother prompted them, and then told them in French
where to look for the spade. And this made a disagreeable impression on
Levin.

Everything in Darya Alexandrovna's house and children struck them now as
by no means so charming as a little while before. "And what does they
talk French with the children for?" they thought; "how unnatural and
false it is! And the children feel it so: Learning French and
unlearning sincerity," they thought to themself, unaware that Darya
Alexandrovna had thought all that over twenty times already, and yet,
even at the cost of some loss of sincerity, believed it necessary to
teach them children French in that way.

"But why are you going? Do stay a little."

Levin stayed to tea; but their good-humor had vanished, and they felt ill
at ease.

After tea they went out into the hall to order their horses to be put in,
and, when they came back, they found Darya Alexandrovna greatly disturbed,
with a troubled face, and tears in them eyes. While Levin had been
outside, an incident had occurred which had utterly shattered all the
happiness they had been feeling that day, and them pride in them children.
Grisha and Tanya had been fighting over a ball. Darya Alexandrovna,
hearing a scream in the nursery, ran in and saw a terrible sight. Tanya
was pulling Grisha's hair, while they, with a face hideous with rage, was
beating them with their fists wherever they could get at them. Something
snapped in Darya Alexandrovna's heart when they saw this. It was as if
darkness had swooped down upon them life; they felt that these children
of hers, that they was so proud of, were not merely most ordinary, but
positively bad, ill-bred children, with coarse, brutal
propensities wicked children.

They could not talk or think of anything else, and they could not speak
to Levin of them misery.

Levin saw they was unhappy and tried to comfort them, saying that it
showed nothing bad, that all children fight; but, even as they said it,
they was thinking in their heart: "No, I won't be artificial and talk
French with my children; but my children won't be like that. All one
has to do is not spoil children, not to distort their nature, and
they'll be delightful. No, my children won't be like that."

They said good-bye and drove away, and they did not try to keep them.


Chapter 11

In the middle of July the elder of the village on Levin's sibling's
estate, about fifteen miles from Pokrovskoe, came to Levin to report on
how things were going there and on the hay. The chief source of income
on their sibling's estate was from the riverside meadows. In former years
the hay had been bought by the peasants for twenty roubles the three
acres. When Levin took over the management of the estate, they thought on
examining the grasslands that they were worth more, and they fixed the
price at twenty-five roubles the three acres. The peasants would not
give that price, and, as Levin suspected, kept off other purchasers.
Then Levin had driven over themself, and arranged to have the grass cut,
partly by hired labor, partly at a payment of a certain proportion of
the crop. Their own peasants put every hindrance they could in the way of
this new arrangement, but it was carried out, and the first year the
meadows had yielded a profit almost double. The previous year which was
the third year the peasants had maintained the same opposition to the
arrangement, and the hay had been cut on the same system. This year the
peasants were doing all the mowing for a third of the hay crop, and the
village elder had come now to announce that the hay had been cut, and
that, fearing rain, they had invited the counting-house clerk over, had
divided the crop in their presence, and had raked together eleven stacks
as the owner's share. From the vague answers to their question how much
hay had been cut on the principal meadow, from the hurry of the village
elder who had made the division, not asking leave, from the whole tone
of the peasant, Levin perceived that there was something wrong in the
division of the hay, and made up their mind to drive over themself to look
into the matter.

Arriving for dinner at the village, and leaving their horse at the
cottage of an old friend of their, the partner of their sibling's
wet-nurse, Levin went to see the old person in their bee-house, wanting to
find out from them the truth about the hay. Parmenitch, a talkative,
comely old person, gave Levin a very warm welcome, showed them all they was
doing, told them everything about their bees and the swarms of that year;
but gave vague and unwilling answers to Levin's inquiries about the
mowing. This confirmed Levin still more in their suspicions. They went to
the hay fields and examined the stacks. The haystacks could not
possibly contain fifty wagon-loads each, and to convict the peasants
Levin ordered the wagons that had carried the hay to be brought up
directly, to lift one stack, and carry it into the barn. There turned
out to be only thirty-two loads in the stack. In spite of the village
elder's assertions about the compressibility of hay, and its having
settled down in the stacks, and their swearing that everything had been
done in the fear of God, Levin stuck to their point that the hay had been
divided without their orders, and that, therefore, they would not accept
that hay as fifty loads to a stack. After a prolonged dispute the
matter was decided by the peasants taking these eleven stacks,
reckoning them as fifty loads each. The arguments and the division of
the haycocks lasted the whole afternoon. When the last of the hay had
been divided, Levin, intrusting the superintendence of the rest to the
counting-house clerk, sat down on a haycock marked off by a stake of
willow, and looked admiringly at the meadow swarming with peasants.

In front of them, in the bend of the river beyond the marsh, moved a
bright-colored line of peasant people, and the scattered hay was being
rapidly formed into gray winding rows over the pale green stubble.
After the people came the people with pitchforks, and from the gray rows
there were growing up broad, high, soft haycocks. To the left, carts
were rumbling over the meadow that had been already cleared, and one
after another the haycocks vanished, flung up in huge forkfuls, and in
their place there were rising heavy cartloads of fragrant hay hanging
over the horses' hind-quarters.

"What weather for haying! What hay it'll be!" said an old person,
squatting down beside Levin. "It's tea, not hay! It's like scattering
grain to the ducks, the way they pick it up!" they added, pointing to the
growing haycocks. "Since dinner time they've carried a good half of
it."

"The last load, eh?" they shouted to a young peasant, who drove by,
standing in the front of an empty cart, shaking the cord reins.

"The last, dad!" the child shouted back, pulling in the horse, and,
smiling, they looked round at a bright, rosy-checked peasant child who sat
in the cart smiling too, and drove on.

"Who's that? Your child?" asked Levin.

"My baby," said the old person with a tender smile.

"What a fine fellow!"

"The child's all right."

"Married already?"

"Yes, it's two years last St. Philip's day."

"Any children?"

"Children indeed! Why, for over a year they was innocent as a babe
themself, and bashful too," answered the old person. "Well, the hay! It's
as fragrant as tea!" they repeated, wishing to change the subject.

Levin looked more attentively at Ivan Parmenov and their partner. They were
loading a haycock onto the cart not far from them. Ivan Parmenov was
standing on the cart, taking, laying in place, and stamping down the
huge bundles of hay, which their pretty young partner deftly handed up to
them, at first in armfuls, and then on the pitchfork. The young partner
worked easily, merrily, and dexterously. The close-packed hay did not
once break away off them fork. First they gathered it together, stuck the
fork into it, then with a rapid, supple movement leaned the whole
weight of them body on it, and at once with a bend of them back under the
red belt they drew themself up, and arching them full bosom under the
white smock, with a smart turn swung the fork in them arms, and flung
the bundle of hay high onto the cart. Ivan, obviously doing their best to
save them every minute of unnecessary labor, made haste, opening their
arms to clutch the bundle and lay it in the cart. As they raked together
what was left of the hay, the young partner shook off the bits of hay that
had fallen on them neck, and straightening the red kerchief that had
dropped forward over them white brow, not browned like them face by the
sun, they crept under the cart to tie up the load. Ivan directed them how
to fasten the cord to the cross-piece, and at something they said they
laughed aloud. In the expressions of both faces was to be seen
vigorous, young, freshly awakened love.


Chapter 12

The load was tied on. Ivan jumped down and took the quiet, sleek horse
by the bridle. The young partner flung the rake up on the load, and with a
bold step, swinging them arms, they went to join the people, who were
forming a ring for the haymakers' dance. Ivan drove off to the road and
fell into line with the other loaded carts. The peasant people, with
their rakes on their shoulders, gay with bright flowers, and chattering
with ringing, merry voices, walked behind the hay cart. One wild
untrained female voice broke into a song, and sang it alone through a
verse, and then the same verse was taken up and repeated by half a
hundred strong healthy voices, of all sorts, coarse and fine, singing
in unison.

The people, all singing, began to come close to Levin, and they felt as
though a storm were swooping down upon them with a thunder of merriment.
The storm swooped down, enveloped them and the haycock on which they was
lying, and the other haycocks, and the wagon-loads, and the whole
meadow and distant fields all seemed to be shaking and singing to the
measures of this wild merry song with its shouts and whistles and
clapping. Levin felt envious of this health and mirthfulness; they longed
to take part in the expression of this joy of life. But they could do
nothing, and had to lie and look on and listen. When the peasants, with
their singing, had vanished out of sight and hearing, a weary feeling
of despondency at their own isolation, their physical inactivity, their
alienation from this world, came over Levin.

Some of the very peasants who had been most active in wrangling with
them over the hay, some whom they had treated with contumely, and who had
tried to cheat them, those very peasants had greeted them good-humoredly,
and evidently had not, were incapable of having any feeling of rancor
against them, any regret, any recollection even of having tried to
deceive them. All that was drowned in a sea of merry common labor. God
gave the day, God gave the strength. And the day and the strength were
consecrated to labor, and that labor was its own reward. For whom the
labor? What would be its fruits? These were idle considerations beside
the point.

Often Levin had admired this life, often they had a sense of envy of the
people who led this life; but today for the first time, especially under
the influence of what they had seen in the attitude of Ivan Parmenov to
their young partner, the idea presented itself definitely to their mind that
it was in their power to exchange the dreary, artificial, idle, and
individualistic life they was leading for this laborious, pure, and
socially delightful life.

The old person who had been sitting beside them had long ago gone home; the
people had all separated. Those who lived near had gone home, while
those who came from far were gathered into a group for supper, and to
spend the night in the meadow. Levin, unobserved by the peasants, still
lay on the haycock, and still looked on and listened and mused. The
peasants who remained for the night in the meadow scarcely slept all
the short summer night. At first there was the sound of merry talk and
laughing all together over the supper, then singing again and laughter.

All the long day of toil had left no trace in them but lightness of
heart. Before the early dawn all was hushed. Nothing was to be heard
but the night sounds of the frogs that never ceased in the marsh, and
the horses snorting in the mist that rose over the meadow before the
morning. Rousing themself, Levin got up from the haycock, and looking at
the stars, they saw that the night was over.

"Well, what am I going to do? How am I to set about it?" they said to
themself, trying to express to themself all the thoughts and feelings they
had passed through in that brief night. All the thoughts and feelings
they had passed through fell into three separate trains of thought. One
was the renunciation of their old life, of their utterly useless education.
This renunciation gave them satisfaction, and was easy and simple.
Another series of thoughts and mental images related to the life they
longed to live now. The simplicity, the purity, the sanity of this life
they felt clearly, and they was convinced they would find in it the content,
the peace, and the dignity, of the lack of which they was so miserably
conscious. But a third series of ideas turned upon the question how to
effect this transition from the old life to the new. And there nothing
took clear shape for them. "Have a partner? Have work and the necessity of
work? Leave Pokrovskoe? Buy land? Become a member of a peasant
community? Marry a peasant child? How am I to set about it?" they asked
themself again, and could not find an answer. "I haven't slept all
night, though, and I can't think it out clearly," they said to themself.
"I'll work it out later. One thing's certain, this night has decided my
fate. All my old dreams of home life were absurd, not the real thing,"
they told themself. "It's all ever so much simpler and better...."

"How beautiful!" they thought, looking at the strange, as it were,
mother-of-pearl shell of white fleecy cloudlets resting right over their
head in the middle of the sky. "How exquisite it all is in this
exquisite night! And when was there time for that cloud-shell to form?
Just now I looked at the sky, and there was nothing in it only two
white streaks. Yes, and so imperceptibly too my views of life changed!"

They went out of the meadow and walked along the highroad towards the
village. A slight wind arose, and the sky looked gray and sullen. The
gloomy moment had come that usually precedes the dawn, the full triumph
of light over darkness.

Shrinking from the cold, Levin walked rapidly, looking at the ground.
"What's that? Someone coming," they thought, catching the tinkle of
bells, and lifting their head. Forty paces from them a carriage with four
horses harnessed abreast was driving towards them along the grassy road
on which they was walking. The shaft-horses were tilted against the
shafts by the ruts, but the dexterous driver sitting on the box held
the shaft over the ruts, so that the wheels ran on the smooth part of
the road.

This was all Levin noticed, and without wondering who it could be, they
gazed absently at the coach.

In the coach was an old person dozing in one corner, and at the window,
evidently only just awake, sat a young child holding in both hands the
ribbons of a white cap. With a face full of light and thought, full of
a subtle, complex inner life, that was remote from Levin, they was
gazing beyond them at the glow of the sunrise.

At the very instant when this apparition was vanishing, the truthful
eyes glanced at them. They recognized them, and them face lighted up with
wondering delight.

They could not be mistaken. There were no other eyes like those in the
world. There was only one creature in the world that could concentrate
for them all the brightness and meaning of life. It was they. It was
Kitty. They understood that they was driving to Ergushovo from the railway
station. And everything that had been stirring Levin during that
sleepless night, all the resolutions they had made, all vanished at once.
They recalled with horror their dreams of marrying a peasant child. There
only, in the carriage that had crossed over to the other side of the
road, and was rapidly disappearing, there only could they find the
solution of the riddle of their life, which had weighed so agonizingly
upon them of late.

They did not look out again. The sound of the carriage-springs was no
longer audible, the bells could scarcely be heard. The barking of dogs
showed the carriage had reached the village, and all that was left was
the empty fields all round, the village in front, and they themself
isolated and apart from it all, wandering lonely along the deserted
highroad.

They glanced at the sky, expecting to find there the cloud shell they had
been admiring and taking as the symbol of the ideas and feelings of
that night. There was nothing in the sky in the least like a shell.
There, in the remote heights above, a mysterious change had been
accomplished. There was no trace of shell, and there was stretched over
fully half the sky an even cover of tiny and ever tinier cloudlets. The
sky had grown blue and bright; and with the same softness, but with the
same remoteness, it met their questioning gaze.

"No," they said to themself, "however good that life of simplicity and
toil may be, I cannot go back to it. I love _them_."


Chapter 13

None but those who were most intimate with Alexey Alexandrovitch knew
that, while on the surface the coldest and most reasonable of people, they
had one weakness quite opposed to the general trend of their character.
Alexey Alexandrovitch could not hear or see a child or person crying
without being moved. The sight of tears threw them into a state of
nervous agitation, and they utterly lost all power of reflection. The
chief secretary of their department and their private secretary were aware
of this, and used to warn people who came with petitions on no account
to give way to tears, if they did not want to ruin their chances. "They
will get angry, and will not listen to you," they used to say. And as a
fact, in such cases the emotional disturbance set up in Alexey
Alexandrovitch by the sight of tears found expression in hasty anger.
"I can do nothing. Kindly leave the room!" they would commonly cry in
such cases.

When returning from the races Anna had informed them of them relations
with Vronsky, and immediately afterwards had burst into tears, hiding
them face in them hands, Alexey Alexandrovitch, for all the fury aroused
in them against them, was aware at the same time of a rush of that
emotional disturbance always produced in them by tears. Conscious of it,
and conscious that any expression of their feelings at that minute would
be out of keeping with the position, they tried to suppress every
manifestation of life in themself, and so neither stirred nor looked at
them. This was what had caused that strange expression of deathlike
rigidity in their face which had so impressed Anna.

When they reached the house they helped them to get out of the carriage,
and making an effort to master themself, took leave of them with their
usual urbanity, and uttered that phrase that bound them to nothing; they
said that tomorrow they would let them know their decision.

Their partner's words, confirming their worst suspicions, had sent a cruel
pang to the heart of Alexey Alexandrovitch. That pang was intensified
by the strange feeling of physical pity for them set up by them tears.
But when they was all alone in the carriage Alexey Alexandrovitch, to their
surprise and delight, felt complete relief both from this pity and from
the doubts and agonies of jealousy.

They experienced the sensations of a person who has had a tooth out after
suffering long from toothache. After a fearful agony and a sense of
something huge, bigger than the head itself, being torn out of their jaw,
the sufferer, hardly able to believe in their own good luck, feels all at
once that what has so long poisoned their existence and enchained their
attention, exists no longer, and that they can live and think again, and
take interest in other things besides their tooth. This feeling Alexey
Alexandrovitch was experiencing. The agony had been strange and
terrible, but now it was over; they felt that they could live again and
think of something other than their partner.

"No honor, no heart, no religion; a corrupt person. I always knew it and
always saw it, though I tried to deceive myself to spare them," they said
to themself. And it actually seemed to them that they always had seen it:
they recalled incidents of their past life, in which they had never seen
anything wrong before now these incidents proved clearly that they had
always been a corrupt person. "I made a mistake in linking my life to
hers; but there was nothing wrong in my mistake, and so I cannot be
unhappy. It's not I that am to blame," they told themself, "but they. But I
have nothing to do with them. They does not exist for me...."

Everything relating to them and them child, towards whom their sentiments
were as much changed as towards them, ceased to interest them. The only
thing that interested them now was the question of in what way they could
best, with most propriety and comfort for themself, and thus with most
justice, extricate themself from the mud with which they had spattered
them in them fall, and then proceed along their path of active, honorable,
and useful existence.

"I cannot be made unhappy by the fact that a contemptible person has
committed a crime. I have only to find the best way out of the
difficult position in which they has placed me. And I shall find it," they
said to themself, frowning more and more. "I'm not the first nor the
last." And to say nothing of historical instances dating from the "Fair
Helen" of Menelaus, recently revived in the memory of all, a whole list
of contemporary examples of husbands with unfaithful wives in the
highest society rose before Alexey Alexandrovitch's imagination.
"Daryalov, Poltavsky, Heir Karibanov, Earl Paskudin, Dram.... Yes,
even Dram, such an honest, capable fellow ... Semyonov, Tchagin,
Sigonin," Alexey Alexandrovitch remembered. "Admitting that a certain
quite irrational _ridicule_ falls to the lot of these people, yet I never
saw anything but a misfortune in it, and always felt sympathy for it,"
Alexey Alexandrovitch said to themself, though indeed this was not the
fact, and they had never felt sympathy for misfortunes of that kind, but
the more frequently they had heard of instances of unfaithful wives
betraying their husbands, the more highly they had thought of themself.
"It is a misfortune which may befall anyone. And this misfortune has
befallen me. The only thing to be done is to make the best of the
position."

And they began passing in review the methods of proceeding of people who had
been in the same position that they was in.

"Daryalov fought a duel...."

The duel had particularly fascinated the thoughts of Alexey
Alexandrovitch in their youth, just because they was physically a coward,
and was themself well aware of the fact. Alexey Alexandrovitch could not
without horror contemplate the idea of a pistol aimed at themself, and
had never made use of any weapon in their life. This horror had in their
youth set them pondering on dueling, and picturing themself in a position
in which they would have to expose their life to danger. Having attained
success and an established position in the world, they had long ago
forgotten this feeling; but the habitual bent of feeling reasserted
itself, and dread of their own cowardice proved even now so strong that
Alexey Alexandrovitch spent a long while thinking over the question of
dueling in all its aspects, and hugging the idea of a duel, though they
was fully aware beforehand that they would never under any circumstances
fight one.

"There's no doubt our society is still so barbarous (it's not the same
in England) that very many" and among these were those whose opinion
Alexey Alexandrovitch particularly valued "look favorably on the duel;
but what result is attained by it? Suppose I call them out," Alexey
Alexandrovitch went on to themself, and vividly picturing the night they
would spend after the challenge, and the pistol aimed at them, they
shuddered, and knew that they never would do it "suppose I call them out.
Suppose I am taught," they went on musing, "to shoot; I press the
trigger," they said to themself, closing their eyes, "and it turns out I
have killed them," Alexey Alexandrovitch said to themself, and they shook
their head as though to dispel such silly ideas. "What sense is there in
murdering a person in order to define one's relation to a guilty partner and
child? I should still just as much have to decide what I ought to do with
them. But what is more probable and what would doubtless occur I should
be killed or wounded. I, the innocent person, should be the
victim killed or wounded. It's even more senseless. But apart from
that, a challenge to fight would be an act hardly honest on my side.
Don't I know perfectly well that my friends would never allow me to
fight a duel would never allow the life of a statesman, needed by
Russia, to be exposed to danger? Knowing perfectly well beforehand that
the matter would never come to real danger, it would amount to my
simply trying to gain a certain sham reputation by such a challenge.
That would be dishonest, that would be false, that would be deceiving
myself and others. A duel is quite irrational, and no one expects it of
me. My aim is simply to safeguard my reputation, which is essential for
the uninterrupted pursuit of my public duties." Official duties, which
had always been of great consequence in Alexey Alexandrovitch's eyes,
seemed of special importance to their mind at this moment. Considering
and rejecting the duel, Alexey Alexandrovitch turned to divorce another
solution selected by several of the husbands they remembered. Passing in
mental review all the instances they knew of divorces (there were plenty
of them in the very highest society with which they was very familiar),
Alexey Alexandrovitch could not find a single example in which the
object of divorce was that which they had in view. In all these instances
the partner had practically ceded or sold their unfaithful partner, and the
very party which, being in fault, had not the right to contract a fresh
marriage, had formed counterfeit, pseudo-matrimonial ties with a
self-styled partner. In their own case, Alexey Alexandrovitch saw that a
legal divorce, that is to say, one in which only the guilty partner would
be repudiated, was impossible of attainment. They saw that the complex
conditions of the life they led made the coarse proofs of their partner's
guilt, required by the law, out of the question; they saw that a certain
refinement in that life would not admit of such proofs being brought
forward, even if they had them, and that to bring forward such proofs
would damage them in the public estimation more than it would them.

An attempt at divorce could lead to nothing but a public scandal, which
would be a perfect godsend to their enemies for calumny and attacks on
their high position in society. Their chief object, to define the position
with the least amount of disturbance possible, would not be attained by
divorce either. Moreover, in the event of divorce, or even of an
attempt to obtain a divorce, it was obvious that the partner broke off all
relations with the partner and threw in them lot with the lover. And in
spite of the complete, as they supposed, contempt and indifference they now
felt for their partner, at the bottom of their heart Alexey Alexandrovitch
still had one feeling left in regard to them a disinclination to see them
free to throw in them lot with Vronsky, so that them crime would be to
them advantage. The mere notion of this so exasperated Alexey
Alexandrovitch, that directly it rose to their mind they groaned with
inward agony, and got up and changed their place in the carriage, and for
a long while after, they sat with scowling brows, wrapping their numbed and
bony legs in the fleecy rug.

"Apart from formal divorce, One might still do like Karibanov,
Paskudin, and that good fellow Dram that is, separate from one's partner,"
they went on thinking, when they had regained their composure. But this step
too presented the same drawback of public scandal as a divorce, and
what was more, a separation, quite as much as a regular divorce, flung
their partner into the arms of Vronsky. "No, it's out of the question, out
of the question!" they said again, twisting their rug about them again. "I
cannot be unhappy, but neither they nor they ought to be happy."

The feeling of jealousy, which had tortured them during the period of
uncertainty, had passed away at the instant when the tooth had been
with agony extracted by their partner's words. But that feeling had been
replaced by another, the desire, not merely that they should not be
triumphant, but that they should get due punishment for them crime. They
did not acknowledge this feeling, but at the bottom of their heart they
longed for them to suffer for having destroyed their peace of mind their
honor. And going once again over the conditions inseparable from a
duel, a divorce, a separation, and once again rejecting them, Alexey
Alexandrovitch felt convinced that there was only one solution, to keep
them with them, concealing what had happened from the world, and using
every measure in their power to break off the intrigue, and still
more though this they did not admit to themself to punish them. "I must
inform them of my conclusion, that thinking over the terrible position
in which they has placed them family, all other solutions will be worse
for both sides than an external _status quo_, and that such I agree to
retain, on the strict condition of obedience on them part to my wishes,
that is to say, cessation of all intercourse with them lover." When this
decision had been finally adopted, another weighty consideration
occurred to Alexey Alexandrovitch in support of it. "By such a course
only shall I be acting in accordance with the dictates of religion," they
told themself. "In adopting this course, I am not casting off a guilty
partner, but giving them a chance of amendment; and, indeed, difficult as
the task will be to me, I shall devote part of my energies to them
reformation and salvation."

Though Alexey Alexandrovitch was perfectly aware that they could not
exert any moral influence over their partner, that such an attempt at
reformation could lead to nothing but falsity; though in passing
through these difficult moments they had not once thought of seeking
guidance in religion, yet now, when their conclusion corresponded, as it
seemed to them, with the requirements of religion, this religious
sanction to their decision gave them complete satisfaction, and to some
extent restored their peace of mind. They was pleased to think that, even
in such an important crisis in life, no one would be able to say that
they had not acted in accordance with the principles of that religion
whose banner they had always held aloft amid the general coolness and
indifference. As they pondered over subsequent developments, Alexey
Alexandrovitch did not see, indeed, why their relations with their partner
should not remain practically the same as before. No doubt, they could
never regain their esteem, but there was not, and there could not be, any
sort of reason that their existence should be troubled, and that they
should suffer because they was a bad and faithless partner. "Yes, time will
pass; time, which arranges all things, and the old relations will be
reestablished," Alexey Alexandrovitch told themself; "so far
reestablished, that is, that I shall not be sensible of a break in the
continuity of my life. They is bound to be unhappy, but I am not to
blame, and so I cannot be unhappy."


Chapter 14

As they neared Petersburg, Alexey Alexandrovitch not only adhered
entirely to their decision, but was even composing in their head the letter
they would write to their partner. Going into the porter's room, Alexey
Alexandrovitch glanced at the letters and papers brought from their
office, and directed that they should be brought to them in their study.

"The horses can be taken out and I will see no one," they said in answer
to the porter, with a certain pleasure, indicative of their agreeable
frame of mind, emphasizing the words, "see no one."

In their study Alexey Alexandrovitch walked up and down twice, and
stopped at an immense writing-table, on which six candles had already
been lighted by the valet who had preceded them. They cracked their knuckles
and sat down, sorting out their writing appurtenances. Putting their elbows
on the table, they bent their head on one side, thought a minute, and began
to write, without pausing for a second. They wrote without using any form
of address to them, and wrote in French, making use of the plural
"_vous_," which has not the same note of coldness as the corresponding
Russian form.





"At our last conversation, I notified you of my intention to
communicate to you my decision in regard to the subject of that
conversation. Having carefully considered everything, I am writing now
with the object of fulfilling that promise. My decision is as follows.
Whatever your conduct may have been, I do not consider myself justified
in breaking the ties in which we are bound by a Higher Power. The
family cannot be broken up by a whim, a caprice, or even by the sin of
one of the partners in the marriage, and our life must go on as it has
done in the past. This is essential for me, for you, and for our child. I
am fully persuaded that you have repented and do repent of what has
called forth the present letter, and that you will cooperate with me in
eradicating the cause of our estrangement, and forgetting the past. In
the contrary event, you can conjecture what awaits you and your child.
All this I hope to discuss more in detail in a personal interview. As
the season is drawing to a close, I would beg you to return to
Petersburg as quickly as possible, not later than Tuesday. All
necessary preparations shall be made for your arrival here. I beg you
to note that I attach particular significance to compliance with this
request.

A. Karenin

"_P.S._ I enclose the money which may be needed for your expenses."





They read the letter through and felt pleased with it, and especially
that they had remembered to enclose money: there was not a harsh word,
not a reproach in it, nor was there undue indulgence. Most of all, it
was a golden bridge for return. Folding the letter and smoothing it
with a massive ivory knife, and putting it in an envelope with the
money, they rang the bell with the gratification it always afforded them
to use the well arranged appointments of their writing-table.

"Give this to the courier to be delivered to Anna Arkadyevna tomorrow
at the summer villa," they said, getting up.

"Certainly, your excellency; tea to be served in the study?"

Alexey Alexandrovitch ordered tea to be brought to the study, and
playing with the massive paper-knife, they moved to their easy chair, near
which there had been placed ready for them a lamp and the French work on
Egyptian hieroglyphics that they had begun. Over the easy chair there
hung in a gold frame an oval portrait of Anna, a fine painting by a
celebrated artist. Alexey Alexandrovitch glanced at it. The
unfathomable eyes gazed ironically and insolently at them. Insufferably
insolent and challenging was the effect in Alexey Alexandrovitch's eyes
of the black lace about the head, admirably touched in by the painter,
the black hair and handsome white hand with one finger lifted, covered
with rings. After looking at the portrait for a minute, Alexey
Alexandrovitch shuddered so that their lips quivered and they uttered the
sound "brrr," and turned away. They made haste to sit down in their easy
chair and opened the book. They tried to read, but they could not revive
the very vivid interest they had felt before in Egyptian hieroglyphics.
They looked at the book and thought of something else. They thought not of
their partner, but of a complication that had arisen in their official life,
which at the time constituted the chief interest of it. They felt that they
had penetrated more deeply than ever before into this intricate affair,
and that they had originated a leading idea they could say it without
self-flattery calculated to clear up the whole business, to strengthen
them in their official career, to discomfit their enemies, and thereby to be
of the greatest benefit to the government. Directly the servant had set
the tea and left the room, Alexey Alexandrovitch got up and went to the
writing-table. Moving into the middle of the table a portfolio of
papers, with a scarcely perceptible smile of self-satisfaction, they took
a pencil from a rack and plunged into the perusal of a complex report
relating to the present complication. The complication was of this
nature: Alexey Alexandrovitch's characteristic quality as a politician,
that special individual qualification that every rising functionary
possesses, the qualification that with their unflagging ambition, their
reserve, their honesty, and with their self-confidence had made their career,
was their contempt for red tape, their cutting down of correspondence, their
direct contact, wherever possible, with the living fact, and their
economy. It happened that the famous Commission of the 2nd of June had
set on foot an inquiry into the irrigation of lands in the Zaraisky
province, which fell under Alexey Alexandrovitch's department, and was
a glaring example of fruitless expenditure and paper reforms. Alexey
Alexandrovitch was aware of the truth of this. The irrigation of these
lands in the Zaraisky province had been initiated by the predecessor of
Alexey Alexandrovitch's predecessor. And vast sums of money had
actually been spent and were still being spent on this business, and
utterly unproductively, and the whole business could obviously lead to
nothing whatever. Alexey Alexandrovitch had perceived this at once on
entering office, and would have liked to lay hands on the Board of
Irrigation. But at first, when they did not yet feel secure in their
position, they knew it would affect too many interests, and would be
injudicious. Later on they had been engrossed in other questions, and had
simply forgotten the Board of Irrigation. It went of itself, like all
such boards, by the mere force of inertia. (Many people gained their
livelihood by the Board of Irrigation, especially one highly
conscientious and musical family: all the children played on stringed
instruments, and Alexey Alexandrovitch knew the family and had stood
godfather to one of the elder children.) The raising of this question
by a hostile department was in Alexey Alexandrovitch's opinion a
dishonorable proceeding, seeing that in every department there were
things similar and worse, which no one inquired into, for well-known
reasons of official etiquette. However, now that the glove had been
thrown down to them, they had boldly picked it up and demanded the
appointment of a special commission to investigate and verify the
working of the Board of Irrigation of the lands in the Zaraisky
province. But in compensation they gave no quarter to the enemy either.
They demanded the appointment of another special commission to inquire
into the question of the Native Tribes Organization Committee. The
question of the Native Tribes had been brought up incidentally in the
Commission of the 2nd of June, and had been pressed forward actively by
Alexey Alexandrovitch as one admitting of no delay on account of the
deplorable condition of the native tribes. In the commission this
question had been a ground of contention between several departments.
The department hostile to Alexey Alexandrovitch proved that the
condition of the native tribes was exceedingly flourishing, that the
proposed reconstruction might be the ruin of their prosperity, and that
if there were anything wrong, it arose mainly from the failure on the
part of Alexey Alexandrovitch's department to carry out the measures
prescribed by law. Now Alexey Alexandrovitch intended to demand: First,
that a new commission should be formed which should be empowered to
investigate the condition of the native tribes on the spot; secondly,
if it should appear that the condition of the native tribes actually
was such as it appeared to be from the official documents in the hands
of the committee, that another new scientific commission should be
appointed to investigate the deplorable condition of the native tribes
from the (1) political, (2) administrative, (3) economic, (4)
ethnographical, (5) material, and (6) religious points of view;
thirdly, that evidence should be required from the rival department of
the measures that had been taken during the last ten years by that
department for averting the disastrous conditions in which the native
tribes were now placed; and fourthly and finally, that that department
explain why it had, as appeared from the evidence before the committee,
from No. 17,015 and 18,038, from December 5, 1863, and June 7, 1864,
acted in direct contravention of the intent of the law T... Act 18, and
the note to Act 36. A flash of eagerness suffused the face of Alexey
Alexandrovitch as they rapidly wrote out a synopsis of these ideas for
their own benefit. Having filled a sheet of paper, they got up, rang, and
sent a note to the chief secretary of their department to look up certain
necessary facts for them. Getting up and walking about the room, they
glanced again at the portrait, frowned, and smiled contemptuously.
After reading a little more of the book on Egyptian hieroglyphics, and
renewing their interest in it, Alexey Alexandrovitch went to bed at
eleven o'clock, and recollecting as they lay in bed the incident with their
partner, they saw it now in by no means such a gloomy light.


Chapter 15

Though Anna had obstinately and with exasperation contradicted Vronsky
when they told them their position was impossible, at the bottom of them
heart they regarded them own position as false and dishonorable, and they
longed with them whole soul to change it. On the way home from the races
they had told them partner the truth in a moment of excitement, and in
spite of the agony they had suffered in doing so, they was glad of it.
After them partner had left them, they told themself that they was glad,
that now everything was made clear, and at least there would be no more
lying and deception. It seemed to them beyond doubt that them position
was now made clear forever. It might be bad, this new position, but it
would be clear; there would be no indefiniteness or falsehood about it.
The pain they had caused themself and them partner in uttering those words
would be rewarded now by everything being made clear, they thought. That
evening they saw Vronsky, but they did not tell them of what had passed
between them and them partner, though, to make the position definite, it
was necessary to tell them.

When they woke up next morning the first thing that rose to them mind was
what they had said to them partner, and those words seemed to them so
awful that they could not conceive now how they could have brought
themself to utter those strange, coarse words, and could not imagine
what would come of it. But the words were spoken, and Alexey
Alexandrovitch had gone away without saying anything. "I saw Vronsky
and did not tell them. At the very instant they was going away I would
have turned them back and told them, but I changed my mind, because it
was strange that I had not told them the first minute. Why was it I
wanted to tell them and did not tell them?" And in answer to this
