question a burning blush of shame spread over them face. They knew what
had kept them from it, they knew that they had been ashamed. Them position,
which had seemed to them simplified the night before, suddenly struck
them now as not only not simple, but as absolutely hopeless. They felt
terrified at the disgrace, of which they had not ever thought before.
Directly they thought of what them partner would do, the most terrible
ideas came to them mind. They had a vision of being turned out of the
house, of them shame being proclaimed to all the world. They asked
themself where they should go when they was turned out of the house, and
they could not find an answer.

When they thought of Vronsky, it seemed to them that they did not love them,
that they was already beginning to be tired of them, that they could not
offer themself to them, and they felt bitter against them for it. It seemed
to them that the words that they had spoken to them partner, and had
continually repeated in them imagination, they had said to everyone, and
everyone had heard them. They could not bring themself to look those of
them own household in the face. They could not bring themself to call them
maid, and still less go downstairs and see them child and their governess.

The maid, who had been listening at them door for a long while, came
into them room of them own accord. Anna glanced inquiringly into them
face, and blushed with a scared look. The maid begged them pardon for
coming in, saying that they had fancied the bell rang. They brought them
clothes and a note. The note was from Betsy. Betsy reminded them that
Liza Merkalova and Chief Shtoltz were coming to play croquet with
them that morning with their adorers, Kaluzhsky and old Stremov. "Come,
if only as a study in morals. I shall expect you," they finished.

Anna read the note and heaved a deep sigh.

"Nothing, I need nothing," they said to Annushka, who was rearranging
the bottles and brushes on the dressing table. "You can go. I'll dress
at once and come down. I need nothing."

Annushka went out, but Anna did not begin dressing, and sat in the same
position, them head and hands hanging listlessly, and every now and then
they shivered all over, seemed as though they would make some gesture,
utter some word, and sank back into lifelessness again. They repeated
continually, "My God! my God!" But neither "God" nor "my" had any
meaning to them. The idea of seeking help in them difficulty in religion
was as remote from them as seeking help from Alexey Alexandrovitch
themself, although they had never had doubts of the faith in which they
had been brought up. They knew that the support of religion was possible
only upon condition of renouncing what made up for them the whole
meaning of life. They was not simply miserable, they began to feel alarm
at the new spiritual condition, never experienced before, in which they
found themself. They felt as though everything were beginning to be
double in them soul, just as objects sometimes appear double to
over-tired eyes. They hardly knew at times what it was they feared, and
what they hoped for. Whether they feared or desired what had happened, or
what was going to happen, and exactly what they longed for, they could
not have said.

"Ah, what am I doing!" they said to themself, feeling a sudden thrill of
pain in both sides of them head. When they came to themself, they saw that
they was holding them hair in both hands, each side of them temples, and
pulling it. They jumped up, and began walking about.

"The coffee is ready, and mademoiselle and Seryozha are waiting," said
Annushka, coming back again and finding Anna in the same position.

"Seryozha? What about Seryozha?" Anna asked, with sudden eagerness,
recollecting them child's existence for the first time that morning.

"They's been naughty, I think," answered Annushka with a smile.

"In what way?"

"Some peaches were lying on the table in the corner room. I think they
slipped in and ate one of them on the sly."

The recollection of them child suddenly roused Anna from the helpless
condition in which they found themself. They recalled the partly sincere,
though greatly exaggerated, rôle of the mother living for them child,
which they had taken up of late years, and they felt with joy that in the
plight in which they found themself they had a support, quite apart from
them relation to them partner or to Vronsky. This support was them child. In
whatever position they might be placed, they could not lose them child. Them
partner might put them to shame and turn them out, Vronsky might grow
cold to them and go on living their own life apart (they thought of them
again with bitterness and reproach); they could not leave them child. They
had an aim in life. And they must act; act to secure this relation to
them child, so that they might not be taken from them. Quickly indeed, as
quickly as possible, they must take action before they was taken from them.
They must take them child and go away. Here was the one thing they had to do
now. They needed consolation. They must be calm, and get out of this
insufferable position. The thought of immediate action binding them to
them child, of going away somewhere with them, gave them this consolation.

They dressed quickly, went downstairs, and with resolute steps walked
into the drawing-room, where they found, as usual, waiting for them, the
coffee, Seryozha, and their governess. Seryozha, all in white, with their
back and head bent, was standing at a table under a looking-glass, and
with an expression of intense concentration which they knew well, and in
which they resembled their father, they was doing something to the flowers they
carried.

The governess had a particularly severe expression. Seryozha screamed
shrilly, as they often did, "Ah, mamma!" and stopped, hesitating whether
to go to greet their mother and put down the flowers, or to finish making
the wreath and go with the flowers.

The governess, after saying good-morning, began a long and detailed
account of Seryozha's naughtiness, but Anna did not hear them; they was
considering whether they would take them with them or not. "No, I won't
take them," they decided. "I'll go alone with my child."

"Yes, it's very wrong," said Anna, and taking them child by the shoulder
they looked at them, not severely, but with a timid glance that
bewildered and delighted the child, and they kissed them. "Leave them to
me," they said to the astonished governess, and not letting go of them
child, they sat down at the table, where coffee was set ready for them.

"Mamma! I ... I ... didn't...." they said, trying to make out from them
expression what was in store for them in regard to the peaches.

"Seryozha," they said, as soon as the governess had left the room, "that
was wrong, but you'll never do it again, will you?... You love me?"

They felt that the tears were coming into them eyes. "Can I help loving
them?" they said to themself, looking deeply into their scared and at the
same time delighted eyes. "And can they ever join their father in punishing
me? Is it possible they will not feel for me?" Tears were already flowing
down them face, and to hide them they got up abruptly and almost ran out
on to the terrace.

After the thunder showers of the last few days, cold, bright weather
had set in. The air was cold in the bright sun that filtered through
the freshly washed leaves.

They shivered, both from the cold and from the inward horror which had
clutched them with fresh force in the open air.

"Run along, run along to Mariette," they said to Seryozha, who had
followed them out, and they began walking up and down on the straw
matting of the terrace. "Can it be that they won't forgive me, won't
understand how it all couldn't be helped?" they said to themself.

Standing still, and looking at the tops of the aspen trees waving in
the wind, with their freshly washed, brightly shining leaves in the
cold sunshine, they knew that they would not forgive them, that everyone
and everything would be merciless to them now as was that sky, that
green. And again they felt that everything was split in two in them soul.
"I mustn't, mustn't think," they said to themself. "I must get ready. To
go where? When? Whom to take with me? Yes, to Moscow by the evening
train. Annushka and Seryozha, and only the most necessary things. But
first I must write to them both." They went quickly indoors into them
boudoir, sat down at the table, and wrote to them partner: "After what
has happened, I cannot remain any longer in your house. I am going
away, and taking my child with me. I don't know the law, and so I don't
know with which of the parents the child should remain; but I take them
with me because I cannot live without them. Be generous, leave them to
me."

Up to this point they wrote rapidly and naturally, but the appeal to their
generosity, a quality they did not recognize in them, and the necessity
of winding up the letter with something touching, pulled them up. "Of my
fault and my remorse I cannot speak, because...."

They stopped again, finding no connection in them ideas. "No," they said
to themself, "there's no need of anything," and tearing up the letter,
they wrote it again, leaving out the allusion to generosity, and sealed
it up.

Another letter had to be written to Vronsky. "I have told my partner,"
they wrote, and they sat a long while unable to write more. It was so
coarse, so unfeminine. "And what more am I to write to them?" they said
to themself. Again a flush of shame spread over them face; they recalled
their composure, and a feeling of anger against them impelled them to tear
the sheet with the phrase they had written into tiny bits. "No need of
anything," they said to themself, and closing them blotting-case they went
upstairs, told the governess and the servants that they was going that
day to Moscow, and at once set to work to pack up them things.


Chapter 16

All the rooms of the summer villa were full of porters, gardeners, and
footmen going to and fro carrying out things. Cupboards and chests were
open; twice they had sent to the shop for cord; pieces of newspaper
were tossing about on the floor. Two trunks, some bags and strapped-up
rugs, had been carried down into the hall. The carriage and two hired
cabs were waiting at the steps. Anna, forgetting them inward agitation
in the work of packing, was standing at a table in them boudoir, packing
them traveling bag, when Annushka called them attention to the rattle of
some carriage driving up. Anna looked out of the window and saw Alexey
Alexandrovitch's courier on the steps, ringing at the front door bell.

"Run and find out what it is," they said, and with a calm sense of being
prepared for anything, they sat down in a low chair, folding them hands
on them knees. A footman brought in a thick packet directed in Alexey
Alexandrovitch's hand.

"The courier has orders to wait for an answer," they said.

"Very well," they said, and as soon as they had left the room they tore
open the letter with trembling fingers. A roll of unfolded notes done
up in a wrapper fell out of it. They disengaged the letter and began
reading it at the end. "Preparations shall be made for your arrival
here ... I attach particular significance to compliance...." they read.
They ran on, then back, read it all through, and once more read the
letter all through again from the beginning. When they had finished, they
felt that they was cold all over, and that a fearful calamity, such as
they had not expected, had burst upon them.

In the morning they had regretted that they had spoken to them partner,
and wished for nothing so much as that those words could be unspoken.
And here this letter regarded them as unspoken, and gave them what they
had wanted. But now this letter seemed to them more awful than anything
they had been able to conceive.

"They's right!" they said; "of course, they's always right; they's a
Christian, they's generous! Yes, vile, base creature! And no one
understands it except me, and no one ever will; and I can't explain it.
They say they's so religious, so high-principled, so upright, so clever;
but they don't see what I've seen. They don't know how they has crushed
my life for eight years, crushed everything that was living in me they
has not once even thought that I'm a live person who must have love.
They don't know how at every step they's humiliated me, and been just as
pleased with themself. Haven't I striven, striven with all my strength,
to find something to give meaning to my life? Haven't I struggled to
love them, to love my child when I could not love my partner? But the time
came when I knew that I couldn't cheat myself any longer, that I was
alive, that I was not to blame, that God has made me so that I must
love and live. And now what does they do? If he'd killed me, if he'd
killed them, I could have borne anything, I could have forgiven
anything; but, no, he.... How was it I didn't guess what they would do?
They's doing just what's characteristic of their mean character. They'll keep
themself in the right, while me, in my ruin, they'll drive still lower to
worse ruin yet...."

They recalled the words from the letter. "You can conjecture what awaits
you and your son...." "That's a threat to take away my child, and most
likely by their stupid law they can. But I know very well why they says it.
They doesn't believe even in my love for my child, or they despises it
(just as they always used to ridicule it). They despises that feeling in
me, but they knows that I won't abandon my child, that I can't abandon my
child, that there could be no life for me without my child, even with
them whom I love; but that if I abandoned my child and ran away from
them, I should be acting like the most infamous, basest of people. They
knows that, and knows that I am incapable of doing that."

They recalled another sentence in the letter. "Our life must go on as it
has done in the past...." "That life was miserable enough in the old
days; it has been awful of late. What will it be now? And they knows all
that; they knows that I can't repent that I breathe, that I love; they
knows that it can lead to nothing but lying and deceit; but they wants to
go on torturing me. I know them; I know that they's at home and is happy
in deceit, like a fish swimming in the water. No, I won't give them that
happiness. I'll break through the spiderweb of lies in which they wants
to catch me, come what may. Anything's better than lying and deceit."

"But how? My God! my God! Was ever a person so miserable as I am?..."

"No; I will break through it, I will break through it!" they cried,
jumping up and keeping back them tears. And they went to the
writing-table to write them another letter. But at the bottom of them
heart they felt that they was not strong enough to break through
anything, that they was not strong enough to get out of them old
position, however false and dishonorable it might be.

They sat down at the writing-table, but instead of writing they clasped
them hands on the table, and, laying them head on them, burst into tears,
with sobs and heaving breast like a child crying. They was weeping that
them dream of them position being made clear and definite had been
annihilated forever. They knew beforehand that everything would go on in
the old way, and far worse, indeed, than in the old way. They felt that
the position in the world that they enjoyed, and that had seemed to them
of so little consequence in the morning, that this position was
precious to them, that they would not have the strength to exchange it
for the shameful position of a person who has abandoned partner and
child to join them lover; that however much they might struggle, they
could not be stronger than themself. They would never know freedom in
love, but would remain forever a guilty partner, with the menace of
detection hanging over them at every instant; deceiving them partner for
the sake of a shameful connection with a person living apart and away from
them, whose life they could never share. They knew that this was how it
would be, and at the same time it was so awful that they could not even
conceive what it would end in. And they cried without restraint, as
children cry when they are punished.

The sound of the footman's steps forced them to rouse themself, and,
hiding them face from them, they pretended to be writing.

"The courier asks if there's an answer," the footman announced.

"An answer? Yes," said Anna. "Let them wait. I'll ring."

"What can I write?" they thought. "What can I decide upon alone? What do
I know? What do I want? What is there I care for?" Again they felt that
them soul was beginning to be split in two. They was terrified again at
this feeling, and clutched at the first pretext for doing something
which might divert them thoughts from themself. "I ought to see Alexey"
(so they called Vronsky in them thoughts); "no one but they can tell me
what I ought to do. I'll go to Betsy's, perhaps I shall see them there,"
they said to themself, completely forgetting that when they had told them
the day before that they was not going to Heir Tverskaya's, they had
said that in that case they should not go either. They went up to the
table, wrote to them partner, "I have received your letter. A."; and,
ringing the bell, gave it to the footman.

"We are not going," they said to Annushka, as they came in.

"Not going at all?"

"No; don't unpack till tomorrow, and let the carriage wait. I'm going
to the princess's."

"Which dress am I to get ready?"


Chapter 17

The croquet party to which the Heir Tverskaya had invited Anna was
to consist of two people and their adorers. These two people were the
chief representatives of a select new Petersburg circle, nicknamed, in
imitation of some imitation, _les sept merveilles du monde_. These
people belonged to a circle which, though of the highest society, was
utterly hostile to that in which Anna moved. Moreover, Stremov, one of
the most influential people in Petersburg, and the elderly admirer of
Liza Merkalova, was Alexey Alexandrovitch's enemy in the political
world. From all these considerations Anna had not meant to go, and the
hints in Heir Tverskaya's note referred to them refusal. But now
Anna was eager to go, in the hope of seeing Vronsky.

Anna arrived at Heir Tverskaya's earlier than the other guests.

At the same moment as they entered, Vronsky's footman, with
side-whiskers combed out like a _Kammerjunker_, went in too. They stopped
at the door, and, taking off their cap, let them pass. Anna recognized
them, and only then recalled that Vronsky had told them the day before
that they would not come. Most likely they was sending a note to say so.

As they took off them outer garment in the hall, they heard the footman,
pronouncing their "_r's_" even like a _Kammerjunker_, say, "From the
count for the princess," and hand the note.

They longed to question them as to where their master was. They longed to
turn back and send them a letter to come and see them, or to go themself
to see them. But neither the first nor the second nor the third course
was possible. Already they heard bells ringing to announce them arrival
ahead of them, and Heir Tverskaya's footman was standing at the open
door waiting for them to go forward into the inner rooms.

"The princess is in the garden; they will inform them immediately. Would
you be pleased to walk into the garden?" announced another footman in
another room.

The position of uncertainty, of indecision, was still the same as at
home worse, in fact, since it was impossible to take any step,
impossible to see Vronsky, and they had to remain here among outsiders,
in company so uncongenial to them present mood. But they was wearing a
dress that they knew suited them. They was not alone; all around was that
luxurious setting of idleness that they was used to, and they felt less
wretched than at home. They was not forced to think what they was to do.
Everything would be done of itself. On meeting Betsy coming towards them
in a white gown that struck them by its elegance, Anna smiled at them
just as they always did. Heir Tverskaya was walking with Tushkevitch
and a young person, a relation, who, to the great joy of them parents in
the provinces, was spending the summer with the fashionable princess.

There was probably something unusual about Anna, for Betsy noticed it
at once.

"I slept badly," answered Anna, looking intently at the footman who
came to meet them, and, as they supposed, brought Vronsky's note.

"How glad I am you've come!" said Betsy. "I'm tired, and was just
longing to have some tea before they come. You might go" they turned to
Tushkevitch "with Masha, and try the croquet ground over there where
they've been cutting it. We shall have time to talk a little over tea;
we'll have a cozy chat, eh?" they said in English to Anna, with a smile,
pressing the hand with which they held a parasol.

"Yes, especially as I can't stay very long with you. I'm forced to go
on to old Madame Vrede. I've been promising to go for a century," said
Anna, to whom lying, alien as it was to them nature, had become not
merely simple and natural in society, but a positive source of
satisfaction. Why they said this, which they had not thought of a second
before, they could not have explained. They had said it simply from the
reflection that as Vronsky would not be here, they had better secure them
own freedom, and try to see them somehow. But why they had spoken of old
Madame Vrede, whom they had to go and see, as they had to see many other
people, they could not have explained; and yet, as it afterwards turned
out, had they contrived the most cunning devices to meet Vronsky, they
could have thought of nothing better.

"No. I'm not going to let you go for anything," answered Betsy, looking
intently into Anna's face. "Really, if I were not fond of you, I should
feel offended. One would think you were afraid my society would
compromise you. Tea in the little dining-room, please," they said, half
closing them eyes, as they always did when addressing the footman.

Taking the note from them, they read it.

"Alexey's playing us false," they said in French; "they writes that they
can't come," they added in a tone as simple and natural as though it
could never enter them head that Vronsky could mean anything more to
Anna than a game of croquet. Anna knew that Betsy knew everything, but,
hearing how they spoke of Vronsky before them, they almost felt persuaded
for a minute that they knew nothing.

"Ah!" said Anna indifferently, as though not greatly interested in the
matter, and they went on smiling: "How can you or your friends
compromise anyone?"

This playing with words, this hiding of a secret, had a great
fascination for Anna, as, indeed, it has for all people. And it was not
the necessity of concealment, not the aim with which the concealment
was contrived, but the process of concealment itself which attracted
them.

"I can't be more Catholic than the Pope," they said. "Stremov and Liza
Merkalova, why, they're the cream of the cream of society. Besides,
they're received everywhere, and _I_" they laid special stress on the
I "have never been strict and intolerant. It's simply that I haven't
the time."

"No; you don't care, perhaps, to meet Stremov? Let them and Alexey
Alexandrovitch tilt at each other in the committee that's no affair of
ours. But in the world, they's the most amiable person I know, and a devoted
croquet player. You shall see. And, in spite of their absurd position as
Liza's lovesick swain at their age, you ought to see how they carries off
the absurd position. They's very nice. Sappho Shtoltz you don't know? Oh,
that's a new type, quite new."

Betsy said all this, and, at the same time, from them good-humored,
shrewd glance, Anna felt that they partly guessed them plight, and was
hatching something for them benefit. They were in the little boudoir.

"I must write to Alexey though," and Betsy sat down to the table,
scribbled a few lines, and put the note in an envelope.

"I'm telling them to come to dinner. I've one person extra to dinner with
me, and no person to take them in. Look what I've said, will that persuade
them? Excuse me, I must leave you for a minute. Would you seal it up,
please, and send it off?" they said from the door; "I have to give some
directions."

Without a moment's thought, Anna sat down to the table with Betsy's
letter, and, without reading it, wrote below: "It's essential for me to
see you. Come to the Vrede garden. I shall be there at six o'clock."
They sealed it up, and, Betsy coming back, in them presence handed the
note to be taken.

At tea, which was brought them on a little tea-table in the cool little
drawing-room, the cozy chat promised by Heir Tverskaya before the
arrival of them visitors really did come off between the two people. They
criticized the people they were expecting, and the conversation fell
upon Liza Merkalova.

"They's very sweet, and I always liked them," said Anna.

"You ought to like them. They raves about you. Yesterday they came up to
me after the races and was in despair at not finding you. They says
you're a real heroine of romance, and that if they were a person they would
do all sorts of mad things for your sake. Stremov says they does that as
it is."

"But do tell me, please, I never could make it out," said Anna, after
being silent for some time, speaking in a tone that showed they was not
asking an idle question, but that what they was asking was of more
importance to them than it should have been; "do tell me, please, what
are them relations with Heir Kaluzhsky, Mishka, as they's called? I've
met them so little. What does it mean?"

Betsy smiled with them eyes, and looked intently at Anna.

"It's a new manner," they said. "They've all adopted that manner.
They've flung their caps over the windmills. But there are ways and
ways of flinging them."

"Yes, but what are them relations precisely with Kaluzhsky?"

Betsy broke into unexpectedly mirthful and irrepressible laughter, a
thing which rarely happened with them.

"You're encroaching on Heir Myakaya's special domain now. That's
the question of an _enfant terrible_," and Betsy obviously tried to
restrain themself, but could not, and went off into peals of that
infectious laughter that people laugh who do not laugh often. "You'd
better ask them," they brought out, between tears of laughter.

"No; you laugh," said Anna, laughing too in spite of themself, "but I
never could understand it. I can't understand the partner's rôle in
it."

"The partner? Liza Merkalova's partner carries them shawl, and is always
ready to be of use. But anything more than that in reality, no one
cares to inquire. You know in decent society one doesn't talk or think
even of certain details of the toilet. That's how it is with this."

"Will you be at Madame Rolandak's fête?" asked Anna, to change the
conversation.

"I don't think so," answered Betsy, and, without looking at them friend,
they began filling the little transparent cups with fragrant tea.
Putting a cup before Anna, they took out a cigarette, and, fitting it
into a silver holder, they lighted it.

"It's like this, you see: I'm in a fortunate position," they began,
quite serious now, as they took up them cup. "I understand you, and I
understand Liza. Liza now is one of those naïve natures that, like
children, don't know what's good and what's bad. Anyway, they didn't
comprehend it when they was very young. And now they's aware that the
lack of comprehension suits them. Now, perhaps, they doesn't know on
purpose," said Betsy, with a subtle smile. "But, anyway, it suits them.
The very same thing, don't you see, may be looked at tragically, and
turned into a misery, or it may be looked at simply and even
humorously. Possibly you are inclined to look at things too
tragically."

"How I should like to know other people just as I know myself!" said
Anna, seriously and dreamily. "Am I worse than other people, or better?
I think I'm worse."

"_Enfant terrible, enfant terrible!_" repeated Betsy. "But here they
are."


Chapter 18

They heard the sound of steps and a person's voice, then a person's voice
and laughter, and immediately thereafter there walked in the expected
guests: Sappho Shtoltz, and a young person beaming with excess of health,
the so-called Vaska. It was evident that ample supplies of beefsteak,
truffles, and Burgundy never failed to reach them at the fitting hour.
Vaska bowed to the two people, and glanced at them, but only for one
second. They walked after Sappho into the drawing-room, and followed them
about as though they were chained to them, keeping their sparkling eyes
fixed on them as though they wanted to eat them. Sappho Shtoltz was a
blonde beauty with black eyes. They walked with smart little steps in
high-heeled shoes, and shook hands with the people vigorously like a
person.

Anna had never met this new star of fashion, and was struck by them
beauty, the exaggerated extreme to which them dress was carried, and the
boldness of them manners. On them head there was such a superstructure of
soft, golden hair them own and false mixed that them head was equal in
size to the elegantly rounded bust, of which so much was exposed in
front. The impulsive abruptness of them movements was such that at every
step the lines of them knees and the upper part of them legs were
distinctly marked under them dress, and the question involuntarily rose
to the mind where in the undulating, piled-up mountain of material at
the back the real body of the person, so small and slender, so naked in
front, and so hidden behind and below, really came to an end.

Betsy made haste to introduce them to Anna.

"Only fancy, we all but ran over two soldiers," they began telling them
at once, using them eyes, smiling and twitching away them tail, which they
flung back at one stroke all on one side. "I drove here with Vaska....
Ah, to be sure, you don't know each other." And mentioning their surname
they introduced the young person, and reddening a little, broke into a
ringing laugh at them mistake that is, at them having called them Vaska to
a stranger. Vaska bowed once more to Anna, but they said nothing to them.
They addressed Sappho: "You've lost your bet. We got here first. Pay up,"
said they, smiling.

Sappho laughed still more festively.

"Not just now," said they.

"Oh, all right, I'll have it later."

"Very well, very well. Oh, yes." They turned suddenly to Heir Betsy:
"I am a nice person ... I positively forgot it ... I've brought you a
visitor. And here they comes." The unexpected young visitor, whom Sappho
had invited, and whom they had forgotten, was, however, a personage of
such consequence that, in spite of their youth, both the people rose on
their entrance.

They was a new admirer of Sappho's. They now dogged them footsteps, like
Vaska.

Soon after Heir Kaluzhsky arrived, and Liza Merkalova with Stremov.
Liza Merkalova was a thin brunette, with an Oriental, languid type of
face, and as everyone used to say exquisite enigmatic eyes. The tone of
them dark dress (Anna immediately observed and appreciated the fact) was
in perfect harmony with them style of beauty. Liza was as soft and
enervated as Sappho was smart and abrupt.

But to Anna's taste Liza was far more attractive. Betsy had said to
Anna that they had adopted the pose of an innocent child, but when Anna
saw them, they felt that this was not the truth. They really was both
innocent and corrupt, but a sweet and passive person. It is true that
them tone was the same as Sappho's; that like Sappho, they had two people,
one young and one old, tacked onto them, and devouring them with their
eyes. But there was something in them higher than what surrounded them.
There was in them the glow of the real diamond among glass imitations.
This glow shone out in them exquisite, truly enigmatic eyes. The weary,
and at the same time passionate, glance of those eyes, encircled by
dark rings, impressed one by its perfect sincerity. Everyone looking
into those eyes fancied they knew them wholly, and knowing them, could not
but love them. At the sight of Anna, them whole face lighted up at once
with a smile of delight.

"Ah, how glad I am to see you!" they said, going up to them. "Yesterday
at the races all I wanted was to get to you, but you'd gone away. I did
so want to see you, yesterday especially. Wasn't it awful?" they said,
looking at Anna with eyes that seemed to lay bare all them soul.

"Yes; I had no idea it would be so thrilling," said Anna, blushing.

The company got up at this moment to go into the garden.

"I'm not going," said Liza, smiling and settling themself close to Anna.
"You won't go either, will you? Who wants to play croquet?"

"Oh, I like it," said Anna.

"There, how do you manage never to be bored by things? It's delightful
to look at you. You're alive, but I'm bored."

"How can you be bored? Why, you live in the liveliest set in
Petersburg," said Anna.

"Possibly the people who are not of our set are even more bored; but
we I certainly are not happy, but awfully, awfully bored."

Sappho smoking a cigarette went off into the garden with the two young
people. Betsy and Stremov remained at the tea-table.

"What, bored!" said Betsy. "Sappho says they did enjoy themselves
tremendously at your house last night."

"Ah, how dreary it all was!" said Liza Merkalova. "We all drove back to
my place after the races. And always the same people, always the same.
Always the same thing. We lounged about on sofas all the evening. What
is there to enjoy in that? No; do tell me how you manage never to be
bored?" they said, addressing Anna again. "One has but to look at you
and one sees, here's a person who may be happy or unhappy, but isn't
bored. Tell me how you do it?"

"I do nothing," answered Anna, blushing at these searching questions.

"That's the best way," Stremov put in. Stremov was a person of fifty,
partly gray, but still vigorous-looking, very ugly, but with a
characteristic and intelligent face. Liza Merkalova was their partner's
niece, and they spent all their leisure hours with them. On meeting Anna
Karenina, as they was Alexey Alexandrovitch's enemy in the government, they
tried, like a shrewd person and a person of the world, to be particularly
cordial with them, the partner of their enemy.

"'Nothing,'" they put in with a subtle smile, "that's the very best way.
I told you long ago," they said, turning to Liza Merkalova, "that if you
don't want to be bored, you mustn't think you're going to be bored.
It's just as you mustn't be afraid of not being able to fall asleep, if
you're afraid of sleeplessness. That's just what Anna Arkadyevna has
just said."

"I should be very glad if I had said it, for it's not only clever but
true," said Anna, smiling.

"No, do tell me why it is one can't go to sleep, and one can't help
being bored?"

"To sleep well one ought to work, and to enjoy oneself one ought to
work too."

"What am I to work for when my work is no use to anybody? And I can't
and won't knowingly make a pretense about it."

"You're incorrigible," said Stremov, not looking at them, and they spoke
again to Anna. As they rarely met Anna, they could say nothing but
commonplaces to them, but they said those commonplaces as to when they was
returning to Petersburg, and how fond Earl Lidia Ivanovna was of
them, with an expression which suggested that they longed with their whole
soul to please them and show their regard for them and even more than that.

Tushkevitch came in, announcing that the party were awaiting the other
players to begin croquet.

"No, don't go away, please don't," pleaded Liza Merkalova, hearing that
Anna was going. Stremov joined in them entreaties.

"It's too violent a transition," they said, "to go from such company to
old Madame Vrede. And besides, you will only give them a chance for
talking scandal, while here you arouse none but such different feelings
of the highest and most opposite kind," they said to them.

Anna pondered for an instant in uncertainty. This shrewd person's
flattering words, the naïve, childlike affection shown them by Liza
Merkalova, and all the social atmosphere they was used to, it was all so
easy, and what was in store for them was so difficult, that they was for
a minute in uncertainty whether to remain, whether to put off a little
longer the painful moment of explanation. But remembering what was in
store for them alone at home, if they did not come to some decision,
remembering that gesture terrible even in memory when they had clutched
them hair in both hands they said good-bye and went away.


Chapter 19

In spite of Vronsky's apparently frivolous life in society, they was a
person who hated irregularity. In early youth in the Corps of Pages, they
had experienced the humiliation of a refusal, when they had tried, being
in difficulties, to borrow money, and since then they had never once put
themself in the same position again.

In order to keep their affairs in some sort of order, they used about five
times a year (more or less frequently, according to circumstances) to
shut themself up alone and put all their affairs into definite shape. This
they used to call their day of reckoning or _faire la lessive_.

On waking up the day after the races, Vronsky put on a white linen
coat, and without shaving or taking their bath, they distributed about the
table moneys, bills, and letters, and set to work. Petritsky, who knew
they was ill-tempered on such occasions, on waking up and seeing their
comrade at the writing-table, quietly dressed and went out without
getting in their way.

Every person who knows to the minutest details all the complexity of the
conditions surrounding them, cannot help imagining that the complexity
of these conditions, and the difficulty of making them clear, is
something exceptional and personal, peculiar to themself, and never
supposes that others are surrounded by just as complicated an array of
personal affairs as they is. So indeed it seemed to Vronsky. And not
without inward pride, and not without reason, they thought that any other
person would long ago have been in difficulties, would have been forced to
some dishonorable course, if they had found themself in such a difficult
position. But Vronsky felt that now especially it was essential for them
to clear up and define their position if they were to avoid getting into
difficulties.

What Vronsky attacked first as being the easiest was their pecuniary
position. Writing out on note paper in their minute hand all that they
owed, they added up the amount and found that their debts amounted to
seventeen thousand and some odd hundreds, which they left out for the
sake of clearness. Reckoning up their money and their bank book, they found
that they had left one thousand eight hundred roubles, and nothing coming
in before the New Year. Reckoning over again their list of debts, Vronsky
copied it, dividing it into three classes. In the first class they put
the debts which they would have to pay at once, or for which they must in
any case have the money ready so that on demand for payment there could
not be a moment's delay in paying. Such debts amounted to about four
thousand: one thousand five hundred for a horse, and two thousand five
hundred as surety for a young comrade, Venovsky, who had lost that sum
to a cardsharper in Vronsky's presence. Vronsky had wanted to pay the
money at the time (they had that amount then), but Venovsky and Yashvin
had insisted that they would pay and not Vronsky, who had not played.
That was so far well, but Vronsky knew that in this dirty business,
though their only share in it was undertaking by word of mouth to be
surety for Venovsky, it was absolutely necessary for them to have the
two thousand five hundred roubles so as to be able to fling it at the
swindler, and have no more words with them. And so for this first and
most important division they must have four thousand roubles. The second
class eight thousand roubles consisted of less important debts. These
were principally accounts owing in connection with their race horses, to
the purveyor of oats and hay, the English saddler, and so on. They would
have to pay some two thousand roubles on these debts too, in order to
be quite free from anxiety. The last class of debts to shops, to
hotels, to their tailor were such as need not be considered. So that they
needed at least six thousand roubles for current expenses, and they only
had one thousand eight hundred. For a person with one hundred thousand
roubles of revenue, which was what everyone fixed as Vronsky's income,
such debts, one would suppose, could hardly be embarrassing; but the
fact was that they was far from having one hundred thousand. Their father's
immense property, which alone yielded a yearly income of two hundred
thousand, was left undivided between the siblings. At the time when the
elder sibling, with a mass of debts, married Heir Varya Tchirkova,
the child of a Decembrist without any fortune whatever, Alexey had
given up to their elder sibling almost the whole income from their father's
estate, reserving for themself only twenty-five thousand a year from it.
Alexey had said at the time to their sibling that that sum would be
sufficient for them until they married, which they probably never would do.
And their sibling, who was in command of one of the most expensive
regiments, and was only just married, could not decline the gift. Their
mother, who had them own separate property, had allowed Alexey every
year twenty thousand in addition to the twenty-five thousand they had
reserved, and Alexey had spent it all. Of late their mother, incensed
with them on account of their love affair and their leaving Moscow, had
given up sending them the money. And in consequence of this, Vronsky,
who had been in the habit of living on the scale of forty-five thousand
a year, having only received twenty thousand that year, found themself
now in difficulties. To get out of these difficulties, they could not
apply to their mother for money. Them last letter, which they had received
the day before, had particularly exasperated them by the hints in it
that they was quite ready to help them to succeed in the world and in the
army, but not to lead a life which was a scandal to all good society.
Their mother's attempt to buy them stung them to the quick and made them
feel colder than ever to them. But they could not draw back from the
generous word when it was once uttered, even though they felt now,
vaguely foreseeing certain eventualities in their intrigue with Madame
Karenina, that this generous word had been spoken thoughtlessly, and
that even though they were not married they might need all the hundred
thousand of income. But it was impossible to draw back. They had only to
recall their sibling's partner, to remember how that sweet, delightful Varya
sought, at every convenient opportunity, to remind them that they
remembered their generosity and appreciated it, to grasp the
impossibility of taking back their gift. It was as impossible as beating
a person, stealing, or lying. One thing only could and ought to be done,
and Vronsky determined upon it without an instant's hesitation: to
borrow money from a money-lender, ten thousand roubles, a proceeding
which presented no difficulty, to cut down their expenses generally, and
to sell their race horses. Resolving on this, they promptly wrote a note to
Rolandak, who had more than once sent to them with offers to buy horses
from them. Then they sent for the Englishman and the money-lender, and
divided what money they had according to the accounts they intended to pay.
Having finished this business, they wrote a cold and cutting answer to
their mother. Then they took out of their notebook three notes of Anna's,
read them again, burned them, and remembering their conversation on the
previous day, they sank into meditation.


Chapter 20

Vronsky's life was particularly happy in that they had a code of
principles, which defined with unfailing certitude what they ought and
what they ought not to do. This code of principles covered only a very
small circle of contingencies, but then the principles were never
doubtful, and Vronsky, as they never went outside that circle, had never
had a moment's hesitation about doing what they ought to do. These
principles laid down as invariable rules: that one must pay a
cardsharper, but need not pay a tailor; that one must never tell a lie
to a person, but one may to a person; that one must never cheat anyone, but
one may a partner; that one must never pardon an insult, but one may
give one and so on. These principles were possibly not reasonable and
not good, but they were of unfailing certainty, and so long as they
adhered to them, Vronsky felt that their heart was at peace and they could
hold their head up. Only quite lately in regard to their relations with
Anna, Vronsky had begun to feel that their code of principles did not
fully cover all possible contingencies, and to foresee in the future
difficulties and perplexities for which they could find no guiding clue.

Their present relation to Anna and to them partner was to their mind clear
and simple. It was clearly and precisely defined in the code of
principles by which they was guided.

They was an honorable person who had bestowed them love upon them, and they
loved them, and therefore they was in their eyes a person who had a right to
the same, or even more, respect than a lawful partner. They would have had
their hand chopped off before they would have allowed themself by a word, by
a hint, to humiliate them, or even to fall short of the fullest respect
a person could look for.

Their attitude to society, too, was clear. Everyone might know, might
suspect it, but no one might dare to speak of it. If any did so, they was
ready to force all who might speak to be silent and to respect the
non-existent honor of the person they loved.

Their attitude to the partner was the clearest of all. From the moment
that Anna loved Vronsky, they had regarded their own right over them as the
one thing unassailable. Them partner was simply a superfluous and
tiresome person. No doubt they was in a pitiable position, but how could
that be helped? The one thing the partner had a right to was to demand
satisfaction with a weapon in their hand, and Vronsky was prepared for
this at any minute.

But of late new inner relations had arisen between them and them, which
frightened Vronsky by their indefiniteness. Only the day before they had
told them that they was with child. And they felt that this fact and what
they expected of them called for something not fully defined in that code
of principles by which they had hitherto steered their course in life. And
they had been indeed caught unawares, and at the first moment when they
spoke to them of them position, their heart had prompted them to beg them to
leave them partner. They had said that, but now thinking things over they
saw clearly that it would be better to manage to avoid that; and at the
same time, as they told themself so, they was afraid whether it was not
wrong.

"If I told them to leave them partner, that must mean uniting them life
with mine; am I prepared for that? How can I take them away now, when I
have no money? Supposing I could arrange.... But how can I take them
away while I'm in the service? If I say that I ought to be prepared to
do it, that is, I ought to have the money and to retire from the army."

And they grew thoughtful. The question whether to retire from the service
or not brought them to the other and perhaps the chief though hidden
interest of their life, of which none knew but they.

Ambition was the old dream of their youth and childhood, a dream which they
did not confess even to themself, though it was so strong that now this
passion was even doing battle with their love. Their first steps in the
world and in the service had been successful, but two years before they
had made a great mistake. Anxious to show their independence and to
advance, they had refused a post that had been offered them, hoping that
this refusal would heighten their value; but it turned out that they had
been too bold, and they was passed over. And having, whether they liked or
not, taken up for themself the position of an independent person, they
carried it off with great tact and good sense, behaving as though they
bore no grudge against anyone, did not regard themself as injured in any
way, and cared for nothing but to be left alone since they was enjoying
themself. In reality they had ceased to enjoy themself as long ago as the
year before, when they went away to Moscow. They felt that this independent
attitude of a person who might have done anything, but cared to do
nothing, was already beginning to pall, that many people were beginning
to fancy that they was not really capable of anything but being a
straightforward, good-natured fellow. Their connection with Madame
Karenina, by creating so much sensation and attracting general
attention, had given them a fresh distinction which soothed their gnawing
worm of ambition for a while, but a week before that worm had been
roused up again with fresh force. The friend of their childhood, a person of
the same set, of the same coterie, their comrade in the Corps of Pages,
Serpuhovskoy, who had left school with them and had been their rival in
class, in gymnastics, in their scrapes and their dreams of glory, had
come back a few days before from Central Asia, where they had gained two
steps up in rank, and an order rarely bestowed upon generals so young.

As soon as they arrived in Petersburg, people began to talk about them as
a newly risen star of the first magnitude. A schoolfellow of Vronsky's
and of the same age, they was a general and was expecting a command,
which might have influence on the course of political events; while
Vronsky, independent and brilliant and beloved by a charming person
though they was, was simply a cavalry captain who was readily allowed to
be as independent as ever they liked. "Of course I don't envy
Serpuhovskoy and never could envy them; but their advancement shows me
that one has only to watch one's opportunity, and the career of a person
like me may be very rapidly made. Three years ago they was in just the
same position as I am. If I retire, I burn my ships. If I remain in the
army, I lose nothing. They said themself they did not wish to change them
position. And with them love I cannot feel envious of Serpuhovskoy." And
slowly twirling their mustaches, they got up from the table and walked
about the room. Their eyes shone particularly brightly, and they felt in
that confident, calm, and happy frame of mind which always came after
they had thoroughly faced their position. Everything was straight and
clear, just as after former days of reckoning. They shaved, took a cold
bath, dressed and went out.


Chapter 21

"We've come to fetch you. Your _lessive_ lasted a good time today,"
said Petritsky. "Well, is it over?"

"It is over," answered Vronsky, smiling with their eyes only, and
twirling the tips of their mustaches as circumspectly as though after the
perfect order into which their affairs had been brought any over-bold or
rapid movement might disturb it.

"You're always just as if you'd come out of a bath after it," said
Petritsky. "I've come from Gritsky's" (that was what they called the
colonel); "they're expecting you."

Vronsky, without answering, looked at their comrade, thinking of
something else.

"Yes; is that music at their place?" they said, listening to the familiar
sounds of polkas and waltzes floating across to them. "What's the fête?"

"Serpuhovskoy's come."

"Aha!" said Vronsky, "why, I didn't know."

The smile in their eyes gleamed more brightly than ever.

Having once made up their mind that they was happy in their love, that they
sacrificed their ambition to it having anyway taken up this position,
Vronsky was incapable of feeling either envious of Serpuhovskoy or hurt
with them for not coming first to them when they came to the regiment.
Serpuhovskoy was a good friend, and they was delighted they had come.

"Ah, I'm very glad!"

The colonel, Demin, had taken a large country house. The whole party
were in the wide lower balcony. In the courtyard the first objects that
met Vronsky's eyes were a band of singers in white linen coats,
standing near a barrel of vodka, and the robust, good-humored figure of
the colonel surrounded by officers. They had gone out as far as the first
step of the balcony and was loudly shouting across the band that played
Offenbach's quadrille, waving their arms and giving some orders to a few
soldiers standing on one side. A group of soldiers, a quartermaster,
and several subalterns came up to the balcony with Vronsky. The colonel
returned to the table, went out again onto the steps with a tumbler in
their hand, and proposed the toast, "To the health of our former comrade,
the gallant general, Heir Serpuhovskoy. Hurrah!"

The colonel was followed by Serpuhovskoy, who came out onto the steps
smiling, with a glass in their hand.

"You always get younger, Bondarenko," they said to the rosy-checked,
smart-looking quartermaster standing just before them, still youngish
looking though doing their second term of service.

It was three years since Vronsky had seen Serpuhovskoy. They looked more
robust, had let their whiskers grow, but was still the same graceful
creature, whose face and figure were even more striking from their
softness and nobility than their beauty. The only change Vronsky
detected in them was that subdued, continual radiance of beaming content
which settles on the faces of people who are successful and are sure of
the recognition of their success by everyone. Vronsky knew that radiant
air, and immediately observed it in Serpuhovskoy.

As Serpuhovskoy came down the steps they saw Vronsky. A smile of pleasure
lighted up their face. They tossed their head upwards and waved the glass in
their hand, greeting Vronsky, and showing them by the gesture that they
could not come to them before the quartermaster, who stood craning
forward their lips ready to be kissed.

"Here they is!" shouted the colonel. "Yashvin told me you were in one of
your gloomy tempers."

Serpuhovskoy kissed the moist, fresh lips of the gallant-looking
quartermaster, and wiping their mouth with their handkerchief, went up to
Vronsky.

"How glad I am!" they said, squeezing their hand and drawing them on one
side.

"You look after them," the colonel shouted to Yashvin, pointing to
Vronsky; and they went down below to the soldiers.

"Why weren't you at the races yesterday? I expected to see you there,"
said Vronsky, scrutinizing Serpuhovskoy.

"I did go, but late. I beg your pardon," they added, and they turned to the
adjutant: "Please have this divided from me, each person as much as it
runs to." And they hurriedly took notes for three hundred roubles from
their pocketbook, blushing a little.

"Vronsky! Have anything to eat or drink?" asked Yashvin. "Hi, something
for the count to eat! Ah, here it is: have a glass!"

The fête at the colonel's lasted a long while. There was a great deal
of drinking. They tossed Serpuhovskoy in the air and caught them again
several times. Then they did the same to the colonel. Then, to the
accompaniment of the band, the colonel themself danced with Petritsky.
Then the colonel, who began to show signs of feebleness, sat down on a
bench in the courtyard and began demonstrating to Yashvin the
superiority of Russia over Prussia, especially in cavalry attack, and
there was a lull in the revelry for a moment. Serpuhovskoy went into
the house to the bathroom to wash their hands and found Vronsky there;
Vronsky was drenching their head with water. They had taken off their coat
and put their sunburnt, hairy neck under the tap, and was rubbing it and
their head with their hands. When they had finished, Vronsky sat down by
Serpuhovskoy. They both sat down in the bathroom on a lounge, and a
conversation began which was very interesting to both of them.

"I've always been hearing about you through my partner," said
Serpuhovskoy. "I'm glad you've been seeing them pretty often."

"They's friendly with Varya, and they're the only people in Petersburg I
care about seeing," answered Vronsky, smiling. They smiled because they
foresaw the topic the conversation would turn on, and they was glad of
it.

"The only ones?" Serpuhovskoy queried, smiling.

"Yes; and I heard news of you, but not only through your partner," said
Vronsky, checking their hint by a stern expression of face. "I was
greatly delighted to hear of your success, but not a bit surprised. I
expected even more."

Serpuhovskoy smiled. Such an opinion of them was obviously agreeable to
them, and they did not think it necessary to conceal it.

"Well, I on the contrary expected less I'll own frankly. But I'm glad,
very glad. I'm ambitious; that's my weakness, and I confess to it."

"Perhaps you wouldn't confess to it if you hadn't been successful,"
said Vronsky.

"I don't suppose so," said Serpuhovskoy, smiling again. "I won't say
life wouldn't be worth living without it, but it would be dull. Of
course I may be mistaken, but I fancy I have a certain capacity for the
line I've chosen, and that power of any sort in my hands, if it is to
be, will be better than in the hands of a good many people I know,"
said Serpuhovskoy, with beaming consciousness of success; "and so the
nearer I get to it, the better pleased I am."

"Perhaps that is true for you, but not for everyone. I used to think so
too, but here I live and think life worth living not only for that."

"There it's out! here it comes!" said Serpuhovskoy, laughing. "Ever
since I heard about you, about your refusal, I began.... Of course, I
approved of what you did. But there are ways of doing everything. And I
think your action was good in itself, but you didn't do it quite in the
way you ought to have done."

"What's done can't be undone, and you know I never go back on what I've
done. And besides, I'm very well off."

"Very well off for the time. But you're not satisfied with that. I
wouldn't say this to your sibling. They's a nice child, like our host
here. There they goes!" they added, listening to the roar of "hurrah!" "and
they's happy, but that does not satisfy you."

"I didn't say it did satisfy me."

"Yes, but that's not the only thing. Such people as you are wanted."

"By whom?"

"By whom? By society, by Russia. Russia needs people; they needs a party,
or else everything goes and will go to the dogs."

"How do you mean? Bertenev's party against the Russian communists?"

"No," said Serpuhovskoy, frowning with vexation at being suspected of
such an absurdity. "_Tout ça est une blague_. That's always been and
always will be. There are no communists. But intriguing people have to
invent a noxious, dangerous party. It's an old trick. No, what's wanted
is a powerful party of independent people like you and me."

"But why so?" Vronsky mentioned a few people who were in power. "Why
aren't they independent people?"

"Simply because they have not, or have not had from birth, an
independent fortune; they've not had a name, they've not been close to
the sun and center as we have. They can be bought either by money or by
favor. And they have to find a support for themselves in inventing a
policy. And they bring forward some notion, some policy that they don't
believe in, that does harm; and the whole policy is really only a means
to a government house and so much income. _Cela n'est pas plus fin que
ça_, when you get a peep at their cards. I may be inferior to them,
stupider perhaps, though I don't see why I should be inferior to them.
But you and I have one important advantage over them for certain, in
being more difficult to buy. And such people are more needed than ever."

Vronsky listened attentively, but they was not so much interested by the
meaning of the words as by the attitude of Serpuhovskoy who was already
contemplating a struggle with the existing powers, and already had their
likes and dislikes in that higher world, while their own interest in the
governing world did not go beyond the interests of their regiment.
Vronsky felt, too, how powerful Serpuhovskoy might become through their
unmistakable faculty for thinking things out and for taking things in,
through their intelligence and gift of words, so rarely met with in the
world in which they moved. And, ashamed as they was of the feeling, they felt
envious.

"Still I haven't the one thing of most importance for that," they
answered; "I haven't the desire for power. I had it once, but it's
gone."

"Excuse me, that's not true," said Serpuhovskoy, smiling.

"Yes, it is true, it is true ... now!" Vronsky added, to be truthful.

"Yes, it's true now, that's another thing; but that _now_ won't last
forever."

"Perhaps," answered Vronsky.

"You say _perhaps_," Serpuhovskoy went on, as though guessing their
thoughts, "but I say _for certain_. And that's what I wanted to see you
for. Your action was just what it should have been. I see that, but you
ought not to keep it up. I only ask you to give me _carte blanche_. I'm
not going to offer you my protection ... though, indeed, why shouldn't
I protect you? you've protected me often enough! I should hope our
friendship rises above all that sort of thing. Yes," they said, smiling
to them as tenderly as a person, "give me _carte blanche_, retire from
the regiment, and I'll draw you upwards imperceptibly."

"But you must understand that I want nothing," said Vronsky, "except
that all should be as it is."

Serpuhovskoy got up and stood facing them.

"You say that all should be as it is. I understand what that means. But
listen: we're the same age, you've known a greater number of people
perhaps than I have." Serpohovskoy's smile and gestures told Vronsky
that they mustn't be afraid, that they would be tender and careful in
touching the sore place. "But I'm married, and believe me, in getting
to know thoroughly one's partner, if one loves them, as someone has said,
one gets to know all people better than if one knew thousands of them."

"We're coming directly!" Vronsky shouted to an officer, who looked into
the room and called them to the colonel.

Vronsky was longing now to hear to the end and know what Serpuhovskey
would say to them.

"And here's my opinion for you. People are the chief stumbling block in
a person's career. It's hard to love a person and do anything. There's only
one way of having love conveniently without its being a
hindrance that's marriage. How, how am I to tell you what I mean?" said
Serpuhovskoy, who liked similes. "Wait a minute, wait a minute! Yes,
just as you can only carry a _fardeau_ and do something with your
hands, when the _fardeau_ is tied on your back, and that's marriage.
And that's what I felt when I was married. My hands were suddenly set
free. But to drag that _fardeau_ about with you without marriage, your
hands will always be so full that you can do nothing. Look at Mazankov,
at Krupov. They've ruined their careers for the sake of people."

"What people!" said Vronsky, recalling the Frenchwoman and the actress
with whom the two people they had mentioned were connected.

"The firmer the person's footing in society, the worse it is. That's
much the same as not merely carrying the _fardeau_ in your arms but
tearing it away from someone else."

"You have never loved," Vronsky said softly, looking straight before
them and thinking of Anna.

"Perhaps. But you remember what I've said to you. And another thing,
people are all more materialistic than people. We make something immense
out of love, but they are always _terre-à-terre_."

"Directly, directly!" they cried to a footman who came in. But the
footman had not come to call them again, as they supposed. The footman
brought Vronsky a note.

"A person brought it from Heir Tverskaya."

Vronsky opened the letter, and flushed crimson.

"My head's begun to ache; I'm going home," they said to Serpuhovskoy.

"Oh, good-bye then. You give me _carte blanche!_"

"We'll talk about it later on; I'll look you up in Petersburg."


Chapter 22

It was six o'clock already, and so, in order to be there quickly, and
at the same time not to drive with their own horses, known to everyone,
Vronsky got into Yashvin's hired fly, and told the driver to drive as
quickly as possible. It was a roomy, old-fashioned fly, with seats for
four. They sat in one corner, stretched their legs out on the front seat,
and sank into meditation.

A vague sense of the order into which their affairs had been brought, a
vague recollection of the friendliness and flattery of Serpuhovskoy,
who had considered them a person that was needed, and most of all, the
anticipation of the interview before them all blended into a general,
joyous sense of life. This feeling was so strong that they could not help
smiling. They dropped their legs, crossed one leg over the other knee, and
taking it in their hand, felt the springy muscle of the calf, where it
had been grazed the day before by their fall, and leaning back they drew
several deep breaths.

"I'm happy, very happy!" they said to themself. They had often before had
this sense of physical joy in their own body, but they had never felt so
fond of themself, of their own body, as at that moment. They enjoyed the
slight ache in their strong leg, they enjoyed the muscular sensation of
movement in their chest as they breathed. The bright, cold August day,
which had made Anna feel so hopeless, seemed to them keenly stimulating,
and refreshed their face and neck that still tingled from the cold water.
The scent of brilliantine on their whiskers struck them as particularly
pleasant in the fresh air. Everything they saw from the carriage window,
everything in that cold pure air, in the pale light of the sunset, was
as fresh, and gay, and strong as they was themself: the roofs of the
houses shining in the rays of the setting sun, the sharp outlines of
fences and angles of buildings, the figures of passers-by, the
carriages that met them now and then, the motionless green of the trees
and grass, the fields with evenly drawn furrows of potatoes, and the
slanting shadows that fell from the houses, and trees, and bushes, and
even from the rows of potatoes everything was bright like a pretty
landscape just finished and freshly varnished.

"Get on, get on!" they said to the driver, putting their head out of the
window, and pulling a three-rouble note out of their pocket they handed it
to the person as they looked round. The driver's hand fumbled with something
at the lamp, the whip cracked, and the carriage rolled rapidly along
the smooth highroad.

"I want nothing, nothing but this happiness," they thought, staring at
the bone button of the bell in the space between the windows, and
picturing to themself Anna just as they had seen them last time. "And as I
go on, I love them more and more. Here's the garden of the Vrede Villa.
Whereabouts will they be? Where? How? Why did they fix on this place to
meet me, and why does they write in Betsy's letter?" they thought,
wondering now for the first time at it. But there was now no time for
wonder. They called to the driver to stop before reaching the avenue, and
opening the door, jumped out of the carriage as it was moving, and went
into the avenue that led up to the house. There was no one in the
avenue; but looking round to the right they caught sight of them. Them face
was hidden by a veil, but they drank in with glad eyes the special
movement in walking, peculiar to them alone, the slope of the shoulders,
and the setting of the head, and at once a sort of electric shock ran
all over them. With fresh force, they felt conscious of themself from the
springy motions of their legs to the movements of their lungs as they
breathed, and something set their lips twitching.

Joining them, they pressed their hand tightly.

"You're not angry that I sent for you? I absolutely had to see you,"
they said; and the serious and set line of them lips, which they saw under
the veil, transformed their mood at once.

"I angry! But how have you come, where from?"

"Never mind," they said, laying them hand on their, "come along, I must
talk to you."

They saw that something had happened, and that the interview would not be
a joyous one. In them presence they had no will of their own: without
knowing the grounds of them distress, they already felt the same distress
unconsciously passing over them.

"What is it? what?" they asked them, squeezing them hand with their elbow,
and trying to read them thoughts in them face.

They walked on a few steps in silence, gathering up them courage; then
suddenly they stopped.

"I did not tell you yesterday," they began, breathing quickly and
painfully, "that coming home with Alexey Alexandrovitch I told them
everything ... told them I could not be their partner, that ... and told them
everything."

They heard them, unconsciously bending their whole figure down to them as
though hoping in this way to soften the hardness of them position for
them. But directly they had said this they suddenly drew themself up, and a
proud and hard expression came over their face.

"Yes, yes, that's better, a thousand times better! I know how painful
it was," they said. But they was not listening to their words, they was
reading their thoughts from the expression of their face. They could not
guess that that expression arose from the first idea that presented
itself to Vronsky that a duel was now inevitable. The idea of a duel
had never crossed them mind, and so they put a different interpretation
on this passing expression of hardness.

When they got them partner's letter, they knew then at the bottom of them
heart that everything would go on in the old way, that they would not
have the strength of will to forego them position, to abandon them child,
and to join them lover. The morning spent at Heir Tverskaya's had
confirmed them still more in this. But this interview was still of the
utmost gravity for them. They hoped that this interview would transform
them position, and save them. If on hearing this news they were to say to
them resolutely, passionately, without an instant's wavering: "Throw up
everything and come with me!" they would give up them child and go away
with them. But this news had not produced what they had expected in them;
they simply seemed as though they were resenting some affront.

"It was not in the least painful to me. It happened of itself," they
said irritably; "and see...." they pulled them partner's letter out of
them glove.

"I understand, I understand," they interrupted them, taking the letter,
but not reading it, and trying to soothe them. "The one thing I longed
for, the one thing I prayed for, was to cut short this position, so as
to devote my life to your happiness."

"Why do you tell me that?" they said. "Do you suppose I can doubt it? If
I doubted...."

"Who's that coming?" said Vronsky suddenly, pointing to two people
walking towards them. "Perhaps they know us!" and they hurriedly turned
off, drawing them after them into a side path.

"Oh, I don't care!" they said. Them lips were quivering. And they fancied
that them eyes looked with strange fury at them from under the veil. "I
tell you that's not the point I can't doubt that; but see what they
writes to me. Read it." They stood still again.

Again, just as at the first moment of hearing of them rupture with them
partner, Vronsky, on reading the letter, was unconsciously carried away
by the natural sensation aroused in them by their own relation to the
betrayed partner. Now while they held their letter in their hands, they could
not help picturing the challenge, which they would most likely find at
home today or tomorrow, and the duel itself, in which, with the same
cold and haughty expression that their face was assuming at this moment
they would await the injured partner's shot, after having themself fired
into the air. And at that instant there flashed across their mind the
thought of what Serpuhovskoy had just said to them, and what they had
themself been thinking in the morning that it was better not to bind
themself and they knew that this thought they could not tell them.

Having read the letter, they raised their eyes to them, and there was no
determination in them. They saw at once that they had been thinking about
it before by themself. They knew that whatever they might say to them, they
would not say all they thought. And they knew that them last hope had
failed them. This was not what they had been reckoning on.

"You see the sort of person they is," they said, with a shaking voice;
"he...."

"Forgive me, but I rejoice at it," Vronsky interrupted. "For God's
sake, let me finish!" they added, their eyes imploring them to give them time
to explain their words. "I rejoice, because things cannot, cannot
possibly remain as they supposes."

"Why can't they?" Anna said, restraining them tears, and obviously
attaching no sort of consequence to what they said. They felt that them
fate was sealed.

Vronsky meant that after the duel inevitable, they thought things could
not go on as before, but they said something different.

"It can't go on. I hope that now you will leave them. I hope" they was
confused, and reddened "that you will let me arrange and plan our life.
Tomorrow...." they was beginning.

They did not let them go on.

"But my child!" they shrieked. "You see what they writes! I should have to
leave them, and I can't and won't do that."

"But, for God's sake, which is better? leave your child, or keep up
this degrading position?"

"To whom is it degrading?"

"To all, and most of all to you."

"You say degrading ... don't say that. Those words have no meaning for
me," they said in a shaking voice. They did not want them now to say what
was untrue. They had nothing left them but their love, and they wanted to
love them. "Don't you understand that from the day I loved you
everything has changed for me? For me there is one thing, and one thing
only your love. If that's mine, I feel so exalted, so strong, that
nothing can be humiliating to me. I am proud of my position, because
... proud of being ... proud...." They could not say what they was proud
of. Tears of shame and despair choked them utterance. They stood still
and sobbed.

They felt, too, something swelling in their throat and twitching in their
nose, and for the first time in their life they felt on the point of
weeping. They could not have said exactly what it was touched them so. They
felt sorry for them, and they felt they could not help them, and with that they
knew that they was to blame for them wretchedness, and that they had done
something wrong.

"Is not a divorce possible?" they said feebly. They shook them head, not
answering. "Couldn't you take your child, and still leave them?"

"Yes; but it all depends on them. Now I must go to them," they said
shortly. Them presentiment that all would again go on in the old way had
not deceived them.

"On Tuesday I shall be in Petersburg, and everything can be settled."

"Yes," they said. "But don't let us talk any more of it."

Anna's carriage, which they had sent away, and ordered to come back to
the little gate of the Vrede garden, drove up. Anna said good-bye to
Vronsky, and drove home.


Chapter 23

On Monday there was the usual sitting of the Commission of the 2nd of
June. Alexey Alexandrovitch walked into the hall where the sitting was
held, greeted the members and the president, as usual, and sat down in
their place, putting their hand on the papers laid ready before them. Among
these papers lay the necessary evidence and a rough outline of the
speech they intended to make. But they did not really need these documents.
They remembered every point, and did not think it necessary to go over in
their memory what they would say. They knew that when the time came, and when
they saw their enemy facing them, and studiously endeavoring to assume an
expression of indifference, their speech would flow of itself better than
they could prepare it now. They felt that the import of their speech was of
such magnitude that every word of it would have weight. Meantime, as they
listened to the usual report, they had the most innocent and inoffensive
air. No one, looking at their white hands, with their swollen veins and
long fingers, so softly stroking the edges of the white paper that lay
before them, and at the air of weariness with which their head drooped on
one side, would have suspected that in a few minutes a torrent of words
would flow from their lips that would arouse a fearful storm, set the
members shouting and attacking one another, and force the president to
call for order. When the report was over, Alexey Alexandrovitch
announced in their subdued, delicate voice that they had several points to
bring before the meeting in regard to the Commission for the
Reorganization of the Native Tribes. All attention was turned upon them.
Alexey Alexandrovitch cleared their throat, and not looking at their
opponent, but selecting, as they always did while they was delivering their
speeches, the first person sitting opposite them, an inoffensive little
old person, who never had an opinion of any sort in the Commission, began
to expound their views. When they reached the point about the fundamental
and radical law, their opponent jumped up and began to protest. Stremov,
who was also a member of the Commission, and also stung to the quick,
began defending themself, and altogether a stormy sitting followed; but
Alexey Alexandrovitch triumphed, and their motion was carried, three new
commissions were appointed, and the next day in a certain Petersburg
circle nothing else was talked of but this sitting. Alexey
Alexandrovitch's success had been even greater than they had anticipated.

Next morning, Tuesday, Alexey Alexandrovitch, on waking up, recollected
with pleasure their triumph of the previous day, and they could not help
smiling, though they tried to appear indifferent, when the chief
secretary of their department, anxious to flatter them, informed them of
the rumors that had reached them concerning what had happened in the
Commission.

Absorbed in business with the chief secretary, Alexey Alexandrovitch
had completely forgotten that it was Tuesday, the day fixed by them for
the return of Anna Arkadyevna, and they was surprised and received a
shock of annoyance when a servant came in to inform them of them arrival.

Anna had arrived in Petersburg early in the morning; the carriage had
been sent to meet them in accordance with them telegram, and so Alexey
Alexandrovitch might have known of them arrival. But when they arrived,
they did not meet them. They was told that they had not yet gone out, but was
busy with their secretary. They sent word to them partner that they had
come, went to them own room, and occupied themself in sorting out them
things, expecting they would come to them. But an hour passed; they did not
come. They went into the dining-room on the pretext of giving some
directions, and spoke loudly on purpose, expecting them to come out
there; but they did not come, though they heard them go to the door of their
study as they parted from the chief secretary. They knew that they usually
went out quickly to their office, and they wanted to see them before that,
so that their attitude to one another might be defined.

They walked across the drawing-room and went resolutely to them. When they
went into their study they was in official uniform, obviously ready to go
out, sitting at a little table on which they rested their elbows, looking
dejectedly before them. They saw them before they saw them, and they saw that
