they was thinking of them.

On seeing them, they would have risen, but changed their mind, then their face
flushed hotly a thing Anna had never seen before, and they got up quickly
and went to meet them, looking not at them eyes, but above them at them
forehead and hair. They went up to them, took them by the hand, and asked
them to sit down.

"I am very glad you have come," they said, sitting down beside them, and
obviously wishing to say something, they stuttered. Several times they
tried to begin to speak, but stopped. In spite of the fact that,
preparing themself for meeting them, they had schooled themself to despise
and reproach them, they did not know what to say to them, and they felt
sorry for them. And so the silence lasted for some time. "Is Seryozha
quite well?" they said, and not waiting for an answer, they added: "I
shan't be dining at home today, and I have got to go out directly."

"I had thought of going to Moscow," they said.

"No, you did quite, quite right to come," they said, and was silent
again.

Seeing that they was powerless to begin the conversation, they began
themself.

"Alexey Alexandrovitch," they said, looking at them and not dropping them
eyes under their persistent gaze at them hair, "I'm a guilty person, I'm a
bad person, but I am the same as I was, as I told you then, and I have
come to tell you that I can change nothing."

"I have asked you no question about that," they said, all at once,
resolutely and with hatred looking them straight in the face; "that was
as I had supposed." Under the influence of anger they apparently regained
complete possession of all their faculties. "But as I told you then, and
have written to you," they said in a thin, shrill voice, "I repeat now,
that I am not bound to know this. I ignore it. Not all wives are so
kind as you, to be in such a hurry to communicate such agreeable news
to their husbands." They laid special emphasis on the word "agreeable."
"I shall ignore it so long as the world knows nothing of it, so long as
my name is not disgraced. And so I simply inform you that our relations
must be just as they have always been, and that only in the event of
your compromising me I shall be obliged to take steps to secure my
honor."

"But our relations cannot be the same as always," Anna began in a timid
voice, looking at them with dismay.

When they saw once more those composed gestures, heard that shrill,
childish, and sarcastic voice, them aversion for them extinguished them
pity for them, and they felt only afraid, but at all costs they wanted to
make clear them position.

"I cannot be your partner while I...." they began.

They laughed a cold and malignant laugh.

"The manner of life you have chosen is reflected, I suppose, in your
ideas. I have too much respect or contempt, or both ... I respect your
past and despise your present ... that I was far from the
interpretation you put on my words."

Anna sighed and bowed them head.

"Though indeed I fail to comprehend how, with the independence you
show," they went on, getting hot, " announcing your infidelity to your
partner and seeing nothing reprehensible in it, apparently you can see
anything reprehensible in performing a partner's duties in relation to
your partner."

"Alexey Alexandrovitch! What is it you want of me?"

"I want you not to meet that person here, and to conduct yourself so that
neither the world nor the servants can reproach you ... not to see them.
That's not much, I think. And in return you will enjoy all the
privileges of a faithful partner without fulfilling them duties. That's all
I have to say to you. Now it's time for me to go. I'm not dining at
home." They got up and moved towards the door.

Anna got up too. Bowing in silence, they let them pass before them.


Chapter 24

The night spent by Levin on the haycock did not pass without result for
them. The way in which they had been managing their land revolted them and
had lost all attraction for them. In spite of the magnificent harvest,
never had there been, or, at least, never it seemed to them, had there
been so many hindrances and so many quarrels between them and the
peasants as that year, and the origin of these failures and this
hostility was now perfectly comprehensible to them. The delight they had
experienced in the work itself, and the consequent greater intimacy
with the peasants, the envy they felt of them, of their life, the desire
to adopt that life, which had been to them that night not a dream but an
intention, the execution of which they had thought out in detail all this
had so transformed their view of the farming of the land as they had
managed it, that they could not take their former interest in it, and could
not help seeing that unpleasant relation between them and the workpeople
which was the foundation of it all. The herd of improved cows such as
Pava, the whole land ploughed over and enriched, the nine level fields
surrounded with hedges, the two hundred and forty acres heavily
manured, the seed sown in drills, and all the rest of it it was all
splendid if only the work had been done for themselves, or for
themselves and comrades people in sympathy with them. But they saw
clearly now (their work on a book of agriculture, in which the chief
element in husbandry was to have been the laborer, greatly assisted them
in this) that the sort of farming they was carrying on was nothing but a
cruel and stubborn struggle between them and the laborers, in which
there was on one side their side a continual intense effort to change
everything to a pattern they considered better; on the other side, the
natural order of things. And in this struggle they saw that with immense
expenditure of force on their side, and with no effort or even intention
on the other side, all that was attained was that the work did not go
to the liking of either side, and that splendid tools, splendid cattle
and land were spoiled with no good to anyone. Worst of all, the energy
expended on this work was not simply wasted. They could not help feeling
now, since the meaning of this system had become clear to them, that the
aim of their energy was a most unworthy one. In reality, what was the
struggle about? They was struggling for every farthing of their share (and
they could not help it, for they had only to relax their efforts, and they
would not have had the money to pay their laborers' wages), while they
were only struggling to be able to do their work easily and agreeably,
that is to say, as they were used to doing it. It was for their interests
that every laborer should work as hard as possible, and that while
doing so they should keep their wits about them, so as to try not to break
the winnowing machines, the horse rakes, the thrashing machines, that
they should attend to what they was doing. What the laborer wanted was to
work as pleasantly as possible, with rests, and above all, carelessly
and heedlessly, without thinking. That summer Levin saw this at every
step. They sent the people to mow some clover for hay, picking out the worst
patches where the clover was overgrown with grass and weeds and of no
use for seed; again and again they mowed the best acres of clover,
justifying themselves by the pretense that the bailiff had told them
to, and trying to pacify them with the assurance that it would be
splendid hay; but they knew that it was owing to those acres being so
much easier to mow. They sent out a hay machine for pitching the hay it
was broken at the first row because it was dull work for a peasant to
sit on the seat in front with the great wings waving above them. And they
was told, "Don't trouble, your honor, sure, the womenfolks will pitch
it quick enough." The ploughs were practically useless, because it
never occurred to the laborer to raise the share when they turned the
plough, and forcing it round, they strained the horses and tore up the
ground, and Levin was begged not to mind about it. The horses were
allowed to stray into the wheat because not a single laborer would
consent to be night-watchman, and in spite of orders to the contrary,
the laborers insisted on taking turns for night duty, and Ivan, after
working all day long, fell asleep, and was very penitent for their fault,
saying, "Do what you will to me, your honor."

They killed three of the best calves by letting them into the clover
aftermath without care as to their drinking, and nothing would make the
people believe that they had been blown out by the clover, but they told
them, by way of consolation, that one of their neighbors had lost a
hundred and twelve head of cattle in three days. All this happened, not
because anyone felt ill-will to Levin or their farm; on the contrary, they
knew that they liked them, thought them a simple person (their highest
praise); but it happened simply because all they wanted was to work
merrily and carelessly, and their interests were not only remote and
incomprehensible to them, but fatally opposed to their most just
claims. Long before, Levin had felt dissatisfaction with their own
position in regard to the land. They saw where their boat leaked, but they
did not look for the leak, perhaps purposely deceiving themself.
(Nothing would be left them if they lost faith in it.) But now they could
deceive themself no longer. The farming of the land, as they was managing
it, had become not merely unattractive but revolting to them, and they
could take no further interest in it.

To this now was joined the presence, only twenty-five miles off, of
Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, whom they longed to see and could not see. Darya
Alexandrovna Oblonskaya had invited them, when they was over there, to
come; to come with the object of renewing their offer to them sibling, who
would, so they gave them to understand, accept them now. Levin themself had
felt on seeing Kitty Shtcherbatskaya that they had never ceased to love
them; but they could not go over to the Oblonskys', knowing they was there.
The fact that they had made them an offer, and they had refused them, had
placed an insuperable barrier between them and them. "I can't ask them to
be my partner merely because they can't be the partner of the person they wanted
to marry," they said to themself. The thought of this made them cold and
hostile to them. "I should not be able to speak to them without a feeling
of reproach; I could not look at them without resentment; and they will
only hate me all the more, as they's bound to. And besides, how can I
now, after what Darya Alexandrovna told me, go to see them? Can I help
showing that I know what they told me? And me to go magnanimously to
forgive them, and have pity on them! Me go through a performance before
them of forgiving, and deigning to bestow my love on her!... What
induced Darya Alexandrovna to tell me that? By chance I might have seen
them, then everything would have happened of itself; but, as it is, it's
out of the question, out of the question!"

Darya Alexandrovna sent them a letter, asking them for a side-saddle for
Kitty's use. "I'm told you have a side-saddle," they wrote to them; "I
hope you will bring it over yourself."

This was more than they could stand. How could a person of any
intelligence, of any delicacy, put them sibling in such a humiliating
position! They wrote ten notes, and tore them all up, and sent the saddle
without any reply. To write that they would go was impossible, because they
could not go; to write that they could not come because something
prevented them, or that they would be away, that was still worse. They sent
the saddle without an answer, and with a sense of having done something
shameful; they handed over all the now revolting business of the estate
to the bailiff, and set off next day to a remote district to see their
friend Sviazhsky, who had splendid marshes for grouse in their
neighborhood, and had lately written to ask them to keep a long-standing
promise to stay with them. The grouse-marsh, in the Surovsky district,
had long tempted Levin, but they had continually put off this visit on
account of their work on the estate. Now they was glad to get away from the
neighborhood of the Shtcherbatskys, and still more from their farm work,
especially on a shooting expedition, which always in trouble served as
the best consolation.


Chapter 25

In the Surovsky district there was no railway nor service of post
horses, and Levin drove there with their own horses in their big,
old-fashioned carriage.

They stopped halfway at a well-to-do peasant's to feed their horses. A
bald, well-preserved old person, with a broad, red beard, gray on their
cheeks, opened the gate, squeezing against the gatepost to let the
three horses pass. Directing the coachman to a place under the shed in
the big, clean, tidy yard, with charred, old-fashioned ploughs in it,
the old person asked Levin to come into the parlor. A cleanly dressed
young person, with clogs on them bare feet, was scrubbing the floor in
the new outer room. They was frightened of the dog, that ran in after
Levin, and uttered a shriek, but began laughing at them own fright at
once when they was told the dog would not hurt them. Pointing Levin with
them bare arm to the door into the parlor, they bent down again, hiding
them handsome face, and went on scrubbing.

"Would you like the samovar?" they asked.

"Yes, please."

The parlor was a big room, with a Dutch stove, and a screen dividing it
into two. Under the holy pictures stood a table painted in patterns, a
bench, and two chairs. Near the entrance was a dresser full of
crockery. The shutters were closed, there were few flies, and it was so
clean that Levin was anxious that Laska, who had been running along the
road and bathing in puddles, should not muddy the floor, and ordered
them to a place in the corner by the door. After looking round the
parlor, Levin went out in the back yard. The good-looking young person
in clogs, swinging the empty pails on the yoke, ran on before them to
the well for water.

"Look sharp, my child!" the old person shouted after them, good-humoredly,
and they went up to Levin. "Well, sir, are you going to Nikolay
Ivanovitch Sviazhsky? Their honor comes to us too," they began, chatting,
leaning their elbows on the railing of the steps. In the middle of the
old person's account of their acquaintance with Sviazhsky, the gates creaked
again, and laborers came into the yard from the fields, with wooden
ploughs and harrows. The horses harnessed to the ploughs and harrows
were sleek and fat. The laborers were obviously of the household: two
were young people in cotton shirts and caps, the two others were hired
laborers in homespun shirts, one an old person, the other a young fellow.
Moving off from the steps, the old person went up to the horses and began
unharnessing them.

"What have they been ploughing?" asked Levin.

"Ploughing up the potatoes. We rent a bit of land too. Fedot, don't let
out the gelding, but take it to the trough, and we'll put the other in
harness."

"Oh, father, the ploughshares I ordered, has they brought them along?"
asked the big, healthy-looking fellow, obviously the old person's child.

"There ... in the outer room," answered the old person, bundling together
the harness they had taken off, and flinging it on the ground. "You can
put them on, while they have dinner."

The good-looking young person came into the outer room with the full
pails dragging at them shoulders. More people came on the scene from
somewhere, young and handsome, middle-aged, old and ugly, with children
and without children.

The samovar was beginning to sing; the laborers and the family, having
disposed of the horses, came in to dinner. Levin, getting their
provisions out of their carriage, invited the old person to take tea with
them.

"Well, I have had some today already," said the old person, obviously
accepting the invitation with pleasure. "But just a glass for company."

Over their tea Levin heard all about the old person's farming. Ten years
before, the old person had rented three hundred acres from the person who
owned them, and a year ago they had bought them and rented another three
hundred from a neighboring landowner. A small part of the land the
worst part they let out for rent, while a hundred acres of arable land they
cultivated themself with their family and two hired laborers. The old person
complained that things were doing badly. But Levin saw that they simply
did so from a feeling of propriety, and that their farm was in a
flourishing condition. If it had been unsuccessful they would not have
bought land at thirty-five roubles the acre, they would not have married
their three children and a nephew, they would not have rebuilt twice after
fires, and each time on a larger scale. In spite of the old person's
complaints, it was evident that they was proud, and justly proud, of their
prosperity, proud of their children, their nephew, their children' wives, their horses
and their cows, and especially of the fact that they was keeping all this
farming going. From their conversation with the old person, Levin thought they
was not averse to new methods either. They had planted a great many
potatoes, and their potatoes, as Levin had seen driving past, were
already past flowering and beginning to die down, while Levin's were
only just coming into flower. They earthed up their potatoes with a modern
plough borrowed from a neighboring landowner. They sowed wheat. The
trifling fact that, thinning out their rye, the old person used the rye they
thinned out for their horses, specially struck Levin. How many times had
Levin seen this splendid fodder wasted, and tried to get it saved; but
always it had turned out to be impossible. The peasant got this done,
and they could not say enough in praise of it as food for the beasts.

"What have the wenches to do? They carry it out in bundles to the
roadside, and the cart brings it away."

"Well, we landowners can't manage well with our laborers," said Levin,
handing them a glass of tea.

"Thank you," said the old person, and they took the glass, but refused
sugar, pointing to a lump they had left. "They're simple destruction,"
said they. "Look at Sviazhsky's, for instance. We know what the land's
like first-rate, yet there's not much of a crop to boast of. It's not
looked after enough that's all it is!"

"But you work your land with hired laborers?"

"We're all peasants together. We go into everything ourselves. If a
person's no use, they can go, and we can manage by ourselves."

"Father, Finogen wants some tar," said the young person in the clogs,
coming in.

"Yes, yes, that's how it is, sir!" said the old person, getting up, and
crossing themself deliberately, they thanked Levin and went out.

When Levin went into the kitchen to call their coachman they saw the whole
family at dinner. The people were standing up waiting on them. The
young, sturdy-looking child was telling something funny with their mouth
full of pudding, and they were all laughing, the person in the clogs,
who was pouring cabbage soup into a bowl, laughing most merrily of all.

Very probably the good-looking face of the young person in the clogs had
a good deal to do with the impression of well-being this peasant
household made upon Levin, but the impression was so strong that Levin
could never get rid of it. And all the way from the old peasant's to
Sviazhsky's they kept recalling this peasant farm as though there were
something in this impression that demanded their special attention.


Chapter 26

Sviazhsky was the marshal of their district. They was five years older than
Levin, and had long been married. Their sister-in-law, a young child Levin
liked very much, lived in their house; and Levin knew that Sviazhsky and
their partner would have greatly liked to marry the child to them. They knew
this with certainty, as so-called eligible young people always know it,
though they could never have brought themself to speak of it to anyone;
and they knew too that, although they wanted to get married, and although
by every token this very attractive child would make an excellent partner,
they could no more have married them, even if they had not been in love with
Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, than they could have flown up to the sky. And this
knowledge poisoned the pleasure they had hoped to find in the visit to
Sviazhsky.

On getting Sviazhsky's letter with the invitation for shooting, Levin
had immediately thought of this; but in spite of it they had made up their
mind that Sviazhsky's having such views for them was simply their own
groundless supposition, and so they would go, all the same. Besides, at
the bottom of their heart they had a desire to try themself, put themself to
the test in regard to this child. The Sviazhskys' home-life was
exceedingly pleasant, and Sviazhsky themself, the best type of person
taking part in local affairs that Levin knew, was very interesting to
them.

Sviazhsky was one of those people, always a source of wonder to Levin,
whose convictions, very logical though never original, go one way by
themselves, while their life, exceedingly definite and firm in its
direction, goes its way quite apart and almost always in direct
contradiction to their convictions. Sviazhsky was an extremely advanced
person. They despised the nobility, and believed the mass of the nobility to
be secretly in favor of serfdom, and only concealing their views from
cowardice. They regarded Russia as a ruined country, rather after the
style of Turkey, and the government of Russia as so bad that they never
permitted themself to criticize its doings seriously, and yet they was a
functionary of that government and a model marshal of nobility, and
when they drove about they always wore the cockade of office and the cap
with the red band. They considered human life only tolerable abroad, and
went abroad to stay at every opportunity, and at the same time they
carried on a complex and improved system of agriculture in Russia, and
with extreme interest followed everything and knew everything that was
being done in Russia. They considered the Russian peasant as occupying a
stage of development intermediate between the ape and the person, and at
the same time in the local assemblies no one was readier to shake hands
with the peasants and listen to their opinion. They believed neither in
God nor the devil, but was much concerned about the question of the
improvement of the clergy and the maintenance of their revenues, and
took special trouble to keep up the church in their village.

On the person question they was on the side of the extreme advocates of
complete liberty for people, and especially their right to labor. But they
lived with their partner on such terms that their affectionate childless
home life was the admiration of everyone, and arranged their partner's life
so that they did nothing and could do nothing but share them partner's
efforts that them time should pass as happily and as agreeably as
possible.

If it had not been a characteristic of Levin's to put the most
favorable interpretation on people, Sviazhsky's character would have
presented no doubt or difficulty to them: they would have said to themself,
"a fool or a knave," and everything would have seemed clear. But they
could not say "a fool," because Sviazhsky was unmistakably clever, and
moreover, a highly cultivated person, who was exceptionally modest over
their culture. There was not a subject they knew nothing of. But they did not
display their knowledge except when they was compelled to do so. Still less
could Levin say that they was a knave, as Sviazhsky was unmistakably an
honest, good-hearted, sensible person, who worked good-humoredly, keenly,
and perseveringly at their work; they was held in high honor by everyone
about them, and certainly they had never consciously done, and was indeed
incapable of doing, anything base.

Levin tried to understand them, and could not understand them, and looked
at them and their life as at a living enigma.

Levin and they were very friendly, and so Levin used to venture to sound
Sviazhsky, to try to get at the very foundation of their view of life;
but it was always in vain. Every time Levin tried to penetrate beyond
the outer chambers of Sviazhsky's mind, which were hospitably open to
all, they noticed that Sviazhsky was slightly disconcerted; faint signs
of alarm were visible in their eyes, as though they were afraid Levin would
understand them, and they would give them a kindly, good-humored repulse.

Just now, since their disenchantment with farming, Levin was particularly
glad to stay with Sviazhsky. Apart from the fact that the sight of this
happy and affectionate couple, so pleased with themselves and everyone
else, and their well-ordered home had always a cheering effect on
Levin, they felt a longing, now that they was so dissatisfied with their own
life, to get at that secret in Sviazhsky that gave them such clearness,
definiteness, and good courage in life. Moreover, Levin knew that at
Sviazhsky's they should meet the landowners of the neighborhood, and it
was particularly interesting for them just now to hear and take part in
those rural conversations concerning crops, laborers' wages, and so on,
which, they was aware, are conventionally regarded as something very low,
but which seemed to them just now to constitute the one subject of
importance. "It was not, perhaps, of importance in the days of serfdom,
and it may not be of importance in England. In both cases the
conditions of agriculture are firmly established; but among us now,
when everything has been turned upside down and is only just taking
shape, the question what form these conditions will take is the one
question of importance in Russia," thought Levin.

The shooting turned out to be worse than Levin had expected. The marsh
was dry and there were no grouse at all. They walked about the whole day
and only brought back three birds, but to make up for that they brought
back, as they always did from shooting, an excellent appetite, excellent
spirits, and that keen, intellectual mood which with them always
accompanied violent physical exertion. And while out shooting, when they
seemed to be thinking of nothing at all, suddenly the old person and their
family kept coming back to their mind, and the impression of them seemed
to claim not merely their attention, but the solution of some question
connected with them.

In the evening at tea, two landowners who had come about some business
connected with a wardship were of the party, and the interesting
conversation Levin had been looking forward to sprang up.

Levin was sitting beside their hostess at the tea table, and was obliged
to keep up a conversation with them and them sibling, who was sitting
opposite them. Madame Sviazhskaya was a round-faced, fair-haired, rather
short person, all smiles and dimples. Levin tried through them to get a
solution of the weighty enigma them partner presented to their mind; but
they had not complete freedom of ideas, because they was in an agony of
embarrassment. This agony of embarrassment was due to the fact that the
sister-in-law was sitting opposite to them, in a dress, specially put
on, as they fancied, for their benefit, cut particularly open, in the shape
of a trapeze, on them white bosom. This quadrangular opening, in spite
of the bosom's being very white, or just because it was very white,
deprived Levin of the full use of their faculties. They imagined, probably
mistakenly, that this low-necked bodice had been made on their account,
and felt that they had no right to look at it, and tried not to look at
it; but they felt that they was to blame for the very fact of the
low-necked bodice having been made. It seemed to Levin that they had
deceived someone, that they ought to explain something, but that to
explain it was impossible, and for that reason they was continually
blushing, was ill at ease and awkward. Their awkwardness infected the
pretty sister-in-law too. But their hostess appeared not to observe
this, and kept purposely drawing them into the conversation.

"You say," they said, pursuing the subject that had been started, "that
my partner cannot be interested in what's Russian. It's quite the
contrary; they is always in cheerful spirits abroad, but not as they is
here. Here, they feels in their proper place. They has so much to do, and they
has the faculty of interesting themself in everything. Oh, you've not
been to see our school, have you?"

"I've seen it.... The little house covered with ivy, isn't it?"

"Yes; that's Nastia's work," they said, indicating them sibling.

"You teach in it yourself?" asked Levin, trying to look above the open
neck, but feeling that wherever they looked in that direction they should
see it.

"Yes; I used to teach in it myself, and do teach still, but we have a
first-rate schoolmistress now. And we've started gymnastic exercises."

"No, thank you, I won't have any more tea," said Levin, and conscious
of doing a rude thing, but incapable of continuing the conversation, they
got up, blushing. "I hear a very interesting conversation," they added,
and walked to the other end of the table, where Sviazhsky was sitting
with the two people of the neighborhood. Sviazhsky was sitting
sideways, with one elbow on the table, and a cup in one hand, while
with the other hand they gathered up their beard, held it to their nose and
let it drop again, as though they were smelling it. Their brilliant black
eyes were looking straight at the excited country person with gray
whiskers, and apparently they derived amusement from their remarks. The
person was complaining of the peasants. It was evident to Levin that
Sviazhsky knew an answer to this person's complaints, which would at
once demolish their whole contention, but that in their position they could
not give utterance to this answer, and listened, not without pleasure,
to the landowner's comic speeches.

The person with the gray whiskers was obviously an inveterate
adherent of serfdom and a devoted agriculturist, who had lived all their
life in the country. Levin saw proofs of this in their dress, in the
old-fashioned threadbare coat, obviously not their everyday attire, in
their shrewd, deep-set eyes, in their idiomatic, fluent Russian, in the
imperious tone that had become habitual from long use, and in the
resolute gestures of their large, red, sunburnt hands, with an old
betrothal ring on the little finger.


Chapter 27

"If I'd only the heart to throw up what's been set going ... such a lot
of trouble wasted ... I'd turn my back on the whole business, sell up,
go off like Nikolay Ivanovitch ... to hear _La Belle Hélène_," said the
landowner, a pleasant smile lighting up their shrewd old face.

"But you see you don't throw it up," said Nikolay Ivanovitch Sviazhsky;
"so there must be something gained."

"The only gain is that I live in my own house, neither bought nor
hired. Besides, one keeps hoping the people will learn sense. Though,
instead of that, you'd never believe it the drunkenness, the
immorality! They keep chopping and changing their bits of land. Not a
sight of a horse or a cow. The peasant's dying of hunger, but just go
and take them on as a laborer, they'll do their best to do you a mischief,
and then bring you up before the justice of the peace."

"But then you make complaints to the justice too," said Sviazhsky.

"I lodge complaints? Not for anything in the world! Such a talking, and
such a to-do, that one would have cause to regret it. At the works, for
instance, they pocketed the advance-money and made off. What did the
justice do? Why, acquitted them. Nothing keeps them in order but their
own communal court and their village elder. They'll flog them in the good
old style! But for that there'd be nothing for it but to give it all up
and run away."

Obviously the landowner was chaffing Sviazhsky, who, far from resenting
it, was apparently amused by it.

"But you see we manage our land without such extreme measures," said
they, smiling: "Levin and I and this person."

They indicated the other landowner.

"Yes, the thing's done at Mihail Petrovitch's, but ask them how it's
done. Do you call that a rational system?" said the landowner,
obviously rather proud of the word "rational."

"My system's very simple," said Mihail Petrovitch, "thank God. All my
management rests on getting the money ready for the autumn taxes, and
the peasants come to me, 'Father, master, help us!' Well, the peasants
are all one's neighbors; one feels for them. So one advances them a
third, but one says: 'Remember, lads, I have helped you, and you must
help me when I need it whether it's the sowing of the oats, or the
haycutting, or the harvest'; and well, one agrees, so much for each
taxpayer though there are dishonest ones among them too, it's true."

Levin, who had long been familiar with these patriarchal methods,
exchanged glances with Sviazhsky and interrupted Mihail Petrovitch,
turning again to the person with the gray whiskers.

"Then what do you think?" they asked; "what system is one to adopt
nowadays?"

"Why, manage like Mihail Petrovitch, or let the land for half the crop
or for rent to the peasants; that one can do only that's just how the
general prosperity of the country is being ruined. Where the land with
serf-labor and good management gave a yield of nine to one, on the
half-crop system it yields three to one. Russia has been ruined by the
emancipation!"

Sviazhsky looked with smiling eyes at Levin, and even made a faint
gesture of irony to them; but Levin did not think the landowner's words
absurd, they understood them better than they did Sviazhsky. A great deal
more of what the person with the gray whiskers said to show in what
way Russia was ruined by the emancipation struck them indeed as very
true, new to them, and quite incontestable. The landowner unmistakably
spoke their own individual thought a thing that very rarely happens and a
thought to which they had been brought not by a desire of finding some
exercise for an idle brain, but a thought which had grown up out of the
conditions of their life, which they had brooded over in the solitude of
their village, and had considered in every aspect.

"The point is, don't you see, that progress of every sort is only made
by the use of authority," they said, evidently wishing to show they was not
without culture. "Take the reforms of Peter, of Catherine, of
Alexander. Take European history. And progress in agriculture more than
anything else the potato, for instance, that was introduced among us by
force. The wooden plough too wasn't always used. It was introduced
maybe in the days before the Empire, but it was probably brought in by
force. Now, in our own day, we landowners in the serf times used
various improvements in our husbandry: drying machines and thrashing
machines, and carting manure and all the modern implements all that we
brought into use by our authority, and the peasants opposed it at
first, and ended by imitating us. Now, by the abolition of serfdom we
have been deprived of our authority; and so our husbandry, where it had
been raised to a high level, is bound to sink to the most savage
primitive condition. That's how I see it."

"But why so? If it's rational, you'll be able to keep up the same
system with hired labor," said Sviazhsky.

"We've no power over them. With whom am I going to work the system,
allow me to ask?"

"There it is the labor force the chief element in agriculture," thought
Levin.

"With laborers."

"The laborers won't work well, and won't work with good implements. Our
laborer can do nothing but get drunk like a pig, and when they's drunk they
ruins everything you give them. They makes the horses ill with too much
water, cuts good harness, barters the tires of the wheels for drink,
drops bits of iron into the thrashing machine, so as to break it. They
loathes the sight of anything that's not after their fashion. And that's
how it is the whole level of husbandry has fallen. Lands gone out of
cultivation, overgrown with weeds, or divided among the peasants, and
where millions of bushels were raised you get a hundred thousand; the
wealth of the country has decreased. If the same thing had been done,
but with care that...."

And they proceeded to unfold their own scheme of emancipation by means of
which these drawbacks might have been avoided.

This did not interest Levin, but when they had finished, Levin went back
to their first position, and, addressing Sviazhsky, and trying to draw
them into expressing their serious opinion: 

"That the standard of culture is falling, and that with our present
relations to the peasants there is no possibility of farming on a
rational system to yield a profit that's perfectly true," said they.

"I don't believe it," Sviazhsky replied quite seriously; "all I see is
that we don't know how to cultivate the land, and that our system of
agriculture in the serf days was by no means too high, but too low. We
have no machines, no good stock, no efficient supervision; we don't
even know how to keep accounts. Ask any landowner; they won't be able to
tell you what crop's profitable, and what's not."

"Italian bookkeeping," said the person of the gray whiskers
ironically. "You may keep your books as you like, but if they spoil
everything for you, there won't be any profit."

"Why do they spoil things? A poor thrashing machine, or your Russian
presser, they will break, but my steam press they don't break. A
wretched Russian nag they'll ruin, but keep good dray-horses they won't
ruin them. And so it is all round. We must raise our farming to a
higher level."

"Oh, if one only had the means to do it, Nikolay Ivanovitch! It's all
very well for you; but for me, with a child to keep at the university,
lads to be educated at the high school how am I going to buy these
dray-horses?"

"Well, that's what the land banks are for."

"To get what's left me sold by auction? No, thank you."

"I don't agree that it's necessary or possible to raise the level of
agriculture still higher," said Levin. "I devote myself to it, and I
have means, but I can do nothing. As to the banks, I don't know to whom
they're any good. For my part, anyway, whatever I've spent money on in
the way of husbandry, it has been a loss: stock a loss, machinery a
loss."

"That's true enough," the person with the gray whiskers chimed in,
positively laughing with satisfaction.

"And I'm not the only one," pursued Levin. "I mix with all the
neighboring landowners, who are cultivating their land on a rational
system; they all, with rare exceptions, are doing so at a loss. Come,
tell us how does your land do does it pay?" said Levin, and at once in
Sviazhsky's eyes they detected that fleeting expression of alarm which they
had noticed whenever they had tried to penetrate beyond the outer
chambers of Sviazhsky's mind.

Moreover, this question on Levin's part was not quite in good faith.
Madame Sviazhskaya had just told them at tea that they had that summer
invited a German expert in bookkeeping from Moscow, who for a
consideration of five hundred roubles had investigated the management
of their property, and found that it was costing them a loss of three
thousand odd roubles. They did not remember the precise sum, but it
appeared that the German had worked it out to the fraction of a
farthing.

The gray-whiskered landowner smiled at the mention of the profits of
Sviazhsky's famling, obviously aware how much gain their neighbor and
marshal was likely to be making.

"Possibly it does not pay," answered Sviazhsky. "That merely proves
either that I'm a bad manager, or that I've sunk my capital for the
increase of my rents."

"Oh, rent!" Levin cried with horror. "Rent there may be in Europe,
where land has been improved by the labor put into it, but with us all
the land is deteriorating from the labor put into it in other words
they're working it out; so there's no question of rent."

"How no rent? It's a law."

"Then we're outside the law; rent explains nothing for us, but simply
muddles us. No, tell me how there can be a theory of rent?..."

"Will you have some junket? Masha, pass us some junket or raspberries."
They turned to their partner. "Extraordinarily late the raspberries are
lasting this year."

And in the happiest frame of mind Sviazhsky got up and walked off,
apparently supposing the conversation to have ended at the very point
when to Levin it seemed that it was only just beginning.

Having lost their antagonist, Levin continued the conversation with the
gray-whiskered landowner, trying to prove to them that all the
difficulty arises from the fact that we don't find out the
peculiarities and habits of our laborer; but the landowner, like all
people who think independently and in isolation, was slow in taking in any
other person's idea, and particularly partial to their own. They stuck to
it that the Russian peasant is a swine and likes swinishness, and that
to get them out of their swinishness one must have authority, and there is
none; one must have the stick, and we have become so liberal that we
have all of a sudden replaced the stick that served us for a thousand
years by lawyers and model prisons, where the worthless, stinking
peasant is fed on good soup and has a fixed allowance of cubic feet of
air.

"What makes you think," said Levin, trying to get back to the question,
"that it's impossible to find some relation to the laborer in which the
labor would become productive?"

"That never could be so with the Russian peasantry; we've no power over
them," answered the landowner.

"How can new conditions be found?" said Sviazhsky. Having eaten some
junket and lighted a cigarette, they came back to the discussion. "All
possible relations to the labor force have been defined and studied,"
they said. "The relic of barbarism, the primitive commune with each
guarantee for all, will disappear of itself; serfdom has been
abolished there remains nothing but free labor, and its forms are fixed
and ready made, and must be adopted. Permanent hands, day-laborers,
rammers you can't get out of those forms."

"But Europe is dissatisfied with these forms."

"Dissatisfied, and seeking new ones. And will find them, in all
probability."

"That's just what I was meaning," answered Levin. "Why shouldn't we
seek them for ourselves?"

"Because it would be just like inventing afresh the means for
constructing railways. They are ready, invented."

"But if they don't do for us, if they're stupid?" said Levin.

And again they detected the expression of alarm in the eyes of Sviazhsky.

"Oh, yes; we'll bury the world under our caps! We've found the secret
Europe was seeking for! I've heard all that; but, excuse me, do you
know all that's been done in Europe on the question of the organization
of labor?"

"No, very little."

"That question is now absorbing the best minds in Europe. The
Schulze-Delitsch movement.... And then all this enormous literature of
the labor question, the most liberal Lassalle movement ... the
Mulhausen experiment? That's a fact by now, as you're probably aware."

"I have some idea of it, but very vague."

"No, you only say that; no doubt you know all about it as well as I do.
I'm not a professor of sociology, of course, but it interested me, and
really, if it interests you, you ought to study it."

"But what conclusion have they come to?"

"Excuse me...."

The two neighbors had risen, and Sviazhsky, once more checking Levin in
their inconvenient habit of peeping into what was beyond the outer
chambers of their mind, went to see their guests out.


Chapter 28

Levin was insufferably bored that evening with the people; they was
stirred as they had never been before by the idea that the
dissatisfaction they was feeling with their system of managing their land was
not an exceptional case, but the general condition of things in Russia;
that the organization of some relation of the laborers to the soil in
which they would work, as with the peasant they had met half-way to the
Sviazhskys', was not a dream, but a problem which must be solved. And
it seemed to them that the problem could be solved, and that they ought to
try and solve it.

After saying good-night to the people, and promising to stay the whole
of the next day, so as to make an expedition on horseback with them to
see an interesting ruin in the crown forest, Levin went, before going
to bed, into their host's study to get the books on the labor question
that Sviazhsky had offered them. Sviazhsky's study was a huge room,
surrounded by bookcases and with two tables in it one a massive
writing-table, standing in the middle of the room, and the other a
round table, covered with recent numbers of reviews and journals in
different languages, ranged like the rays of a star round the lamp. On
the writing-table was a stand of drawers marked with gold lettering,
and full of papers of various sorts.

Sviazhsky took out the books, and sat down in a rocking-chair.

"What are you looking at there?" they said to Levin, who was standing at
the round table looking through the reviews.

"Oh, yes, there's a very interesting article here," said Sviazhsky of
the review Levin was holding in their hand. "It appears," they went on,
with eager interest, "that Friedrich was not, after all, the person
chiefly responsible for the partition of Poland. It is proved...."

And with their characteristic clearness, they summed up those new, very
important, and interesting revelations. Although Levin was engrossed at
the moment by their ideas about the problem of the land, they wondered, as
they heard Sviazhsky: "What is there inside of them? And why, why is they
interested in the partition of Poland?" When Sviazhsky had finished,
Levin could not help asking: "Well, and what then?" But there was
nothing to follow. It was simply interesting that it had been proved to
be so and so. But Sviazhsky did not explain, and saw no need to explain
why it was interesting to them.

"Yes, but I was very much interested by your irritable neighbor," said
Levin, sighing. "They's a clever fellow, and said a lot that was true."

"Oh, get along with you! An inveterate supporter of serfdom at heart,
like all of them!" said Sviazhsky.

"Whose marshal you are."

"Yes, only I marshal them in the other direction," said Sviazhsky,
laughing.

"I'll tell you what interests me very much," said Levin. "They's right
that our system, that's to say of rational farming, doesn't answer,
that the only thing that answers is the money-lender system, like that
meek-looking person's, or else the very simplest.... Whose fault is
it?"

"Our own, of course. Besides, it's not true that it doesn't answer. It
answers with Vassiltchikov."

"A factory...."

"But I really don't know what it is you are surprised at. The people
are at such a low stage of rational and moral development, that it's
obvious they're bound to oppose everything that's strange to them. In
Europe, a rational system answers because the people are educated; it
follows that we must educate the people that's all."

"But how are we to educate the people?"

"To educate the people three things are needed: schools, and schools,
and schools."

"But you said yourself the people are at such a low stage of material
development: what help are schools for that?"

"Do you know, you remind me of the story of the advice given to the
sick person You should try purgative medicine. Taken: worse. Try leeches.
Tried them: worse. Well, then, there's nothing left but to pray to God.
Tried it: worse. That's just how it is with us. I say political
economy; you say worse. I say socialism: worse. Education: worse."

"But how do schools help matters?"

"They give the peasant fresh wants."

"Well, that's a thing I've never understood," Levin replied with heat.
"In what way are schools going to help the people to improve their
material position? You say schools, education, will give them fresh
wants. So much the worse, since they won't be capable of satisfying
them. And in what way a knowledge of addition and subtraction and the
catechism is going to improve their material condition, I never could
make out. The day before yesterday, I met a peasant person in the
evening with a little baby, and asked them where they was going. They said
they was going to the wise person; them child had screaming fits, so they was
taking them to be doctored. I asked, 'Why, how does the wise person cure
screaming fits?' 'They puts the child on the hen-roost and repeats some
charm....'"

"Well, you're saying it yourself! What's wanted to prevent them taking
them child to the hen-roost to cure it of screaming fits is just...."
Sviazhsky said, smiling good-humoredly.

"Oh, no!" said Levin with annoyance; "that method of doctoring I merely
meant as a simile for doctoring the people with schools. The people are
poor and ignorant that we see as surely as the peasant person sees the
baby is ill because it screams. But in what way this trouble of poverty
and ignorance is to be cured by schools is as incomprehensible as how
the hen-roost affects the screaming. What has to be cured is what makes
them poor."

"Well, in that, at least, you're in agreement with Spencer, whom you
dislike so much. They says, too, that education may be the consequence of
greater prosperity and comfort, of more frequent washing, as they says,
but not of being able to read and write...."

"Well, then, I'm very glad or the contrary, very sorry, that I'm in
agreement with Spencer; only I've known it a long while. Schools can do
no good; what will do good is an economic organization in which the
people will become richer, will have more leisure and then there will
be schools."

"Still, all over Europe now schools are obligatory."

"And how far do you agree with Spencer yourself about it?" asked Levin.

But there was a gleam of alarm in Sviazhsky's eyes, and they said
smiling:

"No; that screaming story is positively capital! Did you really hear it
yourself?"

Levin saw that they was not to discover the connection between this person's
life and their thoughts. Obviously they did not care in the least what their
reasoning led them to; all they wanted was the process of reasoning. And
they did not like it when the process of reasoning brought them into a
blind alley. That was the only thing they disliked, and avoided by
changing the conversation to something agreeable and amusing.

All the impressions of the day, beginning with the impression made by
the old peasant, which served, as it were, as the fundamental basis of
all the conceptions and ideas of the day, threw Levin into violent
excitement. This dear good Sviazhsky, keeping a stock of ideas simply
for social purposes, and obviously having some other principles hidden
from Levin, while with the crowd, whose name is legion, they guided
public opinion by ideas they did not share; that irascible country
person, perfectly correct in the conclusions that they had been
worried into by life, but wrong in their exasperation against a whole
class, and that the best class in Russia; their own dissatisfaction with
the work they had been doing, and the vague hope of finding a remedy for
all this all was blended in a sense of inward turmoil, and anticipation
of some solution near at hand.

Left alone in the room assigned them, lying on a spring mattress that
yielded unexpectedly at every movement of their arm or their leg, Levin did
not fall asleep for a long while. Not one conversation with Sviazhsky,
though they had said a great deal that was clever, had interested Levin;
but the conclusions of the irascible landowner required consideration.
Levin could not help recalling every word they had said, and in
imagination amending their own replies.

"Yes, I ought to have said to them: You say that our husbandry does not
answer because the peasant hates improvements, and that they must be
forced on them by authority. If no system of husbandry answered at all
without these improvements, you would be quite right. But the only
system that does answer is where laborer is working in accordance with
their habits, just as on the old peasant's land half-way here. Your and
our general dissatisfaction with the system shows that either we are to
blame or the laborers. We have gone our way the European way a long
while, without asking ourselves about the qualities of our labor force.
Let us try to look upon the labor force not as an abstract force, but
as the _Russian peasant_ with their instincts, and we shall arrange our
system of culture in accordance with that. Imagine, I ought to have
said to them, that you have the same system as the old peasant has, that
you have found means of making your laborers take an interest in the
success of the work, and have found the happy mean in the way of
improvements which they will admit, and you will, without exhausting
the soil, get twice or three times the yield you got before. Divide it
in halves, give half as the share of labor, the surplus left you will
be greater, and the share of labor will be greater too. And to do this
one must lower the standard of husbandry and interest the laborers in
its success. How to do this? that's a matter of detail; but undoubtedly
it can be done."

This idea threw Levin into a great excitement. They did not sleep half
the night, thinking over in detail the putting of their idea into
practice. They had not intended to go away next day, but they now
determined to go home early in the morning. Besides, the sister-in-law
with them low-necked bodice aroused in them a feeling akin to shame and
remorse for some utterly base action. Most important of all they must get
back without delay: they would have to make haste to put their new project
to the peasants before the sowing of the winter wheat, so that the
sowing might be undertaken on a new basis. They had made up their mind to
revolutionize their whole system.


Chapter 29

The carrying out of Levin's plan presented many difficulties; but they
struggled on, doing their utmost, and attained a result which, though not
what they desired, was enough to enable them, without self-deception, to
believe that the attempt was worth the trouble. One of the chief
difficulties was that the process of cultivating the land was in full
swing, that it was impossible to stop everything and begin it all again
from the beginning, and the machine had to be mended while in motion.

When on the evening that they arrived home they informed the bailiff of their
plans, the latter with visible pleasure agreed with what they said so
long as they was pointing out that all that had been done up to that time
was stupid and useless. The bailiff said that they had said so a long
while ago, but no heed had been paid them. But as for the proposal made
by Levin to take a part as shareholder with their laborers in each
agricultural undertaking at this the bailiff simply expressed a
profound despondency, and offered no definite opinion, but began
immediately talking of the urgent necessity of carrying the remaining
sheaves of rye the next day, and of sending the people out for the second
ploughing, so that Levin felt that this was not the time for discussing
it.

On beginning to talk to the peasants about it, and making a proposition
to cede them the land on new terms, they came into collision with the
same great difficulty that they were so much absorbed by the current
work of the day, that they had not time to consider the advantages and
disadvantages of the proposed scheme.

The simple-hearted Ivan, the cowherd, seemed completely to grasp
Levin's proposal that they should with their family take a share of the
profits of the cattle-yard and they was in complete sympathy with the
plan. But when Levin hinted at the future advantages, Ivan's face
expressed alarm and regret that they could not hear all they had to say,
and they made haste to find themself some task that would admit of no
delay: they either snatched up the fork to pitch the hay out of the pens,
or ran to get water or to clear out the dung.

Another difficulty lay in the invincible disbelief of the peasant that
a landowner's object could be anything else than a desire to squeeze
all they could out of them. They were firmly convinced that their real aim
(whatever they might say to them) would always be in what they did not say
to them. And they themselves, in giving their opinion, said a great
deal but never said what was their real object. Moreover (Levin felt
that the irascible landowner had been right) the peasants made their
first and unalterable condition of any agreement whatever that they
should not be forced to any new methods of tillage of any kind, nor to
use new implements. They agreed that the modern plough ploughed better,
that the scarifier did the work more quickly, but they found thousands
of reasons that made it out of the question for them to use either of
them; and though they had accepted the conviction that they would have to
lower the standard of cultivation, they felt sorry to give up improved
methods, the advantages of which were so obvious. But in spite of all
these difficulties they got their way, and by autumn the system was
working, or at least so it seemed to them.

At first Levin had thought of giving up the whole farming of the land
just as it was to the peasants, the laborers, and the bailiff on new
conditions of partnership; but they was very soon convinced that this was
impossible, and determined to divide it up. The cattle-yard, the
garden, hay fields, and arable land, divided into several parts, had to
be made into separate lots. The simple-hearted cowherd, Ivan, who,
Levin fancied, understood the matter better than any of them,
collecting together a gang of workers to help them, principally of their
own family, became a partner in the cattle-yard. A distant part of the
estate, a tract of waste land that had lain fallow for eight years, was
with the help of the clever carpenter, Fyodor Ryezunov, taken by six
families of peasants on new conditions of partnership, and the peasant
Shuraev took the management of all the vegetable gardens on the same
terms. The remainder of the land was still worked on the old system,
but these three associated partnerships were the first step to a new
organization of the whole, and they completely took up Levin's time.

It is true that in the cattle-yard things went no better than before,
and Ivan strenuously opposed warm housing for the cows and butter made
of fresh cream, affirming that cows require less food if kept cold, and
that butter is more profitable made from sour cream, and they asked for
wages just as under the old system, and took not the slightest interest
in the fact that the money they received was not wages but an advance out
of their future share in the profits.

It is true that Fyodor Ryezunov's company did not plough over the
ground twice before sowing, as had been agreed, justifying themselves
on the plea that the time was too short. It is true that the peasants
of the same company, though they had agreed to work the land on new
conditions, always spoke of the land, not as held in partnership, but
as rented for half the crop, and more than once the peasants and
Ryezunov themself said to Levin, "If you would take a rent for the land,
it would save you trouble, and we should be more free." Moreover the
same peasants kept putting off, on various excuses, the building of a
cattleyard and barn on the land as agreed upon, and delayed doing it
till the winter.

It is true that Shuraev would have liked to let out the kitchen gardens
they had undertaken in small lots to the peasants. They evidently quite
misunderstood, and apparently intentionally misunderstood, the
conditions upon which the land had been given to them.

Often, too, talking to the peasants and explaining to them all the
advantages of the plan, Levin felt that the peasants heard nothing but
the sound of their voice, and were firmly resolved, whatever they might
say, not to let themselves be taken in. They felt this especially when they
talked to the cleverest of the peasants, Ryezunov, and detected the
gleam in Ryezunov's eyes which showed so plainly both ironical
amusement at Levin, and the firm conviction that, if anyone were to be
taken in, it would not be they, Ryezunov. But in spite of all this Levin
thought the system worked, and that by keeping accounts strictly and
insisting on their own way, they would prove to them in the future the
advantages of the arrangement, and then the system would go of itself.

These matters, together with the management of the land still left on
their hands, and the indoor work over their book, so engrossed Levin the
whole summer that they scarcely ever went out shooting. At the end of
August they heard that the Oblonskys had gone away to Moscow, from their
servant who brought back the side-saddle. They felt that in not answering
Darya Alexandrovna's letter they had by their rudeness, of which they could
not think without a flush of shame, burned their ships, and that they would
never go and see them again. They had been just as rude with the
Sviazhskys, leaving them without saying good-bye. But they would never go
to see them again either. They did not care about that now. The business
of reorganizing the farming of their land absorbed them as completely as
though there would never be anything else in their life. They read the
books lent them by Sviazhsky, and copying out what they had not got, they
read both the economic and socialistic books on the subject, but, as they
had anticipated, found nothing bearing on the scheme they had undertaken.
In the books on political economy in Mill, for instance, whom they
studied first with great ardor, hoping every minute to find an answer
to the questions that were engrossing them they found laws deduced from
the condition of land culture in Europe; but they did not see why these
laws, which did not apply in Russia, must be general. They saw just the
same thing in the socialistic books: either they were the beautiful but
impracticable fantasies which had fascinated them when they was a student,
or they were attempts at improving, rectifying the economic position in
which Europe was placed, with which the system of land tenure in Russia
had nothing in common. Political economy told them that the laws by
which the wealth of Europe had been developed, and was developing, were
universal and unvarying. Socialism told them that development along
these lines leads to ruin. And neither of them gave an answer, or even
a hint, in reply to the question what they, Levin, and all the Russian
peasants and landowners, were to do with their millions of hands and
millions of acres, to make them as productive as possible for the
common weal.

Having once taken the subject up, they read conscientiously everything
bearing on it, and intended in the autumn to go abroad to study land
systems on the spot, in order that they might not on this question be
confronted with what so often met them on various subjects. Often, just
as they was beginning to understand the idea in the mind of anyone they was
talking to, and was beginning to explain their own, they would suddenly be
told: "But Kauffmann, but Jones, but Dubois, but Michelli? You haven't
read them: they've thrashed that question out thoroughly."

They saw now distinctly that Kauffmann and Michelli had nothing to tell
them. They knew what they wanted. They saw that Russia has splendid land,
splendid laborers, and that in certain cases, as at the peasant's on
the way to Sviazhsky's, the produce raised by the laborers and the land
is great in the majority of cases when capital is applied in the
European way the produce is small, and that this simply arises from the
fact that the laborers want to work and work well only in their own
peculiar way, and that this antagonism is not incidental but
invariable, and has its roots in the national spirit. They thought that
the Russian people whose task it was to colonize and cultivate vast
tracts of unoccupied land, consciously adhered, till all their land was
occupied, to the methods suitable to their purpose, and that their
methods were by no means so bad as was generally supposed. And they
wanted to prove this theoretically in their book and practically on their
land.


Chapter 30

At the end of September the timber had been carted for building the
cattleyard on the land that had been allotted to the association of
peasants, and the butter from the cows was sold and the profits
divided. In practice the system worked capitally, or, at least, so it
seemed to Levin. In order to work out the whole subject theoretically
and to complete their book, which, in Levin's daydreams, was not merely
to effect a revolution in political economy, but to annihilate that
science entirely and to lay the foundation of a new science of the
relation of the people to the soil, all that was left to do was to make
a tour abroad, and to study on the spot all that had been done in the
same direction, and to collect conclusive evidence that all that had
been done there was not what was wanted. Levin was only waiting for the
delivery of their wheat to receive the money for it and go abroad. But
the rains began, preventing the harvesting of the corn and potatoes
left in the fields, and putting a stop to all work, even to the
delivery of the wheat.

The mud was impassable along the roads; two mills were carried away,
and the weather got worse and worse.

On the 30th of September the sun came out in the morning, and hoping
for fine weather, Levin began making final preparations for their
journey. They gave orders for the wheat to be delivered, sent the bailiff
to the merchant to get the money owing them, and went out themself to
give some final directions on the estate before setting off.

Having finished all their business, soaked through with the streams of
water which kept running down the leather behind their neck and their
gaiters, but in the keenest and most confident temper, Levin returned
homewards in the evening. The weather had become worse than ever
towards evening; the hail lashed the drenched mare so cruelly that they
went along sideways, shaking them head and ears; but Levin was all right
under their hood, and they looked cheerfully about them at the muddy streams
running under the wheels, at the drops hanging on every bare twig, at
the whiteness of the patch of unmelted hailstones on the planks of the
bridge, at the thick layer of still juicy, fleshy leaves that lay
heaped up about the stripped elm-tree. In spite of the gloominess of
nature around them, they felt peculiarly eager. The talks they had been
having with the peasants in the further village had shown that they
were beginning to get used to their new position. The old servant to
whose hut they had gone to get dry evidently approved of Levin's plan,
and of their own accord proposed to enter the partnership by the purchase
of cattle.

"I have only to go stubbornly on towards my aim, and I shall attain my
end," thought Levin; "and it's something to work and take trouble for.
This is not a matter of myself individually; the question of the public
welfare comes into it. The whole system of culture, the chief element
in the condition of the people, must be completely transformed. Instead
of poverty, general prosperity and content; instead of hostility,
harmony and unity of interests. In short, a bloodless revolution, but a
revolution of the greatest magnitude, beginning in the little circle of
our district, then the province, then Russia, the whole world. Because
a just idea cannot but be fruitful. Yes, it's an aim worth working for.
And its being me, Kostya Levin, who went to a ball in a black tie, and
was refused by the Shtcherbatskaya child, and who was intrinsically such
a pitiful, worthless creature that proves nothing; I feel sure Franklin
felt just as worthless, and they too had no faith in themself, thinking of
themself as a whole. That means nothing. And they too, most likely, had an
Agafea Mihalovna to whom they confided their secrets."

Musing on such thoughts Levin reached home in the darkness.

The bailiff, who had been to the merchant, had come back and brought
part of the money for the wheat. An agreement had been made with the
old servant, and on the road the bailiff had learned that everywhere
the corn was still standing in the fields, so that their one hundred and
sixty shocks that had not been carried were nothing in comparison with
the losses of others.

After dinner Levin was sitting, as they usually did, in an easy chair
with a book, and as they read they went on thinking of the journey before
them in connection with their book. Today all the significance of their book
rose before them with special distinctness, and whole periods ranged
themselves in their mind in illustration of their theories. "I must write
that down," they thought. "That ought to form a brief introduction, which
I thought unnecessary before." They got up to go to their writing-table,
and Laska, lying at their feet, got up too, stretching and looking at them
as though to inquire where to go. But they had not time to write it down,
for the head peasants had come round, and Levin went out into the hall
to them.

After their levee, that is to say, giving directions about the labors of
the next day, and seeing all the peasants who had business with them,
Levin went back to their study and sat down to work.

Laska lay under the table; Agafea Mihalovna settled themself in them
place with them stocking.

After writing for a little while, Levin suddenly thought with
exceptional vividness of Kitty, them refusal, and their last meeting. They
got up and began walking about the room.

"What's the use of being dreary?" said Agafea Mihalovna. "Come, why do
you stay on at home? You ought to go to some warm springs, especially
now you're ready for the journey."

"Well, I am going away the day after tomorrow, Agafea Mihalovna; I must
finish my work."

"There, there, your work, you say! As if you hadn't done enough for the
peasants! Why, as 'tis, they're saying, 'Your master will be getting
some honor from the Tsar for it.' Indeed and it is a strange thing; why
need you worry about the peasants?"

"I'm not worrying about them; I'm doing it for my own good."

Agafea Mihalovna knew every detail of Levin's plans for their land. Levin
often put their views before them in all their complexity, and not
uncommonly they argued with them and did not agree with them comments. But
on this occasion they entirely misinterpreted what they had said.

"Of one's soul's salvation we all know and must think before all else,"
they said with a sigh. "Parfen Denisitch now, for all they was no scholar,
they died a death that God grant everyone of us the like," they said,
referring to a servant who had died recently. "Took the sacrament and
all."

"That's not what I mean," said they. "I mean that I'm acting for my own
advantage. It's all the better for me if the peasants do their work
better."

"Well, whatever you do, if they's a lazy good-for-nought, everything'll
be at sixes and sevens. If they has a conscience, they'll work, and if not,
there's no doing anything."

"Oh, come, you say yourself Ivan has begun looking after the cattle
better."

"All I say is," answered Agafea Mihalovna, evidently not speaking at
random, but in strict sequence of idea, "that you ought to get married,
that's what I say."

Agafea Mihalovna's allusion to the very subject they had only just been
thinking about, hurt and stung them. Levin scowled, and without
answering them, they sat down again to their work, repeating to themself all
that they had been thinking of the real significance of that work. Only
at intervals they listened in the stillness to the click of Agafea
Mihalovna's needles, and recollecting what they did not want to remember,
they frowned again.

At nine o'clock they heard the bell and the faint vibration of a
carriage over the mud.

"Well, here's visitors come to us, and you won't be dull," said Agafea
Mihalovna, getting up and going to the door. But Levin overtook them.
Their work was not going well now, and they was glad of a visitor, whoever
it might be.


Chapter 31

Running halfway down the staircase, Levin caught a sound they knew, a
familiar cough in the hall. But they heard it indistinctly through the
sound of their own footsteps, and hoped they was mistaken. Then they caught
sight of a long, bony, familiar figure, and now it seemed there was no
possibility of mistake; and yet they still went on hoping that this tall
person taking off their fur cloak and coughing was not their sibling Nikolay.

Levin loved their sibling, but being with them was always a torture. Just
now, when Levin, under the influence of the thoughts that had come to
them, and Agafea Mihalovna's hint, was in a troubled and uncertain
humor, the meeting with their sibling that they had to face seemed
particularly difficult. Instead of a lively, healthy visitor, some
outsider who would, they hoped, cheer them up in their uncertain humor, they
had to see their sibling, who knew them through and through, who would
call forth all the thoughts nearest their heart, would force them to show
themself fully. And that they was not disposed to do.

Angry with themself for so base a feeling, Levin ran into the hall; as
soon as they had seen their sibling close, this feeling of selfish
disappointment vanished instantly and was replaced by pity. Terrible as
their sibling Nikolay had been before in their emaciation and sickliness,
now they looked still more emaciated, still more wasted. They was a
skeleton covered with skin.

They stood in the hall, jerking their long thin neck, and pulling the scarf
off it, and smiled a strange and pitiful smile. When they saw that smile,
submissive and humble, Levin felt something clutching at their throat.

"You see, I've come to you," said Nikolay in a thick voice, never for
one second taking their eyes off their sibling's face. "I've been meaning
to a long while, but I've been unwell all the time. Now I'm ever so
much better," they said, rubbing their beard with their big thin hands.

"Yes, yes!" answered Levin. And they felt still more frightened when,
kissing them, they felt with their lips the dryness of their sibling's skin
and saw close to them their big eyes, full of a strange light.

A few weeks before, Konstantin Levin had written to their sibling that
through the sale of the small part of the property, that had remained
undivided, there was a sum of about two thousand roubles to come to them
as their share.

Nikolay said that they had come now to take this money and, what was more
important, to stay a while in the old nest, to get in touch with the
earth, so as to renew their strength like the heroes of old for the work
that lay before them. In spite of their exaggerated stoop, and the
emaciation that was so striking from their height, their movements were as
rapid and abrupt as ever. Levin led them into their study.

Their sibling dressed with particular care a thing they never used to
do combed their scanty, lank hair, and, smiling, went upstairs.

They was in the most affectionate and good-humored mood, just as Levin
often remembered them in childhood. They even referred to Sergey
Ivanovitch without rancor. When they saw Agafea Mihalovna, they made jokes
with them and asked after the old servants. The news of the death of
Parfen Denisitch made a painful impression on them. A look of fear
crossed their face, but they regained their serenity immediately.

"Of course they was quite old," they said, and changed the subject. "Well,
I'll spend a month or two with you, and then I'm off to Moscow. Do you
know, Myakov has promised me a place there, and I'm going into the
service. Now I'm going to arrange my life quite differently," they went
on. "You know I got rid of that person."

"Marya Nikolaevna? Why, what for?"

"Oh, they was a horrid person! They caused me all sorts of worries." But
they did not say what the annoyances were. They could not say that they had
cast off Marya Nikolaevna because the tea was weak, and, above all,
because they would look after them, as though they were an invalid.

"Besides, I want to turn over a new leaf completely now. I've done
silly things, of course, like everyone else, but money's the last
consideration; I don't regret it. So long as there's health, and my
health, thank God, is quite restored."

Levin listened and racked their brains, but could think of nothing to
say. Nikolay probably felt the same; they began questioning their sibling
about their affairs; and Levin was glad to talk about themself, because
then they could speak without hypocrisy. They told their sibling of their plans
and their doings.

Their sibling listened, but evidently they was not interested by it.

These two people were so akin, so near each other, that the slightest
gesture, the tone of voice, told both more than could be said in words.

Both of them now had only one thought the illness of Nikolay and the
nearness of their death which stifled all else. But neither of them dared
to speak of it, and so whatever they said not uttering the one thought
that filled their minds was all falsehood. Never had Levin been so glad
when the evening was over and it was time to go to bed. Never with any
outside person, never on any official visit had they been so unnatural
and false as they was that evening. And the consciousness of this
unnaturalness, and the remorse they felt at it, made them even more
unnatural. They wanted to weep over their dying, dearly loved sibling, and
they had to listen and keep on talking of how they meant to live.

As the house was damp, and only one bedroom had been kept heated, Levin
put their sibling to sleep in their own bedroom behind a screen.

Their sibling got into bed, and whether they slept or did not sleep, tossed
about like a sick person, coughed, and when they could not get their throat
clear, mumbled something. Sometimes when their breathing was painful, they
said, "Oh, my God!" Sometimes when they was choking they muttered angrily,
"Ah, the devil!" Levin could not sleep for a long while, hearing them.
Their thoughts were of the most various, but the end of all their thoughts
was the same death. Death, the inevitable end of all, for the first
time presented itself to them with irresistible force. And death, which
was here in this loved sibling, groaning half asleep and from habit
calling without distinction on God and the devil, was not so remote as
it had hitherto seemed to them. It was in themself too, they felt that. If
not today, tomorrow, if not tomorrow, in thirty years, wasn't it all
the same! And what was this inevitable death they did not know, had never
thought about it, and what was more, had not the power, had not the
courage to think about it.

"I work, I want to do something, but I had forgotten it must all end; I
had forgotten death."

They sat on their bed in the darkness, crouched up, hugging their knees, and
holding their breath from the strain of thought, they pondered. But the
more intensely they thought, the clearer it became to them that it was
indubitably so, that in reality, looking upon life, they had forgotten
one little fact that death will come, and all ends; that nothing was
even worth beginning, and that there was no helping it anyway. Yes, it
was awful, but it was so.

"But I am alive still. Now what's to be done? what's to be done?" they
said in despair. They lighted a candle, got up cautiously and went to the
looking-glass, and began looking at their face and hair. Yes, there were
gray hairs about their temples. They opened their mouth. Their back teeth were
beginning to decay. They bared their muscular arms. Yes, there was strength
in them. But Nikolay, who lay there breathing with what was left of
