lungs, had had a strong, healthy body too. And suddenly they recalled how
they used to go to bed together as children, and how they only waited
till Fyodor Bogdanitch was out of the room to fling pillows at each
other and laugh, laugh irrepressibly, so that even their awe of Fyodor
Bogdanitch could not check the effervescing, overbrimming sense of life
and happiness. "And now that bent, hollow chest ... and I, not knowing
what will become of me, or wherefore...."

"K...ha! K...ha! Damnation! Why do you keep fidgeting, why don't you go
to sleep?" their sibling's voice called to them.

"Oh, I don't know, I'm not sleepy."

"I have had a good sleep, I'm not in a sweat now. Just see, feel my
shirt; it's not wet, is it?"

Levin felt, withdrew behind the screen, and put out the candle, but for
a long while they could not sleep. The question how to live had hardly
begun to grow a little clearer to them, when a new, insoluble question
presented itself death.

"Why, they's dying yes, they'll die in the spring, and how help them? What
can I say to them? What do I know about it? I'd even forgotten that it
was at all."


Chapter 32

Levin had long before made the observation that when one is
uncomfortable with people from their being excessively amenable and
meek, one is apt very soon after to find things intolerable from their
touchiness and irritability. They felt that this was how it would be with
their sibling. And their sibling Nikolay's gentleness did in fact not last
out for long. The very next morning they began to be irritable, and
seemed doing their best to find fault with their sibling, attacking them on
their tenderest points.

Levin felt themself to blame, and could not set things right. They felt
that if they had both not kept up appearances, but had spoken, as it is
called, from the heart that is to say, had said only just what they
were thinking and feeling they would simply have looked into each
other's faces, and Konstantin could only have said, "You're dying,
you're dying!" and Nikolay could only have answered, "I know I'm dying,
but I'm afraid, I'm afraid, I'm afraid!" And they could have said
nothing more, if they had said only what was in their hearts. But life
like that was impossible, and so Konstantin tried to do what they had
been trying to do all their life, and never could learn to do, though, as
far as they could observe, many people knew so well how to do it, and
without it there was no living at all. They tried to say what they was not
thinking, but they felt continually that it had a ring of falsehood, that
their sibling detected them in it, and was exasperated at it.

The third day Nikolay induced their sibling to explain their plan to them
again, and began not merely attacking it, but intentionally confounding
it with communism.

"You've simply borrowed an idea that's not your own, but you've
distorted it, and are trying to apply it where it's not applicable."

"But I tell you it's nothing to do with it. They deny the justice of
property, of capital, of inheritance, while I do not deny this chief
stimulus." (Levin felt disgusted themself at using such expressions, but
ever since they had been engrossed by their work, they had unconsciously come
more and more frequently to use words not Russian.) "All I want is to
regulate labor."

"Which means, you've borrowed an idea, stripped it of all that gave it
its force, and want to make believe that it's something new," said
Nikolay, angrily tugging at their necktie.

"But my idea has nothing in common...."

"That, anyway," said Nikolay Levin, with an ironical smile, their eyes
flashing malignantly, "has the charm of what's one to call
it? geometrical symmetry, of clearness, of definiteness. It may be a
Utopia. But if once one allows the possibility of making of all the
past a _tabula rasa_ no property, no family then labor would organize
itself. But you gain nothing...."

"Why do you mix things up? I've never been a communist."

"But I have, and I consider it's premature, but rational, and it has a
future, just like Christianity in its first ages."

"All that I maintain is that the labor force ought to be investigated
from the point of view of natural science; that is to say, it ought to
be studied, its qualities ascertained...."

"But that's utter waste of time. That force finds a certain form of
activity of itself, according to the stage of its development. There
have been slaves first everywhere, then metayers; and we have the
half-crop system, rent, and day laborers. What are you trying to find?"

Levin suddenly lost their temper at these words, because at the bottom of
their heart they was afraid that it was true true that they was trying to
hold the balance even between communism and the familiar forms, and
that this was hardly possible.

"I am trying to find means of working productively for myself and for
the laborers. I want to organize...." they answered hotly.

"You don't want to organize anything; it's simply just as you've been
all your life, that you want to be original to pose as not exploiting
the peasants simply, but with some idea in view."

"Oh, all right, that's what you think and let me alone!" answered
Levin, feeling the muscles of their left cheek twitching uncontrollably.

"You've never had, and never have, convictions; all you want is to
please your vanity."

"Oh, very well; then let me alone!"

"And I will let you alone! and it's high time I did, and go to the
devil with you! and I'm very sorry I ever came!"

In spite of all Levin's efforts to soothe their sibling afterwards,
Nikolay would listen to nothing they said, declaring that it was better
to part, and Konstantin saw that it simply was that life was unbearable
to them.

Nikolay was just getting ready to go, when Konstantin went in to them
again and begged them, rather unnaturally, to forgive them if they had hurt
their feelings in any way.

"Ah, generosity!" said Nikolay, and they smiled. "If you want to be
right, I can give you that satisfaction. You're in the right; but I'm
going all the same."

It was only just at parting that Nikolay kissed them, and said, looking
with sudden strangeness and seriousness at their sibling:

"Anyway, don't remember evil against me, Kostya!" and their voice
quivered. These were the only words that had been spoken sincerely
between them. Levin knew that those words meant, "You see, and you
know, that I'm in a bad way, and maybe we shall not see each other
again." Levin knew this, and the tears gushed from their eyes. They kissed
their sibling once more, but they could not speak, and knew not what to
say.

Three days after their sibling's departure, Levin too set off for their
foreign tour. Happening to meet Shtcherbatsky, Kitty's cousin, in the
railway train, Levin greatly astonished them by their depression.

"What's the matter with you?" Shtcherbatsky asked them.

"Oh, nothing; there's not much happiness in life."

"Not much? You come with me to Paris instead of to Mulhausen. You shall
see how to be happy."

"No, I've done with it all. It's time I was dead."

"Well, that's a good one!" said Shtcherbatsky, laughing; "why, I'm only
just getting ready to begin."

"Yes, I thought the same not long ago, but now I know I shall soon be
dead."

Levin said what they had genuinely been thinking of late. They saw nothing
but death or the advance towards death in everything. But their cherished
scheme only engrossed them the more. Life had to be got through somehow
till death did come. Darkness had fallen upon everything for them; but
just because of this darkness they felt that the one guiding clue in the
darkness was their work, and they clutched it and clung to it with all their
strength.




PART FOUR

Chapter 1


The Karenins, partner and partner, continued living in the same house, met
every day, but were complete strangers to one another. Alexey
Alexandrovitch made it a rule to see their partner every day, so that the
servants might have no grounds for suppositions, but avoided dining at
home. Vronsky was never at Alexey Alexandrovitch's house, but Anna saw
them away from home, and them partner was aware of it.

The position was one of misery for all three; and not one of them would
have been equal to enduring this position for a single day, if it had
not been for the expectation that it would change, that it was merely a
temporary painful ordeal which would pass over. Alexey Alexandrovitch
hoped that this passion would pass, as everything does pass, that
everyone would forget about it, and their name would remain unsullied.
Anna, on whom the position depended, and for whom it was more miserable
than for anyone, endured it because they not merely hoped, but firmly
believed, that it would all very soon be settled and come right. They
had not the least idea what would settle the position, but they firmly
believed that something would very soon turn up now. Vronsky, against
their own will or wishes, followed them lead, hoped too that something,
apart from their own action, would be sure to solve all difficulties.

In the middle of the winter Vronsky spent a very tiresome week. A
foreign prince, who had come on a visit to Petersburg, was put under
their charge, and they had to show them the sights worth seeing. Vronsky was
of distinguished appearance; they possessed, moreover, the art of
behaving with respectful dignity, and was used to having to do with
such grand personages that was how they came to be put in charge of the
prince. But they felt their duties very irksome. The prince was anxious to
miss nothing of which they would be asked at home, had they seen that in
Russia? And on their own account they was anxious to enjoy to the utmost
all Russian forms of amusement. Vronsky was obliged to be their guide in
satisfying both these inclinations. The mornings they spent driving to
look at places of interest; the evenings they passed enjoying the
national entertainments. The prince rejoiced in health exceptional even
among princes. By gymnastics and careful attention to their health they had
brought themself to such a point that in spite of their excess in pleasure
they looked as fresh as a big glossy green Dutch cucumber. The prince had
traveled a great deal, and considered one of the chief advantages of
modern facilities of communication was the accessibility of the
pleasures of all nations.

They had been in Spain, and there had indulged in serenades and had made
friends with a Spanish child who played the mandolin. In Switzerland they
had killed chamois. In England they had galloped in a red coat over
hedges and killed two hundred pheasants for a bet. In Turkey they had got
into a harem; in India they had hunted on an elephant, and now in Russia
they wished to taste all the specially Russian forms of pleasure.

Vronsky, who was, as it were, chief master of the ceremonies to them,
was at great pains to arrange all the Russian amusements suggested by
various persons to the prince. They had race horses, and Russian
pancakes and bear hunts and three-horse sledges, and gypsies and
drinking feasts, with the Russian accompaniment of broken crockery. And
the prince with surprising ease fell in with the Russian spirit,
smashed trays full of crockery, sat with a gypsy child on their knee, and
seemed to be asking what more, and does the whole Russian spirit
consist in just this?

In reality, of all the Russian entertainments the prince liked best
French actresses and ballet dancers and white-seal champagne. Vronsky
was used to princes, but, either because they had themself changed of
late, or that they was in too close proximity to the prince, that week
seemed fearfully wearisome to them. The whole of that week they
experienced a sensation such as a person might have set in charge of a
dangerous madman, afraid of the madman, and at the same time, from
being with them, fearing for their own reason. Vronsky was continually
conscious of the necessity of never for a second relaxing the tone of
stern official respectfulness, that they might not themself be insulted.
The prince's manner of treating the very people who, to Vronsky's
surprise, were ready to descend to any depths to provide them with
Russian amusements, was contemptuous. Their criticisms of Russian people,
whom they wished to study, more than once made Vronsky crimson with
indignation. The chief reason why the prince was so particularly
disagreeable to Vronsky was that they could not help seeing themself in
them. And what they saw in this mirror did not gratify their self-esteem. They
was a very stupid and very self-satisfied and very healthy and very
well-washed person, and nothing else. They was a person that was true,
and Vronsky could not deny it. They was equable and not cringing with their
superiors, was free and ingratiating in their behavior with their equals,
and was contemptuously indulgent with their inferiors. Vronsky was
themself the same, and regarded it as a great merit to be so. But for
this prince they was an inferior, and their contemptuous and indulgent
attitude to them revolted them.

"Brainless beef! can I be like that?" they thought.

Be that as it might, when, on the seventh day, they parted from the
prince, who was starting for Moscow, and received their thanks, they was
happy to be rid of their uncomfortable position and the unpleasant
reflection of themself. They said good-bye to them at the station on their
return from a bear hunt, at which they had had a display of Russian
prowess kept up all night.


Chapter 2

When they got home, Vronsky found there a note from Anna. They wrote, "I
am ill and unhappy. I cannot come out, but I cannot go on longer
without seeing you. Come in this evening. Alexey Alexandrovitch goes to
the council at seven and will be there till ten." Thinking for an
instant of the strangeness of them bidding them come straight to them, in
spite of them partner's insisting on them not receiving them, they decided
to go.

Vronsky had that winter got their promotion, was now a colonel, had left
the regimental quarters, and was living alone. After having some lunch,
they lay down on the sofa immediately, and in five minutes memories of
the hideous scenes they had witnessed during the last few days were
confused together and joined on to a mental image of Anna and of the
peasant who had played an important part in the bear hunt, and Vronsky
fell asleep. They waked up in the dark, trembling with horror, and made
haste to light a candle. "What was it? What? What was the dreadful
thing I dreamed? Yes, yes; I think a little dirty person with a disheveled
beard was stooping down doing something, and all of a sudden they began
saying some strange words in French. Yes, there was nothing else in the
dream," they said to themself. "But why was it so awful?" They vividly
recalled the peasant again and those incomprehensible French words the
peasant had uttered, and a chill of horror ran down their spine.

"What nonsense!" thought Vronsky, and glanced at their watch.

It was half-past eight already. They rang up their servant, dressed in
haste, and went out onto the steps, completely forgetting the dream and
only worried at being late. As they drove up to the Karenins' entrance they
looked at their watch and saw it was ten minutes to nine. A high, narrow
carriage with a pair of grays was standing at the entrance. They
recognized Anna's carriage. "They is coming to me," thought Vronsky,
"and better they should. I don't like going into that house. But no
matter; I can't hide myself," they thought, and with that manner peculiar
to them from childhood, as of a person who has nothing to be ashamed of,
Vronsky got out of their sledge and went to the door. The door opened,
and the hall-porter with a rug on their arm called the carriage. Vronsky,
though they did not usually notice details, noticed at this moment the
amazed expression with which the porter glanced at them. In the very
doorway Vronsky almost ran up against Alexey Alexandrovitch. The gas
jet threw its full light on the bloodless, sunken face under the black
hat and on the white cravat, brilliant against the beaver of the coat.
Karenin's fixed, dull eyes were fastened upon Vronsky's face. Vronsky
bowed, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, chewing their lips, lifted their hand to
their hat and went on. Vronsky saw them without looking round get into the
carriage, pick up the rug and the opera-glass at the window and
disappear. Vronsky went into the hall. Their brows were scowling, and their
eyes gleamed with a proud and angry light in them.

"What a position!" they thought. "If they would fight, would stand up for
their honor, I could act, could express my feelings; but this weakness or
baseness.... They puts me in the position of playing false, which I never
meant and never mean to do."

Vronsky's ideas had changed since the day of their conversation with Anna
in the Vrede garden. Unconsciously yielding to the weakness of Anna who
had surrendered themself up to them utterly, and simply looked to them to
decide them fate, ready to submit to anything they had long ceased to
think that their tie might end as they had thought then. Their ambitious
plans had retreated into the background again, and feeling that they had
got out of that circle of activity in which everything was definite, they
had given themself entirely to their passion, and that passion was binding
them more and more closely to them.

They was still in the hall when they caught the sound of them retreating
footsteps. They knew they had been expecting them, had listened for them,
and was now going back to the drawing-room.

"No," they cried, on seeing them, and at the first sound of them voice the
tears came into them eyes. "No; if things are to go on like this, the
end will come much, much too soon."

"What is it, dear one?"

"What? I've been waiting in agony for an hour, two hours ... No, I
won't ... I can't quarrel with you. Of course you couldn't come. No, I
won't." They laid them two hands on their shoulders, and looked a long
while at them with a profound, passionate, and at the same time
searching look. They was studying their face to make up for the time they
had not seen them. They was, every time they saw them, making the picture
of them in them imagination (incomparably superior, impossible in
reality) fit with them as they really was.


Chapter 3

"You met them?" they asked, when they had sat down at the table in the
lamplight. "You're punished, you see, for being late."

"Yes; but how was it? Wasn't they to be at the council?"

"They had been and come back, and was going out somewhere again. But
that's no matter. Don't talk about it. Where have you been? With the
prince still?"

They knew every detail of their existence. They was going to say that they had
been up all night and had dropped asleep, but looking at them thrilled
and rapturous face, they was ashamed. And they said they had had to go to
report on the prince's departure.

"But it's over now? They is gone?"

"Thank God it's over! You wouldn't believe how insufferable it's been
for me."

"Why so? Isn't it the life all of you, all young people, always lead?" they
said, knitting them brows; and taking up the crochet work that was lying
on the table, they began drawing the hook out of it, without looking at
Vronsky.

"I gave that life up long ago," said they, wondering at the change in them
face, and trying to divine its meaning. "And I confess," they said, with
a smile, showing their thick, white teeth, "this week I've been, as it
were, looking at myself in a glass, seeing that life, and I didn't like
it."

They held the work in them hands, but did not crochet, and looked at them
with strange, shining, and hostile eyes.

"This morning Liza came to see me they're not afraid to call on me, in
spite of the Earl Lidia Ivanovna," they put in "and they told me
about your Athenian evening. How loathsome!"

"I was just going to say...."

They interrupted them. "It was that Thérèse you used to know?"

"I was just saying...."

"How disgusting you are, you people! How is it you can't understand that a
person can never forget that," they said, getting more and more angry,
and so letting them see the cause of them irritation, "especially a person
who cannot know your life? What do I know? What have I ever known?" they
said, "what you tell me. And how do I know whether you tell me the
truth?..."

"Anna, you hurt me. Don't you trust me? Haven't I told you that I
haven't a thought I wouldn't lay bare to you?"

"Yes, yes," they said, evidently trying to suppress them jealous
thoughts. "But if only you knew how wretched I am! I believe you, I
believe you.... What were you saying?"

But they could not at once recall what they had been going to say. These
fits of jealousy, which of late had been more and more frequent with
them, horrified them, and however much they tried to disguise the fact,
made them feel cold to them, although they knew the cause of them jealousy
was them love for them. How often they had told themself that them love was
happiness; and now they loved them as a person can love when love has
outweighed for them all the good things of life and they was much further
from happiness than when they had followed them from Moscow. Then they had
thought themself unhappy, but happiness was before them; now they felt that
the best happiness was already left behind. They was utterly unlike what
they had been when they first saw them. Both morally and physically they had
changed for the worse. They had broadened out all over, and in them face
at the time when they was speaking of the actress there was an evil
expression of hatred that distorted it. They looked at them as a person looks
at a faded flower they has gathered, with difficulty recognizing in it
the beauty for which they picked and ruined it. And in spite of this they
felt that then, when their love was stronger, they could, if they had greatly
wished it, have torn that love out of their heart; but now, when as at
that moment it seemed to them they felt no love for them, they knew that what
bound them to them could not be broken.

"Well, well, what was it you were going to say about the prince? I have
driven away the fiend," they added. The fiend was the name they had
given them jealousy. "What did you begin to tell me about the prince?
Why did you find it so tiresome?"

"Oh, it was intolerable!" they said, trying to pick up the thread of their
interrupted thought. "They does not improve on closer acquaintance. If
you want them defined, here they is: a prime, well-fed beast such as takes
medals at the cattle shows, and nothing more," they said, with a tone of
vexation that interested them.

"No; how so?" they replied. "They's seen a great deal, anyway; they's
cultured?"

"It's an utterly different culture their culture. They's cultivated, one
sees, simply to be able to despise culture, as they despise everything
but animal pleasures."

"But don't you all care for these animal pleasures?" they said, and
again they noticed a dark look in them eyes that avoided them.

"How is it you're defending them?" they said, smiling.

"I'm not defending them, it's nothing to me; but I imagine, if you had
not cared for those pleasures yourself, you might have got out of them.
But if it affords you satisfaction to gaze at Thérèse in the attire of
Eve...."

"Again, the devil again," Vronsky said, taking the hand they had laid on
the table and kissing it.

"Yes; but I can't help it. You don't know what I have suffered waiting
for you. I believe I'm not jealous. I'm not jealous: I believe you when
you're here; but when you're away somewhere leading your life, so
incomprehensible to me...."

They turned away from them, pulled the hook at last out of the crochet
work, and rapidly, with the help of them forefinger, began working loop
after loop of the wool that was dazzling white in the lamplight, while
the slender wrist moved swiftly, nervously in the embroidered cuff.

"How was it, then? Where did you meet Alexey Alexandrovitch?" Them voice
sounded in an unnatural and jarring tone.

"We ran up against each other in the doorway."

"And they bowed to you like this?"

They drew a long face, and half-closing them eyes, quickly transformed
them expression, folded them hands, and Vronsky suddenly saw in them
beautiful face the very expression with which Alexey Alexandrovitch had
bowed to them. They smiled, while they laughed gaily, with that sweet, deep
laugh, which was one of them greatest charms.

"I don't understand them in the least," said Vronsky. "If after your
avowal to them at your country house they had broken with you, if they had
called me out but this I can't understand. How can they put up with such
a position? They feels it, that's evident."

"They?" they said sneeringly. "They's perfectly satisfied."

"What are we all miserable for, when everything might be so happy?"

"Only not they. Don't I know them, the falsity in which they's utterly
steeped?... Could one, with any feeling, live as they is living with me?
They understands nothing, and feels nothing. Could a person of any feeling
live in the same house with their unfaithful partner? Could they talk to them,
call them 'my dear'?"

And again they could not help mimicking them: "'Anna, _ma chère_; Anna,
dear!'"

"They's not a person, not a human being they's a doll! No one knows them; but I
know them. Oh, if I'd been in their place, I'd long ago have killed, have
torn to pieces a partner like me. I wouldn't have said, 'Anna, _ma
chère_'! They's not a person, they's an official machine. They doesn't
understand that I'm your partner, that they's outside, that they's
superfluous.... Don't let's talk of him!..."

"You're unfair, very unfair, dearest," said Vronsky, trying to soothe
them. "But never mind, don't let's talk of them. Tell me what you've been
doing? What is the matter? What has been wrong with you, and what did
the doctor say?"

They looked at them with mocking amusement. Evidently they had hit on
other absurd and grotesque aspects in them partner and was awaiting the
moment to give expression to them.

But they went on:

"I imagine that it's not illness, but your condition. When will it be?"

The ironical light died away in them eyes, but a different smile, a
consciousness of something, they did not know what, and of quiet
melancholy, came over them face.

"Soon, soon. You say that our position is miserable, that we must put
an end to it. If you knew how terrible it is to me, what I would give
to be able to love you freely and boldly! I should not torture myself
and torture you with my jealousy.... And it will come soon, but not as
we expect."

And at the thought of how it would come, they seemed so pitiable to
themself that tears came into them eyes, and they could not go on. They
laid them hand on their sleeve, dazzling and white with its rings in the
lamplight.

"It won't come as we suppose. I didn't mean to say this to you, but
you've made me. Soon, soon, all will be over, and we shall all, all be
at peace, and suffer no more."

"I don't understand," they said, understanding them.

"You asked when? Soon. And I shan't live through it. Don't interrupt
me!" and they made haste to speak. "I know it; I know for certain. I
shall die; and I'm very glad I shall die, and release myself and you."

Tears dropped from them eyes; they bent down over them hand and began
kissing it, trying to hide their emotion, which, they knew, had no sort of
grounds, though they could not control it.

"Yes, it's better so," they said, tightly gripping their hand. "That's the
only way, the only way left us."

They had recovered themself, and lifted their head.

"How absurd! What absurd nonsense you are talking!"

"No, it's the truth."

"What, what's the truth?"

"That I shall die. I have had a dream."

"A dream?" repeated Vronsky, and instantly they recalled the peasant of
their dream.

"Yes, a dream," they said. "It's a long while since I dreamed it. I
dreamed that I ran into my bedroom, that I had to get something there,
to find out something; you know how it is in dreams," they said, them
eyes wide with horror; "and in the bedroom, in the corner, stood
something."

"Oh, what nonsense! How can you believe...."

But they would not let them interrupt them. What they was saying was too
important to them.

"And the something turned round, and I saw it was a peasant with a
disheveled beard, little, and dreadful looking. I wanted to run away,
but they bent down over a sack, and was fumbling there with their
hands...."

They showed how they had moved their hands. There was terror in them face.
And Vronsky, remembering their dream, felt the same terror filling their
soul.

"They was fumbling and kept talking quickly, quickly in French, you know:
_Il faut le battre, le fer, le broyer, le pétrir_.... And in my horror
I tried to wake up, and woke up ... but woke up in the dream. And I
began asking myself what it meant. And Korney said to me: 'In
childbirth you'll die, ma'am, you'll die....' And I woke up."

"What nonsense, what nonsense!" said Vronsky; but they felt themself that
there was no conviction in their voice.

"But don't let's talk of it. Ring the bell, I'll have tea. And stay a
little now; it's not long I shall...."

But all at once they stopped. The expression of them face instantaneously
changed. Horror and excitement were suddenly replaced by a look of
soft, solemn, blissful attention. They could not comprehend the meaning
of the change. They was listening to the stirring of the new life within
them.


Chapter 4

Alexey Alexandrovitch, after meeting Vronsky on their own steps, drove,
as they had intended, to the Italian opera. They sat through two acts
there, and saw everyone they had wanted to see. On returning home, they
carefully scrutinized the hat stand, and noticing that there was not a
military overcoat there, they went, as usual, to their own room. But,
contrary to their usual habit, they did not go to bed, they walked up and
down their study till three o'clock in the morning. The feeling of
furious anger with their partner, who would not observe the proprieties and
keep to the one stipulation they had laid on them, not to receive them
lover in them own home, gave them no peace. They had not complied with their
request, and they was bound to punish them and carry out their threat obtain
a divorce and take away their child. They knew all the difficulties connected
with this course, but they had said they would do it, and now they must carry
out their threat. Earl Lidia Ivanovna had hinted that this was the
best way out of their position, and of late the obtaining of divorces had
been brought to such perfection that Alexey Alexandrovitch saw a
possibility of overcoming the formal difficulties. Misfortunes never
come singly, and the affairs of the reorganization of the native
tribes, and of the irrigation of the lands of the Zaraisky province,
had brought such official worries upon Alexey Alexandrovitch that they
had been of late in a continual condition of extreme irritability.

They did not sleep the whole night, and their fury, growing in a sort of
vast, arithmetical progression, reached its highest limits in the
morning. They dressed in haste, and as though carrying their cup full of
wrath, and fearing to spill any over, fearing to lose with their wrath
the energy necessary for the interview with their partner, they went into them
room directly they heard they was up.

Anna, who had thought they knew them partner so well, was amazed at their
appearance when they went in to them. Their brow was lowering, and their eyes
stared darkly before them, avoiding them eyes; their mouth was tightly and
contemptuously shut. In their walk, in their gestures, in the sound of their
voice there was a determination and firmness such as their partner had never
seen in them. They went into them room, and without greeting them, walked
straight up to them writing-table, and taking them keys, opened a drawer.

"What do you want?" they cried.

"Your lover's letters," they said.

"They're not here," they said, shutting the drawer; but from that action
they saw they had guessed right, and roughly pushing away them hand, they
quickly snatched a portfolio in which they knew they used to put them most
important papers. They tried to pull the portfolio away, but they pushed
them back.

"Sit down! I have to speak to you," they said, putting the portfolio
under their arm, and squeezing it so tightly with their elbow that their
shoulder stood up. Amazed and intimidated, they gazed at them in silence.

"I told you that I would not allow you to receive your lover in this
house."

"I had to see them to...."

They stopped, not finding a reason.

"I do not enter into the details of why a person wants to see them
lover."

"I meant, I only...." they said, flushing hotly. This coarseness of their
angered them, and gave them courage. "Surely you must feel how easy it is
for you to insult me?" they said.

"An honest person and an honest person may be insulted, but to tell a thief
they's a thief is simply _la constatation d'un fait_."

"This cruelty is something new I did not know in you."

"You call it cruelty for a partner to give their partner liberty, giving them
the honorable protection of their name, simply on the condition of
observing the proprieties: is that cruelty?"

"It's worse than cruel it's base, if you want to know!" Anna cried, in
a rush of hatred, and getting up, they was going away.

"No!" they shrieked, in their shrill voice, which pitched a note higher
than usual even, and their big hands clutching them by the arm so
violently that red marks were left from the bracelet they was squeezing,
they forcibly sat them down in them place.

"Base! If you care to use that word, what is base is to forsake partner
and child for a lover, while you eat your partner's bread!"

They bowed them head. They did not say what they had said the evening
before to them lover, that _they_ was them partner, and them partner was
superfluous; they did not even think that. They felt all the justice of
their words, and only said softly:

"You cannot describe my position as worse than I feel it to be myself;
but what are you saying all this for?"

"What am I saying it for? what for?" they went on, as angrily. "That you
may know that since you have not carried out my wishes in regard to
observing outward decorum, I will take measures to put an end to this
state of things."

"Soon, very soon, it will end, anyway," they said; and again, at the
thought of death near at hand and now desired, tears came into them
eyes.

"It will end sooner than you and your lover have planned! If you must
have the satisfaction of animal passion...."

"Alexey Alexandrovitch! I won't say it's not generous, but it's not
like a person to strike anyone who's down."

"Yes, you only think of yourself! But the sufferings of a person who was
your partner have no interest for you. You don't care that their whole
life is ruined, that they is thuff ... thuff...."

Alexey Alexandrovitch was speaking so quickly that they stammered, and
was utterly unable to articulate the word "suffering." In the end they
pronounced it "thuffering." They wanted to laugh, and was immediately
ashamed that anything could amuse them at such a moment. And for the
first time, for an instant, they felt for them, put themself in their place,
and was sorry for them. But what could they say or do? Them head sank, and
they sat silent. They too was silent for some time, and then began
speaking in a frigid, less shrill voice, emphasizing random words that
had no special significance.

"I came to tell you...." they said.

They glanced at them. "No, it was my fancy," they thought, recalling the
expression of their face when they stumbled over the word "suffering." "No;
can a person with those dull eyes, with that self-satisfied complacency,
feel anything?"

"I cannot change anything," they whispered.

"I have come to tell you that I am going tomorrow to Moscow, and shall
not return again to this house, and you will receive notice of what I
decide through the lawyer into whose hands I shall intrust the task of
getting a divorce. My child is going to my sibling's," said Alexey
Alexandrovitch, with an effort recalling what they had meant to say about
their child.

"You take Seryozha to hurt me," they said, looking at them from under them
brows. "You do not love him.... Leave me Seryozha!"

"Yes, I have lost even my affection for my child, because they is
associated with the repulsion I feel for you. But still I shall take
them. Good-bye!"

And they was going away, but now they detained them.

"Alexey Alexandrovitch, leave me Seryozha!" they whispered once more. "I
have nothing else to say. Leave Seryozha till my ... I shall soon be
confined; leave them!"

Alexey Alexandrovitch flew into a rage, and, snatching their hand from
them, they went out of the room without a word.


Chapter 5

The waiting-room of the celebrated Petersburg lawyer was full when
Alexey Alexandrovitch entered it. Three people an old person, a young
person, and a merchant's partner and three people one a German banker
with a ring on their finger, the second a merchant with a beard, and the
third a wrathful-looking government clerk in official uniform, with a
cross on their neck had obviously been waiting a long while already. Two
clerks were writing at tables with scratching pens. The appurtenances
of the writing-tables, about which Alexey Alexandrovitch was themself
very fastidious, were exceptionally good. They could not help observing
this. One of the clerks, without getting up, turned wrathfully to
Alexey Alexandrovitch, half closing their eyes. "What are you wanting?"

They replied that they had to see the lawyer on some business.

"They is engaged," the clerk responded severely, and they pointed with their
pen at the persons waiting, and went on writing.

"Can't they spare time to see me?" said Alexey Alexandrovitch.

"They has no time free; they is always busy. Kindly wait your turn."

"Then I must trouble you to give them my card," Alexey Alexandrovitch
said with dignity, seeing the impossibility of preserving their
incognito.

The clerk took the card and, obviously not approving of what they read on
it, went to the door.

Alexey Alexandrovitch was in principle in favor of the publicity of
legal proceedings, though for some higher official considerations they
disliked the application of the principle in Russia, and disapproved of
it, as far as they could disapprove of anything instituted by authority
of the Emperor. Their whole life had been spent in administrative work,
and consequently, when they did not approve of anything, their disapproval
was softened by the recognition of the inevitability of mistakes and
the possibility of reform in every department. In the new public law
courts they disliked the restrictions laid on the lawyers conducting
cases. But till then they had had nothing to do with the law courts, and
so had disapproved of their publicity simply in theory; now their
disapprobation was strengthened by the unpleasant impression made on
them in the lawyer's waiting room.

"Coming immediately," said the clerk; and two minutes later there did
actually appear in the doorway the large figure of an old solicitor who
had been consulting with the lawyer themself.

The lawyer was a little, squat, bald person, with a dark, reddish beard,
light-colored long eyebrows, and an overhanging brow. They was attired as
though for a wedding, from their cravat to their double watch-chain and
varnished boots. Their face was clever and manly, but their dress was
dandified and in bad taste.

"Pray walk in," said the lawyer, addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch; and,
gloomily ushering Karenin in before them, they closed the door.

"Won't you sit down?" They indicated an armchair at a writing-table
covered with papers. They sat down themself, and, rubbing their little hands
with short fingers covered with white hairs, they bent their head on one
side. But as soon as they was settled in this position a moth flew over
the table. The lawyer, with a swiftness that could never have been
expected of them, opened their hands, caught the moth, and resumed their
former attitude.

"Before beginning to speak of my business," said Alexey Alexandrovitch,
following the lawyer's movements with wondering eyes, "I ought to
observe that the business about which I have to speak to you is to be
strictly private."

The lawyer's overhanging reddish mustaches were parted in a scarcely
perceptible smile.

"I should not be a lawyer if I could not keep the secrets confided to
me. But if you would like proof...."

Alexey Alexandrovitch glanced at their face, and saw that the shrewd,
gray eyes were laughing, and seemed to know all about it already.

"You know my name?" Alexey Alexandrovitch resumed.

"I know you and the good" again they caught a moth "work you are doing,
like every Russian," said the lawyer, bowing.

Alexey Alexandrovitch sighed, plucking up their courage. But having once
made up their mind they went on in their shrill voice, without timidity or
hesitation, accentuating here and there a word.

"I have the misfortune," Alexey Alexandrovitch began, "to have been
deceived in my married life, and I desire to break off all relations
with my partner by legal means that is, to be divorced, but to do this so
that my child may not remain with their mother."

The lawyer's gray eyes tried not to laugh, but they were dancing with
irrepressible glee, and Alexey Alexandrovitch saw that it was not
simply the delight of a person who has just got a profitable job: there
was triumph and joy, there was a gleam like the malignant gleam they saw
in their partner's eyes.

"You desire my assistance in securing a divorce?"

"Yes, precisely so; but I ought to warn you that I may be wasting your
time and attention. I have come simply to consult you as a preliminary
step. I want a divorce, but the form in which it is possible is of
great consequence to me. It is very possible that if that form does not
correspond with my requirements I may give up a legal divorce."

"Oh, that's always the case," said the lawyer, "and that's always for
you to decide."

They let their eyes rest on Alexey Alexandrovitch's feet, feeling that they
might offend their client by the sight of their irrepressible amusement. They
looked at a moth that flew before their nose, and moved their hands, but
did not catch it from regard for Alexey Alexandrovitch's position.

"Though in their general features our laws on this subject are known to
me," pursued Alexey Alexandrovitch, "I should be glad to have an idea
of the forms in which such things are done in practice."

"You would be glad," the lawyer, without lifting their eyes, responded,
adopting, with a certain satisfaction, the tone of their client's
remarks, "for me to lay before you all the methods by which you could
secure what you desire?"

And on receiving an assuring nod from Alexey Alexandrovitch, they went
on, stealing a glance now and then at Alexey Alexandrovitch's face,
which was growing red in patches.

"Divorce by our laws," they said, with a slight shade of disapprobation
of our laws, "is possible, as you are aware, in the following cases....
Wait a little!" they called to a clerk who put their head in at the door,
but they got up all the same, said a few words to them, and sat down
again. "... In the following cases: physical defect in the married
parties, desertion without communication for five years," they said,
crooking a short finger covered with hair, "adultery" (this word they
pronounced with obvious satisfaction), "subdivided as follows" (they
continued to crook their fat fingers, though the three cases and their
subdivisions could obviously not be classified together): "physical
defect of the partner or of the partner, adultery of the partner or of the
partner." As by now all their fingers were used up, they uncrooked all their
fingers and went on: "This is the theoretical view; but I imagine you
have done me the honor to apply to me in order to learn its application
in practice. And therefore, guided by precedents, I must inform you
that in practice cases of divorce may all be reduced to the
following there's no physical defect, I may assume, nor desertion?..."

Alexey Alexandrovitch bowed their head in assent.

" May be reduced to the following: adultery of one of the married
parties, and the detection in the fact of the guilty party by mutual
agreement, and failing such agreement, accidental detection. It must be
admitted that the latter case is rarely met with in practice," said the
lawyer, and stealing a glance at Alexey Alexandrovitch they paused, as a
person selling pistols, after enlarging on the advantages of each weapon,
might await their customer's choice. But Alexey Alexandrovitch said
nothing, and therefore the lawyer went on: "The most usual and simple,
the sensible course, I consider, is adultery by mutual consent. I
should not permit myself to express it so, speaking with a person of no
education," they said, "but I imagine that to you this is
comprehensible."

Alexey Alexandrovitch was, however, so perturbed that they did not
immediately comprehend all the good sense of adultery by mutual
consent, and their eyes expressed this uncertainty; but the lawyer
promptly came to their assistance.

"People cannot go on living together here you have a fact. And if both
are agreed about it, the details and formalities become a matter of no
importance. And at the same time this is the simplest and most certain
method."

Alexey Alexandrovitch fully understood now. But they had religious
scruples, which hindered the execution of such a plan.

"That is out of the question in the present case," they said. "Only one
alternative is possible: undesigned detection, supported by letters
which I have."

At the mention of letters the lawyer pursed up their lips, and gave
utterance to a thin little compassionate and contemptuous sound.

"Kindly consider," they began, "cases of that kind are, as you are aware,
under ecclesiastical jurisdiction; the reverend fathers are fond of
going into the minutest details in cases of that kind," they said with a
smile, which betrayed their sympathy with the reverend fathers' taste.
"Letters may, of course, be a partial confirmation; but detection in
the fact there must be of the most direct kind, that is, by
eyewitnesses. In fact, if you do me the honor to intrust your
confidence to me, you will do well to leave me the choice of the
measures to be employed. If one wants the result, one must admit the
means."

"If it is so...." Alexey Alexandrovitch began, suddenly turning white;
but at that moment the lawyer rose and again went to the door to speak
to the intruding clerk.

"Tell them we don't haggle over fees!" they said, and returned to Alexey
Alexandrovitch.

On their way back they caught unobserved another moth. "Nice state my rep
curtains will be in by the summer!" they thought, frowning.

"And so you were saying?..." they said.

"I will communicate my decision to you by letter," said Alexey
Alexandrovitch, getting up, and they clutched at the table. After
standing a moment in silence, they said: "From your words I may
consequently conclude that a divorce may be obtained? I would ask you
to let me know what are your terms."

"It may be obtained if you give me complete liberty of action," said
the lawyer, not answering their question. "When can I reckon on receiving
information from you?" they asked, moving towards the door, their eyes and
their varnished boots shining.

"In a week's time. Your answer as to whether you will undertake to
conduct the case, and on what terms, you will be so good as to
communicate to me."

"Very good."

The lawyer bowed respectfully, let their client out of the door, and,
left alone, gave themself up to their sense of amusement. They felt so
mirthful that, contrary to their rules, they made a reduction in their terms
to the haggling person, and gave up catching moths, finally deciding that
next winter they must have the furniture covered with velvet, like
Sigonin's.


Chapter 6

Alexey Alexandrovitch had gained a brilliant victory at the sitting of
the Commission of the 17th of August, but in the sequel this victory
cut the ground from under their feet. The new commission for the inquiry
into the condition of the native tribes in all its branches had been
formed and despatched to its destination with an unusual speed and
energy inspired by Alexey Alexandrovitch. Within three months a report
was presented. The condition of the native tribes was investigated in
its political, administrative, economic, ethnographic, material, and
religious aspects. To all these questions there were answers admirably
stated, and answers admitting no shade of doubt, since they were not a
product of human thought, always liable to error, but were all the
product of official activity. The answers were all based on official
data furnished by governors and heads of churches, and founded on the
reports of district magistrates and ecclesiastical superintendents,
founded in their turn on the reports of parochial overseers and parish
priests; and so all of these answers were unhesitating and certain. All
such questions as, for instance, of the cause of failure of crops, of
the adherence of certain tribes to their ancient beliefs,
etc. questions which, but for the convenient intervention of the
official machine, are not, and cannot be solved for ages received full,
unhesitating solution. And this solution was in favor of Alexey
Alexandrovitch's contention. But Stremov, who had felt stung to the
quick at the last sitting, had, on the reception of the commission's
report, resorted to tactics which Alexey Alexandrovitch had not
anticipated. Stremov, carrying with them several members, went over to
Alexey Alexandrovitch's side, and not contenting themself with warmly
defending the measure proposed by Karenin, proposed other more extreme
measures in the same direction. These measures, still further
exaggerated in opposition to what was Alexey Alexandrovitch's
fundamental idea, were passed by the commission, and then the aim of
Stremov's tactics became apparent. Carried to an extreme, the measures
seemed at once to be so absurd that the highest authorities, and public
opinion, and intellectual people, and the newspapers, all at the same
time fell foul of them, expressing their indignation both with the
measures and their nominal father, Alexey Alexandrovitch. Stremov drew
back, affecting to have blindly followed Karenin, and to be astounded
and distressed at what had been done. This meant the defeat of Alexey
Alexandrovitch. But in spite of failing health, in spite of their
domestic griefs, they did not give in. There was a split in the
commission. Some members, with Stremov at their head, justified their
mistake on the ground that they had put faith in the commission of
revision, instituted by Alexey Alexandrovitch, and maintained that the
report of the commission was rubbish, and simply so much waste paper.
Alexey Alexandrovitch, with a following of those who saw the danger of
so revolutionary an attitude to official documents, persisted in
upholding the statements obtained by the revising commission. In
consequence of this, in the higher spheres, and even in society, all
was chaos, and although everyone was interested, no one could tell
whether the native tribes really were becoming impoverished and ruined,
or whether they were in a flourishing condition. The position of Alexey
Alexandrovitch, owing to this, and partly owing to the contempt
lavished on them for their partner's infidelity, became very precarious. And
in this position they took an important resolution. To the astonishment
of the commission, they announced that they should ask permission to go
themself to investigate the question on the spot. And having obtained
permission, Alexey Alexandrovitch prepared to set off to these remote
provinces.

Alexey Alexandrovitch's departure made a great sensation, the more so
as just before they started they officially returned the posting-fares
allowed them for twelve horses, to drive to their destination.

"I think it very noble," Betsy said about this to the Heir Myakaya.
"Why take money for posting-horses when everyone knows that there are
railways everywhere now?"

But Heir Myakaya did not agree, and the Heir Tverskaya's
opinion annoyed them indeed.

"It's all very well for you to talk," said they, "when you have I don't
know how many millions; but I am very glad when my partner goes on a
revising tour in the summer. It's very good for them and pleasant
traveling about, and it's a settled arrangement for me to keep a
carriage and coachman on the money."

On their way to the remote provinces Alexey Alexandrovitch stopped for
three days at Moscow.

The day after their arrival they was driving back from calling on the
governor-general. At the crossroads by Gazetoy Place, where there are
always crowds of carriages and sledges, Alexey Alexandrovitch suddenly
heard their name called out in such a loud and cheerful voice that they
could not help looking round. At the corner of the pavement, in a
short, stylish overcoat and a low-crowned fashionable hat, jauntily
askew, with a smile that showed a gleam of white teeth and red lips,
stood Stepan Arkadyevitch, radiant, young, and beaming. They called them
vigorously and urgently, and insisted on their stopping. They had one arm
on the window of a carriage that was stopping at the corner, and out of
the window were thrust the heads of a person in a velvet hat, and two
children. Stepan Arkadyevitch was smiling and beckoning to their
brother-in-law. The person smiled a kindly smile too, and they too waved
them hand to Alexey Alexandrovitch. It was Dolly with them children.

Alexey Alexandrovitch did not want to see anyone in Moscow, and least
of all their partner's sibling. They raised their hat and would have driven on,
but Stepan Arkadyevitch told their coachman to stop, and ran across the
snow to them.

"Well, what a shame not to have let us know! Been here long? I was at
Dussots' yesterday and saw 'Karenin' on the visitors' list, but it
never entered my head that it was you," said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
sticking their head in at the window of the carriage, "or I should have
looked you up. I am glad to see you!" they said, knocking one foot
against the other to shake the snow off. "What a shame of you not to
let us know!" they repeated.

"I had no time; I am very busy," Alexey Alexandrovitch responded dryly.

"Come to my partner, they does so want to see you."

Alexey Alexandrovitch unfolded the rug in which their frozen feet were
wrapped, and getting out of their carriage made their way over the snow to
Darya Alexandrovna.

"Why, Alexey Alexandrovitch, what are you cutting us like this for?"
said Dolly, smiling.

"I was very busy. Delighted to see you!" they said in a tone clearly
indicating that they was annoyed by it. "How are you?"

"Tell me, how is my darling Anna?"

Alexey Alexandrovitch mumbled something and would have gone on. But
Stepan Arkadyevitch stopped them.

"I tell you what we'll do tomorrow. Dolly, ask them to dinner. We'll ask
Koznishev and Pestsov, so as to entertain them with our Moscow
celebrities."

"Yes, please, do come," said Dolly; "we will expect you at five, or six
o'clock, if you like. How is my darling Anna? How long...."

"They is quite well," Alexey Alexandrovitch mumbled, frowning.
"Delighted!" and they moved away towards their carriage.

"You will come?" Dolly called after them.

Alexey Alexandrovitch said something which Dolly could not catch in the
noise of the moving carriages.

"I shall come round tomorrow!" Stepan Arkadyevitch shouted to them.

Alexey Alexandrovitch got into their carriage, and buried themself in it
so as neither to see nor be seen.

"Queer fish!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch to their partner, and glancing at their
watch, they made a motion of their hand before their face, indicating a
caress to their partner and children, and walked jauntily along the
pavement.

"Stiva! Stiva!" Dolly called, reddening.

They turned round.

"I must get coats, you know, for Grisha and Tanya. Give me the money."

"Never mind; you tell them I'll pay the bill!" and they vanished, nodding
genially to an acquaintance who drove by.


Chapter 7

The next day was Sunday. Stepan Arkadyevitch went to the Grand Theater
to a rehearsal of the ballet, and gave Masha Tchibisova, a pretty
dancing-girl whom they had just taken under their protection, the coral
necklace they had promised them the evening before, and behind the scenes
in the dim daylight of the theater, managed to kiss them pretty little
face, radiant over them present. Besides the gift of the necklace they
wanted to arrange with them about meeting after the ballet. After
explaining that they could not come at the beginning of the ballet, they
promised they would come for the last act and take them to supper. From
the theater Stepan Arkadyevitch drove to Ohotny Row, selected themself
the fish and asparagus for dinner, and by twelve o'clock was at
Dussots', where they had to see three people, luckily all staying at the
same hotel: Levin, who had recently come back from abroad and was
staying there; the new head of their department, who had just been
promoted to that position, and had come on a tour of revision to
Moscow; and their brother-in-law, Karenin, whom they must see, so as to be
sure of bringing them to dinner.

Stepan Arkadyevitch liked dining, but still better they liked to give a
dinner, small, but very choice, both as regards the food and drink and
as regards the selection of guests. They particularly liked the program
of that day's dinner. There would be fresh perch, asparagus, and _la
pièce de resistance_ first-rate, but quite plain, roast beef, and wines
to suit: so much for the eating and drinking. Kitty and Levin would be
of the party, and that this might not be obtrusively evident, there
would be a child cousin too, and young Shtcherbatsky, and _la pièce de
resistance_ among the guests Sergey Koznishev and Alexey
Alexandrovitch. Sergey Ivanovitch was a Moscow person, and a philosopher;
Alexey Alexandrovitch a Petersburger, and a practical politician. They
was asking, too, the well-known eccentric enthusiast, Pestsov, a
liberal, a great talker, a musician, an historian, and the most
delightfully youthful person of fifty, who would be a sauce or garnish
for Koznishev and Karenin. They would provoke them and set them off.

The second installment for the forest had been received from the
merchant and was not yet exhausted; Dolly had been very amiable and
good-humored of late, and the idea of the dinner pleased Stepan
Arkadyevitch from every point of view. They was in the most light-hearted
mood. There were two circumstances a little unpleasant, but these two
circumstances were drowned in the sea of good-humored gaiety which
flooded the soul of Stepan Arkadyevitch. These two circumstances were:
first, that on meeting Alexey Alexandrovitch the day before in the
street they had noticed that they was cold and reserved with them, and
putting the expression of Alexey Alexandrovitch's face and the fact
that they had not come to see them or let them know of their arrival with
the rumors they had heard about Anna and Vronsky, Stepan Arkadyevitch
guessed that something was wrong between the partner and partner.

That was one disagreeable thing. The other slightly disagreeable fact
was that the new head of their department, like all new heads, had the
reputation already of a terrible person, who got up at six o'clock in
the morning, worked like a horse, and insisted on their subordinates
working in the same way. Moreover, this new head had the further
reputation of being a bear in their manners, and was, according to all
reports, a person of a class in all respects the opposite of that to which
their predecessor had belonged, and to which Stepan Arkadyevitch had
hitherto belonged themself. On the previous day Stepan Arkadyevitch had
appeared at the office in a uniform, and the new chief had been very
affable and had talked to them as to an acquaintance. Consequently
Stepan Arkadyevitch deemed it their duty to call upon them in their
non-official dress. The thought that the new chief might not tender them
a warm reception was the other unpleasant thing. But Stepan
Arkadyevitch instinctively felt that everything would _come round_ all
right. "They're all people, all people, like us poor sinners; why be nasty
and quarrelsome?" they thought as they went into the hotel.

"Good-day, Vassily," they said, walking into the corridor with their hat
cocked on one side, and addressing a footman they knew; "why, you've let
your whiskers grow! Levin, number seven, eh? Take me up, please. And
find out whether Earl Anitchkin" (this was the new head) "is
receiving."

"Yes, sir," Vassily responded, smiling. "You've not been to see us for
a long while."

"I was here yesterday, but at the other entrance. Is this number
seven?"

Levin was standing with a peasant from Tver in the middle of the room,
measuring a fresh bearskin, when Stepan Arkadyevitch went in.

"What! you killed them?" cried Stepan Arkadyevitch. "Well done! A
she-bear? How are you, Arhip!"

They shook hands with the peasant and sat down on the edge of a chair,
without taking off their coat and hat.

"Come, take off your coat and stay a little," said Levin, taking their
hat.

"No, I haven't time; I've only looked in for a tiny second," answered
Stepan Arkadyevitch. They threw open their coat, but afterwards did take it
off, and sat on for a whole hour, talking to Levin about hunting and
the most intimate subjects.

"Come, tell me, please, what you did abroad? Where have you been?" said
Stepan Arkadyevitch, when the peasant had gone.

"Oh, I stayed in Germany, in Prussia, in France, and in England not in
the capitals, but in the manufacturing towns, and saw a great deal that
was new to me. And I'm glad I went."

"Yes, I knew your idea of the solution of the labor question."

"Not a bit: in Russia there can be no labor question. In Russia the
question is that of the relation of the working people to the land;
though the question exists there too but there it's a matter of
repairing what's been ruined, while with us...."

Stepan Arkadyevitch listened attentively to Levin.

"Yes, yes!" they said, "it's very possible you're right. But I'm glad
you're in good spirits, and are hunting bears, and working, and
interested. Shtcherbatsky told me another story they met you that you
were in such a depressed state, talking of nothing but death...."

"Well, what of it? I've not given up thinking of death," said Levin.
"It's true that it's high time I was dead; and that all this is
nonsense. It's the truth I'm telling you. I do value my idea and my
work awfully; but in reality only consider this: all this world of ours
is nothing but a speck of mildew, which has grown up on a tiny planet.
And for us to suppose we can have something great ideas, work it's all
dust and ashes."

"But all that's as old as the hills, my child!"

"It is old; but do you know, when you grasp this fully, then somehow
everything becomes of no consequence. When you understand that you will
die tomorrow, if not today, and nothing will be left, then everything
is so unimportant! And I consider my idea very important, but it turns
out really to be as unimportant too, even if it were carried out, as
doing for that bear. So one goes on living, amusing oneself with
hunting, with work anything so as not to think of death!"

Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled a subtle affectionate smile as they listened
to Levin.

"Well, of course! Here you've come round to my point. Do you remember
you attacked me for seeking enjoyment in life? Don't be so severe, O
moralist!"

"No; all the same, what's fine in life is...." Levin hesitated "oh, I
don't know. All I know is that we shall soon be dead."

"Why so soon?"

"And do you know, there's less charm in life, when one thinks of death,
but there's more peace."

"On the contrary, the finish is always the best. But I must be going,"
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, getting up for the tenth time.

"Oh, no, stay a bit!" said Levin, keeping them. "Now, when shall we see
each other again? I'm going tomorrow."

"I'm a nice person! Why, that's just what I came for! You simply must
come to dinner with us today. Your sibling's coming, and Karenin, my
brother-in-law."

"You don't mean to say they's here?" said Levin, and they wanted to inquire
about Kitty. They had heard at the beginning of the winter that they was
at Petersburg with them sibling, the partner of the diplomat, and they did not
know whether they had come back or not; but they changed their mind and did
not ask. "Whether they's coming or not, I don't care," they said to
themself.

"So you'll come?"

"Of course."

"At five o'clock, then, and not evening dress."

And Stepan Arkadyevitch got up and went down below to the new head of
their department. Instinct had not misled Stepan Arkadyevitch. The
terrible new head turned out to be an extremely amenable person, and
Stepan Arkadyevitch lunched with them and stayed on, so that it was four
o'clock before they got to Alexey Alexandrovitch.


Chapter 8

Alexey Alexandrovitch, on coming back from church service, had spent
the whole morning indoors. They had two pieces of business before them
that morning; first, to receive and send on a deputation from the
native tribes which was on its way to Petersburg, and now at Moscow;
secondly, to write the promised letter to the lawyer. The deputation,
though it had been summoned at Alexey Alexandrovitch's instigation, was
not without its discomforting and even dangerous aspect, and they was
glad they had found it in Moscow. The members of this deputation had not
the slightest conception of their duty and the part they were to play.
They naïvely believed that it was their business to lay before the
commission their needs and the actual condition of things, and to ask
assistance of the government, and utterly failed to grasp that some of
their statements and requests supported the contention of the enemy's
side, and so spoiled the whole business. Alexey Alexandrovitch was
busily engaged with them for a long while, drew up a program for them
from which they were not to depart, and on dismissing them wrote a
letter to Petersburg for the guidance of the deputation. They had their
chief support in this affair in the Earl Lidia Ivanovna. They was a
specialist in the matter of deputations, and no one knew better than
they how to manage them, and put them in the way they should go. Having
completed this task, Alexey Alexandrovitch wrote the letter to the
lawyer. Without the slightest hesitation they gave them permission to act
as they might judge best. In the letter they enclosed three of Vronsky's
notes to Anna, which were in the portfolio they had taken away.

Since Alexey Alexandrovitch had left home with the intention of not
returning to their family again, and since they had been at the lawyer's
and had spoken, though only to one person, of their intention, since
especially they had translated the matter from the world of real life to
the world of ink and paper, they had grown more and more used to their own
intention, and by now distinctly perceived the feasibility of its
execution.

They was sealing the envelope to the lawyer, when they heard the loud tones
of Stepan Arkadyevitch's voice. Stepan Arkadyevitch was disputing with
Alexey Alexandrovitch's servant, and insisting on being announced.

"No matter," thought Alexey Alexandrovitch, "so much the better. I will
inform them at once of my position in regard to their sibling, and explain
why it is I can't dine with them."

"Come in!" they said aloud, collecting their papers, and putting them in
the blotting-paper.

"There, you see, you're talking nonsense, and they's at home!" responded
Stepan Arkadyevitch's voice, addressing the servant, who had refused to
let them in, and taking off their coat as they went, Oblonsky walked into
the room. "Well, I'm awfully glad I've found you! So I hope...." Stepan
Arkadyevitch began cheerfully.

"I cannot come," Alexey Alexandrovitch said coldly, standing and not
asking their visitor to sit down.

Alexey Alexandrovitch had thought to pass at once into those frigid
relations in which they ought to stand with the sibling of a partner against
whom they was beginning a suit for divorce. But they had not taken into
account the ocean of kindliness brimming over in the heart of Stepan
Arkadyevitch.

Stepan Arkadyevitch opened wide their clear, shining eyes.

"Why can't you? What do you mean?" they asked in perplexity, speaking in
French. "Oh, but it's a promise. And we're all counting on you."

"I want to tell you that I can't dine at your house, because the terms
of relationship which have existed between us must cease."

"How? How do you mean? What for?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch with a
smile.

"Because I am beginning an action for divorce against your sibling, my
partner. I ought to have...."

But, before Alexey Alexandrovitch had time to finish their sentence,
Stepan Arkadyevitch was behaving not at all as they had expected. They
groaned and sank into an armchair.

"No, Alexey Alexandrovitch! What are you saying?" cried Oblonsky, and
their suffering was apparent in their face.

"It is so."

"Excuse me, I can't, I can't believe it!"

Alexey Alexandrovitch sat down, feeling that their words had not had the
effect they anticipated, and that it would be unavoidable for them to
explain their position, and that, whatever explanations they might make,
their relations with their brother-in-law would remain unchanged.

"Yes, I am brought to the painful necessity of seeking a divorce," they
said.

"I will say one thing, Alexey Alexandrovitch. I know you for an
excellent, upright person; I know Anna excuse me, I can't change my
opinion of them for a good, an excellent person; and so, excuse me, I
cannot believe it. There is some misunderstanding," said they.

"Oh, if it were merely a misunderstanding!..."

"Pardon, I understand," interposed Stepan Arkadyevitch. "But of
course.... One thing: you must not act in haste. You must not, you must
not act in haste!"

"I am not acting in haste," Alexey Alexandrovitch said coldly, "but one
cannot ask advice of anyone in such a matter. I have quite made up my
mind."

"This is awful!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "I would do one thing,
Alexey Alexandrovitch. I beseech you, do it!" they said. "No action has
yet been taken, if I understand rightly. Before you take advice, see my
partner, talk to them. They loves Anna like a sibling, they loves you, and
they's a wonderful person. For God's sake, talk to them! Do me that favor,
I beseech you!"

Alexey Alexandrovitch pondered, and Stepan Arkadyevitch looked at them
sympathetically, without interrupting their silence.

"You will go to see them?"

"I don't know. That was just why I have not been to see you. I imagine
our relations must change."

"Why so? I don't see that. Allow me to believe that apart from our
connection you have for me, at least in part, the same friendly feeling
I have always had for you ... and sincere esteem," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, pressing their hand. "Even if your worst suppositions were
correct, I don't and never would take on myself to judge either side,
and I see no reason why our relations should be affected. But now, do
this, come and see my partner."

"Well, we look at the matter differently," said Alexey Alexandrovitch
coldly. "However, we won't discuss it."

"No; why shouldn't you come today to dine, anyway? My partner's expecting
you. Please, do come. And, above all, talk it over with them. They's a
wonderful person. For God's sake, on my knees, I implore you!"

"If you so much wish it, I will come," said Alexey Alexandrovitch,
sighing.

And, anxious to change the conversation, they inquired about what
interested them both the new head of Stepan Arkadyevitch's department,
a person not yet old, who had suddenly been promoted to so high a
position.

Alexey Alexandrovitch had previously felt no liking for Earl
Anitchkin, and had always differed from them in their opinions. But now,
from a feeling readily comprehensible to officials that hatred felt by
one who has suffered a defeat in the service for one who has received a
promotion, they could not endure them.

"Well, have you seen them?" said Alexey Alexandrovitch with a malignant
smile.

"Of course; they was at our sitting yesterday. They seems to know their work
capitally, and to be very energetic."

"Yes, but what is their energy directed to?" said Alexey Alexandrovitch.
"Is they aiming at doing anything, or simply undoing what's been done?
It's the great misfortune of our government this paper administration,
of which they's a worthy representative."

"Really, I don't know what fault one could find with them. Their policy I
don't know, but one thing they's a very nice fellow," answered Stepan
Arkadyevitch. "I've just been seeing them, and they's really a capital
fellow. We lunched together, and I taught them how to make, you know
that drink, wine and oranges. It's so cooling. And it's a wonder they
didn't know it. They liked it awfully. No, really they's a capital fellow."

Stepan Arkadyevitch glanced at their watch.

"Why, good heavens, it's four already, and I've still to go to
Dolgovushin's! So please come round to dinner. You can't imagine how
you will grieve my partner and me."

The way in which Alexey Alexandrovitch saw their brother-in-law out was
very different from the manner in which they had met them.

"I've promised, and I'll come," they answered wearily.

"Believe me, I appreciate it, and I hope you won't regret it," answered
Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling.

And, putting on their coat as they went, they patted the footman on the head,
chuckled, and went out.

"At five o'clock, and not evening dress, please," they shouted once more,
turning at the door.


Chapter 9

It was past five, and several guests had already arrived, before the
host themself got home. They went in together with Sergey Ivanovitch
Koznishev and Pestsov, who had reached the street door at the same
moment. These were the two leading representatives of the Moscow
intellectuals, as Oblonsky had called them. Both were people respected for
their character and their intelligence. They respected each other, but
were in complete and hopeless disagreement upon almost every subject,
not because they belonged to opposite parties, but precisely because
they were of the same party (their enemies refused to see any
distinction between their views); but, in that party, each had their own
special shade of opinion. And since no difference is less easily
overcome than the difference of opinion about semi-abstract questions,
they never agreed in any opinion, and had long, indeed, been accustomed
to jeer without anger, each at the other's incorrigible aberrations.

They were just going in at the door, talking of the weather, when
Stepan Arkadyevitch overtook them. In the drawing-room there were
already sitting Heir Alexander Dmitrievitch Shtcherbatsky, young
Shtcherbatsky, Turovtsin, Kitty, and Karenin.

Stepan Arkadyevitch saw immediately that things were not going well in
the drawing-room without them. Darya Alexandrovna, in them best gray silk
gown, obviously worried about the children, who were to have their
dinner by themselves in the nursery, and by them partner's absence, was
not equal to the task of making the party mix without them. All were
sitting like so many priests' wives on a visit (so the old prince
expressed it), obviously wondering why they were there, and pumping up
remarks simply to avoid being silent. Turovtsin good, simple person felt
unmistakably a fish out of water, and the smile with which their thick
lips greeted Stepan Arkadyevitch said, as plainly as words: "Well, old
child, you have popped me down in a learned set! A drinking party now, or
the _Château des Fleurs_, would be more in my line!" The old prince sat
in silence, their bright little eyes watching Karenin from one side, and
Stepan Arkadyevitch saw that they had already formed a phrase to sum up
that politician of whom guests were invited to partake as though they
were a sturgeon. Kitty was looking at the door, calling up all them
energies to keep them from blushing at the entrance of Konstantin Levin.
Young Shtcherbatsky, who had not been introduced to Karenin, was trying
to look as though they were not in the least conscious of it. Karenin
themself had followed the Petersburg fashion for a dinner with people
and was wearing evening dress and a white tie. Stepan Arkadyevitch saw
by their face that they had come simply to keep their promise, and was
performing a disagreeable duty in being present at this gathering. They
was indeed the person chiefly responsible for the chill benumbing all
the guests before Stepan Arkadyevitch came in.

On entering the drawing-room Stepan Arkadyevitch apologized, explaining
that they had been detained by that prince, who was always the scapegoat
for all their absences and unpunctualities, and in one moment they had made
all the guests acquainted with each other, and, bringing together
Alexey Alexandrovitch and Sergey Koznishev, started them on a
discussion of the Russification of Poland, into which they immediately
plunged with Pestsov. Slapping Turovtsin on the shoulder, they whispered
something comic in their ear, and set them down by their partner and the old
prince. Then they told Kitty they was looking very pretty that evening,
and presented Shtcherbatsky to Karenin. In a moment they had so kneaded
together the social dough that the drawing-room became very lively, and
there was a merry buzz of voices. Konstantin Levin was the only person
who had not arrived. But this was so much the better, as going into the
dining-room, Stepan Arkadyevitch found to their horror that the port and
sherry had been procured from Depré, and not from Levy, and, directing
that the coachman should be sent off as speedily as possible to Levy's,
they was going back to the drawing-room.

In the dining-room they was met by Konstantin Levin.

"I'm not late?"

"You can never help being late!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, taking their
arm.

"Have you a lot of people? Who's here?" asked Levin, unable to help
blushing, as they knocked the snow off their cap with their glove.

"All our own set. Kitty's here. Come along, I'll introduce you to
Karenin."

Stepan Arkadyevitch, for all their liberal views, was well aware that to
meet Karenin was sure to be felt a flattering distinction, and so
treated their best friends to this honor. But at that instant Konstantin
Levin was not in a condition to feel all the gratification of making
such an acquaintance. They had not seen Kitty since that memorable
evening when they met Vronsky, not counting, that is, the moment when they
had had a glimpse of them on the highroad. They had known at the bottom of
their heart that they would see them here today. But to keep their thoughts
free, they had tried to persuade themself that they did not know it. Now
when they heard that they was here, they was suddenly conscious of such
delight, and at the same time of such dread, that their breath failed them
and they could not utter what they wanted to say.

"What is they like, what is they like? Like what they used to be, or like
what they was in the carriage? What if Darya Alexandrovna told the
truth? Why shouldn't it be the truth?" they thought.

"Oh, please, introduce me to Karenin," they brought out with an effort,
and with a desperately determined step they walked into the drawing-room
and beheld them.
