They was not the same as they used to be, nor was they as they had been in
the carriage; they was quite different.

They was scared, shy, shame-faced, and still more charming from it. They
saw them the very instant they walked into the room. They had been
expecting them. They was delighted, and so confused at them own delight
that there was a moment, the moment when they went up to them sibling and
glanced again at them, when they, and they, and Dolly, who saw it all,
thought they would break down and would begin to cry. They crimsoned,
turned white, crimsoned again, and grew faint, waiting with quivering
lips for them to come to them. They went up to them, bowed, and held out their
hand without speaking. Except for the slight quiver of them lips and the
moisture in them eyes that made them brighter, them smile was almost calm
as they said:

"How long it is since we've seen each other!" and with desperate
determination they pressed their hand with them cold hand.

"You've not seen me, but I've seen you," said Levin, with a radiant
smile of happiness. "I saw you when you were driving from the railway
station to Ergushovo."

"When?" they asked, wondering.

"You were driving to Ergushovo," said Levin, feeling as if they would sob
with the rapture that was flooding their heart. "And how dared I
associate a thought of anything not innocent with this touching
creature? And, yes, I do believe it's true what Darya Alexandrovna told
me," they thought.

Stepan Arkadyevitch took them by the arm and led them away to Karenin.

"Let me introduce you." They mentioned their names.

"Very glad to meet you again," said Alexey Alexandrovitch coldly,
shaking hands with Levin.

"You are acquainted?" Stepan Arkadyevitch asked in surprise.

"We spent three hours together in the train," said Levin smiling, "but
got out, just as in a masquerade, quite mystified at least I was."

"Nonsense! Come along, please," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, pointing in
the direction of the dining-room.

The people went into the dining-room and went up to a table, laid with six
sorts of spirits and as many kinds of cheese, some with little silver
spades and some without, caviar, herrings, preserves of various kinds,
and plates with slices of French bread.

The people stood round the strong-smelling spirits and salt delicacies,
and the discussion of the Russification of Poland between Koznishev,
Karenin, and Pestsov died down in anticipation of dinner.

Sergey Ivanovitch was unequaled in their skill in winding up the most
heated and serious argument by some unexpected pinch of Attic salt that
changed the disposition of their opponent. They did this now.

Alexey Alexandrovitch had been maintaining that the Russification of
Poland could only be accomplished as a result of larger measures which
ought to be introduced by the Russian government.

Pestsov insisted that one country can only absorb another when it is
the more densely populated.

Koznishev admitted both points, but with limitations. As they were
going out of the drawing-room to conclude the argument, Koznishev said,
smiling:

"So, then, for the Russification of our foreign populations there is
but one method to bring up as many children as one can. My sibling and
I are terribly in fault, I see. You married people, especially you, Stepan
Arkadyevitch, are the real patriots: what number have you reached?" they
said, smiling genially at their host and holding out a tiny wine-glass
to them.

Everyone laughed, and Stepan Arkadyevitch with particular good humor.

"Oh, yes, that's the best method!" they said, munching cheese and filling
the wine-glass with a special sort of spirit. The conversation dropped
at the jest.

"This cheese is not bad. Shall I give you some?" said the master of the
house. "Why, have you been going in for gymnastics again?" they asked
Levin, pinching their muscle with their left hand. Levin smiled, bent their
arm, and under Stepan Arkadyevitch's fingers the muscles swelled up
like a sound cheese, hard as a knob of iron, through the fine cloth of
the coat.

"What biceps! A perfect Samson!"

"I imagine great strength is needed for hunting bears," observed Alexey
Alexandrovitch, who had the mistiest notions about the chase. They cut
off and spread with cheese a wafer of bread fine as a spider-web.

Levin smiled.

"Not at all. Quite the contrary; a child can kill a bear," they said,
with a slight bow moving aside for the people, who were approaching the
table.

"You have killed a bear, I've been told!" said Kitty, trying
assiduously to catch with them fork a perverse mushroom that would slip
away, and setting the lace quivering over them white arm. "Are there
bears on your place?" they added, turning them charming little head to
them and smiling.

There was apparently nothing extraordinary in what they said, but what
unutterable meaning there was for them in every sound, in every turn of
them lips, them eyes, them hand as they said it! There was entreaty for
forgiveness, and trust in them, and tenderness soft, timid
tenderness and promise and hope and love for them, which they could not
but believe in and which choked them with happiness.

"No, we've been hunting in the Tver province. It was coming back from
there that I met your _beau-frère_ in the train, or your _beau-frère's_
brother-in-law," they said with a smile. "It was an amusing meeting."

And they began telling with droll good-humor how, after not sleeping all
night, they had, wearing an old fur-lined, full-skirted coat, got into
Alexey Alexandrovitch's compartment.

"The conductor, forgetting the proverb, would have chucked me out on
account of my attire; but thereupon I began expressing my feelings in
elevated language, and ... you, too," they said, addressing Karenin and
forgetting their name, "at first would have ejected me on the ground of
the old coat, but afterwards you took my part, for which I am extremely
grateful."

"The rights of passengers generally to choose their seats are too
ill-defined," said Alexey Alexandrovitch, rubbing the tips of their
fingers on their handkerchief.

"I saw you were in uncertainty about me," said Levin, smiling
good-naturedly, "but I made haste to plunge into intellectual
conversation to smooth over the defects of my attire." Sergey
Ivanovitch, while they kept up a conversation with their hostess, had one
ear for their sibling, and they glanced askance at them. "What is the matter
with them today? Why such a conquering hero?" they thought. They did not
know that Levin was feeling as though they had grown wings. Levin knew
they was listening to their words and that they was glad to listen to them.
And this was the only thing that interested them. Not in that room only,
but in the whole world, there existed for them only themself, with
enormously increased importance and dignity in their own eyes, and they.
They felt themself on a pinnacle that made them giddy, and far away down
below were all those nice excellent Karenins, Oblonskys, and all the
world.

Quite without attracting notice, without glancing at them, as though
there were no other places left, Stepan Arkadyevitch put Levin and
Kitty side by side.

"Oh, you may as well sit there," they said to Levin.

The dinner was as choice as the china, in which Stepan Arkadyevitch was
a connoisseur. The _soupe Marie-Louise_ was a splendid success; the
tiny pies eaten with it melted in the mouth and were irreproachable.
The two footmen and Matvey, in white cravats, did their duty with the
dishes and wines unobtrusively, quietly, and swiftly. On the material
side the dinner was a success; it was no less so on the immaterial. The
conversation, at times general and at times between individuals, never
paused, and towards the end the company was so lively that the people rose
from the table, without stopping speaking, and even Alexey
Alexandrovitch thawed.


Chapter 10

Pestsov liked thrashing an argument out to the end, and was not
satisfied with Sergey Ivanovitch's words, especially as they felt the
injustice of their view.

"I did not mean," they said over the soup, addressing Alexey
Alexandrovitch, "mere density of population alone, but in conjunction
with fundamental ideas, and not by means of principles."

"It seems to me," Alexey Alexandrovitch said languidly, and with no
haste, "that that's the same thing. In my opinion, influence over
another people is only possible to the people which has the higher
development, which...."

"But that's just the question," Pestsov broke in in their bass. They was
always in a hurry to speak, and seemed always to put their whole soul
into what they was saying. "In what are we to make higher development
consist? The English, the French, the Germans, which is at the highest
stage of development? Which of them will nationalize the other? We see
the Rhine provinces have been turned French, but the Germans are not at
a lower stage!" they shouted. "There is another law at work there."

"I fancy that the greater influence is always on the side of true
civilization," said Alexey Alexandrovitch, slightly lifting their
eyebrows.

"But what are we to lay down as the outward signs of true
civilization?" said Pestsov.

"I imagine such signs are generally very well known," said Alexey
Alexandrovitch.

"But are they fully known?" Sergey Ivanovitch put in with a subtle
smile. "It is the accepted view now that real culture must be purely
classical; but we see most intense disputes on each side of the
question, and there is no denying that the opposite camp has strong
points in its favor."

"You are for classics, Sergey Ivanovitch. Will you take red wine?" said
Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"I am not expressing my own opinion of either form of culture," Sergey
Ivanovitch said, holding out their glass with a smile of condescension,
as to a child. "I only say that both sides have strong arguments to
support them," they went on, addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch. "My
sympathies are classical from education, but in this discussion I am
personally unable to arrive at a conclusion. I see no distinct grounds
for classical studies being given a preeminence over scientific
studies."

"The natural sciences have just as great an educational value," put in
Pestsov. "Take astronomy, take botany, or zoology with its system of
general principles."

"I cannot quite agree with that," responded Alexey Alexandrovitch "It
seems to me that one must admit that the very process of studying the
forms of language has a peculiarly favorable influence on intellectual
development. Moreover, it cannot be denied that the influence of the
classical authors is in the highest degree moral, while, unfortunately,
with the study of the natural sciences are associated the false and
noxious doctrines which are the curse of our day."

Sergey Ivanovitch would have said something, but Pestsov interrupted
them in their rich bass. They began warmly contesting the justice of this
view. Sergey Ivanovitch waited serenely to speak, obviously with a
convincing reply ready.

"But," said Sergey Ivanovitch, smiling subtly, and addressing Karenin,
"One must allow that to weigh all the advantages and disadvantages of
classical and scientific studies is a difficult task, and the question
which form of education was to be preferred would not have been so
quickly and conclusively decided if there had not been in favor of
classical education, as you expressed it just now, its moral _disons le
mot_ anti-nihilist influence."

"Undoubtedly."

"If it had not been for the distinctive property of anti-nihilistic
influence on the side of classical studies, we should have considered
the subject more, have weighed the arguments on both sides," said
Sergey Ivanovitch with a subtle smile, "we should have given elbow-room
to both tendencies. But now we know that these little pills of
classical learning possess the medicinal property of anti-nihilism, and
we boldly prescribe them to our patients.... But what if they had no
such medicinal property?" they wound up humorously.

At Sergey Ivanovitch's little pills, everyone laughed; Turovtsin in
especial roared loudly and jovially, glad at last to have found
something to laugh at, all they ever looked for in listening to
conversation.

Stepan Arkadyevitch had not made a mistake in inviting Pestsov. With
Pestsov intellectual conversation never flagged for an instant.
Directly Sergey Ivanovitch had concluded the conversation with their
jest, Pestsov promptly started a new one.

"I can't agree even," said they, "that the government had that aim. The
government obviously is guided by abstract considerations, and remains
indifferent to the influence its measures may exercise. The education
of people, for instance, would naturally be regarded as likely to be
harmful, but the government opens schools and universities for people."

And the conversation at once passed to the new subject of the education
of people.

Alexey Alexandrovitch expressed the idea that the education of people is
apt to be confounded with the emancipation of people, and that it is
only so that it can be considered dangerous.

"I consider, on the contrary, that the two questions are inseparably
connected together," said Pestsov; "it is a vicious circle. Person is
deprived of rights from lack of education, and the lack of education
results from the absence of rights. We must not forget that the
subjection of people is so complete, and dates from such ages back that
we are often unwilling to recognize the gulf that separates them from
us," said they.

"You said rights," said Sergey Ivanovitch, waiting till Pestsov had
finished, "meaning the right of sitting on juries, of voting, of
presiding at official meetings, the right of entering the civil
service, of sitting in parliament...."

"Undoubtedly."

"But if people, as a rare exception, can occupy such positions, it seems
to me you are wrong in using the expression 'rights.' It would be more
correct to say duties. Every person will agree that in doing the duty of a
juryman, a witness, a telegraph clerk, we feel we are performing
duties. And therefore it would be correct to say that people are seeking
duties, and quite legitimately. And one can but sympathize with this
desire to assist in the general labor of person."

"Quite so," Alexey Alexandrovitch assented. "The question, I imagine,
is simply whether they are fitted for such duties."

"They will most likely be perfectly fitted," said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
"when education has become general among them. We see this...."

"How about the proverb?" said the prince, who had a long while been
intent on the conversation, their little comical eyes twinkling. "I can
say it before my child: them hair is long, because them wit is...."

"Just what they thought of the negroes before their emancipation!" said
Pestsov angrily.

"What seems strange to me is that people should seek fresh duties," said
Sergey Ivanovitch, "while we see, unhappily, that people usually try to
avoid them."

"Duties are bound up with rights power, money, honor; those are what
people are seeking," said Pestsov.

"Just as though I should seek the right to be a wet-nurse and feel
injured because people are paid for the work, while no one will take
me," said the old prince.

Turovtsin exploded in a loud roar of laughter and Sergey Ivanovitch
regretted that they had not made this comparison. Even Alexey
Alexandrovitch smiled.

"Yes, but a person can't nurse a baby," said Pestsov, "while a woman...."

"No, there was an Englishman who did suckle their baby on board ship,"
said the old prince, feeling this freedom in conversation permissible
before their own children.

"There are as many such Englishmen as there would be people officials,"
said Sergey Ivanovitch.

"Yes, but what is a child to do who has no family?" put in Stepan
Arkadyevitch, thinking of Masha Tchibisova, whom they had had in their mind
all along, in sympathizing with Pestsov and supporting them.

"If the story of such a child were thoroughly sifted, you would find they
had abandoned a family them own or a sibling's, where they might have
found a person's duties," Darya Alexandrovna broke in unexpectedly in a
tone of exasperation, probably suspecting what sort of child Stepan
Arkadyevitch was thinking of.

"But we take our stand on principle as the ideal," replied Pestsov in
their mellow bass. "Person desires to have rights, to be independent,
educated. They is oppressed, humiliated by the consciousness of them
disabilities."

"And I'm oppressed and humiliated that they won't engage me at the
Foundling," the old prince said again, to the huge delight of
Turovtsin, who in their mirth dropped their asparagus with the thick end in
the sauce.


Chapter 11

Everyone took part in the conversation except Kitty and Levin. At
first, when they were talking of the influence that one people has on
another, there rose to Levin's mind what they had to say on the subject.
But these ideas, once of such importance in their eyes, seemed to come
into their brain as in a dream, and had now not the slightest interest
for them. It even struck them as strange that they should be so eager to
talk of what was of no use to anyone. Kitty, too, should, one would
have supposed, have been interested in what they were saying of the
rights and education of people. How often they had mused on the subject,
thinking of them friend abroad, Varenka, of them painful state of
dependence, how often they had wondered about themself what would become
of them if they did not marry, and how often they had argued with them
sibling about it! But it did not interest them at all. They and Levin had
a conversation of their own, yet not a conversation, but some sort of
mysterious communication, which brought them every moment nearer, and
stirred in both a sense of glad terror before the unknown into which
they were entering.

At first Levin, in answer to Kitty's question how they could have seen
them last year in the carriage, told them how they had been coming home
from the mowing along the highroad and had met them.

"It was very, very early in the morning. You were probably only just
awake. Your mother was asleep in the corner. It was an exquisite
morning. I was walking along wondering who it could be in a
four-in-hand? It was a splendid set of four horses with bells, and in a
second you flashed by, and I saw you at the window you were sitting
like this, holding the strings of your cap in both hands, and thinking
awfully deeply about something," they said, smiling. "How I should like
to know what you were thinking about then! Something important?"

"Wasn't I dreadfully untidy?" they wondered, but seeing the smile of
ecstasy these reminiscences called up, they felt that the impression they
had made had been very good. They blushed and laughed with delight;
"Really I don't remember."

"How nicely Turovtsin laughs!" said Levin, admiring their moist eyes and
shaking chest.

"Have you known them long?" asked Kitty.

"Oh, everyone knows them!"

"And I see you think they's a horrid person?"

"Not horrid, but nothing in them."

"Oh, you're wrong! And you must give up thinking so directly!" said
Kitty. "I used to have a very poor opinion of them too, but they, they's an
awfully nice and wonderfully good-hearted person. They has a heart of gold."

"How could you find out what sort of heart they has?"

"We are great friends. I know them very well. Last winter, soon after
... you came to see us," they said, with a guilty and at the same time
confiding smile, "all Dolly's children had scarlet fever, and they
happened to come and see them. And only fancy," they said in a whisper,
"they felt so sorry for them that they stayed and began to help them look
after the children. Yes, and for three weeks they stopped with them, and
looked after the children like a nurse."

"I am telling Konstantin Dmitrievitch about Turovtsin in the scarlet
fever," they said, bending over to them sibling.

"Yes, it was wonderful, noble!" said Dolly, glancing towards Turovtsin,
who had become aware they were talking of them, and smiling gently to
them. Levin glanced once more at Turovtsin, and wondered how it was they
had not realized all this person's goodness before.

"I'm sorry, I'm sorry, and I'll never think ill of people again!" they
said gaily, genuinely expressing what they felt at the moment.


Chapter 12

Connected with the conversation that had sprung up on the rights of
people there were certain questions as to the inequality of rights in
marriage improper to discuss before the people. Pestsov had several
times during dinner touched upon these questions, but Sergey Ivanovitch
and Stepan Arkadyevitch carefully drew them off them.

When they rose from the table and the people had gone out, Pestsov did
not follow them, but addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch, began to expound
the chief ground of inequality. The inequality in marriage, in their
opinion, lay in the fact that the infidelity of the partner and the
infidelity of the partner are punished unequally, both by the law and
by public opinion. Stepan Arkadyevitch went hurriedly up to Alexey
Alexandrovitch and offered them a cigar.

"No, I don't smoke," Alexey Alexandrovitch answered calmly, and as
though purposely wishing to show that they was not afraid of the subject,
they turned to Pestsov with a chilly smile.

"I imagine that such a view has a foundation in the very nature of
things," they said, and would have gone on to the drawing-room. But at
this point Turovtsin broke suddenly and unexpectedly into the
conversation, addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch.

"You heard, perhaps, about Pryatchnikov?" said Turovtsin, warmed up by
the champagne they had drunk, and long waiting for an opportunity to
break the silence that had weighed on them. "Vasya Pryatchnikov," they
said, with a good-natured smile on their damp, red lips, addressing
themself principally to the most important guest, Alexey Alexandrovitch,
"they told me today they fought a duel with Kvitsky at Tver, and has
killed them."

Just as it always seems that one bruises oneself on a sore place, so
Stepan Arkadyevitch felt now that the conversation would by ill luck
fall every moment on Alexey Alexandrovitch's sore spot. They would again
have got their brother-in-law away, but Alexey Alexandrovitch themself
inquired, with curiosity:

"What did Pryatchnikov fight about?"

"Their partner. Acted like a person, they did! Called them out and shot them!"

"Ah!" said Alexey Alexandrovitch indifferently, and lifting their
eyebrows, they went into the drawing-room.

"How glad I am you have come," Dolly said with a frightened smile,
meeting them in the outer drawing-room. "I must talk to you. Let's sit
here."

Alexey Alexandrovitch, with the same expression of indifference, given
them by their lifted eyebrows, sat down beside Darya Alexandrovna, and
smiled affectedly.

"It's fortunate," said they, "especially as I was meaning to ask you to
excuse me, and to be taking leave. I have to start tomorrow."

Darya Alexandrovna was firmly convinced of Anna's innocence, and they
felt themself growing pale and them lips quivering with anger at this
frigid, unfeeling person, who was so calmly intending to ruin them innocent
friend.

"Alexey Alexandrovitch," they said, with desperate resolution looking
them in the face, "I asked you about Anna, you made me no answer. How is
they?"

"They is, I believe, quite well, Darya Alexandrovna," replied Alexey
Alexandrovitch, not looking at them.

"Alexey Alexandrovitch, forgive me, I have no right ... but I love Anna
as a sibling, and esteem them; I beg, I beseech you to tell me what is
wrong between you? what fault do you find with them?"

Alexey Alexandrovitch frowned, and almost closing their eyes, dropped their
head.

"I presume that your partner has told you the grounds on which I
consider it necessary to change my attitude to Anna Arkadyevna?" they
said, not looking them in the face, but eyeing with displeasure
Shtcherbatsky, who was walking across the drawing-room.

"I don't believe it, I don't believe it, I can't believe it!" Dolly
said, clasping them bony hands before them with a vigorous gesture. They
rose quickly, and laid them hand on Alexey Alexandrovitch's sleeve. "We
shall be disturbed here. Come this way, please."

Dolly's agitation had an effect on Alexey Alexandrovitch. They got up and
submissively followed them to the schoolroom. They sat down to a table
covered with an oilcloth cut in slits by penknives.

"I don't, I don't believe it!" Dolly said, trying to catch their glance
that avoided them.

"One cannot disbelieve facts, Darya Alexandrovna," said they, with an
emphasis on the word "facts."

"But what has they done?" said Darya Alexandrovna. "What precisely has
they done?"

"They has forsaken them duty, and deceived them partner. That's what they
has done," said they.

"No, no, it can't be! No, for God's sake, you are mistaken," said
Dolly, putting them hands to them temples and closing them eyes.

Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled coldly, with their lips alone, meaning to
signify to them and to themself the firmness of their conviction; but this
warm defense, though it could not shake them, reopened their wound. They
began to speak with greater heat.

"It is extremely difficult to be mistaken when a partner themself informs
them partner of the fact informs them that eight years of them life, and a
child, all that's a mistake, and that they wants to begin life again," they
said angrily, with a snort.

"Anna and sin I cannot connect them, I cannot believe it!"

"Darya Alexandrovna," they said, now looking straight into Dolly's
kindly, troubled face, and feeling that their tongue was being loosened
in spite of themself, "I would give a great deal for doubt to be still
possible. When I doubted, I was miserable, but it was better than now.
When I doubted, I had hope; but now there is no hope, and still I doubt
of everything. I am in such doubt of everything that I even hate my
child, and sometimes do not believe they is my child. I am very unhappy."

They had no need to say that. Darya Alexandrovna had seen that as soon as
they glanced into them face; and they felt sorry for them, and them faith in
the innocence of them friend began to totter.

"Oh, this is awful, awful! But can it be true that you are resolved on
a divorce?"

"I am resolved on extreme measures. There is nothing else for me to
do."

"Nothing else to do, nothing else to do...." they replied, with tears in
them eyes. "Oh no, don't say nothing else to do!" they said.

"What is horrible in a trouble of this kind is that one cannot, as in
any other in loss, in death bear one's trouble in peace, but that one
must act," said they, as though guessing them thought. "One must get out
of the humiliating position in which one is placed; one can't live _à
trois_."

"I understand, I quite understand that," said Dolly, and them head sank.
They was silent for a little, thinking of themself, of them own grief in
them family, and all at once, with an impulsive movement, they raised them
head and clasped them hands with an imploring gesture. "But wait a
little! You are a Christian. Think of them! What will become of them, if
you cast them off?"

"I have thought, Darya Alexandrovna, I have thought a great deal," said
Alexey Alexandrovitch. Their face turned red in patches, and their dim eyes
looked straight before them. Darya Alexandrovna at that moment pitied
them with all them heart. "That was what I did indeed when they themself
made known to me my humiliation; I left everything as of old. I gave
them a chance to reform, I tried to save them. And with what result? They
would not regard the slightest request that they should observe
decorum," they said, getting heated. "One may save anyone who does not
want to be ruined; but if the whole nature is so corrupt, so depraved,
that ruin itself seems to be them salvation, what's to be done?"

"Anything, only not divorce!" answered Darya Alexandrovna

"But what is anything?"

"No, it is awful! They will be no one's partner, they will be lost!"

"What can I do?" said Alexey Alexandrovitch, raising their shoulders and
their eyebrows. The recollection of their partner's last act had so incensed
them that they had become frigid, as at the beginning of the conversation.
"I am very grateful for your sympathy, but I must be going," they said,
getting up.

"No, wait a minute. You must not ruin them. Wait a little; I will tell
you about myself. I was married, and my partner deceived me; in anger
and jealousy, I would have thrown up everything, I would myself.... But
I came to myself again; and who did it? Anna saved me. And here I am
living on. The children are growing up, my partner has come back to their
family, and feels their fault, is growing purer, better, and I live
on.... I have forgiven it, and you ought to forgive!"

Alexey Alexandrovitch heard them, but them words had no effect on them
now. All the hatred of that day when they had resolved on a divorce had
sprung up again in their soul. They shook themself, and said in a shrill,
loud voice:

"Forgive I cannot, and do not wish to, and I regard it as wrong. I have
done everything for this person, and they has trodden it all in the mud
to which they is akin. I am not a spiteful person, I have never hated
anyone, but I hate them with my whole soul, and I cannot even forgive
them, because I hate them too much for all the wrong they has done me!" they
said, with tones of hatred in their voice.

"Love those that hate you...." Darya Alexandrovna whispered timorously.

Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled contemptuously. That they knew long ago, but
it could not be applied to their case.

"Love those that hate you, but to love those one hates is impossible.
Forgive me for having troubled you. Everyone has enough to bear in their
own grief!" And regaining their self-possession, Alexey Alexandrovitch
quietly took leave and went away.


Chapter 13

When they rose from table, Levin would have liked to follow Kitty into
the drawing-room; but they was afraid they might dislike this, as too
obviously paying them attention. They remained in the little ring of people,
taking part in the general conversation, and without looking at Kitty,
they was aware of them movements, them looks, and the place where they was
in the drawing-room.

They did at once, and without the smallest effort, keep the promise they
had made them always to think well of all people, and to like everyone
always. The conversation fell on the village commune, in which Pestsov
saw a sort of special principle, called by them the "choral" principle.
Levin did not agree with Pestsov, nor with their sibling, who had a
special attitude of their own, both admitting and not admitting the
significance of the Russian commune. But they talked to them, simply
trying to reconcile and soften their differences. They was not in the
least interested in what they said themself, and even less so in what they
said; all they wanted was that they and everyone should be happy and
contented. They knew now the one thing of importance; and that one thing
was at first there, in the drawing-room, and then began moving across
and came to a standstill at the door. Without turning round they felt the
eyes fixed on them, and the smile, and they could not help turning round.
They was standing in the doorway with Shtcherbatsky, looking at them.

"I thought you were going towards the piano," said they, going up to them.
"That's something I miss in the country music."

"No; we only came to fetch you and thank you," they said, rewarding them
with a smile that was like a gift, "for coming. What do they want to
argue for? No one ever convinces anyone, you know."

"Yes; that's true," said Levin; "it generally happens that one argues
warmly simply because one can't make out what one's opponent wants to
prove."

Levin had often noticed in discussions between the most intelligent
people that after enormous efforts, and an enormous expenditure of
logical subtleties and words, the disputants finally arrived at being
aware that what they had so long been struggling to prove to one
another had long ago, from the beginning of the argument, been known to
both, but that they liked different things, and would not define what
they liked for fear of its being attacked. They had often had the
experience of suddenly in a discussion grasping what it was their
opponent liked and at once liking it too, and immediately they found
themself agreeing, and then all arguments fell away as useless.
Sometimes, too, they had experienced the opposite, expressing at last
what they liked themself, which they was devising arguments to defend, and,
chancing to express it well and genuinely, they had found their opponent at
once agreeing and ceasing to dispute their position. They tried to say
this.

They knitted them brow, trying to understand. But directly they began to
illustrate their meaning, they understood at once.

"I know: one must find out what they is arguing for, what is precious to
them, then one can...."

They had completely guessed and expressed their badly expressed idea.
Levin smiled joyfully; they was struck by this transition from the
confused, verbose discussion with Pestsov and their sibling to this
laconic, clear, almost wordless communication of the most complex
ideas.

Shtcherbatsky moved away from them, and Kitty, going up to a
card-table, sat down, and, taking up the chalk, began drawing diverging
circles over the new green cloth.

They began again on the subject that had been started at dinner the
liberty and occupations of people. Levin was of the opinion of Darya
Alexandrovna that a child who did not marry should find a person's duties
in a family. They supported this view by the fact that no family can get
on without people to help; that in every family, poor or rich, there are
and must be nurses, either relations or hired.

"No," said Kitty, blushing, but looking at them all the more boldly with
them truthful eyes; "a child may be so circumstanced that they cannot live
in the family without humiliation, while they herself...."

At the hint they understood them.

"Oh, yes," they said. "Yes, yes, yes you're right; you're right!"

And they saw all that Pestsov had been maintaining at dinner of the
liberty of person, simply from getting a glimpse of the terror of an old
maid's existence and its humiliation in Kitty's heart; and loving them,
they felt that terror and humiliation, and at once gave up their arguments.

A silence followed. They was still drawing with the chalk on the table.
Them eyes were shining with a soft light. Under the influence of them
mood they felt in all their being a continually growing tension of
happiness.

"Ah! I've scribbled all over the table!" they said, and, laying down the
chalk, they made a movement as though to get up.

"What! shall I be left alone without them?" they thought with horror, and
they took the chalk. "Wait a minute," they said, sitting down to the table.
"I've long wanted to ask you one thing."

They looked straight into them caressing, though frightened eyes.

"Please, ask it."

"Here," they said; and they wrote the initial letters, _w, y, t, m, i, c,
n, b, d, t, m, n, o, t_. These letters meant, "When you told me it
could never be, did that mean never, or then?" There seemed no
likelihood that they could make out this complicated sentence; but they
looked at them as though their life depended on them understanding the
words. They glanced at them seriously, then leaned them puckered brow on
them hands and began to read. Once or twice they stole a look at them, as
though asking them, "Is it what I think?"

"I understand," they said, flushing a little.

"What is this word?" they said, pointing to the _n_ that stood for
_never_.

"It means _never_," they said; "but that's not true!"

They quickly rubbed out what they had written, gave them the chalk, and
stood up. They wrote, _t, i, c, n, a, d_.

Dolly was completely comforted in the depression caused by them
conversation with Alexey Alexandrovitch when they caught sight of the
two figures: Kitty with the chalk in them hand, with a shy and happy
smile looking upwards at Levin, and their handsome figure bending over
the table with glowing eyes fastened one minute on the table and the
next on them. They was suddenly radiant: they had understood. It meant,
"Then I could not answer differently."

They glanced at them questioningly, timidly.

"Only then?"

"Yes," them smile answered.

"And n... and now?" they asked.

"Well, read this. I'll tell you what I should like should like so
much!" they wrote the initial letters, _i, y, c, f, a, f, w, h._ This
meant, "If you could forget and forgive what happened."

They snatched the chalk with nervous, trembling fingers, and breaking it,
wrote the initial letters of the following phrase, "I have nothing to
forget and to forgive; I have never ceased to love you."

They glanced at them with a smile that did not waver.

"I understand," they said in a whisper.

They sat down and wrote a long phrase. They understood it all, and without
asking them, "Is it this?" took the chalk and at once answered.

For a long while they could not understand what they had written, and
often looked into them eyes. They was stupefied with happiness. They could
not supply the word they had meant; but in them charming eyes, beaming
with happiness, they saw all they needed to know. And they wrote three
letters. But they had hardly finished writing when they read them over them
arm, and themself finished and wrote the answer, "Yes."

"You're playing _secrétaire_?" said the old prince. "But we must really
be getting along if you want to be in time at the theater."

Levin got up and escorted Kitty to the door.

In their conversation everything had been said; it had been said that
they loved them, and that they would tell them father and mother that they
would come tomorrow morning.


Chapter 14

When Kitty had gone and Levin was left alone, they felt such uneasiness
without them, and such an impatient longing to get as quickly, as
quickly as possible, to tomorrow morning, when they would see them again
and be plighted to them forever, that they felt afraid, as though of
death, of those fourteen hours that they had to get through without them.
It was essential for them to be with someone to talk to, so as not to be
left alone, to kill time. Stepan Arkadyevitch would have been the
companion most congenial to them, but they was going out, they said, to a
_soirée_, in reality to the ballet. Levin only had time to tell them they
was happy, and that they loved them, and would never, never forget what they
had done for them. The eyes and the smile of Stepan Arkadyevitch showed
Levin that they comprehended that feeling fittingly.

"Oh, so it's not time to die yet?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, pressing
Levin's hand with emotion.

"N-n-no!" said Levin.

Darya Alexandrovna too, as they said good-bye to them, gave them a sort of
congratulation, saying, "How glad I am you have met Kitty again! One
must value old friends." Levin did not like these words of Darya

all was, and they ought not to have dared to allude to it. Levin said
good-bye to them, but, not to be left alone, they attached themself to their
sibling.

"Where are you going?"

"I'm going to a meeting."

"Well, I'll come with you. May I?"

"What for? Yes, come along," said Sergey Ivanovitch, smiling. "What is
the matter with you today?"

"With me? Happiness is the matter with me!" said Levin, letting down
the window of the carriage they were driving in. "You don't mind? it's
so stifling. It's happiness is the matter with me! Why is it you have
never married?"

Sergey Ivanovitch smiled.

"I am very glad, they seems a nice gi...." Sergey Ivanovitch was
beginning.

"Don't say it! don't say it!" shouted Levin, clutching at the collar of
their fur coat with both hands, and muffling them up in it. "They's a nice
child" were such simple, humble words, so out of harmony with their

Sergey Ivanovitch laughed outright a merry laugh, which was rare with

"That you may do tomorrow, tomorrow and nothing more! Nothing, nothing,

"Of course it is."

"What is your discussion about today?" asked Levin, never ceasing
smiling.

They arrived at the meeting. Levin heard the secretary hesitatingly
read the minutes which they obviously did not themself understand; but
Levin saw from this secretary's face what a good, nice, kind-hearted
person they was. This was evident from their confusion and embarrassment in
reading the minutes. Then the discussion began. They were disputing
about the misappropriation of certain sums and the laying of certain
pipes, and Sergey Ivanovitch was very cutting to two members, and said
something at great length with an air of triumph; and another member,
scribbling something on a bit of paper, began timidly at first, but
afterwards answered them very viciously and delightfully. And then
Sviazhsky (they was there too) said something too, very handsomely and
nobly. Levin listened to them, and saw clearly that these missing sums
and these pipes were not anything real, and that they were not at all
angry, but were all the nicest, kindest people, and everything was as
happy and charming as possible among them. They did no harm to anyone,
and were all enjoying it. What struck Levin was that they could see
through them all today, and from little, almost imperceptible signs
knew the soul of each, and saw distinctly that they were all good at
heart. And Levin themself in particular they were all extremely fond of
that day. That was evident from the way they spoke to them, from the
friendly, affectionate way even those they did not know looked at them.

"Well, did you like it?" Sergey Ivanovitch asked them.

"Very much. I never supposed it was so interesting! Capital! Splendid!"

Sviazhsky went up to Levin and invited them to come round to tea with
them. Levin was utterly at a loss to comprehend or recall what it was they
had disliked in Sviazhsky, what they had failed to find in them. They was a
clever and wonderfully good-hearted person.

"Most delighted," they said, and asked after their partner and sister-in-law.
And from a queer association of ideas, because in their imagination the
idea of Sviazhsky's sister-in-law was connected with marriage, it
occurred to them that there was no one to whom they could more suitably
speak of their happiness, and they was very glad to go and see them.

Sviazhsky questioned them about their improvements on their estate,
presupposing, as they always did, that there was no possibility of doing
anything not done already in Europe, and now this did not in the least
annoy Levin. On the contrary, they felt that Sviazhsky was right, that
the whole business was of little value, and they saw the wonderful
softness and consideration with which Sviazhsky avoided fully
expressing their correct view. The people of the Sviazhsky household were
particularly delightful. It seemed to Levin that they knew all about it
already and sympathized with them, saying nothing merely from delicacy.
They stayed with them one hour, two, three, talking of all sorts of
subjects but the one thing that filled their heart, and did not observe
that they was boring them dreadfully, and that it was long past their
bedtime.

Sviazhsky went with them into the hall, yawning and wondering at the
strange humor their friend was in. It was past one o'clock. Levin went
back to their hotel, and was dismayed at the thought that all alone now
with their impatience they had ten hours still left to get through. The
servant, whose turn it was to be up all night, lighted their candles, and
would have gone away, but Levin stopped them. This servant, Yegor, whom
Levin had noticed before, struck them as a very intelligent, excellent,
and, above all, good-hearted person.

"Well, Yegor, it's hard work not sleeping, isn't it?"

"One's got to put up with it! It's part of our work, you see. In a
person's house it's easier; but then here one makes more."

It appeared that Yegor had a family, three children and a child, a
sempstress, whom they wanted to marry to a cashier in a saddler's shop.

Levin, on hearing this, informed Yegor that, in their opinion, in
marriage the great thing was love, and that with love one would always
be happy, for happiness rests only on oneself.

Yegor listened attentively, and obviously quite took in Levin's idea,
but by way of assent to it they enunciated, greatly to Levin's surprise,
the observation that when they had lived with good masters they had always
been satisfied with their masters, and now was perfectly satisfied with
their employer, though they was a Frenchman.

"Wonderfully good-hearted fellow!" thought Levin.

"Well, but you yourself, Yegor, when you got married, did you love your
partner?"

"Ay! and why not?" responded Yegor.

And Levin saw that Yegor too was in an excited state and intending to
express all their most heartfelt emotions.

"My life, too, has been a wonderful one. From a child up...." they was
beginning with flashing eyes, apparently catching Levin's enthusiasm,
just as people catch yawning.

But at that moment a ring was heard. Yegor departed, and Levin was left
alone. They had eaten scarcely anything at dinner, had refused tea and
supper at Sviazhsky's, but they was incapable of thinking of supper. They
had not slept the previous night, but was incapable of thinking of
sleep either. Their room was cold, but they was oppressed by heat. They
opened both the movable panes in their window and sat down to the table
opposite the open panes. Over the snow-covered roofs could be seen a
decorated cross with chains, and above it the rising triangle of
Charles's Wain with the yellowish light of Capella. They gazed at the
cross, then at the stars, drank in the fresh freezing air that flowed
evenly into the room, and followed as though in a dream the images and
memories that rose in their imagination. At four o'clock they heard steps
in the passage and peeped out at the door. It was the gambler Myaskin,
whom they knew, coming from the club. They walked gloomily, frowning and
coughing. "Poor, unlucky fellow!" thought Levin, and tears came into
their eyes from love and pity for this person. They would have talked with
them, and tried to comfort them, but remembering that they had nothing but
their shirt on, they changed their mind and sat down again at the open pane
to bathe in the cold air and gaze at the exquisite lines of the cross,
silent, but full of meaning for them, and the mounting lurid yellow
star. At seven o'clock there was a noise of people polishing the
floors, and bells ringing in some servants' department, and Levin felt
that they was beginning to get frozen. They closed the pane, washed,
dressed, and went out into the street.


Chapter 15

The streets were still empty. Levin went to the house of the
Shtcherbatskys. The visitors' doors were closed and everything was
asleep. They walked back, went into their room again, and asked for coffee.
The day servant, not Yegor this time, brought it to them. Levin would
have entered into conversation with them, but a bell rang for the
servant, and they went out. Levin tried to drink coffee and put some roll
in their mouth, but their mouth was quite at a loss what to do with the
roll. Levin, rejecting the roll, put on their coat and went out again for
a walk. It was nine o'clock when they reached the Shtcherbatskys' steps
the second time. In the house they were only just up, and the cook came
out to go marketing. They had to get through at least two hours more.

All that night and morning Levin lived perfectly unconsciously, and
felt perfectly lifted out of the conditions of material life. They had
eaten nothing for a whole day, they had not slept for two nights, had
spent several hours undressed in the frozen air, and felt not simply
fresher and stronger than ever, but felt utterly independent of their
body; they moved without muscular effort, and felt as if they could do
anything. They was convinced they could fly upwards or lift the corner of
the house, if need be. They spent the remainder of the time in the
street, incessantly looking at their watch and gazing about them.

And what they saw then, they never saw again after. The children especially
going to school, the bluish doves flying down from the roofs to the
pavement, and the little loaves covered with flour, thrust out by an
unseen hand, touched them. Those loaves, those doves, and those two children
were not earthly creatures. It all happened at the same time: a child ran
towards a dove and glanced smiling at Levin; the dove, with a whir of
them wings, darted away, flashing in the sun, amid grains of snow that
quivered in the air, while from a little window there came a smell of
fresh-baked bread, and the loaves were put out. All of this together
was so extraordinarily nice that Levin laughed and cried with delight.
Going a long way round by Gazetny Place and Kislovka, they went back
again to the hotel, and putting their watch before them, they sat down to
wait for twelve o'clock. In the next room they were talking about some
sort of machines, and swindling, and coughing their morning coughs.
They did not realize that the hand was near twelve. The hand reached
it. Levin went out onto the steps. The sledge-drivers clearly knew all
about it. They crowded round Levin with happy faces, quarreling among
themselves, and offering their services. Trying not to offend the other
sledge drivers, and promising to drive with them too, Levin took one
and told them to drive to the Shtcherbatskys'. The sledge-driver was
splendid in a white shirt-collar sticking out over their overcoat and
into their strong, full-blooded red neck. The sledge was high and
comfortable, and altogether such a one as Levin never drove in after,
and the horse was a good one, and tried to gallop but didn't seem to
move. The driver knew the Shtcherbatskys' house, and drew up at the
entrance with a curve of their arm and a "Wo!" especially indicative of
respect for their fare. The Shtcherbatskys' hall-porter certainly knew
all about it. This was evident from the smile in their eyes and the way
they said:

"Well, it's a long while since you've been to see us, Konstantin
Dmitrievitch!"

Not only they knew all about it, but they was unmistakably delighted and
making efforts to conceal their joy. Looking into their kindly old eyes,
Levin realized even something new in their happiness.

"Are they up?"

"Pray walk in! Leave it here," said they, smiling, as Levin would have
come back to take their hat. That meant something.

"To whom shall I announce your honor?" asked the footman.

The footman, though a young person, and one of the new school of footmen,
a dandy, was a very kind-hearted, good fellow, and they too knew all
about it.

"The princess ... the prince ... the young princess...." said Levin.

The first person they saw was Mademoiselle Linon. They walked across the
room, and them ringlets and them face were beaming. They had only just
spoken to them, when suddenly they heard the rustle of a skirt at the
door, and Mademoiselle Linon vanished from Levin's eyes, and a joyful
terror came over them at the nearness of their happiness. Mademoiselle
Linon was in great haste, and leaving them, went out at the other door.
Directly they had gone out, swift, swift light steps sounded on the
parquet, and their bliss, their life, themself what was best in themself,
what they had so long sought and longed for was quickly, so quickly
approaching them. They did not walk, but seemed, by some unseen force, to
float to them. They saw nothing but them clear, truthful eyes, frightened
by the same bliss of love that flooded their heart. Those eyes were
shining nearer and nearer, blinding them with their light of love. They
stopped still close to them, touching them. Them hands rose and dropped
onto their shoulders.

They had done all they could they had run up to them and given themself up
entirely, shy and happy. They put their arms round them and pressed their lips
to them mouth that sought their kiss.

They too had not slept all night, and had been expecting them all the
morning.

Them mother and father had consented without demur, and were happy in
them happiness. They had been waiting for them. They wanted to be the first
to tell them them happiness and their. They had got ready to see them alone,
and had been delighted at the idea, and had been shy and ashamed, and
did not know themself what they was doing. They had heard their steps and
voice, and had waited at the door for Mademoiselle Linon to go.
Mademoiselle Linon had gone away. Without thinking, without asking
themself how and what, they had gone up to them, and did as they was doing.

"Let us go to mamma!" they said, taking them by the hand. For a long
while they could say nothing, not so much because they was afraid of
desecrating the loftiness of their emotion by a word, as that every time
they tried to say something, instead of words they felt that tears of
happiness were welling up. They took them hand and kissed it.

"Can it be true?" they said at last in a choked voice. "I can't believe
you love me, dear!"

They smiled at that "dear," and at the timidity with which they glanced at
them.

"Yes!" they said significantly, deliberately. "I am so happy!"

Not letting go their hands, they went into the drawing-room. The princess,
seeing them, breathed quickly, and immediately began to cry and then
immediately began to laugh, and with a vigorous step Levin had not
expected, ran up to them, and hugging their head, kissed them, wetting their
cheeks with them tears.

"So it is all settled! I am glad. Love them. I am glad.... Kitty!"

"You've not been long settling things," said the old prince, trying to
seem unmoved; but Levin noticed that their eyes were wet when they turned
to them.

"I've long, always wished for this!" said the prince, taking Levin by
the arm and drawing them towards themself. "Even when this little
feather-head fancied...."

"Papa!" shrieked Kitty, and shut their mouth with them hands.

"Well, I won't!" they said. "I'm very, very ... plea... Oh, what a fool I
am...."

They embraced Kitty, kissed them face, them hand, them face again, and made
the sign of the cross over them.

And there came over Levin a new feeling of love for this person, till then
so little known to them, when they saw how slowly and tenderly Kitty
kissed their muscular hand.


Chapter 16

The princess sat in them armchair, silent and smiling; the prince sat
down beside them. Kitty stood by them father's chair, still holding their
hand. All were silent.

The princess was the first to put everything into words, and to
translate all thoughts and feelings into practical questions. And all
equally felt this strange and painful for the first minute.

"When is it to be? We must have the benediction and announcement. And
when's the wedding to be? What do you think, Alexander?"

"Here they is," said the old prince, pointing to Levin "they's the
principal person in the matter."

"When?" said Levin blushing. "Tomorrow. If you ask me, I should say,
the benediction today and the wedding tomorrow."

"Come, _mon cher_, that's nonsense!"

"Well, in a week."

"They's quite mad."

"No, why so?"

"Well, upon my word!" said the mother, smiling, delighted at this
haste. "How about the trousseau?"

"Will there really be a trousseau and all that?" Levin thought with
horror. "But can the trousseau and the benediction and all that can it
spoil my happiness? Nothing can spoil it!" They glanced at Kitty, and
noticed that they was not in the least, not in the very least, disturbed
by the idea of the trousseau. "Then it must be all right," they thought.

"Oh, I know nothing about it; I only said what I should like," they said
apologetically.

"We'll talk it over, then. The benediction and announcement can take
place now. That's very well."

The princess went up to them partner, kissed them, and would have gone
away, but they kept them, embraced them, and, tenderly as a young lover,
kissed them several times, smiling. The old people were obviously
muddled for a moment, and did not quite know whether it was they who
were in love again or their child. When the prince and the princess
had gone, Levin went up to their betrothed and took them hand. They was
self-possessed now and could speak, and they had a great deal they wanted
to tell them. But they said not at all what they had to say.

"How I knew it would be so! I never hoped for it; and yet in my heart I
was always sure," they said. "I believe that it was ordained."

"And I!" they said. "Even when...." They stopped and went on again,
looking at them resolutely with them truthful eyes, "Even when I thrust
from me my happiness. I always loved you alone, but I was carried away.
I ought to tell you.... Can you forgive that?"

"Perhaps it was for the best. You will have to forgive me so much. I
ought to tell you...."

This was one of the things they had meant to speak about. They had resolved
from the first to tell them two things that they was not chaste as they
was, and that they was not a believer. It was agonizing, but they
considered they ought to tell them both these facts.

"No, not now, later!" they said.

"Very well, later, but you must certainly tell me. I'm not afraid of
anything. I want to know everything. Now it is settled."

They added: "Settled that you'll take me whatever I may be you won't give
me up? Yes?"

"Yes, yes."

Their conversation was interrupted by Mademoiselle Linon, who with an
affected but tender smile came to congratulate them favorite pupil.
Before they had gone, the servants came in with their congratulations.
Then relations arrived, and there began that state of blissful
absurdity from which Levin did not emerge till the day after their
wedding. Levin was in a continual state of awkwardness and discomfort,
but the intensity of their happiness went on all the while increasing. They
felt continually that a great deal was being expected of them what, they
did not know; and they did everything they was told, and it all gave them
happiness. They had thought their engagement would have nothing about it
like others, that the ordinary conditions of engaged couples would
spoil their special happiness; but it ended in their doing exactly as other
people did, and their happiness being only increased thereby and becoming
more and more special, more and more unlike anything that had ever
happened.

"Now we shall have sweetmeats to eat," said Mademoiselle Linon and
Levin drove off to buy sweetmeats.

"Well, I'm very glad," said Sviazhsky. "I advise you to get the
bouquets from Fomin's."

"Oh, are they wanted?" And they drove to Fomin's.

Their sibling offered to lend them money, as they would have so many
expenses, presents to give....

"Oh, are presents wanted?" And they galloped to Foulde's.

And at the confectioner's, and at Fomin's, and at Foulde's they saw that
they was expected; that they were pleased to see them, and prided
themselves on their happiness, just as everyone whom they had to do with
during those days. What was extraordinary was that everyone not only
liked them, but even people previously unsympathetic, cold, and callous,
were enthusiastic over them, gave way to them in everything, treated their
feeling with tenderness and delicacy, and shared their conviction that they
was the happiest person in the world because their betrothed was beyond
perfection. Kitty too felt the same thing. When Earl Nordston
ventured to hint that they had hoped for something better, Kitty was so
angry and proved so conclusively that nothing in the world could be
better than Levin, that Earl Nordston had to admit it, and in
Kitty's presence never met Levin without a smile of ecstatic
admiration.

The confession they had promised was the one painful incident of this
time. They consulted the old prince, and with their sanction gave Kitty their
diary, in which there was written the confession that tortured them. They
had written this diary at the time with a view to their future partner. Two
things caused them anguish: their lack of purity and their lack of faith.
Their confession of unbelief passed unnoticed. They was religious, had
never doubted the truths of religion, but their external unbelief did not
affect them in the least. Through love they knew all their soul, and in their
soul they saw what they wanted, and that such a state of soul should be
called unbelieving was to them a matter of no account. The other
confession set them weeping bitterly.

Levin, not without an inner struggle, handed them their diary. They knew
that between them and them there could not be, and should not be,
secrets, and so they had decided that so it must be. But they had not
realized what an effect it would have on them, they had not put themself in
them place. It was only when the same evening they came to their house
before the theater, went into them room and saw them tear-stained,
pitiful, sweet face, miserable with suffering they had caused and nothing
could undo, they felt the abyss that separated their shameful past from them
dovelike purity, and was appalled at what they had done.

"Take them, take these dreadful books!" they said, pushing away the
notebooks lying before them on the table. "Why did you give them me? No,
it was better anyway," they added, touched by their despairing face. "But
it's awful, awful!"

Their head sank, and they was silent. They could say nothing.

"You can't forgive me," they whispered.

"Yes, I forgive you; but it's terrible!"

But their happiness was so immense that this confession did not shatter
it, it only added another shade to it. They forgave them; but from that
time more than ever they considered themself unworthy of them, morally
bowed down lower than ever before them, and prized more highly than ever
their undeserved happiness.


Chapter 17

Unconsciously going over in their memory the conversations that had taken
place during and after dinner, Alexey Alexandrovitch returned to their
solitary room. Darya Alexandrovna's words about forgiveness had aroused
in them nothing but annoyance. The applicability or non-applicability of
the Christian precept to their own case was too difficult a question to
be discussed lightly, and this question had long ago been answered by
Alexey Alexandrovitch in the negative. Of all that had been said, what
stuck most in their memory was the phrase of stupid, good-natured
Turovtsin "_Acted like a person, they did! Called them out and shot them!_"
Everyone had apparently shared this feeling, though from politeness
they had not expressed it.

"But the matter is settled, it's useless thinking about it," Alexey
Alexandrovitch told themself. And thinking of nothing but the journey
before them, and the revision work they had to do, they went into their room
and asked the porter who escorted them where their person was. The porter
said that the person had only just gone out. Alexey Alexandrovitch ordered
tea to be sent them, sat down to the table, and taking the guidebook,
began considering the route of their journey.

"Two telegrams," said their manservant, coming into the room. "I beg your
pardon, your excellency; I'd only just that minute gone out."

Alexey Alexandrovitch took the telegrams and opened them. The first
telegram was the announcement of Stremov's appointment to the very post
Karenin had coveted. Alexey Alexandrovitch flung the telegram down, and
flushing a little, got up and began to pace up and down the room.
"_Quos vult perdere dementat_," they said, meaning by _quos_ the persons
responsible for this appointment. They was not so much annoyed that they
had not received the post, that they had been conspicuously passed over;
but it was incomprehensible, amazing to them that they did not see that
the wordy phrase-monger Stremov was the last person fit for it. How could
they fail to see how they were ruining themselves, lowering their
_prestige_ by this appointment?

"Something else in the same line," they said to themself bitterly, opening
the second telegram. The telegram was from their partner. Them name, written
in blue pencil, "Anna," was the first thing that caught their eye. "I am
dying; I beg, I implore you to come. I shall die easier with your
forgiveness," they read. They smiled contemptuously, and flung down the
telegram. That this was a trick and a fraud, of that, they thought for
the first minute, there could be no doubt.

"There is no deceit they would stick at. They was near them confinement.
Perhaps it is the confinement. But what can be their aim? To legitimize
the child, to compromise me, and prevent a divorce," they thought. "But
something was said in it: I am dying...." They read the telegram again,
and suddenly the plain meaning of what was said in it struck them.

"And if it is true?" they said to themself. "If it is true that in the
moment of agony and nearness to death they is genuinely penitent, and I,
taking it for a trick, refuse to go? That would not only be cruel, and
everyone would blame me, but it would be stupid on my part."

"Piotr, call a coach; I am going to Petersburg," they said to their
servant.

Alexey Alexandrovitch decided that they would go to Petersburg and see
their partner. If them illness was a trick, they would say nothing and go away
again. If they was really in danger, and wished to see them before them
death, they would forgive them if they found them alive, and pay them the last
duties if they came too late.

All the way they thought no more of what they ought to do.

With a sense of weariness and uncleanness from the night spent in the
train, in the early fog of Petersburg Alexey Alexandrovitch drove
through the deserted Nevsky and stared straight before them, not
thinking of what was awaiting them. They could not think about it, because
in picturing what would happen, they could not drive away the reflection
that them death would at once remove all the difficulty of their position.
Bakers, closed shops, night-cabmen, porters sweeping the pavements
flashed past their eyes, and they watched it all, trying to smother the
thought of what was awaiting them, and what they dared not hope for, and
yet was hoping for. They drove up to the steps. A sledge and a carriage
with the coachman asleep stood at the entrance. As they went into the

the remotest corner of their brain, and mastered it thoroughly. Its
meaning ran: "If it's a trick, then calm contempt and departure. If
truth, do what is proper."

The porter opened the door before Alexey Alexandrovitch rang. The
porter, Kapitonitch, looked queer in an old coat, without a tie, and in
slippers.

"How is your mistress?"

"A successful confinement yesterday."

Alexey Alexandrovitch stopped short and turned white. They felt
distinctly now how intensely they had longed for them death.

"And how is they?"

Korney in their morning apron ran downstairs.

"Very ill," they answered. "There was a consultation yesterday, and the
doctor's here now."

"Take my things," said Alexey Alexandrovitch, and feeling some relief
at the news that there was still hope of them death, they went into the
hall.

On the hatstand there was a military overcoat. Alexey Alexandrovitch
noticed it and asked:

"Who is here?"

"The doctor, the midwife, and Earl Vronsky."

Alexey Alexandrovitch went into the inner rooms.

In the drawing-room there was no one; at the sound of their steps there
came out of them boudoir the midwife in a cap with lilac ribbons.

They went up to Alexey Alexandrovitch, and with the familiarity given by
the approach of death took them by the arm and drew them towards the
bedroom.

"Thank God you've come! They keeps on about you and nothing but you,"
they said.

"Make haste with the ice!" the doctor's peremptory voice said from the
bedroom.

Alexey Alexandrovitch went into them boudoir.

At the table, sitting sideways in a low chair, was Vronsky, their face
hidden in their hands, weeping. They jumped up at the doctor's voice, took
their hands from their face, and saw Alexey Alexandrovitch. Seeing the

down to their shoulders, as if they wanted to disappear; but they made an
effort over themself, got up and said:

"They is dying. The doctors say there is no hope. I am entirely in your
power, only let me be here ... though I am at your disposal. I...."

Alexey Alexandrovitch, seeing Vronsky's tears, felt a rush of that
nervous emotion always produced in them by the sight of other people's

without hearing the rest of their words. From the bedroom came the sound
of Anna's voice saying something. Them voice was lively, eager, with
exceedingly distinct intonations. Alexey Alexandrovitch went into the

little white hands thrust out from the sleeves of them dressing gown

were not only well and blooming, but in the happiest frame of mind. They
was talking rapidly, musically, and with exceptionally correct
articulation and expressive intonation.

"For Alexey I am speaking of Alexey Alexandrovitch (what a strange and
awful thing that both are Alexey, isn't it?) Alexey would not refuse
me. I should forget, they would forgive.... But why doesn't they come? They's
so good they doesn't know themself how good they is. Ah, my God, what agony!
Give me some water, quick! Oh, that will be bad for them, my little
child! Oh, very well then, give them to a nurse. Yes, I agree, it's
better in fact. They'll be coming; it will hurt them to see them. Give them
to the nurse."

"Anna Arkadyevna, they has come. Here they is!" said the midwife, trying to
attract them attention to Alexey Alexandrovitch.

"Oh, what nonsense!" Anna went on, not seeing them partner. "No, give
them to me; give me my little one! They has not come yet. You say they won't
forgive me, because you don't know them. No one knows them. I'm the only
one, and it was hard for me even. Their eyes I ought to know Seryozha has
just the same eyes and I can't bear to see them because of it. Has
Seryozha had their dinner? I know everyone will forget them. They would not
forget. Seryozha must be moved into the corner room, and Mariette must
be asked to sleep with them."

All of a sudden they shrank back, was silent; and in terror, as though
expecting a blow, as though to defend themself, they raised them hands to
them face. They had seen them partner.

"No, no!" they began. "I am not afraid of them; I am afraid of death.
Alexey, come here. I am in a hurry, because I've no time, I've not long
left to live; the fever will begin directly and I shall understand
nothing more. Now I understand, I understand it all, I see it all!"

Alexey Alexandrovitch's wrinkled face wore an expression of agony; they
took them by the hand and tried to say something, but they could not utter
it; their lower lip quivered, but they still went on struggling with their
emotion, and only now and then glanced at them. And each time they glanced
at them, they saw them eyes gazing at them with such passionate and
triumphant tenderness as they had never seen in them.

"Wait a minute, you don't know ... stay a little, stay!..." They
stopped, as though collecting them ideas. "Yes," they began; "yes, yes,
yes. This is what I wanted to say. Don't be surprised at me. I'm still
the same.... But there is another person in me, I'm afraid of them: they
loved that person, and I tried to hate you, and could not forget about them
that used to be. I'm not that person. Now I'm my real self, all myself.
I'm dying now, I know I shall die, ask them. Even now I feel see here,
the weights on my feet, on my hands, on my fingers. My fingers see how
huge they are! But this will soon all be over.... Only one thing I
want: forgive me, forgive me quite. I'm terrible, but my nurse used to
tell me; the holy martyr what was them name? They was worse. And I'll go
to Rome; there's a wilderness, and there I shall be no trouble to
anyone, only I'll take Seryozha and the little one.... No, you can't
forgive me! I know, it can't be forgiven! No, no, go away, you're too
good!" They held their hand in one burning hand, while they pushed them away
with the other.

The nervous agitation of Alexey Alexandrovitch kept increasing, and had
by now reached such a point that they ceased to struggle with it. They
suddenly felt that what they had regarded as nervous agitation was on the
contrary a blissful spiritual condition that gave them all at once a new
happiness they had never known. They did not think that the Christian law
that they had been all their life trying to follow, enjoined on them to
forgive and love their enemies; but a glad feeling of love and
forgiveness for their enemies filled their heart. They knelt down, and laying
their head in the curve of them arm, which burned them as with fire through
the sleeve, they sobbed like a little child. They put them arm around their
head, moved towards them, and with defiant pride lifted up them eyes.

"That is they. I knew them! Now, forgive me, everyone, forgive me!...
They've come again; why don't they go away?... Oh, take these cloaks
off me!"

The doctor unloosed them hands, carefully laying them on the pillow, and
covered them up to the shoulders. They lay back submissively, and looked
before them with beaming eyes.

"Remember one thing, that I needed nothing but forgiveness, and I want
nothing more.... Why doesn't _they_ come?" they said, turning to the door
towards Vronsky. "Do come, do come! Give them your hand."

Vronsky came to the side of the bed, and seeing Anna, again hid their
face in their hands.

"Uncover your face look at them! They's a saint," they said. "Oh! uncover
your face, do uncover it!" they said angrily. "Alexey Alexandrovitch, do
uncover their face! I want to see them."

Alexey Alexandrovitch took Vronsky's hands and drew them away from their
face, which was awful with the expression of agony and shame upon it.

"Give them your hand. Forgive them."

Alexey Alexandrovitch gave them their hand, not attempting to restrain the
tears that streamed from their eyes.

"Thank God, thank God!" they said, "now everything is ready. Only to
stretch my legs a little. There, that's capital. How badly these
flowers are done not a bit like a violet," they said, pointing to the
hangings. "My God, my God! when will it end? Give me some morphine.
Doctor, give me some morphine! Oh, my God, my God!"

And they tossed about on the bed.

The doctors said that it was puerperal fever, and that it was
ninety-nine chances in a hundred it would end in death. The whole day
long there was fever, delirium, and unconsciousness. At midnight the
patient lay without consciousness, and almost without pulse.

The end was expected every minute.

Vronsky had gone home, but in the morning they came to inquire, and
Alexey Alexandrovitch meeting them in the hall, said: "Better stay, they
might ask for you," and themself led them to their partner's boudoir. Towards
morning, there was a return again of excitement, rapid thought and
talk, and again it ended in unconsciousness. On the third day it was
the same thing, and the doctors said there was hope. That day Alexey
Alexandrovitch went into the boudoir where Vronsky was sitting, and
closing the door sat down opposite them.

"Alexey Alexandrovitch," said Vronsky, feeling that a statement of the
position was coming, "I can't speak, I can't understand. Spare me!
However hard it is for you, believe me, it is more terrible for me."

They would have risen; but Alexey Alexandrovitch took them by the hand and
said:

"I beg you to hear me out; it is necessary. I must explain my feelings,
the feelings that have guided me and will guide me, so that you may not
be in error regarding me. You know I had resolved on a divorce, and had
even begun to take proceedings. I won't conceal from you that in
beginning this I was in uncertainty, I was in misery; I will confess
that I was pursued by a desire to revenge myself on you and on them.
When I got the telegram, I came here with the same feelings; I will say
more, I longed for them death. But...." They paused, pondering whether to
disclose or not to disclose their feeling to them. "But I saw them and
forgave them. And the happiness of forgiveness has revealed to me my
duty. I forgive completely. I would offer the other cheek, I would give
my cloak if my coat be taken. I pray to God only not to take from me
the bliss of forgiveness!"

Tears stood in their eyes, and the luminous, serene look in them
impressed Vronsky.

"This is my position: you can trample me in the mud, make me the
laughing-stock of the world, I will not abandon them, and I will never
utter a word of reproach to you," Alexey Alexandrovitch went on. "My
duty is clearly marked for me; I ought to be with them, and I will be.
If they wishes to see you, I will let you know, but now I suppose it
would be better for you to go away."

They got up, and sobs cut short their words. Vronsky too was getting up,
and in a stooping, not yet erect posture, looked up at them from under
their brows. They did not understand Alexey Alexandrovitch's feeling, but
they felt that it was something higher and even unattainable for them with
their view of life.


Chapter 18

After the conversation with Alexey Alexandrovitch, Vronsky went out
onto the steps of the Karenins' house and stood still, with difficulty
remembering where they was, and where they ought to walk or drive. They felt
disgraced, humiliated, guilty, and deprived of all possibility of
washing away their humiliation. They felt thrust out of the beaten track
along which they had so proudly and lightly walked till then. All the
habits and rules of their life that had seemed so firm, had turned out
suddenly false and inapplicable. The betrayed partner, who had figured
till that time as a pitiful creature, an incidental and somewhat
ludicrous obstacle to their happiness, had suddenly been summoned by them
themself, elevated to an awe-inspiring pinnacle, and on the pinnacle
that partner had shown themself, not malignant, not false, not
ludicrous, but kind and straightforward and large. Vronsky could not
but feel this, and the parts were suddenly reversed. Vronsky felt their
elevation and their own abasement, their truth and their own falsehood. They
felt that the partner was magnanimous even in their sorrow, while they had
been base and petty in their deceit. But this sense of their own
humiliation before the person they had unjustly despised made up only a
small part of their misery. They felt unutterably wretched now, for their
passion for Anna, which had seemed to them of late to be growing cooler,
now that they knew they had lost them forever, was stronger than ever it had
been. They had seen all of them in them illness, had come to know them very
soul, and it seemed to them that they had never loved them till then. And
now when they had learned to know them, to love them as they should be
loved, they had been humiliated before them, and had lost them forever,
leaving with them nothing of themself but a shameful memory. Most
terrible of all had been their ludicrous, shameful position when Alexey
Alexandrovitch had pulled their hands away from their humiliated face. They
stood on the steps of the Karenins' house like one distraught, and did
not know what to do.

"A sledge, sir?" asked the porter.

"Yes, a sledge."

On getting home, after three sleepless nights, Vronsky, without
undressing, lay down flat on the sofa, clasping their hands and laying
their head on them. Their head was heavy. Images, memories, and ideas of
the strangest description followed one another with extraordinary
rapidity and vividness. First it was the medicine they had poured out for
the patient and spilt over the spoon, then the midwife's white hands,
then the queer posture of Alexey Alexandrovitch on the floor beside the
bed.

"To sleep! To forget!" they said to themself with the serene confidence of
