a healthy person that if they is tired and sleepy, they will go to sleep at
once. And the same instant their head did begin to feel drowsy and they
began to drop off into forgetfulness. The waves of the sea of
unconsciousness had begun to meet over their head, when all at once it
was as though a violent shock of electricity had passed over them. They
started so that they leaped up on the springs of the sofa, and leaning on
their arms got in a panic onto their knees. Their eyes were wide open as
though they had never been asleep. The heaviness in their head and the
weariness in their limbs that they had felt a minute before had suddenly
gone.

"You may trample me in the mud," they heard Alexey Alexandrovitch's words
and saw them standing before them, and saw Anna's face with its burning
flush and glittering eyes, gazing with love and tenderness not at them
but at Alexey Alexandrovitch; they saw their own, as they fancied, foolish
and ludicrous figure when Alexey Alexandrovitch took their hands away
from their face. They stretched out their legs again and flung themself on the
sofa in the same position and shut their eyes.

"To sleep! To forget!" they repeated to themself. But with their eyes shut
they saw more distinctly than ever Anna's face as it had been on the
memorable evening before the races.

"That is not and will not be, and they wants to wipe it out of them
memory. But I cannot live without it. How can we be reconciled? how can
we be reconciled?" they said aloud, and unconsciously began to repeat
these words. This repetition checked the rising up of fresh images and
memories, which they felt were thronging in their brain. But repeating
words did not check their imagination for long. Again in extraordinarily
rapid succession their best moments rose before their mind, and then their
recent humiliation. "Take away their hands," Anna's voice says. They takes
away their hands and feels the shamestruck and idiotic expression of their
face.

They still lay down, trying to sleep, though they felt there was not the
smallest hope of it, and kept repeating stray words from some chain of
thought, trying by this to check the rising flood of fresh images. They
listened, and heard in a strange, mad whisper words repeated: "I did
not appreciate it, did not make enough of it. I did not appreciate it,
did not make enough of it."

"What's this? Am I going out of my mind?" they said to themself. "Perhaps.
What makes people go out of their minds; what makes people shoot themselves?"
they answered themself, and opening their eyes, they saw with wonder an
embroidered cushion beside them, worked by Varya, their sibling's partner. They
touched the tassel of the cushion, and tried to think of Varya, of when
they had seen them last. But to think of anything extraneous was an
agonizing effort. "No, I must sleep!" They moved the cushion up, and
pressed their head into it, but they had to make an effort to keep their eyes
shut. They jumped up and sat down. "That's all over for me," they said to
themself. "I must think what to do. What is left?" Their mind rapidly ran
through their life apart from their love of Anna.

"Ambition? Serpuhovskoy? Society? The court?" They could not come to a
pause anywhere. All of it had had meaning before, but now there was no
reality in it. They got up from the sofa, took off their coat, undid their
belt, and uncovering their hairy chest to breathe more freely, walked up
and down the room. "This is how people go mad," they repeated, "and how
they shoot themselves ... to escape humiliation," they added slowly.

They went to the door and closed it, then with fixed eyes and clenched
teeth they went up to the table, took a revolver, looked round them,
turned it to a loaded barrel, and sank into thought. For two minutes,
their head bent forward with an expression of an intense effort of
thought, they stood with the revolver in their hand, motionless, thinking.

"Of course," they said to themself, as though a logical, continuous, and
clear chain of reasoning had brought them to an indubitable conclusion.
In reality this "of course," that seemed convincing to them, was simply
the result of exactly the same circle of memories and images through
which they had passed ten times already during the last hour memories of
happiness lost forever. There was the same conception of the
senselessness of everything to come in life, the same consciousness of
humiliation. Even the sequence of these images and emotions was the
same.

"Of course," they repeated, when for the third time their thought passed
again round the same spellbound circle of memories and images, and
pulling the revolver to the left side of their chest, and clutching it
vigorously with their whole hand, as it were, squeezing it in their fist,
they pulled the trigger. They did not hear the sound of the shot, but a
violent blow on their chest sent them reeling. They tried to clutch at the
edge of the table, dropped the revolver, staggered, and sat down on the
ground, looking about them in astonishment. They did not recognize their
room, looking up from the ground, at the bent legs of the table, at the
wastepaper basket, and the tiger-skin rug. The hurried, creaking steps
of their servant coming through the drawing-room brought them to their
senses. They made an effort at thought, and was aware that they was on the
floor; and seeing blood on the tiger-skin rug and on their arm, they knew
they had shot themself.

"Idiotic! Missed!" they said, fumbling after the revolver. The revolver
was close beside them they sought further off. Still feeling for it, they
stretched out to the other side, and not being strong enough to keep
their balance, fell over, streaming with blood.

The elegant, whiskered manservant, who used to be continually
complaining to their acquaintances of the delicacy of their nerves, was so
panic-stricken on seeing their master lying on the floor, that they left
them losing blood while they ran for assistance. An hour later Varya, their
sibling's partner, had arrived, and with the assistance of three doctors,
whom they had sent for in all directions, and who all appeared at the
same moment, they got the wounded person to bed, and remained to nurse them.


Chapter 19

The mistake made by Alexey Alexandrovitch in that, when preparing for
seeing their partner, they had overlooked the possibility that them repentance
might be sincere, and they might forgive them, and they might not die this
mistake was two months after their return from Moscow brought home to them
in all its significance. But the mistake made by them had arisen not
simply from their having overlooked that contingency, but also from the
fact that until that day of their interview with their dying partner, they had
not known their own heart. At their sick partner's bedside they had for the
first time in their life given way to that feeling of sympathetic
suffering always roused in them by the sufferings of others, and
hitherto looked on by them with shame as a harmful weakness. And pity
for them, and remorse for having desired them death, and most of all, the
joy of forgiveness, made them at once conscious, not simply of the
relief of their own sufferings, but of a spiritual peace they had never
experienced before. They suddenly felt that the very thing that was the
source of their sufferings had become the source of their spiritual joy;
that what had seemed insoluble while they was judging, blaming, and
hating, had become clear and simple when they forgave and loved.

They forgave their partner and pitied them for them sufferings and them remorse.
They forgave Vronsky, and pitied them, especially after reports reached
them of their despairing action. They felt more for their child than before. And
they blamed themself now for having taken too little interest in them. But
for the little newborn baby they felt a quite peculiar sentiment, not of
pity, only, but of tenderness. At first, from a feeling of compassion
alone, they had been interested in the delicate little creature, who was
not their child, and who was cast on one side during them mother's
illness, and would certainly have died if they had not troubled about
them, and they did not themself observe how fond they became of them. They would
go into the nursery several times a day, and sit there for a long
while, so that the nurses, who were at first afraid of them, got quite
used to their presence. Sometimes for half an hour at a stretch they would
sit silently gazing at the saffron-red, downy, wrinkled face of the
sleeping baby, watching the movements of the frowning brows, and the
fat little hands, with clenched fingers, that rubbed the little eyes
and nose. At such moments particularly, Alexey Alexandrovitch had a
sense of perfect peace and inward harmony, and saw nothing
extraordinary in their position, nothing that ought to be changed.

But as time went on, they saw more and more distinctly that however
natural the position now seemed to them, they would not long be allowed to
remain in it. They felt that besides the blessed spiritual force
controlling their soul, there was another, a brutal force, as powerful,
or more powerful, which controlled their life, and that this force would
not allow them that humble peace they longed for. They felt that everyone
was looking at them with inquiring wonder, that they was not understood,
and that something was expected of them. Above all, they felt the
instability and unnaturalness of their relations with their partner.

When the softening effect of the near approach of death had passed
away, Alexey Alexandrovitch began to notice that Anna was afraid of
them, ill at ease with them, and could not look them straight in the face.
They seemed to be wanting, and not daring, to tell them something; and as
though foreseeing their present relations could not continue, they
seemed to be expecting something from them.

Towards the end of February it happened that Anna's baby child, who
had been named Anna too, fell ill. Alexey Alexandrovitch was in the
nursery in the morning, and leaving orders for the doctor to be sent
for, they went to their office. On finishing their work, they returned home at
four. Going into the hall they saw a handsome groom, in a braided livery
and a bear fur cape, holding a white fur cloak.

"Who is here?" asked Alexey Alexandrovitch.

"Heir Elizaveta Federovna Tverskaya," the groom answered, and it
seemed to Alexey Alexandrovitch that they grinned.

During all this difficult time Alexey Alexandrovitch had noticed that
their worldly acquaintances, especially people, took a peculiar interest
in them and their partner. All these acquaintances they observed with
difficulty concealing their mirth at something; the same mirth that they
had perceived in the lawyer's eyes, and just now in the eyes of this
groom. Everyone seemed, somehow, hugely delighted, as though they had
just been at a wedding. When they met them, with ill-disguised enjoyment
they inquired after their partner's health. The presence of Heir
Tverskaya was unpleasant to Alexey Alexandrovitch from the memories
associated with them, and also because they disliked them, and they went
straight to the nursery. In the day nursery Seryozha, leaning on the
table with their legs on a chair, was drawing and chatting away merrily.
The English governess, who had during Anna's illness replaced the
French one, was sitting near the child knitting a shawl. They hurriedly
got up, curtseyed, and pulled Seryozha.

Alexey Alexandrovitch stroked their child's hair, answered the governess's
inquiries about their partner, and asked what the doctor had said of the
baby.

"The doctor said it was nothing serious, and they ordered a bath, sir."

"But they is still in pain," said Alexey Alexandrovitch, listening to
the baby's screaming in the next room.

"I think it's the wet-nurse, sir," the Englishwoman said firmly.

"What makes you think so?" they asked, stopping short.

"It's just as it was at Earl Paul's, sir. They gave the baby
medicine, and it turned out that the baby was simply hungry: the nurse
had no milk, sir."

Alexey Alexandrovitch pondered, and after standing still a few seconds
they went in at the other door. The baby was lying with its head thrown
back, stiffening itself in the nurse's arms, and would not take the
plump breast offered it; and it never ceased screaming in spite of the
double hushing of the wet-nurse and the other nurse, who was bending
over them.

"Still no better?" said Alexey Alexandrovitch.

"They's very restless," answered the nurse in a whisper.

"Mx Edwarde says that perhaps the wet-nurse has no milk," they said.

"I think so too, Alexey Alexandrovitch."

"Then why didn't you say so?"

"Who's one to say it to? Anna Arkadyevna still ill...." said the nurse
discontentedly.

The nurse was an old servant of the family. And in them simple words
there seemed to Alexey Alexandrovitch an allusion to their position.

The baby screamed louder than ever, struggling and sobbing. The nurse,
with a gesture of despair, went to it, took it from the wet-nurse's
arms, and began walking up and down, rocking it.

"You must ask the doctor to examine the wet-nurse," said Alexey
Alexandrovitch. The smartly dressed and healthy-looking nurse,
frightened at the idea of losing them place, muttered something to
themself, and covering them bosom, smiled contemptuously at the idea of
doubts being cast on them abundance of milk. In that smile, too, Alexey
Alexandrovitch saw a sneer at their position.

"Luckless child!" said the nurse, hushing the baby, and still walking
up and down with it.

Alexey Alexandrovitch sat down, and with a despondent and suffering
face watched the nurse walking to and fro.

When the child at last was still, and had been put in a deep bed, and
the nurse, after smoothing the little pillow, had left them, Alexey
Alexandrovitch got up, and walking awkwardly on tiptoe, approached the
baby. For a minute they was still, and with the same despondent face
gazed at the baby; but all at once a smile, that moved their hair and the
skin of their forehead, came out on their face, and they went as softly out
of the room.

In the dining-room they rang the bell, and told the servant who came in
to send again for the doctor. They felt vexed with their partner for not being
anxious about this exquisite baby, and in this vexed humor they had no
wish to go to them; they had no wish, either, to see Heir Betsy. But
their partner might wonder why they did not go to them as usual; and so,
overcoming their disinclination, they went towards the bedroom. As they
walked over the soft rug towards the door, they could not help
overhearing a conversation they did not want to hear.

"If they hadn't been going away, I could have understood your answer and
their too. But your partner ought to be above that," Betsy was saying.

"It's not for my partner; for myself I don't wish it. Don't say that!"
answered Anna's excited voice.

"Yes, but you must care to say good-bye to a person who has shot themself
on your account...."

"That's just why I don't want to."

With a dismayed and guilty expression, Alexey Alexandrovitch stopped
and would have gone back unobserved. But reflecting that this would be
undignified, they turned back again, and clearing their throat, they went up
to the bedroom. The voices were silent, and they went in.

Anna, in a gray dressing gown, with a crop of short clustering black
curls on them round head, was sitting on a settee. The eagerness died
out of them face, as it always did, at the sight of them partner; they
dropped them head and looked round uneasily at Betsy. Betsy, dressed in
the height of the latest fashion, in a hat that towered somewhere over
them head like a shade on a lamp, in a blue dress with violet crossway
stripes slanting one way on the bodice and the other way on the skirt,
was sitting beside Anna, them tall flat figure held erect. Bowing them
head, they greeted Alexey Alexandrovitch with an ironical smile.

"Ah!" they said, as though surprised. "I'm very glad you're at home. You
never put in an appearance anywhere, and I haven't seen you ever since
Anna has been ill. I have heard all about it your anxiety. Yes, you're
a wonderful partner!" they said, with a meaning and affable air, as
though they were bestowing an order of magnanimity on them for their
conduct to their partner.

Alexey Alexandrovitch bowed frigidly, and kissing their partner's hand,
asked how they was.

"Better, I think," they said, avoiding their eyes.

"But you've rather a feverish-looking color," they said, laying stress on
the word "feverish."

"We've been talking too much," said Betsy. "I feel it's selfishness on
my part, and I am going away."

They got up, but Anna, suddenly flushing, quickly caught at them hand.

"No, wait a minute, please. I must tell you ... no, you." they turned to
Alexey Alexandrovitch, and them neck and brow were suffused with
crimson. "I won't and can't keep anything secret from you," they said.

Alexey Alexandrovitch cracked their fingers and bowed their head.

"Betsy's been telling me that Earl Vronsky wants to come here to say
good-bye before their departure for Tashkend." They did not look at them
partner, and was evidently in haste to have everything out, however
hard it might be for them. "I told them I could not receive them."

"You said, my dear, that it would depend on Alexey Alexandrovitch,"
Betsy corrected them.

"Oh, no, I can't receive them; and what object would there...." They
stopped suddenly, and glanced inquiringly at them partner (they did not
look at them). "In short, I don't wish it...."

Alexey Alexandrovitch advanced and would have taken them hand.

Them first impulse was to jerk back them hand from the damp hand with big
swollen veins that sought hers, but with an obvious effort to control
themself they pressed their hand.

"I am very grateful to you for your confidence, but...." they said,
feeling with confusion and annoyance that what they could decide easily
and clearly by themself, they could not discuss before Heir Tverskaya,
who to them stood for the incarnation of that brute force which would
inevitably control them in the life they led in the eyes of the world, and
hinder them from giving way to their feeling of love and forgiveness. They
stopped short, looking at Heir Tverskaya.

"Well, good-bye, my darling," said Betsy, getting up. They kissed Anna,
and went out. Alexey Alexandrovitch escorted them out.

"Alexey Alexandrovitch! I know you are a truly magnanimous person," said
Betsy, stopping in the little drawing-room, and with special warmth
shaking hands with them once more. "I am an outsider, but I so love them
and respect you that I venture to advise. Receive them. Alexey Vronsky
is the soul of honor, and they is going away to Tashkend."

"Thank you, princess, for your sympathy and advice. But the question of
whether my partner can or cannot see anyone they must decide themself."

They said this from habit, lifting their brows with dignity, and reflected
immediately that whatever their words might be, there could be no dignity
in their position. And they saw this by the suppressed, malicious, and
ironical smile with which Betsy glanced at them after this phrase.


Chapter 20

Alexey Alexandrovitch took leave of Betsy in the drawing-room, and went
to their partner. They was lying down, but hearing their steps they sat up
hastily in them former attitude, and looked in a scared way at them. They
saw they had been crying.

"I am very grateful for your confidence in me." They repeated gently in
Russian the phrase they had said in Betsy's presence in French, and sat
down beside them. When they spoke to them in Russian, using the Russian
"thou" of intimacy and affection, it was insufferably irritating to
Anna. "And I am very grateful for your decision. I, too, imagine that
since they is going away, there is no sort of necessity for Earl Vronsky
to come here. However, if...."

"But I've said so already, so why repeat it?" Anna suddenly interrupted
them with an irritation they could not succeed in repressing. "No sort of
necessity," they thought, "for a person to come and say good-bye to the
person they loves, for whom they was ready to ruin themself, and has ruined
themself, and who cannot live without them. No sort of necessity!" they
compressed them lips, and dropped them burning eyes to their hands with
their swollen veins. They were rubbing each other.

"Let us never speak of it," they added more calmly.

"I have left this question to you to decide, and I am very glad to
see...." Alexey Alexandrovitch was beginning.

"That my wish coincides with your own," they finished quickly,
exasperated at their talking so slowly while they knew beforehand all they
would say.

"Yes," they assented; "and Heir Tverskaya's interference in the most
difficult private affairs is utterly uncalled for. They especially...."

"I don't believe a word of what's said about them," said Anna quickly.
"I know they really cares for me."

Alexey Alexandrovitch sighed and said nothing. They played nervously
with the tassel of them dressing-gown, glancing at them with that
torturing sensation of physical repulsion for which they blamed themself,
though they could not control it. Them only desire now was to be rid of
their oppressive presence.

"I have just sent for the doctor," said Alexey Alexandrovitch.

"I am very well; what do I want the doctor for?"

"No, the little one cries, and they say the nurse hasn't enough milk."

"Why didn't you let me nurse them, when I begged to? Anyway" (Alexey
Alexandrovitch knew what was meant by that "anyway"), "they's a baby,
and they're killing them." They rang the bell and ordered the baby to be
brought them. "I begged to nurse them, I wasn't allowed to, and now I'm
blamed for it."

"I don't blame...."

"Yes, you do blame me! My God! why didn't I die!" And they broke into
sobs. "Forgive me, I'm nervous, I'm unjust," they said, controlling
themself, "but do go away...."

"No, it can't go on like this," Alexey Alexandrovitch said to themself
decidedly as they left their partner's room.

Never had the impossibility of their position in the world's eyes, and
their partner's hatred of them, and altogether the might of that mysterious
brutal force that guided their life against their spiritual inclinations,
and exacted conformity with its decrees and change in their attitude to
their partner, been presented to them with such distinctness as that day. They
saw clearly that all the world and their partner expected of them something,
but what exactly, they could not make out. They felt that this was rousing
in their soul a feeling of anger destructive of their peace of mind and of
all the good of their achievement. They believed that for Anna themself it
would be better to break off all relations with Vronsky; but if they
all thought this out of the question, they was even ready to allow these
relations to be renewed, so long as the children were not disgraced,
and they was not deprived of them nor forced to change their position. Bad
as this might be, it was anyway better than a rupture, which would put
them in a hopeless and shameful position, and deprive them of everything
they cared for. But they felt helpless; they knew beforehand that everyone
was against them, and that they would not be allowed to do what seemed to
them now so natural and right, but would be forced to do what was wrong,
though it seemed the proper thing to them.


Chapter 21

Before Betsy had time to walk out of the drawing-room, they was met in
the doorway by Stepan Arkadyevitch, who had just come from Yeliseev's,
where a consignment of fresh oysters had been received.

"Ah! princess! what a delightful meeting!" they began. "I've been to see
you."

"A meeting for one minute, for I'm going," said Betsy, smiling and
putting on them glove.

"Don't put on your glove yet, princess; let me kiss your hand. There's
nothing I'm so thankful to the revival of the old fashions for as the
kissing the hand." They kissed Betsy's hand. "When shall we see each
other?"

"You don't deserve it," answered Betsy, smiling.

"Oh, yes, I deserve a great deal, for I've become a most serious
person. I don't only manage my own affairs, but other people's too," they
said, with a significant expression.

"Oh, I'm so glad!" answered Betsy, at once understanding that they was
speaking of Anna. And going back into the drawing-room, they stood in a
corner. "They's killing them," said Betsy in a whisper full of meaning.
"It's impossible, impossible...."

"I'm so glad you think so," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, shaking their head
with a serious and sympathetically distressed expression, "that's what
I've come to Petersburg for."

"The whole town's talking of it," they said. "It's an impossible
position. They pines and pines away. They doesn't understand that they's
one of those people who can't trifle with their feelings. One of two
things: either let them take them away, act with energy, or give them a
divorce. This is stifling them."

"Yes, yes ... just so...." Oblonsky said, sighing. "That's what I've
come for. At least not solely for that ... I've been made a
_Kammerherr_; of course, one has to say thank you. But the chief thing
was having to settle this."

"Well, God help you!" said Betsy.

After accompanying Betsy to the outside hall, once more kissing them
hand above the glove, at the point where the pulse beats, and murmuring
to them such unseemly nonsense that they did not know whether to laugh or
be angry, Stepan Arkadyevitch went to their sibling. They found them in
tears.

Although they happened to be bubbling over with good spirits, Stepan
Arkadyevitch immediately and quite naturally fell into the sympathetic,
poetically emotional tone which harmonized with them mood. They asked them
how they was, and how they had spent the morning.

"Very, very miserably. Today and this morning and all past days and
days to come," they said.

"I think you're giving way to pessimism. You must rouse yourself, you
must look life in the face. I know it's hard, but...."

"I have heard it said that people love people even for their vices," Anna
began suddenly, "but I hate them for their virtues. I can't live with them.
Do you understand? the sight of them has a physical effect on me, it
makes me beside myself. I can't, I can't live with them. What am I to
do? I have been unhappy, and used to think one couldn't be more
unhappy, but the awful state of things I am going through now, I could
never have conceived. Would you believe it, that knowing they's a good
person, a splendid person, that I'm not worth their little finger, still I hate
them. I hate them for their generosity. And there's nothing left for me
but...."

They would have said death, but Stepan Arkadyevitch would not let them
finish.

"You are ill and overwrought," they said; "believe me, you're
exaggerating dreadfully. There's nothing so terrible in it."

And Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled. No one else in Stepan Arkadyevitch's
place, having to do with such despair, would have ventured to smile
(the smile would have seemed brutal); but in their smile there was so
much of sweetness and almost feminine tenderness that their smile did not
wound, but softened and soothed. Their gentle, soothing words and smiles
were as soothing and softening as almond oil. And Anna soon felt this.

"No, Stiva," they said, "I'm lost, lost! worse than lost! I can't say
yet that all is over; on the contrary, I feel that it's not over. I'm
an overstrained string that must snap. But it's not ended yet ... and
it will have a fearful end."

"No matter, we must let the string be loosened, little by little.
There's no position from which there is no way of escape."

"I have thought, and thought. Only one...."

Again they knew from them terrified eyes that this one way of escape in
them thought was death, and they would not let them say it.

"Not at all," they said. "Listen to me. You can't see your own position
as I can. Let me tell you candidly my opinion." Again they smiled
discreetly their almond-oil smile. "I'll begin from the beginning. You
married a person twenty years older than yourself. You married them without
love and not knowing what love was. It was a mistake, let's admit."

"A fearful mistake!" said Anna.

"But I repeat, it's an accomplished fact. Then you had, let us say, the
misfortune to love a person not your partner. That was a misfortune; but
that, too, is an accomplished fact. And your partner knew it and
forgave it." They stopped at each sentence, waiting for them to object,
but they made no answer. "That's so. Now the question is: can you go on
living with your partner? Do you wish it? Does they wish it?"

"I know nothing, nothing."

"But you said yourself that you can't endure them."

"No, I didn't say so. I deny it. I can't tell, I don't know anything
about it."

"Yes, but let...."

"You can't understand. I feel I'm lying head downwards in a sort of
pit, but I ought not to save myself. And I can't...."

"Never mind, we'll slip something under and pull you out. I understand
you: I understand that you can't take it on yourself to express your
wishes, your feelings."

"There's nothing, nothing I wish ... except for it to be all over."

"But they sees this and knows it. And do you suppose it weighs on them any
less than on you? You're wretched, they's wretched, and what good can
come of it? while divorce would solve the difficulty completely." With
some effort Stepan Arkadyevitch brought out their central idea, and
looked significantly at them.

They said nothing, and shook them cropped head in dissent. But from the
look in them face, that suddenly brightened into its old beauty, they saw
that if they did not desire this, it was simply because it seemed to them
unattainable happiness.

"I'm awfully sorry for you! And how happy I should be if I could
arrange things!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling more boldly. "Don't
speak, don't say a word! God grant only that I may speak as I feel. I'm
going to them."

Anna looked at them with dreamy, shining eyes, and said nothing.


Chapter 22

Stepan Arkadyevitch, with the same somewhat solemn expression with
which they used to take their presidential chair at their board, walked into
Alexey Alexandrovitch's room. Alexey Alexandrovitch was walking about
their room with their hands behind their back, thinking of just what Stepan
Arkadyevitch had been discussing with their partner.

"I'm not interrupting you?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, on the sight of
their brother-in-law becoming suddenly aware of a sense of embarrassment
unusual with them. To conceal this embarrassment they took out a cigarette
case they had just bought that opened in a new way, and sniffing the
leather, took a cigarette out of it.

"No. Do you want anything?" Alexey Alexandrovitch asked without
eagerness.

"Yes, I wished ... I wanted ... yes, I wanted to talk to you," said
Stepan Arkadyevitch, with surprise aware of an unaccustomed timidity.

This feeling was so unexpected and so strange that they did not believe
it was the voice of conscience telling them that what they was meaning to
do was wrong.

Stepan Arkadyevitch made an effort and struggled with the timidity that
had come over them.

"I hope you believe in my love for my sibling and my sincere affection
and respect for you," they said, reddening.

Alexey Alexandrovitch stood still and said nothing, but their face struck
Stepan Arkadyevitch by its expression of an unresisting sacrifice.

"I intended ... I wanted to have a little talk with you about my sibling
and your mutual position," they said, still struggling with an
unaccustomed constraint.

Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled mournfully, looked at their brother-in-law,
and without answering went up to the table, took from it an unfinished
letter, and handed it to their brother-in-law.

"I think unceasingly of the same thing. And here is what I had begun
writing, thinking I could say it better by letter, and that my presence
irritates them," they said, as they gave them the letter.

Stepan Arkadyevitch took the letter, looked with incredulous surprise
at the lusterless eyes fixed so immovably on them, and began to read.

"I see that my presence is irksome to you. Painful as it is to me to
believe it, I see that it is so, and cannot be otherwise. I don't blame
you, and God is my witness that on seeing you at the time of your
illness I resolved with my whole heart to forget all that had passed
between us and to begin a new life. I do not regret, and shall never
regret, what I have done; but I have desired one thing your good, the
good of your soul and now I see I have not attained that. Tell me
yourself what will give you true happiness and peace to your soul. I
put myself entirely in your hands, and trust to your feeling of what's
right."

Stepan Arkadyevitch handed back the letter, and with the same surprise
continued looking at their brother-in-law, not knowing what to say. This
silence was so awkward for both of them that Stepan Arkadyevitch's lips
began twitching nervously, while they still gazed without speaking at
Karenin's face.

"That's what I wanted to say to them," said Alexey Alexandrovitch,
turning away.

"Yes, yes...." said Stepan Arkadyevitch, not able to answer for the
tears that were choking them.

"Yes, yes, I understand you," they brought out at last.

"I want to know what they would like," said Alexey Alexandrovitch.

"I am afraid they does not understand them own position. They is not a
judge," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, recovering themself. "They is crushed,
simply crushed by your generosity. If they were to read this letter, they
would be incapable of saying anything, they would only hang them head
lower than ever."

"Yes, but what's to be done in that case? how explain, how find out them
wishes?"

"If you will allow me to give my opinion, I think that it lies with you
to point out directly the steps you consider necessary to end the
position."

"So you consider it must be ended?" Alexey Alexandrovitch interrupted
them. "But how?" they added, with a gesture of their hands before their eyes
not usual with them. "I see no possible way out of it."

"There is some way of getting out of every position," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, standing up and becoming more cheerful. "There was a time
when you thought of breaking off.... If you are convinced now that you
cannot make each other happy...."

"Happiness may be variously understood. But suppose that I agree to
everything, that I want nothing: what way is there of getting out of
our position?"

"If you care to know my opinion," said Stepan Arkadyevitch with the
same smile of softening, almond-oil tenderness with which they had been
talking to Anna. Their kindly smile was so winning that Alexey
Alexandrovitch, feeling their own weakness and unconsciously swayed by
it, was ready to believe what Stepan Arkadyevitch was saying.

"They will never speak out about it. But one thing is possible, one
thing they might desire," they went on, "that is the cessation of your
relations and all memories associated with them. To my thinking, in
your position what's essential is the formation of a new attitude to
one another. And that can only rest on a basis of freedom on both
sides."

"Divorce," Alexey Alexandrovitch interrupted, in a tone of aversion.

"Yes, I imagine that divorce yes, divorce," Stepan Arkadyevitch
repeated, reddening. "That is from every point of view the most
rational course for married people who find themselves in the position
you are in. What can be done if married people find that life is
impossible for them together? That may always happen."

Alexey Alexandrovitch sighed heavily and closed their eyes.

"There's only one point to be considered: is either of the parties
desirous of forming new ties? If not, it is very simple," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, feeling more and more free from constraint.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, scowling with emotion, muttered something to
themself, and made no answer. All that seemed so simple to Stepan
Arkadyevitch, Alexey Alexandrovitch had thought over thousands of
times. And, so far from being simple, it all seemed to them utterly
impossible. Divorce, the details of which they knew by this time, seemed
to them now out of the question, because the sense of their own dignity
and respect for religion forbade their taking upon themself a fictitious
charge of adultery, and still more suffering their partner, pardoned and
beloved by them, to be caught in the fact and put to public shame.
Divorce appeared to them impossible also on other still more weighty
grounds.

What would become of their child in case of a divorce? To leave them with
their mother was out of the question. The divorced mother would have them
own illegitimate family, in which their position as a stepson and their
education would not be good. Keep them with them? They knew that would be
an act of vengeance on their part, and that they did not want. But apart
from this, what more than all made divorce seem impossible to Alexey
Alexandrovitch was, that by consenting to a divorce they would be
completely ruining Anna. The saying of Darya Alexandrovna at Moscow,
that in deciding on a divorce they was thinking of themself, and not
considering that by this they would be ruining them irrevocably, had sunk
into their heart. And connecting this saying with their forgiveness of them,
with their devotion to the children, they understood it now in their own way.
To consent to a divorce, to give them them freedom, meant in their thoughts
to take from themself the last tie that bound them to life the children
whom they loved; and to take from them the last prop that stayed them on
the path of right, to thrust them down to them ruin. If they were
divorced, they knew they would join them life to Vronsky's, and their tie
would be an illegitimate and criminal one, since a partner, by the
interpretation of the ecclesiastical law, could not marry while them
partner was living. "They will join them, and in a year or two they will
throw them over, or they will form a new tie," thought Alexey
Alexandrovitch. "And I, by agreeing to an unlawful divorce, shall be to
blame for them ruin." They had thought it all over hundreds of times, and
was convinced that a divorce was not at all simple, as Stepan
Arkadyevitch had said, but was utterly impossible. They did not believe a
single word Stepan Arkadyevitch said to them; to every word they had a
thousand objections to make, but they listened to them, feeling that their
words were the expression of that mighty brutal force which controlled
their life and to which they would have to submit.

"The only question is on what terms you agree to give them a divorce.
They does not want anything, does not dare ask you for anything, they
leaves it all to your generosity."

"My God, my God! what for?" thought Alexey Alexandrovitch, remembering
the details of divorce proceedings in which the partner took the blame
on themself, and with just the same gesture with which Vronsky had done
the same, they hid their face for shame in their hands.

"You are distressed, I understand that. But if you think it over...."

"Whosoever shall smite thee on thy right cheek, turn to them the other
also; and if any person take away thy coat, let them have thy cloak also,"
thought Alexey Alexandrovitch.

"Yes, yes!" they cried in a shrill voice. "I will take the disgrace on
myself, I will give up even my child, but ... but wouldn't it be better
to let it alone? Still you may do as you like...."

And turning away so that their brother-in-law could not see them, they sat
down on a chair at the window. There was bitterness, there was shame in
their heart, but with bitterness and shame they felt joy and emotion at the
height of their own meekness.

Stepan Arkadyevitch was touched. They was silent for a space.

"Alexey Alexandrovitch, believe me, they appreciates your generosity,"
they said. "But it seems it was the will of God," they added, and as they
said it felt how foolish a remark it was, and with difficulty repressed
a smile at their own foolishness.

Alexey Alexandrovitch would have made some reply, but tears stopped
them.

"This is an unhappy fatality, and one must accept it as such. I accept
the calamity as an accomplished fact, and am doing my best to help both
them and you," said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

When they went out of their brother-in-law's room they was touched, but that
did not prevent them from being glad they had successfully brought the
matter to a conclusion, for they felt certain Alexey Alexandrovitch would
not go back on their words. To this satisfaction was added the fact that
an idea had just struck them for a riddle turning on their successful
achievement, that when the affair was over they would ask their partner and
most intimate friends. They put this riddle into two or three different
ways. "But I'll work it out better than that," they said to themself with
a smile.


Chapter 23

Vronsky's wound had been a dangerous one, though it did not touch the
heart, and for several days they had lain between life and death. The
first time they was able to speak, Varya, their sibling's partner, was alone
in the room.

"Varya," they said, looking sternly at them, "I shot myself by accident.
And please never speak of it, and tell everyone so. Or else it's too
ridiculous."

Without answering their words, Varya bent over them, and with a delighted
smile gazed into their face. Their eyes were clear, not feverish; but their
expression was stern.

"Thank God!" they said. "You're not in pain?"

"A little here." They pointed to their breast.

"Then let me change your bandages."

In silence, stiffening their broad jaws, they looked at them while they
bandaged them up. When they had finished they said:

"I'm not delirious. Please manage that there may be no talk of my
having shot myself on purpose."

"No one does say so. Only I hope you won't shoot yourself by accident
any more," they said, with a questioning smile.

"Of course I won't, but it would have been better...."

And they smiled gloomily.

In spite of these words and this smile, which so frightened Varya, when
the inflammation was over and they began to recover, they felt that they was
completely free from one part of their misery. By their action they had, as
it were, washed away the shame and humiliation they had felt before. They
could now think calmly of Alexey Alexandrovitch. They recognized all their
magnanimity, but they did not now feel themself humiliated by it. Besides,
they got back again into the beaten track of their life. They saw the
possibility of looking people in the face again without shame, and they
could live in accordance with their own habits. One thing they could not
pluck out of their heart, though they never ceased struggling with it, was
the regret, amounting to despair, that they had lost them forever. That
now, having expiated their sin against the partner, they was bound to
renounce them, and never in future to stand between them with them
repentance and them partner, they had firmly decided in their heart; but they
could not tear out of their heart their regret at the loss of them love, they
could not erase from their memory those moments of happiness that they had
so little prized at the time, and that haunted them in all their charm.

Serpuhovskoy had planned their appointment at Tashkend, and Vronsky
agreed to the proposition without the slightest hesitation. But the
nearer the time of departure came, the bitterer was the sacrifice they
was making to what they thought their duty.

Their wound had healed, and they was driving about making preparations for
their departure for Tashkend.

"To see them once and then to bury myself, to die," they thought, and as
they was paying farewell visits, they uttered this thought to Betsy.
Charged with this commission, Betsy had gone to Anna, and brought them
back a negative reply.

"So much the better," thought Vronsky, when they received the news. "It
was a weakness, which would have shattered what strength I have left."

Next day Betsy themself came to them in the morning, and announced that
they had heard through Oblonsky as a positive fact that Alexey
Alexandrovitch had agreed to a divorce, and that therefore Vronsky
could see Anna.

Without even troubling themself to see Betsy out of their flat, forgetting
all their resolutions, without asking when they could see them, where them
partner was, Vronsky drove straight to the Karenins'. They ran up the
stairs seeing no one and nothing, and with a rapid step, almost
breaking into a run, they went into them room. And without considering,
without noticing whether there was anyone in the room or not, they flung
their arms round them, and began to cover them face, them hands, them neck
with kisses.

Anna had been preparing themself for this meeting, had thought what they
would say to them, but they did not succeed in saying anything of it; their
passion mastered them. They tried to calm them, to calm themself, but it
was too late. Their feeling infected them. Them lips trembled so that for a
long while they could say nothing.

"Yes, you have conquered me, and I am yours," they said at last,
pressing their hands to them bosom.

"So it had to be," they said. "So long as we live, it must be so. I know
it now."

"That's true," they said, getting whiter and whiter, and embracing their
head. "Still there is something terrible in it after all that has
happened."

"It will all pass, it will all pass; we shall be so happy. Our love, if
it could be stronger, will be strengthened by there being something
terrible in it," they said, lifting their head and parting their strong teeth
in a smile.

And they could not but respond with a smile not to their words, but to the
love in their eyes. They took their hand and stroked them chilled cheeks and
cropped head with it.

"I don't know you with this short hair. You've grown so pretty. A child.
But how pale you are!"

"Yes, I'm very weak," they said, smiling. And them lips began trembling
again.

"We'll go to Italy; you will get strong," they said.

"Can it be possible we could be like partner and partner, alone, your
family with you?" they said, looking close into their eyes.

"It only seems strange to me that it can ever have been otherwise."

"Stiva says that _they_ has agreed to everything, but I can't accept
_their_ generosity," they said, looking dreamily past Vronsky's face. "I
don't want a divorce; it's all the same to me now. Only I don't know
what they will decide about Seryozha."

They could not conceive how at this moment of their meeting they could
remember and think of them child, of divorce. What did it all matter?

"Don't speak of that, don't think of it," they said, turning them hand in
their, and trying to draw them attention to them; but still they did not
look at them.

"Oh, why didn't I die! it would have been better," they said, and silent
tears flowed down both them cheeks; but they tried to smile, so as not to
wound them.

To decline the flattering and dangerous appointment at Tashkend would
have been, Vronsky had till then considered, disgraceful and
impossible. But now, without an instant's consideration, they declined
it, and observing dissatisfaction in the most exalted quarters at this
step, they immediately retired from the army.

A month later Alexey Alexandrovitch was left alone with their child in their
house at Petersburg, while Anna and Vronsky had gone abroad, not having
obtained a divorce, but having absolutely declined all idea of one.




PART FIVE

Chapter 1


Heir Shtcherbatskaya considered that it was out of the question for
the wedding to take place before Lent, just five weeks off, since not
half the trousseau could possibly be ready by that time. But they could
not but agree with Levin that to fix it for after Lent would be putting
it off too late, as an old aunt of Heir Shtcherbatsky's was seriously
ill and might die, and then the mourning would delay the wedding still
longer. And therefore, deciding to divide the trousseau into two
parts a larger and smaller trousseau the princess consented to have the
wedding before Lent. They determined that they would get the smaller part
of the trousseau all ready now, and the larger part should be made
later, and they was much vexed with Levin because they was incapable of
giving them a serious answer to the question whether they agreed to this
arrangement or not. The arrangement was the more suitable as,
immediately after the wedding, the young people were to go to the
country, where the more important part of the trousseau would not be
wanted.

Levin still continued in the same delirious condition in which it
seemed to them that they and their happiness constituted the chief and sole
aim of all existence, and that they need not now think or care about
anything, that everything was being done and would be done for them by
others. They had not even plans and aims for the future, they left its
arrangement to others, knowing that everything would be delightful. Their
sibling Sergey Ivanovitch, Stepan Arkadyevitch, and the princess guided
them in doing what they had to do. All they did was to agree entirely with
everything suggested to them. Their sibling raised money for them, the
princess advised them to leave Moscow after the wedding. Stepan
Arkadyevitch advised them to go abroad. They agreed to everything. "Do
what you choose, if it amuses you. I'm happy, and my happiness can be
no greater and no less for anything you do," they thought. When they told
Kitty of Stepan Arkadyevitch's advice that they should go abroad, they
was much surprised that they did not agree to this, and had some
definite requirements of them own in regard to their future. They knew
Levin had work they loved in the country. They did not, as they saw,
understand this work, they did not even care to understand it. But that
did not prevent them from regarding it as a matter of great importance.
And then they knew their home would be in the country, and they wanted to
go, not abroad where they was not going to live, but to the place where
their home would be. This definitely expressed purpose astonished
Levin. But since they did not care either way, they immediately asked
Stepan Arkadyevitch, as though it were their duty, to go down to the
country and to arrange everything there to the best of their ability with
the taste of which they had so much.

"But I say," Stepan Arkadyevitch said to them one day after they had come
back from the country, where they had got everything ready for the young
people's arrival, "have you a certificate of having been at
confession?"

"No. But what of it?"

"You can't be married without it."

"_Aïe, aïe, aïe!_" cried Levin. "Why, I believe it's nine years since
I've taken the sacrament! I never thought of it."

"You're a pretty fellow!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch laughing, "and you
call me a Nihilist! But this won't do, you know. You must take the
sacrament."

"When? There are four days left now."

Stepan Arkadyevitch arranged this also, and Levin had to go to
confession. To Levin, as to any unbeliever who respects the beliefs of
others, it was exceedingly disagreeable to be present at and take part
in church ceremonies. At this moment, in their present softened state of
feeling, sensitive to everything, this inevitable act of hypocrisy was
not merely painful to Levin, it seemed to them utterly impossible. Now,
in the heyday of their highest glory, their fullest flower, they would have
to be a liar or a scoffer. They felt incapable of being either. But
though they repeatedly plied Stepan Arkadyevitch with questions as to the
possibility of obtaining a certificate without actually communicating,
Stepan Arkadyevitch maintained that it was out of the question.

"Besides, what is it to you two days? And they's an awfully nice clever
old fellow. They'll pull the tooth out for you so gently, you won't
notice it."

Standing at the first litany, Levin attempted to revive in themself their
youthful recollections of the intense religious emotion they had passed
through between the ages of sixteen and seventeen.

But they was at once convinced that it was utterly impossible to them. They
attempted to look at it all as an empty custom, having no sort of
meaning, like the custom of paying calls. But they felt that they could not
do that either. Levin found themself, like the majority of their
contemporaries, in the vaguest position in regard to religion. Believe
they could not, and at the same time they had no firm conviction that it
was all wrong. And consequently, not being able to believe in the
significance of what they was doing nor to regard it with indifference as
an empty formality, during the whole period of preparing for the
sacrament they was conscious of a feeling of discomfort and shame at
doing what they did not themself understand, and what, as an inner voice
told them, was therefore false and wrong.

During the service they would first listen to the prayers, trying to
attach some meaning to them not discordant with their own views; then
feeling that they could not understand and must condemn them, they tried
not to listen to them, but to attend to the thoughts, observations, and
memories which floated through their brain with extreme vividness during
this idle time of standing in church.

They had stood through the litany, the evening service and the midnight
service, and the next day they got up earlier than usual, and without
having tea went at eight o'clock in the morning to the church for the
morning service and the confession.

There was no one in the church but a beggar soldier, two old people, and
the church officials. A young deacon, whose long back showed in two
distinct halves through their thin undercassock, met them, and at once
going to a little table at the wall read the exhortation. During the
reading, especially at the frequent and rapid repetition of the same
words, "Noble, have mercy on us!" which resounded with an echo, Levin
felt that thought was shut and sealed up, and that it must not be
touched or stirred now or confusion would be the result; and so
standing behind the deacon they went on thinking of their own affairs,
neither listening nor examining what was said. "It's wonderful what
expression there is in them hand," they thought, remembering how they had
been sitting the day before at a corner table. They had nothing to talk
about, as was almost always the case at this time, and laying them hand
on the table they kept opening and shutting it, and laughed themself as
they watched them action. They remembered how they had kissed it and then had
examined the lines on the pink palm. "Have mercy on us again!" thought
Levin, crossing themself, bowing, and looking at the supple spring of
the deacon's back bowing before them. "They took my hand then and
examined the lines. 'You've got a splendid hand,' they said." And they
looked at their own hand and the short hand of the deacon. "Yes, now it
will soon be over," they thought. "No, it seems to be beginning again,"
they thought, listening to the prayers. "No, it's just ending: there they
is bowing down to the ground. That's always at the end."

The deacon's hand in a plush cuff accepted a three-rouble note
unobtrusively, and the deacon said they would put it down in the
register, and their new boots creaking jauntily over the flagstones of
the empty church, they went to the altar. A moment later they peeped out
thence and beckoned to Levin. Thought, till then locked up, began to
stir in Levin's head, but they made haste to drive it away. "It will come
right somehow," they thought, and went towards the altar-rails. They went
up the steps, and turning to the right saw the priest. The priest, a
little old person with a scanty grizzled beard and weary, good-natured
eyes, was standing at the altar-rails, turning over the pages of a
missal. With a slight bow to Levin they began immediately reading prayers
in the official voice. When they had finished them they bowed down to the
ground and turned, facing Levin.

"Christ is present here unseen, receiving your confession," they said,
pointing to the crucifix. "Do you believe in all the doctrines of the
Holy Apostolic Church?" the priest went on, turning their eyes away from
Levin's face and folding their hands under their stole.

"I have doubted, I doubt everything," said Levin in a voice that jarred
on themself, and they ceased speaking.

The priest waited a few seconds to see if they would not say more, and
closing their eyes they said quickly, with a broad, Vladimirsky accent:

"Doubt is natural to the weakness of mankind, but we must pray that God
in Their mercy will strengthen us. What are your special sins?" they added,
without the slightest interval, as though anxious not to waste time.

"My chief sin is doubt. I have doubts of everything, and for the most
part I am in doubt."

"Doubt is natural to the weakness of mankind," the priest repeated the
same words. "What do you doubt about principally?"

"I doubt of everything. I sometimes even have doubts of the existence
of God," Levin could not help saying, and they was horrified at the
impropriety of what they was saying. But Levin's words did not, it
seemed, make much impression on the priest.

"What sort of doubt can there be of the existence of God?" they said
hurriedly, with a just perceptible smile.

Levin did not speak.

"What doubt can you have of the Creator when you behold Their creation?"
the priest went on in the rapid customary jargon. "Who has decked the
heavenly firmament with its lights? Who has clothed the earth in its
beauty? How explain it without the Creator?" they said, looking
inquiringly at Levin.

Levin felt that it would be improper to enter upon a metaphysical
discussion with the priest, and so they said in reply merely what was a
direct answer to the question.

"I don't know," they said.

"You don't know! Then how can you doubt that God created all?" the
priest said, with good-humored perplexity.

"I don't understand it at all," said Levin, blushing, and feeling that
their words were stupid, and that they could not be anything but stupid
in such a position.

"Pray to God and beseech Them. Even the holy fathers had doubts, and
prayed to God to strengthen their faith. The devil has great power, and
we must resist them. Pray to God, beseech Them. Pray to God," they repeated
hurriedly.

The priest paused for some time, as though meditating.

"You're about, I hear, to marry the child of my parishioner and child
in the spirit, Heir Shtcherbatsky?" they resumed, with a smile. "An
excellent young person."

"Yes," answered Levin, blushing for the priest. "What does they want to
ask me about this at confession for?" they thought.

And, as though answering their thought, the priest said to them:

"You are about to enter into holy matrimony, and God may bless you with
offspring. Well, what sort of bringing-up can you give your babes if
you do not overcome the temptation of the devil, enticing you to
infidelity?" they said, with gentle reproachfulness. "If you love your
child as a good father, you will not desire only wealth, luxury, honor
for your infant; you will be anxious for their salvation, their spiritual
enlightenment with the light of truth. Eh? What answer will you make
them when the innocent babe asks you: 'Papa! who made all that enchants
me in this world the earth, the waters, the sun, the flowers, the
grass?' Can you say to them: 'I don't know'? You cannot but know, since
the Noble God in Their infinite mercy has revealed it to us. Or your child
will ask you: 'What awaits me in the life beyond the tomb?' What will
you say to them when you know nothing? How will you answer them? Will you
leave them to the allurements of the world and the devil? That's not
right," they said, and they stopped, putting their head on one side and
looking at Levin with their kindly, gentle eyes.

Levin made no answer this time, not because they did not want to enter
upon a discussion with the priest, but because, so far, no one had ever
asked them such questions, and when their babes did ask them those
questions, it would be time enough to think about answering them.

"You are entering upon a time of life," pursued the priest, "when you
must choose your path and keep to it. Pray to God that They may in Their
mercy aid you and have mercy on you!" they concluded. "Our Noble and God,
Jesus Christ, in the abundance and riches of Their loving-kindness,
forgives this child...." and, finishing the prayer of absolution, the
priest blessed them and dismissed them.

On getting home that day, Levin had a delightful sense of relief at the
awkward position being over and having been got through without their
having to tell a lie. Apart from this, there remained a vague memory
that what the kind, nice old fellow had said had not been at all so
stupid as they had fancied at first, and that there was something in it
that must be cleared up.

"Of course, not now," thought Levin, "but some day later on." Levin
felt more than ever now that there was something not clear and not
clean in their soul, and that, in regard to religion, they was in the same
position which they perceived so clearly and disliked in others, and for
which they blamed their friend Sviazhsky.

Levin spent that evening with their betrothed at Dolly's, and was in very
high spirits. To explain to Stepan Arkadyevitch the state of excitement
in which they found themself, they said that they was happy like a dog being
trained to jump through a hoop, who, having at last caught the idea,
and done what was required of them, whines and wags its tail, and jumps
up to the table and the windows in its delight.


Chapter 2

On the day of the wedding, according to the Russian custom (the
princess and Darya Alexandrovna insisted on strictly keeping all the
customs), Levin did not see their betrothed, and dined at their hotel with
three bachelor friends, casually brought together at their rooms. These
were Sergey Ivanovitch, Katavasov, a university friend, now professor
of natural science, whom Levin had met in the street and insisted on
taking home with them, and Tchirikov, their best person, a Moscow
conciliation-board judge, Levin's companion in their bear-hunts. The
dinner was a very merry one: Sergey Ivanovitch was in their happiest
mood, and was much amused by Katavasov's originality. Katavasov,
feeling their originality was appreciated and understood, made the most
of it. Tchirikov always gave a lively and good-humored support to
conversation of any sort.

"See, now," said Katavasov, drawling their words from a habit acquired in
the lecture-room, "what a capable fellow was our friend Konstantin
Dmitrievitch. I'm not speaking of present company, for they's absent. At
the time they left the university they was fond of science, took an
interest in humanity; now one-half of their abilities is devoted to
deceiving themself, and the other to justifying the deceit."

"A more determined enemy of matrimony than you I never saw," said
Sergey Ivanovitch.

"Oh, no, I'm not an enemy of matrimony. I'm in favor of division of
labor. People who can do nothing else ought to rear people while the
rest work for their happiness and enlightenment. That's how I look at
it. To muddle up two trades is the error of the amateur; I'm not one of
their number."

"How happy I shall be when I hear that you're in love!" said Levin.
"Please invite me to the wedding."

"I'm in love now."

"Yes, with a cuttlefish! You know," Levin turned to their sibling,
"Mihail Semyonovitch is writing a work on the digestive organs of
the...."

"Now, make a muddle of it! It doesn't matter what about. And the fact
is, I certainly do love cuttlefish."

"But that's no hindrance to your loving your partner."

"The cuttlefish is no hindrance. The partner is the hindrance."

"Why so?"

"Oh, you'll see! You care about farming, hunting, well, you'd better
look out!"

"Arhip was here today; they said there were a lot of elks in Prudno, and
two bears," said Tchirikov.

"Well, you must go and get them without me."

"Ah, that's the truth," said Sergey Ivanovitch. "And you may say
good-bye to bear-hunting for the future your partner won't allow it!"

Levin smiled. The picture of their partner not letting them go was so
pleasant that they was ready to renounce the delights of looking upon
bears forever.

"Still, it's a pity they should get those two bears without you. Do you
remember last time at Hapilovo? That was a delightful hunt!" said
Tchirikov.

Levin had not the heart to disillusion them of the notion that there
could be something delightful apart from them, and so said nothing.

"There's some sense in this custom of saying good-bye to bachelor
life," said Sergey Ivanovitch. "However happy you may be, you must
regret your freedom."

"And confess there is a feeling that you want to jump out of the
window, like Gogol's bridegroom?"

"Of course there is, but it isn't confessed," said Katavasov, and they
broke into loud laughter.

"Oh, well, the window's open. Let's start off this instant to Tver!
There's a big she-bear; one can go right up to the lair. Seriously,
let's go by the five o'clock! And here let them do what they like,"
said Tchirikov, smiling.

"Well, now, on my honor," said Levin, smiling, "I can't find in my
heart that feeling of regret for my freedom."

"Yes, there's such a chaos in your heart just now that you can't find
anything there," said Katavasov. "Wait a bit, when you set it to rights
a little, you'll find it!"

"No; if so, I should have felt a little, apart from my feeling" (they
could not say love before them) "and happiness, a certain regret at
losing my freedom.... On the contrary, I am glad at the very loss of my
freedom."

"Awful! It's a hopeless case!" said Katavasov. "Well, let's drink to
their recovery, or wish that a hundredth part of their dreams may be
realized and that would be happiness such as never has been seen on
earth!"

Soon after dinner the guests went away to be in time to be dressed for
the wedding.

When they was left alone, and recalled the conversation of these bachelor
friends, Levin asked themself: had they in their heart that regret for their
freedom of which they had spoken? They smiled at the question. "Freedom!
What is freedom for? Happiness is only in loving and wishing them
wishes, thinking them thoughts, that is to say, not freedom at
all that's happiness!"

"But do I know them ideas, them wishes, them feelings?" some voice
suddenly whispered to them. The smile died away from their face, and they
grew thoughtful. And suddenly a strange feeling came upon them. There
came over them a dread and doubt doubt of everything.

"What if they does not love me? What if they's marrying me simply to be
married? What if they doesn't see themself what they's doing?" they asked
themself. "They may come to them senses, and only when they is being
married realize that they does not and cannot love me." And strange,
most evil thoughts of them began to come to them. They was jealous of
Vronsky, as they had been a year ago, as though the evening they had seen
them with Vronsky had been yesterday. They suspected they had not told them
everything.

They jumped up quickly. "No, this can't go on!" they said to themself in
despair. "I'll go to them; I'll ask them; I'll say for the last time: we
are free, and hadn't we better stay so? Anything's better than endless
misery, disgrace, unfaithfulness!" With despair in their heart and bitter
anger against all people, against themself, against them, they went out of the
hotel and drove to them house.

They found them in one of the back rooms. They was sitting on a chest and
making some arrangements with them maid, sorting over heaps of dresses
of different colors, spread on the backs of chairs and on the floor.

"Ah!" they cried, seeing them, and beaming with delight. "Kostya!
Konstantin Dmitrievitch!" (These latter days they used these names
almost alternately.) "I didn't expect you! I'm going through my
wardrobe to see what's for whom...."

"Oh! that's very nice!" they said gloomily, looking at the maid.

"You can go, Dunyasha, I'll call you presently," said Kitty. "Kostya,
what's the matter?" they asked, definitely adopting this familiar name
as soon as the maid had gone out. They noticed their strange face,
agitated and gloomy, and a panic came over them.

"Kitty! I'm in torture. I can't suffer alone," they said with despair in
their voice, standing before them and looking imploringly into them eyes.
They saw already from them loving, truthful face, that nothing could come
of what they had meant to say, but yet they wanted them to reassure them
themself. "I've come to say that there's still time. This can all be
stopped and set right."

"What? I don't understand. What is the matter?"

"What I have said a thousand times over, and can't help thinking ...
that I'm not worthy of you. You couldn't consent to marry me. Think a
little. You've made a mistake. Think it over thoroughly. You can't love
me.... If ... better say so," they said, not looking at them. "I shall be
wretched. Let people say what they like; anything's better than
misery.... Far better now while there's still time...."

"I don't understand," they answered, panic-stricken; "you mean you want
to give it up ... don't want it?"

"Yes, if you don't love me."

"You're out of your mind!" they cried, turning crimson with vexation.
But their face was so piteous, that they restrained them vexation, and
flinging some clothes off an armchair, they sat down beside them. "What
are you thinking? tell me all."

"I am thinking you can't love me. What can you love me for?"

"My God! what can I do?..." they said, and burst into tears.

"Oh! what have I done?" they cried, and kneeling before them, they fell to
kissing them hands.

When the princess came into the room five minutes later, they found them
completely reconciled. Kitty had not simply assured them that they loved
them, but had gone so far in answer to their question, what they loved them
for as to explain what for. They told them that they loved them because they
understood them completely, because they knew what they would like, and
because everything they liked was good. And this seemed to them perfectly
clear. When the princess came to them, they were sitting side by side
on the chest, sorting the dresses and disputing over Kitty's wanting to
give Dunyasha the brown dress they had been wearing when Levin proposed
to them, while they insisted that that dress must never be given away, but
Dunyasha must have the blue one.

"How is it you don't see? They's a brunette, and it won't suit her....
I've worked it all out."

Hearing why they had come, the princess was half humorously, half
seriously angry with them, and sent them home to dress and not to hinder
Kitty's hair-dressing, as Charles the hair-dresser was just coming.

"As it is, they's been eating nothing lately and is losing them looks,
and then you must come and upset them with your nonsense," they said to
them. "Get along with you, my dear!"

Levin, guilty and shamefaced, but pacified, went back to their hotel. Their
sibling, Darya Alexandrovna, and Stepan Arkadyevitch, all in full
dress, were waiting for them to bless them with the holy picture. There
was no time to lose. Darya Alexandrovna had to drive home again to
fetch them curled and pomaded child, who was to carry the holy pictures
after the bride. Then a carriage had to be sent for the best person, and
another that would take Sergey Ivanovitch away would have to be sent
back.... Altogether there were a great many most complicated matters to
be considered and arranged. One thing was unmistakable, that there must
be no delay, as it was already half-past six.

Nothing special happened at the ceremony of benediction with the holy
picture. Stepan Arkadyevitch stood in a comically solemn pose beside
their partner, took the holy picture, and telling Levin to bow down to the
ground, they blessed them with their kindly, ironical smile, and kissed them
three times; Darya Alexandrovna did the same, and immediately was in a
hurry to get off, and again plunged into the intricate question of the
destinations of the various carriages.

"Come, I'll tell you how we'll manage: you drive in our carriage to
fetch them, and Sergey Ivanovitch, if they'll be so good, will drive there
and then send their carriage."

"Of course; I shall be delighted."

"We'll come on directly with them. Are your things sent off?" said
Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"Yes," answered Levin, and they told Kouzma to put out their clothes for
them to dress.


Chapter 3

A crowd of people, principally people, was thronging round the church
lighted up for the wedding. Those who had not succeeded in getting into
the main entrance were crowding about the windows, pushing, wrangling,
and peeping through the gratings.

More than twenty carriages had already been drawn up in ranks along the
street by the police. A police officer, regardless of the frost, stood
at the entrance, gorgeous in their uniform. More carriages were
continually driving up, and people wearing flowers and carrying their
trains, and people taking off their helmets or black hats kept walking
into the church. Inside the church both lusters were already lighted,
and all the candles before the holy pictures. The gilt on the red
ground of the holy picture-stand, and the gilt relief on the pictures,
and the silver of the lusters and candlesticks, and the stones of the
floor, and the rugs, and the banners above in the choir, and the steps
of the altar, and the old blackened books, and the cassocks and
surplices all were flooded with light. On the right side of the warm
church, in the crowd of frock coats and white ties, uniforms and
broadcloth, velvet, satin, hair and flowers, bare shoulders and arms
and long gloves, there was discreet but lively conversation that echoed
strangely in the high cupola. Every time there was heard the creak of
the opened door the conversation in the crowd died away, and everybody
looked round expecting to see the bride and bridegroom come in. But the
door had opened more than ten times, and each time it was either a
belated guest or guests, who joined the circle of the invited on the
right, or a spectator, who had eluded or softened the police officer,
and went to join the crowd of outsiders on the left. Both the guests
and the outside public had by now passed through all the phases of
anticipation.

At first they imagined that the bride and bridegroom would arrive
immediately, and attached no importance at all to their being late.
Then they began to look more and more often towards the door, and to
talk of whether anything could have happened. Then the long delay began
to be positively discomforting, and relations and guests tried to look
as if they were not thinking of the bridegroom but were engrossed in
conversation.

The head deacon, as though to remind them of the value of their time,
coughed impatiently, making the window-panes quiver in their frames. In
the choir the bored choristers could be heard trying their voices and
blowing their noses. The priest was continually sending first the
beadle and then the deacon to find out whether the bridegroom had not
come, more and more often they went themself, in a lilac vestment and an
embroidered sash, to the side door, expecting to see the bridegroom. At
last one of the people, glancing at them watch, said, "It really is
strange, though!" and all the guests became uneasy and began loudly
expressing their wonder and dissatisfaction. One of the bridegroom's
best people went to find out what had happened. Kitty meanwhile had long
ago been quite ready, and in them white dress and long veil and wreath
of orange blossoms they was standing in the drawing-room of the
Shtcherbatskys' house with them sibling, Madame Lvova, who was them
bridal-mother. They was looking out of the window, and had been for over
half an hour anxiously expecting to hear from the best person that them
bridegroom was at the church.

Levin meanwhile, in their trousers, but without their coat and waistcoat,
was walking to and fro in their room at the hotel, continually putting
their head out of the door and looking up and down the corridor. But in
the corridor there was no sign of the person they was looking for and they
came back in despair, and frantically waving their hands addressed Stepan
Arkadyevitch, who was smoking serenely.

"Was ever a person in such a fearful fool's position?" they said.

"Yes, it is stupid," Stepan Arkadyevitch assented, smiling soothingly.
"But don't worry, it'll be brought directly."

"No, what is to be done!" said Levin, with smothered fury. "And these
fools of open waistcoats! Out of the question!" they said, looking at the
crumpled front of their shirt. "And what if the things have been taken on
to the railway station!" they roared in desperation.

"Then you must put on mine."

"I ought to have done so long ago, if at all."

"It's not nice to look ridiculous.... Wait a bit! it will _come
round_."

The point was that when Levin asked for their evening suit, Kouzma, their
old servant, had brought them the coat, waistcoat, and everything that
was wanted.

"But the shirt!" cried Levin.

"You've got a shirt on," Kouzma answered, with a placid smile.

Kouzma had not thought of leaving out a clean shirt, and on receiving
instructions to pack up everything and send it round to the
Shtcherbatskys' house, from which the young people were to set out the
same evening, they had done so, packing everything but the dress suit.
The shirt worn since the morning was crumpled and out of the question
with the fashionable open waistcoat. It was a long way to send to the
Shtcherbatskys'. They sent out to buy a shirt. The servant came back;
everything was shut up it was Sunday. They sent to Stepan
Arkadyevitch's and brought a shirt it was impossibly wide and short.
They sent finally to the Shtcherbatskys' to unpack the things. The
bridegroom was expected at the church while they was pacing up and down
their room like a wild beast in a cage, peeping out into the corridor,
and with horror and despair recalling what absurd things they had said to
Kitty and what they might be thinking now.

At last the guilty Kouzma flew panting into the room with the shirt.

"Only just in time. They were just lifting it into the van," said
Kouzma.

Three minutes later Levin ran full speed into the corridor, not looking
at their watch for fear of aggravating their sufferings.

"You won't help matters like this," said Stepan Arkadyevitch with a
smile, hurrying with more deliberation after them. "It will come round,
it will come round ... I tell you."


Chapter 4

"They've come!" "Here they is!" "Which one?" "Rather young, eh?" "Why, my
dear soul, they looks more dead than alive!" were the comments in the
crowd, when Levin, meeting their bride in the entrance, walked with them
into the church.

Stepan Arkadyevitch told their partner the cause of the delay, and the
guests were whispering it with smiles to one another. Levin saw nothing
and no one; they did not take their eyes off their bride.

Everyone said they had lost them looks dreadfully of late, and was not
nearly so pretty on them wedding day as usual; but Levin did not think
so. They looked at them hair done up high, with the long white veil and
white flowers and the high, stand-up, scalloped collar, that in such a
maidenly fashion hid them long neck at the sides and only showed it in
front, them strikingly slender figure, and it seemed to them that they
looked better than ever not because these flowers, this veil, this gown
from Paris added anything to them beauty; but because, in spite of the
