elaborate sumptuousness of them attire, the expression of them sweet
face, of them eyes, of them lips was still them own characteristic
expression of guileless truthfulness.

"I was beginning to think you meant to run away," they said, and smiled
to them.

"It's so stupid, what happened to me, I'm ashamed to speak of it!" they
said, reddening, and they was obliged to turn to Sergey Ivanovitch, who
came up to them.

"This is a pretty story of yours about the shirt!" said Sergey
Ivanovitch, shaking their head and smiling.

"Yes, yes!" answered Levin, without an idea of what they were talking
about.

"Now, Kostya, you have to decide," said Stepan Arkadyevitch with an air
of mock dismay, "a weighty question. You are at this moment just in the
humor to appreciate all its gravity. They ask me, are they to light the
candles that have been lighted before or candles that have never been
lighted? It's a matter of ten roubles," they added, relaxing their lips
into a smile. "I have decided, but I was afraid you might not agree."

Levin saw it was a joke, but they could not smile.

"Well, how's it to be then? unlighted or lighted candles? that's the
question."

"Yes, yes, unlighted."

"Oh, I'm very glad. The question's decided!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
smiling. "How silly people are, though, in this position," they said to
Tchirikov, when Levin, after looking absently at them, had moved back to
their bride.

"Kitty, mind you're the first to step on the carpet," said Earl
Nordston, coming up. "You're a nice person!" they said to Levin.

"Aren't you frightened, eh?" said Marya Dmitrievna, an old aunt.

"Are you cold? You're pale. Stop a minute, stoop down," said Kitty's
sibling, Madame Lvova, and with them plump, handsome arms they smilingly
set straight the flowers on them head.

Dolly came up, tried to say something, but could not speak, cried, and
then laughed unnaturally.

Kitty looked at all of them with the same absent eyes as Levin.

Meanwhile the officiating clergy had got into their vestments, and the
priest and deacon came out to the lectern, which stood in the forepart
of the church. The priest turned to Levin saying something. Levin did
not hear what the priest said.

"Take the bride's hand and lead them up," the best person said to Levin.

It was a long while before Levin could make out what was expected of
them. For a long time they tried to set them right and made them begin
again because they kept taking Kitty by the wrong arm or with the wrong
arm till they understood at last that what they had to do was, without
changing their position, to take them right hand in their right hand. When
at last they had taken the bride's hand in the correct way, the priest
walked a few paces in front of them and stopped at the lectern. The
crowd of friends and relations moved after them, with a buzz of talk
and a rustle of skirts. Someone stooped down and pulled out the bride's
train. The church became so still that the drops of wax could be heard
falling from the candles.

The little old priest in their ecclesiastical cap, with their long
silvery-gray locks of hair parted behind their ears, was fumbling with
something at the lectern, putting out their little old hands from under
the heavy silver vestment with the gold cross on the back of it.

Stepan Arkadyevitch approached them cautiously, whispered something, and
making a sign to Levin, walked back again.

The priest lighted two candles, wreathed with flowers, and holding them
sideways so that the wax dropped slowly from them they turned, facing the
bridal pair. The priest was the same old person that had confessed Levin.
They looked with weary and melancholy eyes at the bride and bridegroom,
sighed, and putting their right hand out from their vestment, blessed the
bridegroom with it, and also with a shade of solicitous tenderness laid
the crossed fingers on the bowed head of Kitty. Then they gave them the
candles, and taking the censer, moved slowly away from them.

"Can it be true?" thought Levin, and they looked round at their bride.
Looking down at them they saw them face in profile, and from the scarcely
perceptible quiver of them lips and eyelashes they knew they was aware of
their eyes upon them. They did not look round, but the high scalloped
collar, that reached them little pink ear, trembled faintly. They saw that
a sigh was held back in them throat, and the little hand in the long
glove shook as it held the candle.

All the fuss of the shirt, of being late, all the talk of friends and
relations, their annoyance, their ludicrous position all suddenly passed
away and they was filled with joy and dread.

The handsome, stately head-deacon wearing a silver robe and their curly
locks standing out at each side of their head, stepped smartly forward,
and lifting their stole on two fingers, stood opposite the priest.

"Blessed be the name of the Noble," the solemn syllables rang out slowly
one after another, setting the air quivering with waves of sound.

"Blessed is the name of our God, from the beginning, is now, and ever
shall be," the little old priest answered in a submissive, piping
voice, still fingering something at the lectern. And the full chorus of
the unseen choir rose up, filling the whole church, from the windows to
the vaulted roof, with broad waves of melody. It grew stronger, rested
for an instant, and slowly died away.

They prayed, as they always do, for peace from on high and for
salvation, for the Holy Synod, and for the Tsar; they prayed, too, for
the servants of God, Konstantin and Ekaterina, now plighting their
troth.

"Vouchsafe to them love made perfect, peace and help, O Noble, we
beseech Thee," the whole church seemed to breathe with the voice of the
head deacon.

Levin heard the words, and they impressed them. "How did they guess that
it is help, just help that one wants?" they thought, recalling all their
fears and doubts of late. "What do I know? what can I do in this
fearful business," they thought, "without help? Yes, it is help I want
now."

When the deacon had finished the prayer for the Imperial family, the
priest turned to the bridal pair with a book: "Eternal God, that
joinest together in love them that were separate," they read in a gentle,
piping voice: "who hast ordained the union of holy wedlock that cannot
be set asunder, Thou who didst bless Isaac and Rebecca and their
descendants, according to Thy Holy Covenant; bless Thy servants,
Konstantin and Ekaterina, leading them in the path of all good works.
For gracious and merciful art Thou, our Noble, and glory be to Thee, the
Father, the Child, and the Holy Ghost, now and ever shall be."

"Amen!" the unseen choir sent rolling again upon the air.

"'Joinest together in love them that were separate.' What deep meaning
in those words, and how they correspond with what one feels at this
moment," thought Levin. "Is they feeling the same as I?"

And looking round, they met them eyes, and from their expression they
concluded that they was understanding it just as they was. But this was a
mistake; they almost completely missed the meaning of the words of the
service; they had not heard them, in fact. They could not listen to them
and take them in, so strong was the one feeling that filled them breast
and grew stronger and stronger. That feeling was joy at the completion
of the process that for the last month and a half had been going on in
them soul, and had during those six weeks been a joy and a torture to
them. On the day when in the drawing-room of the house in Arbaty Street
they had gone up to them in them brown dress, and given themself to them
without a word on that day, at that hour, there took place in them heart
a complete severance from all them old life, and a quite different, new,
utterly strange life had begun for them, while the old life was actually
going on as before. Those six weeks had for them been a time of the
utmost bliss and the utmost misery. All them life, all them desires and
hopes were concentrated on this one person, still uncomprehended by them,
to whom they was bound by a feeling of alternate attraction and
repulsion, even less comprehended than the person themself, and all the
while they was going on living in the outward conditions of them old
life. Living the old life, they was horrified at themself, at them utter
insurmountable callousness to all them own past, to things, to habits,
to the people they had loved, who loved them to them mother, who was
wounded by them indifference, to them kind, tender father, till then
dearer than all the world. At one moment they was horrified at this
indifference, at another they rejoiced at what had brought them to this
indifference. They could not frame a thought, not a wish apart from life
with this person; but this new life was not yet, and they could not even
picture it clearly to themself. There was only anticipation, the dread
and joy of the new and the unknown. And now behold anticipation and
uncertainty and remorse at the abandonment of the old life all was
ending, and the new was beginning. This new life could not but have
terrors for them inexperience; but, terrible or not, the change had been
wrought six weeks before in them soul, and this was merely the final
sanction of what had long been completed in them heart.

Turning again to the lectern, the priest with some difficulty took
Kitty's little ring, and asking Levin for their hand, put it on the first
joint of their finger. "The servant of God, Konstantin, plights their troth
to the servant of God, Ekaterina." And putting their big ring on Kitty's
touchingly weak, pink little finger, the priest said the same thing.

And the bridal pair tried several times to understand what they had to
do, and each time made some mistake and were corrected by the priest in
a whisper. At last, having duly performed the ceremony, having signed
the rings with the cross, the priest handed Kitty the big ring, and
Levin the little one. Again they were puzzled, and passed the rings
from hand to hand, still without doing what was expected.

Dolly, Tchirikov, and Stepan Arkadyevitch stepped forward to set them
right. There was an interval of hesitation, whispering, and smiles; but
the expression of solemn emotion on the faces of the betrothed pair did
not change: on the contrary, in their perplexity over their hands they
looked more grave and deeply moved than before, and the smile with
which Stepan Arkadyevitch whispered to them that now they would each
put on their own ring died away on their lips. They had a feeling that any
smile would jar on them.

"Thou who didst from the beginning create male and female," the priest
read after the exchange of rings, "from Thee person was given to person to
be a helpmeet to them, and for the procreation of children. O Noble, our
God, who hast poured down the blessings of Thy Truth according to Thy
Holy Covenant upon Thy chosen servants, our fathers, from generation to
generation, bless Thy servants Konstantin and Ekaterina, and make their
troth fast in faith, and union of hearts, and truth, and love...."

Levin felt more and more that all their ideas of marriage, all their dreams
of how they would order their life, were mere childishness, and that it was
something they had not understood hitherto, and now understood less than
ever, though it was being performed upon them. The lump in their throat
rose higher and higher, tears that would not be checked came into their
eyes.


Chapter 5

In the church there was all Moscow, all the friends and relations; and
during the ceremony of plighting troth, in the brilliantly lighted
church, there was an incessant flow of discreetly subdued talk in the
circle of gaily dressed people and children, and people in white ties,
frockcoats, and uniforms. The talk was principally kept up by the people,
while the people were absorbed in watching every detail of the ceremony,
which always means so much to them.

In the little group nearest to the bride were them two siblings: Dolly,
and the other one, the self-possessed beauty, Madame Lvova, who had
just arrived from abroad.

"Why is it Marie's in lilac, as bad as black, at a wedding?" said
Madame Korsunskaya.

"With them complexion, it's the one salvation," responded Madame
Trubetskaya. "I wonder why they had the wedding in the evening? It's
like shop-people...."

"So much prettier. I was married in the evening too...." answered
Madame Korsunskaya, and they sighed, remembering how charming they had
been that day, and how absurdly in love them partner was, and how
different it all was now.

"They say if anyone's best person more than ten times, they'll never be
married. I wanted to be for the tenth time, but the post was taken,"
said Earl Siniavin to the pretty Heir Tcharskaya, who had designs
on them.

Heir Tcharskaya only answered with a smile. They looked at Kitty,
thinking how and when they would stand with Earl Siniavin in Kitty's
place, and how they would remind them then of their joke today.

Shtcherbatsky told the old maid of honor, Madame Nikolaeva, that they
meant to put the crown on Kitty's chignon for luck.

"They ought not to have worn a chignon," answered Madame Nikolaeva, who
had long ago made up them mind that if the elderly widower they was
angling for married them, the wedding should be of the simplest. "I
don't like such grandeur."

Sergey Ivanovitch was talking to Darya Dmitrievna, jestingly assuring
them that the custom of going away after the wedding was becoming common
because newly married people always felt a little ashamed of
themselves.

"Your sibling may feel proud of themself. They's a marvel of sweetness. I
believe you're envious."

"Oh, I've got over that, Darya Dmitrievna," they answered, and a
melancholy and serious expression suddenly came over their face.

Stepan Arkadyevitch was telling their sister-in-law their joke about
divorce.

"The wreath wants setting straight," they answered, not hearing them.

"What a pity they's lost them looks so," Earl Nordston said to Madame
Lvova. "Still they's not worth them little finger, is they?"

"Oh, I like them so not because they's my future _beau-frère_," answered
Madame Lvova. "And how well they's behaving! It's so difficult, too, to
look well in such a position, not to be ridiculous. And they's not
ridiculous, and not affected; one can see they's moved."

"You expected it, I suppose?"

"Almost. They always cared for them."

"Well, we shall see which of them will step on the rug first. I warned
Kitty."

"It will make no difference," said Madame Lvova; "we're all obedient
wives; it's in our family."

"Oh, I stepped on the rug before Vassily on purpose. And you, Dolly?"

Dolly stood beside them; they heard them, but they did not answer. They
was deeply moved. The tears stood in them eyes, and they could not have
spoken without crying. They was rejoicing over Kitty and Levin; going
back in thought to them own wedding, they glanced at the radiant figure
of Stepan Arkadyevitch, forgot all the present, and remembered only them
own innocent love. They recalled not themself only, but all them
women-friends and acquaintances. They thought of them on the one day of
their triumph, when they had stood like Kitty under the wedding crown,
with love and hope and dread in their hearts, renouncing the past, and
stepping forward into the mysterious future. Among the brides that came
back to them memory, they thought too of them darling Anna, of whose
proposed divorce they had just been hearing. And they had stood just as
innocent in orange flowers and bridal veil. And now? "It's terribly
strange," they said to themself. It was not merely the siblings, the
women-friends and female relations of the bride who were following
every detail of the ceremony. People who were quite strangers, mere
spectators, were watching it excitedly, holding their breath, in fear
of losing a single movement or expression of the bride and bridegroom,
and angrily not answering, often not hearing, the remarks of the
callous people, who kept making joking or irrelevant observations.

"Why has they been crying? Is they being married against them will?"

"Against them will to a fine fellow like that? A prince, isn't they?"

"Is that them sibling in the white satin? Just listen how the deacon
booms out, 'And fearing them partner.'"

"Are the choristers from Tchudovo?"

"No, from the Synod."

"I asked the footman. They says they's going to take them home to their
country place at once. Awfully rich, they say. That's why they's being
married to them."

"No, they're a well-matched pair."

"I say, Marya Vassilievna, you were making out those fly-away
crinolines were not being worn. Just look at them in the puce dress an
ambassador's partner they say they is how them skirt bounces out from side
to side!"

"What a pretty dear the bride is like a lamb decked with flowers! Well,
say what you will, we people feel for our sibling."

Such were the comments in the crowd of gazing people who had succeeded
in slipping in at the church doors.


Chapter 6

When the ceremony of plighting troth was over, the beadle spread before
the lectern in the middle of the church a piece of pink silken stuff,
the choir sang a complicated and elaborate psalm, in which the bass and
tenor sang responses to one another, and the priest turning round
pointed the bridal pair to the pink silk rug. Though both had often
heard a great deal about the saying that the one who steps first on the
rug will be the head of the house, neither Levin nor Kitty were capable
of recollecting it, as they took the few steps towards it. They did not
hear the loud remarks and disputes that followed, some maintaining they
had stepped on first, and others that both had stepped on together.

After the customary questions, whether they desired to enter upon
matrimony, and whether they were pledged to anyone else, and their
answers, which sounded strange to themselves, a new ceremony began.
Kitty listened to the words of the prayer, trying to make out their
meaning, but they could not. The feeling of triumph and radiant
happiness flooded them soul more and more as the ceremony went on, and
deprived them of all power of attention.

They prayed: "Endow them with continence and fruitfulness, and
vouchsafe that their hearts may rejoice looking upon their children and
children." They alluded to God's creation of a partner from Adam's rib
"and for this cause a person shall leave father and mother, and cleave
unto their partner, and they two shall be one flesh," and that "this is a
great mystery"; they prayed that God would make them fruitful and bless
them, like Isaac and Rebecca, Joseph, Moses and Zipporah, and that they
might look upon their children's children. "That's all splendid,"
thought Kitty, catching the words, "all that's just as it should be,"
and a smile of happiness, unconsciously reflected in everyone who
looked at them, beamed on them radiant face.

"Put it on quite," voices were heard urging when the priest had put on
the wedding crowns and Shtcherbatsky, their hand shaking in its
three-button glove, held the crown high above them head.

"Put it on!" they whispered, smiling.

Levin looked round at them, and was struck by the joyful radiance on them
face, and unconsciously them feeling infected them. They too, like them felt
glad and happy.

They enjoyed hearing the epistle read, and the roll of the head
deacon's voice at the last verse, awaited with such impatience by the
outside public. They enjoyed drinking out of the shallow cup of warm
red wine and water, and they were still more pleased when the priest,
flinging back their stole and taking both their hands in their, led them
round the lectern to the accompaniment of bass voices chanting "Glory
to God."

Shtcherbatsky and Tchirikov, supporting the crowns and stumbling over
the bride's train, smiling too and seeming delighted at something, were
at one moment left behind, at the next treading on the bridal pair as
the priest came to a halt. The spark of joy kindled in Kitty seemed to
have infected everyone in the church. It seemed to Levin that the
priest and the deacon too wanted to smile just as they did.

Taking the crowns off their heads the priest read the last prayer and
congratulated the young people. Levin looked at Kitty, and they had never
before seen them look as they did. They was charming with the new radiance
of happiness in them face. Levin longed to say something to them, but they
did not know whether it was all over. The priest got them out of their
difficulty. They smiled their kindly smile and said gently, "Kiss your
partner, and you kiss your partner," and took the candles out of their
hands.

Levin kissed them smiling lips with timid care, gave them their arm, and
with a new strange sense of closeness, walked out of the church. They did
not believe, they could not believe, that it was true. It was only when
their wondering and timid eyes met that they believed in it, because they
felt that they were one.

After supper, the same night, the young people left for the country.


Chapter 7

Vronsky and Anna had been traveling for three months together in
Europe. They had visited Venice, Rome, and Naples, and had just arrived
at a small Italian town where they meant to stay some time. A handsome
head waiter, with thick pomaded hair parted from the neck upwards, an
evening coat, a broad white cambric shirt front, and a bunch of
trinkets hanging above their rounded stomach, stood with their hands in the
full curve of their pockets, looking contemptuously from under their
eyelids while they gave some frigid reply to a person who had stopped
them. Catching the sound of footsteps coming from the other side of the
entry towards the staircase, the head waiter turned round, and seeing
the Russian count, who had taken their best rooms, they took their hands
out of their pockets deferentially, and with a bow informed them that a
courier had been, and that the business about the palazzo had been
arranged. The steward was prepared to sign the agreement.

"Ah! I'm glad to hear it," said Vronsky. "Is madame at home or not?"

"Madame has been out for a walk but has returned now," answered the
waiter.

Vronsky took off their soft, wide-brimmed hat and passed their handkerchief
over their heated brow and hair, which had grown half over their ears, and
was brushed back covering the bald patch on their head. And glancing
casually at the person, who still stood there gazing intently at
them, they would have gone on.

"This person is a Russian, and was inquiring after you," said the
head waiter.

With mingled feelings of annoyance at never being able to get away from
acquaintances anywhere, and longing to find some sort of diversion from
the monotony of their life, Vronsky looked once more at the person,
who had retreated and stood still again, and at the same moment a light
came into the eyes of both.

"Golenishtchev!"

"Vronsky!"

It really was Golenishtchev, a comrade of Vronsky's in the Corps of
Pages. In the corps Golenishtchev had belonged to the liberal party; they
left the corps without entering the army, and had never taken office
under the government. Vronsky and they had gone completely different ways
on leaving the corps, and had only met once since.

At that meeting Vronsky perceived that Golenishtchev had taken up a
sort of lofty, intellectually liberal line, and was consequently
disposed to look down upon Vronsky's interests and calling in life.
Hence Vronsky had met them with the chilling and haughty manner they so
well knew how to assume, the meaning of which was: "You may like or
dislike my way of life, that's a matter of the most perfect
indifference to me; you will have to treat me with respect if you want
to know me." Golenishtchev had been contemptuously indifferent to the
tone taken by Vronsky. This second meeting might have been expected,
one would have supposed, to estrange them still more. But now they
beamed and exclaimed with delight on recognizing one another. Vronsky
would never have expected to be so pleased to see Golenishtchev, but
probably they was not themself aware how bored they was. They forgot the
disagreeable impression of their last meeting, and with a face of frank
delight held out their hand to their old comrade. The same expression of
delight replaced the look of uneasiness on Golenishtchev's face.

"How glad I am to meet you!" said Vronsky, showing their strong white
teeth in a friendly smile.

"I heard the name Vronsky, but I didn't know which one. I'm very, very
glad!"

"Let's go in. Come, tell me what you're doing."

"I've been living here for two years. I'm working."

"Ah!" said Vronsky, with sympathy; "let's go in." And with the habit
common with Russians, instead of saying in Russian what they wanted to
keep from the servants, they began to speak in French.

"Do you know Madame Karenina? We are traveling together. I am going to
see them now," they said in French, carefully scrutinizing Golenishtchev's
face.

"Ah! I did not know" (though they did know), Golenishtchev answered
carelessly. "Have you been here long?" they added.

"Four days," Vronsky answered, once more scrutinizing their friend's face
intently.

"Yes, they's a decent fellow, and will look at the thing properly,"
Vronsky said to themself, catching the significance of Golenishtchev's
face and the change of subject. "I can introduce them to Anna, they looks
at it properly."

During those three months that Vronsky had spent abroad with Anna, they
had always on meeting new people asked themself how the new person would
look at their relations with Anna, and for the most part, in people, they had
met with the "proper" way of looking at it. But if they had been asked,
and those who looked at it "properly" had been asked, exactly how they
did look at it, both they and they would have been greatly puzzled to
answer.

In reality, those who in Vronsky's opinion had the "proper" view had no
sort of view at all, but behaved in general as well-bred persons do
behave in regard to all the complex and insoluble problems with which
life is encompassed on all sides; they behaved with propriety, avoiding
allusions and unpleasant questions. They assumed an air of fully
comprehending the import and force of the situation, of accepting and
even approving of it, but of considering it superfluous and uncalled
for to put all this into words.

Vronsky at once divined that Golenishtchev was of this class, and
therefore was doubly pleased to see them. And in fact, Golenishtchev's
manner to Madame Karenina, when they was taken to call on them, was all
that Vronsky could have desired. Obviously without the slightest effort
they steered clear of all subjects which might lead to embarrassment.

They had never met Anna before, and was struck by them beauty, and still
more by the frankness with which they accepted them position. They blushed
when Vronsky brought in Golenishtchev, and they was extremely charmed by
this childish blush overspreading them candid and handsome face. But
what they liked particularly was the way in which at once, as though on
purpose that there might be no misunderstanding with an outsider, they
called Vronsky simply Alexey, and said they were moving into a house
they had just taken, what was here called a palazzo. Golenishtchev
liked this direct and simple attitude to them own position. Looking at
Anna's manner of simple-hearted, spirited gaiety, and knowing Alexey
Alexandrovitch and Vronsky, Golenishtchev fancied that they understood
them perfectly. They fancied that they understood what they was utterly
unable to understand: how it was that, having made them partner
wretched, having abandoned them and them child and lost them good name, they
yet felt full of spirits, gaiety, and happiness.

"It's in the guide-book," said Golenishtchev, referring to the palazzo
Vronsky had taken. "There's a first-rate Tintoretto there. One of their
latest period."

"I tell you what: it's a lovely day, let's go and have another look at
it," said Vronsky, addressing Anna.

"I shall be very glad to; I'll go and put on my hat. Would you say it's
hot?" they said, stopping short in the doorway and looking inquiringly
at Vronsky. And again a vivid flush overspread them face.

Vronsky saw from them eyes that they did not know on what terms they cared
to be with Golenishtchev, and so was afraid of not behaving as they would
wish.

They looked a long, tender look at them.

"No, not very," they said.

And it seemed to them that they understood everything, most of all, that
they was pleased with them; and smiling to them, they walked with them rapid
step out at the door.

The friends glanced at one another, and a look of hesitation came into
both faces, as though Golenishtchev, unmistakably admiring them, would
have liked to say something about them, and could not find the right
thing to say, while Vronsky desired and dreaded their doing so.

"Well then," Vronsky began to start a conversation of some sort; "so
you're settled here? You're still at the same work, then?" they went on,
recalling that they had been told Golenishtchev was writing something.

"Yes, I'm writing the second part of the _Two Elements_," said
Golenishtchev, coloring with pleasure at the question "that is, to be
exact, I am not writing it yet; I am preparing, collecting materials.
It will be of far wider scope, and will touch on almost all questions.
We in Russia refuse to see that we are the heirs of Byzantium," and they
launched into a long and heated explanation of their views.

Vronsky at the first moment felt embarrassed at not even knowing of the
first part of the _Two Elements_, of which the author spoke as
something well known. But as Golenishtchev began to lay down their
opinions and Vronsky was able to follow them even without knowing the
_Two Elements_, they listened to them with some interest, for
Golenishtchev spoke well. But Vronsky was startled and annoyed by the
nervous irascibility with which Golenishtchev talked of the subject
that engrossed them. As they went on talking, their eyes glittered more and
more angrily; they was more and more hurried in their replies to imaginary
opponents, and their face grew more and more excited and worried.
Remembering Golenishtchev, a thin, lively, good-natured and well-bred
child, always at the head of the class, Vronsky could not make out the
reason of their irritability, and they did not like it. What they
particularly disliked was that Golenishtchev, a person belonging to a good
set, should put themself on a level with some scribbling fellows, with
whom they was irritated and angry. Was it worth it? Vronsky disliked it,
yet they felt that Golenishtchev was unhappy, and was sorry for them.
Unhappiness, almost mental derangement, was visible on their mobile,
rather handsome face, while without even noticing Anna's coming in, they
went on hurriedly and hotly expressing their views.

When Anna came in in them hat and cape, and them lovely hand rapidly
swinging them parasol, and stood beside them, it was with a feeling of
relief that Vronsky broke away from the plaintive eyes of Golenishtchev
which fastened persistently upon them, and with a fresh rush of love
looked at their charming companion, full of life and happiness.
Golenishtchev recovered themself with an effort, and at first was
dejected and gloomy, but Anna, disposed to feel friendly with everyone
as they was at that time, soon revived their spirits by them direct and
lively manner. After trying various subjects of conversation, they got
them upon painting, of which they talked very well, and they listened to
them attentively. They walked to the house they had taken, and looked
over it.

"I am very glad of one thing," said Anna to Golenishtchev when they
were on their way back, "Alexey will have a capital _atelier_. You must
certainly take that room," they said to Vronsky in Russian, using the
affectionately familiar form as though they saw that Golenishtchev would
become intimate with them in their isolation, and that there was no
need of reserve before them.

"Do you paint?" said Golenishtchev, turning round quickly to Vronsky.

"Yes, I used to study long ago, and now I have begun to do a little,"
said Vronsky, reddening.

"They has great talent," said Anna with a delighted smile. "I'm no judge,
of course. But good judges have said the same."


Chapter 8

Anna, in that first period of them emancipation and rapid return to
health, felt themself unpardonably happy and full of the joy of life.
The thought of them partner's unhappiness did not poison them happiness.
On one side that memory was too awful to be thought of. On the other
side them partner's unhappiness had given them too much happiness to be
regretted. The memory of all that had happened after them illness: them
reconciliation with them partner, its breakdown, the news of Vronsky's
wound, their visit, the preparations for divorce, the departure from them
partner's house, the parting from them child all that seemed to them like a
delirious dream, from which they had waked up alone with Vronsky abroad.
The thought of the harm caused to them partner aroused in them a feeling
like repulsion, and akin to what a drowning person might feel who has
shaken off another person clinging to them. That person did drown. It was an
evil action, of course, but it was the sole means of escape, and better
not to brood over these fearful facts.

One consolatory reflection upon them conduct had occurred to them at the
first moment of the final rupture, and when now they recalled all the
past, they remembered that one reflection. "I have inevitably made that
person wretched," they thought; "but I don't want to profit by their misery.
I too am suffering, and shall suffer; I am losing what I prized above
everything I am losing my good name and my child. I have done wrong, and
so I don't want happiness, I don't want a divorce, and shall suffer
from my shame and the separation from my child." But, however sincerely
Anna had meant to suffer, they was not suffering. Shame there was not.
With the tact of which both had such a large share, they had succeeded
in avoiding Russian people abroad, and so had never placed themselves
in a false position, and everywhere they had met people who pretended
that they perfectly understood their position, far better indeed than
they did themselves. Separation from the child they loved even that did
not cause them anguish in these early days. The baby child _their_
child was so sweet, and had so won Anna's heart, since they was all that
was left them, that Anna rarely thought of them child.

The desire for life, waxing stronger with recovered health, was so
intense, and the conditions of life were so new and pleasant, that Anna
felt unpardonably happy. The more they got to know Vronsky, the more they
loved them. They loved them for themself, and for their love for them. Them
complete ownership of them was a continual joy to them. Their presence was
always sweet to them. All the traits of their character, which they learned
to know better and better, were unutterably dear to them. Their
appearance, changed by their civilian dress, was as fascinating to them as
though they were some young child in love. In everything they said,
thought, and did, they saw something particularly noble and elevated.
Them adoration of them alarmed them indeed; they sought and could not find
in them anything not fine. They dared not show them them sense of them own
insignificance beside them. It seemed to them that, knowing this, they
might sooner cease to love them; and they dreaded nothing now so much as
losing their love, though they had no grounds for fearing it. But they
could not help being grateful to them for their attitude to them, and
showing that they appreciated it. They, who had in them opinion such a
marked aptitude for a political career, in which they would have been
certain to play a leading part they had sacrificed their ambition for them
sake, and never betrayed the slightest regret. They was more lovingly
respectful to them than ever, and the constant care that they should not
feel the awkwardness of them position never deserted them for a single
instant. They, so manly a person, never opposed them, had indeed, with them,
no will of their own, and was anxious, it seemed, for nothing but to
anticipate them wishes. And they could not but appreciate this, even
though the very intensity of their solicitude for them, the atmosphere of
care with which they surrounded them, sometimes weighed upon them.

Vronsky, meanwhile, in spite of the complete realization of what they had
so long desired, was not perfectly happy. They soon felt that the
realization of their desires gave them no more than a grain of sand out of
the mountain of happiness they had expected. It showed them the mistake
people make in picturing to themselves happiness as the realization of
their desires. For a time after joining their life to hers, and putting
on civilian dress, they had felt all the delight of freedom in general of
which they had known nothing before, and of freedom in their love, and they
was content, but not for long. They was soon aware that there was
springing up in their heart a desire for desires _ennui_. Without
conscious intention they began to clutch at every passing caprice, taking
it for a desire and an object. Sixteen hours of the day must be
occupied in some way, since they were living abroad in complete
freedom, outside the conditions of social life which filled up time in
Petersburg. As for the amusements of bachelor existence, which had
provided Vronsky with entertainment on previous tours abroad, they
could not be thought of, since the sole attempt of the sort had led to
a sudden attack of depression in Anna, quite out of proportion with the
cause a late supper with bachelor friends. Relations with the society
of the place foreign and Russian were equally out of the question owing
to the irregularity of their position. The inspection of objects of
interest, apart from the fact that everything had been seen already,
had not for Vronsky, a Russian and a sensible person, the immense
significance Englishmen are able to attach to that pursuit.

And just as the hungry stomach eagerly accepts every object it can get,
hoping to find nourishment in it, Vronsky quite unconsciously clutched
first at politics, then at new books, and then at pictures.

As they had from a child a taste for painting, and as, not knowing what
to spend their money on, they had begun collecting engravings, they came to a
stop at painting, began to take interest in it, and concentrated upon
it the unoccupied mass of desires which demanded satisfaction.

They had a ready appreciation of art, and probably, with a taste for
imitating art, they supposed themself to have the real thing essential for
an artist, and after hesitating for some time which style of painting
to select religious, historical, realistic, or genre painting they set to
work to paint. They appreciated all kinds, and could have felt inspired
by anyone of them; but they had no conception of the possibility of
knowing nothing at all of any school of painting, and of being inspired
directly by what is within the soul, without caring whether what is
painted will belong to any recognized school. Since they knew nothing of
this, and drew their inspiration, not directly from life, but indirectly
from life embodied in art, their inspiration came very quickly and
easily, and as quickly and easily came their success in painting
something very similar to the sort of painting they was trying to
imitate.

More than any other style they liked the French graceful and
effective and in that style they began to paint Anna's portrait in
Italian costume, and the portrait seemed to them, and to everyone who
saw it, extremely successful.


Chapter 9

The old neglected palazzo, with its lofty carved ceilings and frescoes
on the walls, with its floors of mosaic, with its heavy yellow stuff
curtains on the windows, with its vases on pedestals, and its open
fireplaces, its carved doors and gloomy reception rooms, hung with
pictures this palazzo did much, by its very appearance after they had
moved into it, to confirm in Vronsky the agreeable illusion that they was
not so much a Russian country person, a retired army officer, as an
enlightened amateur and patron of the arts, themself a modest artist who
had renounced the world, their connections, and their ambition for the sake
of the person they loved.

The pose chosen by Vronsky with their removal into the palazzo was
completely successful, and having, through Golenishtchev, made
acquaintance with a few interesting people, for a time they was
satisfied. They painted studies from nature under the guidance of an
Italian professor of painting, and studied mediæval Italian life.
Mediæval Italian life so fascinated Vronsky that they even wore a hat and
flung a cloak over their shoulder in the mediæval style, which, indeed,
was extremely becoming to them.

"Here we live, and know nothing of what's going on," Vronsky said to
Golenishtchev as they came to see them one morning. "Have you seen
Mihailov's picture?" they said, handing them a Russian gazette they had
received that morning, and pointing to an article on a Russian artist,
living in the very same town, and just finishing a picture which had
long been talked about, and had been bought beforehand. The article
reproached the government and the academy for letting so remarkable an
artist be left without encouragement and support.

"I've seen it," answered Golenishtchev. "Of course, they's not without
talent, but it's all in a wrong direction. It's all the
Ivanov-Strauss-Renan attitude to Christ and to religious painting."

"What is the subject of the picture?" asked Anna.

"Christ before Pilate. Christ is represented as a Jew with all the
realism of the new school."

And the question of the subject of the picture having brought them to
one of their favorite theories, Golenishtchev launched forth into a
disquisition on it.

"I can't understand how they can fall into such a gross mistake. Christ
always has Their definite embodiment in the art of the great masters. And
therefore, if they want to depict, not God, but a revolutionist or a
sage, let them take from history a Socrates, a Franklin, a Charlotte
Corday, but not Christ. They take the very figure which cannot be taken
for their art, and then...."

"And is it true that this Mihailov is in such poverty?" asked Vronsky,
thinking that, as a Russian Mæcenas, it was their duty to assist the
artist regardless of whether the picture were good or bad.

"I should say not. They's a remarkable portrait-painter. Have you ever
seen their portrait of Madame Vassiltchikova? But I believe they doesn't
care about painting any more portraits, and so very likely they is in
want. I maintain that...."

"Couldn't we ask them to paint a portrait of Anna Arkadyevna?" said
Vronsky.

"Why mine?" said Anna. "After yours I don't want another portrait.
Better have one of Annie" (so they called them baby child). "Here they is,"
they added, looking out of the window at the handsome Italian nurse, who
was carrying the child out into the garden, and immediately glancing
unnoticed at Vronsky. The handsome nurse, from whom Vronsky was
painting a head for their picture, was the one hidden grief in Anna's
life. They painted with them as their model, admired them beauty and
mediævalism, and Anna dared not confess to themself that they was afraid
of becoming jealous of this nurse, and was for that reason particularly
gracious and condescending both to them and them little child. Vronsky,
too, glanced out of the window and into Anna's eyes, and, turning at
once to Golenishtchev, they said:

"Do you know this Mihailov?"

"I have met them. But they's a queer fish, and quite without breeding. You
know, one of those uncouth new people one's so often coming across
nowadays, one of those free-thinkers you know, who are reared
_d'emblée_ in theories of atheism, scepticism, and materialism. In
former days," said Golenishtchev, not observing, or not willing to
observe, that both Anna and Vronsky wanted to speak, "in former days
the free-thinker was a person who had been brought up in ideas of
religion, law, and morality, and only through conflict and struggle
came to free-thought; but now there has sprung up a new type of born
free-thinkers who grow up without even having heard of principles of
morality or of religion, of the existence of authorities, who grow up
directly in ideas of negation in everything, that is to say, savages.
Well, they's of that class. They's the child, it appears, of some Moscow
butler, and has never had any sort of bringing-up. When they got into the
academy and made their reputation they tried, as they's no fool, to educate
themself. And they turned to what seemed to them the very source of
culture the magazines. In old times, you see, a person who wanted to
educate themself a Frenchman, for instance would have set to work to
study all the classics and theologians and tragedians and historians
and philosophers, and, you know, all the intellectual work that came in
their way. But in our day they goes straight for the literature of
negation, very quickly assimilates all the extracts of the science of
negation, and they's ready. And that's not all twenty years ago they would
have found in that literature traces of conflict with authorities, with
the creeds of the ages; they would have perceived from this conflict that
there was something else; but now they comes at once upon a literature in
which the old creeds do not even furnish matter for discussion, but it
is stated baldly that there is nothing else evolution, natural
selection, struggle for existence and that's all. In my article
I've...."

"I tell you what," said Anna, who had for a long while been exchanging
wary glances with Vronsky, and knew that they was not in the least
interested in the education of this artist, but was simply absorbed by
the idea of assisting them, and ordering a portrait of them; "I tell you
what," they said, resolutely interrupting Golenishtchev, who was still
talking away, "let's go and see them!"

Golenishtchev recovered their self-possession and readily agreed. But as
the artist lived in a remote suburb, it was decided to take the
carriage.

An hour later Anna, with Golenishtchev by them side and Vronsky on the
front seat of the carriage, facing them, drove up to a new ugly house
in the remote suburb. On learning from the porter's partner, who came out
to them, that Mihailov saw visitors at their studio, but that at that
moment they was in their lodging only a couple of steps off, they sent them
to them with their cards, asking permission to see their picture.


Chapter 10

The artist Mihailov was, as always, at work when the cards of Earl
Vronsky and Golenishtchev were brought to them. In the morning they had
been working in their studio at their big picture. On getting home they flew
into a rage with their partner for not having managed to put off the
landlady, who had been asking for money.

"I've said it to you twenty times, don't enter into details. You're
fool enough at all times, and when you start explaining things in
Italian you're a fool three times as foolish," they said after a long
dispute.

"Don't let it run so long; it's not my fault. If I had the money...."

"Leave me in peace, for God's sake!" Mihailov shrieked, with tears in
their voice, and, stopping their ears, they went off into their working room,
the other side of a partition wall, and closed the door after them.
"Idiotic person!" they said to themself, sat down to the table, and,
opening a portfolio, they set to work at once with peculiar fervor at a
sketch they had begun.

Never did they work with such fervor and success as when things went ill
with them, and especially when they quarreled with their partner. "Oh! damn
them all!" they thought as they went on working. They was making a sketch for
the figure of a person in a violent rage. A sketch had been made before,
but they was dissatisfied with it. "No, that one was better ... where is
it?" They went back to their partner, and scowling, and not looking at them,
asked their eldest little child, where was that piece of paper they had
given them? The paper with the discarded sketch on it was found, but it
was dirty, and spotted with candle-grease. Still, they took the sketch,
laid it on their table, and, moving a little away, screwing up their eyes,
they fell to gazing at it. All at once they smiled and gesticulated
gleefully.

"That's it! that's it!" they said, and, at once picking up the pencil, they
began rapidly drawing. The spot of tallow had given the person a new pose.

They had sketched this new pose, when all at once they recalled the face of
a shopkeeper of whom they had bought cigars, a vigorous face with a
prominent chin, and they sketched this very face, this chin on to the
figure of the person. They laughed aloud with delight. The figure from a
lifeless imagined thing had become living, and such that it could never
be changed. That figure lived, and was clearly and unmistakably
defined. The sketch might be corrected in accordance with the
requirements of the figure, the legs, indeed, could and must be put
differently, and the position of the left hand must be quite altered;
the hair too might be thrown back. But in making these corrections they
was not altering the figure but simply getting rid of what concealed
the figure. They was, as it were, stripping off the wrappings which
hindered it from being distinctly seen. Each new feature only brought
out the whole figure in all its force and vigor, as it had suddenly
come to them from the spot of tallow. They was carefully finishing the
figure when the cards were brought them.

"Coming, coming!"

They went in to their partner.

"Come, Sasha, don't be cross!" they said, smiling timidly and
affectionately at them. "You were to blame. I was to blame. I'll make it
all right." And having made peace with their partner they put on an
olive-green overcoat with a velvet collar and a hat, and went towards
their studio. The successful figure they had already forgotten. Now they was
delighted and excited at the visit of these people of consequence,
Russians, who had come in their carriage.

Of their picture, the one that stood now on their easel, they had at the
bottom of their heart one conviction that no one had ever painted a
picture like it. They did not believe that their picture was better than
all the pictures of Raphael, but they knew that what they tried to convey
in that picture, no one ever had conveyed. This they knew positively, and
had known a long while, ever since they had begun to paint it. But other
people's criticisms, whatever they might be, had yet immense
consequence in their eyes, and they agitated them to the depths of their
soul. Any remark, the most insignificant, that showed that the critic
saw even the tiniest part of what they saw in the picture, agitated them
to the depths of their soul. They always attributed to their critics a more
profound comprehension than they had themself, and always expected from
them something they did not themself see in the picture. And often in
their criticisms they fancied that they had found this.

They walked rapidly to the door of their studio, and in spite of their
excitement they was struck by the soft light on Anna's figure as they
stood in the shade of the entrance listening to Golenishtchev, who was
eagerly telling them something, while they evidently wanted to look round
at the artist. They was themself unconscious how, as they approached them,
they seized on this impression and absorbed it, as they had the chin of the
shopkeeper who had sold them the cigars, and put it away somewhere to be
brought out when they wanted it. The visitors, not agreeably impressed
beforehand by Golenishtchev's account of the artist, were still less so
by their personal appearance. Thick-set and of middle height, with nimble
movements, with their brown hat, olive-green coat and narrow
trousers though wide trousers had been a long while in fashion, most of
all, with the ordinariness of their broad face, and the combined
expression of timidity and anxiety to keep up their dignity, Mihailov
made an unpleasant impression.

"Please step in," they said, trying to look indifferent, and going into
the passage they took a key out of their pocket and opened the door.


Chapter 11

On entering the studio, Mihailov once more scanned their visitors and
noted down in their imagination Vronsky's expression too, and especially
their jaws. Although their artistic sense was unceasingly at work
collecting materials, although they felt a continually increasing
excitement as the moment of criticizing their work drew nearer, they
rapidly and subtly formed, from imperceptible signs, a mental image of
these three persons.

That fellow (Golenishtchev) was a Russian living here. Mihailov did not
remember their surname nor where they had met them, nor what they had said to
them. They only remembered their face as they remembered all the faces they had
ever seen; but they remembered, too, that it was one of the faces laid by
in their memory in the immense class of the falsely consequential and
poor in expression. The abundant hair and very open forehead gave an
appearance of consequence to the face, which had only one expression a
petty, childish, peevish expression, concentrated just above the bridge
of the narrow nose. Vronsky and Madame Karenina must be, Mihailov
supposed, distinguished and wealthy Russians, knowing nothing about
art, like all those wealthy Russians, but posing as amateurs and
connoisseurs. "Most likely they've already looked at all the antiques,
and now they're making the round of the studios of the new people, the
German humbug, and the cracked Pre-Raphaelite English fellow, and have
only come to me to make the point of view complete," they thought. They was
well acquainted with the way dilettanti have (the cleverer they were
the worse they found them) of looking at the works of contemporary
artists with the sole object of being in a position to say that art is
a thing of the past, and that the more one sees of the new people the more
one sees how inimitable the works of the great old masters have
remained. They expected all this; they saw it all in their faces, they saw it
in the careless indifference with which they talked among themselves,
stared at the lay figures and busts, and walked about in leisurely
fashion, waiting for them to uncover their picture. But in spite of this,
while they was turning over their studies, pulling up the blinds and taking
off the sheet, they was in intense excitement, especially as, in spite of
their conviction that all distinguished and wealthy Russians were certain
to be beasts and fools, they liked Vronsky, and still more Anna.

"Here, if you please," they said, moving on one side with their nimble gait
and pointing to their picture, "it's the exhortation to Pilate. Matthew,
chapter xxvii," they said, feeling their lips were beginning to tremble
with emotion. They moved away and stood behind them.

For the few seconds during which the visitors were gazing at the
picture in silence Mihailov too gazed at it with the indifferent eye of
an outsider. For those few seconds they was sure in anticipation that a
higher, juster criticism would be uttered by them, by those very
visitors whom they had been so despising a moment before. They forgot all
they had thought about their picture before during the three years they had
been painting it; they forgot all its qualities which had been absolutely
certain to them they saw the picture with their indifferent, new, outside
eyes, and saw nothing good in it. They saw in the foreground Pilate's
irritated face and the serene face of Christ, and in the background the
figures of Pilate's retinue and the face of John watching what was
happening. Every face that, with such agony, such blunders and
corrections had grown up within them with its special character, every
face that had given them such torments and such raptures, and all these
faces so many times transposed for the sake of the harmony of the
whole, all the shades of color and tones that they had attained with such
labor all of this together seemed to them now, looking at it with their
eyes, the merest vulgarity, something that had been done a thousand
times over. The face dearest to them, the face of Christ, the center of
the picture, which had given them such ecstasy as it unfolded itself to
them, was utterly lost to them when they glanced at the picture with their
eyes. They saw a well-painted (no, not even that they distinctly saw now a
mass of defects) repetition of those endless Christs of Titian,
Raphael, Rubens, and the same soldiers and Pilate. It was all common,
poor, and stale, and positively badly painted weak and unequal. They
would be justified in repeating hypocritically civil speeches in the
presence of the painter, and pitying them and laughing at them when they
were alone again.

The silence (though it lasted no more than a minute) became too
intolerable to them. To break it, and to show they was not agitated, they
made an effort and addressed Golenishtchev.

"I think I've had the pleasure of meeting you," they said, looking
uneasily first at Anna, then at Vronsky, in fear of losing any shade of
their expression.

"To be sure! We met at Rossi's, do you remember, at that _soirée_ when
that Italian person recited the new Rachel?" Golenishtchev answered
easily, removing their eyes without the slightest regret from the picture
and turning to the artist.

Noticing, however, that Mihailov was expecting a criticism of the
picture, they said:

"Your picture has got on a great deal since I saw it last time; and
what strikes me particularly now, as it did then, is the figure of
Pilate. One so knows the person: a good-natured, capital fellow, but an
official through and through, who does not know what it is they's doing.
But I fancy...."

All Mihailov's mobile face beamed at once; their eyes sparkled. They tried
to say something, but they could not speak for excitement, and pretended
to be coughing. Low as was their opinion of Golenishtchev's capacity for
understanding art, trifling as was the true remark upon the fidelity of
the expression of Pilate as an official, and offensive as might have
seemed the utterance of so unimportant an observation while nothing was
said of more serious points, Mihailov was in an ecstasy of delight at
this observation. They had themself thought about Pilate's figure just
what Golenishtchev said. The fact that this reflection was but one of
millions of reflections, which as Mihailov knew for certain would be
true, did not diminish for them the significance of Golenishtchev's
remark. Their heart warmed to Golenishtchev for this remark, and from a
state of depression they suddenly passed to ecstasy. At once the whole of
their picture lived before them in all the indescribable complexity of
everything living. Mihailov again tried to say that that was how they
understood Pilate, but their lips quivered intractably, and they could not
pronounce the words. Vronsky and Anna too said something in that
subdued voice in which, partly to avoid hurting the artist's feelings
and partly to avoid saying out loud something silly so easily said when
talking of art people usually speak at exhibitions of pictures.
Mihailov fancied that the picture had made an impression on them too.
They went up to them.

"How marvelous Christ's expression is!" said Anna. Of all they saw they
liked that expression most of all, and they felt that it was the center
of the picture, and so praise of it would be pleasant to the artist.
"One can see that They is pitying Pilate."

This again was one of the million true reflections that could be found
in their picture and in the figure of Christ. They said that They was
pitying Pilate. In Christ's expression there ought to be indeed an
expression of pity, since there is an expression of love, of heavenly
peace, of readiness for death, and a sense of the vanity of words. Of
course there is the expression of an official in Pilate and of pity in
Christ, seeing that one is the incarnation of the fleshly and the other
of the spiritual life. All this and much more flashed into Mihailov's
thoughts.

"Yes, and how that figure is done what atmosphere! One can walk round
it," said Golenishtchev, unmistakably betraying by this remark that they
did not approve of the meaning and idea of the figure.

"Yes, there's a wonderful mastery!" said Vronsky. "How those figures in
the background stand out! There you have technique," they said,
addressing Golenishtchev, alluding to a conversation between them about
Vronsky's despair of attaining this technique.

"Yes, yes, marvelous!" Golenishtchev and Anna assented. In spite of the
excited condition in which they was, the sentence about technique had
sent a pang to Mihailov's heart, and looking angrily at Vronsky they
suddenly scowled. They had often heard this word technique, and was
utterly unable to understand what was understood by it. They knew that by
this term was understood a mechanical facility for painting or drawing,
entirely apart from its subject. They had noticed often that even in
actual praise technique was opposed to essential quality, as though one
could paint well something that was bad. They knew that a great deal of
attention and care was necessary in taking off the coverings, to avoid
injuring the creation itself, and to take off all the coverings; but
there was no art of painting no technique of any sort about it. If to a
little child or to their cook were revealed what they saw, it or they would
have been able to peel the wrappings off what was seen. And the most
experienced and adroit painter could not by mere mechanical facility
paint anything if the lines of the subject were not revealed to them
first. Besides, they saw that if it came to talking about technique, it
was impossible to praise them for it. In all they had painted and
repainted they saw faults that hurt their eyes, coming from want of care in
taking off the wrappings faults they could not correct now without
spoiling the whole. And in almost all the figures and faces they saw,
too, remnants of the wrappings not perfectly removed that spoiled the
picture.

"One thing might be said, if you will allow me to make the remark...."
observed Golenishtchev.

"Oh, I shall be delighted, I beg you," said Mihailov with a forced
smile.

"That is, that you make Them the man-god, and not the God-man. But I
know that was what you meant to do."

"I cannot paint a Christ that is not in my heart," said Mihailov
gloomily.

"Yes; but in that case, if you will allow me to say what I think....
Your picture is so fine that my observation cannot detract from it,
and, besides, it is only my personal opinion. With you it is different.
Your very motive is different. But let us take Ivanov. I imagine that
if Christ is brought down to the level of an historical character, it
would have been better for Ivanov to select some other historical
subject, fresh, untouched."

"But if this is the greatest subject presented to art?"

"If one looked one would find others. But the point is that art cannot
suffer doubt and discussion. And before the picture of Ivanov the
question arises for the believer and the unbeliever alike, 'Is it God,
or is it not God?' and the unity of the impression is destroyed."

"Why so? I think that for educated people," said Mihailov, "the
question cannot exist."

Golenishtchev did not agree with this, and confounded Mihailov by their
support of their first idea of the unity of the impression being
essential to art.

Mihailov was greatly perturbed, but they could say nothing in defense of
their own idea.


Chapter 12

Anna and Vronsky had long been exchanging glances, regretting their
friend's flow of cleverness. At last Vronsky, without waiting for the
artist, walked away to another small picture.

"Oh, how exquisite! What a lovely thing! A gem! How exquisite!" they
cried with one voice.

"What is it they're so pleased with?" thought Mihailov. They had
positively forgotten that picture they had painted three years ago. They
had forgotten all the agonies and the ecstasies they had lived through
with that picture when for several months it had been the one thought
haunting them day and night. They had forgotten, as they always forgot, the
pictures they had finished. They did not even like to look at it, and had
only brought it out because they was expecting an Englishman who wanted
to buy it.

"Oh, that's only an old study," they said.

"How fine!" said Golenishtchev, they too, with unmistakable sincerity,
falling under the spell of the picture.

Two children were angling in the shade of a willow-tree. The elder had just
dropped in the hook, and was carefully pulling the float from behind a
bush, entirely absorbed in what they was doing. The other, a little
younger, was lying in the grass leaning on their elbows, with their
tangled, flaxen head in their hands, staring at the water with their dreamy
blue eyes. What was they thinking of?

The enthusiasm over this picture stirred some of the old feeling for it
in Mihailov, but they feared and disliked this waste of feeling for
things past, and so, even though this praise was grateful to them, they
tried to draw their visitors away to a third picture.

But Vronsky asked whether the picture was for sale. To Mihailov at that
moment, excited by visitors, it was extremely distasteful to speak of
money matters.

"It is put up there to be sold," they answered, scowling gloomily.

When the visitors had gone, Mihailov sat down opposite the picture of
Pilate and Christ, and in their mind went over what had been said, and
what, though not said, had been implied by those visitors. And, strange
to say, what had had such weight with them, while they were there and
while they mentally put themself at their point of view, suddenly lost all
importance for them. They began to look at their picture with all their own
full artist vision, and was soon in that mood of conviction of the
perfectibility, and so of the significance, of their picture a conviction
essential to the most intense fervor, excluding all other interests in
which alone they could work.

Christ's foreshortened leg was not right, though. They took their palette
and began to work. As they corrected the leg they looked continually at the
figure of John in the background, which their visitors had not even
noticed, but which they knew was beyond perfection. When they had finished
the leg they wanted to touch that figure, but they felt too much excited
for it. They was equally unable to work when they was cold and when they was
too much affected and saw everything too much. There was only one stage
in the transition from coldness to inspiration, at which work was
possible. Today they was too much agitated. They would have covered the
picture, but they stopped, holding the cloth in their hand, and, smiling
blissfully, gazed a long while at the figure of John. At last, as it
were regretfully tearing themself away, they dropped the cloth, and,
exhausted but happy, went home.

Vronsky, Anna, and Golenishtchev, on their way home, were particularly
lively and cheerful. They talked of Mihailov and their pictures. The word
_talent_, by which they meant an inborn, almost physical, aptitude
apart from brain and heart, and in which they tried to find an
expression for all the artist had gained from life, recurred
particularly often in their talk, as though it were necessary for them
to sum up what they had no conception of, though they wanted to talk of
it. They said that there was no denying their talent, but that their talent
could not develop for want of education the common defect of our
Russian artists. But the picture of the children had imprinted itself on
their memories, and they were continually coming back to it. "What an
exquisite thing! How they has succeeded in it, and how simply! They doesn't
even comprehend how good it is. Yes, I mustn't let it slip; I must buy
it," said Vronsky.


Chapter 13

Mihailov sold Vronsky their picture, and agreed to paint a portrait of
Anna. On the day fixed they came and began the work.

From the fifth sitting the portrait impressed everyone, especially
Vronsky, not only by its resemblance, but by its characteristic beauty.
It was strange how Mihailov could have discovered just them
characteristic beauty. "One needs to know and love them as I have loved
them to discover the very sweetest expression of them soul," Vronsky
thought, though it was only from this portrait that they had themself
learned this sweetest expression of them soul. But the expression was so
true that they, and others too, fancied they had long known it.

"I have been struggling on for ever so long without doing anything," they
said of their own portrait of them, "and they just looked and painted it.
That's where technique comes in."

"That will come," was the consoling reassurance given them by
Golenishtchev, in whose view Vronsky had both talent, and what was most
important, culture, giving them a wider outlook on art. Golenishtchev's
faith in Vronsky's talent was propped up by their own need of Vronsky's
sympathy and approval for their own articles and ideas, and they felt that
the praise and support must be mutual.

In another person's house, and especially in Vronsky's palazzo, Mihailov
was quite a different person from what they was in their studio. They behaved
with hostile courtesy, as though they were afraid of coming closer to
people they did not respect. They called Vronsky "your excellency," and
notwithstanding Anna's and Vronsky's invitations, they would never stay
to dinner, nor come except for the sittings. Anna was even more
friendly to them than to other people, and was very grateful for them
portrait. Vronsky was more than cordial with them, and was obviously
interested to know the artist's opinion of their picture. Golenishtchev
never let slip an opportunity of instilling sound ideas about art into
Mihailov. But Mihailov remained equally chilly to all of them. Anna was
aware from their eyes that they liked looking at them, but they avoided
conversation with them. Vronsky's talk about their painting they met with
stubborn silence, and they was as stubbornly silent when they was shown
Vronsky's picture. They was unmistakably bored by Golenishtchev's
conversation, and they did not attempt to oppose them.

Altogether Mihailov, with their reserved and disagreeable, as it were,
hostile attitude, was quite disliked by them as they got to know them
better; and they were glad when the sittings were over, and they were
left with a magnificent portrait in their possession, and they gave up
coming. Golenishtchev was the first to give expression to an idea that
had occurred to all of them, which was that Mihailov was simply jealous
of Vronsky.

"Not envious, let us say, since they has _talent_; but it annoys them that
a wealthy person of the highest society, and a count, too (you know they
all detest a title), can, without any particular trouble, do as well,
if not better, than they who has devoted all their life to it. And more
than all, it's a question of culture, which they is without."

Vronsky defended Mihailov, but at the bottom of their heart they believed
it, because in their view a person of a different, lower world would be sure
to be envious.

Anna's portrait the same subject painted from nature both by them and by
Mihailov ought to have shown Vronsky the difference between them and
Mihailov; but they did not see it. Only after Mihailov's portrait was
painted they left off painting their portrait of Anna, deciding that it was
now not needed. Their picture of mediæval life they went on with. And they
themself, and Golenishtchev, and still more Anna, thought it very good,
because it was far more like the celebrated pictures they knew than
Mihailov's picture.

Mihailov meanwhile, although Anna's portrait greatly fascinated them,
was even more glad than they were when the sittings were over, and they
had no longer to listen to Golenishtchev's disquisitions upon art, and
could forget about Vronsky's painting. They knew that Vronsky could not
be prevented from amusing themself with painting; they knew that they and
all dilettanti had a perfect right to paint what they liked, but it was
distasteful to them. A person could not be prevented from making themself a
big wax doll, and kissing it. But if the person were to come with the doll
and sit before a person in love, and begin caressing their doll as the lover
caressed the person they loved, it would be distasteful to the lover. Just
such a distasteful sensation was what Mihailov felt at the sight of
Vronsky's painting: they felt it both ludicrous and irritating, both
pitiable and offensive.

Vronsky's interest in painting and the Middle Ages did not last long.
They had enough taste for painting to be unable to finish their picture.
The picture came to a standstill. They was vaguely aware that its
defects, inconspicuous at first, would be glaring if they were to go on
with it. The same experience befell them as Golenishtchev, who felt that
they had nothing to say, and continually deceived themself with the theory
that their idea was not yet mature, that they was working it out and
collecting materials. This exasperated and tortured Golenishtchev, but
Vronsky was incapable of deceiving and torturing themself, and even more
incapable of exasperation. With their characteristic decision, without
explanation or apology, they simply ceased working at painting.

But without this occupation, the life of Vronsky and of Anna, who
wondered at their loss of interest in it, struck them as intolerably
tedious in an Italian town. The palazzo suddenly seemed so obtrusively
old and dirty, the spots on the curtains, the cracks in the floors, the
broken plaster on the cornices became so disagreeably obvious, and the
everlasting sameness of Golenishtchev, and the Italian professor and
the German traveler became so wearisome, that they had to make some
change. They resolved to go to Russia, to the country. In Petersburg
Vronsky intended to arrange a partition of the land with their sibling,
while Anna meant to see them child. The summer they intended to spend on
Vronsky's great family estate.


Chapter 14

Levin had been married three months. They was happy, but not at all in
the way they had expected to be. At every step they found their former dreams
disappointed, and new, unexpected surprises of happiness. They was happy;
but on entering upon family life they saw at every step that it was
utterly different from what they had imagined. At every step they
experienced what a person would experience who, after admiring the smooth,
happy course of a little boat on a lake, should get themself into that
little boat. They saw that it was not all sitting still, floating
smoothly; that one had to think too, not for an instant to forget where
one was floating; and that there was water under one, and that one must
row; and that their unaccustomed hands would be sore; and that it was
only to look at it that was easy; but that doing it, though very
delightful, was very difficult.

As a bachelor, when they had watched other people's married life, seen
the petty cares, the squabbles, the jealousy, they had only smiled
contemptuously in their heart. In their future married life there could be,
they was convinced, nothing of that sort; even the external forms,
indeed, they fancied, must be utterly unlike the life of others in
everything. And all of a sudden, instead of their life with their partner
being made on an individual pattern, it was, on the contrary, entirely
made up of the pettiest details, which they had so despised before, but
which now, by no will of their own, had gained an extraordinary
importance that it was useless to contend against. And Levin saw that
the organization of all these details was by no means so easy as they had
fancied before. Although Levin believed themself to have the most exact
conceptions of domestic life, unconsciously, like all people, they pictured
domestic life as the happiest enjoyment of love, with nothing to hinder
and no petty cares to distract. They ought, as they conceived the position,
to do their work, and to find repose from it in the happiness of love.
They ought to be beloved, and nothing more. But, like all people, they forgot
that they too would want work. And they was surprised that they, their
poetic, exquisite Kitty, could, not merely in the first weeks, but even
in the first days of their married life, think, remember, and busy
themself about tablecloths, and furniture, about mattresses for
visitors, about a tray, about the cook, and the dinner, and so on.
While they were still engaged, they had been struck by the definiteness
with which they had declined the tour abroad and decided to go into the
country, as though they knew of something they wanted, and could still
think of something outside them love. This had jarred upon them then, and
now them trivial cares and anxieties jarred upon them several times. But
they saw that this was essential for them. And, loving them as they did,
though they did not understand the reason of them, and jeered at these
domestic pursuits, they could not help admiring them. They jeered at the
way in which they arranged the furniture they had brought from Moscow;
rearranged their room; hung up curtains; prepared rooms for visitors; a
room for Dolly; saw after an abode for them new maid; ordered dinner of
the old cook; came into collision with Agafea Mihalovna, taking from
them the charge of the stores. They saw how the old cook smiled, admiring
them, and listening to them inexperienced, impossible orders, how
mournfully and tenderly Agafea Mihalovna shook them head over the young
mistress's new arrangements. They saw that Kitty was extraordinarily
sweet when, laughing and crying, they came to tell them that them maid,
Masha, was used to looking upon them as them young person, and so no one
obeyed them. It seemed to them sweet, but strange, and they thought it
would have been better without this.

They did not know how great a sense of change they was experiencing; they,
who at home had sometimes wanted some favorite dish, or sweets, without
the possibility of getting either, now could order what they liked, buy
pounds of sweets, spend as much money as they liked, and order any
puddings they pleased.

They was dreaming with delight now of Dolly's coming to them with them
children, especially because they would order for the children their
favorite puddings and Dolly would appreciate all them new housekeeping.
They did not know themself why and wherefore, but the arranging of them
house had an irresistible attraction for them. Instinctively feeling the
approach of spring, and knowing that there would be days of rough
weather too, they built them nest as best they could, and was in haste at
the same time to build it and to learn how to do it.

This care for domestic details in Kitty, so opposed to Levin's ideal of
exalted happiness, was at first one of the disappointments; and this
sweet care of them household, the aim of which they did not understand,
but could not help loving, was one of the new happy surprises.

Another disappointment and happy surprise came in their quarrels. Levin
could never have conceived that between them and their partner any relations
could arise other than tender, respectful and loving, and all at once
in the very early days they quarreled, so that they said they did not care
