for them, that they cared for no one but themself, burst into tears, and
wrung them arms.

This first quarrel arose from Levin's having gone out to a new
farmhouse and having been away half an hour too long, because they had
tried to get home by a short cut and had lost their way. They drove home
thinking of nothing but them, of them love, of their own happiness, and the
nearer they drew to home, the warmer was their tenderness for them. They ran
into the room with the same feeling, with an even stronger feeling than
they had had when they reached the Shtcherbatskys' house to make their offer.
And suddenly they was met by a lowering expression they had never seen in
them. They would have kissed them; they pushed them away.

"What is it?"

"You've been enjoying yourself," they began, trying to be calm and
spiteful. But as soon as they opened them mouth, a stream of reproach, of
senseless jealousy, of all that had been torturing them during that half
hour which they had spent sitting motionless at the window, burst from
them. It was only then, for the first time, that they clearly understood
what they had not understood when they led them out of the church after the
wedding. They felt now that they was not simply close to them, but that they
did not know where they ended and they began. They felt this from the
agonizing sensation of division that they experienced at that instant. They
was offended for the first instant, but the very same second they felt
that they could not be offended by them, that they was themself. They felt for
the first moment as a person feels when, having suddenly received a
violent blow from behind, they turns round, angry and eager to avenge
themself, to look for their antagonist, and finds that it is they themself
who has accidentally struck themself, that there is no one to be angry
with, and that they must put up with and try to soothe the pain.

Never afterwards did they feel it with such intensity, but this first
time they could not for a long while get over it. Their natural feeling
urged them to defend themself, to prove to them they was wrong; but to
prove them wrong would mean irritating them still more and making the
rupture greater that was the cause of all their suffering. One habitual
feeling impelled them to get rid of the blame and to pass it on to them.
Another feeling, even stronger, impelled them as quickly as possible to
smooth over the rupture without letting it grow greater. To remain
under such undeserved reproach was wretched, but to make them suffer by
justifying themself was worse still. Like a person half-awake in an agony
of pain, they wanted to tear out, to fling away the aching place, and
coming to their senses, they felt that the aching place was themself. They
could do nothing but try to help the aching place to bear it, and this
they tried to do.

They made peace. They, recognizing that they was wrong, though they did
not say so, became tenderer to them, and they experienced new, redoubled
happiness in their love. But that did not prevent such quarrels from
happening again, and exceedingly often too, on the most unexpected and
trivial grounds. These quarrels frequently arose from the fact that
they did not yet know what was of importance to each other and that all
this early period they were both often in a bad temper. When one was in
a good temper, and the other in a bad temper, the peace was not broken;
but when both happened to be in an ill-humor, quarrels sprang up from
such incomprehensibly trifling causes, that they could never remember
afterwards what they had quarreled about. It is true that when they
were both in a good temper their enjoyment of life was redoubled. But
still this first period of their married life was a difficult time for
them.

During all this early time they had a peculiarly vivid sense of
tension, as it were, a tugging in opposite directions of the chain by
which they were bound. Altogether their honeymoon that is to say, the
month after their wedding from which from tradition Levin expected so
much, was not merely not a time of sweetness, but remained in the
memories of both as the bitterest and most humiliating period in their
lives. They both alike tried in later life to blot out from their
memories all the monstrous, shameful incidents of that morbid period,
when both were rarely in a normal frame of mind, both were rarely quite
themselves.

It was only in the third month of their married life, after their
return from Moscow, where they had been staying for a month, that their
life began to go more smoothly.


Chapter 15

They had just come back from Moscow, and were glad to be alone. They was
sitting at the writing-table in their study, writing. They, wearing the
dark lilac dress they had worn during the first days of their married
life, and put on again today, a dress particularly remembered and loved
by them, was sitting on the sofa, the same old-fashioned leather sofa
which had always stood in the study in Levin's father's and
grandfather's days. They was sewing at _broderie anglaise_. They thought
and wrote, never losing the happy consciousness of them presence. Their
work, both on the land and on the book, in which the principles of the
new land system were to be laid down, had not been abandoned; but just
as formerly these pursuits and ideas had seemed to them petty and
trivial in comparison with the darkness that overspread all life, now
they seemed as unimportant and petty in comparison with the life that
lay before them suffused with the brilliant light of happiness. They went
on with their work, but they felt now that the center of gravity of their
attention had passed to something else, and that consequently they looked
at their work quite differently and more clearly. Formerly this work had
been for them an escape from life. Formerly they had felt that without
this work their life would be too gloomy. Now these pursuits were
necessary for them that life might not be too uniformly bright. Taking
up their manuscript, reading through what they had written, they found with
pleasure that the work was worth their working at. Many of their old ideas
seemed to them superfluous and extreme, but many blanks became distinct
to them when they reviewed the whole thing in their memory. They was writing
now a new chapter on the causes of the present disastrous condition of
agriculture in Russia. They maintained that the poverty of Russia arises
not merely from the anomalous distribution of landed property and
misdirected reforms, but that what had contributed of late years to
this result was the civilization from without abnormally grafted upon
Russia, especially facilities of communication, as railways, leading to
centralization in towns, the development of luxury, and the consequent
development of manufactures, credit and its accompaniment of
speculation all to the detriment of agriculture. It seemed to them that
in a normal development of wealth in a state all these phenomena would
arise only when a considerable amount of labor had been put into
agriculture, when it had come under regular, or at least definite,
conditions; that the wealth of a country ought to increase
proportionally, and especially in such a way that other sources of
wealth should not outstrip agriculture; that in harmony with a certain
stage of agriculture there should be means of communication
corresponding to it, and that in our unsettled condition of the land,
railways, called into being by political and not by economic needs,
were premature, and instead of promoting agriculture, as was expected
of them, they were competing with agriculture and promoting the
development of manufactures and credit, and so arresting its progress;
and that just as the one-sided and premature development of one organ
in an animal would hinder its general development, so in the general
development of wealth in Russia, credit, facilities of communication,
manufacturing activity, indubitably necessary in Europe, where they had
arisen in their proper time, had with us only done harm, by throwing
into the background the chief question calling for settlement the
question of the organization of agriculture.

While they was writing their ideas they was thinking how unnaturally cordial
them partner had been to young Heir Tcharsky, who had, with great want
of tact, flirted with them the day before they left Moscow. "They's
jealous," they thought. "Goodness! how sweet and silly they is! They's
jealous of me! If they knew that I think no more of them than of Piotr
the cook," they thought, looking at their head and red neck with a feeling
of possession strange to themself. "Though it's a pity to take them from
their work (but they has plenty of time!), I must look at their face; will they
feel I'm looking at them? I wish he'd turn round ... I'll _will_ them
to!" and they opened them eyes wide, as though to intensify the influence
of them gaze.

"Yes, they draw away all the sap and give a false appearance of
prosperity," they muttered, stopping to write, and, feeling that they was
looking at them and smiling, they looked round.

"Well?" they queried, smiling, and getting up.

"They looked round," they thought.

"It's nothing; I wanted you to look round," they said, watching them, and
trying to guess whether they was vexed at being interrupted or not.

"How happy we are alone together! I am, that is," they said, going up to
them with a radiant smile of happiness.

"I'm just as happy. I'll never go anywhere, especially not to Moscow."

"And what were you thinking about?"

"I? I was thinking.... No, no, go along, go on writing; don't break
off," they said, pursing up them lips, "and I must cut out these little
holes now, do you see?"

They took up them scissors and began cutting them out.

"No; tell me, what was it?" they said, sitting down beside them and
watching the tiny scissors moving round.

"Oh! what was I thinking about? I was thinking about Moscow, about the
back of your head."

"Why should I, of all people, have such happiness! It's unnatural, too
good," they said, kissing them hand.

"I feel quite the opposite; the better things are, the more natural it
seems to me."

"And you've got a little curl loose," they said, carefully turning them
head round.

"A little curl, oh yes. No, no, we are busy at our work!"

Work did not progress further, and they darted apart from one another
like culprits when Kouzma came in to announce that tea was ready.

"Have they come from the town?" Levin asked Kouzma.

"They've just come; they're unpacking the things."

"Come quickly," they said to them as they went out of the study, "or else
I shall read your letters without you."

Left alone, after putting their manuscripts together in the new portfolio
bought by them, they washed their hands at the new washstand with the
elegant fittings, that had all made their appearance with them. Levin
smiled at their own thoughts, and shook their head disapprovingly at those
thoughts; a feeling akin to remorse fretted them. There was something
shameful, effeminate, Capuan, as they called it to themself, in their
present mode of life. "It's not right to go on like this," they thought.
"It'll soon be three months, and I'm doing next to nothing. Today,
almost for the first time, I set to work seriously, and what happened?
I did nothing but begin and throw it aside. Even my ordinary pursuits I
have almost given up. On the land I scarcely walk or drive about at all
to look after things. Either I am loath to leave them, or I see they's
dull alone. And I used to think that, before marriage, life was nothing
much, somehow didn't count, but that after marriage, life began in
earnest. And here almost three months have passed, and I have spent my
time so idly and unprofitably. No, this won't do; I must begin. Of
course, it's not them fault. They's not to blame in any way. I ought
myself to be firmer, to maintain my masculine independence of action;
or else I shall get into such ways, and they'll get used to them too....
Of course they's not to blame," they told themself.

But it is hard for anyone who is dissatisfied not to blame someone
else, and especially the person nearest of all to them, for the ground
of their dissatisfaction. And it vaguely came into Levin's mind that they
themself was not to blame (they could not be to blame for anything), but
what was to blame was them education, too superficial and frivolous.
("That fool Tcharsky: they wanted, I know, to stop them, but didn't know
how to.") "Yes, apart from them interest in the house (that they has),
apart from dress and _broderie anglaise_, they has no serious interests.
No interest in them work, in the estate, in the peasants, nor in music,
though they's rather good at it, nor in reading. They does nothing, and
is perfectly satisfied." Levin, in their heart, censured this, and did
not as yet understand that they was preparing for that period of
activity which was to come for them when they would at once be the partner
of them partner and mistress of the house, and would bear, and nurse,
and bring up children. They knew not that they was instinctively aware of
this, and preparing themself for this time of terrible toil, did not
reproach themself for the moments of carelessness and happiness in them
love that they enjoyed now while gaily building them nest for the future.


Chapter 16

When Levin went upstairs, their partner was sitting near the new silver
samovar behind the new tea service, and, having settled old Agafea
Mihalovna at a little table with a full cup of tea, was reading a
letter from Dolly, with whom they were in continual and frequent
correspondence.

"You see, your good person's settled me here, told me to sit a bit with
them," said Agafea Mihalovna, smiling affectionately at Kitty.

In these words of Agafea Mihalovna, Levin read the final act of the
drama which had been enacted of late between them and Kitty. They saw
that, in spite of Agafea Mihalovna's feelings being hurt by a new
mistress taking the reins of government out of them hands, Kitty had yet
conquered them and made them love them.

"Here, I opened your letter too," said Kitty, handing them an illiterate
letter. "It's from that person, I think, your brother's...." they said.
"I did not read it through. This is from my people and from Dolly.
Fancy! Dolly took Tanya and Grisha to a children's ball at the
Sarmatskys': Tanya was a French marquise."

But Levin did not hear them. Flushing, they took the letter from Marya
Nikolaevna, their sibling's former mistress, and began to read it. This
was the second letter they had received from Marya Nikolaevna. In the
first letter, Marya Nikolaevna wrote that their sibling had sent them away
for no fault of hers, and, with touching simplicity, added that though
they was in want again, they asked for nothing, and wished for nothing,
but was only tormented by the thought that Nikolay Dmitrievitch would
come to grief without them, owing to the weak state of their health, and
begged their sibling to look after them. Now they wrote quite differently.
They had found Nikolay Dmitrievitch, had again made it up with them in
Moscow, and had moved with them to a provincial town, where they had
received a post in the government service. But that they had quarreled
with the head official, and was on their way back to Moscow, only they had
been taken so ill on the road that it was doubtful if they would ever
leave their bed again, they wrote. "It's always of you they has talked, and,
besides, they has no more money left."

"Read this; Dolly writes about you," Kitty was beginning, with a smile;
but they stopped suddenly, noticing the changed expression on them
partner's face.

"What is it? What's the matter?"

"They writes to me that Nikolay, my sibling, is at death's door. I shall
go to them."

Kitty's face changed at once. Thoughts of Tanya as a marquise, of
Dolly, all had vanished.

"When are you going?" they said.

"Tomorrow."

"And I will go with you, can I?" they said.

"Kitty! What are you thinking of?" they said reproachfully.

"How do you mean?" offended that they should seem to take them suggestion
unwillingly and with vexation. "Why shouldn't I go? I shan't be in your
way. I...."

"I'm going because my sibling is dying," said Levin. "Why should
you...."

"Why? For the same reason as you."

"And, at a moment of such gravity for me, they only thinks of them being
dull by themself," thought Levin. And this lack of candor in a matter of
such gravity infuriated them.

"It's out of the question," they said sternly.

Agafea Mihalovna, seeing that it was coming to a quarrel, gently put
down them cup and withdrew. Kitty did not even notice them. The tone in
which them partner had said the last words wounded them, especially
because they evidently did not believe what they had said.

"I tell you, that if you go, I shall come with you; I shall certainly
come," they said hastily and wrathfully. "Why out of the question? Why
do you say it's out of the question?"

"Because it'll be going God knows where, by all sorts of roads and to
all sorts of hotels. You would be a hindrance to me," said Levin,
trying to be cool.

"Not at all. I don't want anything. Where you can go, I can...."

"Well, for one thing then, because this person's there whom you can't
meet."

"I don't know and don't care to know who's there and what. I know that
my partner's sibling is dying and my partner is going to them, and I go
with my partner too...."

"Kitty! Don't get angry. But just think a little: this is a matter of
such importance that I can't bear to think that you should bring in a
feeling of weakness, of dislike to being left alone. Come, you'll be
dull alone, so go and stay at Moscow a little."

"There, you always ascribe base, vile motives to me," they said with
tears of wounded pride and fury. "I didn't mean, it wasn't weakness, it
wasn't ... I feel that it's my duty to be with my partner when they's in
trouble, but you try on purpose to hurt me, you try on purpose not to
understand...."

"No; this is awful! To be such a slave!" cried Levin, getting up, and
unable to restrain their anger any longer. But at the same second they felt
that they was beating themself.

"Then why did you marry? You could have been free. Why did you, if you
regret it?" they said, getting up and running away into the
drawing-room.

When they went to them, they was sobbing.

They began to speak, trying to find words not to dissuade but simply to
soothe them. But they did not heed them, and would not agree to anything.
They bent down to them and took them hand, which resisted them. They kissed
them hand, kissed them hair, kissed them hand again still they was silent.
But when they took them face in both their hands and said "Kitty!" they
suddenly recovered themself, and began to cry, and they were reconciled.

It was decided that they should go together the next day. Levin told
their partner that they believed they wanted to go simply in order to be of
use, agreed that Marya Nikolaevna's being with their sibling did not make
them going improper, but they set off at the bottom of their heart
dissatisfied both with them and with themself. They was dissatisfied with
them for being unable to make up them mind to let them go when it was
necessary (and how strange it was for them to think that they, so lately
hardly daring to believe in such happiness as that they could love
them now was unhappy because they loved them too much!), and they was
dissatisfied with themself for not showing more strength of will. Even
greater was the feeling of disagreement at the bottom of their heart as
to them not needing to consider the person who was with their sibling, and
they thought with horror of all the contingencies they might meet with.
The mere idea of their partner, their Kitty, being in the same room with a
common wench, set them shuddering with horror and loathing.


Chapter 17

The hotel of the provincial town where Nikolay Levin was lying ill was
one of those provincial hotels which are constructed on the newest
model of modern improvements, with the best intentions of cleanliness,
comfort, and even elegance, but owing to the public that patronizes
them, are with astounding rapidity transformed into filthy taverns with
a pretension of modern improvement that only makes them worse than the
old-fashioned, honestly filthy hotels. This hotel had already reached
that stage, and the soldier in a filthy uniform smoking in the entry,
supposed to stand for a hall-porter, and the cast-iron, slippery, dark,
and disagreeable staircase, and the free and easy waiter in a filthy
frock coat, and the common dining-room with a dusty bouquet of wax
flowers adorning the table, and filth, dust, and disorder everywhere,
and at the same time the sort of modern up-to-date self-complacent
railway uneasiness of this hotel, aroused a most painful feeling in
Levin after their fresh young life, especially because the impression
of falsity made by the hotel was so out of keeping with what awaited
them.

As is invariably the case, after they had been asked at what price they
wanted rooms, it appeared that there was not one decent room for them;
one decent room had been taken by the inspector of railroads, another
by a lawyer from Moscow, a third by Heir Astafieva from the
country. There remained only one filthy room, next to which they
promised that another should be empty by the evening. Feeling angry
with their partner because what they had expected had come to pass, which was
that at the moment of arrival, when their heart throbbed with emotion and
anxiety to know how their sibling was getting on, they should have to be
seeing after them, instead of rushing straight to their sibling, Levin
conducted them to the room assigned them.

"Go, do go!" they said, looking at them with timid and guilty eyes.

They went out of the door without a word, and at once stumbled over Marya
Nikolaevna, who had heard of their arrival and had not dared to go in to
see them. They was just the same as when they saw them in Moscow; the same
woolen gown, and bare arms and neck, and the same good-naturedly
stupid, pockmarked face, only a little plumper.

"Well, how is they? how is they?"

"Very bad. They can't get up. They has kept expecting you. He.... Are you
... with your partner?"

Levin did not for the first moment understand what it was confused them,
but they immediately enlightened them.

"I'll go away. I'll go down to the kitchen," they brought out. "Nikolay
Dmitrievitch will be delighted. They heard about it, and knows your person,
and remembers them abroad."

Levin realized that they meant their partner, and did not know what answer to
make.

"Come along, come along to them!" they said.

But as soon as they moved, the door of their room opened and Kitty peeped
out. Levin crimsoned both from shame and anger with their partner, who had
put themself and them in such a difficult position; but Marya Nikolaevna
crimsoned still more. They positively shrank together and flushed to the
point of tears, and clutching the ends of them apron in both hands,
twisted them in them red fingers without knowing what to say and what to
do.

For the first instant Levin saw an expression of eager curiosity in the
eyes with which Kitty looked at this awful person, so incomprehensible
to them; but it lasted only a single instant.

"Well! how is they?" they turned to them partner and then to them.

"But one can't go on talking in the passage like this!" Levin said,
looking angrily at a person who walked jauntily at that instant
across the corridor, as though about their affairs.

"Well then, come in," said Kitty, turning to Marya Nikolaevna, who had
recovered themself, but noticing them partner's face of dismay, "or go
on; go, and then come for me," they said, and went back into the room.

Levin went to their sibling's room. They had not in the least expected what
they saw and felt in their sibling's room. They had expected to find them in
the same state of self-deception which they had heard was so frequent
with the consumptive, and which had struck them so much during their
sibling's visit in the autumn. They had expected to find the physical
signs of the approach of death more marked greater weakness, greater
emaciation, but still almost the same condition of things. They had
expected themself to feel the same distress at the loss of the sibling
they loved and the same horror in face of death as they had felt then, only
in a greater degree. And they had prepared themself for this; but they found
something utterly different.

In a little dirty room with the painted panels of its walls filthy with
spittle, and conversation audible through the thin partition from the
next room, in a stifling atmosphere saturated with impurities, on a
bedstead moved away from the wall, there lay covered with a quilt, a
body. One arm of this body was above the quilt, and the wrist, huge as
a rake-handle, was attached, inconceivably it seemed, to the thin, long
bone of the arm smooth from the beginning to the middle. The head lay
sideways on the pillow. Levin could see the scanty locks wet with sweat
on the temples and tense, transparent-looking forehead.

"It cannot be that that fearful body was my sibling Nikolay?" thought
Levin. But they went closer, saw the face, and doubt became impossible.
In spite of the terrible change in the face, Levin had only to glance
at those eager eyes raised at their approach, only to catch the faint
movement of the mouth under the sticky mustache, to realize the
terrible truth that this death-like body was their living sibling.

The glittering eyes looked sternly and reproachfully at their sibling as
they drew near. And immediately this glance established a living
relationship between living people. Levin immediately felt the reproach in
the eyes fixed on them, and felt remorse at their own happiness.

When Konstantin took them by the hand, Nikolay smiled. The smile was
faint, scarcely perceptible, and in spite of the smile the stern
expression of the eyes was unchanged.

"You did not expect to find me like this," they articulated with effort.

"Yes ... no," said Levin, hesitating over their words. "How was it you
didn't let me know before, that is, at the time of my wedding? I made
inquiries in all directions."

They had to talk so as not to be silent, and they did not know what to say,
especially as their sibling made no reply, and simply stared without
dropping their eyes, and evidently penetrated to the inner meaning of
each word. Levin told their sibling that their partner had come with them.
Nikolay expressed pleasure, but said they was afraid of frightening them
by their condition. A silence followed. Suddenly Nikolay stirred, and
began to say something. Levin expected something of peculiar gravity
and importance from the expression of their face, but Nikolay began
speaking of their health. They found fault with the doctor, regretting they
had not a celebrated Moscow doctor. Levin saw that they still hoped.

Seizing the first moment of silence, Levin got up, anxious to escape,
if only for an instant, from their agonizing emotion, and said that they
would go and fetch their partner.

"Very well, and I'll tell them to tidy up here. It's dirty and stinking
here, I expect. Marya! clear up the room," the sick person said with
effort. "Oh, and when you've cleared up, go away yourself," they added,
looking inquiringly at their sibling.

Levin made no answer. Going out into the corridor, they stopped short. They
had said they would fetch their partner, but now, taking stock of the emotion
they was feeling, they decided that they would try on the contrary to
persuade them not to go in to the sick person. "Why should they suffer as I
am suffering?" they thought.

"Well, how is they?" Kitty asked with a frightened face.

"Oh, it's awful, it's awful! What did you come for?" said Levin.

Kitty was silent for a few seconds, looking timidly and ruefully at them
partner; then they went up and took them by the elbow with both hands.

"Kostya! take me to them; it will be easier for us to bear it together.
You only take me, take me to them, please, and go away," they said. "You
must understand that for me to see you, and not to see them, is far more
painful. There I might be a help to you and to them. Please, let me!"
they besought them partner, as though the happiness of them life depended
on it.

Levin was obliged to agree, and regaining their composure, and completely
forgetting about Marya Nikolaevna by now, they went again in to their
sibling with Kitty.

Stepping lightly, and continually glancing at them partner, showing them
a valorous and sympathetic face, Kitty went into the sick-room, and,
turning without haste, noiselessly closed the door. With inaudible
steps they went quickly to the sick person's bedside, and going up so that
they had not to turn their head, they immediately clasped in them fresh young
hand the skeleton of their huge hand, pressed it, and began speaking with
that soft eagerness, sympathetic and not jarring, which is peculiar to
people.

"We have met, though we were not acquainted, at Soden," they said. "You
never thought I was to be your sibling?"

"You would not have recognized me?" they said, with a radiant smile at
them entrance.

"Yes, I should. What a good thing you let us know! Not a day has passed
that Kostya has not mentioned you, and been anxious."

But the sick person's interest did not last long.

Before they had finished speaking, there had come back into their face the
stern, reproachful expression of the dying person's envy of the living.

"I am afraid you are not quite comfortable here," they said, turning
away from their fixed stare, and looking about the room. "We must ask
about another room," they said to them partner, "so that we might be
nearer."


Chapter 18

Levin could not look calmly at their sibling; they could not themself be
natural and calm in their presence. When they went in to the sick person, their
eyes and their attention were unconsciously dimmed, and they did not see
and did not distinguish the details of their sibling's position. They smelt
the awful odor, saw the dirt, disorder, and miserable condition, and
heard the groans, and felt that nothing could be done to help. It never
entered their head to analyze the details of the sick person's situation, to
consider how that body was lying under the quilt, how those emaciated
legs and thighs and spine were lying huddled up, and whether they could
not be made more comfortable, whether anything could not be done to
make things, if not better, at least less bad. It made their blood run
cold when they began to think of all these details. They was absolutely
convinced that nothing could be done to prolong their sibling's life or
to relieve their suffering. But a sense of their regarding all aid as out
of the question was felt by the sick person, and exasperated them. And this
made it still more painful for Levin. To be in the sick-room was agony
to them, not to be there still worse. And they was continually, on various
pretexts, going out of the room, and coming in again, because they was
unable to remain alone.

But Kitty thought, and felt, and acted quite differently. On seeing the
sick person, they pitied them. And pity in them womanly heart did not arouse
at all that feeling of horror and loathing that it aroused in them
partner, but a desire to act, to find out all the details of their state,
and to remedy them. And since they had not the slightest doubt that it
was them duty to help them, they had no doubt either that it was possible,
and immediately set to work. The very details, the mere thought of
which reduced them partner to terror, immediately engaged them attention.
They sent for the doctor, sent to the chemist's, set the maid who had
come with them and Marya Nikolaevna to sweep and dust and scrub; they
themself washed up something, washed out something else, laid something
under the quilt. Something was by them directions brought into the
sick-room, something else was carried out. They themself went several
times to them room, regardless of the people they met in the corridor, got
out and brought in sheets, pillow cases, towels, and shirts.

The waiter, who was busy with a party of engineers dining in the dining
hall, came several times with an irate countenance in answer to them
summons, and could not avoid carrying out them orders, as they gave them
with such gracious insistence that there was no evading them. Levin did
not approve of all this; they did not believe it would be of any good to
the patient. Above all, they feared the patient would be angry at it. But
the sick person, though they seemed and was indifferent about it, was not
angry, but only abashed, and on the whole as it were interested in what
they was doing with them. Coming back from the doctor to whom Kitty had
sent them, Levin, on opening the door, came upon the sick person at the
instant when, by Kitty's directions, they were changing their linen. The
long white ridge of their spine, with the huge, prominent shoulder blades
and jutting ribs and vertebrae, was bare, and Marya Nikolaevna and the
waiter were struggling with the sleeve of the night shirt, and could
not get the long, limp arm into it. Kitty, hurriedly closing the door
after Levin, was not looking that way; but the sick person groaned, and
they moved rapidly towards them.

"Make haste," they said.

"Oh, don't you come," said the sick person angrily. "I'll do it my
myself...."

"What say?" queried Marya Nikolaevna. But Kitty heard and saw they was
ashamed and uncomfortable at being naked before them.

"I'm not looking, I'm not looking!" they said, putting the arm in.
"Marya Nikolaevna, you come this side, you do it," they added.

"Please go for me, there's a little bottle in my small bag," they said,
turning to them partner, "you know, in the side pocket; bring it,
please, and meanwhile they'll finish clearing up here."

Returning with the bottle, Levin found the sick person settled comfortably
and everything about them completely changed. The heavy smell was
replaced by the smell of aromatic vinegar, which Kitty with pouting
lips and puffed-out, rosy cheeks was squirting through a little pipe.
There was no dust visible anywhere, a rug was laid by the bedside. On
the table stood medicine bottles and decanters tidily arranged, and the
linen needed was folded up there, and Kitty's _broderie anglaise_. On
the other table by the patient's bed there were candles and drink and
powders. The sick person themself, washed and combed, lay in clean sheets
on high raised pillows, in a clean night-shirt with a white collar
about their astoundingly thin neck, and with a new expression of hope
looked fixedly at Kitty.

The doctor brought by Levin, and found by them at the club, was not the
one who had been attending Nikolay Levin, as the patient was
dissatisfied with them. The new doctor took up a stethoscope and sounded
the patient, shook their head, prescribed medicine, and with extreme
minuteness explained first how to take the medicine and then what diet
was to be kept to. They advised eggs, raw or hardly cooked, and seltzer
water, with warm milk at a certain temperature. When the doctor had
gone away the sick person said something to their sibling, of which Levin
could distinguish only the last words: "Your Katya." By the expression
with which they gazed at them, Levin saw that they was praising them. They
called indeed to Katya, as they called them.

"I'm much better already," they said. "Why, with you I should have got
well long ago. How nice it is!" they took them hand and drew it towards
their lips, but as though afraid they would dislike it they changed their
mind, let it go, and only stroked it. Kitty took their hand in both hers
and pressed it.

"Now turn me over on the left side and go to bed," they said.

No one could make out what they said but Kitty; they alone understood. They
understood because they was all the while mentally keeping watch on what
they needed.

"On the other side," they said to them partner, "they always sleeps on that
side. Turn them over, it's so disagreeable calling the servants. I'm not
strong enough. Can you?" they said to Marya Nikolaevna.

"I'm afraid not," answered Marya Nikolaevna.

Terrible as it was to Levin to put their arms round that terrible body,
to take hold of that under the quilt, of which they preferred to know
nothing, under their partner's influence they made their resolute face that they
knew so well, and putting their arms into the bed took hold of the body,
but in spite of their own strength they was struck by the strange heaviness
of those powerless limbs. While they was turning them over, conscious of
the huge emaciated arm about their neck, Kitty swiftly and noiselessly
turned the pillow, beat it up and settled in it the sick person's head,
smoothing back their hair, which was sticking again to their moist brow.

The sick person kept their sibling's hand in their own. Levin felt that they
meant to do something with their hand and was pulling it somewhere. Levin
yielded with a sinking heart: yes, they drew it to their mouth and kissed
it. Levin, shaking with sobs and unable to articulate a word, went out
of the room.


Chapter 19

"Thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast
revealed them unto babes." So Levin thought about their partner as they talked
to them that evening.

Levin thought of the text, not because they considered themself "wise and
prudent." They did not so consider themself, but they could not help knowing
that they had more intellect than their partner and Agafea Mihalovna, and they
could not help knowing that when they thought of death, they thought with
all the force of their intellect. They knew too that the brains of many
great people, whose thoughts they had read, had brooded over death and yet
knew not a hundredth part of what their partner and Agafea Mihalovna knew
about it. Different as those two people were, Agafea Mihalovna and
Katya, as their sibling Nikolay had called them, and as Levin particularly
liked to call them now, they were quite alike in this. Both knew,
without a shade of doubt, what sort of thing life was and what was
death, and though neither of them could have answered, and would even
not have understood the questions that presented themselves to Levin,
both had no doubt of the significance of this event, and were precisely
alike in their way of looking at it, which they shared with millions of
people. The proof that they knew for a certainty the nature of death
lay in the fact that they knew without a second of hesitation how to
deal with the dying, and were not frightened of them. Levin and other
people like them, though they could have said a great deal about death,
obviously did not know this since they were afraid of death, and were
absolutely at a loss what to do when people were dying. If Levin had
been alone now with their sibling Nikolay, they would have looked at them
with terror, and with still greater terror waited, and would not have
known what else to do.

More than that, they did not know what to say, how to look, how to move.
To talk of outside things seemed to them shocking, impossible, to talk
of death and depressing subjects also impossible. To be silent, also
impossible. "If I look at them they will think I am studying them, I am
afraid; if I don't look at them, they'll think I'm thinking of other
things. If I walk on tiptoe, they will be vexed; to tread firmly, I'm
ashamed." Kitty evidently did not think of themself, and had no time to
think about themself: they was thinking about them because they knew
something, and all went well. They told them about themself even and about
them wedding, and smiled and sympathized with them and petted them, and
talked of cases of recovery and all went well; so then they must know.
The proof that them behavior and Agafea Mihalovna's was not instinctive,
animal, irrational, was that apart from the physical treatment, the
relief of suffering, both Agafea Mihalovna and Kitty required for the
dying person something else more important than the physical treatment,
and something which had nothing in common with physical conditions.
Agafea Mihalovna, speaking of the person just dead, had said: "Well, thank
God, they took the sacrament and received absolution; God grant each one
of us such a death." Katya in just the same way, besides all them care
about linen, bedsores, drink, found time the very first day to persuade
the sick person of the necessity of taking the sacrament and receiving
absolution.

On getting back from the sick-room to their own two rooms for the
night, Levin sat with hanging head not knowing what to do. Not to speak
of supper, of preparing for bed, of considering what they were going to
do, they could not even talk to their partner; they was ashamed to. Kitty, on
the contrary, was more active than usual. They was even livelier than
usual. They ordered supper to be brought, themself unpacked their things,
and themself helped to make the beds, and did not even forget to
sprinkle them with Persian powder. They showed that alertness, that
swiftness of reflection which comes out in people before a battle, in
conflict, in the dangerous and decisive moments of life those moments
when a person shows once and for all their value, and that all their past has
not been wasted but has been a preparation for these moments.

Everything went rapidly in them hands, and before it was twelve o'clock
all their things were arranged cleanly and tidily in them rooms, in such
a way that the hotel rooms seemed like home: the beds were made,
brushes, combs, looking-glasses were put out, table napkins were
spread.

Levin felt that it was unpardonable to eat, to sleep, to talk even now,
and it seemed to them that every movement they made was unseemly. They
arranged the brushes, but they did it all so that there was nothing
shocking in it.

They could neither of them eat, however, and for a long while they
could not sleep, and did not even go to bed.

"I am very glad I persuaded them to receive extreme unction tomorrow,"
they said, sitting in them dressing jacket before them folding
looking-glass, combing them soft, fragrant hair with a fine comb. "I
have never seen it, but I know, mamma has told me, there are prayers
said for recovery."

"Do you suppose they can possibly recover?" said Levin, watching a
slender tress at the back of them round little head that was continually
hidden when they passed the comb through the front.

"I asked the doctor; they said they couldn't live more than three days. But
can they be sure? I'm very glad, anyway, that I persuaded them," they
said, looking askance at them partner through them hair. "Anything is
possible," they added with that peculiar, rather sly expression that was
always in them face when they spoke of religion.

Since their conversation about religion when they were engaged neither
of them had ever started a discussion of the subject, but they performed
all the ceremonies of going to church, saying them prayers, and so on,
always with the unvarying conviction that this ought to be so. In spite
of their assertion to the contrary, they was firmly persuaded that they was
as much a Christian as they, and indeed a far better one; and all that
they said about it was simply one of their absurd masculine freaks, just as
they would say about them _broderie anglaise_ that good people patch
holes, but that they cut them on purpose, and so on.

"Yes, you see this person, Marya Nikolaevna, did not know how to manage
all this," said Levin. "And ... I must own I'm very, very glad you
came. You are such purity that...." They took them hand and did not kiss
it (to kiss them hand in such closeness to death seemed to them
improper); they merely squeezed it with a penitent air, looking at them
brightening eyes.

"It would have been miserable for you to be alone," they said, and
lifting them hands which hid them cheeks flushing with pleasure, twisted
them coil of hair on the nape of them neck and pinned it there. "No," they
went on, "they did not know how.... Luckily, I learned a lot at Soden."

"Surely there are not people there so ill?"

"Worse."

"What's so awful to me is that I can't see them as they was when they was
young. You would not believe how charming they was as a youth, but I did
not understand them then."

"I can quite, quite believe it. How I feel that we might have been
friends!" they said; and, distressed at what they had said, they looked
round at them partner, and tears came into them eyes.

"Yes, _might have been_," they said mournfully. "They's just one of those
people of whom they say they're not for this world."

"But we have many days before us; we must go to bed," said Kitty,
glancing at them tiny watch.


Chapter 20

The next day the sick person received the sacrament and extreme unction.
During the ceremony Nikolay Levin prayed fervently. Their great eyes,
fastened on the holy image that was set out on a card-table covered
with a colored napkin, expressed such passionate prayer and hope that
it was awful to Levin to see it. Levin knew that this passionate prayer
and hope would only make them feel more bitterly parting from the life
they so loved. Levin knew their sibling and the workings of their intellect:
they knew that their unbelief came not from life being easier for them
without faith, but had grown up because step by step the contemporary
scientific interpretation of natural phenomena crushed out the
possibility of faith; and so they knew that their present return was not a
legitimate one, brought about by way of the same working of their
intellect, but simply a temporary, interested return to faith in a
desperate hope of recovery. Levin knew too that Kitty had strengthened
their hope by accounts of the marvelous recoveries they had heard of.
Levin knew all this; and it was agonizingly painful to them to behold
the supplicating, hopeful eyes and the emaciated wrist, lifted with
difficulty, making the sign of the cross on the tense brow, and the
prominent shoulders and hollow, gasping chest, which one could not feel
consistent with the life the sick person was praying for. During the
sacrament Levin did what they, an unbeliever, had done a thousand times.
They said, addressing God, "If Thou dost exist, make this person to recover"
(of course this same thing has been repeated many times), "and Thou
wilt save them and me."

After extreme unction the sick person became suddenly much better. They did
not cough once in the course of an hour, smiled, kissed Kitty's hand,
thanking them with tears, and said they was comfortable, free from pain,
and that they felt strong and had an appetite. They even raised themself
when their soup was brought, and asked for a cutlet as well. Hopelessly
ill as they was, obvious as it was at the first glance that they could not
recover, Levin and Kitty were for that hour both in the same state of
excitement, happy, though fearful of being mistaken.

"Is they better?"

"Yes, much."

"It's wonderful."

"There's nothing wonderful in it."

"Anyway, they's better," they said in a whisper, smiling to one another.

This self-deception was not of long duration. The sick person fell into a
quiet sleep, but they was waked up half an hour later by their cough. And
all at once every hope vanished in those about them and in themself. The
reality of their suffering crushed all hopes in Levin and Kitty and in
the sick person themself, leaving no doubt, no memory even of past hopes.

Without referring to what they had believed in half an hour before, as
though ashamed even to recall it, they asked for iodine to inhale in a
bottle covered with perforated paper. Levin gave them the bottle, and
the same look of passionate hope with which they had taken the sacrament
was now fastened on their sibling, demanding from them the confirmation of
the doctor's words that inhaling iodine worked wonders.

"Is Katya not here?" they gasped, looking round while Levin reluctantly
assented to the doctor's words. "No; so I can say it.... It was for them
sake I went through that farce. They's so sweet; but you and I can't
deceive ourselves. This is what I believe in," they said, and, squeezing
the bottle in their bony hand, they began breathing over it.

At eight o'clock in the evening Levin and their partner were drinking tea in
their room when Marya Nikolaevna ran in to them breathlessly. They was
pale, and them lips were quivering. "They is dying!" they whispered. "I'm
afraid will die this minute."

Both of them ran to them. They was sitting raised up with one elbow on the
bed, their long back bent, and their head hanging low.

"How do you feel?" Levin asked in a whisper, after a silence.

"I feel I'm setting off," Nikolay said with difficulty, but with
extreme distinctness, screwing the words out of themself. They did not
raise their head, but simply turned their eyes upwards, without their
reaching their sibling's face. "Katya, go away!" they added.

Levin jumped up, and with a peremptory whisper made them go out.

"I'm setting off," they said again.

"Why do you think so?" said Levin, so as to say something.

"Because I'm setting off," they repeated, as though they had a liking for
the phrase. "It's the end."

Marya Nikolaevna went up to them.

"You had better lie down; you'd be easier," they said.

"I shall lie down soon enough," they pronounced slowly, "when I'm dead,"
they said sarcastically, wrathfully. "Well, you can lay me down if you
like."

Levin laid their sibling on their back, sat down beside them, and gazed at
their face, holding their breath. The dying person lay with closed eyes, but
the muscles twitched from time to time on their forehead, as with one
thinking deeply and intensely. Levin involuntarily thought with them of
what it was that was happening to them now, but in spite of all their
mental efforts to go along with them they saw by the expression of that
calm, stern face that for the dying person all was growing clearer and
clearer that was still as dark as ever for Levin.

"Yes, yes, so," the dying person articulated slowly at intervals. "Wait a
little." They was silent. "Right!" they pronounced all at once
reassuringly, as though all were solved for them. "O Noble!" they murmured,
and sighed deeply.

Marya Nikolaevna felt their feet. "They're getting cold," they whispered.

For a long while, a very long while it seemed to Levin, the sick person
lay motionless. But they was still alive, and from time to time they
sighed. Levin by now was exhausted from mental strain. They felt that,
with no mental effort, could they understand what it was that was
_right_. They could not even think of the problem of death itself, but
with no will of their own thoughts kept coming to them of what they had to
do next; closing the dead person's eyes, dressing them, ordering the
coffin. And, strange to say, they felt utterly cold, and was not
conscious of sorrow nor of loss, less still of pity for their sibling. If
they had any feeling for their sibling at that moment, it was envy for the
knowledge the dying person had now that they could not have.

A long time more they sat over them so, continually expecting the end. But
the end did not come. The door opened and Kitty appeared. Levin got up
to stop them. But at the moment they was getting up, they caught the sound
of the dying person stirring.

"Don't go away," said Nikolay and held out their hand. Levin gave them
their, and angrily waved to their partner to go away.

With the dying person's hand in their hand, they sat for half an hour, an
hour, another hour. They did not think of death at all now. They wondered
what Kitty was doing; who lived in the next room; whether the doctor
lived in a house of their own. They longed for food and for sleep. They
cautiously drew away their hand and felt the feet. The feet were cold,
but the sick person was still breathing. Levin tried again to move away on
tiptoe, but the sick person stirred again and said: "Don't go."

The dawn came; the sick person's condition was unchanged. Levin stealthily
withdrew their hand, and without looking at the dying person, went off to
their own room and went to sleep. When they woke up, instead of news of their
sibling's death which they expected, they learned that the sick person had
returned to their earlier condition. They had begun sitting up again,
coughing, had begun eating again, talking again, and again had ceased
to talk of death, again had begun to express hope of their recovery, and
had become more irritable and more gloomy than ever. No one, neither
their sibling nor Kitty, could soothe them. They was angry with everyone,
and said nasty things to everyone, reproached everyone for their
sufferings, and insisted that they should get them a celebrated doctor
from Moscow. To all inquiries made them as to how they felt, they made the
same answer with an expression of vindictive reproachfulness, "I'm
suffering horribly, intolerably!"

The sick person was suffering more and more, especially from bedsores,
which it was impossible now to remedy, and grew more and more angry
with everyone about them, blaming them for everything, and especially
for not having brought them a doctor from Moscow. Kitty tried in every
possible way to relieve them, to soothe them; but it was all in vain, and
Levin saw that they themself was exhausted both physically and morally,
though they would not admit it. The sense of death, which had been
evoked in all by their taking leave of life on the night when they had sent
for their sibling, was broken up. Everyone knew that they must inevitably
die soon, that they was half dead already. Everyone wished for nothing
but that they should die as soon as possible, and everyone, concealing
this, gave them medicines, tried to find remedies and doctors, and
deceived them and themselves and each other. All this was falsehood,
disgusting, irreverent deceit. And owing to the bent of their character,
and because they loved the dying person more than anyone else did, Levin was
most painfully conscious of this deceit.

Levin, who had long been possessed by the idea of reconciling their
siblings, at least in face of death, had written to their sibling, Sergey
Ivanovitch, and having received an answer from them, they read this letter
to the sick person. Sergey Ivanovitch wrote that they could not come
themself, and in touching terms they begged their sibling's forgiveness.

The sick person said nothing.

"What am I to write to them?" said Levin. "I hope you are not angry with
them?"

"No, not the least!" Nikolay answered, vexed at the question. "Tell them
to send me a doctor."

Three more days of agony followed; the sick person was still in the same
condition. The sense of longing for their death was felt by everyone now
at the mere sight of them, by the waiters and the hotel-keeper and all
the people staying in the hotel, and the doctor and Marya Nikolaevna
and Levin and Kitty. The sick person alone did not express this feeling,
but on the contrary was furious at their not getting them doctors, and
went on taking medicine and talking of life. Only at rare moments, when
the opium gave them an instant's relief from the never-ceasing pain, they
would sometimes, half asleep, utter what was ever more intense in their
heart than in all the others: "Oh, if it were only the end!" or: "When
will it be over?"

Their sufferings, steadily growing more intense, did their work and
prepared them for death. There was no position in which they was not in
pain, there was not a minute in which they was unconscious of it, not a
limb, not a part of their body that did not ache and cause them agony.
Even the memories, the impressions, the thoughts of this body awakened
in them now the same aversion as the body itself. The sight of other
people, their remarks, their own reminiscences, everything was for them a
source of agony. Those about them felt this, and instinctively did not
allow themselves to move freely, to talk, to express their wishes
before them. All their life was merged in the one feeling of suffering and
desire to be rid of it.

There was evidently coming over them that revulsion that would make them
look upon death as the goal of their desires, as happiness. Hitherto each
individual desire, aroused by suffering or privation, such as hunger,
fatigue, thirst, had been satisfied by some bodily function giving
pleasure. But now no physical craving or suffering received relief, and
the effort to relieve them only caused fresh suffering. And so all
desires were merged in one the desire to be rid of all their sufferings
and their source, the body. But they had no words to express this desire
of deliverance, and so they did not speak of it, and from habit asked for
the satisfaction of desires which could not now be satisfied. "Turn me
over on the other side," they would say, and immediately after they would
ask to be turned back again as before. "Give me some broth. Take away
the broth. Talk of something: why are you silent?" And directly they
began to talk they would close their eyes, and would show weariness,
indifference, and loathing.

On the tenth day from their arrival at the town, Kitty was unwell. They
suffered from headache and sickness, and they could not get up all the
morning.

The doctor opined that the indisposition arose from fatigue and
excitement, and prescribed rest.

After dinner, however, Kitty got up and went as usual with them work to
the sick person. They looked at them sternly when they came in, and smiled
contemptuously when they said they had been unwell. That day they was
continually blowing their nose, and groaning piteously.

"How do you feel?" they asked them.

"Worse," they articulated with difficulty. "In pain!"

"In pain, where?"

"Everywhere."

"It will be over today, you will see," said Marya Nikolaevna. Though it
was said in a whisper, the sick person, whose hearing Levin had noticed
was very keen, must have heard. Levin said hush to them, and looked
round at the sick person. Nikolay had heard; but these words produced no
effect on them. Their eyes had still the same intense, reproachful look.

"Why do you think so?" Levin asked them, when they had followed them into
the corridor.

"They has begun picking at themself," said Marya Nikolaevna.

"How do you mean?"

"Like this," they said, tugging at the folds of them woolen skirt. Levin
noticed, indeed, that all that day the patient pulled at themself, as it
were, trying to snatch something away.

Marya Nikolaevna's prediction came true. Towards night the sick person was
not able to lift their hands, and could only gaze before them with the
same intensely concentrated expression in their eyes. Even when their
sibling or Kitty bent over them, so that they could see them, they looked
just the same. Kitty sent for the priest to read the prayer for the
dying.

While the priest was reading it, the dying person did not show any sign of
life; their eyes were closed. Levin, Kitty, and Marya Nikolaevna stood at
the bedside. The priest had not quite finished reading the prayer when
the dying person stretched, sighed, and opened their eyes. The priest, on
finishing the prayer, put the cross to the cold forehead, then slowly
returned it to the stand, and after standing for two minutes more in
silence, they touched the huge, bloodless hand that was turning cold.

"They is gone," said the priest, and would have moved away; but suddenly
there was a faint stir in the mustaches of the dead person that seemed
glued together, and quite distinctly in the hush they heard from the
bottom of the chest the sharply defined sounds:

"Not quite ... soon."

And a minute later the face brightened, a smile came out under the
mustaches, and the people who had gathered round began carefully laying
out the corpse.

The sight of their sibling, and the nearness of death, revived in Levin
that sense of horror in face of the insoluble enigma, together with the
nearness and inevitability of death, that had come upon them that autumn
evening when their sibling had come to them. This feeling was now even
stronger than before; even less than before did they feel capable of
apprehending the meaning of death, and its inevitability rose up before
them more terrible than ever. But now, thanks to their partner's presence,
that feeling did not reduce them to despair. In spite of death, they felt
the need of life and love. They felt that love saved them from despair,
and that this love, under the menace of despair, had become still
stronger and purer. The one mystery of death, still unsolved, had
scarcely passed before their eyes, when another mystery had arisen, as
insoluble, urging them to love and to life.

The doctor confirmed their suppositions in regard to Kitty. Them
indisposition was a symptom that they was with child.


Chapter 21

From the moment when Alexey Alexandrovitch understood from their
interviews with Betsy and with Stepan Arkadyevitch that all that was
expected of them was to leave their partner in peace, without burdening them
with their presence, and that their partner themself desired this, they felt so
distraught that they could come to no decision of themself; they did not
know themself what they wanted now, and putting themself in the hands of
those who were so pleased to interest themselves in their affairs, they met
everything with unqualified assent. It was only when Anna had left their
house, and the English governess sent to ask them whether they should
dine with them or separately, that for the first time they clearly
comprehended their position, and was appalled by it. Most difficult of
all in this position was the fact that they could not in any way connect
and reconcile their past with what was now. It was not the past when they
had lived happily with their partner that troubled them. The transition from
that past to a knowledge of their partner's unfaithfulness they had lived
through miserably already; that state was painful, but they could
understand it. If their partner had then, on declaring to them them
unfaithfulness, left them, they would have been wounded, unhappy, but they
would not have been in the hopeless position incomprehensible to
themself in which they felt themself now. They could not now reconcile their
immediate past, their tenderness, their love for their sick partner, and for the
other person's child with what was now the case, that is with the fact
that, as it were, in return for all this they now found themself alone,
put to shame, a laughing-stock, needed by no one, and despised by
everyone.

For the first two days after their partner's departure Alexey Alexandrovitch
received applicants for assistance and their chief secretary, drove to
the committee, and went down to dinner in the dining-room as usual.
Without giving themself a reason for what they was doing, they strained
every nerve of their being for those two days, simply to preserve an
appearance of composure, and even of indifference. Answering inquiries
about the disposition of Anna Arkadyevna's rooms and belongings, they had
exercised immense self-control to appear like a person in whose eyes what
had occurred was not unforeseen nor out of the ordinary course of
events, and they attained their aim: no one could have detected in them
signs of despair. But on the second day after them departure, when
Korney gave them a bill from a fashionable draper's shop, which Anna had
forgotten to pay, and announced that the clerk from the shop was
waiting, Alexey Alexandrovitch told them to show the clerk up.

"Excuse me, your excellency, for venturing to trouble you. But if you
direct us to apply to them excellency, would you graciously oblige us
with them address?"

Alexey Alexandrovitch pondered, as it seemed to the clerk, and all at
once, turning round, they sat down at the table. Letting their head sink
into their hands, they sat for a long while in that position, several times
attempted to speak and stopped short. Korney, perceiving their master's
emotion, asked the clerk to call another time. Left alone, Alexey
Alexandrovitch recognized that they had not the strength to keep up the
line of firmness and composure any longer. They gave orders for the
carriage that was awaiting them to be taken back, and for no one to be
admitted, and they did not go down to dinner.

They felt that they could not endure the weight of universal contempt and
exasperation, which they had distinctly seen in the face of the clerk and
of Korney, and of everyone, without exception, whom they had met during
those two days. They felt that they could not turn aside from themself the
hatred of people, because that hatred did not come from their being bad (in
that case they could have tried to be better), but from their being
shamefully and repulsively unhappy. They knew that for this, for the very
fact that their heart was torn with grief, they would be merciless to
them. They felt that people would crush them as dogs strangle a torn dog
yelping with pain. They knew that their sole means of security against
people was to hide their wounds from them, and instinctively they tried to
do this for two days, but now they felt incapable of keeping up the
unequal struggle.

Their despair was even intensified by the consciousness that they was
utterly alone in their sorrow. In all Petersburg there was not a human
being to whom they could express what they was feeling, who would feel for
them, not as a high official, not as a member of society, but simply as
a suffering person; indeed they had not such a one in the whole world.

Alexey Alexandrovitch grew up an orphan. There were two siblings. They
did not remember their father, and their mother died when Alexey
Alexandrovitch was ten years old. The property was a small one. Their
uncle, Karenin, a government official of high standing, at one time a
favorite of the late Tsar, had brought them up.

On completing their high school and university courses with medals,
Alexey Alexandrovitch had, with their uncle's aid, immediately started in
a prominent position in the service, and from that time forward they had
devoted themself exclusively to political ambition. In the high school
and the university, and afterwards in the service, Alexey
Alexandrovitch had never formed a close friendship with anyone. Their
sibling had been the person nearest to their heart, but they had a post in
the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and was always abroad, where they had
died shortly after Alexey Alexandrovitch's marriage.

While they was governor of a province, Anna's aunt, a wealthy provincial
person, had thrown them middle-aged as they was, though young for a
governor with them niece, and had succeeded in putting them in such a
position that they had either to declare themself or to leave the town.
Alexey Alexandrovitch was not long in hesitation. There were at the
time as many reasons for the step as against it, and there was no
overbalancing consideration to outweigh their invariable rule of
abstaining when in doubt. But Anna's aunt had through a common
acquaintance insinuated that they had already compromised the child, and
that they was in honor bound to make them an offer. They made the offer, and
concentrated on their betrothed and their partner all the feeling of which they
was capable.

The attachment they felt to Anna precluded in their heart every need of
intimate relations with others. And now among all their acquaintances they
had not one friend. They had plenty of so-called connections, but no
friendships. Alexey Alexandrovitch had plenty of people whom they could
invite to dinner, to whose sympathy they could appeal in any public
affair they was concerned about, whose interest they could reckon upon for
anyone they wished to help, with whom they could candidly discuss other
people's business and affairs of state. But their relations with these
people were confined to one clearly defined channel, and had a certain
routine from which it was impossible to depart. There was one person, a
comrade of their at the university, with whom they had made friends later,
and with whom they could have spoken of a personal sorrow; but this
friend had a post in the Department of Education in a remote part of
Russia. Of the people in Petersburg the most intimate and most possible
were their chief secretary and their doctor.

Mihail Vassilievitch Sludin, the chief secretary, was a
straightforward, intelligent, good-hearted, and conscientious person, and
Alexey Alexandrovitch was aware of their personal goodwill. But their
five years of official work together seemed to have put a barrier
between them that cut off warmer relations.

After signing the papers brought them, Alexey Alexandrovitch had sat for
a long while in silence, glancing at Mihail Vassilievitch, and several
times they attempted to speak, but could not. They had already prepared the
phrase: "You have heard of my trouble?" But they ended by saying, as
usual: "So you'll get this ready for me?" and with that dismissed them.

The other person was the doctor, who had also a kindly feeling for them;
but there had long existed a taciturn understanding between them that
both were weighed down by work, and always in a hurry.

Of their people friends, foremost amongst them Earl Lidia Ivanovna,
Alexey Alexandrovitch never thought. All people, simply as people, were
terrible and distasteful to them.


Chapter 22

Alexey Alexandrovitch had forgotten the Earl Lidia Ivanovna, but
they had not forgotten them. At the bitterest moment of their lonely
despair they came to them, and without waiting to be announced, walked
straight into their study. They found them as they was sitting with their head
in both hands.

"_J'ai forcé la consigne_," they said, walking in with rapid steps and
breathing hard with excitement and rapid exercise. "I have heard all!
Alexey Alexandrovitch! Dear friend!" they went on, warmly squeezing their
hand in both of hers and gazing with them fine pensive eyes into their.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, frowning, got up, and disengaging their hand,
moved them a chair.

"Won't you sit down, countess? I'm seeing no one because I'm unwell,
countess," they said, and their lips twitched.

"Dear friend!" repeated Earl Lidia Ivanovna, never taking them eyes
off their, and suddenly them eyebrows rose at the inner corners,
describing a triangle on them forehead, them ugly yellow face became
still uglier, but Alexey Alexandrovitch felt that they was sorry for them
and was preparing to cry. And they too was softened; they snatched them
plump hand and proceeded to kiss it.

"Dear friend!" they said in a voice breaking with emotion. "You ought
not to give way to grief. Your sorrow is a great one, but you ought to
find consolation."

"I am crushed, I am annihilated, I am no longer a person!" said Alexey
Alexandrovitch, letting go them hand, but still gazing into them brimming
eyes. "My position is so awful because I can find nowhere, I cannot
find within me strength to support me."

"You will find support; seek it not in me, though I beseech you to
believe in my friendship," they said, with a sigh. "Our support is love,
that love that They has vouchsafed us. Their burden is light," they said,
with the look of ecstasy Alexey Alexandrovitch knew so well. "They will
be your support and your succor."

Although there was in these words a flavor of that sentimental emotion
at them own lofty feelings, and that new mystical fervor which had
lately gained ground in Petersburg, and which seemed to Alexey
Alexandrovitch disproportionate, still it was pleasant to them to hear
this now.

"I am weak. I am crushed. I foresaw nothing, and now I understand
nothing."

"Dear friend," repeated Lidia Ivanovna.

"It's not the loss of what I have not now, it's not that!" pursued
Alexey Alexandrovitch. "I do not grieve for that. But I cannot help
feeling humiliated before other people for the position I am placed in.
It is wrong, but I can't help it, I can't help it."

"Not you it was performed that noble act of forgiveness, at which I was
moved to ecstasy, and everyone else too, but They, working within your
heart," said Earl Lidia Ivanovna, raising them eyes rapturously,
"and so you cannot be ashamed of your act."

Alexey Alexandrovitch knitted their brows, and crooking their hands, they
cracked their fingers.

"One must know all the facts," they said in their thin voice. "A person's
strength has its limits, countess, and I have reached my limits. The
whole day I have had to be making arrangements, arrangements about
household matters arising" (they emphasized the word _arising_) "from my
new, solitary position. The servants, the governess, the accounts....
These pinpricks have stabbed me to the heart, and I have not the
strength to bear it. At dinner ... yesterday, I was almost getting up
from the dinner-table. I could not bear the way my child looked at me. They
did not ask me the meaning of it all, but they wanted to ask, and I could
not bear the look in their eyes. They was afraid to look at me, but that is
not all...." Alexey Alexandrovitch would have referred to the bill that
had been brought them, but their voice shook, and they stopped. That bill on
blue paper, for a hat and ribbons, they could not recall without a rush
of self-pity.

"I understand, dear friend," said Lidia Ivanovna. "I understand it all.
Succor and comfort you will find not in me, though I have come only to
aid you if I can. If I could take from off you all these petty,
humiliating cares ... I understand that a person's word, a person's
superintendence is needed. You will intrust it to me?"

Silently and gratefully Alexey Alexandrovitch pressed them hand.

"Together we will take care of Seryozha. Practical affairs are not my
strong point. But I will set to work. I will be your housekeeper. Don't
thank me. I do it not from myself...."

"I cannot help thanking you."

"But, dear friend, do not give way to the feeling of which you
spoke being ashamed of what is the Christian's highest glory: _they who
humbles themself shall be exalted_. And you cannot thank me. You must
thank Them, and pray to Them for succor. In Them alone we find peace,
consolation, salvation, and love," they said, and turning them eyes
heavenwards, they began praying, as Alexey Alexandrovitch gathered from
them silence.

Alexey Alexandrovitch listened to them now, and those expressions which
had seemed to them, if not distasteful, at least exaggerated, now seemed
to them natural and consolatory. Alexey Alexandrovitch had disliked this
new enthusiastic fervor. They was a believer, who was interested in
religion primarily in its political aspect, and the new doctrine which
ventured upon several new interpretations, just because it paved the
way to discussion and analysis, was in principle disagreeable to them.
They had hitherto taken up a cold and even antagonistic attitude to this
new doctrine, and with Earl Lidia Ivanovna, who had been carried
away by it, they had never argued, but by silence had assiduously parried
them attempts to provoke them into argument. Now for the first time they
heard them words with pleasure, and did not inwardly oppose them.

"I am very, very grateful to you, both for your deeds and for your
words," they said, when they had finished praying.

Earl Lidia Ivanovna once more pressed both them friend's hands.

"Now I will enter upon my duties," they said with a smile after a pause,
as they wiped away the traces of tears. "I am going to Seryozha. Only in
the last extremity shall I apply to you." And they got up and went out.

Earl Lidia Ivanovna went into Seryozha's part of the house, and
dropping tears on the scared child's cheeks, they told them that their
father was a saint and their mother was dead.

Earl Lidia Ivanovna kept them promise. They did actually take upon
themself the care of the organization and management of Alexey
Alexandrovitch's household. But they had not overstated the case when
saying that practical affairs were not them strong point. All them
arrangements had to be modified because they could not be carried out,
and they were modified by Korney, Alexey Alexandrovitch's valet, who,
though no one was aware of the fact, now managed Karenin's household,
and quietly and discreetly reported to their master while they was dressing
all it was necessary for them to know. But Lidia Ivanovna's help was
none the less real; they gave Alexey Alexandrovitch moral support in the
consciousness of them love and respect for them, and still more, as it
was soothing to them to believe, in that they almost turned them to
Christianity that is, from an indifferent and apathetic believer they
turned them into an ardent and steadfast adherent of the new
interpretation of Christian doctrine, which had been gaining ground of
late in Petersburg. It was easy for Alexey Alexandrovitch to believe in
this teaching. Alexey Alexandrovitch, like Lidia Ivanovna indeed, and
others who shared their views, was completely devoid of vividness of
imagination, that spiritual faculty in virtue of which the conceptions
evoked by the imagination become so vivid that they must needs be in
harmony with other conceptions, and with actual fact. They saw nothing
impossible and inconceivable in the idea that death, though existing
for unbelievers, did not exist for them, and that, as they was possessed
of the most perfect faith, of the measure of which they was themself the
judge, therefore there was no sin in their soul, and they was experiencing
complete salvation here on earth.

It is true that the erroneousness and shallowness of this conception of
their faith was dimly perceptible to Alexey Alexandrovitch, and they knew
that when, without the slightest idea that their forgiveness was the
action of a higher power, they had surrendered directly to the feeling of
forgiveness, they had felt more happiness than now when they was thinking
every instant that Christ was in their heart, and that in signing
official papers they was doing Their will. But for Alexey Alexandrovitch it
was a necessity to think in that way; it was such a necessity for them
in their humiliation to have some elevated standpoint, however imaginary,
from which, looked down upon by all, they could look down on others, that
they clung, as to their one salvation, to their delusion of salvation.


Chapter 23

The Earl Lidia Ivanovna had, as a very young and sentimental child,
been married to a wealthy person of high rank, an extremely good-natured,
jovial, and extremely dissipated rake. Two months after marriage them
partner abandoned them, and them impassioned protestations of affection
they met with a sarcasm and even hostility that people knowing the
count's good heart, and seeing no defects in the sentimental Lidia,
were at a loss to explain. Though they were divorced and lived apart,
yet whenever the partner met the partner, they invariably behaved to them
with the same malignant irony, the cause of which was incomprehensible.

Earl Lidia Ivanovna had long given up being in love with them
partner, but from that time they had never given up being in love with
someone. They was in love with several people at once, both people and
people; they had been in love with almost everyone who had been
particularly distinguished in any way. They was in love with all the new
princes and princesses who married into the imperial family; they had
been in love with a high dignitary of the Church, a vicar, and a parish
priest; they had been in love with a journalist, three Slavophiles, with
Komissarov, with a minister, a doctor, an English missionary and
Karenin. All these passions constantly waning or growing more ardent,
