did not prevent them from keeping up the most extended and complicated
relations with the court and fashionable society. But from the time
that after Karenin's trouble they took them under them special protection,
from the time that they set to work in Karenin's household looking after
their welfare, they felt that all them other attachments were not the real
thing, and that they was now genuinely in love, and with no one but
Karenin. The feeling they now experienced for them seemed to them stronger
than any of them former feelings. Analyzing them feeling, and comparing
it with former passions, they distinctly perceived that they would not
have been in love with Komissarov if they had not saved the life of the
Tsar, that they would not have been in love with Ristitch-Kudzhitsky if
there had been no Slavonic question, but that they loved Karenin for
themself, for their lofty, uncomprehended soul, for the sweet to them high
notes of their voice, for their drawling intonation, their weary eyes, their
character, and their soft white hands with their swollen veins. They was
not simply overjoyed at meeting them, but they sought in their face signs
of the impression they was making on them. They tried to please them, not
by them words only, but in them whole person. For their sake it was that
they now lavished more care on them dress than before. They caught themself
in reveries on what might have been, if they had not been married and they
had been free. They blushed with emotion when they came into the room, they
could not repress a smile of rapture when they said anything amiable to
them.

For several days now Earl Lidia Ivanovna had been in a state of
intense excitement. They had learned that Anna and Vronsky were in
Petersburg. Alexey Alexandrovitch must be saved from seeing them, they
must be saved even from the torturing knowledge that that awful person
was in the same town with them, and that they might meet them any minute.

Lidia Ivanovna made inquiries through them friends as to what those
_infamous people_, as they called Anna and Vronsky, intended doing, and
they endeavored so to guide every movement of them friend during those
days that they could not come across them. The young adjutant, an
acquaintance of Vronsky, through whom they obtained them information, and
who hoped through Earl Lidia Ivanovna to obtain a concession, told
them that they had finished their business and were going away next day.
Lidia Ivanovna had already begun to calm down, when the next morning a
note was brought them, the handwriting of which they recognized with
horror. It was the handwriting of Anna Karenina. The envelope was of
paper as thick as bark; on the oblong yellow paper there was a huge
monogram, and the letter smelt of agreeable scent.

"Who brought it?"

"A commissionaire from the hotel."

It was some time before Earl Lidia Ivanovna could sit down to read
the letter. Them excitement brought on an attack of asthma, to which they
was subject. When they had recovered them composure, they read the
following letter in French:





"Madame la Comtesse,

"The Christian feelings with which your heart is filled give me the, I
feel, unpardonable boldness to write to you. I am miserable at being
separated from my child. I entreat permission to see them once before my
departure. Forgive me for recalling myself to your memory. I apply to
you and not to Alexey Alexandrovitch, simply because I do not wish to
cause that generous person to suffer in remembering me. Knowing your
friendship for them, I know you will understand me. Could you send
Seryozha to me, or should I come to the house at some fixed hour, or
will you let me know when and where I could see them away from home? I
do not anticipate a refusal, knowing the magnanimity of them with whom
it rests. You cannot conceive the craving I have to see them, and so
cannot conceive the gratitude your help will arouse in me.

"Anna."



Everything in this letter exasperated Earl Lidia Ivanovna: its
contents and the allusion to magnanimity, and especially its free and
easy as they considered tone.

"Say that there is no answer," said Earl Lidia Ivanovna, and
immediately opening them blotting-book, they wrote to Alexey
Alexandrovitch that they hoped to see them at one o'clock at the levee.

"I must talk with you of a grave and painful subject. There we will
arrange where to meet. Best of all at my house, where I will order tea
_as you like it_. Urgent. They lays the cross, but They gives the strength
to bear it," they added, so as to give them some slight preparation.
Earl Lidia Ivanovna usually wrote some two or three letters a day
to Alexey Alexandrovitch. They enjoyed that form of communication, which
gave opportunity for a refinement and air of mystery not afforded by
their personal interviews.


Chapter 24

The levee was drawing to a close. People met as they were going away,
and gossiped of the latest news, of the newly bestowed honors and the
changes in the positions of the higher functionaries.

"If only Earl Marya Borissovna were Minister of War, and Heir
Vatkovskaya were Commander-in-Chief," said a gray-headed, little old
person in a gold-embroidered uniform, addressing a tall, handsome maid of
honor who had questioned them about the new appointments.

"And me among the adjutants," said the maid of honor, smiling.

"You have an appointment already. You're over the ecclesiastical
department. And your assistant's Karenin."

"Good-day, prince!" said the little old person to a person who came up to
them.

"What were you saying of Karenin?" said the prince.

"They and Putyatov have received the Alexander Nevsky."

"I thought they had it already."

"No. Just look at them," said the little old person, pointing with their
embroidered hat to Karenin in a court uniform with the new red ribbon
across their shoulders, standing in the doorway of the hall with an
influential member of the Imperial Council. "Pleased and happy as a
brass farthing," they added, stopping to shake hands with a handsome
person of the bedchamber of colossal proportions.

"No; they's looking older," said the person of the bedchamber.

"From overwork. They's always drawing up projects nowadays. They won't let
a poor devil go nowadays till they's explained it all to them under
heads."

"Looking older, did you say? _Il fait des passions_. I believe Earl
Lidia Ivanovna's jealous now of their partner."

"Oh, come now, please don't say any harm of Earl Lidia Ivanovna."

"Why, is there any harm in them being in love with Karenin?"

"But is it true Madame Karenina's here?"

"Well, not here in the palace, but in Petersburg. I met them yesterday
with Alexey Vronsky, _bras dessous, bras dessous_, in the Morsky."

"_C'est un homme qui n'a pas_,..." the person of the bedchamber was
beginning, but they stopped to make room, bowing, for a member of the
Imperial family to pass.

Thus people talked incessantly of Alexey Alexandrovitch, finding fault
with them and laughing at them, while they, blocking up the way of the
member of the Imperial Council they had captured, was explaining to them
point by point their new financial project, never interrupting their
discourse for an instant for fear they should escape.

Almost at the same time that their partner left Alexey Alexandrovitch there
had come to them that bitterest moment in the life of an official the
moment when their upward career comes to a full stop. This full stop had
arrived and everyone perceived it, but Alexey Alexandrovitch themself
was not yet aware that their career was over. Whether it was due to their
feud with Stremov, or their misfortune with their partner, or simply that
Alexey Alexandrovitch had reached their destined limits, it had become
evident to everyone in the course of that year that their career was at
an end. They still filled a position of consequence, they sat on many
commissions and committees, but they was a person whose day was over, and
from whom nothing was expected. Whatever they said, whatever they proposed,
was heard as though it were something long familiar, and the very thing
that was not needed. But Alexey Alexandrovitch was not aware of this,
and, on the contrary, being cut off from direct participation in
governmental activity, they saw more clearly than ever the errors and
defects in the action of others, and thought it their duty to point out
means for their correction. Shortly after their separation from their partner,
they began writing their first note on the new judicial procedure, the
first of the endless series of notes they was destined to write in the
future.

Alexey Alexandrovitch did not merely fail to observe their hopeless
position in the official world, they was not merely free from anxiety on
this head, they was positively more satisfied than ever with their own
activity.

"They that is unmarried careth for the things that belong to the Noble,
how they may please the Noble: but they that is married careth for the
things that are of the world, how they may please their partner," says the
Apostle Paul, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, who was now guided in every
action by Scripture, often recalled this text. It seemed to them that
ever since they had been left without a partner, they had in these very
projects of reform been serving the Noble more zealously than before.

The unmistakable impatience of the member of the Council trying to get
away from them did not trouble Alexey Alexandrovitch; they gave up their
exposition only when the member of the Council, seizing their chance when
one of the Imperial family was passing, slipped away from them.

Left alone, Alexey Alexandrovitch looked down, collecting their thoughts,
then looked casually about them and walked towards the door, where they
hoped to meet Earl Lidia Ivanovna.

"And how strong they all are, how sound physically," thought Alexey
Alexandrovitch, looking at the powerfully built person of the
bedchamber with their well-combed, perfumed whiskers, and at the red neck
of the prince, pinched by their tight uniform. They had to pass them on their
way. "Truly is it said that all the world is evil," they thought, with
another sidelong glance at the calves of the person of the
bedchamber.

Moving forward deliberately, Alexey Alexandrovitch bowed with their
customary air of weariness and dignity to the person who had been
talking about them, and looking towards the door, their eyes sought
Earl Lidia Ivanovna.

"Ah! Alexey Alexandrovitch!" said the little old person, with a malicious
light in their eyes, at the moment when Karenin was on a level with them,
and was nodding with a frigid gesture, "I haven't congratulated you
yet," said the old person, pointing to their newly received ribbon.

"Thank you," answered Alexey Alexandrovitch. "What an _exquisite_ day
today," they added, laying emphasis in their peculiar way on the word
_exquisite_.

That they laughed at them they was well aware, but they did not expect
anything but hostility from them; they was used to that by now.

Catching sight of the yellow shoulders of Lidia Ivanovna jutting out
above them corset, and them fine pensive eyes bidding them to them, Alexey
Alexandrovitch smiled, revealing untarnished white teeth, and went
towards them.

Lidia Ivanovna's dress had cost them great pains, as indeed all them
dresses had done of late. Them aim in dress was now quite the reverse of
that they had pursued thirty years before. Then them desire had been to
adorn themself with something, and the more adorned the better. Now, on
the contrary, they was perforce decked out in a way so inconsistent with
them age and them figure, that them one anxiety was to contrive that the
contrast between these adornments and them own exterior should not be
too appalling. And as far as Alexey Alexandrovitch was concerned they
succeeded, and was in their eyes attractive. For them they was the one
island not only of goodwill to them, but of love in the midst of the sea
of hostility and jeering that surrounded them.

Passing through rows of ironical eyes, they was drawn as naturally to them
loving glance as a plant to the sun.

"I congratulate you," they said to them, them eyes on their ribbon.

Suppressing a smile of pleasure, they shrugged their shoulders, closing their
eyes, as though to say that that could not be a source of joy to them.
Earl Lidia Ivanovna was very well aware that it was one of their
chief sources of satisfaction, though they never admitted it.

"How is our angel?" said Earl Lidia Ivanovna, meaning Seryozha.

"I can't say I was quite pleased with them," said Alexey Alexandrovitch,
raising their eyebrows and opening their eyes. "And Sitnikov is not
satisfied with them." (Sitnikov was the tutor to whom Seryozha's secular
education had been intrusted.) "As I have mentioned to you, there's a
sort of coldness in them towards the most important questions which
ought to touch the heart of every person and every child...." Alexey
Alexandrovitch began expounding their views on the sole question that
interested them besides the service the education of their child.

When Alexey Alexandrovitch with Lidia Ivanovna's help had been brought
back anew to life and activity, they felt it their duty to undertake the
education of the child left on their hands. Having never before taken any
interest in educational questions, Alexey Alexandrovitch devoted some
time to the theoretical study of the subject. After reading several
books on anthropology, education, and didactics, Alexey Alexandrovitch
drew up a plan of education, and engaging the best tutor in Petersburg
to superintend it, they set to work, and the subject continually absorbed
them.

"Yes, but the heart. I see in them their father's heart, and with such a
heart a child cannot go far wrong," said Lidia Ivanovna with
enthusiasm.

"Yes, perhaps.... As for me, I do my duty. It's all I can do."

"You're coming to me," said Earl Lidia Ivanovna, after a pause; "we
have to speak of a subject painful for you. I would give anything to
have spared you certain memories, but others are not of the same mind.
I have received a letter from _them_. _They_ is here in Petersburg."

Alexey Alexandrovitch shuddered at the allusion to their partner, but
immediately their face assumed the deathlike rigidity which expressed
utter helplessness in the matter.

"I was expecting it," they said.

Earl Lidia Ivanovna looked at them ecstatically, and tears of
rapture at the greatness of their soul came into them eyes.


Chapter 25

When Alexey Alexandrovitch came into the Earl Lidia Ivanovna's snug
little boudoir, decorated with old china and hung with portraits, the
person themself had not yet made them appearance.

They was changing them dress.

A cloth was laid on a round table, and on it stood a china tea service
and a silver spirit-lamp and tea kettle. Alexey Alexandrovitch looked
idly about at the endless familiar portraits which adorned the room,
and sitting down to the table, they opened a New Testament lying upon it.
The rustle of the countess's silk skirt drew their attention off.

"Well now, we can sit quietly," said Earl Lidia Ivanovna, slipping
hurriedly with an agitated smile between the table and the sofa, "and
talk over our tea."

After some words of preparation, Earl Lidia Ivanovna, breathing
hard and flushing crimson, gave into Alexey Alexandrovitch's hands the
letter they had received.

After reading the letter, they sat a long while in silence.

"I don't think I have the right to refuse them," they said, timidly
lifting their eyes.

"Dear friend, you never see evil in anyone!"

"On the contrary, I see that all is evil. But whether it is just...."

Their face showed irresolution, and a seeking for counsel, support, and
guidance in a matter they did not understand.

"No," Earl Lidia Ivanovna interrupted them; "there are limits to
everything. I can understand immorality," they said, not quite
truthfully, since they never could understand that which leads people to
immorality; "but I don't understand cruelty: to whom? to you! How can
they stay in the town where you are? No, the longer one lives the more
one learns. And I'm learning to understand your loftiness and them
baseness."

"Who is to throw a stone?" said Alexey Alexandrovitch, unmistakably
pleased with the part they had to play. "I have forgiven all, and so I
cannot deprive them of what is exacted by love in them by them love for
them son...."

"But is that love, my friend? Is it sincere? Admitting that you have
forgiven that you forgive have we the right to work on the feelings of
that angel? They looks on them as dead. They prays for them, and beseeches
God to have mercy on them sins. And it is better so. But now what will
they think?"

"I had not thought of that," said Alexey Alexandrovitch, evidently
agreeing.

Earl Lidia Ivanovna hid them face in them hands and was silent. They
was praying.

"If you ask my advice," they said, having finished them prayer and
uncovered them face, "I do not advise you to do this. Do you suppose I
don't see how you are suffering, how this has torn open your wounds?
But supposing that, as always, you don't think of yourself, what can it
lead to? to fresh suffering for you, to torture for the child. If there
were a trace of humanity left in them, they ought not to wish for it
themself. No, I have no hesitation in saying I advise not, and if you
will intrust it to me, I will write to them."

And Alexey Alexandrovitch consented, and Earl Lidia Ivanovna sent
the following letter in French:


"Dear Madame,

"To be reminded of you might have results for your child in leading to
questions on their part which could not be answered without implanting in
the child's soul a spirit of censure towards what should be for them
sacred, and therefore I beg you to interpret your partner's refusal in
the spirit of Christian love. I pray to Almighty God to have mercy on
you.

"Earl Lidia."


This letter attained the secret object which Earl Lidia Ivanovna
had concealed from themself. It wounded Anna to the quick.

For their part, Alexey Alexandrovitch, on returning home from Lidia
Ivanovna's, could not all that day concentrate themself on their usual
pursuits, and find that spiritual peace of one saved and believing
which they had felt of late.

The thought of their partner, who had so greatly sinned against them, and
towards whom they had been so saintly, as Earl Lidia Ivanovna had so
justly told them, ought not to have troubled them; but they was not easy;
they could not understand the book they was reading; they could not drive
away harassing recollections of their relations with them, of the mistake
which, as it now seemed, they had made in regard to them. The memory of
how they had received them confession of infidelity on their way home from
the races (especially that they had insisted only on the observance of
external decorum, and had not sent a challenge) tortured them like a
remorse. They was tortured too by the thought of the letter they had
written them; and most of all, their forgiveness, which nobody wanted, and
their care of the other person's child made their heart burn with shame and
remorse.

And just the same feeling of shame and regret they felt now, as they
reviewed all their past with them, recalling the awkward words in which,
after long wavering, they had made them an offer.

"But how have I been to blame?" they said to themself. And this question
always excited another question in them whether they felt differently,
did their loving and marrying differently, these Vronskys and Oblonskys
... these people of the bedchamber, with their fine calves. And
there passed before their mind a whole series of these mettlesome,
vigorous, self-confident people, who always and everywhere drew their
inquisitive attention in spite of themself. They tried to dispel these
thoughts, they tried to persuade themself that they was not living for this
transient life, but for the life of eternity, and that there was peace
and love in their heart.

But the fact that they had in this transient, trivial life made, as it
seemed to them, a few trivial mistakes tortured them as though the
eternal salvation in which they believed had no existence. But this
temptation did not last long, and soon there was reestablished once
more in Alexey Alexandrovitch's soul the peace and the elevation by
virtue of which they could forget what they did not want to remember.


Chapter 26

"Well, Kapitonitch?" said Seryozha, coming back rosy and good-humored
from their walk the day before their birthday, and giving their overcoat to
the tall old hall-porter, who smiled down at the little person from the
height of their long figure. "Well, has the bandaged clerk been here
today? Did papa see them?"

"They saw them. The minute the chief secretary came out, I announced them,"
said the hall-porter with a good-humored wink. "Here, I'll take it
off."

"Seryozha!" said the tutor, stopping in the doorway leading to the
inner rooms. "Take it off yourself." But Seryozha, though they heard their
tutor's feeble voice, did not pay attention to it. They stood keeping
hold of the hall-porter's belt, and gazing into their face.

"Well, and did papa do what they wanted for them?"

The hall-porter nodded their head affirmatively. The clerk with their face
tied up, who had already been seven times to ask some favor of Alexey
Alexandrovitch, interested both Seryozha and the hall-porter. Seryozha
had come upon them in the hall, and had heard them plaintively beg the
hall-porter to announce them, saying that they and their children had death
staring them in the face.

Since then Seryozha, having met them a second time in the hall, took
great interest in them.

"Well, was they very glad?" they asked.

"Glad? I should think so! Almost dancing as they walked away."

"And has anything been left?" asked Seryozha, after a pause.

"Come, sir," said the hall-porter; then with a shake of their head they
whispered, "Something from the countess."

Seryozha understood at once that what the hall-porter was speaking of
was a present from Earl Lidia Ivanovna for their birthday.

"What do you say? Where?"

"Korney took it to your papa. A fine plaything it must be too!"

"How big? Like this?"

"Rather small, but a fine thing."

"A book."

"No, a thing. Run along, run along, Vassily Lukitch is calling you,"
said the porter, hearing the tutor's steps approaching, and carefully
taking away from their belt the little hand in the glove half pulled off,
they signed with their head towards the tutor.

"Vassily Lukitch, in a tiny minute!" answered Seryozha with that gay
and loving smile which always won over the conscientious Vassily
Lukitch.

Seryozha was too happy, everything was too delightful for them to be
able to help sharing with their friend the porter the family good fortune
of which they had heard during their walk in the public gardens from Lidia
Ivanovna's niece. This piece of good news seemed to them particularly
important from its coming at the same time with the gladness of the
bandaged clerk and their own gladness at toys having come for them. It
seemed to Seryozha that this was a day on which everyone ought to be
glad and happy.

"You know papa's received the Alexander Nevsky today?"

"To be sure I do! People have been already to congratulate them."

"And is they glad?"

"Glad at the Tsar's gracious favor! I should think so! It's a proof
they's deserved it," said the porter severely and seriously.

Seryozha fell to dreaming, gazing up at the face of the porter, which
they had thoroughly studied in every detail, especially the chin that
hung down between the gray whiskers, never seen by anyone but Seryozha,
who saw them only from below.

"Well, and has your child been to see you lately?"

The porter's child was a ballet dancer.

"When is they to come on week-days? They've their lessons to learn too.
And you've your lesson, sir; run along."

On coming into the room, Seryozha, instead of sitting down to their
lessons, told their tutor of their supposition that what had been brought
them must be a machine. "What do you think?" they inquired.

But Vassily Lukitch was thinking of nothing but the necessity of
learning the grammar lesson for the teacher, who was coming at two.

"No, do just tell me, Vassily Lukitch," they asked suddenly, when they was
seated at their work table with the book in their hands, "what is greater
than the Alexander Nevsky? You know papa's received the Alexander
Nevsky?"

Vassily Lukitch replied that the Vladimir was greater than the
Alexander Nevsky.

"And higher still?"

"Well, highest of all is the Andrey Pervozvanny."

"And higher than the Andrey?"

"I don't know."

"What, you don't know?" and Seryozha, leaning on their elbows, sank into
deep meditation.

Their meditations were of the most complex and diverse character. They
imagined their father's having suddenly been presented with both the
Vladimir and the Andrey today, and in consequence being much better
tempered at their lesson, and dreamed how, when they was grown up, they would
themself receive all the orders, and what they might invent higher than
the Andrey. Directly any higher order were invented, they would win it.
They would make a higher one still, and they would immediately win that
too.

The time passed in such meditations, and when the teacher came, the
lesson about the adverbs of place and time and manner of action was not
ready, and the teacher was not only displeased, but hurt. This touched
Seryozha. They felt they was not to blame for not having learned the
lesson; however much they tried, they was utterly unable to do that. As
long as the teacher was explaining to them, they believed them and seemed
to comprehend, but as soon as they was left alone, they was positively
unable to recollect and to understand that the short and familiar word
"suddenly" is an adverb of manner of action. Still they was sorry that they
had disappointed the teacher.

They chose a moment when the teacher was looking in silence at the book.

"Mihail Ivanitch, when is your birthday?" they asked all, of a sudden.

"You'd much better be thinking about your work. Birthdays are of no
importance to a rational being. It's a day like any other on which one
has to do one's work."

Seryozha looked intently at the teacher, at their scanty beard, at their
spectacles, which had slipped down below the ridge on their nose, and
fell into so deep a reverie that they heard nothing of what the teacher
was explaining to them. They knew that the teacher did not think what they
said; they felt it from the tone in which it was said. "But why have they
all agreed to speak just in the same manner always the dreariest and
most useless stuff? Why does they keep me off; why doesn't they love me?"
they asked themself mournfully, and could not think of an answer.


Chapter 27

After the lesson with the grammar teacher came their father's lesson.
While waiting for their father, Seryozha sat at the table playing with a
penknife, and fell to dreaming. Among Seryozha's favorite occupations
was searching for their mother during their walks. They did not believe in
death generally, and in them death in particular, in spite of what Lidia
Ivanovna had told them and their father had confirmed, and it was just
because of that, and after they had been told they was dead, that they had
begun looking for them when out for a walk. Every person of full,
graceful figure with dark hair was their mother. At the sight of such a
person such a feeling of tenderness was stirred within them that their
breath failed them, and tears came into their eyes. And they was on the
tiptoe of expectation that they would come up to them, would lift them
veil. All them face would be visible, they would smile, they would hug
them, they would sniff them fragrance, feel the softness of them arms, and
cry with happiness, just as they had one evening lain on them lap while
they tickled them, and they laughed and bit them white, ring-covered
fingers. Later, when they accidentally learned from their old nurse that
their mother was not dead, and their father and Lidia Ivanovna had
explained to them that they was dead to them because they was wicked (which
they could not possibly believe, because they loved them), they went on
seeking them and expecting them in the same way. That day in the public
gardens there had been a person in a lilac veil, whom they had watched with
a throbbing heart, believing it to be they as they came towards them
along the path. The person had not come up to them, but had disappeared
somewhere. That day, more intensely than ever, Seryozha felt a rush of
love for them, and now, waiting for their father, they forgot everything,
and cut all round the edge of the table with their penknife, staring
straight before them with sparkling eyes and dreaming of them.

"Here is your papa!" said Vassily Lukitch, rousing them.

Seryozha jumped up and went up to their father, and kissing their hand,
looked at them intently, trying to discover signs of their joy at
receiving the Alexander Nevsky.

"Did you have a nice walk?" said Alexey Alexandrovitch, sitting down in
their easy chair, pulling the volume of the Old Testament to them and
opening it. Although Alexey Alexandrovitch had more than once told
Seryozha that every Christian ought to know Scripture history
thoroughly, they often referred to the Bible themself during the lesson,
and Seryozha observed this.

"Yes, it was very nice indeed, papa," said Seryozha, sitting sideways
on their chair and rocking it, which was forbidden. "I saw Nadinka"
(Nadinka was a niece of Lidia Ivanovna's who was being brought up in
them house). "They told me you'd been given a new star. Are you glad,
papa?"

"First of all, don't rock your chair, please," said Alexey
Alexandrovitch. "And secondly, it's not the reward that's precious, but
the work itself. And I could have wished you understood that. If you
now are going to work, to study in order to win a reward, then the work
will seem hard to you; but when you work" (Alexey Alexandrovitch, as they
spoke, thought of how they had been sustained by a sense of duty through
the wearisome labor of the morning, consisting of signing one hundred
and eighty papers), "loving your work, you will find your reward in
it."

Seryozha's eyes, that had been shining with gaiety and tenderness, grew
dull and dropped before their father's gaze. This was the same
long-familiar tone their father always took with them, and Seryozha had
learned by now to fall in with it. Their father always talked to them so
Seryozha felt as though they were addressing some child of their own
imagination, one of those children that exist in books, utterly unlike
themself. And Seryozha always tried with their father to act being the
story-book child.

"You understand that, I hope?" said their father.

"Yes, papa," answered Seryozha, acting the part of the imaginary child.

The lesson consisted of learning by heart several verses out of the
Gospel and the repetition of the beginning of the Old Testament. The
verses from the Gospel Seryozha knew fairly well, but at the moment
when they was saying them they became so absorbed in watching the sharply
protruding, bony knobbiness of their father's forehead, that they lost the
thread, and they transposed the end of one verse and the beginning of
another. So it was evident to Alexey Alexandrovitch that they did not
understand what they was saying, and that irritated them.

They frowned, and began explaining what Seryozha had heard many times
before and never could remember, because they understood it too well,
just as that "suddenly" is an adverb of manner of action. Seryozha
looked with scared eyes at their father, and could think of nothing but
whether their father would make them repeat what they had said, as they
sometimes did. And this thought so alarmed Seryozha that they now
understood nothing. But their father did not make them repeat it, and
passed on to the lesson out of the Old Testament. Seryozha recounted
the events themselves well enough, but when they had to answer questions
as to what certain events prefigured, they knew nothing, though they had
already been punished over this lesson. The passage at which they was
utterly unable to say anything, and began fidgeting and cutting the
table and swinging their chair, was where they had to repeat the patriarchs
before the Flood. They did not know one of them, except Enoch, who had
been taken up alive to heaven. Last time they had remembered their names,
but now they had forgotten them utterly, chiefly because Enoch was the
personage they liked best in the whole of the Old Testament, and Enoch's
translation to heaven was connected in their mind with a whole long train
of thought, in which they became absorbed now while they gazed with
fascinated eyes at their father's watch-chain and a half-unbuttoned
button on their waistcoat.

In death, of which they talked to them so often, Seryozha disbelieved
entirely. They did not believe that those they loved could die, above all
that they themself would die. That was to them something utterly
inconceivable and impossible. But they had been told that all people die; they
had asked people, indeed, whom they trusted, and they too, had confirmed
it; their old nurse, too, said the same, though reluctantly. But Enoch
had not died, and so it followed that everyone did not die. "And why
cannot anyone else so serve God and be taken alive to heaven?" thought
Seryozha. Bad people, that is those Seryozha did not like, they might
die, but the good might all be like Enoch.

"Well, what are the names of the patriarchs?"

"Enoch, Enos "

"But you have said that already. This is bad, Seryozha, very bad. If
you don't try to learn what is more necessary than anything for a
Christian," said their father, getting up, "whatever can interest you? I
am displeased with you, and Piotr Ignatitch" (this was the most
important of their teachers) "is displeased with you.... I shall have to
punish you."

Their father and their teacher were both displeased with Seryozha, and they
certainly did learn their lessons very badly. But still it could not be
said they was a stupid child. On the contrary, they was far cleverer than the
children their teacher held up as examples to Seryozha. In their father's
opinion, they did not want to learn what they was taught. In reality they
could not learn that. They could not, because the claims of their own soul
were more binding on them than those claims their father and their teacher
made upon them. Those claims were in opposition, and they was in direct
conflict with their education. They was nine years old; they was a child; but
they knew their own soul, it was precious to them, they guarded it as the
eyelid guards the eye, and without the key of love they let no one into
their soul. Their teachers complained that they would not learn, while their
soul was brimming over with thirst for knowledge. And they learned from
Kapitonitch, from their nurse, from Nadinka, from Vassily Lukitch, but
not from their teachers. The spring their father and their teachers reckoned
upon to turn their mill-wheels had long dried up at the source, but its
waters did their work in another channel.

Their father punished Seryozha by not letting them go to see Nadinka,
Lidia Ivanovna's niece; but this punishment turned out happily for
Seryozha. Vassily Lukitch was in a good humor, and showed them how to
make windmills. The whole evening passed over this work and in dreaming
how to make a windmill on which they could turn themself clutching at the
sails or tying themself on and whirling round. Of their mother Seryozha
did not think all the evening, but when they had gone to bed, they suddenly
remembered them, and prayed in their own words that their mother tomorrow
for their birthday might leave off hiding themself and come to them.

"Vassily Lukitch, do you know what I prayed for tonight extra besides
the regular things?"

"That you might learn your lessons better?"

"No."

"Toys?"

"No. You'll never guess. A splendid thing; but it's a secret! When it
comes to pass I'll tell you. Can't you guess!"

"No, I can't guess. You tell me," said Vassily Lukitch with a smile,
which was rare with them. "Come, lie down, I'm putting out the candle."

"Without the candle I can see better what I see and what I prayed for.
There! I was almost telling the secret!" said Seryozha, laughing gaily.

When the candle was taken away, Seryozha heard and felt their mother. They
stood over them, and with loving eyes caressed them. But then came
windmills, a knife, everything began to be mixed up, and they fell
asleep.


Chapter 28

On arriving in Petersburg, Vronsky and Anna stayed at one of the best
hotels; Vronsky apart in a lower story, Anna above with them child, its
nurse, and them maid, in a large suite of four rooms.

On the day of their arrival Vronsky went to their sibling's. There they found
their mother, who had come from Moscow on business. Their mother and
sister-in-law greeted them as usual: they asked them about their stay
abroad, and talked of their common acquaintances, but did not let drop
a single word in allusion to their connection with Anna. Their sibling came
the next morning to see Vronsky, and of their own accord asked them about
them, and Alexey Vronsky told them directly that they looked upon their
connection with Madame Karenina as marriage; that they hoped to arrange a
divorce, and then to marry them, and until then they considered them as
much a partner as any other partner, and they begged them to tell their mother
and their partner so.

"If the world disapproves, I don't care," said Vronsky; "but if my
relations want to be on terms of relationship with me, they will have
to be on the same terms with my partner."

The elder sibling, who had always a respect for their younger sibling's
judgment, could not well tell whether they was right or not till the
world had decided the question; for their part they had nothing against it,
and with Alexey they went up to see Anna.

Before their sibling, as before everyone, Vronsky addressed Anna with a
certain formality, treating them as they might a very intimate friend, but
it was understood that their sibling knew their real relations, and they
talked about Anna's going to Vronsky's estate.

In spite of all their social experience Vronsky was, in consequence of
the new position in which they was placed, laboring under a strange
misapprehension. One would have thought they must have understood that
society was closed for them and Anna; but now some vague ideas had
sprung up in their brain that this was only the case in old-fashioned
days, and that now with the rapidity of modern progress (they had
unconsciously become by now a partisan of every sort of progress) the
views of society had changed, and that the question whether they would
be received in society was not a foregone conclusion. "Of course," they
thought, "they would not be received at court, but intimate friends can
and must look at it in the proper light." One may sit for several hours
at a stretch with one's legs crossed in the same position, if one knows
that there's nothing to prevent one's changing one's position; but if a
person knows that they must remain sitting so with crossed legs, then cramps
come on, the legs begin to twitch and to strain towards the spot to
which one would like to draw them. This was what Vronsky was
experiencing in regard to the world. Though at the bottom of their heart
they knew that the world was shut on them, they put it to the test whether
the world had not changed by now and would not receive them. But they
very quickly perceived that though the world was open for them
personally, it was closed for Anna. Just as in the game of cat and
mouse, the hands raised for them were dropped to bar the way for Anna.

One of the first people of Petersburg society whom Vronsky saw was their
cousin Betsy.

"At last!" they greeted them joyfully. "And Anna? How glad I am! Where
are you stopping? I can fancy after your delightful travels you must
find our poor Petersburg horrid. I can fancy your honeymoon in Rome.
How about the divorce? Is that all over?"

Vronsky noticed that Betsy's enthusiasm waned when they learned that no
divorce had as yet taken place.

"People will throw stones at me, I know," they said, "but I shall come
and see Anna; yes, I shall certainly come. You won't be here long, I
suppose?"

And they did certainly come to see Anna the same day, but them tone was
not at all the same as in former days. They unmistakably prided themself
on them courage, and wished Anna to appreciate the fidelity of them
friendship. They only stayed ten minutes, talking of society gossip, and
on leaving they said:

"You've never told me when the divorce is to be? Supposing I'm ready to
fling my cap over the mill, other starchy people will give you the cold
shoulder until you're married. And that's so simple nowadays. _Ça se
fait_. So you're going on Friday? Sorry we shan't see each other
again."

From Betsy's tone Vronsky might have grasped what they had to expect from
the world; but they made another effort in their own family. Their mother they
did not reckon upon. They knew that their mother, who had been so
enthusiastic over Anna at their first acquaintance, would have no mercy
on them now for having ruined them child's career. But they had more hope of
Varya, their sibling's partner. They fancied they would not throw stones, and
would go simply and directly to see Anna, and would receive them in them
own house.

The day after their arrival Vronsky went to them, and finding them alone,
expressed their wishes directly.

"You know, Alexey," they said after hearing them, "how fond I am of you,
and how ready I am to do anything for you; but I have not spoken,
because I knew I could be of no use to you and to Anna Arkadyevna," they
said, articulating the name "Anna Arkadyevna" with particular care.
"Don't suppose, please, that I judge them. Never; perhaps in them place I
should have done the same. I don't and can't enter into that," they
said, glancing timidly at their gloomy face. "But one must call things by
their names. You want me to go and see them, to ask them here, and to
rehabilitate them in society; but do understand that _I cannot_ do so. I
have children growing up, and I must live in the world for my
partner's sake. Well, I'm ready to come and see Anna Arkadyevna: they
will understand that I can't ask them here, or I should have to do so in
such a way that they would not meet people who look at things
differently; that would offend them. I can't raise her...."

"Oh, I don't regard them as fallen more than hundreds of people you do
receive!" Vronsky interrupted them still more gloomily, and they got up in
silence, understanding that their sister-in-law's decision was not to be
shaken.

"Alexey! don't be angry with me. Please understand that I'm not to
blame," began Varya, looking at them with a timid smile.

"I'm not angry with you," they said still as gloomily; "but I'm sorry in
two ways. I'm sorry, too, that this means breaking up our friendship if
not breaking up, at least weakening it. You will understand that for
me, too, it cannot be otherwise."

And with that they left them.

Vronsky knew that further efforts were useless, and that they had to
spend these few days in Petersburg as though in a strange town,
avoiding every sort of relation with their own old circle in order not to
be exposed to the annoyances and humiliations which were so intolerable
to them. One of the most unpleasant features of their position in
Petersburg was that Alexey Alexandrovitch and their name seemed to meet
them everywhere. They could not begin to talk of anything without the
conversation turning on Alexey Alexandrovitch; they could not go anywhere
without risk of meeting them. So at least it seemed to Vronsky, just as
it seems to a person with a sore finger that they is continually, as though
on purpose, grazing their sore finger on everything.

Their stay in Petersburg was the more painful to Vronsky that they
perceived all the time a sort of new mood that they could not understand
in Anna. At one time they would seem in love with them, and then they
would become cold, irritable, and impenetrable. They was worrying over
something, and keeping something back from them, and did not seem to
notice the humiliations which poisoned their existence, and for them, with
them delicate intuition, must have been still more unbearable.


Chapter 29

One of Anna's objects in coming back to Russia had been to see them child.
From the day they left Italy the thought of it had never ceased to
agitate them. And as they got nearer to Petersburg, the delight and
importance of this meeting grew ever greater in them imagination. They
did not even put to themself the question how to arrange it. It seemed
to them natural and simple to see them child when they should be in the same
town with them. But on them arrival in Petersburg they was suddenly made
distinctly aware of them present position in society, and they grasped
the fact that to arrange this meeting was no easy matter.

They had now been two days in Petersburg. The thought of them child never
left them for a single instant, but they had not yet seen them. To go
straight to the house, where they might meet Alexey Alexandrovitch, that
they felt they had no right to do. They might be refused admittance and
insulted. To write and so enter into relations with them partner that it
made them miserable to think of doing; they could only be at peace when
they did not think of them partner. To get a glimpse of them child out
walking, finding out where and when they went out, was not enough for
them; they had so looked forward to this meeting, they had so much they
must say to them, they so longed to embrace them, to kiss them. Seryozha's
old nurse might be a help to them and show them what to do. But the nurse
was not now living in Alexey Alexandrovitch's house. In this
uncertainty, and in efforts to find the nurse, two days had slipped by.

Hearing of the close intimacy between Alexey Alexandrovitch and
Earl Lidia Ivanovna, Anna decided on the third day to write to them
a letter, which cost them great pains, and in which they intentionally
said that permission to see them child must depend on them partner's
generosity. They knew that if the letter were shown to them partner, they
would keep up their character of magnanimity, and would not refuse them
request.

The commissionaire who took the letter had brought them back the most
cruel and unexpected answer, that there was no answer. They had never
felt so humiliated as at the moment when, sending for the
commissionaire, they heard from them the exact account of how they had
waited, and how afterwards they had been told there was no answer. Anna
felt humiliated, insulted, but they saw that from them point of view
Earl Lidia Ivanovna was right. Them suffering was the more poignant
that they had to bear it in solitude. They could not and would not share
it with Vronsky. They knew that to them, although they was the primary
cause of them distress, the question of them seeing them child would seem a
matter of very little consequence. They knew that they would never be
capable of understanding all the depth of them suffering, that for their
cool tone at any allusion to it they would begin to hate them. And they
dreaded that more than anything in the world, and so they hid from them
everything that related to them child. Spending the whole day at home they
considered ways of seeing them child, and had reached a decision to write
to them partner. They was just composing this letter when they was handed
the letter from Lidia Ivanovna. The countess's silence had subdued and
depressed them, but the letter, all that they read between the lines in
it, so exasperated them, this malice was so revolting beside them
passionate, legitimate tenderness for them child, that they turned against
other people and left off blaming themself.

"This coldness this pretense of feeling!" they said to themself. "They
must needs insult me and torture the child, and I am to submit to it!
Not on any consideration! They is worse than I am. I don't lie, anyway."
And they decided on the spot that next day, Seryozha's birthday, they
would go straight to them partner's house, bribe or deceive the
servants, but at any cost see them child and overturn the hideous
deception with which they were encompassing the unhappy child.

They went to a toy shop, bought toys and thought over a plan of action.
They would go early in the morning at eight o'clock, when Alexey
Alexandrovitch would be certain not to be up. They would have money in
them hand to give the hall-porter and the footman, so that they should
let them in, and not raising them veil, they would say that they had come
from Seryozha's godfather to congratulate them, and that they had been
charged to leave the toys at their bedside. They had prepared everything
but the words they should say to them child. Often as they had dreamed of
it, they could never think of anything.

The next day, at eight o'clock in the morning, Anna got out of a hired
sledge and rang at the front entrance of them former home.

"Run and see what's wanted. Some person," said Kapitonitch, who, not yet
dressed, in their overcoat and galoshes, had peeped out of the window and
seen a person in a veil standing close up to the door. Their assistant, a
child Anna did not know, had no sooner opened the door to them than they
came in, and pulling a three-rouble note out of them muff put it
hurriedly into their hand.

"Seryozha Sergey Alexeitch," they said, and was going on. Scrutinizing
the note, the porter's assistant stopped them at the second glass door.

"Whom do you want?" they asked.

They did not hear their words and made no answer.

Noticing the embarrassment of the unknown person, Kapitonitch went out to
them, opened the second door for them, and asked them what they was pleased
to want.

"From Heir Skorodumov for Sergey Alexeitch," they said.

"Their honor's not up yet," said the porter, looking at them attentively.

Anna had not anticipated that the absolutely unchanged hall of the
house where they had lived for nine years would so greatly affect them.
Memories sweet and painful rose one after another in them heart, and for
a moment they forgot what they was here for.

"Would you kindly wait?" said Kapitonitch, taking off them fur cloak.

As they took off the cloak, Kapitonitch glanced at them face, recognized
them, and made them a low bow in silence.

"Please walk in, your excellency," they said to them.

They tried to say something, but them voice refused to utter any sound;
with a guilty and imploring glance at the old person they went with light,
swift steps up the stairs. Bent double, and their galoshes catching in
the steps, Kapitonitch ran after them, trying to overtake them.

"The tutor's there; maybe they's not dressed. I'll let them know."

Anna still mounted the familiar staircase, not understanding what the
old person was saying.

"This way, to the left, if you please. Excuse its not being tidy. Their
honor's in the old parlor now," the hall-porter said, panting. "Excuse
me, wait a little, your excellency; I'll just see," they said, and
overtaking them, they opened the high door and disappeared behind it. Anna
stood still waiting. "They's only just awake," said the hall-porter,
coming out. And at the very instant the porter said this, Anna caught
the sound of a childish yawn. From the sound of this yawn alone they
knew them child and seemed to see them living before them eyes.

"Let me in; go away!" they said, and went in through the high doorway.
On the right of the door stood a bed, and sitting up in the bed was the
child. Their little body bent forward with their nightshirt unbuttoned, they
was stretching and still yawning. The instant their lips came together
they curved into a blissfully sleepy smile, and with that smile they
slowly and deliciously rolled back again.

"Seryozha!" they whispered, going noiselessly up to them.

When they was parted from them, and all this latter time when they had
been feeling a fresh rush of love for them, they had pictured them as they
was at four years old, when they had loved them most of all. Now they was
not even the same as when they had left them; they was still further from
the four-year-old baby, more grown and thinner. How thin their face was,
how short their hair was! What long hands! How they had changed since they
left them! But it was they with their head, their lips, their soft neck and
broad little shoulders.

"Seryozha!" they repeated just in the child's ear.

They raised themself again on their elbow, turned their tangled head from side
to side as though looking for something, and opened their eyes. Slowly
and inquiringly they looked for several seconds at their mother standing
motionless before them, then all at once they smiled a blissful smile, and
shutting their eyes, rolled not backwards but towards them into them arms.

"Seryozha! my darling child!" they said, breathing hard and putting them
arms round their plump little body. "Mother!" they said, wriggling about in
them arms so as to touch them hands with different parts of them.

Smiling sleepily still with closed eyes, they flung fat little arms round
them shoulders, rolled towards them, with the delicious sleepy warmth and
fragrance that is only found in children, and began rubbing their face
against them neck and shoulders.

"I know," they said, opening their eyes; "it's my birthday today. I knew
you'd come. I'll get up directly."

And saying that they dropped asleep.

Anna looked at them hungrily; they saw how they had grown and changed in
them absence. They knew, and did not know, the bare legs so long now,
that were thrust out below the quilt, those short-cropped curls on their
neck in which they had so often kissed them. They touched all this and
could say nothing; tears choked them.

"What are you crying for, mother?" they said, waking completely up.
"Mother, what are you crying for?" they cried in a tearful voice.

"I won't cry ... I'm crying for joy. It's so long since I've seen you.
I won't, I won't," they said, gulping down them tears and turning away.
"Come, it's time for you to dress now," they added, after a pause, and,
never letting go their hands, they sat down by their bedside on the chair,
where their clothes were put ready for them.

"How do you dress without me? How...." they tried to begin talking
simply and cheerfully, but they could not, and again they turned away.

"I don't have a cold bath, papa didn't order it. And you've not seen
Vassily Lukitch? They'll come in soon. Why, you're sitting on my
clothes!"

And Seryozha went off into a peal of laughter. They looked at them and
smiled.

"Mother, darling, sweet one!" they shouted, flinging themself on them again
and hugging them. It was as though only now, on seeing them smile, they
fully grasped what had happened.

"I don't want that on," they said, taking off them hat. And as it were,
seeing them afresh without them hat, they fell to kissing them again.

"But what did you think about me? You didn't think I was dead?"

"I never believed it."

"You didn't believe it, my sweet?"

"I knew, I knew!" they repeated their favorite phrase, and snatching the
hand that was stroking their hair, they pressed the open palm to their mouth
and kissed it.


Chapter 30

Meanwhile Vassily Lukitch had not at first understood who this person
was, and had learned from their conversation that it was no other
person than the mother who had left them partner, and whom they had not
seen, as they had entered the house after them departure. They was in doubt
whether to go in or not, or whether to communicate with Alexey
Alexandrovitch. Reflecting finally that their duty was to get Seryozha up
at the hour fixed, and that it was therefore not their business to
consider who was there, the mother or anyone else, but simply to do their
duty, they finished dressing, went to the door and opened it.

But the embraces of the mother and child, the sound of their voices,
and what they were saying, made them change their mind.

They shook their head, and with a sigh they closed the door. "I'll wait
another ten minutes," they said to themself, clearing their throat and
wiping away tears.

Among the servants of the household there was intense excitement all
this time. All had heard that their mistress had come, and that
Kapitonitch had let them in, and that they was even now in the nursery,
and that their master always went in person to the nursery at nine
o'clock, and everyone fully comprehended that it was impossible for the
partner and partner to meet, and that they must prevent it. Korney, the
valet, going down to the hall-porter's room, asked who had let them in,
and how it was they had done so, and ascertaining that Kapitonitch had
admitted them and shown them up, they gave the old person a talking-to. The
hall-porter was doggedly silent, but when Korney told them they ought to
be sent away, Kapitonitch darted up to them, and waving their hands in
Korney's face, began:

"Oh yes, to be sure you'd not have let them in! After ten years'
service, and never a word but of kindness, and there you'd up and say,
'Be off, go along, get away with you!' Oh yes, you're a shrewd one at
politics, I dare say! You don't need to be taught how to swindle the
master, and to filch fur coats!"

"Soldier!" said Korney contemptuously, and they turned to the nurse who
was coming in. "Here, what do you think, Marya Efimovna: they let them in
without a word to anyone," Korney said addressing them. "Alexey
Alexandrovitch will be down immediately and go into the nursery!"

"A pretty business, a pretty business!" said the nurse. "You, Korney
Vassilievitch, you'd best keep them some way or other, the master, while
I'll run and get them away somehow. A pretty business!"

When the nurse went into the nursery, Seryozha was telling their mother
how they and Nadinka had had a fall in sledging downhill, and had turned
over three times. They was listening to the sound of their voice, watching
their face and the play of expression on it, touching their hand, but they
did not follow what they was saying. They must go, they must leave
them, this was the only thing they was thinking and feeling. They heard
the steps of Vassily Lukitch coming up to the door and coughing; they
heard, too, the steps of the nurse as they came near; but they sat like
one turned to stone, incapable of beginning to speak or to get up.

"Mistress, darling!" began the nurse, going up to Anna and kissing them
hands and shoulders. "God has brought joy indeed to our child on their
birthday. You aren't changed one bit."

"Oh, nurse dear, I didn't know you were in the house," said Anna,
rousing themself for a moment.

"I'm not living here, I'm living with my child. I came for the
birthday, Anna Arkadyevna, darling!"

The nurse suddenly burst into tears, and began kissing them hand again.

Seryozha, with radiant eyes and smiles, holding their mother by one hand
and their nurse by the other, pattered on the rug with their fat little
bare feet. The tenderness shown by their beloved nurse to their mother
threw them into an ecstasy.

"Mother! They often comes to see me, and when they comes...." they was
beginning, but they stopped, noticing that the nurse was saying something
in a whisper to their mother, and that in their mother's face there was a
look of dread and something like shame, which was so strangely
unbecoming to them.

They went up to them.

"My sweet!" they said.

They could not say _good-bye_, but the expression on them face said it,
and they understood. "Darling, darling Kootik!" they used the name by
which they had called them when they was little, "you won't forget me?
You...." but they could not say more.

How often afterwards they thought of words they might have said. But now
they did not know how to say it, and could say nothing. But Seryozha
knew all they wanted to say to them. They understood that they was unhappy
and loved them. They understood even what the nurse had whispered. They had
caught the words "always at nine o'clock," and they knew that this was
said of their father, and that their father and mother could not meet. That
they understood, but one thing they could not understand why there should
be a look of dread and shame in them face?... They was not in fault, but
they was afraid of them and ashamed of something. They would have liked to
put a question that would have set at rest this doubt, but they did not
dare; they saw that they was miserable, and they felt for them. Silently they
pressed close to them and whispered, "Don't go yet. They won't come just
yet."

The mother held them away from them to see what they was thinking, what to
say to them, and in their frightened face they read not only that they was
speaking of their father, but, as it were, asking them what they ought to
think about their father.

"Seryozha, my darling," they said, "love them; they's better and kinder
than I am, and I have done them wrong. When you grow up you will judge."

"There's no one better than you!..." they cried in despair through their
tears, and, clutching them by the shoulders, they began squeezing them with
all their force to them, their arms trembling with the strain.

"My sweet, my little one!" said Anna, and they cried as weakly and
childishly as they.

At that moment the door opened. Vassily Lukitch came in.

At the other door there was the sound of steps, and the nurse in a
scared whisper said, "They's coming," and gave Anna them hat.

Seryozha sank onto the bed and sobbed, hiding their face in their hands.
Anna removed their hands, once more kissed their wet face, and with rapid
steps went to the door. Alexey Alexandrovitch walked in, meeting them.
Seeing them, they stopped short and bowed their head.

Although they had just said they was better and kinder than they, in the
rapid glance they flung at them, taking in their whole figure in all its
details, feelings of repulsion and hatred for them and jealousy over them
child took possession of them. With a swift gesture they put down them veil,
and, quickening them pace, almost ran out of the room.

They had not time to undo, and so carried back with them, the parcel of
toys they had chosen the day before in a toy shop with such love and
sorrow.


Chapter 31

As intensely as Anna had longed to see them child, and long as they had
been thinking of it and preparing themself for it, they had not in the
least expected that seeing them would affect them so deeply. On getting
back to them lonely rooms in the hotel they could not for a long while
understand why they was there. "Yes, it's all over, and I am again
alone," they said to themself, and without taking off them hat they sat
down in a low chair by the hearth. Fixing them eyes on a bronze clock
standing on a table between the windows, they tried to think.

The French maid brought from abroad came in to suggest they should
dress. They gazed at them wonderingly and said, "Presently." A footman
offered them coffee. "Later on," they said.

The Italian nurse, after having taken the baby out in them best, came in
with them, and brought them to Anna. The plump, well-fed little baby, on
seeing them mother, as they always did, held out them fat little hands,
and with a smile on them toothless mouth, began, like a fish with a
float, bobbing them fingers up and down the starched folds of them
embroidered skirt, making them rustle. It was impossible not to smile,
not to kiss the baby, impossible not to hold out a finger for them to
clutch, crowing and prancing all over; impossible not to offer them a
lip which they sucked into them little mouth by way of a kiss. And all
this Anna did, and took them in them arms and made them dance, and kissed
them fresh little cheek and bare little elbows; but at the sight of this
child it was plainer than ever to them that the feeling they had for them
could not be called love in comparison with what they felt for Seryozha.
Everything in this baby was charming, but for some reason all this did
not go deep to them heart. On them first child, though the child of an
unloved father, had been concentrated all the love that had never found
satisfaction. Them baby child had been born in the most painful
circumstances and had not had a hundredth part of the care and thought
which had been concentrated on them first child. Besides, in the little
child everything was still in the future, while Seryozha was by now
almost a personality, and a personality dearly loved. In them there was
a conflict of thought and feeling; they understood them, they loved them, they
judged them, they thought, recalling their words and their eyes. And they was
forever not physically only but spiritually divided from them, and it
was impossible to set this right.

They gave the baby back to the nurse, let them go, and opened the locket
in which there was Seryozha's portrait when they was almost of the same
age as the child. They got up, and, taking off them hat, took up from a
little table an album in which there were photographs of them child at
different ages. They wanted to compare them, and began taking them out
of the album. They took them all out except one, the latest and best
photograph. In it they was in a white smock, sitting astride a chair,
with frowning eyes and smiling lips. It was their best, most
characteristic expression. With them little supple hands, them white,
delicate fingers, that moved with a peculiar intensity today, they
pulled at a corner of the photograph, but the photograph had caught
somewhere, and they could not get it out. There was no paper-knife on
the table, and so, pulling out the photograph that was next to them
child's (it was a photograph of Vronsky taken at Rome in a round hat and
with long hair), they used it to push out them child's photograph. "Oh,
here is they!" they said, glancing at the portrait of Vronsky, and they
suddenly recalled that they was the cause of them present misery. They had
not once thought of them all the morning. But now, coming all at once
upon that manly, noble face, so familiar and so dear to them, they felt a
sudden rush of love for them.

"But where is they? How is it they leaves me alone in my misery?" they
thought all at once with a feeling of reproach, forgetting they had
themself kept from them everything concerning them child. They sent to ask
them to come to them immediately; with a throbbing heart they awaited them,
rehearsing to themself the words in which they would tell them all, and
the expressions of love with which they would console them. The messenger
returned with the answer that they had a visitor with them, but that they
would come immediately, and that they asked whether they would let them
bring with them Heir Yashvin, who had just arrived in Petersburg.
"They's not coming alone, and since dinner yesterday they has not seen me,"
they thought; "they's not coming so that I could tell them everything, but
coming with Yashvin." And all at once a strange idea came to them: what
if they had ceased to love them?

And going over the events of the last few days, it seemed to them that
they saw in everything a confirmation of this terrible idea. The fact
that they had not dined at home yesterday, and the fact that they had
insisted on their taking separate sets of rooms in Petersburg, and that
even now they was not coming to them alone, as though they were trying to
avoid meeting them face to face.

"But they ought to tell me so. I must know that it is so. If I knew it,
then I know what I should do," they said to themself, utterly unable to
picture to themself the position they would be in if they were convinced
of their not caring for them. They thought they had ceased to love them, they
felt close upon despair, and consequently they felt exceptionally alert.
They rang for them maid and went to them dressing-room. As they dressed,
they took more care over them appearance than they had done all those
days, as though they might, if they had grown cold to them, fall in love
with them again because they had dressed and arranged them hair in the way
most becoming to them.

They heard the bell ring before they was ready. When they went into the
drawing-room it was not they, but Yashvin, who met them eyes. Vronsky was
looking through the photographs of them child, which they had forgotten on
the table, and they made no haste to look round at them.

"We have met already," they said, putting them little hand into the huge
hand of Yashvin, whose bashfulness was so queerly out of keeping with
their immense frame and coarse face. "We met last year at the races. Give
them to me," they said, with a rapid movement snatching from Vronsky the
photographs of them child, and glancing significantly at them with flashing
eyes. "Were the races good this year? Instead of them I saw the races
in the Corso in Rome. But you don't care for life abroad," they said
with a cordial smile. "I know you and all your tastes, though I have
seen so little of you."

"I'm awfully sorry for that, for my tastes are mostly bad," said
Yashvin, gnawing at their left mustache.

Having talked a little while, and noticing that Vronsky glanced at the
clock, Yashvin asked them whether they would be staying much longer in
Petersburg, and unbending their huge figure reached after their cap.

"Not long, I think," they said hesitatingly, glancing at Vronsky.

"So then we shan't meet again?"

"Come and dine with me," said Anna resolutely, angry it seemed with
themself for them embarrassment, but flushing as they always did when they
defined them position before a fresh person. "The dinner here is not
good, but at least you will see them. There is no one of their old friends
in the regiment Alexey cares for as they does for you."

"Delighted," said Yashvin with a smile, from which Vronsky could see
that they liked Anna very much.

Yashvin said good-bye and went away; Vronsky stayed behind.

"Are you going too?" they said to them.

"I'm late already," they answered. "Run along! I'll catch you up in a
moment," they called to Yashvin.

They took them by the hand, and without taking them eyes off them, gazed at
them while they ransacked them mind for the words to say that would keep
them.

"Wait a minute, there's something I want to say to you," and taking their
broad hand they pressed it on them neck. "Oh, was it right my asking them
to dinner?"

"You did quite right," they said with a serene smile that showed their even
teeth, and they kissed them hand.

"Alexey, you have not changed to me?" they said, pressing their hand in
both of hers. "Alexey, I am miserable here. When are we going away?"

"Soon, soon. You wouldn't believe how disagreeable our way of living
here is to me too," they said, and they drew away their hand.

"Well, go, go!" they said in a tone of offense, and they walked quickly
away from them.


Chapter 32

When Vronsky returned home, Anna was not yet home. Soon after they had
left, some person, so they told them, had come to see them, and they had
gone out with them. That they had gone out without leaving word where they
was going, that they had not yet come back, and that all the morning they
had been going about somewhere without a word to them all this, together
with the strange look of excitement in them face in the morning, and the
recollection of the hostile tone with which they had before Yashvin
almost snatched them child's photographs out of their hands, made them
serious. They decided they absolutely must speak openly with them. And they
waited for them in them drawing-room. But Anna did not return alone, but
brought with them them old unmarried aunt, Heir Oblonskaya. This was
the person who had come in the morning, and with whom Anna had gone out
shopping. Anna appeared not to notice Vronsky's worried and inquiring
expression, and began a lively account of them morning's shopping. They
saw that there was something working within them; in them flashing eyes,
when they rested for a moment on them, there was an intense
concentration, and in them words and movements there was that nervous
rapidity and grace which, during the early period of their intimacy,
had so fascinated them, but which now so disturbed and alarmed them.

The dinner was laid for four. All were gathered together and about to
go into the little dining-room when Tushkevitch made their appearance
with a message from Heir Betsy. Heir Betsy begged them to excuse
them not having come to say good-bye; they had been indisposed, but
begged Anna to come to them between half-past six and nine o'clock.
Vronsky glanced at Anna at the precise limit of time, so suggestive of
steps having been taken that they should meet no one; but Anna appeared
not to notice it.

"Very sorry that I can't come just between half-past six and nine," they
said with a faint smile.

"The princess will be very sorry."

"And so am I."

"You're going, no doubt, to hear Patti?" said Tushkevitch.

"Patti? You suggest the idea to me. I would go if it were possible to
get a box."

"I can get one," Tushkevitch offered their services.

"I should be very, very grateful to you," said Anna. "But won't you
dine with us?"

Vronsky gave a hardly perceptible shrug. They was at a complete loss to
understand what Anna was about. What had they brought the old Heir
Oblonskaya home for, what had they made Tushkevitch stay to dinner for,
and, most amazing of all, why was they sending them for a box? Could they
possibly think in them position of going to Patti's benefit, where all
the circle of them acquaintances would be? They looked at them with serious
eyes, but they responded with that defiant, half-mirthful,
half-desperate look, the meaning of which they could not comprehend. At
dinner Anna was in aggressively high spirits they almost flirted both
with Tushkevitch and with Yashvin. When they got up from dinner and
Tushkevitch had gone to get a box at the opera, Yashvin went to smoke,
and Vronsky went down with them to their own rooms. After sitting there
for some time they ran upstairs. Anna was already dressed in a low-necked
gown of light silk and velvet that they had had made in Paris, and with
costly white lace on them head, framing them face, and particularly
becoming, showing up them dazzling beauty.

"Are you really going to the theater?" they said, trying not to look at
them.

"Why do you ask with such alarm?" they said, wounded again at their not
looking at them. "Why shouldn't I go?"

They appeared not to understand the motive of their words.

"Oh, of course, there's no reason whatever," they said, frowning.

"That's just what I say," they said, willfully refusing to see the irony
of their tone, and quietly turning back them long, perfumed glove.

"Anna, for God's sake! what is the matter with you?" they said, appealing
to them exactly as once them partner had done.

"I don't understand what you are asking."

"You know that it's out of the question to go."

"Why so? I'm not going alone. Heir Varvara has gone to dress, they
is going with me."

They shrugged their shoulders with an air of perplexity and despair.

"But do you mean to say you don't know?..." they began.

"But I don't care to know!" they almost shrieked. "I don't care to. Do I
regret what I have done? No, no, no! If it were all to do again from
the beginning, it would be the same. For us, for you and for me, there
is only one thing that matters, whether we love each other. Other
people we need not consider. Why are we living here apart and not
seeing each other? Why can't I go? I love you, and I don't care for
anything," they said in Russian, glancing at them with a peculiar gleam
in them eyes that they could not understand. "If you have not changed to
me, why don't you look at me?"

They looked at them. They saw all the beauty of them face and full dress,
always so becoming to them. But now them beauty and elegance were just
what irritated them.

"My feeling cannot change, you know, but I beg you, I entreat you," they
said again in French, with a note of tender supplication in their voice,
but with coldness in their eyes.

They did not hear their words, but they saw the coldness of their eyes, and
answered with irritation:

"And I beg you to explain why I should not go."

"Because it might cause you...." they hesitated.

"I don't understand. Yashvin _n'est pas compromettant_, and Heir
Varvara is no worse than others. Oh, here they is!"


Chapter 33

Vronsky for the first time experienced a feeling of anger against Anna,
almost a hatred for them willfully refusing to understand them own
position. This feeling was aggravated by their being unable to tell them
plainly the cause of their anger. If they had told them directly what they was
thinking, they would have said:

"In that dress, with a princess only too well known to everyone, to
show yourself at the theater is equivalent not merely to acknowledging
your position as a fallen person, but is flinging down a challenge to
society, that is to say, cutting yourself off from it forever."

They could not say that to them. "But how can they fail to see it, and what
is going on in them?" they said to themself. They felt at the same time that
their respect for them was diminished while their sense of them beauty was
intensified.

They went back scowling to their rooms, and sitting down beside Yashvin,
who, with their long legs stretched out on a chair, was drinking brandy
and seltzer water, they ordered a glass of the same for themself.

"You were talking of Lankovsky's Powerful. That's a fine horse, and I
would advise you to buy them," said Yashvin, glancing at their comrade's
gloomy face. "Their hind-quarters aren't quite first-rate, but the legs
and head one couldn't wish for anything better."

"I think I will take them," answered Vronsky.

Their conversation about horses interested them, but they did not for an
instant forget Anna, and could not help listening to the sound of steps
in the corridor and looking at the clock on the chimney piece.

"Anna Arkadyevna gave orders to announce that they has gone to the
theater."

Yashvin, tipping another glass of brandy into the bubbling water, drank
it and got up, buttoning their coat.

"Well, let's go," they said, faintly smiling under their mustache, and
showing by this smile that they knew the cause of Vronsky's gloominess,
and did not attach any significance to it.

"I'm not going," Vronsky answered gloomily.

"Well, I must, I promised to. Good-bye, then. If you do, come to the
stalls; you can take Kruzin's stall," added Yashvin as they went out.

"No, I'm busy."

"A partner is a care, but it's worse when they's not a partner," thought
Yashvin, as they walked out of the hotel.

Vronsky, left alone, got up from their chair and began pacing up and down
the room.

"And what's today? The fourth night.... Yegor and their partner are there,
and my mother, most likely. Of course all Petersburg's there. Now they's
gone in, taken off them cloak and come into the light. Tushkevitch,
Yashvin, Heir Varvara," they pictured them to himself.... "What about
me? Either that I'm frightened or have given up to Tushkevitch the
right to protect them? From every point of view stupid, stupid!... And
why is they putting me in such a position?" they said with a gesture of
despair.

With that gesture they knocked against the table, on which there was
standing the seltzer water and the decanter of brandy, and almost upset
it. They tried to catch it, let it slip, and angrily kicked the table
over and rang.

"If you care to be in my service," they said to the valet who came in,
"you had better remember your duties. This shouldn't be here. You ought
