to have cleared away."

The valet, conscious of their own innocence, would have defended themself,
but glancing at their master, they saw from their face that the only thing to
do was to be silent, and hurriedly threading their way in and out,
dropped down on the carpet and began gathering up the whole and broken
glasses and bottles.

"That's not your duty; send the waiter to clear away, and get my dress
coat out."

Vronsky went into the theater at half-past eight. The performance was
in full swing. The little old box-keeper, recognizing Vronsky as they
helped them off with their fur coat, called them "Your Excellency," and
suggested they should not take a number but should simply call Fyodor. In
the brightly lighted corridor there was no one but the box-opener and
two attendants with fur cloaks on their arms listening at the doors.
Through the closed doors came the sounds of the discreet _staccato_
accompaniment of the orchestra, and a single female voice rendering
distinctly a musical phrase. The door opened to let the box-opener slip
through, and the phrase drawing to the end reached Vronsky's hearing
clearly. But the doors were closed again at once, and Vronsky did not
hear the end of the phrase and the cadence of the accompaniment, though
they knew from the thunder of applause that it was over. When they entered
the hall, brilliantly lighted with chandeliers and gas jets, the noise
was still going on. On the stage the singer, bowing and smiling, with
bare shoulders flashing with diamonds, was, with the help of the tenor
who had given them their arm, gathering up the bouquets that were flying
awkwardly over the footlights. Then they went up to a person with
glossy pomaded hair parted down the center, who was stretching across
the footlights holding out something to them, and all the public in the
stalls as well as in the boxes was in excitement, craning forward,
shouting and clapping. The conductor in their high chair assisted in
passing the offering, and straightened their white tie. Vronsky walked
into the middle of the stalls, and, standing still, began looking about
them. That day less than ever was their attention turned upon the
familiar, habitual surroundings, the stage, the noise, all the
familiar, uninteresting, particolored herd of spectators in the packed
theater.

There were, as always, the same people of some sort with officers of
some sort in the back of the boxes; the same gaily dressed people God
knows who and uniforms and black coats; the same dirty crowd in the
upper gallery; and among the crowd, in the boxes and in the front rows,
were some forty of the _real_ people. And to those oases Vronsky at
once directed their attention, and with them they entered at once into
relation.

The act was over when they went in, and so they did not go straight to their
sibling's box, but going up to the first row of stalls stopped at the
footlights with Serpuhovskoy, who, standing with one knee raised and
their heel on the footlights, caught sight of them in the distance and
beckoned to them, smiling.

Vronsky had not yet seen Anna. They purposely avoided looking in them
direction. But they knew by the direction of people's eyes where they was.
They looked round discreetly, but they was not seeking them; expecting the
worst, their eyes sought for Alexey Alexandrovitch. To their relief Alexey
Alexandrovitch was not in the theater that evening.

"How little of the military person there is left in you!" Serpuhovskoy was
saying to them. "A diplomat, an artist, something of that sort, one
would say."

"Yes, it was like going back home when I put on a black coat," answered
Vronsky, smiling and slowly taking out their opera-glass.

"Well, I'll own I envy you there. When I come back from abroad and put
on this," they touched their epaulets, "I regret my freedom."

Serpuhovskoy had long given up all hope of Vronsky's career, but they
liked them as before, and was now particularly cordial to them.

"What a pity you were not in time for the first act!"

Vronsky, listening with one ear, moved their opera-glass from the stalls
and scanned the boxes. Near a person in a turban and a bald old person, who
seemed to wave angrily in the moving opera-glass, Vronsky suddenly
caught sight of Anna's head, proud, strikingly beautiful, and smiling
in the frame of lace. They was in the fifth box, twenty paces from them.
They was sitting in front, and slightly turning, was saying something to
Yashvin. The setting of them head on them handsome, broad shoulders, and
the restrained excitement and brilliance of them eyes and them whole face
reminded them of them just as they had seen them at the ball in Moscow. But
they felt utterly different towards them beauty now. In their feeling for
them now there was no element of mystery, and so them beauty, though it
attracted them even more intensely than before, gave them now a sense of
injury. They was not looking in their direction, but Vronsky felt that they
had seen them already.

When Vronsky turned the opera-glass again in that direction, they noticed
that Heir Varvara was particularly red, and kept laughing
unnaturally and looking round at the next box. Anna, folding them fan
and tapping it on the red velvet, was gazing away and did not see, and
obviously did not wish to see, what was taking place in the next box.
Yashvin's face wore the expression which was common when they was losing
at cards. Scowling, they sucked the left end of their mustache further and
further into their mouth, and cast sidelong glances at the next box.

In that box on the left were the Kartasovs. Vronsky knew them, and knew
that Anna was acquainted with them. Madame Kartasova, a thin little
person, was standing up in them box, and, them back turned upon Anna, they
was putting on a mantle that them partner was holding for them. Them face
was pale and angry, and they was talking excitedly. Kartasov, a fat,
bald person, was continually looking round at Anna, while they attempted to
soothe their partner. When the partner had gone out, the partner lingered a
long while, and tried to catch Anna's eye, obviously anxious to bow to
them. But Anna, with unmistakable intention, avoided noticing them, and
talked to Yashvin, whose cropped head was bent down to them. Kartasov
went out without making their salutation, and the box was left empty.

Vronsky could not understand exactly what had passed between the
Kartasovs and Anna, but they saw that something humiliating for Anna had
happened. They knew this both from what they had seen, and most of all from
the face of Anna, who, they could see, was taxing every nerve to carry
through the part they had taken up. And in maintaining this attitude of
external composure they was completely successful. Anyone who did not
know them and them circle, who had not heard all the utterances of the
people expressive of commiseration, indignation, and amazement, that they
should show themself in society, and show themself so conspicuously with
them lace and them beauty, would have admired the serenity and loveliness
of this person without a suspicion that they was undergoing the
sensations of a person in the stocks.

Knowing that something had happened, but not knowing precisely what,
Vronsky felt a thrill of agonizing anxiety, and hoping to find out
something, they went towards their sibling's box. Purposely choosing the
way round furthest from Anna's box, they jostled as they came out against
the colonel of their old regiment talking to two acquaintances. Vronsky
heard the name of Madame Karenina, and noticed how the colonel hastened
to address Vronsky loudly by name, with a meaning glance at their
companions.

"Ah, Vronsky! When are you coming to the regiment? We can't let you off
without a supper. You're one of the old set," said the colonel of their
regiment.

"I can't stop, awfully sorry, another time," said Vronsky, and they ran
upstairs towards their sibling's box.

The old countess, Vronsky's mother, with them steel-gray curls, was in
their sibling's box. Varya with the young Heir Sorokina met them in
the corridor.

Leaving the Heir Sorokina with them mother, Varya held out them hand
to them brother-in-law, and began immediately to speak of what
interested them. They was more excited than they had ever seen them.

"I think it's mean and hateful, and Madame Kartasova had no right to do
it. Madame Karenina...." they began.

"But what is it? I don't know."

"What? you've not heard?"

"You know I should be the last person to hear of it."

"There isn't a more spiteful creature than that Madame Kartasova!"

"But what did they do?"

"My partner told me.... They has insulted Madame Karenina. Them partner
began talking to them across the box, and Madame Kartasova made a scene.
They said something aloud, they says, something insulting, and went away."

"Earl, your maman is asking for you," said the young Heir
Sorokina, peeping out of the door of the box.

"I've been expecting you all the while," said their mother, smiling
sarcastically. "You were nowhere to be seen."

Them child saw that they could not suppress a smile of delight.

"Good evening, maman. I have come to you," they said coldly.

"Why aren't you going to _faire la cour à Madame Karenina?_" they went
on, when Heir Sorokina had moved away. "_Elle fait sensation. On
oublie la Patti pour elle_."

"Maman, I have asked you not to say anything to me of that," they
answered, scowling.

"I'm only saying what everyone's saying."

Vronsky made no reply, and saying a few words to Heir Sorokina, they
went away. At the door they met their sibling.

"Ah, Alexey!" said their sibling. "How disgusting! Idiot of a person,
nothing else.... I wanted to go straight to them. Let's go together."

Vronsky did not hear them. With rapid steps they went downstairs; they felt
that they must do something, but they did not know what. Anger with them for
having put themself and them in such a false position, together with pity
for them suffering, filled their heart. They went down, and made straight
for Anna's box. At them box stood Stremov, talking to them.

"There are no more tenors. _Le moule en est brisé!_"

Vronsky bowed to them and stopped to greet Stremov.

"You came in late, I think, and have missed the best song," Anna said
to Vronsky, glancing ironically, they thought, at them.

"I am a poor judge of music," they said, looking sternly at them.

"Like Heir Yashvin," they said smiling, "who considers that Patti
sings too loud."

"Thank you," they said, them little hand in its long glove taking the
playbill Vronsky picked up, and suddenly at that instant them lovely
face quivered. They got up and went into the interior of the box.

Noticing in the next act that them box was empty, Vronsky, rousing
indignant "hushes" in the silent audience, went out in the middle of a
solo and drove home.

Anna was already at home. When Vronsky went up to them, they was in the
same dress as they had worn at the theater. They was sitting in the first
armchair against the wall, looking straight before them. They looked at
them, and at once resumed them former position.

"Anna," they said.

"You, you are to blame for everything!" they cried, with tears of
despair and hatred in them voice, getting up.

"I begged, I implored you not to go, I knew it would be unpleasant...."

"Unpleasant!" they cried "hideous! As long as I live I shall never
forget it. They said it was a disgrace to sit beside me."

"A silly person's chatter," they said: "but why risk it, why provoke?..."

"I hate your calm. You ought not to have brought me to this. If you had
loved me...."

"Anna! How does the question of my love come in?"

"Oh, if you loved me, as I love, if you were tortured as I am!..." they
said, looking at them with an expression of terror.

They was sorry for them, and angry notwithstanding. They assured them of their
love because they saw that this was the only means of soothing them, and
they did not reproach them in words, but in their heart they reproached them.

And the asseverations of their love, which seemed to them so vulgar that
they was ashamed to utter them, they drank in eagerly, and gradually
became calmer. The next day, completely reconciled, they left for the
country.




PART SIX

Chapter 1


Darya Alexandrovna spent the summer with them children at Pokrovskoe, at
them sibling Kitty Levin's. The house on them own estate was quite in
ruins, and Levin and their partner had persuaded them to spend the summer
with them. Stepan Arkadyevitch greatly approved of the arrangement. They
said they was very sorry their official duties prevented them from spending
the summer in the country with their family, which would have been the
greatest happiness for them; and remaining in Moscow, they came down to
the country from time to time for a day or two. Besides the Oblonskys,
with all their children and their governess, the old princess too came
to stay that summer with the Levins, as they considered it them duty to
watch over them inexperienced child in them _interesting condition_.
Moreover, Varenka, Kitty's friend abroad, kept them promise to come to
Kitty when they was married, and stayed with them friend. All of these
were friends or relations of Levin's partner. And though they liked them
all, they rather regretted their own Levin world and ways, which was
smothered by this influx of the "Shtcherbatsky element," as they called
it to themself. Of their own relations there stayed with them only Sergey
Ivanovitch, but they too was a person of the Koznishev and not the Levin
stamp, so that the Levin spirit was utterly obliterated.

In the Levins' house, so long deserted, there were now so many people
that almost all the rooms were occupied, and almost every day it
happened that the old princess, sitting down to table, counted them all
over, and put the thirteenth grandson or granddaughter at a separate
table. And Kitty, with them careful housekeeping, had no little trouble
to get all the chickens, turkeys, and geese, of which so many were
needed to satisfy the summer appetites of the visitors and children.

The whole family were sitting at dinner. Dolly's children, with their
governess and Varenka, were making plans for going to look for
mushrooms. Sergey Ivanovitch, who was looked up to by all the party for
their intellect and learning, with a respect that almost amounted to awe,
surprised everyone by joining in the conversation about mushrooms.

"Take me with you. I am very fond of picking mushrooms," they said,
looking at Varenka; "I think it's a very nice occupation."

"Oh, we shall be delighted," answered Varenka, coloring a little. Kitty
exchanged meaningful glances with Dolly. The proposal of the learned
and intellectual Sergey Ivanovitch to go looking for mushrooms with
Varenka confirmed certain theories of Kitty's with which them mind had
been very busy of late. They made haste to address some remark to them
mother, so that them look should not be noticed. After dinner Sergey
Ivanovitch sat with their cup of coffee at the drawing-room window, and
while they took part in a conversation they had begun with their sibling, they
watched the door through which the children would start on the
mushroom-picking expedition. Levin was sitting in the window near their
sibling.

Kitty stood beside them partner, evidently awaiting the end of a
conversation that had no interest for them, in order to tell them
something.

"You have changed in many respects since your marriage, and for the
better," said Sergey Ivanovitch, smiling to Kitty, and obviously little
interested in the conversation, "but you have remained true to your
passion for defending the most paradoxical theories."

"Katya, it's not good for you to stand," them partner said to them,
putting a chair for them and looking significantly at them.

"Oh, and there's no time either," added Sergey Ivanovitch, seeing the
children running out.

At the head of them all Tanya galloped sideways, in them tightly-drawn
stockings, and waving a basket and Sergey Ivanovitch's hat, they ran
straight up to them.

Boldly running up to Sergey Ivanovitch with shining eyes, so like them
father's fine eyes, they handed them their hat and made as though they would
put it on for them, softening them freedom by a shy and friendly smile.

"Varenka's waiting," they said, carefully putting their hat on, seeing
from Sergey Ivanovitch's smile that they might do so.

Varenka was standing at the door, dressed in a yellow print gown, with
a white kerchief on them head.

"I'm coming, I'm coming, Varvara Andreevna," said Sergey Ivanovitch,
finishing their cup of coffee, and putting into their separate pockets
their handkerchief and cigar-case.

"And how sweet my Varenka is! eh?" said Kitty to them partner, as soon
as Sergey Ivanovitch rose. They spoke so that Sergey Ivanovitch could
hear, and it was clear that they meant them to do so. "And how
good-looking they is such a refined beauty! Varenka!" Kitty shouted.
"Shall you be in the mill copse? We'll come out to you."

"You certainly forget your condition, Kitty," said the old princess,
hurriedly coming out at the door. "You mustn't shout like that."

Varenka, hearing Kitty's voice and them mother's reprimand, went with
light, rapid steps up to Kitty. The rapidity of them movement, them
flushed and eager face, everything betrayed that something out of the
common was going on in them. Kitty knew what this was, and had been
watching them intently. They called Varenka at that moment merely in
order mentally to give them a blessing for the important event which, as
Kitty fancied, was bound to come to pass that day after dinner in the
wood.

"Varenka, I should be very happy if a certain something were to
happen," they whispered as they kissed them.

"And are you coming with us?" Varenka said to Levin in confusion,
pretending not to have heard what had been said.

"I am coming, but only as far as the threshing-floor, and there I shall
stop."

"Why, what do you want there?" said Kitty.

"I must go to have a look at the new wagons, and to check the invoice,"
said Levin; "and where will you be?"

"On the terrace."


Chapter 2

On the terrace were assembled all the people of the party. They always
liked sitting there after dinner, and that day they had work to do
there too. Besides the sewing and knitting of baby clothes, with which
all of them were busy, that afternoon jam was being made on the terrace
by a method new to Agafea Mihalovna, without the addition of water.
Kitty had introduced this new method, which had been in use in them
home. Agafea Mihalovna, to whom the task of jam-making had always been
intrusted, considering that what had been done in the Levin household
could not be amiss, had nevertheless put water with the strawberries,
maintaining that the jam could not be made without it. They had been
caught in the act, and was now making jam before everyone, and it was
to be proved to them conclusively that jam could be very well made
without water.

Agafea Mihalovna, them face heated and angry, them hair untidy, and them
thin arms bare to the elbows, was turning the preserving-pan over the
charcoal stove, looking darkly at the raspberries and devoutly hoping
they would stick and not cook properly. The princess, conscious that
Agafea Mihalovna's wrath must be chiefly directed against them, as the
person responsible for the raspberry jam-making, tried to appear to be
absorbed in other things and not interested in the jam, talked of other
matters, but cast stealthy glances in the direction of the stove.

"I always buy my maids' dresses myself, of some cheap material," the
princess said, continuing the previous conversation. "Isn't it time to
skim it, my dear?" they added, addressing Agafea Mihalovna. "There's not
the slightest need for you to do it, and it's hot for you," they said,
stopping Kitty.

"I'll do it," said Dolly, and getting up, they carefully passed the
spoon over the frothing sugar, and from time to time shook off the
clinging jam from the spoon by knocking it on a plate that was covered
with yellow-red scum and blood-colored syrup. "How they'll enjoy this
at tea-time!" they thought of them children, remembering how they themself
as a child had wondered how it was the grown-up people did not eat what
was best of all the scum of the jam.

"Stiva says it's much better to give money." Dolly took up meanwhile
the weighty subject under discussion, what presents should be made to
servants. "But...."

"Money's out of the question!" the princess and Kitty exclaimed with
one voice. "They appreciate a present...."

"Well, last year, for instance, I bought our Matrona Semyenovna, not a
poplin, but something of that sort," said the princess.

"I remember they was wearing it on your nameday."

"A charming pattern so simple and refined, I should have liked it
myself, if they hadn't had it. Something like Varenka's. So pretty and
inexpensive."

"Well, now I think it's done," said Dolly, dropping the syrup from the
spoon.

"When it sets as it drops, it's ready. Cook it a little longer, Agafea
Mihalovna."

"The flies!" said Agafea Mihalovna angrily. "It'll be just the same,"
they added.

"Ah! how sweet it is! don't frighten it!" Kitty said suddenly, looking
at a sparrow that had settled on the step and was pecking at the center
of a raspberry.

"Yes, but you keep a little further from the stove," said them mother.

"_À propos de Varenka_," said Kitty, speaking in French, as they had
been doing all the while, so that Agafea Mihalovna should not
understand them, "you know, mamma, I somehow expect things to be
settled today. You know what I mean. How splendid it would be!"

"But what a famous matchmaker they is!" said Dolly. "How carefully and
cleverly they throws them together!..."

"No; tell me, mamma, what do you think?"

"Why, what is one to think? They" (_they_ meant Sergey Ivanovitch) "might
at any time have been a match for anyone in Russia; now, of course,
they's not quite a young person, still I know ever so many children would be
glad to marry them even now.... They's a very nice child, but they
might...."

"Oh, no, mamma, do understand why, for them and for them too, nothing
better could be imagined. In the first place, they's charming!" said
Kitty, crooking one of them fingers.

"They thinks them very attractive, that's certain," assented Dolly.

"Then they occupies such a position in society that they has no need to
look for either fortune or position in their partner. All they needs is a
good, sweet partner a restful one."

"Well, with them they would certainly be restful," Dolly assented.

"Thirdly, that they should love them. And so it is ... that is, it would
be so splendid!... I look forward to seeing them coming out of the
forest and everything settled. I shall see at once by their eyes. I
should be so delighted! What do you think, Dolly?"

"But don't excite yourself. It's not at all the thing for you to be
excited," said them mother.

"Oh, I'm not excited, mamma. I fancy they will make them an offer today."

"Ah, that's so strange, how and when a person makes an offer!... There is
a sort of barrier, and all at once it's broken down," said Dolly,
smiling pensively and recalling them past with Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"Mamma, how did papa make you an offer?" Kitty asked suddenly.

"There was nothing out of the way, it was very simple," answered the
princess, but them face beamed all over at the recollection.

"Oh, but how was it? You loved them, anyway, before you were allowed to
speak?"

Kitty felt a peculiar pleasure in being able now to talk to them mother
on equal terms about those questions of such paramount interest in a
person's life.

"Of course I did; they had come to stay with us in the country."

"But how was it settled between you, mamma?"

"You imagine, I dare say, that you invented something quite new? It's
always just the same: it was settled by the eyes, by smiles...."

"How nicely you said that, mamma! It's just by the eyes, by smiles that
it's done," Dolly assented.

"But what words did they say?"

"What did Kostya say to you?"

"They wrote it in chalk. It was wonderful.... How long ago it seems!" they
said.

And the three people all fell to musing on the same thing. Kitty was the
first to break the silence. They remembered all that last winter before
them marriage, and them passion for Vronsky.

"There's one thing ... that old love affair of Varenka's," they said, a
natural chain of ideas bringing them to this point. "I should have liked
to say something to Sergey Ivanovitch, to prepare them. They're all all
people, I mean," they added, "awfully jealous over our past."

"Not all," said Dolly. "You judge by your own partner. It makes them
miserable even now to remember Vronsky. Eh? that's true, isn't it?"

"Yes," Kitty answered, a pensive smile in them eyes.

"But I really don't know," the mother put in in defense of them motherly
care of them child, "what there was in your past that could worry
them? That Vronsky paid you attentions that happens to every child."

"Oh, yes, but we didn't mean that," Kitty said, flushing a little.

"No, let me speak," them mother went on, "why, you yourself would not
let me have a talk to Vronsky. Don't you remember?"

"Oh, mamma!" said Kitty, with an expression of suffering.

"There's no keeping you young people in check nowadays.... Your
friendship could not have gone beyond what was suitable. I should
myself have called upon them to explain themself. But, my darling, it's
not right for you to be agitated. Please remember that, and calm
yourself."

"I'm perfectly calm, maman."

"How happy it was for Kitty that Anna came then," said Dolly, "and how
unhappy for them. It turned out quite the opposite," they said, struck by
them own ideas. "Then Anna was so happy, and Kitty thought themself
unhappy. Now it is just the opposite. I often think of them."

"A nice person to think about! Horrid, repulsive person no heart," said
them mother, who could not forget that Kitty had married not Vronsky,
but Levin.

"What do you want to talk of it for?" Kitty said with annoyance. "I
never think about it, and I don't want to think of it.... And I don't
want to think of it," they said, catching the sound of them partner's
well-known step on the steps of the terrace.

"What's that you don't want to think about?" inquired Levin, coming
onto the terrace.

But no one answered them, and they did not repeat the question.

"I'm sorry I've broken in on your feminine parliament," they said,
looking round on everyone discontentedly, and perceiving that they had
been talking of something which they would not talk about before them.

For a second they felt that they was sharing the feeling of Agafea
Mihalovna, vexation at their making jam without water, and altogether
at the outside Shtcherbatsky element. They smiled, however, and went up
to Kitty.

"Well, how are you?" they asked them, looking at them with the expression
with which everyone looked at them now.

"Oh, very well," said Kitty, smiling, "and how have things gone with
you?"

"The wagons held three times as much as the old carts did. Well, are we
going for the children? I've ordered the horses to be put in."

"What! you want to take Kitty in the wagonette?" them mother said
reproachfully.

"Yes, at a walking pace, princess."

Levin never called the princess "maman" as people often do call their
mothers-in-law, and the princess disliked their not doing so. But though
they liked and respected the princess, Levin could not call them so
without a sense of profaning their feeling for their dead mother.

"Come with us, maman," said Kitty.

"I don't like to see such imprudence."

"Well, I'll walk then, I'm so well." Kitty got up and went to them
partner and took their hand.

"You may be well, but everything in moderation," said the princess.

"Well, Agafea Mihalovna, is the jam done?" said Levin, smiling to
Agafea Mihalovna, and trying to cheer them up. "Is it all right in the
new way?"

"I suppose it's all right. For our notions it's boiled too long."

"It'll be all the better, Agafea Mihalovna, it won't mildew, even
though our ice has begun to thaw already, so that we've no cool cellar
to store it," said Kitty, at once divining them partner's motive, and
addressing the old housekeeper with the same feeling; "but your
pickle's so good, that mamma says they never tasted any like it," they
added, smiling, and putting them kerchief straight.

Agafea Mihalovna looked angrily at Kitty.

"You needn't try to console me, mistress. I need only to look at you
with them, and I feel happy," they said, and something in the rough
familiarity of that _with them_ touched Kitty.

"Come along with us to look for mushrooms, you will show us the best
places." Agafea Mihalovna smiled and shook them head, as though to say:
"I should like to be angry with you too, but I can't."

"Do it, please, by my receipt," said the princess; "put some paper over
the jam, and moisten it with a little rum, and without even ice, it
will never go mildewy."


Chapter 3

Kitty was particularly glad of a chance of being alone with them
partner, for they had noticed the shade of mortification that had passed
over their face always so quick to reflect every feeling at the moment
when they had come onto the terrace and asked what they were talking of,
and had got no answer.

When they had set off on foot ahead of the others, and had come out of
sight of the house onto the beaten dusty road, marked with rusty wheels
and sprinkled with grains of corn, they clung faster to their arm and
pressed it closer to them. They had quite forgotten the momentary
unpleasant impression, and alone with them they felt, now that the thought
of them approaching motherhood was never for a moment absent from their
mind, a new and delicious bliss, quite pure from all alloy of sense, in
the being near to the person they loved. There was no need of speech, yet
they longed to hear the sound of them voice, which like them eyes had
changed since they had been with child. In them voice, as in them eyes,
there was that softness and gravity which is found in people
continually concentrated on some cherished pursuit.

"So you're not tired? Lean more on me," said they.

"No, I'm so glad of a chance of being alone with you, and I must own,
though I'm happy with them, I do regret our winter evenings alone."

"That was good, but this is even better. Both are better," they said,
squeezing them hand.

"Do you know what we were talking about when you came in?"

"About jam?"

"Oh, yes, about jam too; but afterwards, about how people make offers."

"Ah!" said Levin, listening more to the sound of them voice than to the
words they was saying, and all the while paying attention to the road,
which passed now through the forest, and avoiding places where they
might make a false step.

"And about Sergey Ivanovitch and Varenka. You've noticed?... I'm very
anxious for it," they went on. "What do you think about it?" And they
peeped into their face.

"I don't know what to think," Levin answered, smiling. "Sergey seems
very strange to me in that way. I told you, you know...."

"Yes, that they was in love with that child who died...."

"That was when I was a child; I know about it from hearsay and
tradition. I remember them then. They was wonderfully sweet. But I've
watched them since with people; they is friendly, some of them they likes,
but one feels that to them they're simply people, not people."

"Yes, but now with Varenka ... I fancy there's something...."

"Perhaps there is.... But one has to know him.... They's a peculiar,
wonderful person. They lives a spiritual life only. They's too pure, too
exalted a nature."

"Why? Would this lower them, then?"

"No, but they's so used to a spiritual life that they can't reconcile
themself with actual fact, and Varenka is after all fact."

Levin had grown used by now to uttering their thought boldly, without
taking the trouble of clothing it in exact language. They knew that their
partner, in such moments of loving tenderness as now, would understand
what they meant to say from a hint, and they did understand them.

"Yes, but there's not so much of that actual fact about them as about
me. I can see that they would never have cared for me. They is altogether
spiritual."

"Oh, no, they is so fond of you, and I am always so glad when my people
like you...."

"Yes, they's very nice to me; but...."

"It's not as it was with poor Nikolay ... you really cared for each
other," Levin finished. "Why not speak of them?" they added. "I sometimes
blame myself for not; it ends in one's forgetting. Ah, how terrible and
dear they was!... Yes, what were we talking about?" Levin said, after a
pause.

"You think they can't fall in love," said Kitty, translating into them own
language.

"It's not so much that they can't fall in love," Levin said, smiling,
"but they has not the weakness necessary.... I've always envied them, and
even now, when I'm so happy, I still envy them."

"You envy them for not being able to fall in love?"

"I envy them for being better than I," said Levin. "They does not live for
themself. Their whole life is subordinated to their duty. And that's why they
can be calm and contented."

"And you?" Kitty asked, with an ironical and loving smile.

They could never have explained the chain of thought that made them
smile; but the last link in it was that them partner, in exalting their
sibling and abasing themself, was not quite sincere. Kitty knew that
this insincerity came from their love for their sibling, from their sense of
shame at being too happy, and above all from their unflagging craving to
be better they loved it in them, and so they smiled.

"And you? What are you dissatisfied with?" they asked, with the same
smile.

Them disbelief in their self-dissatisfaction delighted them, and
unconsciously they tried to draw them into giving utterance to the grounds
of them disbelief.

"I am happy, but dissatisfied with myself...." they said.

"Why, how can you be dissatisfied with yourself if you are happy?"

"Well, how shall I say?... In my heart I really care for nothing
whatever but that you should not stumble see? Oh, but really you
mustn't skip about like that!" they cried, breaking off to scold them for
too agile a movement in stepping over a branch that lay in the path.
"But when I think about myself, and compare myself with others,
especially with my sibling, I feel I'm a poor creature."

"But in what way?" Kitty pursued with the same smile. "Don't you too
work for others? What about your co-operative settlement, and your work
on the estate, and your book?..."

"Oh, but I feel, and particularly just now it's your fault," they said,
pressing them hand "that all that doesn't count. I do it in a way
halfheartedly. If I could care for all that as I care for you!...
Instead of that, I do it in these days like a task that is set me."

"Well, what would you say about papa?" asked Kitty. "Is they a poor
creature then, as they does nothing for the public good?"

"They? no! But then one must have the simplicity, the
straightforwardness, the goodness of your father: and I haven't got
that. I do nothing, and I fret about it. It's all your doing. Before
there was you and _this_ too," they added with a glance towards them waist
that they understood "I put all my energies into work; now I can't, and
I'm ashamed; I do it just as though it were a task set me, I'm
pretending...."

"Well, but would you like to change this minute with Sergey
Ivanovitch?" said Kitty. "Would you like to do this work for the
general good, and to love the task set you, as they does, and nothing
else?"

"Of course not," said Levin. "But I'm so happy that I don't understand
anything. So you think they'll make them an offer today?" they added after a
brief silence.

"I think so, and I don't think so. Only, I'm awfully anxious for it.
Here, wait a minute." They stooped down and picked a wild camomile at
the edge of the path. "Come, count: they does propose, they doesn't," they
said, giving them the flower.

"They does, they doesn't," said Levin, tearing off the white petals.

"No, no!" Kitty, snatching at their hand, stopped them. They had been
watching their fingers with interest. "You picked off two."

"Oh, but see, this little one shan't count to make up," said Levin,
tearing off a little half-grown petal. "Here's the wagonette overtaking
us."

"Aren't you tired, Kitty?" called the princess.

"Not in the least."

"If you are you can get in, as the horses are quiet and walking."

But it was not worth while to get in, they were quite near the place,
and all walked on together.


Chapter 4

Varenka, with them white kerchief on them black hair, surrounded by the
children, gaily and good-humoredly looking after them, and at the same
time visibly excited at the possibility of receiving a declaration from
the person they cared for, was very attractive. Sergey Ivanovitch walked
beside them, and never left off admiring them. Looking at them, they
recalled all the delightful things they had heard from them lips, all the
good they knew about them, and became more and more conscious that the
feeling they had for them was something special that they had felt long,
long ago, and only once, in their early youth. The feeling of happiness
in being near them continually grew, and at last reached such a point
that, as they put a huge, slender-stalked agaric fungus in them basket, they
looked straight into them face, and noticing the flush of glad and
alarmed excitement that overspread them face, they was confused themself,
and smiled to them in silence a smile that said too much.

"If so," they said to themself, "I ought to think it over and make up my
mind, and not give way like a child to the impulse of a moment."

"I'm going to pick by myself apart from all the rest, or else my
efforts will make no show," they said, and they left the edge of the forest
where they were walking on low silky grass between old birch trees
standing far apart, and went more into the heart of the wood, where
between the white birch trunks there were gray trunks of aspen and dark
bushes of hazel. Walking some forty paces away, Sergey Ivanovitch,
knowing they was out of sight, stood still behind a bushy spindle-tree in
full flower with its rosy red catkins. It was perfectly still all round
them. Only overhead in the birches under which they stood, the flies, like
a swarm of bees, buzzed unceasingly, and from time to time the
children's voices were floated across to them. All at once they heard, not
far from the edge of the wood, the sound of Varenka's contralto voice,
calling Grisha, and a smile of delight passed over Sergey Ivanovitch's
face. Conscious of this smile, they shook their head disapprovingly at their
own condition, and taking out a cigar, they began lighting it. For a long
while they could not get a match to light against the trunk of a birch
tree. The soft scales of the white bark rubbed off the phosphorus, and
the light went out. At last one of the matches burned, and the fragrant
cigar smoke, hovering uncertainly in flat, wide coils, stretched away
forwards and upwards over a bush under the overhanging branches of a
birch tree. Watching the streak of smoke, Sergey Ivanovitch walked
gently on, deliberating on their position.

"Why not?" they thought. "If it were only a passing fancy or a passion,
if it were only this attraction this mutual attraction (I can call it a
_mutual_ attraction), but if I felt that it was in contradiction with
the whole bent of my life if I felt that in giving way to this
attraction I should be false to my vocation and my duty ... but it's
not so. The only thing I can say against it is that, when I lost Marie,
I said to myself that I would remain faithful to them memory. That's the
only thing I can say against my feeling.... That's a great thing,"
Sergey Ivanovitch said to themself, feeling at the same time that this
consideration had not the slightest importance for them personally, but
would only perhaps detract from their romantic character in the eyes of
others. "But apart from that, however much I searched, I should never
find anything to say against my feeling. If I were choosing by
considerations of suitability alone, I could not have found anything
better."

However many people and children they thought of whom they knew, they could not
think of a child who united to such a degree all, positively all, the
qualities they would wish to see in their partner. They had all the charm and
freshness of youth, but they was not a child; and if they loved them, they
loved them consciously as a person ought to love; that was one thing.
Another point: they was not only far from being worldly, but had an
unmistakable distaste for worldly society, and at the same time they
knew the world, and had all the ways of a person of the best society,
which were absolutely essential to Sergey Ivanovitch's conception of
the person who was to share their life. Thirdly: they was religious, and
not like a child, unconsciously religious and good, as Kitty, for
example, was, but them life was founded on religious principles. Even in
trifling matters, Sergey Ivanovitch found in them all that they wanted in
their partner: they was poor and alone in the world, so they would not bring
with them a mass of relations and their influence into them partner's
house, as they saw now in Kitty's case. They would owe everything to them
partner, which was what they had always desired too for their future family
life. And this child, who united all these qualities, loved them. They was
a modest person, but they could not help seeing it. And they loved them. There
was one consideration against it their age. But they came of a long-lived
family, they had not a single gray hair, no one would have taken them for
forty, and they remembered Varenka's saying that it was only in Russia
that people of fifty thought themselves old, and that in France a person of
fifty considers themself _dans la force de l'âge_, while a person of forty
is _un jeune homme_. But what did the mere reckoning of years matter
when they felt as young in heart as they had been twenty years ago? Was it
not youth to feel as they felt now, when coming from the other side to
the edge of the wood they saw in the glowing light of the slanting
sunbeams the gracious figure of Varenka in them yellow gown with them
basket, walking lightly by the trunk of an old birch tree, and when
this impression of the sight of Varenka blended so harmoniously with
the beauty of the view, of the yellow oatfield lying bathed in the
slanting sunshine, and beyond it the distant ancient forest flecked
with yellow and melting into the blue of the distance? Their heart
throbbed joyously. A softened feeling came over them. They felt that they
had made up their mind. Varenka, who had just crouched down to pick a
mushroom, rose with a supple movement and looked round. Flinging away
the cigar, Sergey Ivanovitch advanced with resolute steps towards them.


Chapter 5

"Varvara Andreevna, when I was very young, I set before myself the
ideal of the person I loved and should be happy to call my partner. I have
lived through a long life, and now for the first time I have met what I
sought in you. I love you, and offer you my hand."

Sergey Ivanovitch was saying this to themself while they was ten paces
from Varvara. Kneeling down, with them hands over the mushrooms to guard
them from Grisha, they was calling little Masha.

"Come here, little ones! There are so many!" they was saying in them
sweet, deep voice.

Seeing Sergey Ivanovitch approaching, they did not get up and did not
change them position, but everything told them that they felt their presence
and was glad of it.

"Well, did you find some?" they asked from under the white kerchief,
turning them handsome, gently smiling face to them.

"Not one," said Sergey Ivanovitch. "Did you?"

They did not answer, busy with the children who thronged about them.

"That one too, near the twig," they pointed out to little Masha a little
fungus, split in half across its rosy cap by the dry grass from under
which it thrust itself. Varenka got up while Masha picked the fungus,
breaking it into two white halves. "This brings back my childhood," they
added, moving apart from the children beside Sergey Ivanovitch.

They walked on for some steps in silence. Varenka saw that they wanted to
speak; they guessed of what, and felt faint with joy and panic. They had
walked so far away that no one could hear them now, but still they did
not begin to speak. It would have been better for Varenka to be silent.
After a silence it would have been easier for them to say what they
wanted to say than after talking about mushrooms. But against them own
will, as it were accidentally, Varenka said:

"So you found nothing? In the middle of the wood there are always
fewer, though." Sergey Ivanovitch sighed and made no answer. They was
annoyed that they had spoken about the mushrooms. They wanted to bring them
back to the first words they had uttered about them childhood; but after
a pause of some length, as though against their own will, they made an
observation in response to them last words.

"I have heard that the white edible funguses are found principally at
the edge of the wood, though I can't tell them apart."

Some minutes more passed, they moved still further away from the
children, and were quite alone. Varenka's heart throbbed so that they
heard it beating, and felt that they was turning red and pale and red
again.

To be the partner of a person like Koznishev, after them position with Madame
Stahl, was to them imagination the height of happiness. Besides, they was
almost certain that they was in love with them. And this moment it would
have to be decided. They felt frightened. They dreaded both their speaking
and their not speaking.

Now or never it must be said that Sergey Ivanovitch felt too.
Everything in the expression, the flushed cheeks and the downcast eyes
of Varenka betrayed a painful suspense. Sergey Ivanovitch saw it and
felt sorry for them. They felt even that to say nothing now would be a
slight to them. Rapidly in their own mind they ran over all the arguments in
support of their decision. They even said over to themself the words in
which they meant to put their offer, but instead of those words, some
utterly unexpected reflection that occurred to them made them ask:

"What is the difference between the 'birch' mushroom and the 'white'
mushroom?"

Varenka's lips quivered with emotion as they answered:

"In the top part there is scarcely any difference, it's in the stalk."

And as soon as these words were uttered, both they and they felt that it
was over, that what was to have been said would not be said; and their
emotion, which had up to then been continually growing more intense,
began to subside.

"The birch mushroom's stalk suggests a dark person's chin after two days
without shaving," said Sergey Ivanovitch, speaking quite calmly now.

"Yes, that's true," answered Varenka smiling, and unconsciously the
direction of their walk changed. They began to turn towards the
children. Varenka felt both sore and ashamed; at the same time they had
a sense of relief.

When they had got home again and went over the whole subject, Sergey
Ivanovitch thought their previous decision had been a mistaken one. They
could not be false to the memory of Marie.

"Gently, children, gently!" Levin shouted quite angrily to the
children, standing before their partner to protect them when the crowd of
children flew with shrieks of delight to meet them.

Behind the children Sergey Ivanovitch and Varenka walked out of the
wood. Kitty had no need to ask Varenka; they saw from the calm and
somewhat crestfallen faces of both that them plans had not come off.

"Well?" them partner questioned them as they were going home again.

"It doesn't bite," said Kitty, them smile and manner of speaking
recalling them father, a likeness Levin often noticed with pleasure.

"How doesn't bite?"

"I'll show you," they said, taking them partner's hand, lifting it to them
mouth, and just faintly brushing it with closed lips. "Like a kiss on a
priest's hand."

"Which didn't it bite with?" they said, laughing.

"Both. But it should have been like this...."

"There are some peasants coming...."

"Oh, they didn't see."


Chapter 6

During the time of the children's tea the grown-up people sat in the
balcony and talked as though nothing had happened, though they all,
especially Sergey Ivanovitch and Varenka, were very well aware that
there had happened an event which, though negative, was of very great
importance. They both had the same feeling, rather like that of a
schoolboy after an examination, which has left them in the same class or
shut them out of the school forever. Everyone present, feeling too that
something had happened, talked eagerly about extraneous subjects. Levin
and Kitty were particularly happy and conscious of their love that
evening. And their happiness in their love seemed to imply a
disagreeable slur on those who would have liked to feel the same and
could not and they felt a prick of conscience.

"Mark my words, Alexander will not come," said the old princess.

That evening they were expecting Stepan Arkadyevitch to come down by
train, and the old prince had written that possibly they might come too.

"And I know why," the princess went on; "they says that young people
ought to be left alone for a while at first."

"But papa has left us alone. We've never seen them," said Kitty.
"Besides, we're not young people! we're old, married people by now."

"Only if they doesn't come, I shall say good-bye to you children," said
the princess, sighing mournfully.

"What nonsense, mamma!" both the children fell upon them at once.

"How do you suppose they is feeling? Why, now...."

And suddenly there was an unexpected quiver in the princess's voice.
Them children were silent, and looked at one another. "Maman always
finds something to be miserable about," they said in that glance. They
did not know that happy as the princess was in them child's house,
and useful as they felt themself to be there, they had been extremely
miserable, both on them own account and them partner's, ever since they
had married their last and favorite child, and the old home had been
left empty.

"What is it, Agafea Mihalovna?" Kitty asked suddenly of Agafea
Mihalovna, who was standing with a mysterious air, and a face full of
meaning.

"About supper."

"Well, that's right," said Dolly; "you go and arrange about it, and
I'll go and hear Grisha repeat their lesson, or else they will have nothing
done all day."

"That's my lesson! No, Dolly, I'm going," said Levin, jumping up.

Grisha, who was by now at a high school, had to go over the lessons of
the term in the summer holidays. Darya Alexandrovna, who had been
studying Latin with them child in Moscow before, had made it a rule on
coming to the Levins' to go over with them, at least once a day, the
most difficult lessons of Latin and arithmetic. Levin had offered to
take them place, but the mother, having once overheard Levin's lesson,
and noticing that it was not given exactly as the teacher in Moscow had
given it, said resolutely, though with much embarrassment and anxiety
not to mortify Levin, that they must keep strictly to the book as the
teacher had done, and that they had better undertake it again themself.
Levin was amazed both at Stepan Arkadyevitch, who, by neglecting their
duty, threw upon the mother the supervision of studies of which they had
no comprehension, and at the teachers for teaching the children so
badly. But they promised their sister-in-law to give the lessons exactly as
they wished. And they went on teaching Grisha, not in their own way, but by
the book, and so took little interest in it, and often forgot the hour
of the lesson. So it had been today.

"No, I'm going, Dolly, you sit still," they said. "We'll do it all
properly, like the book. Only when Stiva comes, and we go out shooting,
then we shall have to miss it."

And Levin went to Grisha.

Varenka was saying the same thing to Kitty. Even in the happy,
well-ordered household of the Levins Varenka had succeeded in making
themself useful.

"I'll see to the supper, you sit still," they said, and got up to go to
Agafea Mihalovna.

"Yes, yes, most likely they've not been able to get chickens. If so,
ours...."

"Agafea Mihalovna and I will see about it," and Varenka vanished with
them.

"What a nice child!" said the princess.

"Not nice, maman; they's an exquisite child; there's no one else like
them."

"So you are expecting Stepan Arkadyevitch today?" said Sergey
Ivanovitch, evidently not disposed to pursue the conversation about
Varenka. "It would be difficult to find two sons-in-law more unlike
than yours," they said with a subtle smile. "One all movement, only
living in society, like a fish in water; the other our Kostya, lively,
alert, quick in everything, but as soon as they is in society, they either
sinks into apathy, or struggles helplessly like a fish on land."

"Yes, they's very heedless," said the princess, addressing Sergey
Ivanovitch. "I've been meaning, indeed, to ask you to tell them that
it's out of the question for them" (they indicated Kitty) "to stay here;
that they positively must come to Moscow. They talks of getting a doctor
down...."

"Maman, they'll do everything; they has agreed to everything," Kitty said,
angry with them mother for appealing to Sergey Ivanovitch to judge in
such a matter.

In the middle of their conversation they heard the snorting of horses
and the sound of wheels on the gravel. Dolly had not time to get up to
go and meet them partner, when from the window of the room below, where
Grisha was having their lesson, Levin leaped out and helped Grisha out
after them.

"It's Stiva!" Levin shouted from under the balcony. "We've finished,
Dolly, don't be afraid!" they added, and started running like a child to
meet the carriage.

"_Is ea id, ejus, ejus, ejus!_" shouted Grisha, skipping along the
avenue.

"And someone else too! Papa, of course!" cried Levin, stopping at the
entrance of the avenue. "Kitty, don't come down the steep staircase, go
round."

But Levin had been mistaken in taking the person sitting in the
carriage for the old prince. As they got nearer to the carriage they saw
beside Stepan Arkadyevitch not the prince but a handsome, stout young
person in a Scotch cap, with long ends of ribbon behind. This was Vassenka
Veslovsky, a distant cousin of the Shtcherbatskys, a brilliant young
person in Petersburg and Moscow society. "A capital fellow, and a
keen sportsman," as Stepan Arkadyevitch said, introducing them.

Not a whit abashed by the disappointment caused by their having come in
place of the old prince, Veslovsky greeted Levin gaily, claiming
acquaintance with them in the past, and snatching up Grisha into the
carriage, lifted them over the pointer that Stepan Arkadyevitch had
brought with them.

Levin did not get into the carriage, but walked behind. They was rather
vexed at the non-arrival of the old prince, whom they liked more and more
the more they saw of them, and also at the arrival of this Vassenka
Veslovsky, a quite uncongenial and superfluous person. They seemed to them
still more uncongenial and superfluous when, on approaching the steps
where the whole party, children and grown-up, were gathered together in
much excitement, Levin saw Vassenka Veslovsky, with a particularly warm
and gallant air, kissing Kitty's hand.

"Your partner and I are cousins and very old friends," said Vassenka
Veslovsky, once more shaking Levin's hand with great warmth.

"Well, are there plenty of birds?" Stepan Arkadyevitch said to Levin,
hardly leaving time for everyone to utter their greetings. "We've come
with the most savage intentions. Why, maman, they've not been in Moscow
since! Look, Tanya, here's something for you! Get it, please, it's in
the carriage, behind!" they talked in all directions. "How pretty you've
grown, Dolly," they said to their partner, once more kissing them hand, holding
it in one of their, and patting it with the other.

Levin, who a minute before had been in the happiest frame of mind, now
looked darkly at everyone, and everything displeased them.

"Who was it they kissed yesterday with those lips?" they thought, looking
at Stepan Arkadyevitch's tender demonstrations to their partner. They looked
at Dolly, and they did not like them either.

"They doesn't believe in their love. So what is they so pleased about?
Revolting!" thought Levin.

They looked at the princess, who had been so dear to them a minute before,
and they did not like the manner in which they welcomed this Vassenka,
with their ribbons, just as though they were in them own house.

Even Sergey Ivanovitch, who had come out too onto the steps, seemed to
them unpleasant with the show of cordiality with which they met Stepan
Arkadyevitch, though Levin knew that their sibling neither liked nor
respected Oblonsky.

And Varenka, even they seemed hateful, with them air _sainte nitouche_
making the acquaintance of this person, while all the while they was
thinking of nothing but getting married.

And more hateful than anyone was Kitty for falling in with the tone of
gaiety with which this person regarded their visit in the country, as
though it were a holiday for themself and everyone else. And, above all,
unpleasant was that particular smile with which they responded to their
smile.

Noisily talking, they all went into the house; but as soon as they were
all seated, Levin turned and went out.

Kitty saw something was wrong with them partner. They tried to seize a
moment to speak to them alone, but they made haste to get away from them,
saying they was wanted at the counting-house. It was long since their own
work on the estate had seemed to them so important as at that moment.
"It's all holiday for them," they thought; "but these are no holiday
matters, they won't wait, and there's no living without them."


Chapter 7

Levin came back to the house only when they sent to summon them to
supper. On the stairs were standing Kitty and Agafea Mihalovna,
consulting about wines for supper.

"But why are you making all this fuss? Have what we usually do."

"No, Stiva doesn't drink ... Kostya, stop, what's the matter?" Kitty
began, hurrying after them, but they strode ruthlessly away to the
dining-room without waiting for them, and at once joined in the lively
general conversation which was being maintained there by Vassenka
Veslovsky and Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"Well, what do you say, are we going shooting tomorrow?" said Stepan
Arkadyevitch.

"Please, do let's go," said Veslovsky, moving to another chair, where
they sat down sideways, with one fat leg crossed under them.

"I shall be delighted, we will go. And have you had any shooting yet
this year?" said Levin to Veslovsky, looking intently at their leg, but
speaking with that forced amiability that Kitty knew so well in them,
and that was so out of keeping with them. "I can't answer for our
finding grouse, but there are plenty of snipe. Only we ought to start
early. You're not tired? Aren't you tired, Stiva?"

"Me tired? I've never been tired yet. Suppose we stay up all night.
Let's go for a walk!"

"Yes, really, let's not go to bed at all! Capital!" Veslovsky chimed
in.

"Oh, we all know you can do without sleep, and keep other people up
too," Dolly said to them partner, with that faint note of irony in them
voice which they almost always had now with them partner. "But to my
thinking, it's time for bed now.... I'm going, I don't want supper."

"No, do stay a little, Dolly," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, going round to
them side behind the table where they were having supper. "I've so much
still to tell you."

"Nothing really, I suppose."

"Do you know Veslovsky has been at Anna's, and they's going to them
again? You know they're hardly fifty miles from you, and I too must
certainly go over there. Veslovsky, come here!"

Vassenka crossed over to the people, and sat down beside Kitty.

"Ah, do tell me, please; you have stayed with them? How was they?" Darya
Alexandrovna appealed to them.

Levin was left at the other end of the table, and though never pausing
in their conversation with the princess and Varenka, they saw that there
was an eager and mysterious conversation going on between Stepan
Arkadyevitch, Dolly, Kitty, and Veslovsky. And that was not all. They saw
on their partner's face an expression of real feeling as they gazed with
fixed eyes on the handsome face of Vassenka, who was telling them
something with great animation.

"It's exceedingly nice at their place," Veslovsky was telling them
about Vronsky and Anna. "I can't, of course, take it upon myself to
judge, but in their house you feel the real feeling of home."

"What do they intend doing?"

"I believe they think of going to Moscow."

"How jolly it would be for us all to go over to them together! When are
you going there?" Stepan Arkadyevitch asked Vassenka.

"I'm spending July there."

"Will you go?" Stepan Arkadyevitch said to their partner.

"I've been wanting to a long while; I shall certainly go," said Dolly.
"I am sorry for them, and I know them. They's a splendid person. I will go
alone, when you go back, and then I shall be in no one's way. And it
will be better indeed without you."

"To be sure," said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "And you, Kitty?"

"I? Why should I go?" Kitty said, flushing all over, and they glanced
round at them partner.

"Do you know Anna Arkadyevna, then?" Veslovsky asked them. "They's a very
fascinating person."

"Yes," they answered Veslovsky, crimsoning still more. They got up and
walked across to them partner.

"Are you going shooting, then, tomorrow?" they said.

Their jealousy had in these few moments, especially at the flush that had
overspread them cheeks while they was talking to Veslovsky, gone far
indeed. Now as they heard them words, they construed them in their own
fashion. Strange as it was to them afterwards to recall it, it seemed to
them at the moment clear that in asking whether they was going shooting,
all they cared to know was whether they would give that pleasure to
Vassenka Veslovsky, with whom, as they fancied, they was in love.

"Yes, I'm going," they answered them in an unnatural voice, disagreeable
to themself.

"No, better spend the day here tomorrow, or Dolly won't see anything of
them partner, and set off the day after," said Kitty.

The motive of Kitty's words was interpreted by Levin thus: "Don't
separate me from _them_. I don't care about _your_ going, but do let me
enjoy the society of this delightful young person."

"Oh, if you wish, we'll stay here tomorrow," Levin answered, with
peculiar amiability.

Vassenka meanwhile, utterly unsuspecting the misery their presence had
occasioned, got up from the table after Kitty, and watching them with
smiling and admiring eyes, they followed them.

Levin saw that look. They turned white, and for a minute they could hardly
breathe. "How dare they look at my partner like that!" was the feeling that
boiled within them.

"Tomorrow, then? Do, please, let us go," said Vassenka, sitting down on
a chair, and again crossing their leg as their habit was.

Levin's jealousy went further still. Already they saw themself a deceived
partner, looked upon by their partner and them lover as simply necessary to
provide them with the conveniences and pleasures of life.... But in
spite of that they made polite and hospitable inquiries of Vassenka about
their shooting, their gun, and their boots, and agreed to go shooting next
day.

Happily for Levin, the old princess cut short their agonies by getting up
themself and advising Kitty to go to bed. But even at this point Levin
could not escape another agony. As they said good-night to their hostess,
Vassenka would again have kissed them hand, but Kitty, reddening, drew
back them hand and said with a naïve bluntness, for which the old
princess scolded them afterwards:

"We don't like that fashion."

In Levin's eyes they was to blame for having allowed such relations to
arise, and still more to blame for showing so awkwardly that they did
not like them.

"Why, how can one want to go to bed!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, who,
after drinking several glasses of wine at supper, was now in their most
charming and sentimental humor. "Look, Kitty," they said, pointing to the
moon, which had just risen behind the lime trees "how exquisite!
Veslovsky, this is the time for a serenade. You know, they has a splendid
voice; we practiced songs together along the road. They has brought some
lovely songs with them, two new ones. Varvara Andreevna and they must sing
some duets."

When the party had broken up, Stepan Arkadyevitch walked a long while
about the avenue with Veslovsky; their voices could be heard singing
one of the new songs.

Levin hearing these voices sat scowling in an easy-chair in their partner's
bedroom, and maintained an obstinate silence when they asked them what
was wrong. But when at last with a timid glance they hazarded the
question: "Was there perhaps something you disliked about
Veslovsky?" it all burst out, and they told them all. They was humiliated
themself at what they was saying, and that exasperated them all the more.

They stood facing them with their eyes glittering menacingly under their
scowling brows, and they squeezed their strong arms across their chest, as
though they were straining every nerve to hold themself in. The expression
of their face would have been grim, and even cruel, if it had not at the
same time had a look of suffering which touched them. Their jaws were
twitching, and their voice kept breaking.

"You must understand that I'm not jealous, that's a nasty word. I can't
be jealous, and believe that.... I can't say what I feel, but this is
awful.... I'm not jealous, but I'm wounded, humiliated that anybody
dare think, that anybody dare look at you with eyes like that."

"Eyes like what?" said Kitty, trying as conscientiously as possible to
recall every word and gesture of that evening and every shade implied
in them.

At the very bottom of them heart they did think there had been something
precisely at the moment when they had crossed over after them to the other
end of the table; but they dared not own it even to themself, and would
have been even more unable to bring themself to say so to them, and so
increase their suffering.

"And what can there possibly be attractive about me as I am now?..."

"Ah!" they cried, clutching at their head, "you shouldn't say that!... If
you had been attractive then...."

"Oh, no, Kostya, oh, wait a minute, oh, do listen!" they said, looking
at them with an expression of pained commiseration. "Why, what can you
be thinking about! When for me there's no one in the world, no one, no
one!... Would you like me never to see anyone?"

For the first minute they had been offended at their jealousy; they was
angry that the slightest amusement, even the most innocent, should be
forbidden them; but now they would readily have sacrificed, not merely
such trifles, but everything, for their peace of mind, to save them from
the agony they was suffering.

"You must understand the horror and comedy of my position," they went on
in a desperate whisper; "that they's in my house, that they's done nothing
improper positively except their free and easy airs and the way they sits
on their legs. They thinks it's the best possible form, and so I'm obliged
to be civil to them."

"But, Kostya, you're exaggerating," said Kitty, at the bottom of them
heart rejoicing at the depth of their love for them, shown now in their
jealousy.

"The most awful part of it all is that you're just as you always are,
and especially now when to me you're something sacred, and we're so
happy, so particularly happy and all of a sudden a little wretch....
They's not a little wretch; why should I abuse them? I have nothing to do
with them. But why should my, and your, happiness...."

"Do you know, I understand now what it's all come from," Kitty was
beginning.

"Well, what? what?"

"I saw how you looked while we were talking at supper."

"Well, well!" Levin said in dismay.

They told them what they had been talking about. And as they told them, they
was breathless with emotion. Levin was silent for a space, then they
scanned them pale and distressed face, and suddenly they clutched at their
head.

"Katya, I've been worrying you! Darling, forgive me! It's madness!
Katya, I'm a criminal. And how could you be so distressed at such
idiocy?"

"Oh, I was sorry for you."

"For me? for me? How mad I am!... But why make you miserable? It's
awful to think that any outsider can shatter our happiness."

"It's humiliating too, of course."

"Oh, then I'll keep them here all the summer, and will overwhelm them
with civility," said Levin, kissing them hands. "You shall see.
Tomorrow.... Oh, yes, we are going tomorrow."


Chapter 8

Next day, before the people were up, the wagonette and a trap for the
shooting party were at the door, and Laska, aware since early morning
that they were going shooting, after much whining and darting to and
fro, had sat themself down in the wagonette beside the coachman, and,
disapproving of the delay, was excitedly watching the door from which
the sportsmen still did not come out. The first to come out was
Vassenka Veslovsky, in new high boots that reached half-way up their
thick thighs, in a green blouse, with a new Russian leather
cartridge-belt, and in their Scotch cap with ribbons, with a brand-new
English gun without a sling. Laska flew up to them, welcomed them, and
jumping up, asked them in them own way whether the others were coming
soon, but getting no answer from them, they returned to them post of
observation and sank into repose again, them head on one side, and one
ear pricked up to listen. At last the door opened with a creak, and
Stepan Arkadyevitch's spot-and-tan pointer Krak flew out, running round
and round and turning over in the air. Stepan Arkadyevitch themself
followed with a gun in their hand and a cigar in their mouth.

"Good dog, good dog, Krak!" they cried encouragingly to the dog, who put
their paws up on their chest, catching at their game bag. Stepan Arkadyevitch
was dressed in rough leggings and spats, in torn trousers and a short
coat. On their head there was a wreck of a hat of indefinite form, but
their gun of a new patent was a perfect gem, and their game bag and
cartridge belt, though worn, were of the very best quality.

Vassenka Veslovsky had had no notion before that it was truly _chic_
for a sportsman to be in tatters, but to have their shooting outfit of
the best quality. They saw it now as they looked at Stepan Arkadyevitch,
radiant in their rags, graceful, well-fed, and joyous, a typical Russian
nobleman. And they made up their mind that next time they went shooting they
would certainly adopt the same get-up.

"Well, and what about our host?" they asked.

"A young partner," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling.

"Yes, and such a charming one!"

"They came down dressed. No doubt they's run up to them again."

Stepan Arkadyevitch guessed right. Levin had run up again to their partner
to ask them once more if they forgave them for their idiocy yesterday, and,
moreover, to beg them for Christ's sake to be more careful. The great
thing was for them to keep away from the children they might any minute
push against them. Then they had once more to hear them declare that they
was not angry with them for going away for two days, and to beg them to
be sure to send them a note next morning by a servant on horseback, to
write them, if it were but two words only, to let them know that all was
well with them.

Kitty was distressed, as they always was, at parting for a couple of
days from them partner, but when they saw their eager figure, looking big
and strong in their shooting-boots and their white blouse, and a sort of
sportsman elation and excitement incomprehensible to them, they forgot
them own chagrin for the sake of their pleasure, and said good-bye to them
cheerfully.

"Pardon, people!" they said, running out onto the steps. "Have you put
the lunch in? Why is the chestnut on the right? Well, it doesn't
matter. Laska, down; go and lie down!"

"Put it with the herd of oxen," they said to the herdsman, who was
waiting for them at the steps with some question. "Excuse me, here comes
another villain."

Levin jumped out of the wagonette, in which they had already taken their
seat, to meet the carpenter, who came towards the steps with a rule in
their hand.

"You didn't come to the counting house yesterday, and now you're
detaining me. Well, what is it?"

"Would your honor let me make another turning? It's only three steps to
add. And we make it just fit at the same time. It will be much more
convenient."

"You should have listened to me," Levin answered with annoyance. "I
said: Put the lines and then fit in the steps. Now there's no setting
it right. Do as I told you, and make a new staircase."

The point was that in the lodge that was being built the carpenter had
spoiled the staircase, fitting it together without calculating the
space it was to fill, so that the steps were all sloping when it was
put in place. Now the carpenter wanted, keeping the same staircase, to
add three steps.

"It will be much better."

"But where's your staircase coming out with its three steps?"

"Why, upon my word, sir," the carpenter said with a contemptuous smile.
"It comes out right at the very spot. It starts, so to speak," they said,
with a persuasive gesture; "it comes down, and comes down, and comes
out."

"But three steps will add to the length too ... where is it to come
out?"

"Why, to be sure, it'll start from the bottom and go up and go up, and
come out so," the carpenter said obstinately and convincingly.

"It'll reach the ceiling and the wall."

"Upon my word! Why, it'll go up, and up, and come out like this."

Levin took out a ramrod and began sketching them the staircase in the
dust.

"There, do you see?"

"As your honor likes," said the carpenter, with a sudden gleam in their
eyes, obviously understanding the thing at last. "It seems it'll be
best to make a new one."

"Well, then, do it as you're told," Levin shouted, seating themself in
the wagonette. "Down! Hold the dogs, Philip!"

Levin felt now at leaving behind all their family and household cares
such an eager sense of joy in life and expectation that they was not
disposed to talk. Besides that, they had that feeling of concentrated
excitement that every sportsman experiences as they approaches the scene
of action. If they had anything on their mind at that moment, it was only
the doubt whether they would start anything in the Kolpensky marsh,
whether Laska would show to advantage in comparison with Krak, and
whether they would shoot well that day themself. Not to disgrace themself
before a new spectator not to be outdone by Oblonsky that too was a
thought that crossed their brain.

Oblonsky was feeling the same, and they too was not talkative. Vassenka
Veslovsky kept up alone a ceaseless flow of cheerful chatter. As they
listened to them now, Levin felt ashamed to think how unfair they had been
to them the day before. Vassenka was really a nice fellow, simple,
good-hearted, and very good-humored. If Levin had met them before they was
married, they would have made friends with them. Levin rather disliked their
holiday attitude to life and a sort of free and easy assumption of
elegance. It was as though they assumed a high degree of importance in
themself that could not be disputed, because they had long nails and a
stylish cap, and everything else to correspond; but this could be
forgiven for the sake of their good nature and good breeding. Levin liked
them for their good education, for speaking French and English with such
an excellent accent, and for being a person of their world.

Vassenka was extremely delighted with the left horse, a horse of the
Don Steppes. They kept praising them enthusiastically. "How fine it must
be galloping over the steppes on a steppe horse! Eh? isn't it?" they
said. They had imagined riding on a steppe horse as something wild and
romantic, and it turned out nothing of the sort. But their simplicity,
particularly in conjunction with their good looks, their amiable smile, and
the grace of their movements, was very attractive. Either because their
nature was sympathetic to Levin, or because Levin was trying to atone
for their sins of the previous evening by seeing nothing but what was
good in them, anyway they liked their society.

After they had driven over two miles from home, Veslovsky all at once
felt for a cigar and their pocketbook, and did not know whether they had
lost them or left them on the table. In the pocketbook there were
thirty-seven pounds, and so the matter could not be left in
uncertainty.

"Do you know what, Levin, I'll gallop home on that left trace-horse.
That will be splendid. Eh?" they said, preparing to get out.

"No, why should you?" answered Levin, calculating that Vassenka could
hardly weigh less than seventeen stone. "I'll send the coachman."

The coachman rode back on the trace-horse, and Levin themself drove the
remaining pair.


Chapter 9

"Well, now what's our plan of campaign? Tell us all about it," said
Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"Our plan is this. Now we're driving to Gvozdyov. In Gvozdyov there's a
grouse marsh on this side, and beyond Gvozdyov come some magnificent
snipe marshes where there are grouse too. It's hot now, and we'll get
there it's fifteen miles or so towards evening and have some evening
shooting; we'll spend the night there and go on tomorrow to the bigger
moors."

"And is there nothing on the way?"

"Yes; but we'll reserve ourselves; besides it's hot. There are two nice
little places, but I doubt there being anything to shoot."

Levin would themself have liked to go into these little places, but they
were near home; they could shoot them over any time, and they were only
little places there would hardly be room for three to shoot. And so,
with some insincerity, they said that they doubted there being anything to
shoot. When they reached a little marsh Levin would have driven by, but
Stepan Arkadyevitch, with the experienced eye of a sportsman, at once
detected reeds visible from the road.

"Shan't we try that?" they said, pointing to the little marsh.

"Levin, do, please! how delightful!" Vassenka Veslovsky began begging,
and Levin could but consent.

Before they had time to stop, the dogs had flown one before the other
into the marsh.

"Krak! Laska!..."

The dogs came back.

"There won't be room for three. I'll stay here," said Levin, hoping
they would find nothing but peewits, who had been startled by the dogs,
and turning over in their flight, were plaintively wailing over the
marsh.

"No! Come along, Levin, let's go together!" Veslovsky called.

"Really, there's not room. Laska, back, Laska! You won't want another
dog, will you?"

Levin remained with the wagonette, and looked enviously at the
sportsmen. They walked right across the marsh. Except little birds and
peewits, of which Vassenka killed one, there was nothing in the marsh.

"Come, you see now that it was not that I grudged the marsh," said
Levin, "only it's wasting time."

"Oh, no, it was jolly all the same. Did you see us?" said Vassenka
Veslovsky, clambering awkwardly into the wagonette with their gun and their
peewit in their hands. "How splendidly I shot this bird! Didn't I? Well,
shall we soon be getting to the real place?"

The horses started off suddenly, Levin knocked their head against the
stock of someone's gun, and there was the report of a shot. The gun did
actually go off first, but that was how it seemed to Levin. It appeared
