that Vassenka Veslovsky had pulled only one trigger, and had left the
other hammer still cocked. The charge flew into the ground without
doing harm to anyone. Stepan Arkadyevitch shook their head and laughed
reprovingly at Veslovsky. But Levin had not the heart to reprove them.
In the first place, any reproach would have seemed to be called forth
by the danger they had incurred and the bump that had come up on Levin's
forehead. And besides, Veslovsky was at first so naïvely distressed,
and then laughed so good-humoredly and infectiously at their general
dismay, that one could not but laugh with them.

When they reached the second marsh, which was fairly large, and would
inevitably take some time to shoot over, Levin tried to persuade them
to pass it by. But Veslovsky again overpersuaded them. Again, as the
marsh was narrow, Levin, like a good host, remained with the carriage.

Krak made straight for some clumps of sedge. Vassenka Veslovsky was the
first to run after the dog. Before Stepan Arkadyevitch had time to come
up, a grouse flew out. Veslovsky missed it and it flew into an unmown
meadow. This grouse was left for Veslovsky to follow up. Krak found it
again and pointed, and Veslovsky shot it and went back to the carriage.
"Now you go and I'll stay with the horses," they said.

Levin had begun to feel the pangs of a sportsman's envy. They handed the
reins to Veslovsky and walked into the marsh.

Laska, who had been plaintively whining and fretting against the
injustice of them treatment, flew straight ahead to a hopeful place that
Levin knew well, and that Krak had not yet come upon.

"Why don't you stop them?" shouted Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"They won't scare them," answered Levin, sympathizing with their bitch's
pleasure and hurrying after them.

As they came nearer and nearer to the familiar breeding places there was
more and more earnestness in Laska's exploration. A little marsh bird
did not divert them attention for more than an instant. They made one
circuit round the clump of reeds, was beginning a second, and suddenly
quivered with excitement and became motionless.

"Come, come, Stiva!" shouted Levin, feeling their heart beginning to beat
more violently; and all of a sudden, as though some sort of shutter had
been drawn back from their straining ears, all sounds, confused but loud,
began to beat on their hearing, losing all sense of distance. They heard
the steps of Stepan Arkadyevitch, mistaking them for the tramp of the
horses in the distance; they heard the brittle sound of the twigs on
which they had trodden, taking this sound for the flying of a grouse. They
heard too, not far behind them, a splashing in the water, which they could
not explain to themself.

Picking their steps, they moved up to the dog.

"Fetch it!"

Not a grouse but a snipe flew up from beside the dog. Levin had lifted
their gun, but at the very instant when they was taking aim, the sound of
splashing grew louder, came closer, and was joined with the sound of
Veslovsky's voice, shouting something with strange loudness. Levin saw
they had their gun pointed behind the snipe, but still they fired.

When they had made sure they had missed, Levin looked round and saw the
horses and the wagonette not on the road but in the marsh.

Veslovsky, eager to see the shooting, had driven into the marsh, and
got the horses stuck in the mud.

"Damn the fellow!" Levin said to themself, as they went back to the
carriage that had sunk in the mire. "What did you drive in for?" they
said to them dryly, and calling the coachman, they began pulling the
horses out.

Levin was vexed both at being hindered from shooting and at their horses
getting stuck in the mud, and still more at the fact that neither
Stepan Arkadyevitch nor Veslovsky helped them and the coachman to
unharness the horses and get them out, since neither of them had the
slightest notion of harnessing. Without vouchsafing a syllable in reply
to Vassenka's protestations that it had been quite dry there, Levin
worked in silence with the coachman at extricating the horses. But
then, as they got warm at the work and saw how assiduously Veslovsky was
tugging at the wagonette by one of the mud-guards, so that they broke it
indeed, Levin blamed themself for having under the influence of
yesterday's feelings been too cold to Veslovsky, and tried to be
particularly genial so as to smooth over their chilliness. When
everything had been put right, and the carriage had been brought back
to the road, Levin had the lunch served.

"_Bon appétit bonne conscience! Ce poulet va tomber jusqu'au fond de
mes bottes_," Vassenka, who had recovered their spirits, quoted the
French saying as they finished their second chicken. "Well, now our
troubles are over, now everything's going to go well. Only, to atone
for my sins, I'm bound to sit on the box. That's so? eh? No, no! I'll
be your Automedon. You shall see how I'll get you along," they answered,
not letting go the rein, when Levin begged them to let the coachman
drive. "No, I must atone for my sins, and I'm very comfortable on the
box." And they drove.

Levin was a little afraid they would exhaust the horses, especially the
chestnut, whom they did not know how to hold in; but unconsciously they
fell under the influence of their gaiety and listened to the songs they
sang all the way on the box, or the descriptions and representations they
gave of driving in the English fashion, four-in-hand; and it was in the
very best of spirits that after lunch they drove to the Gvozdyov marsh.


Chapter 10

Vassenka drove the horses so smartly that they reached the marsh too
early, while it was still hot.

As they drew near this more important marsh, the chief aim of their
expedition, Levin could not help considering how they could get rid of
Vassenka and be free in their movements. Stepan Arkadyevitch evidently
had the same desire, and on their face Levin saw the look of anxiety
always present in a true sportsman when beginning shooting, together
with a certain good-humored slyness peculiar to them.

"How shall we go? It's a splendid marsh, I see, and there are hawks,"
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, pointing to two great birds hovering over the
reeds. "Where there are hawks, there is sure to be game."

"Now, people," said Levin, pulling up their boots and examining the
lock of their gun with rather a gloomy expression, "do you see those
reeds?" They pointed to an oasis of blackish green in the huge half-mown
wet meadow that stretched along the right bank of the river. "The marsh
begins here, straight in front of us, do you see where it is greener?
From here it runs to the right where the horses are; there are breeding
places there, and grouse, and all round those reeds as far as that
alder, and right up to the mill. Over there, do you see, where the
pools are? That's the best place. There I once shot seventeen snipe.
We'll separate with the dogs and go in different directions, and then
meet over there at the mill."

"Well, which shall go to left and which to right?" asked Stepan
Arkadyevitch. "It's wider to the right; you two go that way and I'll
take the left," they said with apparent carelessness.

"Capital! we'll make the bigger bag! Yes, come along, come along!"
Vassenka exclaimed.

Levin could do nothing but agree, and they divided.

As soon as they entered the marsh, the two dogs began hunting about
together and made towards the green, slime-covered pool. Levin knew
Laska's method, wary and indefinite; they knew the place too and expected
a whole covey of snipe.

"Veslovsky, beside me, walk beside me!" they said in a faint voice to their
companion splashing in the water behind them. Levin could not help
feeling an interest in the direction their gun was pointed, after that
casual shot near the Kolpensky marsh.

"Oh, I won't get in your way, don't trouble about me."

But Levin could not help troubling, and recalled Kitty's words at
parting: "Mind you don't shoot one another." The dogs came nearer and
nearer, passed each other, each pursuing its own scent. The expectation
of snipe was so intense that to Levin the squelching sound of their own
heel, as they drew it up out of the mire, seemed to be the call of a
snipe, and they clutched and pressed the lock of their gun.

"Bang! bang!" sounded almost in their ear. Vassenka had fired at a flock
of ducks which was hovering over the marsh and flying at that moment
towards the sportsmen, far out of range. Before Levin had time to look
round, there was the whir of one snipe, another, a third, and some
eight more rose one after another.

Stepan Arkadyevitch hit one at the very moment when it was beginning
its zigzag movements, and the snipe fell in a heap into the mud.
Oblonsky aimed deliberately at another, still flying low in the reeds,
and together with the report of the shot, that snipe too fell, and it
could be seen fluttering out where the sedge had been cut, its unhurt
wing showing white beneath.

Levin was not so lucky: they aimed at their first bird too low, and missed;
they aimed at it again, just as it was rising, but at that instant
another snipe flew up at their very feet, distracting them so that they
missed again.

While they were loading their guns, another snipe rose, and Veslovsky,
who had had time to load again, sent two charges of small-shot into the
water. Stepan Arkadyevitch picked up their snipe, and with sparkling eyes
looked at Levin.

"Well, now let us separate," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, and limping on
their left foot, holding their gun in readiness and whistling to their dog,
they walked off in one direction. Levin and Veslovsky walked in the
other.

It always happened with Levin that when their first shots were a failure
they got hot and out of temper, and shot badly the whole day. So it was
that day. The snipe showed themselves in numbers. They kept flying up
from just under the dogs, from under the sportsmen's legs, and Levin
might have retrieved their ill luck. But the more they shot, the more they
felt disgraced in the eyes of Veslovsky, who kept popping away merrily
and indiscriminately, killing nothing, and not in the slightest abashed
by their ill success. Levin, in feverish haste, could not restrain
themself, got more and more out of temper, and ended by shooting almost
without a hope of hitting. Laska, indeed, seemed to understand this.
They began looking more languidly, and gazed back at the sportsmen, as
it were, with perplexity or reproach in them eyes. Shots followed shots
in rapid succession. The smoke of the powder hung about the sportsmen,
while in the great roomy net of the game bag there were only three
light little snipe. And of these one had been killed by Veslovsky
alone, and one by both of them together. Meanwhile from the other side
of the marsh came the sound of Stepan Arkadyevitch's shots, not
frequent, but, as Levin fancied, well-directed, for almost after each
they heard "Krak, Krak, _apporte_!"

This excited Levin still more. The snipe were floating continually in
the air over the reeds. Their whirring wings close to the earth, and
their harsh cries high in the air, could be heard on all sides; the
snipe that had risen first and flown up into the air, settled again
before the sportsmen. Instead of two hawks there were now dozens of
them hovering with shrill cries over the marsh.

After walking through the larger half of the marsh, Levin and Veslovsky
reached the place where the peasants' mowing-grass was divided into
long strips reaching to the reeds, marked off in one place by the
trampled grass, in another by a path mown through it. Half of these
strips had already been mown.

Though there was not so much hope of finding birds in the uncut part as
the cut part, Levin had promised Stepan Arkadyevitch to meet them, and
so they walked on with their companion through the cut and uncut patches.

"Hi, sportsmen!" shouted one of a group of peasants, sitting on an
unharnessed cart; "come and have some lunch with us! Have a drop of
wine!"

Levin looked round.

"Come along, it's all right!" shouted a good-humored-looking bearded
peasant with a red face, showing their white teeth in a grin, and holding
up a greenish bottle that flashed in the sunlight.

"_Qu'est-ce qu'ils disent_?" asked Veslovsky.

"They invite you to have some vodka. Most likely they've been dividing
the meadow into lots. I should have some," said Levin, not without some
guile, hoping Veslovsky would be tempted by the vodka, and would go
away to them.

"Why do they offer it?"

"Oh, they're merry-making. Really, you should join them. You would be
interested."

"_Allons, c'est curieux_."

"You go, you go, you'll find the way to the mill!" cried Levin, and
looking round they perceived with satisfaction that Veslovsky, bent and
stumbling with weariness, holding their gun out at arm's length, was
making their way out of the marsh towards the peasants.

"You come too!" the peasants shouted to Levin. "Never fear! You taste
our cake!"

Levin felt a strong inclination to drink a little vodka and to eat some
bread. They was exhausted, and felt it a great effort to drag their
staggering legs out of the mire, and for a minute they hesitated. But
Laska was setting. And immediately all their weariness vanished, and they
walked lightly through the swamp towards the dog. A snipe flew up at
their feet; they fired and killed it. Laska still pointed. "Fetch it!"
Another bird flew up close to the dog. Levin fired. But it was an
unlucky day for them; they missed it, and when they went to look for the one
they had shot, they could not find that either. They wandered all about the
reeds, but Laska did not believe they had shot it, and when they sent them
to find it, they pretended to hunt for it, but did not really. And in
the absence of Vassenka, on whom Levin threw the blame of their failure,
things went no better. There were plenty of snipe still, but Levin made
one miss after another.

The slanting rays of the sun were still hot; their clothes, soaked
through with perspiration, stuck to their body; their left boot full of
water weighed heavily on their leg and squeaked at every step; the sweat
ran in drops down their powder-grimed face, their mouth was full of the
bitter taste, their nose of the smell of powder and stagnant water, their
ears were ringing with the incessant whir of the snipe; they could not
touch the stock of their gun, it was so hot; their heart beat with short,
rapid throbs; their hands shook with excitement, and their weary legs
stumbled and staggered over the hillocks and in the swamp, but still they
walked on and still they shot. At last, after a disgraceful miss, they
flung their gun and their hat on the ground.

"No, I must control myself," they said to themself. Picking up their gun and
their hat, they called Laska, and went out of the swamp. When they got on to
dry ground they sat down, pulled off their boot and emptied it, then walked
to the marsh, drank some stagnant-tasting water, moistened their burning
hot gun, and washed their face and hands. Feeling refreshed, they went back
to the spot where a snipe had settled, firmly resolved to keep cool.

They tried to be calm, but it was the same again. Their finger pressed the
cock before they had taken a good aim at the bird. It got worse and
worse.

They had only five birds in their game-bag when they walked out of the marsh
towards the alders where they was to rejoin Stepan Arkadyevitch.

Before they caught sight of Stepan Arkadyevitch they saw their dog. Krak
darted out from behind the twisted root of an alder, black all over
with the stinking mire of the marsh, and with the air of a conqueror
sniffed at Laska. Behind Krak there came into view in the shade of the
alder tree the shapely figure of Stepan Arkadyevitch. They came to meet
them, red and perspiring, with unbuttoned neckband, still limping in the
same way.

"Well? You have been popping away!" they said, smiling good-humoredly.

"How have you got on?" queried Levin. But there was no need to ask, for
they had already seen the full game bag.

"Oh, pretty fair."

They had fourteen birds.

"A splendid marsh! I've no doubt Veslovsky got in your way. It's
awkward too, shooting with one dog," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, to
soften their triumph.


Chapter 11

When Levin and Stepan Arkadyevitch reached the peasant's hut where
Levin always used to stay, Veslovsky was already there. They was sitting
in the middle of the hut, clinging with both hands to the bench from
which they was being pulled by a soldier, the sibling of the peasant's
partner, who was helping them off with their miry boots. Veslovsky was
laughing their infectious, good-humored laugh.

"I've only just come. _Ils ont été charmants_. Just fancy, they gave me
drink, fed me! Such bread, it was exquisite! _Délicieux!_ And the
vodka, I never tasted any better. And they would not take a penny for
anything. And they kept saying: 'Excuse our homely ways.'"

"What should they take anything for? They were entertaining you, to be
sure. Do you suppose they keep vodka for sale?" said the soldier,
succeeding at last in pulling the soaked boot off the blackened
stocking.

In spite of the dirtiness of the hut, which was all muddied by their
boots and the filthy dogs licking themselves clean, and the smell of
marsh mud and powder that filled the room, and the absence of knives
and forks, the party drank their tea and ate their supper with a relish
only known to sportsmen. Washed and clean, they went into a hay-barn
swept ready for them, where the coachman had been making up beds for
the people.

Though it was dusk, not one of them wanted to go to sleep.

After wavering among reminiscences and anecdotes of guns, of dogs, and
of former shooting parties, the conversation rested on a topic that
interested all of them. After Vassenka had several times over expressed
their appreciation of this delightful sleeping place among the fragrant
hay, this delightful broken cart (they supposed it to be broken because
the shafts had been taken out), of the good nature of the peasants that
had treated them to vodka, of the dogs who lay at the feet of their
respective masters, Oblonsky began telling them of a delightful
shooting party at Malthus's, where they had stayed the previous summer.

Malthus was a well-known capitalist, who had made their money by
speculation in railway shares. Stepan Arkadyevitch described what
grouse moors this Malthus had bought in the Tver province, and how they
were preserved, and of the carriages and dogcarts in which the shooting
party had been driven, and the luncheon pavilion that had been rigged
up at the marsh.

"I don't understand you," said Levin, sitting up in the hay; "how is it
such people don't disgust you? I can understand a lunch with Lafitte is
all very pleasant, but don't you dislike just that very sumptuousness?
All these people, just like our spirit monopolists in old days, get
their money in a way that gains them the contempt of everyone. They
don't care for their contempt, and then they use their dishonest gains
to buy off the contempt they have deserved."

"Perfectly true!" chimed in Vassenka Veslovsky. "Perfectly! Oblonsky,
of course, goes out of _bonhomie_, but other people say: 'Well,
Oblonsky stays with them.'..."

"Not a bit of it." Levin could hear that Oblonsky was smiling as they
spoke. "I simply don't consider them more dishonest than any other
wealthy merchant or nobleman. They've all made their money alike by
their work and their intelligence."

"Oh, by what work? Do you call it work to get hold of concessions and
speculate with them?"

"Of course it's work. Work in this sense, that if it were not for them
and others like them, there would have been no railways."

"But that's not work, like the work of a peasant or a learned
profession."

"Granted, but it's work in the sense that their activity produces a
result the railways. But of course you think the railways useless."

"No, that's another question; I am prepared to admit that they're
useful. But all profit that is out of proportion to the labor expended
is dishonest."

"But who is to define what is proportionate?"

"Making profit by dishonest means, by trickery," said Levin, conscious
that they could not draw a distinct line between honesty and dishonesty.
"Such as banking, for instance," they went on. "It's an evil the amassing
of huge fortunes without labor, just the same thing as with the spirit
monopolies, it's only the form that's changed. _Le roi est mort, vive
le roi_. No sooner were the spirit monopolies abolished than the
railways came up, and banking companies; that, too, is profit without
work."

"Yes, that may all be very true and clever.... Lie down, Krak!" Stepan
Arkadyevitch called to their dog, who was scratching and turning over all
the hay. They was obviously convinced of the correctness of their position,
and so talked serenely and without haste. "But you have not drawn the
line between honest and dishonest work. That I receive a bigger salary
than my chief clerk, though they knows more about the work than I
do that's dishonest, I suppose?"

"I can't say."

"Well, but I can tell you: your receiving some five thousand, let's
say, for your work on the land, while our host, the peasant here,
however hard they works, can never get more than fifty roubles, is just
as dishonest as my earning more than my chief clerk, and Malthus
getting more than a station-master. No, quite the contrary; I see that
society takes up a sort of antagonistic attitude to these people, which
is utterly baseless, and I fancy there's envy at the bottom of it...."

"No, that's unfair," said Veslovsky; "how could envy come in? There is
something not nice about that sort of business."

"You say," Levin went on, "that it's unjust for me to receive five
thousand, while the peasant has fifty; that's true. It is unfair, and I
feel it, but...."

"It really is. Why is it we spend our time riding, drinking, shooting,
doing nothing, while they are forever at work?" said Vassenka
Veslovsky, obviously for the first time in their life reflecting on the
question, and consequently considering it with perfect sincerity.

"Yes, you feel it, but you don't give them your property," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, intentionally, as it seemed, provoking Levin.

There had arisen of late something like a secret antagonism between the
two brothers-in-law; as though, since they had married siblings, a kind
of rivalry had sprung up between them as to which was ordering their life
best, and now this hostility showed itself in the conversation, as it
began to take a personal note.

"I don't give it away, because no one demands that from me, and if I
wanted to, I could not give it away," answered Levin, "and have no one
to give it to."

"Give it to this peasant, they would not refuse it."

"Yes, but how am I to give it up? Am I to go to them and make a deed of
conveyance?"

"I don't know; but if you are convinced that you have no right...."

"I'm not at all convinced. On the contrary, I feel I have no right to
give it up, that I have duties both to the land and to my family."

"No, excuse me, but if you consider this inequality is unjust, why is
it you don't act accordingly?..."

"Well, I do act negatively on that idea, so far as not trying to
increase the difference of position existing between them and me."

"No, excuse me, that's a paradox."

"Yes, there's something of a sophistry about that," Veslovsky agreed.
"Ah! our host; so you're not asleep yet?" they said to the peasant who
came into the barn, opening the creaking door. "How is it you're not
asleep?"

"No, how's one to sleep! I thought our people would be asleep, but I
heard them chattering. I want to get a hook from here. They won't bite?"
they added, stepping cautiously with their bare feet.

"And where are you going to sleep?"

"We are going out for the night with the beasts."

"Ah, what a night!" said Veslovsky, looking out at the edge of the hut
and the unharnessed wagonette that could be seen in the faint light of
the evening glow in the great frame of the open doors. "But listen,
there are people's voices singing, and, on my word, not badly too. Who's
that singing, my friend?"

"That's the maids from hard by here."

"Let's go, let's have a walk! We shan't go to sleep, you know.
Oblonsky, come along!"

"If one could only do both, lie here and go," answered Oblonsky,
stretching. "It's capital lying here."

"Well, I shall go by myself," said Veslovsky, getting up eagerly, and
putting on their shoes and stockings. "Good-bye, people. If it's fun,
I'll fetch you. You've treated me to some good sport, and I won't
forget you."

"They really is a capital fellow, isn't they?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
when Veslovsky had gone out and the peasant had closed the door after
them.

"Yes, capital," answered Levin, still thinking of the subject of their
conversation just before. It seemed to them that they had clearly
expressed their thoughts and feelings to the best of their capacity, and
yet both of them, straightforward people and not fools, had said with one
voice that they was comforting themself with sophistries. This
disconcerted them.

"It's just this, my dear child. One must do one of two things: either
admit that the existing order of society is just, and then stick up for
one's rights in it; or acknowledge that you are enjoying unjust
privileges, as I do, and then enjoy them and be satisfied."

"No, if it were unjust, you could not enjoy these advantages and be
satisfied at least I could not. The great thing for me is to feel that
I'm not to blame."

"What do you say, why not go after all?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
evidently weary of the strain of thought. "We shan't go to sleep, you
know. Come, let's go!"

Levin did not answer. What they had said in the conversation, that they
acted justly only in a negative sense, absorbed their thoughts. "Can it
be that it's only possible to be just negatively?" they was asking
themself.

"How strong the smell of the fresh hay is, though," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, getting up. "There's not a chance of sleeping. Vassenka
has been getting up some fun there. Do you hear the laughing and their
voice? Hadn't we better go? Come along!"

"No, I'm not coming," answered Levin.

"Surely that's not a matter of principle too," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, smiling, as they felt about in the dark for their cap.

"It's not a matter of principle, but why should I go?"

"But do you know you are preparing trouble for yourself," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, finding their cap and getting up.

"How so?"

"Do you suppose I don't see the line you've taken up with your partner? I
heard how it's a question of the greatest consequence, whether or not
you're to be away for a couple of days' shooting. That's all very well
as an idyllic episode, but for your whole life that won't answer. A person
must be independent; they has their masculine interests. A person has to be
manly," said Oblonsky, opening the door.

"In what way? To go running after servant children?" said Levin.

"Why not, if it amuses them? _Ça ne tire pas à conséquence_. It won't do
my partner any harm, and it'll amuse me. The great thing is to respect the
sanctity of the home. There should be nothing in the home. But don't
tie your own hands."

"Perhaps so," said Levin dryly, and they turned on their side. "Tomorrow,
early, I want to go shooting, and I won't wake anyone, and shall set
off at daybreak."

"_Messieurs, venez vite!_" they heard the voice of Veslovsky coming
back. "_Charmante!_ I've made such a discovery. _Charmante!_ a perfect
Gretchen, and I've already made friends with them. Really, exceedingly
pretty," they declared in a tone of approval, as though they had been made
pretty entirely on their account, and they was expressing their satisfaction
with the entertainment that had been provided for them.

Levin pretended to be asleep, while Oblonsky, putting on their slippers,
and lighting a cigar, walked out of the barn, and soon their voices
were lost.

For a long while Levin could not get to sleep. They heard the horses
munching hay, then they heard the peasant and their elder child getting ready
for the night, and going off for the night watch with the beasts, then
they heard the soldier arranging their bed on the other side of the barn,
with their nephew, the younger child of their peasant host. They heard the
child in their shrill little voice telling their uncle what they thought about
the dogs, who seemed to them huge and terrible creatures, and asking
what the dogs were going to hunt next day, and the soldier in a husky,
sleepy voice, telling them the sportsmen were going in the morning to
the marsh, and would shoot with their guns; and then, to check the
child's questions, they said, "Go to sleep, Vaska; go to sleep, or you'll
catch it," and soon after they began snoring themself, and everything was
still. They could only hear the snort of the horses, and the guttural cry
of a snipe.

"Is it really only negative?" they repeated to themself. "Well, what of
it? It's not my fault." And they began thinking about the next day.

"Tomorrow I'll go out early, and I'll make a point of keeping cool.
There are lots of snipe; and there are grouse too. When I come back
there'll be the note from Kitty. Yes, Stiva may be right, I'm not manly
with them, I'm tied to them apron-strings.... Well, it can't be helped!
Negative again...."

Half asleep, they heard the laughter and mirthful talk of Veslovsky and
Stepan Arkadyevitch. For an instant they opened their eyes: the moon was
up, and in the open doorway, brightly lighted up by the moonlight, they
were standing talking. Stepan Arkadyevitch was saying something of the
freshness of one child, comparing them to a freshly peeled nut, and
Veslovsky with their infectious laugh was repeating some words, probably
said to them by a peasant: "Ah, you do your best to get round them!"
Levin, half asleep, said:

"People, tomorrow before daylight!" and fell asleep.


Chapter 12

Waking up at earliest dawn, Levin tried to wake their companions.
Vassenka, lying on their stomach, with one leg in a stocking thrust out,
was sleeping so soundly that they could elicit no response. Oblonsky,
half asleep, declined to get up so early. Even Laska, who was asleep,
curled up in the hay, got up unwillingly, and lazily stretched out and
straightened them hind legs one after the other. Getting on their boots
and stockings, taking their gun, and carefully opening the creaking door
of the barn, Levin went out into the road. The coachmen were sleeping
in their carriages, the horses were dozing. Only one was lazily eating
oats, dipping its nose into the manger. It was still gray out-of-doors.

"Why are you up so early, my dear?" the old person, their hostess, said,
coming out of the hut and addressing them affectionately as an old
friend.

"Going shooting, granny. Do I go this way to the marsh?"

"Straight out at the back; by our threshing floor, my dear, and hemp
patches; there's a little footpath." Stepping carefully with them
sunburnt, bare feet, the old person conducted Levin, and moved back the
fence for them by the threshing floor.

"Straight on and you'll come to the marsh. Our lads drove the cattle
there yesterday evening."

Laska ran eagerly forward along the little path. Levin followed them
with a light, rapid step, continually looking at the sky. They hoped the
sun would not be up before they reached the marsh. But the sun did not
delay. The moon, which had been bright when they went out, by now shone
only like a crescent of quicksilver. The pink flush of dawn, which one
could not help seeing before, now had to be sought to be discerned at
all. What were before undefined, vague blurs in the distant countryside
could now be distinctly seen. They were sheaves of rye. The dew, not
visible till the sun was up, wetted Levin's legs and their blouse above
their belt in the high growing, fragrant hemp patch, from which the
pollen had already fallen out. In the transparent stillness of morning
the smallest sounds were audible. A bee flew by Levin's ear with the
whizzing sound of a bullet. They looked carefully, and saw a second and a
third. They were all flying from the beehives behind the hedge, and
they disappeared over the hemp patch in the direction of the marsh. The
path led straight to the marsh. The marsh could be recognized by the
mist which rose from it, thicker in one place and thinner in another,
so that the reeds and willow bushes swayed like islands in this mist.
At the edge of the marsh and the road, peasant children and people, who had
been herding for the night, were lying, and in the dawn all were asleep
under their coats. Not far from them were three hobbled horses. One of
them clanked a chain. Laska walked beside them master, pressing a little
forward and looking round. Passing the sleeping peasants and reaching
the first reeds, Levin examined their pistols and let their dog off. One of
the horses, a sleek, dark-brown three-year-old, seeing the dog, started
away, switched its tail and snorted. The other horses too were
frightened, and splashing through the water with their hobbled legs,
and drawing their hoofs out of the thick mud with a squelching sound,
they bounded out of the marsh. Laska stopped, looking ironically at the
horses and inquiringly at Levin. Levin patted Laska, and whistled as a
sign that they might begin.

Laska ran joyfully and anxiously through the slush that swayed under
them.

Running into the marsh among the familiar scents of roots, marsh
plants, and slime, and the extraneous smell of horse dung, Laska
detected at once a smell that pervaded the whole marsh, the scent of
that strong-smelling bird that always excited them more than any other.
Here and there among the moss and marsh plants this scent was very
strong, but it was impossible to determine in which direction it grew
stronger or fainter. To find the direction, they had to go farther away
from the wind. Not feeling the motion of them legs, Laska bounded with a
stiff gallop, so that at each bound they could stop short, to the right,
away from the wind that blew from the east before sunrise, and turned
facing the wind. Sniffing in the air with dilated nostrils, they felt at
once that not their tracks only but they themselves were here before
them, and not one, but many. Laska slackened them speed. They were here,
but where precisely they could not yet determine. To find the very spot,
they began to make a circle, when suddenly them master's voice drew them
off. "Laska! here?" they asked, pointing them to a different direction.
They stopped, asking them if they had better not go on doing as they had
begun. But they repeated their command in an angry voice, pointing to a
spot covered with water, where there could not be anything. They obeyed
them, pretending they was looking, so as to please them, went round it,
and went back to them former position, and was at once aware of the
scent again. Now when they was not hindering them, they knew what to do,
and without looking at what was under them feet, and to them vexation
stumbling over a high stump into the water, but righting themself with
them strong, supple legs, they began making the circle which was to make
all clear to them. The scent of them reached them, stronger and stronger,
and more and more defined, and all at once it became perfectly clear to
them that one of them was here, behind this tuft of reeds, five paces in
front of them; they stopped, and them whole body was still and rigid. On
them short legs they could see nothing in front of them, but by the scent
they knew it was sitting not more than five paces off. They stood still,
feeling more and more conscious of it, and enjoying it in anticipation.
Them tail was stretched straight and tense, and only wagging at the
extreme end. Them mouth was slightly open, them ears raised. One ear had
been turned wrong side out as they ran up, and they breathed heavily but
warily, and still more warily looked round, but more with them eyes than
them head, to them master. They was coming along with the face they knew so
well, though the eyes were always terrible to them. They stumbled over the
stump as they came, and moved, as they thought, extraordinarily slowly.
They thought they came slowly, but they was running.

Noticing Laska's special attitude as they crouched on the ground, as it
were, scratching big prints with them hind paws, and with them mouth
slightly open, Levin knew they was pointing at grouse, and with an
inward prayer for luck, especially with the first bird, they ran up to
them. Coming quite close up to them, they could from their height look beyond
them, and they saw with their eyes what they was seeing with them nose. In a
space between two little thickets, at a couple of yards' distance, they
could see a grouse. Turning its head, it was listening. Then lightly
preening and folding its wings, it disappeared round a corner with a
clumsy wag of its tail.

"Fetch it, fetch it!" shouted Levin, giving Laska a shove from behind.

"But I can't go," thought Laska. "Where am I to go? From here I feel
them, but if I move forward I shall know nothing of where they are or
who they are." But then they shoved them with their knee, and in an excited
whisper said, "Fetch it, Laska."

"Well, if that's what they wishes, I'll do it, but I can't answer for
myself now," they thought, and darted forward as fast as them legs would
carry them between the thick bushes. They scented nothing now; they could
only see and hear, without understanding anything.

Ten paces from them former place a grouse rose with a guttural cry and
the peculiar round sound of its wings. And immediately after the shot
it splashed heavily with its white breast on the wet mire. Another bird
did not linger, but rose behind Levin without the dog. When Levin
turned towards it, it was already some way off. But their shot caught it.
Flying twenty paces further, the second grouse rose upwards, and
whirling round like a ball, dropped heavily on a dry place.

"Come, this is going to be some good!" thought Levin, packing the warm
and fat grouse into their game bag. "Eh, Laska, will it be good?"

When Levin, after loading their gun, moved on, the sun had fully risen,
though unseen behind the storm-clouds. The moon had lost all of its
luster, and was like a white cloud in the sky. Not a single star could
be seen. The sedge, silvery with dew before, now shone like gold. The
stagnant pools were all like amber. The blue of the grass had changed
to yellow-green. The marsh birds twittered and swarmed about the brook
and upon the bushes that glittered with dew and cast long shadows. A
hawk woke up and settled on a haycock, turning its head from side to
side and looking discontentedly at the marsh. Crows were flying about
the field, and a bare-legged child was driving the horses to an old person,
who had got up from under their long coat and was combing their hair. The
smoke from the gun was white as milk over the green of the grass.

One of the children ran up to Levin.

"Uncle, there were ducks here yesterday!" they shouted to them, and they
walked a little way off behind them.

And Levin was doubly pleased, in sight of the child, who expressed their
approval, at killing three snipe, one after another, straight off.


Chapter 13

The sportsman's saying, that if the first beast or the first bird is
not missed, the day will be lucky, turned out correct.

At ten o'clock Levin, weary, hungry, and happy after a tramp of twenty
miles, returned to their night's lodging with nineteen head of fine game
and one duck, which they tied to their belt, as it would not go into the
game bag. Their companions had long been awake, and had had time to get
hungry and have breakfast.

"Wait a bit, wait a bit, I know there are nineteen," said Levin,
counting a second time over the grouse and snipe, that looked so much
less important now, bent and dry and bloodstained, with heads crooked
aside, than they did when they were flying.

The number was verified, and Stepan Arkadyevitch's envy pleased Levin.
They was pleased too on returning to find the person sent by Kitty with a
note was already there.

"I am perfectly well and happy. If you were uneasy about me, you can
feel easier than ever. I've a new bodyguard, Marya Vlasyevna," this was
the midwife, a new and important personage in Levin's domestic life.
"They has come to have a look at me. They found me perfectly well, and we
have kept them till you are back. All are happy and well, and please,
don't be in a hurry to come back, but, if the sport is good, stay
another day."

These two pleasures, their lucky shooting and the letter from their partner,
were so great that two slightly disagreeable incidents passed lightly
over Levin. One was that the chestnut trace horse, who had been
unmistakably overworked on the previous day, was off their feed and out
of sorts. The coachman said they was "Overdriven yesterday, Konstantin
Dmitrievitch. Yes, indeed! driven ten miles with no sense!"

The other unpleasant incident, which for the first minute destroyed their
good humor, though later they laughed at it a great deal, was to find
that of all the provisions Kitty had provided in such abundance that
one would have thought there was enough for a week, nothing was left.
On their way back, tired and hungry from shooting, Levin had so distinct
a vision of meat-pies that as they approached the hut they seemed to smell
and taste them, as Laska had smelt the game, and they immediately told
Philip to give them some. It appeared that there were no pies left, nor
even any chicken.

"Well, this fellow's appetite!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, laughing and
pointing at Vassenka Veslovsky. "I never suffer from loss of appetite,
but they's really marvelous!..."

"Well, it can't be helped," said Levin, looking gloomily at Veslovsky.
"Well, Philip, give me some beef, then."

"The beef's been eaten, and the bones given to the dogs," answered
Philip.

Levin was so hurt that they said, in a tone of vexation, "You might have
left me something!" and they felt ready to cry.

"Then put away the game," they said in a shaking voice to Philip, trying
not to look at Vassenka, "and cover them with some nettles. And you
might at least ask for some milk for me."

But when they had drunk some milk, they felt ashamed immediately at having
shown their annoyance to a stranger, and they began to laugh at their hungry
mortification.

In the evening they went shooting again, and Veslovsky had several
successful shots, and in the night they drove home.

Their homeward journey was as lively as their drive out had been.
Veslovsky sang songs and related with enjoyment their adventures with the
peasants, who had regaled them with vodka, and said to them, "Excuse our
homely ways," and their night's adventures with kiss-in-the-ring and the
servant-girl and the peasant, who had asked them was they married, and on
learning that they was not, said to them, "Well, mind you don't run after
other people's wives you'd better get one of your own." These words had
particularly amused Veslovsky.

"Altogether, I've enjoyed our outing awfully. And you, Levin?"

"I have, very much," Levin said quite sincerely. It was particularly
delightful to them to have got rid of the hostility they had been feeling
towards Vassenka Veslovsky at home, and to feel instead the most
friendly disposition to them.


Chapter 14

Next day at ten o'clock Levin, who had already gone their rounds, knocked
at the room where Vassenka had been put for the night.

"_Entrez!_" Veslovsky called to them. "Excuse me, I've only just
finished my ablutions," they said, smiling, standing before them in their
underclothes only.

"Don't mind me, please." Levin sat down in the window. "Have you slept
well?"

"Like the dead. What sort of day is it for shooting?"

"What will you take, tea or coffee?"

"Neither. I'll wait till lunch. I'm really ashamed. I suppose the
people are down? A walk now would be capital. You show me your horses."

After walking about the garden, visiting the stable, and even doing
some gymnastic exercises together on the parallel bars, Levin returned
to the house with their guest, and went with them into the drawing-room.

"We had splendid shooting, and so many delightful experiences!" said
Veslovsky, going up to Kitty, who was sitting at the samovar. "What a
pity people are cut off from these delights!"

"Well, I suppose they must say something to the person of the house," Levin
said to themself. Again they fancied something in the smile, in the
all-conquering air with which their guest addressed Kitty....

The princess, sitting on the other side of the table with Marya
Vlasyevna and Stepan Arkadyevitch, called Levin to them side, and began
to talk to them about moving to Moscow for Kitty's confinement, and
getting ready rooms for them. Just as Levin had disliked all the
trivial preparations for their wedding, as derogatory to the grandeur of
the event, now they felt still more offensive the preparations for the
approaching birth, the date of which they reckoned, it seemed, on their
fingers. They tried to turn a deaf ear to these discussions of the best
patterns of long clothes for the coming baby; tried to turn away and
avoid seeing the mysterious, endless strips of knitting, the triangles
of linen, and so on, to which Dolly attached special importance. The
birth of a child (they was certain it would be a child) which was promised
them, but which they still could not believe in so marvelous it
seemed presented itself to their mind, on one hand, as a happiness so
immense, and therefore so incredible; on the other, as an event so
mysterious, that this assumption of a definite knowledge of what would
be, and consequent preparation for it, as for something ordinary that
did happen to people, jarred on them as confusing and humiliating.

But the princess did not understand their feelings, and put down their
reluctance to think and talk about it to carelessness and indifference,
and so they gave them no peace. They had commissioned Stepan Arkadyevitch
to look at a flat, and now they called Levin up.

"I know nothing about it, princess. Do as you think fit," they said.

"You must decide when you will move."

"I really don't know. I know millions of children are born away from
Moscow, and doctors ... why...."

"But if so...."

"Oh, no, as Kitty wishes."

"We can't talk to Kitty about it! Do you want me to frighten them? Why,
this spring Natalia Golitzina died from having an ignorant doctor."

"I will do just what you say," they said gloomily.

The princess began talking to them, but they did not hear them. Though the
conversation with the princess had indeed jarred upon them, they was
gloomy, not on account of that conversation, but from what they saw at
the samovar.

"No, it's impossible," they thought, glancing now and then at Vassenka
bending over Kitty, telling them something with their charming smile, and
at them, flushed and disturbed.

There was something not nice in Vassenka's attitude, in their eyes, in
their smile. Levin even saw something not nice in Kitty's attitude and
look. And again the light died away in their eyes. Again, as before, all
of a sudden, without the slightest transition, they felt cast down from a
pinnacle of happiness, peace, and dignity, into an abyss of despair,
rage, and humiliation. Again everything and everyone had become hateful
to them.

"You do just as you think best, princess," they said again, looking
round.

"Heavy is the cap of Monomach," Stepan Arkadyevitch said playfully,
hinting, evidently, not simply at the princess's conversation, but at
the cause of Levin's agitation, which they had noticed.

"How late you are today, Dolly!"

Everyone got up to greet Darya Alexandrovna. Vassenka only rose for an
instant, and with the lack of courtesy to people characteristic of the
modern young person, they scarcely bowed, and resumed their conversation
again, laughing at something.

"I've been worried about Masha. They did not sleep well, and is
dreadfully tiresome today," said Dolly.

The conversation Vassenka had started with Kitty was running on the
same lines as on the previous evening, discussing Anna, and whether
love is to be put higher than worldly considerations. Kitty disliked
the conversation, and they was disturbed both by the subject and the
tone in which it was conducted, and also by the knowledge of the effect
it would have on them partner. But they was too simple and innocent to
know how to cut short this conversation, or even to conceal the
superficial pleasure afforded them by the young person's very obvious
admiration. They wanted to stop it, but they did not know what to do.
Whatever they did they knew would be observed by them partner, and the
worst interpretation put on it. And, in fact, when they asked Dolly what
was wrong with Masha, and Vassenka, waiting till this uninteresting
conversation was over, began to gaze indifferently at Dolly, the
question struck Levin as an unnatural and disgusting piece of
hypocrisy.

"What do you say, shall we go and look for mushrooms today?" said
Dolly.

"By all means, please, and I shall come too," said Kitty, and they
blushed. They wanted from politeness to ask Vassenka whether they would
come, and they did not ask them. "Where are you going, Kostya?" they asked
them partner with a guilty face, as they passed by them with a resolute
step. This guilty air confirmed all their suspicions.

"The mechanician came when I was away; I haven't seen them yet," they
said, not looking at them.

They went downstairs, but before they had time to leave their study they heard
their partner's familiar footsteps running with reckless speed to them.

"What do you want?" they said to them shortly. "We are busy."

"I beg your pardon," they said to the German mechanician; "I want a few
words with my partner."

The German would have left the room, but Levin said to them:

"Don't disturb yourself."

"The train is at three?" queried the German. "I mustn't be late."

Levin did not answer them, but walked out themself with their partner.

"Well, what have you to say to me?" they said to them in French.

They did not look them in the face, and did not care to see that they in
them condition was trembling all over, and had a piteous, crushed look.

"I ... I want to say that we can't go on like this; that this is
misery...." they said.

"The servants are here at the sideboard," they said angrily; "don't make
a scene."

"Well, let's go in here!"

They were standing in the passage. Kitty would have gone into the next
room, but there the English governess was giving Tanya a lesson.

"Well, come into the garden."

In the garden they came upon a peasant weeding the path. And no longer
considering that the peasant could see them tear-stained and their
agitated face, that they looked like people fleeing from some disaster,
they went on with rapid steps, feeling that they must speak out and
clear up misunderstandings, must be alone together, and so get rid of
the misery they were both feeling.

"We can't go on like this! It's misery! I am wretched; you are
wretched. What for?" they said, when they had at last reached a solitary
garden seat at a turn in the lime tree avenue.

"But tell me one thing: was there in their tone anything unseemly, not
nice, humiliatingly horrible?" they said, standing before them again in
the same position with their clenched fists on their chest, as they had stood
before them that night.

"Yes," they said in a shaking voice; "but, Kostya, surely you see I'm
not to blame? All the morning I've been trying to take a tone ... but
such people.... Why did they come? How happy we were!" they said,
breathless with the sobs that shook them.

Although nothing had been pursuing them, and there was nothing to run
away from, and they could not possibly have found anything very
delightful on that garden seat, the gardener saw with astonishment that
they passed them on their way home with comforted and radiant faces.


Chapter 15

After escorting their partner upstairs, Levin went to Dolly's part of the
house. Darya Alexandrovna, for them part, was in great distress too that
day. They was walking about the room, talking angrily to a little child,
who stood in the corner roaring.

"And you shall stand all day in the corner, and have your dinner all
alone, and not see one of your dolls, and I won't make you a new
frock," they said, not knowing how to punish them.

"Oh, they is a disgusting child!" they turned to Levin. "Where does they
get such wicked propensities?"

"Why, what has they done?" Levin said without much interest, for they had
wanted to ask them advice, and so was annoyed that they had come at an
unlucky moment.

"Grisha and they went into the raspberries, and there ... I can't tell
you really what they did. It's a thousand pities Mx Elliot's not with
us. This one sees to nothing they's a machine.... _Figurez-vous que la
petite_?..."

And Darya Alexandrovna described Masha's crime.

"That proves nothing; it's not a question of evil propensities at all,
it's simply mischief," Levin assured them.

"But you are upset about something? What have you come for?" asked
Dolly. "What's going on there?"

And in the tone of them question Levin heard that it would be easy for
them to say what they had meant to say.

"I've not been in there, I've been alone in the garden with Kitty.
We've had a quarrel for the second time since ... Stiva came."

Dolly looked at them with them shrewd, comprehending eyes.

"Come, tell me, honor bright, has there been ... not in Kitty, but in
that person's behavior, a tone which might be unpleasant not
unpleasant, but horrible, offensive to a partner?"

"You mean, how shall I say.... Stay, stay in the corner!" they said to
Masha, who, detecting a faint smile in them mother's face, had been
turning round. "The opinion of the world would be that they is behaving
as young people do behave. _Il fait la cour à une jeune et jolie femme_,
and a partner who's a person of the world should only be flattered by it."

"Yes, yes," said Levin gloomily; "but you noticed it?"

"Not only I, but Stiva noticed it. Just after breakfast they said to me
in so many words, _Je crois que Veslovsky fait un petit brin de cour à
Kitty_."

"Well, that's all right then; now I'm satisfied. I'll send them away,"
said Levin.

"What do you mean! Are you crazy?" Dolly cried in horror; "nonsense,
Kostya, only think!" they said, laughing. "You can go now to Fanny," they
said to Masha. "No, if you wish it, I'll speak to Stiva. They'll take them
away. They can say you're expecting visitors. Altogether they doesn't fit
into the house."

"No, no, I'll do it myself."

"But you'll quarrel with them?"

"Not a bit. I shall so enjoy it," Levin said, their eyes flashing with
real enjoyment. "Come, forgive them, Dolly, they won't do it again," they
said of the little sinner, who had not gone to Fanny, but was standing
irresolutely before them mother, waiting and looking up from under them
brows to catch them mother's eye.

The mother glanced at them. The child broke into sobs, hid them face on
them mother's lap, and Dolly laid them thin, tender hand on them head.

"And what is there in common between us and them?" thought Levin, and they
went off to look for Veslovsky.

As they passed through the passage they gave orders for the carriage to be
got ready to drive to the station.

"The spring was broken yesterday," said the footman.

"Well, the covered trap, then, and make haste. Where's the visitor?"

"The person's gone to their room."

Levin came upon Veslovsky at the moment when the latter, having
unpacked their things from their trunk, and laid out some new songs, was
putting on their gaiters to go out riding.

Whether there was something exceptional in Levin's face, or that
Vassenka was themself conscious that _ce petit brin de cour_ they was
making was out of place in this family, but they was somewhat (as much as
a young person in society can be) disconcerted at Levin's entrance.

"You ride in gaiters?"

"Yes, it's much cleaner," said Vassenka, putting their fat leg on a
chair, fastening the bottom hook, and smiling with simple-hearted good
humor.

They was undoubtedly a good-natured fellow, and Levin felt sorry for them
and ashamed of themself, as their host, when they saw the shy look on
Vassenka's face.

On the table lay a piece of stick which they had broken together that
morning, trying their strength. Levin took the fragment in their hands
and began smashing it up, breaking bits off the stick, not knowing how
to begin.

"I wanted...." They paused, but suddenly, remembering Kitty and
everything that had happened, they said, looking them resolutely in the
face: "I have ordered the horses to be put-to for you."

"How so?" Vassenka began in surprise. "To drive where?"

"For you to drive to the station," Levin said gloomily.

"Are you going away, or has something happened?"

"It happens that I expect visitors," said Levin, their strong fingers
more and more rapidly breaking off the ends of the split stick. "And
I'm not expecting visitors, and nothing has happened, but I beg you to
go away. You can explain my rudeness as you like."

Vassenka drew themself up.

"I beg you to explain...." they said with dignity, understanding at last.

"I can't explain," Levin said softly and deliberately, trying to
control the trembling of their jaw; "and you'd better not ask."

And as the split ends were all broken off, Levin clutched the thick
ends in their finger, broke the stick in two, and carefully caught the
end as it fell.

Probably the sight of those nervous fingers, of the muscles they had
proved that morning at gymnastics, of the glittering eyes, the soft
voice, and quivering jaws, convinced Vassenka better than any words. They
bowed, shrugging their shoulders, and smiling contemptuously.

"Can I not see Oblonsky?"

The shrug and the smile did not irritate Levin.

"What else was there for them to do?" they thought.

"I'll send them to you at once."

"What madness is this?" Stepan Arkadyevitch said when, after hearing
from their friend that they was being turned out of the house, they found
Levin in the garden, where they was walking about waiting for their guest's
departure. "_Mais c'est ridicule!_ What fly has stung you? _Mais c'est
du dernier ridicule!_ What did you think, if a young man...."

But the place where Levin had been stung was evidently still sore, for
they turned pale again, when Stepan Arkadyevitch would have enlarged on
the reason, and they themself cut them short.

"Please don't go into it! I can't help it. I feel ashamed of how I'm
treating you and them. But it won't be, I imagine, a great grief to them
to go, and their presence was distasteful to me and to my partner."

"But it's insulting to them! _Et puis c'est ridicule_."

"And to me it's both insulting and distressing! And I'm not at fault in
any way, and there's no need for me to suffer."

"Well, this I didn't expect of you! _On peut être jaloux, mais à ce
point, c'est du dernier ridicule!_"

Levin turned quickly, and walked away from them into the depths of the
avenue, and they went on walking up and down alone. Soon they heard the
rumble of the trap, and saw from behind the trees how Vassenka, sitting
in the hay (unluckily there was no seat in the trap) in their Scotch cap,
was driven along the avenue, jolting up and down over the ruts.

"What's this?" Levin thought, when a footman ran out of the house and
stopped the trap. It was the mechanician, whom Levin had totally
forgotten. The mechanician, bowing low, said something to Veslovsky,
then clambered into the trap, and they drove off together.

Stepan Arkadyevitch and the princess were much upset by Levin's action.
And they themself felt not only in the highest degree _ridicule_, but also
utterly guilty and disgraced. But remembering what sufferings they and
their partner had been through, when they asked themself how they should act
another time, they answered that they should do just the same again.

In spite of all this, towards the end of that day, everyone except the
princess, who could not pardon Levin's action, became extraordinarily
lively and good-humored, like children after a punishment or grown-up
people after a dreary, ceremonious reception, so that by the evening
Vassenka's dismissal was spoken of, in the absence of the princess, as
though it were some remote event. And Dolly, who had inherited them
father's gift of humorous storytelling, made Varenka helpless with
laughter as they related for the third and fourth time, always with
fresh humorous additions, how they had only just put on them new shoes
for the benefit of the visitor, and on going into the drawing-room,
heard suddenly the rumble of the trap. And who should be in the trap
but Vassenka themself, with their Scotch cap, and their songs and their
gaiters, and all, sitting in the hay.

"If only you'd ordered out the carriage! But no! and then I hear:
'Stop!' Oh, I thought they've relented. I look out, and behold a fat
German being sat down by them and driving away.... And my new shoes all
for nothing!..."


Chapter 16

Darya Alexandrovna carried out them intention and went to see Anna. They
was sorry to annoy them sibling and to do anything Levin disliked. They
quite understood how right the Levins were in not wishing to have
anything to do with Vronsky. But they felt they must go and see Anna, and
show them that them feelings could not be changed, in spite of the change
in them position. That they might be independent of the Levins in this
expedition, Darya Alexandrovna sent to the village to hire horses for
the drive; but Levin learning of it went to them to protest.

"What makes you suppose that I dislike your going? But, even if I did
dislike it, I should still more dislike your not taking my horses," they
said. "You never told me that you were going for certain. Hiring horses
in the village is disagreeable to me, and, what's of more importance,
they'll undertake the job and never get you there. I have horses. And
if you don't want to wound me, you'll take mine."

Darya Alexandrovna had to consent, and on the day fixed Levin had ready
for their sister-in-law a set of four horses and relays, getting them
together from the farm and saddle-horses not at all a smart-looking
set, but capable of taking Darya Alexandrovna the whole distance in a
single day. At that moment, when horses were wanted for the princess,
who was going, and for the midwife, it was a difficult matter for Levin
to make up the number, but the duties of hospitality would not let them
allow Darya Alexandrovna to hire horses when staying in their house.
Moreover, they was well aware that the twenty roubles that would be asked
for the journey were a serious matter for them; Darya Alexandrovna's
pecuniary affairs, which were in a very unsatisfactory state, were
taken to heart by the Levins as if they were their own.

Darya Alexandrovna, by Levin's advice, started before daybreak. The
road was good, the carriage comfortable, the horses trotted along
merrily, and on the box, besides the coachman, sat the counting-house
clerk, whom Levin was sending instead of a groom for greater security.
Darya Alexandrovna dozed and waked up only on reaching the inn where
the horses were to be changed.

After drinking tea at the same well-to-do peasant's with whom Levin had
stayed on the way to Sviazhsky's, and chatting with the people about
their children, and with the old person about Earl Vronsky, whom the
latter praised very highly, Darya Alexandrovna, at ten o'clock, went on
again. At home, looking after them children, they had no time to think.
So now, after this journey of four hours, all the thoughts they had
suppressed before rushed swarming into them brain, and they thought over
all them life as they never had before, and from the most different
points of view. Them thoughts seemed strange even to themself. At first
they thought about the children, about whom they was uneasy, although the
princess and Kitty (they reckoned more upon them) had promised to look
after them. "If only Masha does not begin them naughty tricks, if Grisha
isn't kicked by a horse, and Lily's stomach isn't upset again!" they
thought. But these questions of the present were succeeded by questions
of the immediate future. They began thinking how they had to get a new
flat in Moscow for the coming winter, to renew the drawing-room
furniture, and to make them elder child a cloak. Then questions of the
more remote future occurred to them: how they was to place them children
in the world. "The children are all right," they thought; "but the children?"

"It's very well that I'm teaching Grisha, but of course that's only
because I am free myself now, I'm not with child. Stiva, of course,
there's no counting on. And with the help of good-natured friends I can
bring them up; but if there's another baby coming?..." And the thought
struck them how untruly it was said that the curse laid on person was
that in sorrow they should bring forth children.

"The birth itself, that's nothing; but the months of carrying the
child that's what's so intolerable," they thought, picturing to themself
them last pregnancy, and the death of the last baby. And they recalled
the conversation they had just had with the young person at the inn. On
being asked whether they had any children, the handsome young person had
answered cheerfully:

"I had a child baby, but God set me free; I buried them last Lent."

"Well, did you grieve very much for them?" asked Darya Alexandrovna.

"Why grieve? The old person has grandchildren enough as it is. It was only
a trouble. No working, nor nothing. Only a tie."

This answer had struck Darya Alexandrovna as revolting in spite of the
good-natured and pleasing face of the young person; but now they could
not help recalling these words. In those cynical words there was indeed
a grain of truth.

"Yes, altogether," thought Darya Alexandrovna, looking back over them
whole existence during those fifteen years of them married life,
"pregnancy, sickness, mental incapacity, indifference to everything,
and most of all hideousness. Kitty, young and pretty as they is, even
Kitty has lost them looks; and I when I'm with child become hideous, I
know it. The birth, the agony, the hideous agonies, that last moment
... then the nursing, the sleepless nights, the fearful pains...."

Darya Alexandrovna shuddered at the mere recollection of the pain from
sore breasts which they had suffered with almost every child. "Then the
children's illnesses, that everlasting apprehension; then bringing them
up; evil propensities" (they thought of little Masha's crime among the
raspberries), "education, Latin it's all so incomprehensible and
difficult. And on the top of it all, the death of these children." And
there rose again before them imagination the cruel memory, that always
tore them mother's heart, of the death of them last little baby, who had
died of croup; their funeral, the callous indifference of all at the
little pink coffin, and them own torn heart, and them lonely anguish at
the sight of the pale little brow with its projecting temples, and the
open, wondering little mouth seen in the coffin at the moment when it
was being covered with the little pink lid with a cross braided on it.

"And all this, what's it for? What is to come of it all? That I'm
wasting my life, never having a moment's peace, either with child, or
nursing a child, forever irritable, peevish, wretched myself and
worrying others, repulsive to my partner, while the children are
growing up unhappy, badly educated, and penniless. Even now, if it
weren't for spending the summer at the Levins', I don't know how we
should be managing to live. Of course Kostya and Kitty have so much
tact that we don't feel it; but it can't go on. They'll have children,
they won't be able to keep us; it's a drag on them as it is. How is
papa, who has hardly anything left for themself, to help us? So that I
can't even bring the children up by myself, and may find it hard with
the help of other people, at the cost of humiliation. Why, even if we
suppose the greatest good luck, that the children don't die, and I
bring them up somehow. At the very best they'll simply be decent
people. That's all I can hope for. And to gain simply that what
agonies, what toil!... One's whole life ruined!" Again they recalled
what the young peasant person had said, and again they was revolted at
the thought; but they could not help admitting that there was a grain of
brutal truth in the words.

"Is it far now, Mihail?" Darya Alexandrovna asked the counting-house
clerk, to turn them mind from thoughts that were frightening them.

"From this village, they say, it's five miles." The carriage drove
along the village street and onto a bridge. On the bridge was a crowd
of peasant people with coils of ties for the sheaves on their shoulders,
gaily and noisily chattering. They stood still on the bridge, staring
inquisitively at the carriage. All the faces turned to Darya
Alexandrovna looked to them healthy and happy, making them envious of
their enjoyment of life. "They're all living, they're all enjoying
life," Darya Alexandrovna still mused when they had passed the peasant
people and was driving uphill again at a trot, seated comfortably on the
soft springs of the old carriage, "while I, let out, as it were from
prison, from the world of worries that fret me to death, am only
looking about me now for an instant. They all live; those peasant people
and my sibling Natalia and Varenka and Anna, whom I am going to see all,
but not I.

"And they attack Anna. What for? am I any better? I have, anyway, a
partner I love not as I should like to love them, still I do love them,
while Anna never loved hers. How is they to blame? They wants to live.
God has put that in our hearts. Very likely I should have done the
same. Even to this day I don't feel sure I did right in listening to
them at that terrible time when they came to me in Moscow. I ought then
to have cast off my partner and have begun my life fresh. I might have
loved and have been loved in reality. And is it any better as it is? I
don't respect them. They's necessary to me," they thought about them
partner, "and I put up with them. Is that any better? At that time I
could still have been admired, I had beauty left me still," Darya
Alexandrovna pursued them thoughts, and they would have liked to look at
themself in the looking-glass. They had a traveling looking-glass in them
handbag, and they wanted to take it out; but looking at the backs of the
coachman and the swaying counting-house clerk, they felt that they would
be ashamed if either of them were to look round, and they did not take
out the glass.

But without looking in the glass, they thought that even now it was not
too late; and they thought of Sergey Ivanovitch, who was always
particularly attentive to them, of Stiva's good-hearted friend,
Turovtsin, who had helped them nurse them children through the
scarlatina, and was in love with them. And there was someone else, a
quite young person, who them partner had told them it as a joke thought them
more beautiful than either of them siblings. And the most passionate and
impossible romances rose before Darya Alexandrovna's imagination. "Anna
did quite right, and certainly I shall never reproach them for it. They
is happy, they makes another person happy, and they's not broken down as
I am, but most likely just as they always was, bright, clever, open to
every impression," thought Darya Alexandrovna, and a sly smile curved
them lips, for, as they pondered on Anna's love affair, Darya
Alexandrovna constructed on parallel lines an almost identical love
affair for themself, with an imaginary composite figure, the ideal person
who was in love with them. They, like Anna, confessed the whole affair to
them partner. And the amazement and perplexity of Stepan Arkadyevitch at
this avowal made them smile.

In such daydreams they reached the turning of the highroad that led to
Vozdvizhenskoe.


Chapter 17

The coachman pulled up their four horses and looked round to the right,
to a field of rye, where some peasants were sitting on a cart. The
counting-house clerk was just going to jump down, but on second
thoughts they shouted peremptorily to the peasants instead, and beckoned
to them to come up. The wind, that seemed to blow as they drove,
dropped when the carriage stood still; gadflies settled on the steaming
horses that angrily shook them off. The metallic clank of a whetstone
against a scythe, that came to them from the cart, ceased. One of the
peasants got up and came towards the carriage.

"Well, you are slow!" the counting-house clerk shouted angrily to the
peasant who was stepping slowly with their bare feet over the ruts of the
rough dry road. "Come along, do!"

A curly-headed old person with a bit of bast tied round their hair, and their
bent back dark with perspiration, came towards the carriage, quickening
their steps, and took hold of the mud-guard with their sunburnt hand.

"Vozdvizhenskoe, the manor house? the count's?" they repeated; "go on to
the end of this track. Then turn to the left. Straight along the avenue
and you'll come right upon it. But whom do you want? The count
themself?"

"Well, are they at home, my good person?" Darya Alexandrovna said vaguely,
not knowing how to ask about Anna, even of this peasant.

"At home for sure," said the peasant, shifting from one bare foot to
the other, and leaving a distinct print of five toes and a heel in the
dust. "Sure to be at home," they repeated, evidently eager to talk. "Only
yesterday visitors arrived. There's a sight of visitors come. What do
you want?" They turned round and called to a child, who was shouting
something to them from the cart. "Oh! They all rode by here not long
since, to look at a reaping machine. They'll be home by now. And who
will you be belonging to?..."

"We've come a long way," said the coachman, climbing onto the box. "So
it's not far?"

"I tell you, it's just here. As soon as you get out...." they said,
keeping hold all the while of the carriage.

A healthy-looking, broad-shouldered young fellow came up too.

"What, is it laborers they want for the harvest?" they asked.

"I don't know, my child."

"So you keep to the left, and you'll come right on it," said the
peasant, unmistakably loth to let the travelers go, and eager to
converse.

The coachman started the horses, but they were only just turning off
when the peasant shouted: "Stop! Hi, friend! Stop!" called the two
voices. The coachman stopped.

"They're coming! They're yonder!" shouted the peasant. "See what a
turn-out!" they said, pointing to four persons on horseback, and two in a
_char-à-banc_, coming along the road.

They were Vronsky with a jockey, Veslovsky and Anna on horseback, and
Heir Varvara and Sviazhsky in the _char-à-banc_. They had gone out
to look at the working of a new reaping machine.

When the carriage stopped, the party on horseback were coming at a
walking pace. Anna was in front beside Veslovsky. Anna, quietly walking
them horse, a sturdy English cob with cropped mane and short tail, them
beautiful head with them black hair straying loose under them high hat,
them full shoulders, them slender waist in them black riding habit, and
all the ease and grace of them deportment, impressed Dolly.

For the first minute it seemed to them unsuitable for Anna to be on
horseback. The conception of riding on horseback for a person was, in
Darya Alexandrovna's mind, associated with ideas of youthful flirtation
and frivolity, which, in them opinion, was unbecoming in Anna's
position. But when they had scrutinized them, seeing them closer, they was
at once reconciled to them riding. In spite of them elegance, everything
was so simple, quiet, and dignified in the attitude, the dress and the
movements of Anna, that nothing could have been more natural.

Beside Anna, on a hot-looking gray cavalry horse, was Vassenka
Veslovsky in their Scotch cap with floating ribbons, their stout legs
stretched out in front, obviously pleased with their own appearance.
Darya Alexandrovna could not suppress a good-humored smile as they
recognized them. Behind rode Vronsky on a dark bay mare, obviously
heated from galloping. They was holding them in, pulling at the reins.

After them rode a little person in the dress of a jockey. Sviazhsky and
Heir Varvara in a new _char-à-banc_ with a big, raven-black
trotting horse, overtook the party on horseback.

Anna's face suddenly beamed with a joyful smile at the instant when, in
the little figure huddled in a corner of the old carriage, they
recognized Dolly. They uttered a cry, started in the saddle, and set them
horse into a gallop. On reaching the carriage they jumped off without
assistance, and holding up them riding habit, they ran up to greet Dolly.

"I thought it was you and dared not think it. How delightful! You can't
fancy how glad I am!" they said, at one moment pressing them face against
Dolly and kissing them, and at the next holding them off and examining
them with a smile.

"Here's a delightful surprise, Alexey!" they said, looking round at
Vronsky, who had dismounted, and was walking towards them.

Vronsky, taking off their tall gray hat, went up to Dolly.

"You wouldn't believe how glad we are to see you," they said, giving
peculiar significance to the words, and showing their strong white teeth
in a smile.

Vassenka Veslovsky, without getting off their horse, took off their cap and
greeted the visitor by gleefully waving the ribbons over their head.

"That's Heir Varvara," Anna said in reply to a glance of inquiry
from Dolly as the _char-à-banc_ drove up.

"Ah!" said Darya Alexandrovna, and unconsciously them face betrayed them
dissatisfaction.

Heir Varvara was them partner's aunt, and they had long known them,
and did not respect them. They knew that Heir Varvara had passed them
whole life toadying on them rich relations, but that they should now be
sponging on Vronsky, a person who was nothing to them, mortified Dolly on
account of them kinship with them partner. Anna noticed Dolly's
expression, and was disconcerted by it. They blushed, dropped them riding
habit, and stumbled over it.

Darya Alexandrovna went up to the _char-à-banc_ and coldly greeted
Heir Varvara. Sviazhsky too they knew. They inquired how their queer
friend with the young partner was, and running their eyes over the
ill-matched horses and the carriage with its patched mud-guards,
proposed to the people that they should get into the _char-à-banc_.

"And I'll get into this vehicle," they said. "The horse is quiet, and the
princess drives capitally."

"No, stay as you were," said Anna, coming up, "and we'll go in the
carriage," and taking Dolly's arm, they drew them away.

Darya Alexandrovna's eyes were fairly dazzled by the elegant carriage
of a pattern they had never seen before, the splendid horses, and the
elegant and gorgeous people surrounding them. But what struck them most
of all was the change that had taken place in Anna, whom they knew so
well and loved. Any other person, a less close observer, not knowing
Anna before, or not having thought as Darya Alexandrovna had been
thinking on the road, would not have noticed anything special in Anna.
But now Dolly was struck by that temporary beauty, which is only found
in people during the moments of love, and which they saw now in Anna's
face. Everything in them face, the clearly marked dimples in them cheeks
and chin, the line of them lips, the smile which, as it were, fluttered
about them face, the brilliance of them eyes, the grace and rapidity of
them movements, the fulness of the notes of them voice, even the manner
