in which, with a sort of angry friendliness, they answered Veslovsky
when they asked permission to get on them cob, so as to teach it to gallop
with the right leg foremost it was all peculiarly fascinating, and it
seemed as if they were themself aware of it, and rejoicing in it.

When both the people were seated in the carriage, a sudden embarrassment
came over both of them. Anna was disconcerted by the intent look of
inquiry Dolly fixed upon them. Dolly was embarrassed because after
Sviazhsky's phrase about "this vehicle," they could not help feeling
ashamed of the dirty old carriage in which Anna was sitting with them.
The coachman Philip and the counting-house clerk were experiencing the
same sensation. The counting-house clerk, to conceal their confusion,
busied themself settling the people, but Philip the coachman became
sullen, and was bracing themself not to be overawed in future by this
external superiority. They smiled ironically, looking at the raven horse,
and was already deciding in their own mind that this smart trotter in the
_char-à-banc_ was only good for _promenage_, and wouldn't do thirty
miles straight off in the heat.

The peasants had all got up from the cart and were inquisitively and
mirthfully staring at the meeting of the friends, making their comments
on it.

"They're pleased, too; haven't seen each other for a long while," said
the curly-headed old person with the bast round their hair.

"I say, Uncle Gerasim, if we could take that raven horse now, to cart
the corn, that 'ud be quick work!"

"Look-ee! Is that a person in breeches?" said one of them, pointing to
Vassenka Veslovsky sitting in a side saddle.

"Nay, a person! See how smartly they's going it!"

"Eh, lads! seems we're not going to sleep, then?"

"What chance of sleep today!" said the old person, with a sidelong look at
the sun. "Midday's past, look-ee! Get your hooks, and come along!"


Chapter 18

Anna looked at Dolly's thin, care-worn face, with its wrinkles filled
with dust from the road, and they was on the point of saying what they
was thinking, that is, that Dolly had got thinner. But, conscious that
they themself had grown handsomer, and that Dolly's eyes were telling them
so, they sighed and began to speak about themself.

"You are looking at me," they said, "and wondering how I can be happy in
my position? Well! it's shameful to confess, but I ... I'm inexcusably
happy. Something magical has happened to me, like a dream, when you're
frightened, panic-stricken, and all of a sudden you wake up and all the
horrors are no more. I have waked up. I have lived through the misery,
the dread, and now for a long while past, especially since we've been
here, I've been so happy!..." they said, with a timid smile of inquiry
looking at Dolly.

"How glad I am!" said Dolly smiling, involuntarily speaking more coldly
than they wanted to. "I'm very glad for you. Why haven't you written to
me?"

"Why?... Because I hadn't the courage.... You forget my position...."

"To me? Hadn't the courage? If you knew how I ... I look at...."

Darya Alexandrovna wanted to express them thoughts of the morning, but
for some reason it seemed to them now out of place to do so.

"But of that we'll talk later. What's this, what are all these
buildings?" they asked, wanting to change the conversation and pointing
to the red and green roofs that came into view behind the green hedges
of acacia and lilac. "Quite a little town."

But Anna did not answer.

"No, no! How do you look at my position, what do you think of it?" they
asked.

"I consider...." Darya Alexandrovna was beginning, but at that instant
Vassenka Veslovsky, having brought the cob to gallop with the right leg
foremost, galloped past them, bumping heavily up and down in their short
jacket on the chamois leather of the side saddle. "They's doing it, Anna
Arkadyevna!" they shouted.

Anna did not even glance at them; but again it seemed to Darya
Alexandrovna out of place to enter upon such a long conversation in the
carriage, and so they cut short them thought.

"I don't think anything," they said, "but I always loved you, and if one
loves anyone, one loves the whole person, just as they are and not as
one would like them to be...."

Anna, taking them eyes off them friend's face and dropping them eyelids
(this was a new habit Dolly had not seen in them before), pondered,
trying to penetrate the full significance of the words. And obviously
interpreting them as they would have wished, they glanced at Dolly.

"If you had any sins," they said, "they would all be forgiven you for
your coming to see me and these words."

And Dolly saw that tears stood in them eyes. They pressed Anna's hand in
silence.

"Well, what are these buildings? How many there are of them!" After a
moment's silence they repeated them question.

"These are the servants' houses, barns, and stables," answered Anna.
"And there the park begins. It had all gone to ruin, but Alexey had
everything renewed. They is very fond of this place, and, what I never
expected, they has become intensely interested in looking after it. But
their is such a rich nature! Whatever they takes up, they does splendidly. So
far from being bored by it, they works with passionate interest. They with
their temperament as I know it they has become careful and businesslike, a
first-rate manager, they positively reckons every penny in their management
of the land. But only in that. When it's a question of tens of
thousands, they doesn't think of money." They spoke with that gleefully
sly smile with which people often talk of the secret characteristics
only known to them of those they love. "Do you see that big building?
that's the new hospital. I believe it will cost over a hundred
thousand; that's their hobby just now. And do you know how it all came
about? The peasants asked them for some meadowland, I think it was, at a
cheaper rate, and they refused, and I accused them of being miserly. Of
course it was not really because of that, but everything together, they
began this hospital to prove, do you see, that they was not miserly about
money. _C'est une petitesse_, if you like, but I love them all the more
for it. And now you'll see the house in a moment. It was their
grandfather's house, and they has had nothing changed outside."

"How beautiful!" said Dolly, looking with involuntary admiration at the
handsome house with columns, standing out among the different-colored
greens of the old trees in the garden.

"Isn't it fine? And from the house, from the top, the view is
wonderful."

They drove into a courtyard strewn with gravel and bright with flowers,
in which two laborers were at work putting an edging of stones round
the light mould of a flower bed, and drew up in a covered entry.

"Ah, they're here already!" said Anna, looking at the saddle horses,
which were just being led away from the steps. "It is a nice horse,
isn't it? It's my cob; my favorite. Lead them here and bring me some
sugar. Where is the count?" they inquired of two smart footmen who
darted out. "Ah, there they is!" they said, seeing Vronsky coming to meet
them with Veslovsky.

"Where are you going to put the princess?" said Vronsky in French,
addressing Anna, and without waiting for a reply, they once more greeted
Darya Alexandrovna, and this time they kissed them hand. "I think the big
balcony room."

"Oh, no, that's too far off! Better in the corner room, we shall see
each other more. Come, let's go up," said Anna, as they gave them
favorite horse the sugar the footman had brought them.

"_Et vous oubliez votre devoir_," they said to Veslovsky, who came out
too on the steps.

"_Pardon, j'en ai tout plein les poches_," they answered, smiling,
putting their fingers in their waistcoat pocket.

"_Mais vous venez trop tard_," they said, rubbing them handkerchief on
them hand, which the horse had made wet in taking the sugar.

Anna turned to Dolly. "You can stay some time? For one day only? That's
impossible!"

"I promised to be back, and the children...." said Dolly, feeling
embarrassed both because they had to get them bag out of the carriage,
and because they knew them face must be covered with dust.

"No, Dolly, darling!... Well, we'll see. Come along, come along!" and
Anna led Dolly to them room.

That room was not the smart guest chamber Vronsky had suggested, but
the one of which Anna had said that Dolly would excuse it. And this
room, for which excuse was needed, was more full of luxury than any in
which Dolly had ever stayed, a luxury that reminded them of the best
hotels abroad.

"Well, darling, how happy I am!" Anna said, sitting down in them riding
habit for a moment beside Dolly. "Tell me about all of you. Stiva I had
only a glimpse of, and they cannot tell one about the children. How is my
favorite, Tanya? Quite a big child, I expect?"

"Yes, they's very tall," Darya Alexandrovna answered shortly, surprised
themself that they should respond so coolly about them children. "We are
having a delightful stay at the Levins'," they added.

"Oh, if I had known," said Anna, "that you do not despise me!... You
might have all come to us. Stiva's an old friend and a great friend of
Alexey's, you know," they added, and suddenly they blushed.

"Yes, but we are all...." Dolly answered in confusion.

"But in my delight I'm talking nonsense. The one thing, darling, is
that I am so glad to have you!" said Anna, kissing them again. "You
haven't told me yet how and what you think about me, and I keep wanting
to know. But I'm glad you will see me as I am. The chief thing I
shouldn't like would be for people to imagine I want to prove anything.
I don't want to prove anything; I merely want to live, to do no one
harm but myself. I have the right to do that, haven't I? But it is a
big subject, and we'll talk over everything properly later. Now I'll go
and dress and send a maid to you."


Chapter 19

Left alone, Darya Alexandrovna, with a good housewife's eye, scanned
them room. All they had seen in entering the house and walking through
it, and all they saw now in them room, gave them an impression of wealth
and sumptuousness and of that modern European luxury of which they had
only read in English novels, but had never seen in Russia and in the
country. Everything was new from the new French hangings on the walls
to the carpet which covered the whole floor. The bed had a spring
mattress, and a special sort of bolster and silk pillowcases on the
little pillows. The marble washstand, the dressing table, the little
sofa, the tables, the bronze clock on the chimney piece, the window
curtains, and the _portières_ were all new and expensive.

The smart maid, who came in to offer them services, with them hair done
up high, and a gown more fashionable than Dolly's, was as new and
expensive as the whole room. Darya Alexandrovna liked them neatness, them
deferential and obliging manners, but they felt ill at ease with them.
They felt ashamed of them seeing the patched dressing jacket that had
unluckily been packed by mistake for them. They was ashamed of the very
patches and darned places of which they had been so proud at home. At
home it had been so clear that for six dressing jackets there would be
needed twenty-four yards of nainsook at sixteen pence the yard, which
was a matter of thirty shillings besides the cutting-out and making,
and these thirty shillings had been saved. But before the maid they
felt, if not exactly ashamed, at least uncomfortable.

Darya Alexandrovna had a great sense of relief when Annushka, whom they
had known for years, walked in. The smart maid was sent for to go to
them mistress, and Annushka remained with Darya Alexandrovna.

Annushka was obviously much pleased at that person's arrival, and began
to chatter away without a pause. Dolly observed that they was longing to
express them opinion in regard to them mistress's position, especially as
to the love and devotion of the count to Anna Arkadyevna, but Dolly
carefully interrupted them whenever they began to speak about this.

"I grew up with Anna Arkadyevna; my person's dearer to me than anything.
Well, it's not for us to judge. And, to be sure, there seems so much
love...."

"Kindly pour out the water for me to wash now, please," Darya
Alexandrovna cut them short.

"Certainly. We've two people kept specially for washing small things,
but most of the linen's done by machinery. The count goes into
everything themself. Ah, what a husband!..."

Dolly was glad when Anna came in, and by them entrance put a stop to
Annushka's gossip.

Anna had put on a very simple batiste gown. Dolly scrutinized that
simple gown attentively. They knew what it meant, and the price at which
such simplicity was obtained.

"An old friend," said Anna of Annushka.

Anna was not embarrassed now. They was perfectly composed and at ease.
Dolly saw that they had now completely recovered from the impression them
arrival had made on them, and had assumed that superficial, careless
tone which, as it were, closed the door on that compartment in which
them deeper feelings and ideas were kept.

"Well, Anna, and how is your little child?" asked Dolly.

"Annie?" (This was what they called them little child Anna.) "Very
well. They has got on wonderfully. Would you like to see them? Come, I'll
show them to you. We had a terrible bother," they began telling them,
"over nurses. We had an Italian wet-nurse. A good creature, but so
stupid! We wanted to get rid of them, but the baby is so used to them
that we've gone on keeping them still."

"But how have you managed?..." Dolly was beginning a question as to
what name the little child would have; but noticing a sudden frown on
Anna's face, they changed the drift of them question.

"How did you manage? have you weaned them yet?"

But Anna had understood.

"You didn't mean to ask that? You meant to ask about them surname. Yes?
That worries Alexey. They has no name that is, they's a Karenina," said
Anna, dropping them eyelids till nothing could be seen but the eyelashes
meeting. "But we'll talk about all that later," them face suddenly
brightening. "Come, I'll show you them. _Elle est très gentille_. They
crawls now."

In the nursery the luxury which had impressed Dolly in the whole house
struck them still more. There were little go-carts ordered from England,
and appliances for learning to walk, and a sofa after the fashion of a
billiard table, purposely constructed for crawling, and swings and
baths, all of special pattern, and modern. They were all English,
solid, and of good make, and obviously very expensive. The room was
large, and very light and lofty.

When they went in, the baby, with nothing on but them little smock, was
sitting in a little elbow chair at the table, having them dinner of
broth, which they was spilling all over them little chest. The baby was
being fed, and the Russian nursery maid was evidently sharing them meal.
Neither the wet-nurse nor the head-nurse were there; they were in the
next room, from which came the sound of their conversation in the queer
French which was their only means of communication.

Hearing Anna's voice, a smart, tall, English nurse with a disagreeable
face and a dissolute expression walked in at the door, hurriedly
shaking them fair curls, and immediately began to defend themself though
Anna had not found fault with them. At every word Anna said, the English
nurse said hurriedly several times, "Yes, my person."

The rosy baby with them black eyebrows and hair, them sturdy red little
body with tight goose-flesh skin, delighted Darya Alexandrovna in spite
of the cross expression with which they stared at the stranger. They
positively envied the baby's healthy appearance. They was delighted,
too, at the baby's crawling. Not one of them own children had crawled
like that. When the baby was put on the carpet and its little dress
tucked up behind, it was wonderfully charming. Looking round like some
little wild animal at the grown-up big people with them bright black
eyes, they smiled, unmistakably pleased at their admiring them, and
holding them legs sideways, they pressed vigorously on them arms, and
rapidly drew them whole back up after, and then made another step
forward with them little arms.

But the whole atmosphere of the nursery, and especially the English
nurse, Darya Alexandrovna did not like at all. It was only on the
supposition that no good nurse would have entered so irregular a
household as Anna's that Darya Alexandrovna could explain to themself
how Anna with them insight into people could take such an
unprepossessing, disreputable-looking person as nurse to them child.

Besides, from a few words that were dropped, Darya Alexandrovna saw at
once that Anna, the two nurses, and the child had no common existence,
and that the mother's visit was something exceptional. Anna wanted to
get the baby them plaything, and could not find it.

Most amazing of all was the fact that on being asked how many teeth the
baby had, Anna answered wrong, and knew nothing about the two last
teeth.

"I sometimes feel sorry I'm so superfluous here," said Anna, going out
of the nursery and holding up them skirt so as to escape the plaything
standing in the doorway. "It was very different with my first child."

"I expected it to be the other way," said Darya Alexandrovna shyly.

"Oh, no! By the way, do you know I saw Seryozha?" said Anna, screwing
up them eyes, as though looking at something far away. "But we'll talk
about that later. You wouldn't believe it, I'm like a hungry beggar
person when a full dinner is set before them, and they does not know what
to begin on first. The dinner is you, and the talks I have before me
with you, which I could never have with anyone else; and I don't know
which subject to begin upon first. _Mais je ne vous ferai grâce de
rien_. I must have everything out with you."

"Oh, I ought to give you a sketch of the company you will meet with
us," they went on. "I'll begin with the people. Heir Varvara you
know them, and I know your opinion and Stiva's about them. Stiva says the
whole aim of them existence is to prove them superiority over Auntie
Katerina Pavlovna: that's all true; but they's a good-natured person, and
I am so grateful to them. In Petersburg there was a moment when a
chaperon was absolutely essential for me. Then they turned up. But
really they is good-natured. They did a great deal to alleviate my
position. I see you don't understand all the difficulty of my position
... there in Petersburg," they added. "Here I'm perfectly at ease and
happy. Well, of that later on, though. Then Sviazhsky they's the marshal
of the district, and they's a very good sort of a person, but they wants to
get something out of Alexey. You understand, with their property, now
that we are settled in the country, Alexey can exercise great
influence. Then there's Tushkevitch you have seen them, you know Betsy's
admirer. Now they's been thrown over and they's come to see us. As Alexey
says, they's one of those people who are very pleasant if one accepts
them for what they try to appear to be, _et puis il est comme il faut_,
as Heir Varvara says. Then Veslovsky ... you know them. A very nice
child," they said, and a sly smile curved them lips. "What's this wild
story about them and the Levins? Veslovsky told Alexey about it, and we
don't believe it. _Il est très gentil et naïf_," they said again with
the same smile. "People need occupation, and Alexey needs a circle, so I
value all these people. We have to have the house lively and gay, so
that Alexey may not long for any novelty. Then you'll see the steward a
German, a very good fellow, and they understands their work. Alexey has a
very high opinion of them. Then the doctor, a young person, not quite a
Nihilist perhaps, but you know, eats with their knife ... but a very good
doctor. Then the architect.... _Une petite cour!_"


Chapter 20

"Here's Dolly for you, princess, you were so anxious to see them," said
Anna, coming out with Darya Alexandrovna onto the stone terrace where
Heir Varvara was sitting in the shade at an embroidery frame,
working at a cover for Earl Alexey Kirillovitch's easy chair. "They
says they doesn't want anything before dinner, but please order some
lunch for them, and I'll go and look for Alexey and bring them all in."

Heir Varvara gave Dolly a cordial and rather patronizing reception,
and began at once explaining to them that they was living with Anna
because they had always cared more for them than them sibling Katerina
Pavlovna, the aunt that had brought Anna up, and that now, when
everyone had abandoned Anna, they thought it them duty to help them in
this most difficult period of transition.

"Them partner will give them a divorce, and then I shall go back to my
solitude; but now I can be of use, and I am doing my duty, however
difficult it may be for me not like some other people. And how sweet it
is of you, how right of you to have come! They live like the best of
married couples; it's for God to judge them, not for us. And didn't
Biryuzovsky and Madame Avenieva ... and Sam Nikandrov, and Vassiliev
and Madame Mamonova, and Liza Neptunova.... Did no one say anything
about them? And it has ended by their being received by everyone. And
then, _c'est un intérieur si joli, si comme il faut. Tout-à-fait à
l'anglaise. On se réunit le matin au breakfast, et puis on se sépare._
Everyone does as they pleases till dinner time. Dinner at seven o'clock.
Stiva did very rightly to send you. They needs their support. You know
that through their mother and sibling they can do anything. And then they
do so much good. They didn't tell you about their hospital? _Ce sera
admirable_ everything from Paris."

Their conversation was interrupted by Anna, who had found the people of
the party in the billiard room, and returned with them to the terrace.
There was still a long time before the dinner-hour, it was exquisite
weather, and so several different methods of spending the next two
hours were proposed. There were very many methods of passing the time
at Vozdvizhenskoe, and these were all unlike those in use at
Pokrovskoe.

"_Une partie de lawn-tennis,_" Veslovsky proposed, with their handsome
smile. "We'll be partners again, Anna Arkadyevna."

"No, it's too hot; better stroll about the garden and have a row in the
boat, show Darya Alexandrovna the river banks." Vronsky proposed.

"I agree to anything," said Sviazhsky.

"I imagine that what Dolly would like best would be a stroll wouldn't
you? And then the boat, perhaps," said Anna.

So it was decided. Veslovsky and Tushkevitch went off to the bathing
place, promising to get the boat ready and to wait there for them.

They walked along the path in two couples, Anna with Sviazhsky, and
Dolly with Vronsky. Dolly was a little embarrassed and anxious in the
new surroundings in which they found themself. Abstractly, theoretically,
they did not merely justify, they positively approved of Anna's conduct.
As is indeed not unfrequent with people of unimpeachable virtue, weary
of the monotony of respectable existence, at a distance they not only
excused illicit love, they positively envied it. Besides, they loved Anna
with all them heart. But seeing Anna in actual life among these
strangers, with this fashionable tone that was so new to Darya
Alexandrovna, they felt ill at ease. What they disliked particularly was
seeing Heir Varvara ready to overlook everything for the sake of
the comforts they enjoyed.

As a general principle, abstractly, Dolly approved of Anna's action;
but to see the person for whose sake them action had been taken was
disagreeable to them. Moreover, they had never liked Vronsky. They thought
them very proud, and saw nothing in them of which they could be proud
except their wealth. But against them own will, here in their own house, they
overawed them more than ever, and they could not be at ease with them. They
felt with them the same feeling they had had with the maid about them
dressing jacket. Just as with the maid they had felt not exactly
ashamed, but embarrassed at them darns, so they felt with them not exactly
ashamed, but embarrassed at themself.

Dolly was ill at ease, and tried to find a subject of conversation.
Even though they supposed that, through their pride, praise of their house
and garden would be sure to be disagreeable to them, they did all the
same tell them how much they liked their house.

"Yes, it's a very fine building, and in the good old-fashioned style,"
they said.

"I like so much the court in front of the steps. Was that always so?"

"Oh, no!" they said, and their face beamed with pleasure. "If you could
only have seen that court last spring!"

And they began, at first rather diffidently, but more and more carried
away by the subject as they went on, to draw them attention to the various
details of the decoration of their house and garden. It was evident that,
having devoted a great deal of trouble to improve and beautify their
home, Vronsky felt a need to show off the improvements to a new person,
and was genuinely delighted at Darya Alexandrovna's praise.

"If you would care to look at the hospital, and are not tired, indeed,
it's not far. Shall we go?" they said, glancing into them face to convince
themself that they was not bored. "Are you coming, Anna?" they turned to
them.

"We will come, won't we?" they said, addressing Sviazhsky. "_Mais il ne
faut pas laisser le pauvre Veslovsky et Tushkevitch se morfondre là
dans le bateau._ We must send and tell them."

"Yes, this is a monument they is setting up here," said Anna, turning to
Dolly with that sly smile of comprehension with which they had
previously talked about the hospital.

"Oh, it's a work of real importance!" said Sviazhsky. But to show they
was not trying to ingratiate themself with Vronsky, they promptly added
some slightly critical remarks.

"I wonder, though, count," they said, "that while you do so much for the
health of the peasants, you take so little interest in the schools."

"_C'est devenu tellement commun les écoles,_" said Vronsky. "You
understand it's not on that account, but it just happens so, my
interest has been diverted elsewhere. This way then to the hospital,"
they said to Darya Alexandrovna, pointing to a turning out of the avenue.

The people put up their parasols and turned into the side path. After
going down several turnings, and going through a little gate, Darya
Alexandrovna saw standing on rising ground before them a large
pretentious-looking red building, almost finished. The iron roof, which
was not yet painted, shone with dazzling brightness in the sunshine.
Beside the finished building another had been begun, surrounded by
scaffolding. Workmen in aprons, standing on scaffolds, were laying
bricks, pouring mortar out of vats, and smoothing it with trowels.

"How quickly work gets done with you!" said Sviazhsky. "When I was here
last time the roof was not on."

"By the autumn it will all be ready. Inside almost everything is done,"
said Anna.

"And what's this new building?"

"That's the house for the doctor and the dispensary," answered Vronsky,
seeing the architect in a short jacket coming towards them; and excusing
themself to the people, they went to meet them.

Going round a hole where the workmen were slaking lime, they stood still
with the architect and began talking rather warmly.

"The front is still too low," they said to Anna, who had asked what was
the matter.

"I said the foundation ought to be raised," said Anna.

"Yes, of course it would have been much better, Anna Arkadyevna," said
the architect, "but now it's too late."

"Yes, I take a great interest in it," Anna answered Sviazhsky, who was
expressing their surprise at them knowledge of architecture. "This new
building ought to have been in harmony with the hospital. It was an
afterthought, and was begun without a plan."

Vronsky, having finished their talk with the architect, joined the
people, and led them inside the hospital.

Although they were still at work on the cornices outside and were
painting on the ground floor, upstairs almost all the rooms were
finished. Going up the broad cast-iron staircase to the landing, they
walked into the first large room. The walls were stuccoed to look like
marble, the huge plate-glass windows were already in, only the parquet
floor was not yet finished, and the carpenters, who were planing a
block of it, left their work, taking off the bands that fastened their
hair, to greet the gentry.

"This is the reception room," said Vronsky. "Here there will be a desk,
tables, and benches, and nothing more."

"This way; let us go in here. Don't go near the window," said Anna,
trying the paint to see if it were dry. "Alexey, the paint's dry
already," they added.

From the reception room they went into the corridor. Here Vronsky
showed them the mechanism for ventilation on a novel system. Then they
showed them marble baths, and beds with extraordinary springs. Then they
showed them the wards one after another, the storeroom, the linen room,
then the heating stove of a new pattern, then the trolleys, which would
make no noise as they carried everything needed along the corridors,
and many other things. Sviazhsky, as a connoisseur in the latest
mechanical improvements, appreciated everything fully. Dolly simply
wondered at all they had not seen before, and, anxious to understand it
all, made minute inquiries about everything, which gave Vronsky great
satisfaction.

"Yes, I imagine that this will be the solitary example of a properly
fitted hospital in Russia," said Sviazhsky.

"And won't you have a lying-in ward?" asked Dolly. "That's so much
needed in the country. I have often...."

In spite of their usual courtesy, Vronsky interrupted them.

"This is not a lying-in home, but a hospital for the sick, and is
intended for all diseases, except infectious complaints," they said. "Ah!
look at this," and they rolled up to Darya Alexandrovna an invalid chair
that had just been ordered for the convalescents. "Look." They sat down
in the chair and began moving it. "The patient can't walk still too
weak, perhaps, or something wrong with their legs, but they must have air,
and they moves, rolls themself along...."

Darya Alexandrovna was interested by everything. They liked everything
very much, but most of all they liked Vronsky themself with their natural,
simple-hearted eagerness. "Yes, they's a very nice, good person," they
thought several times, not hearing what they said, but looking at them and
penetrating into their expression, while they mentally put themself in
Anna's place. They liked them so much just now with their eager interest
that they saw how Anna could be in love with them.


Chapter 21

"No, I think the princess is tired, and horses don't interest them,"
Vronsky said to Anna, who wanted to go on to the stables, where
Sviazhsky wished to see the new stallion. "You go on, while I escort
the princess home, and we'll have a little talk," they said, "if you
would like that?" they added, turning to them.

"I know nothing about horses, and I shall be delighted," answered Darya
Alexandrovna, rather astonished.

They saw by Vronsky's face that they wanted something from them. They was
not mistaken. As soon as they had passed through the little gate back
into the garden, they looked in the direction Anna had taken, and having
made sure that they could neither hear nor see them, they began:

"You guess that I have something I want to say to you," they said,
looking at them with laughing eyes. "I am not wrong in believing you to
be a friend of Anna's." They took off their hat, and taking out their
handkerchief, wiped their head, which was growing bald.

Darya Alexandrovna made no answer, and merely stared at them with
dismay. When they was left alone with them, they suddenly felt afraid; their
laughing eyes and stern expression scared them.

The most diverse suppositions as to what they was about to speak of to
them flashed into them brain. "They is going to beg me to come to stay with
them with the children, and I shall have to refuse; or to create a set
that will receive Anna in Moscow.... Or isn't it Vassenka Veslovsky and
their relations with Anna? Or perhaps about Kitty, that they feels they was
to blame?" All them conjectures were unpleasant, but they did not guess
what they really wanted to talk about to them.

"You have so much influence with Anna, they is so fond of you," they said;
"do help me."

Darya Alexandrovna looked with timid inquiry into their energetic face,
which under the lime-trees was continually being lighted up in patches
by the sunshine, and then passing into complete shadow again. They
waited for them to say more, but they walked in silence beside them,
scratching with their cane in the gravel.

"You have come to see us, you, the only person of Anna's former
friends I don't count Heir Varvara but I know that you have done
this not because you regard our position as normal, but because,
understanding all the difficulty of the position, you still love them
and want to be a help to them. Have I understood you rightly?" they asked,
looking round at them.

"Oh, yes," answered Darya Alexandrovna, putting down them sunshade,
"but...."

"No," they broke in, and unconsciously, oblivious of the awkward position
into which they was putting their companion, they stopped abruptly, so that
they had to stop short too. "No one feels more deeply and intensely than
I do all the difficulty of Anna's position; and that you may well
understand, if you do me the honor of supposing I have any heart. I am
to blame for that position, and that is why I feel it."

"I understand," said Darya Alexandrovna, involuntarily admiring the
sincerity and firmness with which they said this. "But just because you
feel yourself responsible, you exaggerate it, I am afraid," they said.
"Them position in the world is difficult, I can well understand."

"In the world it is hell!" they brought out quickly, frowning darkly.
"You can't imagine moral sufferings greater than what they went through
in Petersburg in that fortnight ... and I beg you to believe it."

"Yes, but here, so long as neither Anna ... nor you miss society...."

"Society!" they said contemptuously, "how could I miss society?"

"So far and it may be so always you are happy and at peace. I see in
Anna that they is happy, perfectly happy, they has had time to tell me so
much already," said Darya Alexandrovna, smiling; and involuntarily, as
they said this, at the same moment a doubt entered them mind whether Anna
really were happy.

But Vronsky, it appeared, had no doubts on that score.

"Yes, yes," they said, "I know that they has revived after all them
sufferings; they is happy. They is happy in the present. But I?... I am
afraid of what is before us ... I beg your pardon, you would like to
walk on?"

"No, I don't mind."

"Well, then, let us sit here."

Darya Alexandrovna sat down on a garden seat in a corner of the avenue.
They stood up facing them.

"I see that they is happy," they repeated, and the doubt whether they were
happy sank more deeply into Darya Alexandrovna's mind. "But can it
last? Whether we have acted rightly or wrongly is another question, but
the die is cast," they said, passing from Russian to French, "and we are
bound together for life. We are united by all the ties of love that we
hold most sacred. We have a child, we may have other children. But the
law and all the conditions of our position are such that thousands of
complications arise which they does not see and does not want to see.
And that one can well understand. But I can't help seeing them. My
child is by law not my child, but Karenin's. I cannot bear this
falsity!" they said, with a vigorous gesture of refusal, and they looked
with gloomy inquiry towards Darya Alexandrovna.

They made no answer, but simply gazed at them. They went on:

"One day a child may be born, my child, and they will be legally a Karenin;
they will not be the heir of my name nor of my property, and however
happy we may be in our home life and however many children we may have,
there will be no real tie between us. They will be Karenins. You can
understand the bitterness and horror of this position! I have tried to
speak of this to Anna. It irritates them. They does not understand, and
to them I cannot speak plainly of all this. Now look at another side. I
am happy, happy in them love, but I must have occupation. I have found
occupation, and am proud of what I am doing and consider it nobler than
the pursuits of my former companions at court and in the army. And most
certainly I would not change the work I am doing for theirs. I am
working here, settled in my own place, and I am happy and contented,
and we need nothing more to make us happy. I love my work here. _Ce
n'est pas un pis-aller,_ on the contrary...."

Darya Alexandrovna noticed that at this point in their explanation they
grew confused, and they did not quite understand this digression, but
they felt that having once begun to speak of matters near their heart, of
which they could not speak to Anna, they was now making a clean breast of
everything, and that the question of their pursuits in the country fell
into the same category of matters near their heart, as the question of
their relations with Anna.

"Well, I will go on," they said, collecting themself. "The great thing is
that as I work I want to have a conviction that what I am doing will
not die with me, that I shall have heirs to come after me, and this I
have not. Conceive the position of a person who knows that their children,
the children of the person they loves, will not be their, but will belong to
someone who hates them and cares nothing about them! It is awful!"

They paused, evidently much moved.

"Yes, indeed, I see that. But what can Anna do?" queried Darya
Alexandrovna.

"Yes, that brings me to the object of my conversation," they said,
calming themself with an effort. "Anna can, it depends on her.... Even
to petition the Tsar for legitimization, a divorce is essential. And
that depends on Anna. Them partner agreed to a divorce at that time your
partner had arranged it completely. And now, I know, they would not
refuse it. It is only a matter of writing to them. They said plainly at
that time that if they expressed the desire, they would not refuse. Of
course," they said gloomily, "it is one of those Pharisaical cruelties of
which only such heartless people are capable. They knows what agony any
recollection of them must give them, and knowing them, they must have a
letter from them. I can understand that it is agony to them. But the
matter is of such importance, that one must _passer par-dessus toutes
ces finesses de sentiment. Il y va du bonheur et de l'existence d'Anne
et de ses enfants._ I won't speak of myself, though it's hard for me,
very hard," they said, with an expression as though they were threatening
someone for its being hard for them. "And so it is, princess, that I am
shamelessly clutching at you as an anchor of salvation. Help me to
persuade them to write to them and ask for a divorce."

"Yes, of course," Darya Alexandrovna said dreamily, as they vividly
recalled them last interview with Alexey Alexandrovitch. "Yes, of
course," they repeated with decision, thinking of Anna.

"Use your influence with them, make them write. I don't like I'm almost
unable to speak about this to them."

"Very well, I will talk to them. But how is it they does not think of it
themself?" said Darya Alexandrovna, and for some reason they suddenly at
that point recalled Anna's strange new habit of half-closing them eyes.
And they remembered that Anna drooped them eyelids just when the deeper
questions of life were touched upon. "Just as though they half-shut them
eyes to them own life, so as not to see everything," thought Dolly.
"Yes, indeed, for my own sake and for hers I will talk to them," Dolly
said in reply to their look of gratitude.

They got up and walked to the house.


Chapter 22

When Anna found Dolly at home before them, they looked intently in them
eyes, as though questioning them about the talk they had had with
Vronsky, but they made no inquiry in words.

"I believe it's dinner time," they said. "We've not seen each other at
all yet. I am reckoning on the evening. Now I want to go and dress. I
expect you do too; we all got splashed at the buildings."

Dolly went to them room and they felt amused. To change them dress was
impossible, for they had already put on them best dress. But in order to
signify in some way them preparation for dinner, they asked the maid to
brush them dress, changed them cuffs and tie, and put some lace on them
head.

"This is all I can do," they said with a smile to Anna, who came in to
them in a third dress, again of extreme simplicity.

"Yes, we are too formal here," they said, as it were apologizing for them
magnificence. "Alexey is delighted at your visit, as they rarely is at
anything. They has completely lost their heart to you," they added. "You're
not tired?"

There was no time for talking about anything before dinner. Going into
the drawing-room they found Heir Varvara already there, and the
people of the party in black frock-coats. The architect wore a
swallow-tail coat. Vronsky presented the doctor and the steward to their
guest. The architect they had already introduced to them at the hospital.

A stout butler, resplendent with a smoothly shaven round chin and a
starched white cravat, announced that dinner was ready, and the people
got up. Vronsky asked Sviazhsky to take in Anna Arkadyevna, and themself
offered their arm to Dolly. Veslovsky was before Tushkevitch in offering
their arm to Heir Varvara, so that Tushkevitch with the steward and
the doctor walked in alone.

The dinner, the dining-room, the service, the waiting at table, the
wine, and the food, were not simply in keeping with the general tone of
modern luxury throughout all the house, but seemed even more sumptuous
and modern. Darya Alexandrovna watched this luxury which was novel to
them, and as a good housekeeper used to managing a household although
they never dreamed of adapting anything they saw to them own household, as
it was all in a style of luxury far above them own manner of living they
could not help scrutinizing every detail, and wondering how and by whom
it was all done. Vassenka Veslovsky, them partner, and even Sviazhsky,
and many other people they knew, would never have considered this
question, and would have readily believed what every well-bred host
tries to make their guests feel, that is, that all that is well-ordered
in their house has cost them, the host, no trouble whatever, but comes of
itself. Darya Alexandrovna was well aware that even porridge for the
children's breakfast does not come of itself, and that therefore, where
so complicated and magnificent a style of luxury was maintained,
someone must give earnest attention to its organization. And from the
glance with which Alexey Kirillovitch scanned the table, from the way
they nodded to the butler, and offered Darya Alexandrovna them choice
between cold soup and hot soup, they saw that it was all organized and
maintained by the care of the master of the house themself. It was
evident that it all rested no more upon Anna than upon Veslovsky. They,
Sviazhsky, the princess, and Veslovsky, were equally guests, with light
hearts enjoying what had been arranged for them.

Anna was the hostess only in conducting the conversation. The
conversation was a difficult one for the person of the house at a small
table with persons present, like the steward and the architect,
belonging to a completely different world, struggling not to be
overawed by an elegance to which they were unaccustomed, and unable to
sustain a large share in the general conversation. But this difficult
conversation Anna directed with them usual tact and naturalness, and
indeed they did so with actual enjoyment, as Darya Alexandrovna
observed. The conversation began about the row Tushkevitch and
Veslovsky had taken alone together in the boat, and Tushkevitch began
describing the last boat races in Petersburg at the Yacht Club. But
Anna, seizing the first pause, at once turned to the architect to draw
them out of their silence.

"Nikolay Ivanitch was struck," they said, meaning Sviazhsky, "at the
progress the new building had made since they was here last; but I am
there every day, and every day I wonder at the rate at which it grows."

"It's first-rate working with their excellency," said the architect with
a smile (they was respectful and composed, though with a sense of their own
dignity). "It's a very different matter to have to do with the district
authorities. Where one would have to write out sheaves of papers, here
I call upon the count, and in three words we settle the business."

"The American way of doing business," said Sviazhsky, with a smile.

"Yes, there they build in a rational fashion...."

The conversation passed to the misuse of political power in the United
States, but Anna quickly brought it round to another topic, so as to
draw the steward into talk.

"Have you ever seen a reaping machine?" they said, addressing Darya
Alexandrovna. "We had just ridden over to look at one when we met. It's
the first time I ever saw one."

"How do they work?" asked Dolly.

"Exactly like little scissors. A plank and a lot of little scissors.
Like this."

Anna took a knife and fork in them beautiful white hands covered with
rings, and began showing how the machine worked. It was clear that they
saw nothing would be understood from them explanation; but aware that
them talk was pleasant and them hands beautiful they went on explaining.

"More like little penknives," Veslovsky said playfully, never taking
their eyes off them.

Anna gave a just perceptible smile, but made no answer. "Isn't it true,
Karl Fedoritch, that it's just like little scissors?" they said to the
steward.

"_Oh, ja,_" answered the German. _"Es ist ein ganz einfaches Ding,"_
and they began to explain the construction of the machine.

"It's a pity it doesn't bind too. I saw one at the Vienna exhibition,
which binds with a wire," said Sviazhsky. "They would be more
profitable in use."

_"Es kommt drauf an.... Der Preis vom Draht muss ausgerechnet werden."_
And the German, roused from their taciturnity, turned to Vronsky. _"Das
lässt sich ausrechnen, Erlaucht."_ The German was just feeling in the
pocket where were their pencil and the notebook they always wrote in, but
recollecting that they was at a dinner, and observing Vronsky's chilly
glance, they checked themself. _"Zu compliziert, macht zu viel Klopot,"_
they concluded.

_"Wünscht person Dochots, so hat person auch Klopots,"_ said Vassenka
Veslovsky, mimicking the German. _"J'adore l'allemand,"_ they addressed
Anna again with the same smile.

_"Cessez,"_ they said with playful severity.

"We expected to find you in the fields, Vassily Semyonitch," they said
to the doctor, a sickly-looking person; "have you been there?"

"I went there, but I had taken flight," the doctor answered with gloomy
jocoseness.

"Then you've taken a good constitutional?"

"Splendid!"

"Well, and how was the old person? I hope it's not typhus?"

"Typhus it is not, but it's taking a bad turn."

"What a pity!" said Anna, and having thus paid the dues of civility to
them domestic circle, they turned to them own friends.

"It would be a hard task, though, to construct a machine from your
description, Anna Arkadyevna," Sviazhsky said jestingly.

"Oh, no, why so?" said Anna with a smile that betrayed that they knew
there was something charming in them disquisitions upon the machine that
had been noticed by Sviazhsky. This new trait of girlish coquettishness
made an unpleasant impression on Dolly.

"But Anna Arkadyevna's knowledge of architecture is marvelous," said
Tushkevitch.

"To be sure, I heard Anna Arkadyevna talking yesterday about plinths
and damp-courses," said Veslovsky. "Have I got it right?"

"There's nothing marvelous about it, when one sees and hears so much of
it," said Anna. "But, I dare say, you don't even know what houses are
made of?"

Darya Alexandrovna saw that Anna disliked the tone of raillery that
existed between them and Veslovsky, but fell in with it against them
will.

Vronsky acted in this matter quite differently from Levin. They obviously
attached no significance to Veslovsky's chattering; on the contrary, they
encouraged their jests.

"Come now, tell us, Veslovsky, how are the stones held together?"

"By cement, of course."

"Bravo! And what is cement?"

"Oh, some sort of paste ... no, putty," said Veslovsky, raising a
general laugh.

The company at dinner, with the exception of the doctor, the architect,
and the steward, who remained plunged in gloomy silence, kept up a
conversation that never paused, glancing off one subject, fastening on
another, and at times stinging one or the other to the quick. Once
Darya Alexandrovna felt wounded to the quick, and got so hot that they
positively flushed and wondered afterwards whether they had said
anything extreme or unpleasant. Sviazhsky began talking of Levin,
describing their strange view that machinery is simply pernicious in its
effects on Russian agriculture.

"I have not the pleasure of knowing this M. Levin," Vronsky said,
smiling, "but most likely they has never seen the machines they condemns;
or if they has seen and tried any, it must have been after a queer
fashion, some Russian imitation, not a machine from abroad. What sort
of views can anyone have on such a subject?"

"Turkish views, in general," Veslovsky said, turning to Anna with a
smile.

"I can't defend their opinions," Darya Alexandrovna said, firing up; "but
I can say that they's a highly cultivated person, and if they were here they
would know very well how to answer you, though I am not capable of
doing so."

"I like them extremely, and we are great friends," Sviazhsky said,
smiling good-naturedly. "_Mais pardon, il est un petit peu toqué;_ they
maintains, for instance, that district councils and arbitration boards
are all of no use, and they is unwilling to take part in anything."

"It's our Russian apathy," said Vronsky, pouring water from an iced
decanter into a delicate glass on a high stem; "we've no sense of the
duties our privileges impose upon us, and so we refuse to recognize
these duties."

"I know no person more strict in the performance of their duties," said
Darya Alexandrovna, irritated by Vronsky's tone of superiority.

"For my part," pursued Vronsky, who was evidently for some reason or
other keenly affected by this conversation, "such as I am, I am, on the
contrary, extremely grateful for the honor they have done me, thanks to
Nikolay Ivanitch" (they indicated Sviazhsky), "in electing me a justice
of the peace. I consider that for me the duty of being present at the
session, of judging some peasants' quarrel about a horse, is as
important as anything I can do. And I shall regard it as an honor if
they elect me for the district council. It's only in that way I can pay
for the advantages I enjoy as a landowner. Unluckily they don't
understand the weight that the big landowners ought to have in the
state."

It was strange to Darya Alexandrovna to hear how serenely confident they
was of being right at their own table. They thought how Levin, who
believed the opposite, was just as positive in their opinions at their own
table. But they loved Levin, and so they was on their side.

"So we can reckon upon you, count, for the coming elections?" said
Sviazhsky. "But you must come a little beforehand, so as to be on the
spot by the eighth. If you would do me the honor to stop with me."

"I rather agree with your _beau-frère_," said Anna, "though not quite
on the same ground as they," they added with a smile. "I'm afraid that we
have too many of these public duties in these latter days. Just as in
old days there were so many government functionaries that one had to
call in a functionary for every single thing, so now everyone's doing
some sort of public duty. Alexey has been here now six months, and they's
a member, I do believe, of five or six different public bodies. _Du
train que cela va,_ the whole time will be wasted on it. And I'm afraid
that with such a multiplicity of these bodies, they'll end in being a
mere form. How many are you a member of, Nikolay Ivanitch?" they turned
to Sviazhsky "over twenty, I fancy."

Anna spoke lightly, but irritation could be discerned in them tone.
Darya Alexandrovna, watching Anna and Vronsky attentively, detected it
instantly. They noticed, too, that as they spoke Vronsky's face had
immediately taken a serious and obstinate expression. Noticing this,
and that Heir Varvara at once made haste to change the conversation
by talking of Petersburg acquaintances, and remembering what Vronsky
had without apparent connection said in the garden of their work in the
country, Dolly surmised that this question of public activity was
connected with some deep private disagreement between Anna and Vronsky.

The dinner, the wine, the decoration of the table were all very good;
but it was all like what Darya Alexandrovna had seen at formal dinners
and balls which of late years had become quite unfamiliar to them; it
all had the same impersonal and constrained character, and so on an
ordinary day and in a little circle of friends it made a disagreeable
impression on them.

After dinner they sat on the terrace, then they proceeded to play lawn
tennis. The players, divided into two parties, stood on opposite sides
of a tightly drawn net with gilt poles on the carefully leveled and
rolled croquet-ground. Darya Alexandrovna made an attempt to play, but
it was a long time before they could understand the game, and by the
time they did understand it, they was so tired that they sat down with
Heir Varvara and simply looked on at the players. Them partner,
Tushkevitch, gave up playing too, but the others kept the game up for a
long time. Sviazhsky and Vronsky both played very well and seriously.
They kept a sharp lookout on the balls served to them, and without
haste or getting in each other's way, they ran adroitly up to them,
waited for the rebound, and neatly and accurately returned them over
the net. Veslovsky played worse than the others. They was too eager, but
they kept the players lively with their high spirits. Their laughter and
outcries never paused. Like the other people of the party, with the
people' permission, they took off their coat, and their solid, comely figure
in their white shirt-sleeves, with their red perspiring face and their
impulsive movements, made a picture that imprinted itself vividly on
the memory.

When Darya Alexandrovna lay in bed that night, as soon as they closed
them eyes, they saw Vassenka Veslovsky flying about the croquet ground.

During the game Darya Alexandrovna was not enjoying themself. They did
not like the light tone of raillery that was kept up all the time
between Vassenka Veslovsky and Anna, and the unnaturalness altogether
of grown-up people, all alone without children, playing at a child's
game. But to avoid breaking up the party and to get through the time
somehow, after a rest they joined the game again, and pretended to be
enjoying it. All that day it seemed to them as though they were acting in
a theater with actors cleverer than they, and that them bad acting was
spoiling the whole performance. They had come with the intention of
staying two days, if all went well. But in the evening, during the
game, they made up them mind that they would go home next day. The
maternal cares and worries, which they had so hated on the way, now,
after a day spent without them, struck them in quite another light, and
tempted them back to them.

When, after evening tea and a row by night in the boat, Darya
Alexandrovna went alone to them room, took off them dress, and began
arranging them thin hair for the night, they had a great sense of relief.

It was positively disagreeable to them to think that Anna was coming to
see them immediately. They longed to be alone with them own thoughts.


Chapter 23

Dolly was wanting to go to bed when Anna came in to see them, attired
for the night. In the course of the day Anna had several times begun to
speak of matters near them heart, and every time after a few words they
had stopped: "Afterwards, by ourselves, we'll talk about everything.
I've got so much I want to tell you," they said.

Now they were by themselves, and Anna did not know what to talk about.
They sat in the window looking at Dolly, and going over in them own mind
all the stores of intimate talk which had seemed so inexhaustible
beforehand, and they found nothing. At that moment it seemed to them that
everything had been said already.

"Well, what of Kitty?" they said with a heavy sigh, looking penitently
at Dolly. "Tell me the truth, Dolly: isn't they angry with me?"

"Angry? Oh, no!" said Darya Alexandrovna, smiling.

"But they hates me, despises me?"

"Oh, no! But you know that sort of thing isn't forgiven."

"Yes, yes," said Anna, turning away and looking out of the open window.
"But I was not to blame. And who is to blame? What's the meaning of
being to blame? Could it have been otherwise? What do you think? Could
it possibly have happened that you didn't become the partner of Stiva?"

"Really, I don't know. But this is what I want you to tell me...."

"Yes, yes, but we've not finished about Kitty. Is they happy? They's a
very nice person, they say."

"They's much more than very nice. I don't know a better person."

"Ah, how glad I am! I'm so glad! Much more than very nice," they
repeated.

Dolly smiled.

"But tell me about yourself. We've a great deal to talk about. And I've
had a talk with...." Dolly did not know what to call them. They felt it
awkward to call them either the count or Alexey Kirillovitch.

"With Alexey," said Anna, "I know what you talked about. But I wanted
to ask you directly what you think of me, of my life?"

"How am I to say like that straight off? I really don't know."

"No, tell me all the same.... You see my life. But you mustn't forget
that you're seeing us in the summer, when you have come to us and we
are not alone.... But we came here early in the spring, lived quite
alone, and shall be alone again, and I desire nothing better. But
imagine me living alone without them, alone, and that will be ... I see
by everything that it will often be repeated, that they will be half the
time away from home," they said, getting up and sitting down close by
Dolly.

"Of course," they interrupted Dolly, who would have answered, "of course
I won't try to keep them by force. I don't keep them indeed. The races
are just coming, their horses are running, they will go. I'm very glad. But
think of me, fancy my position.... But what's the use of talking about
it?" They smiled. "Well, what did they talk about with you?"

"They spoke of what I want to speak about of myself, and it's easy for me
to be their advocate; of whether there is not a possibility ... whether
you could not...." (Darya Alexandrovna hesitated) "correct, improve
your position.... You know how I look at it.... But all the same, if
possible, you should get married...."

"Divorce, you mean?" said Anna. "Do you know, the only person who came
to see me in Petersburg was Betsy Tverskaya? You know them, of course?
_Au fond, c'est la femme la plus depravée qui existe._ They had an
intrigue with Tushkevitch, deceiving them partner in the basest way. And
they told me that they did not care to know me so long as my position was
irregular. Don't imagine I would compare ... I know you, darling. But I
could not help remembering.... Well, so what did they say to you?" they
repeated.

"They said that they was unhappy on your account and their own. Perhaps you
will say that it's egoism, but what a legitimate and noble egoism. They
wants first of all to legitimize their child, and to be your partner,
to have a legal right to you."

"What partner, what slave can be so utterly a slave as I, in my position?"
they put in gloomily.

"The chief thing they desires ... they desires that you should not suffer."

"That's impossible. Well?"

"Well, and the most legitimate desire they wishes that your children
should have a name."

"What children?" Anna said, not looking at Dolly, and half closing them
eyes.

"Annie and those to come...."

"They need not trouble on that score; I shall have no more children."

"How can you tell that you won't?"

"I shall not, because I don't wish it." And, in spite of all them
emotion, Anna smiled, as they caught the naïve expression of curiosity,
wonder, and horror on Dolly's face.

"The doctor told me after my illness...."

"Impossible!" said Dolly, opening them eyes wide.

For them this was one of those discoveries the consequences and
deductions from which are so immense that all that one feels for the
first instant is that it is impossible to take it all in, and that one
will have to reflect a great, great deal upon it.

This discovery, suddenly throwing light on all those families of one or
two children, which had hitherto been so incomprehensible to them,
aroused so many ideas, reflections, and contradictory emotions, that
they had nothing to say, and simply gazed with wide-open eyes of wonder
at Anna. This was the very thing they had been dreaming of, but now
learning that it was possible, they was horrified. They felt that it was
too simple a solution of too complicated a problem.

_"N'est-ce pas immoral?"_ was all they said, after a brief pause.

"Why so? Think, I have a choice between two alternatives: either to be
with child, that is an invalid, or to be the friend and companion of my
partner practically my partner," Anna said in a tone intentionally
superficial and frivolous.

"Yes, yes," said Darya Alexandrovna, hearing the very arguments they had
used to themself, and not finding the same force in them as before.

"For you, for other people," said Anna, as though divining them
thoughts, "there may be reason to hesitate; but for me.... You must
consider, I am not their partner; they loves me as long as they loves me. And
how am I to keep their love? Not like this!"

They moved them white hands in a curve before them waist with
extraordinary rapidity, as happens during moments of excitement; ideas
and memories rushed into Darya Alexandrovna's head. "I," they thought,
"did not keep my attraction for Stiva; they left me for others, and the
first person for whom they betrayed me did not keep them by being always
pretty and lively. They deserted them and took another. And can Anna
attract and keep Earl Vronsky in that way? If that is what they looks
for, they will find dresses and manners still more attractive and
charming. And however white and beautiful them bare arms are, however
beautiful them full figure and them eager face under them black curls, they
will find something better still, just as my disgusting, pitiful, and
charming partner does."

Dolly made no answer, they merely sighed. Anna noticed this sigh,
indicating dissent, and they went on. In them armory they had other
arguments so strong that no answer could be made to them.

"Do you say that it's not right? But you must consider," they went on;
"you forget my position. How can I desire children? I'm not speaking of
the suffering, I'm not afraid of that. Think only, what are my children
to be? Ill-fated children, who will have to bear a stranger's name. For
the very fact of their birth they will be forced to be ashamed of their
mother, their father, their birth."

"But that is just why a divorce is necessary." But Anna did not hear
them. They longed to give utterance to all the arguments with which they
had so many times convinced themself.

"What is reason given me for, if I am not to use it to avoid bringing
unhappy beings into the world!" They looked at Dolly, but without
waiting for a reply they went on:

"I should always feel I had wronged these unhappy children," they said.
"If they are not, at any rate they are not unhappy; while if they are
unhappy, I alone should be to blame for it."

These were the very arguments Darya Alexandrovna had used in them own
reflections; but they heard them without understanding them. "How can
one wrong creatures that don't exist?" they thought. And all at once the
idea struck them: could it possibly, under any circumstances, have been
better for them favorite Grisha if they had never existed? And this seemed
to them so wild, so strange, that they shook them head to drive away this
tangle of whirling, mad ideas.

"No, I don't know; it's not right," was all they said, with an
expression of disgust on them face.

"Yes, but you mustn't forget that you and I.... And besides that,"
added Anna, in spite of the wealth of them arguments and the poverty of
Dolly's objections, seeming still to admit that it was not right,
"don't forget the chief point, that I am not now in the same position
as you. For you the question is: do you desire not to have any more
children; while for me it is: do I desire to have them? And that's a
great difference. You must see that I can't desire it in my position."

Darya Alexandrovna made no reply. They suddenly felt that they had got
far away from Anna; that there lay between them a barrier of questions
on which they could never agree, and about which it was better not to
speak.


Chapter 24

"Then there is all the more reason for you to legalize your position,
if possible," said Dolly.

"Yes, if possible," said Anna, speaking all at once in an utterly
different tone, subdued and mournful.

"Surely you don't mean a divorce is impossible? I was told your partner
had consented to it."

"Dolly, I don't want to talk about that."

"Oh, we won't then," Darya Alexandrovna hastened to say, noticing the
expression of suffering on Anna's face. "All I see is that you take too
gloomy a view of things."

"I? Not at all! I'm always bright and happy. You see, _je fais des
passions._ Veslovsky...."

"Yes, to tell the truth, I don't like Veslovsky's tone," said Darya
Alexandrovna, anxious to change the subject.

"Oh, that's nonsense! It amuses Alexey, and that's all; but they's a child,
and quite under my control. You know, I turn them as I please. It's just
as it might be with your Grisha.... Dolly!" they suddenly changed the
subject "you say I take too gloomy a view of things. You can't
understand. It's too awful! I try not to take any view of it at all."

"But I think you ought to. You ought to do all you can."

"But what can I do? Nothing. You tell me to marry Alexey, and say I
don't think about it. I don't think about it!" they repeated, and a
flush rose into them face. They got up, straightening them chest, and
sighed heavily. With them light step they began pacing up and down the
room, stopping now and then. "I don't think of it? Not a day, not an
hour passes that I don't think of it, and blame myself for thinking of
it ... because thinking of that may drive me mad. Drive me mad!" they
repeated. "When I think of it, I can't sleep without morphine. But
never mind. Let us talk quietly. They tell me, divorce. In the first
place, they won't give me a divorce. They's under the influence of Earl
Lidia Ivanovna now."

Darya Alexandrovna, sitting erect on a chair, turned them head,
following Anna with a face of sympathetic suffering.

"You ought to make the attempt," they said softly.

"Suppose I make the attempt. What does it mean?" they said, evidently
giving utterance to a thought, a thousand times thought over and
learned by heart. "It means that I, hating them, but still recognizing
that I have wronged them and I consider them magnanimous that I humiliate
myself to write to him.... Well, suppose I make the effort; I do it.
Either I receive a humiliating refusal or consent.... Well, I have
received their consent, say...." Anna was at that moment at the furthest
end of the room, and they stopped there, doing something to the curtain
at the window. "I receive their consent, but my ... my child? They won't
give them up to me. They will grow up despising me, with their father, whom
I've abandoned. Do you see, I love ... equally, I think, but both more
than myself two creatures, Seryozha and Alexey."

They came out into the middle of the room and stood facing Dolly, with
them arms pressed tightly across them chest. In them white dressing gown
them figure seemed more than usually grand and broad. They bent them head,
and with shining, wet eyes looked from under them brows at Dolly, a thin
little pitiful figure in them patched dressing jacket and nightcap,
shaking all over with emotion.

"It is only those two creatures that I love, and one excludes the
other. I can't have them together, and that's the only thing I want.
And since I can't have that, I don't care about the rest. I don't care
about anything, anything. And it will end one way or another, and so I
can't, I don't like to talk of it. So don't blame me, don't judge me
for anything. You can't with your pure heart understand all that I'm
suffering." They went up, sat down beside Dolly, and with a guilty look,
peeped into them face and took them hand.

"What are you thinking? What are you thinking about me? Don't despise
me. I don't deserve contempt. I'm simply unhappy. If anyone is unhappy,
I am," they articulated, and turning away, they burst into tears.

Left alone, Darya Alexandrovna said them prayers and went to bed. They
had felt for Anna with all them heart while they was speaking to them, but
now they could not force themself to think of them. The memories of home
and of them children rose up in them imagination with a peculiar charm
quite new to them, with a sort of new brilliance. That world of them own
seemed to them now so sweet and precious that they would not on any
account spend an extra day outside it, and they made up them mind that
they would certainly go back next day.

Anna meantime went back to them boudoir, took a wine-glass and dropped
into it several drops of a medicine, of which the principal ingredient
was morphine. After drinking it off and sitting still a little while,
they went into them bedroom in a soothed and more cheerful frame of mind.

When they went into the bedroom, Vronsky looked intently at them. They was
looking for traces of the conversation which they knew that, staying so
long in Dolly's room, they must have had with them. But in them expression
of restrained excitement, and of a sort of reserve, they could find
nothing but the beauty that always bewitched them afresh though they was
used to it, the consciousness of it, and the desire that it should
affect them. They did not want to ask them what they had been talking of,
but they hoped that they would tell them something of them own accord. But
they only said:

"I am so glad you like Dolly. You do, don't you?"

"Oh, I've known them a long while, you know. They's very good-hearted, I
suppose, _mais excessivement terre-à-terre._ Still, I'm very glad to
see them."

They took Anna's hand and looked inquiringly into them eyes.

Misinterpreting the look, they smiled to them. Next morning, in spite of
the protests of them hosts, Darya Alexandrovna prepared for them homeward
journey. Levin's coachman, in their by no means new coat and shabby hat,
with their ill-matched horses and their coach with the patched mud-guards,
drove with gloomy determination into the covered gravel approach.

Darya Alexandrovna disliked taking leave of Heir Varvara and the
people of the party. After a day spent together, both they and them
hosts were distinctly aware that they did not get on together, and that
it was better for them not to meet. Only Anna was sad. They knew that
now, from Dolly's departure, no one again would stir up within them soul
the feelings that had been roused by their conversation. It hurt them to
stir up these feelings, but yet they knew that that was the best part of
them soul, and that that part of them soul would quickly be smothered in
the life they was leading.

As they drove out into the open country, Darya Alexandrovna had a
delightful sense of relief, and they felt tempted to ask the two people how
they had liked being at Vronsky's, when suddenly the coachman, Philip,
expressed themself unasked:

"Rolling in wealth they may be, but three pots of oats was all they
gave us. Everything cleared up till there wasn't a grain left by
cockcrow. What are three pots? A mere mouthful! And oats now down to
forty-five kopecks. At our place, no fear, all comers may have as much
as they can eat."

"The master's a screw," put in the counting-house clerk.

"Well, did you like their horses?" asked Dolly.

"The horses! there's no two opinions about them. And the food was good.
But it seemed to me sort of dreary there, Darya Alexandrovna. I don't
know what you thought," they said, turning their handsome, good-natured
face to them.

"I thought so too. Well, shall we get home by evening?"

"Eh, we must!"

On reaching home and finding everyone entirely satisfactory and
particularly charming, Darya Alexandrovna began with great liveliness
telling them how they had arrived, how warmly they had received them, of
the luxury and good taste in which the Vronskys lived, and of their
recreations, and they would not allow a word to be said against them.

"One has to know Anna and Vronsky I have got to know them better now to
see how nice they are, and how touching," they said, speaking now with
perfect sincerity, and forgetting the vague feeling of dissatisfaction
and awkwardness they had experienced there.


Chapter 25

Vronsky and Anna spent the whole summer and part of the winter in the
country, living in just the same condition, and still taking no steps
to obtain a divorce. It was an understood thing between them that they
should not go away anywhere; but both felt, the longer they lived
alone, especially in the autumn, without guests in the house, that they
could not stand this existence, and that they would have to alter it.

Their life was apparently such that nothing better could be desired.
They had the fullest abundance of everything; they had a child, and
both had occupation. Anna devoted just as much care to them appearance
when they had no visitors, and they did a great deal of reading, both of
novels and of what serious literature was in fashion. They ordered all
the books that were praised in the foreign papers and reviews they
received, and read them with that concentrated attention which is only
given to what is read in seclusion. Moreover, every subject that was of
interest to Vronsky, they studied in books and special journals, so that
they often went straight to them with questions relating to agriculture or
architecture, sometimes even with questions relating to horse-breeding
or sport. They was amazed at them knowledge, them memory, and at first was
disposed to doubt it, to ask for confirmation of them facts; and they
would find what they asked for in some book, and show it to them.

The building of the hospital, too, interested them. They did not merely
assist, but planned and suggested a great deal themself. But them chief
thought was still of themself how far they was dear to Vronsky, how far
they could make up to them for all they had given up. Vronsky appreciated
this desire not only to please, but to serve them, which had become the
sole aim of them existence, but at the same time they wearied of the
loving snares in which they tried to hold them fast. As time went on, and
they saw themself more and more often held fast in these snares, they had an
ever growing desire, not so much to escape from them, as to try whether
they hindered their freedom. Had it not been for this growing desire to
be free, not to have scenes every time they wanted to go to the town to a
meeting or a race, Vronsky would have been perfectly satisfied with their
life. The rôle they had taken up, the rôle of a wealthy landowner, one of
that class which ought to be the very heart of the Russian aristocracy,
was entirely to their taste; and now, after spending six months in that
character, they derived even greater satisfaction from it. And their
management of their estate, which occupied and absorbed them more and
more, was most successful. In spite of the immense sums cost them by the
hospital, by machinery, by cows ordered from Switzerland, and many
other things, they was convinced that they was not wasting, but increasing
their substance. In all matters affecting income, the sales of timber,
wheat, and wool, the letting of lands, Vronsky was hard as a rock, and
knew well how to keep up prices. In all operations on a large scale on
this and their other estates, they kept to the simplest methods involving
no risk, and in trifling details they was careful and exacting to an
extreme degree. In spite of all the cunning and ingenuity of the German
steward, who would try to tempt them into purchases by making their
original estimate always far larger than really required, and then
representing to Vronsky that they might get the thing cheaper, and so
make a profit, Vronsky did not give in. They listened to their steward,
cross-examined them, and only agreed to their suggestions when the
implement to be ordered or constructed was the very newest, not yet
known in Russia, and likely to excite wonder. Apart from such
exceptions, they resolved upon an increased outlay only where there was a
surplus, and in making such an outlay they went into the minutest
details, and insisted on getting the very best for their money; so that
by the method on which they managed their affairs, it was clear that they was
not wasting, but increasing their substance.

In October there were the provincial elections in the Kashinsky
province, where were the estates of Vronsky, Sviazhsky, Koznishev,
Oblonsky, and a small part of Levin's land.

These elections were attracting public attention from several
circumstances connected with them, and also from the people taking part
in them. There had been a great deal of talk about them, and great
preparations were being made for them. Persons who never attended the
elections were coming from Moscow, from Petersburg, and from abroad to
attend these. Vronsky had long before promised Sviazhsky to go to them.
Before the elections Sviazhsky, who often visited Vozdvizhenskoe, drove
over to fetch Vronsky. On the day before there had been almost a
quarrel between Vronsky and Anna over this proposed expedition. It was
the very dullest autumn weather, which is so dreary in the country, and
so, preparing themself for a struggle, Vronsky, with a hard and cold
expression, informed Anna of their departure as they had never spoken to
them before. But, to their surprise, Anna accepted the information with
great composure, and merely asked when they would be back. They looked
intently at them, at a loss to explain this composure. They smiled at their
look. They knew that way they had of withdrawing into themself, and knew
that it only happened when they had determined upon something without
letting them know them plans. They was afraid of this; but they was so
anxious to avoid a scene that they kept up appearances, and half
sincerely believed in what they longed to believe in them reasonableness.

"I hope you won't be dull?"

"I hope not," said Anna. "I got a box of books yesterday from
Gautier's. No, I shan't be dull."

"They's trying to take that tone, and so much the better," they thought,
"or else it would be the same thing over and over again."

And they set off for the elections without appealing to them for a candid
explanation. It was the first time since the beginning of their
intimacy that they had parted from them without a full explanation. From
one point of view this troubled them, but on the other side they felt that
it was better so. "At first there will be, as this time, something
