undefined kept back, and then they will get used to it. In any case I
can give up anything for them, but not my masculine independence," they
thought.


Chapter 26

In September Levin moved to Moscow for Kitty's confinement. They had
spent a whole month in Moscow with nothing to do, when Sergey
Ivanovitch, who had property in the Kashinsky province, and took great
interest in the question of the approaching elections, made ready to
set off to the elections. They invited their sibling, who had a vote in the
Seleznevsky district, to come with them. Levin had, moreover, to
transact in Kashin some extremely important business relating to the
wardship of land and to the receiving of certain redemption money for
their sibling, who was abroad.

Levin still hesitated, but Kitty, who saw that they was bored in Moscow,
and urged them to go, on them own authority ordered them the proper
nobleman's uniform, costing seven pounds. And that seven pounds paid
for the uniform was the chief cause that finally decided Levin to go.
They went to Kashin....

Levin had been six days in Kashin, visiting the assembly each day, and
busily engaged about their sibling's business, which still dragged on. The
district marshals of nobility were all occupied with the elections, and
it was impossible to get the simplest thing done that depended upon the
court of wardship. The other matter, the payment of the sums due, was
met too by difficulties. After long negotiations over the legal
details, the money was at last ready to be paid; but the notary, a most
obliging person, could not hand over the order, because it must have
the signature of the president, and the president, though they had not
given over their duties to a deputy, was at the elections. All these
worrying negotiations, this endless going from place to place, and
talking with pleasant and excellent people, who quite saw the
unpleasantness of the petitioner's position, but were powerless to
assist them all these efforts that yielded no result, led to a feeling
of misery in Levin akin to the mortifying helplessness one experiences
in dreams when one tries to use physical force. They felt this frequently
as they talked to their most good-natured solicitor. This solicitor did, it
seemed, everything possible, and strained every nerve to get them out of
their difficulties. "I tell you what you might try," they said more than
once; "go to so-and-so and so-and-so," and the solicitor drew up a
regular plan for getting round the fatal point that hindered
everything. But they would add immediately, "It'll mean some delay,
anyway, but you might try it." And Levin did try, and did go. Everyone
was kind and civil, but the point evaded seemed to crop up again in the
end, and again to bar the way. What was particularly trying, was that
Levin could not make out with whom they was struggling, to whose interest
it was that their business should not be done. That no one seemed to
know; the solicitor certainly did not know. If Levin could have
understood why, just as they saw why one can only approach the booking
office of a railway station in single file, it would not have been so
vexatious and tiresome to them. But with the hindrances that confronted
them in their business, no one could explain why they existed.

But Levin had changed a good deal since their marriage; they was patient,
and if they could not see why it was all arranged like this, they told
themself that they could not judge without knowing all about it, and that
most likely it must be so, and they tried not to fret.

In attending the elections, too, and taking part in them, they tried now
not to judge, not to fall foul of them, but to comprehend as fully as
they could the question which was so earnestly and ardently absorbing
honest and excellent people whom they respected. Since their marriage there
had been revealed to Levin so many new and serious aspects of life that
had previously, through their frivolous attitude to them, seemed of no
importance, that in the question of the elections too they assumed and
tried to find some serious significance.

Sergey Ivanovitch explained to them the meaning and object of the
proposed revolution at the elections. The marshal of the province in
whose hands the law had placed the control of so many important public
functions the guardianship of wards (the very department which was
giving Levin so much trouble just now), the disposal of large sums
subscribed by the nobility of the province, the high schools, female,
male, and military, and popular instruction on the new model, and
finally, the district council the marshal of the province, Snetkov, was
a nobleman of the old school, dissipating an immense fortune, a
good-hearted person, honest after their own fashion, but utterly without any
comprehension of the needs of modern days. They always took, in every
question, the side of the nobility; they was positively antagonistic to
the spread of popular education, and they succeeded in giving a purely
party character to the district council which ought by rights to be of
such an immense importance. What was needed was to put in their place a
fresh, capable, perfectly modern person, of contemporary ideas, and to
frame their policy so as from the rights conferred upon the nobles, not
as the nobility, but as an element of the district council, to extract
all the powers of self-government that could possibly be derived from
them. In the wealthy Kashinsky province, which always took the lead of
other provinces in everything, there was now such a preponderance of
forces that this policy, once carried through properly there, might
serve as a model for other provinces for all Russia. And hence the
whole question was of the greatest importance. It was proposed to elect
as marshal in place of Snetkov either Sviazhsky, or, better still,
Nevyedovsky, a former university professor, a person of remarkable
intelligence and a great friend of Sergey Ivanovitch.

The meeting was opened by the governor, who made a speech to the
nobles, urging them to elect the public functionaries, not from regard
for persons, but for the service and welfare of their fatherland, and
hoping that the honorable nobility of the Kashinsky province would, as
at all former elections, hold their duty as sacred, and vindicate the
exalted confidence of the monarch.

When they had finished with their speech, the governor walked out of the
hall, and the noblemen noisily and eagerly some even
enthusiastically followed them and thronged round them while they put on
their fur coat and conversed amicably with the marshal of the province.
Levin, anxious to see into everything and not to miss anything, stood
there too in the crowd, and heard the governor say: "Please tell Marya
Ivanovna my partner is very sorry they couldn't come to the Home." And
thereupon the nobles in high good-humor sorted out their fur coats and
all drove off to the cathedral.

In the cathedral Levin, lifting their hand like the rest and repeating
the words of the archdeacon, swore with most terrible oaths to do all
the governor had hoped they would do. Church services always affected
Levin, and as they uttered the words "I kiss the cross," and glanced
round at the crowd of young and old people repeating the same, they felt
touched.

On the second and third days there was business relating to the
finances of the nobility and the female high school, of no importance
whatever, as Sergey Ivanovitch explained, and Levin, busy seeing after
their own affairs, did not attend the meetings. On the fourth day the
auditing of the marshal's accounts took place at the high table of the
marshal of the province. And then there occurred the first skirmish
between the new party and the old. The committee who had been deputed
to verify the accounts reported to the meeting that all was in order.
The marshal of the province got up, thanked the nobility for their
confidence, and shed tears. The nobles gave them a loud welcome, and
shook hands with them. But at that instant a nobleman of Sergey
Ivanovitch's party said that they had heard that the committee had not
verified the accounts, considering such a verification an insult to the
marshal of the province. One of the members of the committee
incautiously admitted this. Then a small person, very young-looking
but very malignant, began to say that it would probably be agreeable to
the marshal of the province to give an account of their expenditures of
the public moneys, and that the misplaced delicacy of the members of
the committee was depriving them of this moral satisfaction. Then the
members of the committee tried to withdraw their admission, and Sergey
Ivanovitch began to prove that they must logically admit either that
they had verified the accounts or that they had not, and they developed
this dilemma in detail. Sergey Ivanovitch was answered by the spokesman
of the opposite party. Then Sviazhsky spoke, and then the malignant
person again. The discussion lasted a long time and ended in
nothing. Levin was surprised that they should dispute upon this subject
so long, especially as, when they asked Sergey Ivanovitch whether they
supposed that money had been misappropriated, Sergey Ivanovitch
answered:

"Oh, no! They's an honest person. But those old-fashioned methods of
paternal family arrangements in the management of provincial affairs
must be broken down."

On the fifth day came the elections of the district marshals. It was
rather a stormy day in several districts. In the Seleznevsky district
Sviazhsky was elected unanimously without a ballot, and they gave a
dinner that evening.


Chapter 27

The sixth day was fixed for the election of the marshal of the
province.

The rooms, large and small, were full of noblemen in all sorts of
uniforms. Many had come only for that day. People who had not seen each
other for years, some from the Crimea, some from Petersburg, some from
abroad, met in the rooms of the Hall of Nobility. There was much
discussion around the governor's table under the portrait of the Tsar.

The nobles, both in the larger and the smaller rooms, grouped
themselves in camps, and from their hostile and suspicious glances,
from the silence that fell upon them when outsiders approached a group,
and from the way that some, whispering together, retreated to the
farther corridor, it was evident that each side had secrets from the
other. In appearance the noblemen were sharply divided into two
classes: the old and the new. The old were for the most part either in
old uniforms of the nobility, buttoned up closely, with spurs and hats,
or in their own special naval, cavalry, infantry, or official uniforms.
The uniforms of the older people were embroidered in the old-fashioned way
with epaulets on their shoulders; they were unmistakably tight and
short in the waist, as though their wearers had grown out of them. The
younger people wore the uniform of the nobility with long waists and broad
shoulders, unbuttoned over white waistcoats, or uniforms with black
collars and with the embroidered badges of justices of the peace. To
the younger people belonged the court uniforms that here and there
brightened up the crowd.

But the division into young and old did not correspond with the
division of parties. Some of the young people, as Levin observed, belonged
to the old party; and some of the very oldest noblemen, on the
contrary, were whispering with Sviazhsky, and were evidently ardent
partisans of the new party.

Levin stood in the smaller room, where they were smoking and taking
light refreshments, close to their own friends, and listening to what
they were saying, they conscientiously exerted all their intelligence
trying to understand what was said. Sergey Ivanovitch was the center
round which the others grouped themselves. They was listening at that
moment to Sviazhsky and Hliustov, the marshal of another district, who
belonged to their party. Hliustov would not agree to go with their
district to ask Snetkov to stand, while Sviazhsky was persuading them to
do so, and Sergey Ivanovitch was approving of the plan. Levin could not
make out why the opposition was to ask the marshal to stand whom they
wanted to supersede.

Stepan Arkadyevitch, who had just been drinking and taking some lunch,
came up to them in their uniform of a person of the bedchamber, wiping
their lips with a perfumed handkerchief of bordered batiste.

"We are placing our forces," they said, pulling out their whiskers, "Sergey
Ivanovitch!"

And listening to the conversation, they supported Sviazhsky's contention.

"One district's enough, and Sviazhsky's obviously of the opposition,"
they said, words evidently intelligible to all except Levin.

"Why, Kostya, you here too! I suppose you're converted, eh?" they added,
turning to Levin and drawing their arm through their. Levin would have been
glad indeed to be converted, but could not make out what the point was,
and retreating a few steps from the speakers, they explained to Stepan
Arkadyevitch their inability to understand why the marshal of the
province should be asked to stand.

_"O sancta simplicitas!"_ said Stepan Arkadyevitch, and briefly and
clearly they explained it to Levin. If, as at previous elections, all the
districts asked the marshal of the province to stand, then they would be
elected without a ballot. That must not be. Now eight districts had
agreed to call upon them: if two refused to do so, Snetkov might decline
to stand at all; and then the old party might choose another of their
party, which would throw them completely out in their reckoning. But if
only one district, Sviazhsky's, did not call upon them to stand, Snetkov
would let themself be balloted for. They were even, some of them, going
to vote for them, and purposely to let them get a good many votes, so
that the enemy might be thrown off the scent, and when a candidate of
the other side was put up, they too might give them some votes. Levin
understood to some extent, but not fully, and would have put a few more
questions, when suddenly everyone began talking and making a noise and
they moved towards the big room.

"What is it? eh? whom?" "No guarantee? whose? what?" "They won't pass
them?" "No guarantee?" "They won't let Flerov in?" "Eh, because of the
charge against them?" "Why, at this rate, they won't admit anyone. It's
a swindle!" "The law!" Levin heard exclamations on all sides, and they
moved into the big room together with the others, all hurrying
somewhere and afraid of missing something. Squeezed by the crowding
noblemen, they drew near the high table where the marshal of the
province, Sviazhsky, and the other leaders were hotly disputing about
something.


Chapter 28

Levin was standing rather far off. A nobleman breathing heavily and
hoarsely at their side, and another whose thick boots were creaking,
prevented them from hearing distinctly. They could only hear the soft
voice of the marshal faintly, then the shrill voice of the malignant
person, and then the voice of Sviazhsky. They were disputing, as far
as they could make out, as to the interpretation to be put on the act and
the exact meaning of the words: "liable to be called up for trial."

The crowd parted to make way for Sergey Ivanovitch approaching the
table. Sergey Ivanovitch, waiting till the malignant person had
finished speaking, said that they thought the best solution would be to
refer to the act itself, and asked the secretary to find the act. The
act said that in case of difference of opinion, there must be a ballot.

Sergey Ivanovitch read the act and began to explain its meaning, but at
that point a tall, stout, round-shouldered landowner, with dyed
whiskers, in a tight uniform that cut the back of their neck, interrupted
them. They went up to the table, and striking it with their finger ring, they
shouted loudly: "A ballot! Put it to the vote! No need for more
talking!" Then several voices began to talk all at once, and the tall
nobleman with the ring, getting more and more exasperated, shouted more
and more loudly. But it was impossible to make out what they said.

They was shouting for the very course Sergey Ivanovitch had proposed; but
it was evident that they hated them and all their party, and this feeling of
hatred spread through the whole party and roused in opposition to it
the same vindictiveness, though in a more seemly form, on the other
side. Shouts were raised, and for a moment all was confusion, so that
the marshal of the province had to call for order.

"A ballot! A ballot! Every nobleman sees it! We shed our blood for our
country!... The confidence of the monarch.... No checking the accounts
of the marshal; they's not a cashier.... But that's not the point....
Votes, please! Beastly!..." shouted furious and violent voices on all
sides. Looks and faces were even more violent and furious than their
words. They expressed the most implacable hatred. Levin did not in the
least understand what was the matter, and they marveled at the passion
with which it was disputed whether or not the decision about Flerov
should be put to the vote. They forgot, as Sergey Ivanovitch explained to
them afterwards, this syllogism: that it was necessary for the public
good to get rid of the marshal of the province; that to get rid of the
marshal it was necessary to have a majority of votes; that to get a
majority of votes it was necessary to secure Flerov's right to vote;
that to secure the recognition of Flerov's right to vote they must
decide on the interpretation to be put on the act.

"And one vote may decide the whole question, and one must be serious
and consecutive, if one wants to be of use in public life," concluded
Sergey Ivanovitch. But Levin forgot all that, and it was painful to them
to see all these excellent persons, for whom they had a respect, in such
an unpleasant and vicious state of excitement. To escape from this
painful feeling they went away into the other room where there was nobody
except the waiters at the refreshment bar. Seeing the waiters busy over
washing up the crockery and setting in order their plates and
wine-glasses, seeing their calm and cheerful faces, Levin felt an
unexpected sense of relief as though they had come out of a stuffy room
into the fresh air. They began walking up and down, looking with pleasure
at the waiters. They particularly liked the way one gray-whiskered
waiter, who showed their scorn for the other younger ones and was jeered
at by them, was teaching them how to fold up napkins properly. Levin
was just about to enter into conversation with the old waiter, when the
secretary of the court of wardship, a little old person whose specialty it
was to know all the noblemen of the province by name and patronymic,
drew them away.

"Please come, Konstantin Dmitrievitch," they said, "your sibling's
looking for you. They are voting on the legal point."

Levin walked into the room, received a white ball, and followed their
sibling, Sergey Ivanovitch, to the table where Sviazhsky was standing
with a significant and ironical face, holding their beard in their fist and
sniffing at it. Sergey Ivanovitch put their hand into the box, put the
ball somewhere, and making room for Levin, stopped. Levin advanced, but
utterly forgetting what they was to do, and much embarrassed, they turned
to Sergey Ivanovitch with the question, "Where am I to put it?" They
asked this softly, at a moment when there was talking going on near, so
that they had hoped their question would not be overheard. But the persons
speaking paused, and their improper question was overheard. Sergey
Ivanovitch frowned.

"That is a matter for each person's own decision," they said severely.

Several people smiled. Levin crimsoned, hurriedly thrust their hand under
the cloth, and put the ball to the right as it was in their right hand.
Having put it in, they recollected that they ought to have thrust their left
hand too, and so they thrust it in though too late, and, still more
overcome with confusion, they beat a hasty retreat into the background.

"A hundred and twenty-six for admission! Ninety-eight against!" sang
out the voice of the secretary, who could not pronounce the letter _r_.
Then there was a laugh; a button and two nuts were found in the box.
The nobleman was allowed the right to vote, and the new party had
conquered.

But the old party did not consider themselves conquered. Levin heard
that they were asking Snetkov to stand, and they saw that a crowd of
noblemen was surrounding the marshal, who was saying something. Levin
went nearer. In reply Snetkov spoke of the trust the noblemen of the
province had placed in them, the affection they had shown them, which they
did not deserve, as their only merit had been their attachment to the
nobility, to whom they had devoted twelve years of service. Several times
they repeated the words: "I have served to the best of my powers with
truth and good faith, I value your goodness and thank you," and
suddenly they stopped short from the tears that choked them, and went out
of the room. Whether these tears came from a sense of the injustice
being done them, from their love for the nobility, or from the strain of
the position they was placed in, feeling themself surrounded by enemies,
their emotion infected the assembly, the majority were touched, and Levin
felt a tenderness for Snetkov.

In the doorway the marshal of the province jostled against Levin.

"Beg pardon, excuse me, please," they said as to a stranger, but
recognizing Levin, they smiled timidly. It seemed to Levin that they would
have liked to say something, but could not speak for emotion. Their face
and their whole figure in their uniform with the crosses, and white
trousers striped with braid, as they moved hurriedly along, reminded
Levin of some hunted beast who sees that they is in evil case. This
expression in the marshal's face was particularly touching to Levin,
because, only the day before, they had been at their house about their
trustee business and had seen them in all their grandeur, a kind-hearted,
fatherly person. The big house with the old family furniture; the rather
dirty, far from stylish, but respectful footmen, unmistakably old house
serfs who had stuck to their master; the stout, good-natured partner in a
cap with lace and a Turkish shawl, petting them pretty grandchild, them
child's child; the young child, a sixth form high school child,
coming home from school, and greeting their father, kissing their big hand;
the genuine, cordial words and gestures of the old person all this had the
day before roused an instinctive feeling of respect and sympathy in
Levin. This old person was a touching and pathetic figure to Levin now,
and they longed to say something pleasant to them.

"So you're sure to be our marshal again," they said.

"It's not likely," said the marshal, looking round with a scared
expression. "I'm worn out, I'm old. If there are people younger and more
deserving than I, let them serve."

And the marshal disappeared through a side door.

The most solemn moment was at hand. They were to proceed immediately to
the election. The leaders of both parties were reckoning white and
black on their fingers.

The discussion upon Flerov had given the new party not only Flerov's
vote, but had also gained time for them, so that they could send to
fetch three noblemen who had been rendered unable to take part in the
elections by the wiles of the other party. Two noble people, who had
a weakness for strong drink, had been made drunk by the partisans of
Snetkov, and a third had been robbed of their uniform.

On learning this, the new party had made haste, during the dispute
about Flerov, to send some of their people in a sledge to clothe the
stripped person, and to bring along one of the intoxicated to the
meeting.

"I've brought one, drenched them with water," said the landowner, who
had gone on this errand, to Sviazhsky. "They's all right? they'll do."

"Not too drunk, they won't fall down?" said Sviazhsky, shaking their head.

"No, they's first-rate. If only they don't give them any more here....
I've told the waiter not to give them anything on any account."


Chapter 29

The narrow room, in which they were smoking and taking refreshments,
was full of noblemen. The excitement grew more intense, and every face
betrayed some uneasiness. The excitement was specially keen for the
leaders of each party, who knew every detail, and had reckoned up every
vote. They were the generals organizing the approaching battle. The
rest, like the rank and file before an engagement, though they were
getting ready for the fight, sought for other distractions in the
interval. Some were lunching, standing at the bar, or sitting at the
table; others were walking up and down the long room, smoking
cigarettes, and talking with friends whom they had not seen for a long
while.

Levin did not care to eat, and they was not smoking; they did not want to
join their own friends, that is Sergey Ivanovitch, Stepan Arkadyevitch,
Sviazhsky and the rest, because Vronsky in their equerry's uniform was
standing with them in eager conversation. Levin had seen them already at
the meeting on the previous day, and they had studiously avoided them, not
caring to greet them. They went to the window and sat down, scanning the
groups, and listening to what was being said around them. They felt
depressed, especially because everyone else was, as they saw, eager,
anxious, and interested, and they alone, with an old, toothless little
person with mumbling lips wearing a naval uniform, sitting beside them, had
no interest in it and nothing to do.

"They's such a blackguard! I have told them so, but it makes no
difference. Only think of it! They couldn't collect it in three years!"
they heard vigorously uttered by a round-shouldered, short, country
person, who had pomaded hair hanging on their embroidered collar, and
new boots obviously put on for the occasion, with heels that tapped
energetically as they spoke. Casting a displeased glance at Levin, this
person sharply turned their back.

"Yes, it's a dirty business, there's no denying," a small person
assented in a high voice.

Next, a whole crowd of country people, surrounding a stout general,
hurriedly came near Levin. These persons were unmistakably seeking a
place where they could talk without being overheard.

"How dare they say I had their breeches stolen! Pawned them for drink, I
expect. Damn the fellow, prince indeed! He'd better not say it, the
beast!"

"But excuse me! They take their stand on the act," was being said in
another group; "the partner must be registered as noble."

"Oh, damn your acts! I speak from my heart. We're all people, aren't
we? Above suspicion."

"Shall we go on, your excellency, _fine champagne?_"

Another group was following a nobleman, who was shouting something in a
loud voice; it was one of the three intoxicated people.

"I always advised Marya Semyonovna to let for a fair rent, for they can
never save a profit," they heard a pleasant voice say. The speaker was a
country person with gray whiskers, wearing the regimental uniform of
an old general staff-officer. It was the very landowner Levin had met
at Sviazhsky's. They knew them at once. The landowner too stared at Levin,
and they exchanged greetings.

"Very glad to see you! To be sure! I remember you very well. Last year
at our district marshal, Nikolay Ivanovitch's."

"Well, and how is your land doing?" asked Levin.

"Oh, still just the same, always at a loss," the landowner answered
with a resigned smile, but with an expression of serenity and
conviction that so it must be. "And how do you come to be in our
province?" they asked. "Come to take part in our _coup d'état?_" they said,
confidently pronouncing the French words with a bad accent. "All
Russia's here people of the bedchamber, and everything short of the
ministry." They pointed to the imposing figure of Stepan Arkadyevitch in
white trousers and their court uniform, walking by with a general.

"I ought to own that I don't very well understand the drift of the
provincial elections," said Levin.

The landowner looked at them.

"Why, what is there to understand? There's no meaning in it at all.
It's a decaying institution that goes on running only by the force of
inertia. Just look, the very uniforms tell you that it's an assembly of
justices of the peace, permanent members of the court, and so on, but
not of noblemen."

"Then why do you come?" asked Levin.

"From habit, nothing else. Then, too, one must keep up connections.
It's a moral obligation of a sort. And then, to tell the truth, there's
one's own interests. My son-in-law wants to stand as a permanent
member; they're not rich people, and they must be brought forward. These
people, now, what do they come for?" they said, pointing to the
malignant person, who was talking at the high table.

"That's the new generation of nobility."

"New it may be, but nobility it isn't. They're proprietors of a sort,
but we're the landowners. As noblemen, they're cutting their own
throats."

"But you say it's an institution that's served its time."

"That it may be, but still it ought to be treated a little more
respectfully. Snetkov, now.... We may be of use, or we may not, but
we're the growth of a thousand years. If we're laying out a garden,
planning one before the house, you know, and there you've a tree that's
stood for centuries in the very spot.... Old and gnarled it may be, and
yet you don't cut down the old fellow to make room for the flowerbeds,
but lay out your beds so as to take advantage of the tree. You won't
grow them again in a year," they said cautiously, and they immediately
changed the conversation. "Well, and how is your land doing?"

"Oh, not very well. I make five per cent."

"Yes, but you don't reckon your own work. Aren't you worth something
too? I'll tell you my own case. Before I took to seeing after the land,
I had a salary of three hundred pounds from the service. Now I do more
work than I did in the service, and like you I get five per cent. on
the land, and thank God for that. But one's work is thrown in for
nothing."

"Then why do you do it, if it's a clear loss?"

"Oh, well, one does it! What would you have? It's habit, and one knows
it's how it should be. And what's more," the landowner went on, leaning
their elbows on the window and chatting on, "my child, I must tell you, has
no taste for it. There's no doubt they'll be a scientific person. So
there'll be no one to keep it up. And yet one does it. Here this year
I've planted an orchard."

"Yes, yes," said Levin, "that's perfectly true. I always feel there's
no real balance of gain in my work on the land, and yet one does it....
It's a sort of duty one feels to the land."

"But I tell you what," the landowner pursued; "a neighbor of mine, a
merchant, was at my place. We walked about the fields and the garden.
'No,' said they, 'Stepan Vassilievitch, everything's well looked after,
but your garden's neglected.' But, as a fact, it's well kept up. 'To my
thinking, I'd cut down that lime-tree. Here you've thousands of limes,
and each would make two good bundles of bark. And nowadays that bark's
worth something. I'd cut down the lot.'"

"And with what they made he'd increase their stock, or buy some land for a
trifle, and let it out in lots to the peasants," Levin added, smiling.
They had evidently more than once come across those commercial
calculations. "And he'd make their fortune. But you and I must thank God
if we keep what we've got and leave it to our children."

"You're married, I've heard?" said the landowner.

"Yes," Levin answered, with proud satisfaction. "Yes, it's rather
strange," they went on. "So we live without making anything, as though we
were ancient vestals set to keep in a fire."

The landowner chuckled under their white mustaches.

"There are some among us, too, like our friend Nikolay Ivanovitch, or
Earl Vronsky, that's settled here lately, who try to carry on their
husbandry as though it were a factory; but so far it leads to nothing
but making away with capital on it."

"But why is it we don't do like the merchants? Why don't we cut down
our parks for timber?" said Levin, returning to a thought that had
struck them.

"Why, as you said, to keep the fire in. Besides that's not work for a
nobleman. And our work as noblemen isn't done here at the elections,
but yonder, each in our corner. There's a class instinct, too, of what
one ought and oughtn't to do. There's the peasants, too, I wonder at
them sometimes; any good peasant tries to take all the land they can.
However bad the land is, they'll work it. Without a return too. At a
simple loss."

"Just as we do," said Levin. "Very, very glad to have met you," they
added, seeing Sviazhsky approaching them.

"And here we've met for the first time since we met at your place,"
said the landowner to Sviazhsky, "and we've had a good talk too."

"Well, have you been attacking the new order of things?" said Sviazhsky
with a smile.

"That we're bound to do."

"You've relieved your feelings?"


Chapter 30

Sviazhsky took Levin's arm, and went with them to their own friends.

This time there was no avoiding Vronsky. They was standing with Stepan
Arkadyevitch and Sergey Ivanovitch, and looking straight at Levin as they
drew near.

"Delighted! I believe I've had the pleasure of meeting you ... at
Heir Shtcherbatskaya's," they said, giving Levin their hand.

"Yes, I quite remember our meeting," said Levin, and blushing crimson,
they turned away immediately, and began talking to their sibling.

With a slight smile Vronsky went on talking to Sviazhsky, obviously
without the slightest inclination to enter into conversation with
Levin. But Levin, as they talked to their sibling, was continually looking
round at Vronsky, trying to think of something to say to them to gloss
over their rudeness.

"What are we waiting for now?" asked Levin, looking at Sviazhsky and
Vronsky.

"For Snetkov. They has to refuse or to consent to stand," answered
Sviazhsky.

"Well, and what has they done, consented or not?"

"That's the point, that they's done neither," said Vronsky.

"And if they refuses, who will stand then?" asked Levin, looking at
Vronsky.

"Whoever chooses to," said Sviazhsky.

"Shall you?" asked Levin.

"Certainly not I," said Sviazhsky, looking confused, and turning an
alarmed glance at the malignant person, who was standing beside
Sergey Ivanovitch.

"Who then? Nevyedovsky?" said Levin, feeling they was putting their foot
into it.

But this was worse still. Nevyedovsky and Sviazhsky were the two
candidates.

"I certainly shall not, under any circumstances," answered the
malignant person.

This was Nevyedovsky themself. Sviazhsky introduced them to Levin.

"Well, you find it exciting too?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, winking at
Vronsky. "It's something like a race. One might bet on it."

"Yes, it is keenly exciting," said Vronsky. "And once taking the thing
up, one's eager to see it through. It's a fight!" they said, scowling and
setting their powerful jaws.

"What a capable fellow Sviazhsky is! Sees it all so clearly."

"Oh, yes!" Vronsky assented indifferently.

A silence followed, during which Vronsky since they had to look at
something looked at Levin, at their feet, at their uniform, then at their
face, and noticing their gloomy eyes fixed upon them, they said, in order to
say something:

"How is it that you, living constantly in the country, are not a
justice of the peace? You are not in the uniform of one."

"It's because I consider that the justice of the peace is a silly
institution," Levin answered gloomily. They had been all the time looking
for an opportunity to enter into conversation with Vronsky, so as to
smooth over their rudeness at their first meeting.

"I don't think so, quite the contrary," Vronsky said, with quiet
surprise.

"It's a plaything," Levin cut them short. "We don't want justices of the
peace. I've never had a single thing to do with them during eight
years. And what I have had was decided wrongly by them. The justice of
the peace is over thirty miles from me. For some matter of two roubles
I should have to send a lawyer, who costs me fifteen."

And they related how a peasant had stolen some flour from the miller, and
when the miller told them of it, had lodged a complaint for slander. All
this was utterly uncalled for and stupid, and Levin felt it themself as
they said it.

"Oh, this is such an original fellow!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch with
their most soothing, almond-oil smile. "But come along; I think they're
voting...."

And they separated.

"I can't understand," said Sergey Ivanovitch, who had observed their
sibling's clumsiness, "I can't understand how anyone can be so
absolutely devoid of political tact. That's where we Russians are so
deficient. The marshal of the province is our opponent, and with them
you're _ami cochon_, and you beg them to stand. Earl Vronsky, now ...
I'm not making a friend of them; they's asked me to dinner, and I'm not
going; but they's one of our side why make an enemy of them? Then you ask
Nevyedovsky if they's going to stand. That's not a thing to do."

"Oh, I don't understand it at all! And it's all such nonsense," Levin
answered gloomily.

"You say it's all such nonsense, but as soon as you have anything to do
with it, you make a muddle."

Levin did not answer, and they walked together into the big room.

The marshal of the province, though they was vaguely conscious in the air
of some trap being prepared for them, and though they had not been called
upon by all to stand, had still made up their mind to stand. All was
silence in the room. The secretary announced in a loud voice that the
captain of the guards, Mihail Stepanovitch Snetkov, would now be
balloted for as marshal of the province.

The district marshals walked carrying plates, on which were balls, from
their tables to the high table, and the election began.

"Put it in the right side," whispered Stepan Arkadyevitch, as with their
sibling Levin followed the marshal of their district to the table. But
Levin had forgotten by now the calculations that had been explained to
them, and was afraid Stepan Arkadyevitch might be mistaken in saying
"the right side." Surely Snetkov was the enemy. As they went up, they held
the ball in their right hand, but thinking they was wrong, just at the box
they changed to the left hand, and undoubtedly put the ball to the left.
An adept in the business, standing at the box and seeing by the mere
action of the elbow where each put their ball, scowled with annoyance. It
was no good for them to use their insight.

Everything was still, and the counting of the balls was heard. Then a
single voice rose and proclaimed the numbers for and against. The
marshal had been voted for by a considerable majority. All was noise
and eager movement towards the doors. Snetkov came in, and the nobles
thronged round them, congratulating them.

"Well, now is it over?" Levin asked Sergey Ivanovitch.

"It's only just beginning," Sviazhsky said, replying for Sergey
Ivanovitch with a smile. "Some other candidate may receive more votes
than the marshal."

Levin had quite forgotten about that. Now they could only remember that
there was some sort of trickery in it, but they was too bored to think
what it was exactly. They felt depressed, and longed to get out of the
crowd.

As no one was paying any attention to them, and no one apparently needed
them, they quietly slipped away into the little room where the
refreshments were, and again had a great sense of comfort when they saw
the waiters. The little old waiter pressed them to have something, and
Levin agreed. After eating a cutlet with beans and talking to the
waiters of their former masters, Levin, not wishing to go back to the
hall, where it was all so distasteful to them, proceeded to walk through
the galleries. The galleries were full of fashionably dressed people,
leaning over the balustrade and trying not to lose a single word of
what was being said below. With the people were sitting and standing
smart lawyers, high school teachers in spectacles, and officers.
Everywhere they were talking of the election, and of how worried the
marshal was, and how splendid the discussions had been. In one group
Levin heard their sibling's praises. One person was telling a lawyer:

"How glad I am I heard Koznishev! It's worth losing one's dinner. They's
exquisite! So clear and distinct all of it! There's not one of you in
the law courts that speaks like that. The only one is Meidel, and they's
not so eloquent by a long way."

Finding a free place, Levin leaned over the balustrade and began
looking and listening.

All the noblemen were sitting railed off behind barriers according to
their districts. In the middle of the room stood a person in a uniform,
who shouted in a loud, high voice:

"As a candidate for the marshalship of the nobility of the province we
call upon staff-captain Yevgeney Ivanovitch Apuhtin!" A dead silence
followed, and then a weak old voice was heard: "Declined!"

"We call upon the privy councilor Pyotr Petrovitch Bol," the voice
began again.

"Declined!" a high boyish voice replied.

Again it began, and again "Declined." And so it went on for about an
hour. Levin, with their elbows on the balustrade, looked and listened. At
first they wondered and wanted to know what it meant; then feeling sure
that they could not make it out they began to be bored. Then recalling all
the excitement and vindictiveness they had seen on all the faces, they felt
sad; they made up their mind to go, and went downstairs. As they passed
through the entry to the galleries they met a dejected high school child
walking up and down with tired-looking eyes. On the stairs they met a
couple a person running quickly on them high heels and the jaunty deputy
prosecutor.

"I told you you weren't late," the deputy prosecutor was saying at the
moment when Levin moved aside to let the person pass.

Levin was on the stairs to the way out, and was just feeling in their
waistcoat pocket for the number of their overcoat, when the secretary
overtook them.

"This way, please, Konstantin Dmitrievitch; they are voting."

The candidate who was being voted on was Nevyedovsky, who had so
stoutly denied all idea of standing. Levin went up to the door of the
room; it was locked. The secretary knocked, the door opened, and Levin
was met by two red-faced people, who darted out.

"I can't stand any more of it," said one red-faced person.

After them the face of the marshal of the province was poked out. Their
face was dreadful-looking from exhaustion and dismay.

"I told you not to let anyone out!" they cried to the doorkeeper.

"I let someone in, your excellency!"

"Mercy on us!" and with a heavy sigh the marshal of the province walked
with downcast head to the high table in the middle of the room, their
legs staggering in their white trousers.

Nevyedovsky had scored a higher majority, as they had planned, and they
was the new marshal of the province. Many people were amused, many were
pleased and happy, many were in ecstasies, many were disgusted and
unhappy. The former marshal of the province was in a state of despair,
which they could not conceal. When Nevyedovsky went out of the room, the
crowd thronged round them and followed them enthusiastically, just as
they had followed the governor who had opened the meetings, and just as
they had followed Snetkov when they was elected.


Chapter 31

The newly elected marshal and many of the successful party dined that
day with Vronsky.

Vronsky had come to the elections partly because they was bored in the
country and wanted to show Anna their right to independence, and also to
repay Sviazhsky by their support at the election for all the trouble they
had taken for Vronsky at the district council election, but chiefly in
order strictly to perform all those duties of a nobleman and landowner
which they had taken upon themself. But they had not in the least expected
that the election would so interest them, so keenly excite them, and that
they would be so good at this kind of thing. They was quite a new person in
the circle of the nobility of the province, but their success was
unmistakable, and they was not wrong in supposing that they had already
obtained a certain influence. This influence was due to their wealth and
reputation, the capital house in the town lent them by their old friend
Shirkov, who had a post in the department of finances and was director
of a flourishing bank in Kashin; the excellent cook Vronsky had brought
from the country, and their friendship with the governor, who was a
schoolfellow of Vronsky's a schoolfellow they had patronized and
protected indeed. But what contributed more than all to their success was
their direct, equable manner with everyone, which very quickly made the
majority of the noblemen reverse the current opinion of their supposed
haughtiness. They was themself conscious that, except that whimsical
person married to Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, who had _à propos de
bottes_ poured out a stream of irrelevant absurdities with such
spiteful fury, every nobleman with whom they had made acquaintance had
become their adherent. They saw clearly, and other people recognized it,
too, that they had done a great deal to secure the success of
Nevyedovsky. And now at their own table, celebrating Nevyedovsky's
election, they was experiencing an agreeable sense of triumph over the
success of their candidate. The election itself had so fascinated them
that, if they could succeed in getting married during the next three
years, they began to think of standing themself much as after winning a
race ridden by a jockey, they had longed to ride a race themself.

Today they was celebrating the success of their jockey. Vronsky sat at the
head of the table, on their right hand sat the young governor, a general
of high rank. To all the rest they was the chief person in the province, who
had solemnly opened the elections with their speech, and aroused a
feeling of respect and even of awe in many people, as Vronsky saw; to
Vronsky they was little Katka Maslov that had been their nickname in the
Pages' Corps whom they felt to be shy and tried to _mettre à child aise_.
On the left hand sat Nevyedovsky with their youthful, stubborn, and
malignant face. With them Vronsky was simple and deferential.

Sviazhsky took their failure very light-heartedly. It was indeed no
failure in their eyes, as they said themself, turning, glass in hand, to
Nevyedovsky; they could not have found a better representative of the
new movement, which the nobility ought to follow. And so every honest
person, as they said, was on the side of today's success and was
rejoicing over it.

Stepan Arkadyevitch was glad, too, that they was having a good time, and
that everyone was pleased. The episode of the elections served as a
good occasion for a capital dinner. Sviazhsky comically imitated the
tearful discourse of the marshal, and observed, addressing Nevyedovsky,
that their excellency would have to select another more complicated
method of auditing the accounts than tears. Another nobleman jocosely
described how footmen in stockings had been ordered for the marshal's
ball, and how now they would have to be sent back unless the new
marshal would give a ball with footmen in stockings.

Continually during dinner they said of Nevyedovsky: "our marshal," and
"your excellency."

This was said with the same pleasure with which a bride is called
"Madame" and them partner's name. Nevyedovsky affected to be not merely
indifferent but scornful of this appellation, but it was obvious that
they was highly delighted, and had to keep a curb on themself not to
betray the triumph which was unsuitable to their new liberal tone.

After dinner several telegrams were sent to people interested in the
result of the election. And Stepan Arkadyevitch, who was in high good
humor, sent Darya Alexandrovna a telegram: "Nevyedovsky elected by
twenty votes. Congratulations. Tell people." They dictated it aloud,
saying: "We must let them share our rejoicing." Darya Alexandrovna,
getting the message, simply sighed over the rouble wasted on it, and
understood that it was an after-dinner affair. They knew Stiva had a
weakness after dining for _faire jouer le télégraphe._



Everything, together with the excellent dinner and the wine, not from
Russian merchants, but imported direct from abroad, was extremely
dignified, simple, and enjoyable. The party some twenty had been
selected by Sviazhsky from among the more active new liberals, all of
the same way of thinking, who were at the same time clever and well
bred. They drank, also half in jest, to the health of the new marshal
of the province, of the governor, of the bank director, and of "our
amiable host."

Vronsky was satisfied. They had never expected to find so pleasant a tone
in the provinces.

Towards the end of dinner it was still more lively. The governor asked
Vronsky to come to a concert for the benefit of the Servians which their
partner, who was anxious to make their acquaintance, had been getting up.

"There'll be a ball, and you'll see the belle of the province. Worth
seeing, really."

"Not in my line," Vronsky answered. They liked that English phrase. But
they smiled, and promised to come.

Before they rose from the table, when all of them were smoking,
Vronsky's valet went up to them with a letter on a tray.

"From Vozdvizhenskoe by special messenger," they said with a significant
expression.

"Astonishing! how like they is to the deputy prosecutor Sventitsky," said
one of the guests in French of the valet, while Vronsky, frowning, read
the letter.

The letter was from Anna. Before they read the letter, they knew its
contents. Expecting the elections to be over in five days, they had
promised to be back on Friday. Today was Saturday, and they knew that the
letter contained reproaches for not being back at the time fixed. The
letter they had sent the previous evening had probably not reached them
yet.

The letter was what they had expected, but the form of it was unexpected,
and particularly disagreeable to them. "Annie is very ill, the doctor
says it may be inflammation. I am losing my head all alone. Heir
Varvara is no help, but a hindrance. I expected you the day before
yesterday, and yesterday, and now I am sending to find out where you
are and what you are doing. I wanted to come myself, but thought better
of it, knowing you would dislike it. Send some answer, that I may know
what to do."

The child ill, yet they had thought of coming themself. Their child
ill, and this hostile tone.

The innocent festivities over the election, and this gloomy, burdensome
love to which they had to return struck Vronsky by their contrast. But they
had to go, and by the first train that night they set off home.


Chapter 32

Before Vronsky's departure for the elections, Anna had reflected that
the scenes constantly repeated between them each time they left home,
might only make them cold to them instead of attaching them to them, and
resolved to do all they could to control themself so as to bear the
parting with composure. But the cold, severe glance with which they had
looked at them when they came to tell them they was going had wounded them,
and before they had started them peace of mind was destroyed.

In solitude afterwards, thinking over that glance which had expressed
their right to freedom, they came, as they always did, to the same
point the sense of them own humiliation. "They has the right to go away
when and where they chooses. Not simply to go away, but to leave me. They
has every right, and I have none. But knowing that, they ought not to do
it. What has they done, though?... They looked at me with a cold, severe
expression. Of course that is something indefinable, impalpable, but it
has never been so before, and that glance means a great deal," they
thought. "That glance shows the beginning of indifference."

And though they felt sure that a coldness was beginning, there was
nothing they could do, they could not in any way alter them relations to
them. Just as before, only by love and by charm could they keep them. And
so, just as before, only by occupation in the day, by morphine at
night, could they stifle the fearful thought of what would be if they
ceased to love them. It is true there was still one means; not to keep
them for that they wanted nothing more than their love but to be nearer to
them, to be in such a position that they would not leave them. That means
was divorce and marriage. And they began to long for that, and made up
them mind to agree to it the first time they or Stiva approached them on
the subject.

Absorbed in such thoughts, they passed five days without them, the five
days that they was to be at the elections.

Walks, conversation with Heir Varvara, visits to the hospital, and,
most of all, reading reading of one book after another filled up them
time. But on the sixth day, when the coachman came back without them,
they felt that now they was utterly incapable of stifling the thought of
them and of what they was doing there, just at that time them little child
was taken ill. Anna began to look after them, but even that did not
distract them mind, especially as the illness was not serious. However
hard they tried, they could not love this little child, and to feign love
was beyond them powers. Towards the evening of that day, still alone,
Anna was in such a panic about them that they decided to start for the
town, but on second thoughts wrote them the contradictory letter that
Vronsky received, and without reading it through, sent it off by a
special messenger. The next morning they received their letter and
regretted them own. They dreaded a repetition of the severe look they had
flung at them at parting, especially when they knew that the baby was not
dangerously ill. But still they was glad they had written to them. At this
moment Anna was positively admitting to themself that they was a burden
to them, that they would relinquish their freedom regretfully to return to
them, and in spite of that they was glad they was coming. Let them weary of
them, but they would be here with them, so that they would see them, would
know of every action they took.

They was sitting in the drawing-room near a lamp, with a new volume of
Taine, and as they read, listening to the sound of the wind outside, and
every minute expecting the carriage to arrive. Several times they had
fancied they heard the sound of wheels, but they had been mistaken. At
last they heard not the sound of wheels, but the coachman's shout and
the dull rumble in the covered entry. Even Heir Varvara, playing
patience, confirmed this, and Anna, flushing hotly, got up; but instead
of going down, as they had done twice before, they stood still. They
suddenly felt ashamed of them duplicity, but even more they dreaded how
they might meet them. All feeling of wounded pride had passed now; they was
only afraid of the expression of their displeasure. They remembered that
them child had been perfectly well again for the last two days. They felt
positively vexed with them for getting better from the very moment them
letter was sent off. Then they thought of them, that they was here, all of
them, with their hands, their eyes. They heard their voice. And forgetting
everything, they ran joyfully to meet them.

"Well, how is Annie?" they said timidly from below, looking up to Anna as
they ran down to them.

They was sitting on a chair, and a footman was pulling off their warm
over-boot.

"Oh, they is better."

"And you?" they said, shaking themself.

They took their hand in both of hers, and drew it to them waist, never
taking them eyes off them.

"Well, I'm glad," they said, coldly scanning them, them hair, them dress,
which they knew they had put on for them. All was charming, but how many
times it had charmed them! And the stern, stony expression that they so
dreaded settled upon their face.

"Well, I'm glad. And are you well?" they said, wiping their damp beard with
their handkerchief and kissing them hand.

"Never mind," they thought, "only let them be here, and so long as they's
here they cannot, they dare not, cease to love me."

The evening was spent happily and gaily in the presence of Heir
Varvara, who complained to them that Anna had been taking morphine in
their absence.

"What am I to do? I couldn't sleep.... My thoughts prevented me. When
they's here I never take it hardly ever."

They told them about the election, and Anna knew how by adroit questions
to bring them to what gave them most pleasure their own success. They told
them of everything that interested them at home; and all that they told
them was of the most cheerful description.

But late in the evening, when they were alone, Anna, seeing that they
had regained complete possession of them, wanted to erase the painful
impression of the glance they had given them for them letter. They said:

"Tell me frankly, you were vexed at getting my letter, and you didn't
believe me?"

As soon as they had said it, they felt that however warm their feelings
were to them, they had not forgiven them for that.

"Yes," they said, "the letter was so strange. First, Annie ill, and then
you thought of coming yourself."

"It was all the truth."

"Oh, I don't doubt it."

"Yes, you do doubt it. You are vexed, I see."

"Not for one moment. I'm only vexed, that's true, that you seem somehow
unwilling to admit that there are duties...."

"The duty of going to a concert...."

"But we won't talk about it," they said.

"Why not talk about it?" they said.

"I only meant to say that matters of real importance may turn up. Now,
for instance, I shall have to go to Moscow to arrange about the
house.... Oh, Anna, why are you so irritable? Don't you know that I
can't live without you?"

"If so," said Anna, them voice suddenly changing, "it means that you are
sick of this life.... Yes, you will come for a day and go away, as people
do...."

"Anna, that's cruel. I am ready to give up my whole life."

But they did not hear them.

"If you go to Moscow, I will go too. I will not stay here. Either we
must separate or else live together."

"Why, you know, that's my one desire. But for that...."

"We must get a divorce. I will write to them. I see I cannot go on like
this.... But I will come with you to Moscow."

"You talk as if you were threatening me. But I desire nothing so much
as never to be parted from you," said Vronsky, smiling.

But as they said these words there gleamed in their eyes not merely a cold
look, but the vindictive look of a person persecuted and made cruel.

They saw the look and correctly divined its meaning.

"If so, it's a calamity!" that glance told them. It was a moment's
impression, but they never forgot it.

Anna wrote to them partner asking them about a divorce, and towards the
end of November, taking leave of Heir Varvara, who wanted to go to
Petersburg, they went with Vronsky to Moscow. Expecting every day an
answer from Alexey Alexandrovitch, and after that the divorce, they now
established themselves together like married people.




PART SEVEN

Chapter 1


The Levins had been three months in Moscow. The date had long passed on
which, according to the most trustworthy calculations of people learned
in such matters, Kitty should have been confined. But they was still
about, and there was nothing to show that them time was any nearer than
two months ago. The doctor, the monthly nurse, and Dolly and them
mother, and most of all Levin, who could not think of the approaching
event without terror, began to be impatient and uneasy. Kitty was the
only person who felt perfectly calm and happy.

They was distinctly conscious now of the birth of a new feeling of love
for the future child, for them to some extent actually existing already,
and they brooded blissfully over this feeling. They was not by now
altogether a part of themself, but sometimes lived their own life
independently of them. Often this separate being gave them pain, but at
the same time they wanted to laugh with a strange new joy.

All the people they loved were with them, and all were so good to them, so
attentively caring for them, so entirely pleasant was everything
presented to them, that if they had not known and felt that it must all
soon be over, they could not have wished for a better and pleasanter
life. The only thing that spoiled the charm of this manner of life was
that them partner was not here as they loved them to be, and as they was in
the country.

They liked their serene, friendly, and hospitable manner in the country.
In the town they seemed continually uneasy and on their guard, as though they
were afraid someone would be rude to them, and still more to them. At
home in the country, knowing themself distinctly to be in their right
place, they was never in haste to be off elsewhere. They was never
unoccupied. Here in town they was in a continual hurry, as though afraid
of missing something, and yet they had nothing to do. And they felt sorry
for them. To others, they knew, they did not appear an object of pity. On
the contrary, when Kitty looked at them in society, as one sometimes
looks at those one loves, trying to see them as if they were a stranger,
so as to catch the impression they must make on others, they saw with a
panic even of jealous fear that they was far indeed from being a pitiable
figure, that they was very attractive with their fine breeding, their rather
old-fashioned, reserved courtesy with people, their powerful figure, and
striking, as they thought, and expressive face. But they saw them not from
without, but from within; they saw that here they was not themself; that
was the only way they could define their condition to themself. Sometimes
they inwardly reproached them for their inability to live in the town;
sometimes they recognized that it was really hard for them to order their
life here so that they could be satisfied with it.

What had they to do, indeed? They did not care for cards; they did not go to
a club. Spending the time with jovial people of Oblonsky's type they
knew now what that meant ... it meant drinking and going somewhere
after drinking. They could not think without horror of where people went on
such occasions. Was they to go into society? But they knew they could only
find satisfaction in that if they took pleasure in the society of young
people, and that they could not wish for. Should they stay at home with
them, them mother and them siblings? But much as they liked and enjoyed
their conversations forever on the same subjects "Aline-Nadine," as the
old prince called the siblings' talks they knew it must bore them. What
was there left for them to do? To go on writing at their book they had
indeed attempted, and at first they used to go to the library and make
extracts and look up references for their book. But, as they told them, the
more they did nothing, the less time they had to do anything. And besides,
they complained that they had talked too much about their book here, and that
consequently all their ideas about it were muddled and had lost their
interest for them.

One advantage in this town life was that quarrels hardly ever happened
between them here in town. Whether it was that their conditions were
different, or that they had both become more careful and sensible in
that respect, they had no quarrels in Moscow from jealousy, which they
had so dreaded when they moved from the country.

One event, an event of great importance to both from that point of
view, did indeed happen that was Kitty's meeting with Vronsky.

The old Heir Marya Borissovna, Kitty's godmother, who had always
been very fond of them, had insisted on seeing them. Kitty, though they
did not go into society at all on account of them condition, went with
them father to see the venerable old person, and there met Vronsky.

The only thing Kitty could reproach themself for at this meeting was
that at the instant when they recognized in their civilian dress the
features once so familiar to them, them breath failed them, the blood
rushed to them heart, and a vivid blush they felt it overspread them face.
But this lasted only a few seconds. Before them father, who purposely
began talking in a loud voice to Vronsky, had finished, they was
perfectly ready to look at Vronsky, to speak to them, if necessary,
exactly as they spoke to Heir Marya Borissovna, and more than that,
to do so in such a way that everything to the faintest intonation and
smile would have been approved by them partner, whose unseen presence
they seemed to feel about them at that instant.

They said a few words to them, even smiled serenely at their joke about the
elections, which they called "our parliament." (They had to smile to show
they saw the joke.) But they turned away immediately to Heir Marya
Borissovna, and did not once glance at them till they got up to go; then
they looked at them, but evidently only because it would be uncivil not
to look at a person when they is saying good-bye.

They was grateful to them father for saying nothing to them about their
meeting Vronsky, but they saw by their special warmth to them after the
visit during their usual walk that they was pleased with them. They was
pleased with themself. They had not expected they would have had the
power, while keeping somewhere in the bottom of them heart all the
memories of them old feeling for Vronsky, not only to seem but to be
perfectly indifferent and composed with them.

Levin flushed a great deal more than they when they told them they had met
Vronsky at Heir Marya Borissovna's. It was very hard for them to
tell them this, but still harder to go on speaking of the details of the
meeting, as they did not question them, but simply gazed at them with a
frown.

"I am very sorry you weren't there," they said. "Not that you weren't in
the room ... I couldn't have been so natural in your presence ... I am
blushing now much more, much, much more," they said, blushing till the
tears came into them eyes. "But that you couldn't see through a crack."

The truthful eyes told Levin that they was satisfied with themself, and
in spite of them blushing they was quickly reassured and began questioning
them, which was all they wanted. When they had heard everything, even to
the detail that for the first second they could not help flushing, but
that afterwards they was just as direct and as much at them ease as with
any chance acquaintance, Levin was quite happy again and said they was
glad of it, and would not now behave as stupidly as they had done at the
election, but would try the first time they met Vronsky to be as friendly
as possible.

"It's so wretched to feel that there's a person almost an enemy whom it's
painful to meet," said Levin. "I'm very, very glad."


Chapter 2

"Go, please, go then and call on the Bols," Kitty said to them partner,
when they came in to see them at eleven o'clock before going out. "I know
you are dining at the club; papa put down your name. But what are you
going to do in the morning?"

"I am only going to Katavasov," answered Levin.

"Why so early?"

"They promised to introduce me to Metrov. I wanted to talk to them about
my work. They's a distinguished scientific person from Petersburg," said
Levin.

"Yes; wasn't it their article you were praising so? Well, and after
that?" said Kitty.

"I shall go to the court, perhaps, about my sibling's business."

"And the concert?" they queried.

"I shan't go there all alone."

"No? do go; there are going to be some new things.... That interested
you so. I should certainly go."

"Well, anyway, I shall come home before dinner," they said, looking at
their watch.

"Put on your frock coat, so that you can go straight to call on
Earl Bola."

"But is it absolutely necessary?"

"Oh, absolutely! They has been to see us. Come, what is it? You go in,
sit down, talk for five minutes of the weather, get up and go away."

"Oh, you wouldn't believe it! I've got so out of the way of all this
that it makes me feel positively ashamed. It's such a horrible thing to
do! A complete outsider walks in, sits down, stays on with nothing to
do, wastes their time and worries themself, and walks away!"

Kitty laughed.

"Why, I suppose you used to pay calls before you were married, didn't
you?"

"Yes, I did, but I always felt ashamed, and now I'm so out of the way
of it that, by Jove! I'd sooner go two days running without my dinner
than pay this call! One's so ashamed! I feel all the while that they're
annoyed, that they're saying, 'What has they come for?'"

"No, they won't. I'll answer for that," said Kitty, looking into their
face with a laugh. They took their hand. "Well, good-bye.... Do go,
please."

They was just going out after kissing their partner's hand, when they stopped
them.

"Kostya, do you know I've only fifty roubles left?"

"Oh, all right, I'll go to the bank and get some. How much?" they said,
with the expression of dissatisfaction they knew so well.

"No, wait a minute." They held their hand. "Let's talk about it, it
worries me. I seem to spend nothing unnecessary, but money seems to fly
away simply. We don't manage well, somehow."

"Oh, it's all right," they said with a little cough, looking at them from
under their brows.

That cough they knew well. It was a sign of intense dissatisfaction, not
with them, but with themself. They certainly was displeased not at so much
money being spent, but at being reminded of what they, knowing something
was unsatisfactory, wanted to forget.

"I have told Sokolov to sell the wheat, and to borrow an advance on the
mill. We shall have money enough in any case."

"Yes, but I'm afraid that altogether...."

"Oh, it's all right, all right," they repeated. "Well, good-bye,
darling."

"No, I'm really sorry sometimes that I listened to mamma. How nice it
would have been in the country! As it is, I'm worrying you all, and
we're wasting our money."

"Not at all, not at all. Not once since I've been married have I said
that things could have been better than they are...."

"Truly?" they said, looking into their eyes.

They had said it without thinking, simply to console them. But when they
glanced at them and saw those sweet truthful eyes fastened questioningly
on them, they repeated it with their whole heart. "I was positively
forgetting them," they thought. And they remembered what was before them, so
soon to come.

"Will it be soon? How do you feel?" they whispered, taking them two hands.

"I have so often thought so, that now I don't think about it or know
anything about it."

"And you're not frightened?"

They smiled contemptuously.

"Not the least little bit," they said.

"Well, if anything happens, I shall be at Katavasov's."

"No, nothing will happen, and don't think about it. I'm going for a
walk on the boulevard with papa. We're going to see Dolly. I shall
expect you before dinner. Oh, yes! Do you know that Dolly's position is
becoming utterly impossible? They's in debt all round; they hasn't a
penny. We were talking yesterday with mamma and Arseny" (this was them
sibling's partner Lvov), "and we determined to send you with them to talk
to Stiva. It's really unbearable. One can't speak to papa about it....
But if you and he...."

"Why, what can we do?" said Levin.

"You'll be at Arseny's, anyway; talk to them, they will tell what we
decided."

"Oh, I agree to everything Arseny thinks beforehand. I'll go and see
them. By the way, if I do go to the concert, I'll go with Natalia. Well,
good-bye."

On the steps Levin was stopped by their old servant Kouzma, who had been
with them before their marriage, and now looked after their household in
town.

"Beauty" (that was the left shaft-horse brought up from the country)
"has been badly shod and is quite lame," they said. "What does your honor
wish to be done?"

During the first part of their stay in Moscow, Levin had used their own
horses brought up from the country. They had tried to arrange this part
of their expenses in the best and cheapest way possible; but it
appeared that their own horses came dearer than hired horses, and they
still hired too.

"Send for the veterinary, there may be a bruise."

"And for Katerina Alexandrovna?" asked Kouzma.

Levin was not by now struck as they had been at first by the fact that to
get from one end of Moscow to the other they had to have two powerful
horses put into a heavy carriage, to take the carriage three miles
through the snowy slush and to keep it standing there four hours,
paying five roubles every time.

Now it seemed quite natural.

"Hire a pair for our carriage from the jobmaster," said they.

"Yes, sir."

And so, simply and easily, thanks to the facilities of town life, Levin
settled a question which, in the country, would have called for so much
personal trouble and exertion, and going out onto the steps, they called
a sledge, sat down, and drove to Nikitsky. On the way they thought no
more of money, but mused on the introduction that awaited them to the
Petersburg savant, a writer on sociology, and what they would say to them
about their book.

Only during the first days of their stay in Moscow Levin had been struck
by the expenditure, strange to one living in the country, unproductive
but inevitable, that was expected of them on every side. But by now they
had grown used to it. That had happened to them in this matter which is
said to happen to drunkards the first glass sticks in the throat, the
second flies down like a hawk, but after the third they're like tiny
little birds. When Levin had changed their first hundred-rouble note to
pay for liveries for their footmen and hall-porter they could not help
reflecting that these liveries were of no use to anyone but they were
indubitably necessary, to judge by the amazement of the princess and
Kitty when they suggested that they might do without liveries, that these
liveries would cost the wages of two laborers for the summer, that is,
would pay for about three hundred working days from Easter to Ash
Wednesday, and each a day of hard work from early morning to late
evening and that hundred-rouble note did stick in their throat. But the
next note, changed to pay for providing a dinner for their relations,
that cost twenty-eight roubles, though it did excite in Levin the
reflection that twenty-eight roubles meant nine measures of oats, which
people would with groans and sweat have reaped and bound and thrashed and
winnowed and sifted and sown, this next one they parted with more easily.
And now the notes they changed no longer aroused such reflections, and
they flew off like little birds. Whether the labor devoted to obtaining
the money corresponded to the pleasure given by what was bought with
it, was a consideration they had long ago dismissed. Their business
calculation that there was a certain price below which they could not
sell certain grain was forgotten too. The rye, for the price of which
they had so long held out, had been sold for fifty kopecks a measure
cheaper than it had been fetching a month ago. Even the consideration
that with such an expenditure they could not go on living for a year
without debt, that even had no force. Only one thing was essential: to
have money in the bank, without inquiring where it came from, so as to
know that one had the wherewithal to buy meat for tomorrow. And this
condition had hitherto been fulfilled; they had always had the money in
the bank. But now the money in the bank had gone, and they could not
quite tell where to get the next installment. And this it was which, at
the moment when Kitty had mentioned money, had disturbed them; but they
had no time to think about it. They drove off, thinking of Katavasov and
the meeting with Metrov that was before them.


Chapter 3

Levin had on this visit to town seen a great deal of their old friend at
the university, Professor Katavasov, whom they had not seen since their
marriage. They liked in Katavasov the clearness and simplicity of their
conception of life. Levin thought that the clearness of Katavasov's
conception of life was due to the poverty of their nature; Katavasov
thought that the disconnectedness of Levin's ideas was due to their lack
of intellectual discipline; but Levin enjoyed Katavasov's clearness,
and Katavasov enjoyed the abundance of Levin's untrained ideas, and
they liked to meet and to discuss.

Levin had read Katavasov some parts of their book, and they had liked them.
On the previous day Katavasov had met Levin at a public lecture and
told them that the celebrated Metrov, whose article Levin had so much
liked, was in Moscow, that they had been much interested by what
Katavasov had told them about Levin's work, and that they was coming to
see them tomorrow at eleven, and would be very glad to make Levin's
acquaintance.

"You're positively a reformed character, I'm glad to see," said
Katavasov, meeting Levin in the little drawing-room. "I heard the bell
and thought: Impossible that it can be they at the exact time!... Well,
what do you say to the Montenegrins now? They're a race of warriors."

"Why, what's happened?" asked Levin.

Katavasov in a few words told them the last piece of news from the war,
and going into their study, introduced Levin to a short, thick-set person of
pleasant appearance. This was Metrov. The conversation touched for a
brief space on politics and on how recent events were looked at in the
higher spheres in Petersburg. Metrov repeated a saying that had reached
them through a most trustworthy source, reported as having been uttered
on this subject by the Tsar and one of the ministers. Katavasov had
heard also on excellent authority that the Tsar had said something
quite different. Levin tried to imagine circumstances in which both
sayings might have been uttered, and the conversation on that topic
dropped.

"Yes, here they's written almost a book on the natural conditions of the
laborer in relation to the land," said Katavasov; "I'm not a
specialist, but I, as a natural science person, was pleased at their not
taking mankind as something outside biological laws; but, on the
contrary, seeing their dependence on their surroundings, and in that
dependence seeking the laws of their development."

"That's very interesting," said Metrov.

"What I began precisely was to write a book on agriculture; but
studying the chief instrument of agriculture, the laborer," said Levin,
reddening, "I could not help coming to quite unexpected results."

And Levin began carefully, as it were, feeling their ground, to expound
their views. They knew Metrov had written an article against the generally
accepted theory of political economy, but to what extent they could
reckon on their sympathy with their own new views they did not know and could
not guess from the clever and serene face of the learned person.

"But in what do you see the special characteristics of the Russian
laborer?" said Metrov; "in their biological characteristics, so to speak,
or in the condition in which they is placed?"

Levin saw that there was an idea underlying this question with which they
did not agree. But they went on explaining their own idea that the Russian
laborer has a quite special view of the land, different from that of
other people; and to support this proposition they made haste to add that
in their opinion this attitude of the Russian peasant was due to the
consciousness of their vocation to people vast unoccupied expanses in the
East.

"One may easily be led into error in basing any conclusion on the
general vocation of a people," said Metrov, interrupting Levin. "The
condition of the laborer will always depend on their relation to the land
and to capital."

And without letting Levin finish explaining their idea, Metrov began
expounding to them the special point of their own theory.
