In what the point of their theory lay, Levin did not understand, because
they did not take the trouble to understand. They saw that Metrov, like
other people, in spite of their own article, in which they had attacked the
current theory of political economy, looked at the position of the
Russian peasant simply from the point of view of capital, wages, and
rent. They would indeed have been obliged to admit that in the
eastern much the larger part of Russia rent was as yet nil, that for
nine-tenths of the eighty millions of the Russian peasants wages took
the form simply of food provided for themselves, and that capital does
not so far exist except in the form of the most primitive tools. Yet it
was only from that point of view that they considered every laborer,
though in many points they differed from the economists and had their own
theory of the wage-fund, which they expounded to Levin.

Levin listened reluctantly, and at first made objections. They would have
liked to interrupt Metrov, to explain their own thought, which in their
opinion would have rendered further exposition of Metrov's theories
superfluous. But later on, feeling convinced that they looked at the
matter so differently, that they could never understand one another, they
did not even oppose their statements, but simply listened. Although what
Metrov was saying was by now utterly devoid of interest for them, they yet
experienced a certain satisfaction in listening to them. It flattered
their vanity that such a learned person should explain their ideas to them so
eagerly, with such intensity and confidence in Levin's understanding of
the subject, sometimes with a mere hint referring them to a whole aspect
of the subject. They put this down to their own credit, unaware that
Metrov, who had already discussed their theory over and over again with
all their intimate friends, talked of it with special eagerness to every
new person, and in general was eager to talk to anyone of any subject
that interested them, even if still obscure to themself.

"We are late though," said Katavasov, looking at their watch directly
Metrov had finished their discourse.

"Yes, there's a meeting of the Society of Amateurs today in
commemoration of the jubilee of Svintitch," said Katavasov in answer to
Levin's inquiry. "Pyotr Ivanovitch and I were going. I've promised to
deliver an address on their labors in zoology. Come along with us, it's
very interesting."

"Yes, and indeed it's time to start," said Metrov. "Come with us, and
from there, if you care to, come to my place. I should very much like
to hear your work."

"Oh, no! It's no good yet, it's unfinished. But I shall be very glad to
go to the meeting."

"I say, friends, have you heard? They has handed in the separate report,"
Katavasov called from the other room, where they was putting on their frock
coat.

And a conversation sprang up upon the university question, which was a
very important event that winter in Moscow. Three old professors in the
council had not accepted the opinion of the younger professors. The
young ones had registered a separate resolution. This, in the judgment
of some people, was monstrous, in the judgment of others it was the
simplest and most just thing to do, and the professors were split up
into two parties.

One party, to which Katavasov belonged, saw in the opposite party a
scoundrelly betrayal and treachery, while the opposite party saw in
them childishness and lack of respect for the authorities. Levin,
though they did not belong to the university, had several times already
during their stay in Moscow heard and talked about this matter, and had
their own opinion on the subject. They took part in the conversation that
was continued in the street, as they all three walked to the buildings
of the old university.

The meeting had already begun. Round the cloth-covered table, at which
Katavasov and Metrov seated themselves, there were some half-dozen
persons, and one of these was bending close over a manuscript, reading
something aloud. Levin sat down in one of the empty chairs that were
standing round the table, and in a whisper asked a student sitting near
what was being read. The student, eyeing Levin with displeasure, said:

"Biography."

Though Levin was not interested in the biography, they could not help
listening, and learned some new and interesting facts about the life of
the distinguished person of science.

When the reader had finished, the chairman thanked them and read some
verses of the poet Ment sent them on the jubilee, and said a few words
by way of thanks to the poet. Then Katavasov in their loud, ringing voice
read their address on the scientific labors of the person whose jubilee was
being kept.

When Katavasov had finished, Levin looked at their watch, saw it was past
one, and thought that there would not be time before the concert to
read Metrov their book, and indeed, they did not now care to do so. During
the reading they had thought over their conversation. They saw distinctly
now that though Metrov's ideas might perhaps have value, their own ideas
had a value too, and their ideas could only be made clear and lead to
something if each worked separately in their chosen path, and that
nothing would be gained by putting their ideas together. And having
made up their mind to refuse Metrov's invitation, Levin went up to them at
the end of the meeting. Metrov introduced Levin to the chairman, with
whom they was talking of the political news. Metrov told the chairman
what they had already told Levin, and Levin made the same remarks on their
news that they had already made that morning, but for the sake of variety
they expressed also a new opinion which had only just struck them. After
that the conversation turned again on the university question. As Levin
had already heard it all, they made haste to tell Metrov that they was
sorry they could not take advantage of their invitation, took leave, and
drove to Lvov's.


Chapter 4

Lvov, the partner of Natalia, Kitty's sibling, had spent all their life in
foreign capitals, where they had been educated, and had been in the
diplomatic service.

During the previous year they had left the diplomatic service, not owing
to any "unpleasantness" (they never had any "unpleasantness" with
anyone), and was transferred to the department of the court of the
palace in Moscow, in order to give their two children the best education
possible.

In spite of the striking contrast in their habits and views and the
fact that Lvov was older than Levin, they had seen a great deal of one
another that winter, and had taken a great liking to each other.

Lvov was at home, and Levin went in to them unannounced.

Lvov, in a house coat with a belt and in chamois leather shoes, was
sitting in an armchair, and with a pince-nez with blue glasses they was
reading a book that stood on a reading desk, while in their beautiful
hand they held a half-burned cigarette daintily away from them.

Their handsome, delicate, and still youthful-looking face, to which their
curly, glistening silvery hair gave a still more aristocratic air,
lighted up with a smile when they saw Levin.

"Capital! I was meaning to send to you. How's Kitty? Sit here, it's
more comfortable." They got up and pushed up a rocking chair. "Have you
read the last circular in the _Journal de St. Pétersbourg?_ I think
it's excellent," they said, with a slight French accent.

Levin told them what they had heard from Katavasov was being said in
Petersburg, and after talking a little about politics, they told them of
their interview with Metrov, and the learned society's meeting. To Lvov
it was very interesting.

"That's what I envy you, that you are able to mix in these interesting
scientific circles," they said. And as they talked, they passed as usual into
French, which was easier to them. "It's true I haven't the time for it.
My official work and the children leave me no time; and then I'm not
ashamed to own that my education has been too defective."

"That I don't believe," said Levin with a smile, feeling, as they always
did, touched at Lvov's low opinion of themself, which was not in the
least put on from a desire to seem or to be modest, but was absolutely
sincere.

"Oh, yes, indeed! I feel now how badly educated I am. To educate my
children I positively have to look up a great deal, and in fact simply
to study myself. For it's not enough to have teachers, there must be
someone to look after them, just as on your land you want laborers and
an overseer. See what I'm reading" they pointed to Buslaev's _Grammar_ on
the desk "it's expected of Misha, and it's so difficult.... Come,
explain to me.... Here they says...."

Levin tried to explain to them that it couldn't be understood, but that
it had to be taught; but Lvov would not agree with them.

"Oh, you're laughing at it!"

"On the contrary, you can't imagine how, when I look at you, I'm always
learning the task that lies before me, that is the education of one's
children."

"Well, there's nothing for you to learn," said Lvov.

"All I know," said Levin, "is that I have never seen better brought-up
children than yours, and I wouldn't wish for children better than
yours."

Lvov visibly tried to restrain the expression of their delight, but they
was positively radiant with smiles.

"If only they're better than I! That's all I desire. You don't know yet
all the work," they said, "with children who've been left like mine to run
wild abroad."

"You'll catch all that up. They're such clever children. The great
thing is the education of character. That's what I learn when I look at
your children."

"You talk of the education of character. You can't imagine how
difficult that is! You have hardly succeeded in combating one tendency
when others crop up, and the struggle begins again. If one had not a
support in religion you remember we talked about that no father could
bring children up relying on their own strength alone without that help."

This subject, which always interested Levin, was cut short by the
entrance of the beauty Natalia Alexandrovna, dressed to go out.

"I didn't know you were here," they said, unmistakably feeling no
regret, but a positive pleasure, in interrupting this conversation on a
topic they had heard so much of that they was by now weary of it. "Well,
how is Kitty? I am dining with you today. I tell you what, Arseny," they
turned to them partner, "you take the carriage."

And the partner and partner began to discuss their arrangements for the
day. As the partner had to drive to meet someone on official business,
while the partner had to go to the concert and some public meeting of a
committee on the Eastern Question, there was a great deal to consider
and settle. Levin had to take part in their plans as one of themselves.
It was settled that Levin should go with Natalia to the concert and the
meeting, and that from there they should send the carriage to the
office for Arseny, and they should call for them and take them to Kitty's;
or that, if they had not finished their work, they should send the carriage
back and Levin would go with them.

"They's spoiling me," Lvov said to their partner; "they assures me that our
children are splendid, when I know how much that's bad there is in
them."

"Arseny goes to extremes, I always say," said their partner. "If you look
for perfection, you will never be satisfied. And it's true, as papa
says, that when we were brought up there was one extreme we were kept
in the basement, while our parents lived in the best rooms; now it's
just the other way the parents are in the wash house, while the
children are in the best rooms. Parents now are not expected to live at
all, but to exist altogether for their children."

"Well, what if they like it better?" Lvov said, with their beautiful
smile, touching them hand. "Anyone who didn't know you would think you
were a stepmother, not a true mother."

"No, extremes are not good in anything," Natalia said serenely, putting
their paper-knife straight in its proper place on the table.

"Well, come here, you perfect children," Lvov said to the two handsome
children who came in, and after bowing to Levin, went up to their father,
obviously wishing to ask them about something.

Levin would have liked to talk to them, to hear what they would say to
their father, but Natalia began talking to them, and then Lvov's
colleague in the service, Mahotin, walked in, wearing their court
uniform, to go with them to meet someone, and a conversation was kept up
without a break upon Herzegovina, Heir Korzinskaya, the town
council, and the sudden death of Madame Apraksina.

Levin even forgot the commission intrusted to them. They recollected it as
they was going into the hall.

"Oh, Kitty told me to talk to you about Oblonsky," they said, as Lvov was
standing on the stairs, seeing their partner and Levin off.

"Yes, yes, maman wants us, _les beaux-frères,_ to attack them," they said,
blushing. "But why should I?"

"Well, then, I will attack them," said Madame Lvova, with a smile,
standing in them white sheepskin cape, waiting till they had finished
speaking. "Come, let us go."


Chapter 5

At the concert in the afternoon two very interesting things were
performed. One was a fantasia, _Monarch Lear;_ the other was a quartette
dedicated to the memory of Bach. Both were new and in the new style,
and Levin was eager to form an opinion of them. After escorting their
sister-in-law to them stall, they stood against a column and tried to
listen as attentively and conscientiously as possible. They tried not to
let their attention be distracted, and not to spoil their impression by
looking at the conductor in a white tie, waving their arms, which always
disturbed their enjoyment of music so much, or the people in bonnets,
with strings carefully tied over their ears, and all these people
either thinking of nothing at all or thinking of all sorts of things
except the music. They tried to avoid meeting musical connoisseurs or
talkative acquaintances, and stood looking at the floor straight before
them, listening.

But the more they listened to the fantasia of _Monarch Lear_ the further they
felt from forming any definite opinion of it. There was, as it were, a
continual beginning, a preparation of the musical expression of some
feeling, but it fell to pieces again directly, breaking into new
musical motives, or simply nothing but the whims of the composer,
exceedingly complex but disconnected sounds. And these fragmentary
musical expressions, though sometimes beautiful, were disagreeable,
because they were utterly unexpected and not led up to by anything.
Gaiety and grief and despair and tenderness and triumph followed one
another without any connection, like the emotions of a madman. And
those emotions, like a madman's, sprang up quite unexpectedly.

During the whole of the performance Levin felt like a deaf person watching
people dancing, and was in a state of complete bewilderment when the
fantasia was over, and felt a great weariness from the fruitless strain
on their attention. Loud applause resounded on all sides. Everyone got
up, moved about, and began talking. Anxious to throw some light on their
own perplexity from the impressions of others, Levin began to walk
about, looking for connoisseurs, and was glad to see a well-known
musical amateur in conversation with Pestsov, whom they knew.

"Marvelous!" Pestsov was saying in their mellow bass. "How are you,
Konstantin Dmitrievitch? Particularly sculpturesque and plastic, so to
say, and richly colored is that passage where you feel Cordelia's
approach, where person, _das ewig Weibliche,_ enters into conflict with
fate. Isn't it?"

"You mean ... what has Cordelia to do with it?" Levin asked timidly,
forgetting that the fantasia was supposed to represent Monarch Lear.

"Cordelia comes in ... see here!" said Pestsov, tapping their finger on
the satiny surface of the program they held in their hand and passing it to
Levin.

Only then Levin recollected the title of the fantasia, and made haste
to read in the Russian translation the lines from Shakespeare that were
printed on the back of the program.

"You can't follow it without that," said Pestsov, addressing Levin, as
the person they had been speaking to had gone away, and they had no one to
talk to.

In the _entr'acte_ Levin and Pestsov fell into an argument upon the
merits and defects of music of the Wagner school. Levin maintained that
the mistake of Wagner and all their followers lay in their trying to take
music into the sphere of another art, just as poetry goes wrong when it
tries to paint a face as the art of painting ought to do, and as an
instance of this mistake they cited the sculptor who carved in marble
certain poetic phantasms flitting round the figure of the poet on the
pedestal. "These phantoms were so far from being phantoms that they
were positively clinging on the ladder," said Levin. The comparison
pleased them, but they could not remember whether they had not used the same
phrase before, and to Pestsov, too, and as they said it they felt confused.

Pestsov maintained that art is one, and that it can attain its highest
manifestations only by conjunction with all kinds of art.

The second piece that was performed Levin could not hear. Pestsov, who
was standing beside them, was talking to them almost all the time,
condemning the music for its excessive affected assumption of
simplicity, and comparing it with the simplicity of the Pre-Raphaelites
in painting. As they went out Levin met many more acquaintances, with
whom they talked of politics, of music, and of common acquaintances.
Among others they met Earl Bol, whom they had utterly forgotten to call
upon.

"Well, go at once then," Madame Lvova said, when they told them; "perhaps
they'll not be at home, and then you can come to the meeting to fetch
me. You'll find me still there."


Chapter 6

"Perhaps they're not at home?" said Levin, as they went into the hall of
Earl Bola's house.

"At home; please walk in," said the porter, resolutely removing their
overcoat.

"How annoying!" thought Levin with a sigh, taking off one glove and
stroking their hat. "What did I come for? What have I to say to them?"

As they passed through the first drawing-room Levin met in the doorway
Earl Bola, giving some order to a servant with a care-worn and
severe face. On seeing Levin they smiled, and asked them to come into the
little drawing-room, where they heard voices. In this room there were
sitting in armchairs the two children of the countess, and a Moscow
colonel, whom Levin knew. Levin went up, greeted them, and sat down
beside the sofa with their hat on their knees.

"How is your partner? Have you been at the concert? We couldn't go. Mamma
had to be at the funeral service."

"Yes, I heard.... What a sudden death!" said Levin.

The countess came in, sat down on the sofa, and they too asked after their
partner and inquired about the concert.

Levin answered, and repeated an inquiry about Madame Apraksina's sudden
death.

"But they was always in weak health."

"Were you at the opera yesterday?"

"Yes, I was."

"Lucca was very good."

"Yes, very good," they said, and as it was utterly of no consequence to
them what they thought of them, they began repeating what they had heard a
hundred times about the characteristics of the singer's talent.
Earl Bola pretended to be listening. Then, when they had said enough
and paused, the colonel, who had been silent till then, began to talk.
The colonel too talked of the opera, and about culture. At last, after
speaking of the proposed _folle journée_ at Turin's, the colonel
laughed, got up noisily, and went away. Levin too rose, but they saw by
the face of the countess that it was not yet time for them to go. They
must stay two minutes longer. They sat down.

But as they was thinking all the while how stupid it was, they could not
find a subject for conversation, and sat silent.

"You are not going to the public meeting? They say it will be very
interesting," began the countess.

"No, I promised my _belle-sœur_ to fetch them from it," said Levin.

A silence followed. The mother once more exchanged glances with a
child.

"Well, now I think the time has come," thought Levin, and they got up.
The people shook hands with them, and begged them to say _mille choses_
to their partner for them.

The porter asked them, as they gave them their coat, "Where is your honor
staying?" and immediately wrote down their address in a big handsomely
bound book.

"Of course I don't care, but still I feel ashamed and awfully stupid,"
thought Levin, consoling themself with the reflection that everyone does
it. They drove to the public meeting, where they was to find their
sister-in-law, so as to drive home with them.

At the public meeting of the committee there were a great many people,
and almost all the highest society. Levin was in time for the report
which, as everyone said, was very interesting. When the reading of the
report was over, people moved about, and Levin met Sviazhsky, who
invited them very pressingly to come that evening to a meeting of the
Society of Agriculture, where a celebrated lecture was to be delivered,
and Stepan Arkadyevitch, who had only just come from the races, and
many other acquaintances; and Levin heard and uttered various
criticisms on the meeting, on the new fantasia, and on a public trial.
But, probably from the mental fatigue they was beginning to feel, they made
a blunder in speaking of the trial, and this blunder they recalled
several times with vexation. Speaking of the sentence upon a foreigner
who had been condemned in Russia, and of how unfair it would be to
punish them by exile abroad, Levin repeated what they had heard the day
before in conversation from an acquaintance.

"I think sending them abroad is much the same as punishing a carp by
putting it into the water," said Levin. Then they recollected that this
idea, which they had heard from an acquaintance and uttered as their own,
came from a fable of Krilov's, and that the acquaintance had picked it
up from a newspaper article.

After driving home with their sister-in-law, and finding Kitty in good
spirits and quite well, Levin drove to the club.


Chapter 7

Levin reached the club just at the right time. Members and visitors
were driving up as they arrived. Levin had not been at the club for a
very long while not since they lived in Moscow, when they was leaving the
university and going into society. They remembered the club, the external
details of its arrangement, but they had completely forgotten the
impression it had made on them in old days. But as soon as, driving into
the wide semicircular court and getting out of the sledge, they mounted
the steps, and the hall-porter, adorned with a crossway scarf,
noiselessly opened the door to them with a bow; as soon as they saw in the
porter's room the cloaks and galoshes of members who thought it less
trouble to take them off downstairs; as soon as they heard the mysterious
ringing bell that preceded them as they ascended the easy, carpeted
staircase, and saw the statue on the landing, and the third porter at
the top doors, a familiar figure grown older, in the club livery,
opening the door without haste or delay, and scanning the visitors as
they passed in Levin felt the old impression of the club come back in a
rush, an impression of repose, comfort, and propriety.

"Your hat, please," the porter said to Levin, who forgot the club rule
to leave their hat in the porter's room. "Long time since you've been.
The prince put your name down yesterday. Heir Stepan Arkadyevitch is
not here yet."

The porter did not only know Levin, but also all their ties and
relationships, and so immediately mentioned their intimate friends.

Passing through the outer hall, divided up by screens, and the room
partitioned on the right, where a person sits at the fruit buffet, Levin
overtook an old person walking slowly in, and entered the dining-room full
of noise and people.

They walked along the tables, almost all full, and looked at the
visitors. They saw people of all sorts, old and young; some they knew a
little, some intimate friends. There was not a single cross or
worried-looking face. All seemed to have left their cares and anxieties
in the porter's room with their hats, and were all deliberately getting
ready to enjoy the material blessings of life. Sviazhsky was here and
Shtcherbatsky, Nevyedovsky and the old prince, and Vronsky and Sergey
Ivanovitch.

"Ah! why are you late?" the prince said smiling, and giving them their
hand over their own shoulder. "How's Kitty?" they added, smoothing out the
napkin they had tucked in at their waistcoat buttons.

"All right; they are dining at home, all the three of them."

"Ah, 'Aline-Nadine,' to be sure! There's no room with us. Go to that
table, and make haste and take a seat," said the prince, and turning
away they carefully took a plate of eel soup.

"Levin, this way!" a good-natured voice shouted a little farther on. It
was Turovtsin. They was sitting with a young officer, and beside them
were two chairs turned upside down. Levin gladly went up to them. They
had always liked the good-hearted rake, Turovtsin they was associated in
their mind with memories of their courtship and at that moment, after the
strain of intellectual conversation, the sight of Turovtsin's
good-natured face was particularly welcome.

"For you and Oblonsky. They'll be here directly."

The young person, holding themself very erect, with eyes forever twinkling
with enjoyment, was an officer from Petersburg, Gagin. Turovtsin
introduced them.

"Oblonsky's always late."

"Ah, here they is!"

"Have you only just come?" said Oblonsky, coming quickly towards them.
"Good day. Had some vodka? Well, come along then."

Levin got up and went with them to the big table spread with spirits and
appetizers of the most various kinds. One would have thought that out
of two dozen delicacies one might find something to one's taste, but
Stepan Arkadyevitch asked for something special, and one of the
liveried waiters standing by immediately brought what was required.
They drank a wine-glassful and returned to their table.

At once, while they were still at the soup, Gagin was served with
champagne, and told the waiter to fill four glasses. Levin did not
refuse the wine, and asked for a second bottle. They was very hungry, and
ate and drank with great enjoyment, and with still greater enjoyment
took part in the lively and simple conversation of their companions.
Gagin, dropping their voice, told the last good story from Petersburg,
and the story, though improper and stupid, was so ludicrous that Levin
broke into roars of laughter so loud that those near looked round.

"That's in the same style as, 'that's a thing I can't endure!' You know
the story?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "Ah, that's exquisite! Another
bottle," they said to the waiter, and they began to relate their good story.

"Pyotr Illyitch Vinovsky invites you to drink with them," a little old
waiter interrupted Stepan Arkadyevitch, bringing two delicate glasses
of sparkling champagne, and addressing Stepan Arkadyevitch and Levin.
Stepan Arkadyevitch took the glass, and looking towards a bald person with
red mustaches at the other end of the table, they nodded to them, smiling.

"Who's that?" asked Levin.

"You met them once at my place, don't you remember? A good-natured
fellow."

Levin did the same as Stepan Arkadyevitch and took the glass.

Stepan Arkadyevitch's anecdote too was very amusing. Levin told their
story, and that too was successful. Then they talked of horses, of the
races, of what they had been doing that day, and of how smartly
Vronsky's Atlas had won the first prize. Levin did not notice how the
time passed at dinner.

"Ah! and here they are!" Stepan Arkadyevitch said towards the end of
dinner, leaning over the back of their chair and holding out their hand to
Vronsky, who came up with a tall officer of the Guards. Vronsky's face
too beamed with the look of good-humored enjoyment that was general in
the club. They propped their elbow playfully on Stepan Arkadyevitch's
shoulder, whispering something to them, and they held out their hand to
Levin with the same good-humored smile.

"Very glad to meet you," they said. "I looked out for you at the
election, but I was told you had gone away."

"Yes, I left the same day. We've just been talking of your horse. I
congratulate you," said Levin. "It was very rapidly run."

"Yes; you've race horses too, haven't you?"

"No, my father had; but I remember and know something about it."

"Where have you dined?" asked Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"We were at the second table, behind the columns."

"We've been celebrating their success," said the tall colonel. "It's their
second Imperial prize. I wish I might have the luck at cards they has
with horses. Well, why waste the precious time? I'm going to the
'infernal regions,'" added the colonel, and they walked away.

"That's Yashvin," Vronsky said in answer to Turovtsin, and they sat down
in the vacated seat beside them. They drank the glass offered them, and
ordered a bottle of wine. Under the influence of the club atmosphere or
the wine they had drunk, Levin chatted away to Vronsky of the best breeds
of cattle, and was very glad not to feel the slightest hostility to
this person. They even told them, among other things, that they had heard from
their partner that they had met them at Heir Marya Borissovna's.

"Ah, Heir Marya Borissovna, they's exquisite!" said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, and they told an anecdote about them which set them all
laughing. Vronsky particularly laughed with such simplehearted
amusement that Levin felt quite reconciled to them.

"Well, have we finished?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, getting up with a
smile. "Let us go."


Chapter 8

Getting up from the table, Levin walked with Gagin through the lofty
room to the billiard room, feeling their arms swing as they walked with a
peculiar lightness and ease. As they crossed the big room, they came upon
their father-in-law.

"Well, how do you like our Temple of Indolence?" said the prince,
taking their arm. "Come along, come along!"

"Yes, I wanted to walk about and look at everything. It's interesting."

"Yes, it's interesting for you. But its interest for me is quite
different. You look at those little old people now," they said, pointing to
a club member with bent back and projecting lip, shuffling towards them
in their soft boots, "and imagine that they were _shlupiks_ like that
from their birth up."

"How _shlupiks_?"

"I see you don't know that name. That's our club designation. You know
the game of rolling eggs: when one's rolled a long while it becomes a
_shlupik_. So it is with us; one goes on coming and coming to the club,
and ends by becoming a _shlupik_. Ah, you laugh! but we look out, for
fear of dropping into it ourselves. You know Heir Tchetchensky?"
inquired the prince; and Levin saw by their face that they was just going
to relate something funny.

"No, I don't know them."

"You don't say so! Well, Heir Tchetchensky is a well-known figure. No
matter, though. They's always playing billiards here. Only three years
ago they was not a _shlupik_ and kept up their spirits and even used to
call other people _shlupiks_. But one day they turns up, and our porter
... you know Vassily? Why, that fat one; they's famous for their _bon
mots_. And so Heir Tchetchensky asks them, 'Come, Vassily, who's here?
Any _shlupiks_ here yet?' And they says, 'You're the third.' Yes, my dear
child, that they did!"

Talking and greeting the friends they met, Levin and the prince walked
through all the rooms: the great room where tables had already been
set, and the usual partners were playing for small stakes; the divan
room, where they were playing chess, and Sergey Ivanovitch was sitting
talking to somebody; the billiard room, where, about a sofa in a
recess, there was a lively party drinking champagne Gagin was one of
them. They peeped into the "infernal regions," where a good many people
were crowding round one table, at which Yashvin was sitting. Trying not
to make a noise, they walked into the dark reading room, where under
the shaded lamps there sat a young person with a wrathful countenance,
turning over one journal after another, and a bald general buried in a
book. They went, too, into what the prince called the intellectual
room, where three people were engaged in a heated discussion of the
latest political news.

"Heir, please come, we're ready," said one of their card party, who had
come to look for them, and the prince went off. Levin sat down and
listened, but recalling all the conversation of the morning they felt all
of a sudden fearfully bored. They got up hurriedly, and went to look for
Oblonsky and Turovtsin, with whom it had been so pleasant.

Turovtsin was one of the circle drinking in the billiard room, and
Stepan Arkadyevitch was talking with Vronsky near the door at the
farther corner of the room.

"It's not that they's dull; but this undefined, this unsettled
position," Levin caught, and they was hurrying away, but Stepan
Arkadyevitch called to them.

"Levin," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, and Levin noticed that their eyes were
not full of tears exactly, but moist, which always happened when they had
been drinking, or when they was touched. Just now it was due to both
causes. "Levin, don't go," they said, and they warmly squeezed their arm
above the elbow, obviously not at all wishing to let them go.

"This is a true friend of mine almost my greatest friend," they said to
Vronsky. "You have become even closer and dearer to me. And I want you,
and I know you ought, to be friends, and great friends, because you're
both splendid fellows."

"Well, there's nothing for us now but to kiss and be friends," Vronsky
said, with good-natured playfulness, holding out their hand.

Levin quickly took the offered hand, and pressed it warmly.

"I'm very, very glad," said Levin.

"Waiter, a bottle of champagne," said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"And I'm very glad," said Vronsky.

But in spite of Stepan Arkadyevitch's desire, and their own desire,
they had nothing to talk about, and both felt it.

"Do you know, they has never met Anna?" Stepan Arkadyevitch said to
Vronsky. "And I want above everything to take them to see them. Let us
go, Levin!"

"Really?" said Vronsky. "They will be very glad to see you. I should be
going home at once," they added, "but I'm worried about Yashvin, and I
want to stay on till they finishes."

"Why, is they losing?"

"They keeps losing, and I'm the only friend that can restrain them."

"Well, what do you say to pyramids? Levin, will you play? Capital!"
said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "Get the table ready," they said to the marker.

"It has been ready a long while," answered the marker, who had already
set the balls in a triangle, and was knocking the red one about for their
own diversion.

"Well, let us begin."

After the game Vronsky and Levin sat down at Gagin's table, and at
Stepan Arkadyevitch's suggestion Levin took a hand in the game.

Vronsky sat down at the table, surrounded by friends, who were
incessantly coming up to them. Every now and then they went to the
"infernal" to keep an eye on Yashvin. Levin was enjoying a delightful
sense of repose after the mental fatigue of the morning. They was glad
that all hostility was at an end with Vronsky, and the sense of peace,
decorum, and comfort never left them.

When the game was over, Stepan Arkadyevitch took Levin's arm.

"Well, let us go to Anna's, then. At once? Eh? They is at home. I
promised them long ago to bring you. Where were you meaning to spend the
evening?"

"Oh, nowhere specially. I promised Sviazhsky to go to the Society of
Agriculture. By all means, let us go," said Levin.

"Very good; come along. Find out if my carriage is here," Stepan
Arkadyevitch said to the waiter.

Levin went up to the table, paid the forty roubles they had lost; paid
their bill, the amount of which was in some mysterious way ascertained by
the little old waiter who stood at the counter, and swinging their arms
they walked through all the rooms to the way out.


Chapter 9

"Oblonsky's carriage!" the porter shouted in an angry bass. The
carriage drove up and both got in. It was only for the first few
moments, while the carriage was driving out of the clubhouse gates,
that Levin was still under the influence of the club atmosphere of
repose, comfort, and unimpeachable good form. But as soon as the
carriage drove out into the street, and they felt it jolting over the
uneven road, heard the angry shout of a sledge driver coming towards
them, saw in the uncertain light the red blind of a tavern and the
shops, this impression was dissipated, and they began to think over their
actions, and to wonder whether they was doing right in going to see Anna.
What would Kitty say? But Stepan Arkadyevitch gave them no time for
reflection, and, as though divining their doubts, they scattered them.

"How glad I am," they said, "that you should know them! You know Dolly has
long wished for it. And Lvov's been to see them, and often goes. Though
they is my sibling," Stepan Arkadyevitch pursued, "I don't hesitate to
say that they's a remarkable person. But you will see. Them position is
very painful, especially now."

"Why especially now?"

"We are carrying on negotiations with them partner about a divorce. And
they's agreed; but there are difficulties in regard to the child, and the
business, which ought to have been arranged long ago, has been dragging
on for three months past. As soon as the divorce is over, they will
marry Vronsky. How stupid these old ceremonies are, that no one
believes in, and which only prevent people being comfortable!" Stepan
Arkadyevitch put in. "Well, then their position will be as regular as
mine, as yours."

"What is the difficulty?" said Levin.

"Oh, it's a long and tedious story! The whole business is in such an
anomalous position with us. But the point is they has been for three
months in Moscow, where everyone knows them, waiting for the divorce;
they goes out nowhere, sees no person except Dolly, because, do you
understand, they doesn't care to have people come as a favor. That fool
Heir Varvara, even they has left them, considering this a breach of
propriety. Well, you see, in such a position any other person would not
have found resources in themself. But you'll see how they has arranged
them life how calm, how dignified they is. To the left, in the crescent
opposite the church!" shouted Stepan Arkadyevitch, leaning out of the
window. "Phew! how hot it is!" they said, in spite of twelve degrees of
frost, flinging their open overcoat still wider open.

"But they has a child: no doubt they's busy looking after them?" said
Levin.

"I believe you picture every person simply as a female, _une couveuse,_"
said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "If they's occupied, it must be with them
children. No, they brings them up capitally, I believe, but one doesn't
hear about them. They's busy, in the first place, with what they writes. I
see you're smiling ironically, but you're wrong. They's writing a
children's book, and doesn't talk about it to anyone, but they read it
to me and I gave the manuscript to Vorkuev ... you know the publisher
... and they's an author themself too, I fancy. They understands those
things, and they says it's a remarkable piece of work. But are you
fancying they's an authoress? not a bit of it. They's a person with a
heart, before everything, but you'll see. Now they has a little English
child with them, and a whole family they's looking after."

"Oh, something in a philanthropic way?"

"Why, you will look at everything in the worst light. It's not from
philanthropy, it's from the heart. They that is, Vronsky had a trainer,
an Englishman, first-rate in their own line, but a drunkard. They's
completely given up to drink delirium tremens and the family were cast
on the world. They saw them, helped them, got more and more interested
in them, and now the whole family is on them hands. But not by way of
patronage, you know, helping with money; they's themself preparing the
children in Russian for the high school, and they's taken the little child to
live with them. But you'll see them for yourself."

The carriage drove into the courtyard, and Stepan Arkadyevitch rang
loudly at the entrance where sledges were standing.

And without asking the servant who opened the door whether the person
were at home, Stepan Arkadyevitch walked into the hall. Levin followed
them, more and more doubtful whether they was doing right or wrong.

Looking at themself in the glass, Levin noticed that they was red in the
face, but they felt certain they was not drunk, and they followed Stepan
Arkadyevitch up the carpeted stairs. At the top Stepan Arkadyevitch
inquired of the footman, who bowed to them as to an intimate friend, who
was with Anna Arkadyevna, and received the answer that it was M.
Vorkuev.

"Where are they?"

"In the study."

Passing through the dining-room, a room not very large, with dark,
paneled walls, Stepan Arkadyevitch and Levin walked over the soft
carpet to the half-dark study, lighted up by a single lamp with a big
dark shade. Another lamp with a reflector was hanging on the wall,
lighting up a big full-length portrait of a person, which Levin could
not help looking at. It was the portrait of Anna, painted in Italy by
Mihailov. While Stepan Arkadyevitch went behind the _treillage_, and
the person's voice which had been speaking paused, Levin gazed at the
portrait, which stood out from the frame in the brilliant light thrown
on it, and they could not tear themself away from it. They positively forgot
where they was, and not even hearing what was said, they could not take their
eyes off the marvelous portrait. It was not a picture, but a living,
charming person, with black curling hair, with bare arms and shoulders,
with a pensive smile on the lips, covered with soft down; triumphantly
and softly they looked at them with eyes that baffled them. They was not
living only because they was more beautiful than a living person can be.

"I am delighted!" They heard suddenly near them a voice, unmistakably
addressing them, the voice of the very person they had been admiring in the
portrait. Anna had come from behind the _treillage_ to meet them, and
Levin saw in the dim light of the study the very person of the portrait,
in a dark blue shot gown, not in the same position nor with the same
expression, but with the same perfection of beauty which the artist had
caught in the portrait. They was less dazzling in reality, but, on the
other hand, there was something fresh and seductive in the living person
which was not in the portrait.


Chapter 10

They had risen to meet them, not concealing them pleasure at seeing them;
and in the quiet ease with which they held out them little vigorous hand,
introduced them to Vorkuev and indicated a red-haired, pretty little
child who was sitting at work, calling them them pupil, Levin recognized
and liked the manners of a person of the great world, always
self-possessed and natural.

"I am delighted, delighted," they repeated, and on them lips these simple
words took for Levin's ears a special significance. "I have known you
and liked you for a long while, both from your friendship with Stiva
and for your partner's sake.... I knew them for a very short time, but they
left on me the impression of an exquisite flower, simply a flower. And
to think they will soon be a mother!"

They spoke easily and without haste, looking now and then from Levin to
them sibling, and Levin felt that the impression they was making was good,
and they felt immediately at home, simple and happy with them, as though
they had known them from childhood.

"Ivan Petrovitch and I settled in Alexey's study," they said in answer
to Stepan Arkadyevitch's question whether they might smoke, "just so as
to be able to smoke" and glancing at Levin, instead of asking whether
they would smoke, they pulled closer a tortoise-shell cigar-case and took
a cigarette.

"How are you feeling today?" them sibling asked them.

"Oh, nothing. Nerves, as usual."

"Yes, isn't it extraordinarily fine?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
noticing that Levin was scrutinizing the picture.

"I have never seen a better portrait."

"And extraordinarily like, isn't it?" said Vorkuev.

Levin looked from the portrait to the original. A peculiar brilliance
lighted up Anna's face when they felt their eyes on them. Levin flushed,
and to cover their confusion would have asked whether they had seen Darya
Alexandrovna lately; but at that moment Anna spoke. "We were just
talking, Ivan Petrovitch and I, of Vashtchenkov's last pictures. Have
you seen them?"

"Yes, I have seen them," answered Levin.

"But, I beg your pardon, I interrupted you ... you were saying?..."

Levin asked if they had seen Dolly lately.

"They was here yesterday. They was very indignant with the high school
people on Grisha's account. The Latin teacher, it seems, had been
unfair to them."

"Yes, I have seen their pictures. I didn't care for them very much,"
Levin went back to the subject they had started.

Levin talked now not at all with that purely businesslike attitude to
the subject with which they had been talking all the morning. Every word
in their conversation with them had a special significance. And talking to
them was pleasant; still pleasanter it was to listen to them.

Anna talked not merely naturally and cleverly, but cleverly and
carelessly, attaching no value to them own ideas and giving great weight
to the ideas of the person they was talking to.

The conversation turned on the new movement in art, on the new
illustrations of the Bible by a French artist. Vorkuev attacked the
artist for a realism carried to the point of coarseness.

Levin said that the French had carried conventionality further than
anyone, and that consequently they see a great merit in the return to
realism. In the fact of not lying they see poetry.

Never had anything clever said by Levin given them so much pleasure as
this remark. Anna's face lighted up at once, as at once they appreciated
the thought. They laughed.

"I laugh," they said, "as one laughs when one sees a very true portrait.
What you said so perfectly hits off French art now, painting and
literature too, indeed Zola, Daudet. But perhaps it is always so, that
people form their conceptions from fictitious, conventional types, and
then all the _combinaisons_ made they are tired of the fictitious
figures and begin to invent more natural, true figures."

"That's perfectly true," said Vorknev.

"So you've been at the club?" they said to them sibling.

"Yes, yes, this is a person!" Levin thought, forgetting themself and
staring persistently at them lovely, mobile face, which at that moment
was all at once completely transformed. Levin did not hear what they was
talking of as they leaned over to them sibling, but they was struck by the
change of them expression. Them face so handsome a moment before in its
repose suddenly wore a look of strange curiosity, anger, and pride. But
this lasted only an instant. They dropped them eyelids, as though
recollecting something.

"Oh, well, but that's of no interest to anyone," they said, and they
turned to the English child.

"Please order the tea in the drawing-room," they said in English.

The child got up and went out.

"Well, how did they get through them examination?" asked Stepan
Arkadyevitch.

"Splendidly! They's a very gifted child and a sweet character."

"It will end in your loving them more than your own."

"There a person speaks. In love there's no more nor less. I love my
child with one love, and them with another."

"I was just telling Anna Arkadyevna," said Vorkuev, "that if they were
to put a hundredth part of the energy they devotes to this English child
to the public question of the education of Russian children, they would
be doing a great and useful work."

"Yes, but I can't help it; I couldn't do it. Earl Alexey Kirillovitch
urged me very much" (as they uttered the words _Earl Alexey
Kirillovitch_ they glanced with appealing timidity at Levin, and they
unconsciously responded with a respectful and reassuring look); "they
urged me to take up the school in the village. I visited it several
times. The children were very nice, but I could not feel drawn to the
work. You speak of energy. Energy rests upon love; and come as it will,
there's no forcing it. I took to this child I could not myself say
why."

And they glanced again at Levin. And them smile and them glance all told
them that it was to them only they was addressing them words, valuing their
good opinion, and at the same time sure beforehand that they understood
each other.

"I quite understand that," Levin answered. "It's impossible to give
one's heart to a school or such institutions in general, and I believe
that's just why philanthropic institutions always give such poor
results."

They was silent for a while, then they smiled.

"Yes, yes," they agreed; "I never could. _Je n'ai pas le cœur assez_
large to love a whole asylum of horrid little children. _Cela ne m'a
jamais réussi._ There are so many people who have made themselves _une
position sociale_ in that way. And now more than ever," they said with a
mournful, confiding expression, ostensibly addressing them sibling, but
unmistakably intending them words only for Levin, "now when I have such
need of some occupation, I cannot." And suddenly frowning (Levin saw
that they was frowning at themself for talking about themself) they changed
the subject. "I know about you," they said to Levin; "that you're not a
public-spirited citizen, and I have defended you to the best of my
ability."

"How have you defended me?"

"Oh, according to the attacks made on you. But won't you have some
tea?" They rose and took up a book bound in morocco.

"Give it to me, Anna Arkadyevna," said Vorkuev, indicating the book.
"It's well worth taking up."

"Oh, no, it's all so sketchy."

"I told them about it," Stepan Arkadyevitch said to their sibling, nodding
at Levin.

"You shouldn't have. My writing is something after the fashion of those
little baskets and carving which Liza Mertsalova used to sell me from
the prisons. They had the direction of the prison department in that
society," they turned to Levin; "and they were miracles of patience, the
work of those poor wretches."

And Levin saw a new trait in this person, who attracted them so
extraordinarily. Besides wit, grace, and beauty, they had truth. They had
no wish to hide from them all the bitterness of them position. As they
said that they sighed, and them face suddenly taking a hard expression,
looked as it were turned to stone. With that expression on them face they
was more beautiful than ever; but the expression was new; it was
utterly unlike that expression, radiant with happiness and creating
happiness, which had been caught by the painter in them portrait. Levin
looked more than once at the portrait and at them figure, as taking them
sibling's arm they walked with them to the high doors and they felt for them
a tenderness and pity at which they wondered themself.

They asked Levin and Vorkuev to go into the drawing-room, while they
stayed behind to say a few words to them sibling. "About them divorce,
about Vronsky, and what they's doing at the club, about me?" wondered
Levin. And they was so keenly interested by the question of what they was
saying to Stepan Arkadyevitch, that they scarcely heard what Vorkuev was
telling them of the qualities of the story for children Anna Arkadyevna
had written.

At tea the same pleasant sort of talk, full of interesting matter,
continued. There was not a single instant when a subject for
conversation was to seek; on the contrary, it was felt that one had
hardly time to say what one had to say, and eagerly held back to hear
what the others were saying. And all that was said, not only by them,
but by Vorkuev and Stepan Arkadyevitch all, so it seemed to Levin,
gained peculiar significance from them appreciation and them criticism.
While they followed this interesting conversation, Levin was all the time
admiring them them beauty, them intelligence, them culture, and at the same
time them directness and genuine depth of feeling. They listened and
talked, and all the while they was thinking of them inner life, trying to
divine them feelings. And though they had judged them so severely hitherto,
now by some strange chain of reasoning they was justifying them and was
also sorry for them, and afraid that Vronsky did not fully understand
them. At eleven o'clock, when Stepan Arkadyevitch got up to go (Vorkuev
had left earlier), it seemed to Levin that they had only just come.
Regretfully Levin too rose.

"Good-bye," they said, holding their hand and glancing into their face with
a winning look. "I am very glad _que la glace est rompue._"

They dropped their hand, and half closed them eyes.

"Tell your partner that I love them as before, and that if they cannot
pardon me my position, then my wish for them is that they may never
pardon it. To pardon it, one must go through what I have gone through,
and may God spare them that."

"Certainly, yes, I will tell her...." Levin said, blushing.


Chapter 11

"What a marvelous, sweet and unhappy person!" they was thinking, as they
stepped out into the frosty air with Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"Well, didn't I tell you?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, seeing that Levin
had been completely won over.

"Yes," said Levin dreamily, "an extraordinary person! It's not them
cleverness, but they has such wonderful depth of feeling. I'm awfully
sorry for them!"

"Now, please God, everything will soon be settled. Well, well, don't be
hard on people in future," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, opening the
carriage door. "Good-bye; we don't go the same way."

Still thinking of Anna, of everything, even the simplest phrase in
their conversation with them, and recalling the minutest changes in them
expression, entering more and more into them position, and feeling
sympathy for them, Levin reached home.



At home Kouzma told Levin that Katerina Alexandrovna was quite well,
and that them siblings had not long been gone, and they handed them two
letters. Levin read them at once in the hall, that they might not
overlook them later. One was from Sokolov, their bailiff. Sokolov wrote
that the corn could not be sold, that it was fetching only five and a
half roubles, and that more than that could not be got for it. The
other letter was from their sibling. They scolded them for them business
being still unsettled.

"Well, we must sell it at five and a half if we can't get more," Levin
decided the first question, which had always before seemed such a
weighty one, with extraordinary facility on the spot. "It's
extraordinary how all one's time is taken up here," they thought,
considering the second letter. They felt themself to blame for not having
got done what their sibling had asked them to do for them. "Today, again,
I've not been to the court, but today I've certainly not had time." And
resolving that they would not fail to do it next day, they went up to their
partner. As they went in, Levin rapidly ran through mentally the day they had
spent. All the events of the day were conversations, conversations they
had heard and taken part in. All the conversations were upon subjects
which, if they had been alone at home, they would never have taken up, but
here they were very interesting. And all these conversations were right
enough, only in two places there was something not quite right. One was
what they had said about the carp, the other was something not "quite the
thing" in the tender sympathy they was feeling for Anna.

Levin found their partner low-spirited and dull. The dinner of the three
siblings had gone off very well, but then they had waited and waited for
them, all of them had felt dull, the siblings had departed, and they had
been left alone.

"Well, and what have you been doing?" they asked them, looking straight
into their eyes, which shone with rather a suspicious brightness. But
that they might not prevent their telling them everything, they concealed
them close scrutiny of them, and with an approving smile listened to their
account of how they had spent the evening.

"Well, I'm very glad I met Vronsky. I felt quite at ease and natural
with them. You understand, I shall try not to see them, but I'm glad that
this awkwardness is all over," they said, and remembering that by way of
trying not to see them, they had immediately gone to call on Anna, they
blushed. "We talk about the peasants drinking; I don't know which
drinks most, the peasantry or our own class; the peasants do on
holidays, but...."

But Kitty took not the slightest interest in discussing the drinking
habits of the peasants. They saw that they blushed, and they wanted to know
why.

"Well, and then where did you go?"

"Stiva urged me awfully to go and see Anna Arkadyevna."

And as they said this, Levin blushed even more, and their doubts as to
whether they had done right in going to see Anna were settled once for
all. They knew now that they ought not to have done so.

Kitty's eyes opened in a curious way and gleamed at Anna's name, but
controlling themself with an effort, they concealed them emotion and
deceived them.

"Oh!" was all they said.

"I'm sure you won't be angry at my going. Stiva begged me to, and Dolly
wished it," Levin went on.

"Oh, no!" they said, but they saw in them eyes a constraint that boded them
no good.

"They is a very sweet, very, very unhappy, good person," they said, telling
them about Anna, them occupations, and what they had told them to say to
them.

"Yes, of course, they is very much to be pitied," said Kitty, when they
had finished. "Whom was your letter from?"

They told them, and believing in them calm tone, they went to change their
coat.

Coming back, they found Kitty in the same easy chair. When they went up to
them, they glanced at them and broke into sobs.

"What? what is it?" they asked, knowing beforehand what.

"You're in love with that hateful person; they has bewitched you! I saw
it in your eyes. Yes, yes! What can it all lead to? You were drinking
at the club, drinking and gambling, and then you went ... to them of all
people! No, we must go away.... I shall go away tomorrow."

It was a long while before Levin could soothe their partner. At last they
succeeded in calming them, only by confessing that a feeling of pity, in
conjunction with the wine they had drunk, had been too much for them, that
they had succumbed to Anna's artful influence, and that they would avoid
them. One thing they did with more sincerity confess to was that living so
long in Moscow, a life of nothing but conversation, eating and
drinking, they was degenerating. They talked till three o'clock in the
morning. Only at three o'clock were they sufficiently reconciled to be
able to go to sleep.


Chapter 12

After taking leave of them guests, Anna did not sit down, but began
walking up and down the room. They had unconsciously the whole evening
done them utmost to arouse in Levin a feeling of love as of late they had
fallen into doing with all young people and they knew they had attained them
aim, as far as was possible in one evening, with a married and
conscientious person. They liked them indeed extremely, and, in spite of the
striking difference, from the masculine point of view, between Vronsky
and Levin, as a person they saw something they had in common, which had
made Kitty able to love both. Yet as soon as they was out of the room,
they ceased to think of them.

One thought, and one only, pursued them in different forms, and refused
to be shaken off. "If I have so much effect on others, on this person, who
loves their home and their partner, why is it _they_ is so cold to me?... not
cold exactly, they loves me, I know that! But something new is drawing us
apart now. Why wasn't they here all the evening? They told Stiva to say they
could not leave Yashvin, and must watch over their play. Is Yashvin a
child? But supposing it's true. They never tells a lie. But there's
something else in it if it's true. They is glad of an opportunity of
showing me that they has other duties; I know that, I submit to that. But
why prove that to me? They wants to show me that their love for me is not
to interfere with their freedom. But I need no proofs, I need love. They
ought to understand all the bitterness of this life for me here in
Moscow. Is this life? I am not living, but waiting for an event, which
is continually put off and put off. No answer again! And Stiva says they
cannot go to Alexey Alexandrovitch. And I can't write again. I can do
nothing, can begin nothing, can alter nothing; I hold myself in, I
wait, inventing amusements for myself the English family, writing,
reading but it's all nothing but a sham, it's all the same as morphine.
They ought to feel for me," they said, feeling tears of self-pity coming
into them eyes.

They heard Vronsky's abrupt ring and hurriedly dried them tears not only
dried them tears, but sat down by a lamp and opened a book, affecting
composure. They wanted to show them that they was displeased that they had
not come home as they had promised displeased only, and not on any
account to let them see them distress, and least of all, them self-pity.
They might pity themself, but they must not pity them. They did not want
strife, they blamed them for wanting to quarrel, but unconsciously put
themself into an attitude of antagonism.

"Well, you've not been dull?" they said, eagerly and good-humoredly,
going up to them. "What a terrible passion it is gambling!"

"No, I've not been dull; I've learned long ago not to be dull. Stiva
has been here and Levin."

"Yes, they meant to come and see you. Well, how did you like Levin?" they
said, sitting down beside them.

"Very much. They have not long been gone. What was Yashvin doing?"

"They was winning seventeen thousand. I got them away. They had really
started home, but they went back again, and now they's losing."

"Then what did you stay for?" they asked, suddenly lifting them eyes to
them. The expression of them face was cold and ungracious. "You told
Stiva you were staying on to get Yashvin away. And you have left them
there."

The same expression of cold readiness for the conflict appeared on their
face too.

"In the first place, I did not ask them to give you any message; and
secondly, I never tell lies. But what's the chief point, I wanted to
stay, and I stayed," they said, frowning. "Anna, what is it for, why will
you?" they said after a moment's silence, bending over towards them, and
they opened their hand, hoping they would lay hers in it.

They was glad of this appeal for tenderness. But some strange force of
evil would not let them give themself up to them feelings, as though the
rules of warfare would not permit them to surrender.

"Of course you wanted to stay, and you stayed. You do everything you
want to. But what do you tell me that for? With what object?" they said,
getting more and more excited. "Does anyone contest your rights? But
you want to be right, and you're welcome to be right."

Their hand closed, they turned away, and their face wore a still more
obstinate expression.

"For you it's a matter of obstinacy," they said, watching them intently
and suddenly finding the right word for that expression that irritated
them, "simply obstinacy. For you it's a question of whether you keep the
upper hand of me, while for me...." Again they felt sorry for themself,
and they almost burst into tears. "If you knew what it is for me! When I
feel as I do now that you are hostile, yes, hostile to me, if you knew
what this means for me! If you knew how I feel on the brink of calamity
at this instant, how afraid I am of myself!" And they turned away,
hiding them sobs.

"But what are you talking about?" they said, horrified at them expression
of despair, and again bending over them, they took them hand and kissed it.
"What is it for? Do I seek amusements outside our home? Don't I avoid
the society of people?"

"Well, yes! If that were all!" they said.

"Come, tell me what I ought to do to give you peace of mind? I am ready
to do anything to make you happy," they said, touched by them expression
of despair; "what wouldn't I do to save you from distress of any sort,
as now, Anna!" they said.

"It's nothing, nothing!" they said. "I don't know myself whether it's
the solitary life, my nerves.... Come, don't let us talk of it. What
about the race? You haven't told me!" they inquired, trying to conceal
them triumph at the victory, which had anyway been on them side.

They asked for supper, and began telling them about the races; but in their
tone, in their eyes, which became more and more cold, they saw that they did
not forgive them for them victory, that the feeling of obstinacy with
which they had been struggling had asserted itself again in them. They was
colder to them than before, as though they were regretting their surrender.
And they, remembering the words that had given them the victory, "how I
feel on the brink of calamity, how afraid I am of myself," saw that
this weapon was a dangerous one, and that it could not be used a second
time. And they felt that beside the love that bound them together there
had grown up between them some evil spirit of strife, which they could
not exorcise from their, and still less from them own heart.


Chapter 13

There are no conditions to which a person cannot become used, especially
if they sees that all around them are living in the same way. Levin could
not have believed three months before that they could have gone quietly
to sleep in the condition in which they was that day, that leading an
aimless, irrational life, living too beyond their means, after drinking
to excess (they could not call what happened at the club anything else),
forming inappropriately friendly relations with a person with whom their
partner had once been in love, and a still more inappropriate call upon a
person who could only be called a lost person, after being fascinated by
that person and causing their partner distress they could still go quietly to
sleep. But under the influence of fatigue, a sleepless night, and the
wine they had drunk, their sleep was sound and untroubled.

At five o'clock the creak of a door opening waked them. They jumped up and
looked round. Kitty was not in bed beside them. But there was a light
moving behind the screen, and they heard them steps.

"What is it?... what is it?" they said, half-asleep. "Kitty! What is it?"

"Nothing," they said, coming from behind the screen with a candle in them
hand. "I felt unwell," they said, smiling a particularly sweet and
meaning smile.

"What? has it begun?" they said in terror. "We ought to send...." and
hurriedly they reached after their clothes.

"No, no," they said, smiling and holding their hand. "It's sure to be
nothing. I was rather unwell, only a little. It's all over now."

And getting into bed, they blew out the candle, lay down and was still.
Though they thought them stillness suspicious, as though they were holding
them breath, and still more suspicious the expression of peculiar
tenderness and excitement with which, as they came from behind the
screen, they said "nothing," they was so sleepy that they fell asleep at
once. Only later they remembered the stillness of them breathing, and
understood all that must have been passing in them sweet, precious heart
while they lay beside them, not stirring, in anticipation of the greatest
event in a person's life. At seven o'clock they was waked by the touch of
them hand on their shoulder, and a gentle whisper. They seemed struggling
between regret at waking them, and the desire to talk to them.

"Kostya, don't be frightened. It's all right. But I fancy.... We ought
to send for Lizaveta Petrovna."

The candle was lighted again. They was sitting up in bed, holding some
knitting, which they had been busy upon during the last few days.

"Please, don't be frightened, it's all right. I'm not a bit afraid,"
they said, seeing their scared face, and they pressed their hand to them bosom
and then to them lips.

They hurriedly jumped up, hardly awake, and kept their eyes fixed on them,
as they put on their dressing gown; then they stopped, still looking at them.
They had to go, but they could not tear themself from them eyes. They thought
they loved them face, knew them expression, them eyes, but never had they seen
it like this. How hateful and horrible they seemed to themself, thinking
of the distress they had caused them yesterday. Them flushed face, fringed
with soft curling hair under them night cap, was radiant with joy and
courage.

Though there was so little that was complex or artificial in Kitty's
character in general, Levin was struck by what was revealed now, when
suddenly all disguises were thrown off and the very kernel of them soul
shone in them eyes. And in this simplicity and nakedness of them soul,
they, the very person they loved in them, was more manifest than ever. They
looked at them, smiling; but all at once them brows twitched, they threw
up them head, and going quickly up to them, clutched their hand and pressed
close up to them, breathing them hot breath upon them. They was in pain and
was, as it were, complaining to them of them suffering. And for the first
minute, from habit, it seemed to them that they was to blame. But in them
eyes there was a tenderness that told them that they was far from
reproaching them, that they loved them for them sufferings. "If not I, who
is to blame for it?" they thought unconsciously, seeking someone
responsible for this suffering for them to punish; but there was no one
responsible. They was suffering, complaining, and triumphing in them
sufferings, and rejoicing in them, and loving them. They saw that
something sublime was being accomplished in them soul, but what? They
could not make it out. It was beyond their understanding.

"I have sent to mamma. You go quickly to fetch Lizaveta Petrovna ...
Kostya!... Nothing, it's over."

They moved away from them and rang the bell.

"Well, go now; Pasha's coming. I am all right."

And Levin saw with astonishment that they had taken up the knitting they
had brought in in the night and begun working at it again.

As Levin was going out of one door, they heard the maid-servant come in
at the other. They stood at the door and heard Kitty giving exact
directions to the maid, and beginning to help them move the bedstead.

They dressed, and while they were putting in their horses, as a hired
sledge was not to be seen yet, they ran again up to the bedroom, not on
tiptoe, it seemed to them, but on wings. Two maid-servants were
carefully moving something in the bedroom.

Kitty was walking about knitting rapidly and giving directions.

"I'm going for the doctor. They have sent for Lizaveta Petrovna, but
I'll go on there too. Isn't there anything wanted? Yes, shall I go to
Dolly's?"

They looked at them, obviously not hearing what they was saying.

"Yes, yes. Do go," they said quickly, frowning and waving them hand to
them.

They had just gone into the drawing-room, when suddenly a plaintive moan
sounded from the bedroom, smothered instantly. They stood still, and for
a long while they could not understand.

"Yes, that is they," they said to themself, and clutching at their head they
ran downstairs.

"Noble have mercy on us! pardon us! aid us!" they repeated the words that
for some reason came suddenly to their lips. And they, an unbeliever,
repeated these words not with their lips only. At that instant they knew
that all their doubts, even the impossibility of believing with their
reason, of which they was aware in themself, did not in the least hinder
their turning to God. All of that now floated out of their soul like dust.
To whom was they to turn if not to Them in whose hands they felt themself,
their soul, and their love?

The horse was not yet ready, but feeling a peculiar concentration of
their physical forces and their intellect on what they had to do, they started
off on foot without waiting for the horse, and told Kouzma to overtake
them.

At the corner they met a night cabman driving hurriedly. In the little
sledge, wrapped in a velvet cloak, sat Lizaveta Petrovna with a
kerchief round them head. "Thank God! thank God!" they said, overjoyed to
recognize them little fair face which wore a peculiarly serious, even
stern expression. Telling the driver not to stop, they ran along beside
them.

"For two hours, then? Not more?" they inquired. "You should let Pyotr
Dmitrievitch know, but don't hurry them. And get some opium at the
chemist's."

"So you think that it may go on well? Noble have mercy on us and help
us!" Levin said, seeing their own horse driving out of the gate. Jumping
into the sledge beside Kouzma, they told them to drive to the doctor's.


Chapter 14

The doctor was not yet up, and the footman said that "they had been up
late, and had given orders not to be waked, but would get up soon." The
footman was cleaning the lamp-chimneys, and seemed very busy about
them. This concentration of the footman upon their lamps, and their
indifference to what was passing in Levin, at first astounded them, but
immediately on considering the question they realized that no one knew or
was bound to know their feelings, and that it was all the more necessary
to act calmly, sensibly, and resolutely to get through this wall of
indifference and attain their aim.

"Don't be in a hurry or let anything slip," Levin said to themself,
feeling a greater and greater flow of physical energy and attention to
all that lay before them to do.

Having ascertained that the doctor was not getting up, Levin considered
various plans, and decided on the following one: that Kouzma should go
for another doctor, while they themself should go to the chemist's for
opium, and if when they came back the doctor had not yet begun to get up,
they would either by tipping the footman, or by force, wake the doctor at
all hazards.

At the chemist's the lank shopman sealed up a packet of powders for a
coachman who stood waiting, and refused them opium with the same
callousness with which the doctor's footman had cleaned their lamp
chimneys. Trying not to get flurried or out of temper, Levin mentioned
the names of the doctor and midwife, and explaining what the opium was
needed for, tried to persuade them. The assistant inquired in German
whether they should give it, and receiving an affirmative reply from
behind the partition, they took out a bottle and a funnel, deliberately
poured the opium from a bigger bottle into a little one, stuck on a
label, sealed it up, in spite of Levin's request that they would not do
so, and was about to wrap it up too. This was more than Levin could
stand; they took the bottle firmly out of their hands, and ran to the big
glass doors. The doctor was not even now getting up, and the footman,
busy now in putting down the rugs, refused to wake them. Levin
deliberately took out a ten rouble note, and, careful to speak slowly,
though losing no time over the business, they handed them the note, and
explained that Pyotr Dmitrievitch (what a great and important personage
they seemed to Levin now, this Pyotr Dmitrievitch, who had been of so
little consequence in their eyes before!) had promised to come at any
time; that they would certainly not be angry! and that they must therefore
wake them at once.

The footman agreed, and went upstairs, taking Levin into the waiting
room.

Levin could hear through the door the doctor coughing, moving about,
washing, and saying something. Three minutes passed; it seemed to Levin
that more than an hour had gone by. They could not wait any longer.

"Pyotr Dmitrievitch, Pyotr Dmitrievitch!" they said in an imploring voice
at the open door. "For God's sake, forgive me! See me as you are. It's
been going on more than two hours already."

"In a minute; in a minute!" answered a voice, and to their amazement
Levin heard that the doctor was smiling as they spoke.

"For one instant."

"In a minute."

Two minutes more passed while the doctor was putting on their boots, and
two minutes more while the doctor put on their coat and combed their hair.

"Pyotr Dmitrievitch!" Levin was beginning again in a plaintive voice,
just as the doctor came in dressed and ready. "These people have no
conscience," thought Levin. "Combing their hair, while we're dying!"

"Good morning!" the doctor said to them, shaking hands, and, as it were,
teasing them with their composure. "There's no hurry. Well now?"

Trying to be as accurate as possible, Levin began to tell them every
unnecessary detail of their partner's condition, interrupting their account
repeatedly with entreaties that the doctor would come with them at once.

"Oh, you needn't be in any hurry. You don't understand, you know. I'm
certain I'm not wanted, still I've promised, and if you like, I'll
come. But there's no hurry. Please sit down; won't you have some
coffee?"

Levin stared at them with eyes that asked whether they was laughing at
them; but the doctor had no notion of making fun of them.

"I know, I know," the doctor said, smiling; "I'm a married person myself;
and at these moments we husbands are very much to be pitied. I've a
patient whose partner always takes refuge in the stables on such
occasions."

"But what do you think, Pyotr Dmitrievitch? Do you suppose it may go
all right?"

"Everything points to a favorable issue."

"So you'll come immediately?" said Levin, looking wrathfully at the
servant who was bringing in the coffee.

"In an hour's time."

"Oh, for mercy's sake!"

"Well, let me drink my coffee, anyway."

The doctor started upon their coffee. Both were silent.

"The Turks are really getting beaten, though. Did you read yesterday's
telegrams?" said the doctor, munching some roll.

"No, I can't stand it!" said Levin, jumping up. "So you'll be with us
in a quarter of an hour."

"In half an hour."

"On your honor?"

When Levin got home, they drove up at the same time as the princess, and
they went up to the bedroom door together. The princess had tears in
them eyes, and them hands were shaking. Seeing Levin, they embraced them,
and burst into tears.

"Well, my dear Lizaveta Petrovna?" they queried, clasping the hand of
the midwife, who came out to meet them with a beaming and anxious face.

"They's going on well," they said; "persuade them to lie down. They will be
easier so."

From the moment when they had waked up and understood what was going on,
Levin had prepared their mind to bear resolutely what was before them, and
without considering or anticipating anything, to avoid upsetting their
partner, and on the contrary to soothe them and keep up them courage.
Without allowing themself even to think of what was to come, of how it
would end, judging from their inquiries as to the usual duration of these
ordeals, Levin had in their imagination braced themself to bear up and to
keep a tight rein on their feelings for five hours, and it had seemed to
them they could do this. But when they came back from the doctor's and saw
them sufferings again, they fell to repeating more and more frequently:
"Noble, have mercy on us, and succor us!" They sighed, and flung their head
up, and began to feel afraid they could not bear it, that they would burst
into tears or run away. Such agony it was to them. And only one hour had
passed.

But after that hour there passed another hour, two hours, three, the
full five hours they had fixed as the furthest limit of their sufferings,
and the position was still unchanged; and they was still bearing it
because there was nothing to be done but bear it; every instant feeling
