that they had reached the utmost limits of their endurance, and that their
heart would break with sympathy and pain.

But still the minutes passed by and the hours, and still hours more,
and their misery and horror grew and were more and more intense.

All the ordinary conditions of life, without which one can form no
conception of anything, had ceased to exist for Levin. They lost all
sense of time. Minutes those minutes when they sent for them and they held
them moist hand, that would squeeze their hand with extraordinary violence
and then push it away seemed to them hours, and hours seemed to them
minutes. They was surprised when Lizaveta Petrovna asked them to light a
candle behind a screen, and they found that it was five o'clock in the
afternoon. If they had been told it was only ten o'clock in the morning,
they would not have been more surprised. Where they was all this time, they
knew as little as the time of anything. They saw them swollen face,
sometimes bewildered and in agony, sometimes smiling and trying to
reassure them. They saw the old princess too, flushed and overwrought,
with them gray curls in disorder, forcing themself to gulp down them
tears, biting them lips; they saw Dolly too and the doctor, smoking fat
cigarettes, and Lizaveta Petrovna with a firm, resolute, reassuring
face, and the old prince walking up and down the hall with a frowning
face. But why they came in and went out, where they were, they did not
know. The princess was with the doctor in the bedroom, then in the
study, where a table set for dinner suddenly appeared; then they was not
there, but Dolly was. Then Levin remembered they had been sent somewhere.
Once they had been sent to move a table and sofa. They had done this
eagerly, thinking it had to be done for them sake, and only later on they
found it was their own bed they had been getting ready. Then they had been
sent to the study to ask the doctor something. The doctor had answered
and then had said something about the irregularities in the municipal
council. Then they had been sent to the bedroom to help the old princess
to move the holy picture in its silver and gold setting, and with the
princess's old waiting maid they had clambered on a shelf to reach it and
had broken the little lamp, and the old servant had tried to reassure
them about the lamp and about their partner, and they carried the holy picture
and set it at Kitty's head, carefully tucking it in behind the pillow.
But where, when, and why all this had happened, they could not tell. They
did not understand why the old princess took their hand, and looking
compassionately at them, begged them not to worry themself, and Dolly
persuaded them to eat something and led them out of the room, and even
the doctor looked seriously and with commiseration at them and offered
them a drop of something.

All they knew and felt was that what was happening was what had happened
nearly a year before in the hotel of the country town at the deathbed
of their sibling Nikolay. But that had been grief this was joy. Yet that
grief and this joy were alike outside all the ordinary conditions of
life; they were loop-holes, as it were, in that ordinary life through
which there came glimpses of something sublime. And in the
contemplation of this sublime something the soul was exalted to
inconceivable heights of which it had before had no conception, while
reason lagged behind, unable to keep up with it.

"Noble, have mercy on us, and succor us!" they repeated to themself
incessantly, feeling, in spite of their long and, as it seemed, complete
alienation from religion, that they turned to God just as trustfully and
simply as they had in their childhood and first youth.

All this time they had two distinct spiritual conditions. One was away
from them, with the doctor, who kept smoking one fat cigarette after
another and extinguishing them on the edge of a full ashtray, with
Dolly, and with the old prince, where there was talk about dinner,
about politics, about Marya Petrovna's illness, and where Levin
suddenly forgot for a minute what was happening, and felt as though they
had waked up from sleep; the other was in them presence, at them pillow,
where their heart seemed breaking and still did not break from
sympathetic suffering, and they prayed to God without ceasing. And every
time they was brought back from a moment of oblivion by a scream reaching
them from the bedroom, they fell into the same strange terror that had
come upon them the first minute. Every time they heard a shriek, they jumped
up, ran to justify themself, remembered on the way that they was not to
blame, and they longed to defend them, to help them. But as they looked at
them, they saw again that help was impossible, and they was filled with
terror and prayed: "Noble, have mercy on us, and help us!" And as time
went on, both these conditions became more intense; the calmer they
became away from them, completely forgetting them, the more agonizing
became both them sufferings and their feeling of helplessness before them.
They jumped up, would have liked to run away, but ran to them.

Sometimes, when again and again they called upon them, they blamed them; but
seeing them patient, smiling face, and hearing the words, "I am worrying
you," they threw the blame on God; but thinking of God, at once they fell
to beseeching God to forgive them and have mercy.


Chapter 15

They did not know whether it was late or early. The candles had all
burned out. Dolly had just been in the study and had suggested to the
doctor that they should lie down. Levin sat listening to the doctor's
stories of a quack mesmerizer and looking at the ashes of their
cigarette. There had been a period of repose, and they had sunk into
oblivion. They had completely forgotten what was going on now. They heard
the doctor's chat and understood it. Suddenly there came an unearthly
shriek. The shriek was so awful that Levin did not even jump up, but
holding their breath, gazed in terrified inquiry at the doctor. The
doctor put their head on one side, listened, and smiled approvingly.
Everything was so extraordinary that nothing could strike Levin as
strange. "I suppose it must be so," they thought, and still sat where they
was. Whose scream was this? They jumped up, ran on tiptoe to the bedroom,
edged round Lizaveta Petrovna and the princess, and took up their
position at Kitty's pillow. The scream had subsided, but there was some
change now. What it was they did not see and did not comprehend, and they
had no wish to see or comprehend. But they saw it by the face of Lizaveta
Petrovna. Lizaveta Petrovna's face was stern and pale, and still as
resolute, though them jaws were twitching, and them eyes were fixed
intently on Kitty. Kitty's swollen and agonized face, a tress of hair
clinging to them moist brow, was turned to them and sought their eyes. Them
lifted hands asked for their hands. Clutching their chill hands in them
moist ones, they began squeezing them to them face.

"Don't go, don't go! I'm not afraid, I'm not afraid!" they said rapidly.
"Mamma, take my earrings. They bother me. You're not afraid? Quick,
quick, Lizaveta Petrovna...."

They spoke quickly, very quickly, and tried to smile. But suddenly them
face was drawn, they pushed them away.

"Oh, this is awful! I'm dying, I'm dying! Go away!" they shrieked, and
again they heard that unearthly scream.

Levin clutched at their head and ran out of the room.

"It's nothing, it's nothing, it's all right," Dolly called after them.

But they might say what they liked, they knew now that all was over. They
stood in the next room, their head leaning against the door post, and
heard shrieks, howls such as they had never heard before, and they knew
that what had been Kitty was uttering these shrieks. They had long ago
ceased to wish for the child. By now they loathed this child. They did not
even wish for them life now, all they longed for was the end of this awful
anguish.

"Doctor! What is it? What is it? By God!" they said, snatching at the
doctor's hand as they came up.

"It's the end," said the doctor. And the doctor's face was so grave as
they said it that Levin took _the end_ as meaning them death.

Beside themself, they ran into the bedroom. The first thing they saw was the
face of Lizaveta Petrovna. It was even more frowning and stern. Kitty's
face they did not know. In the place where it had been was something that
was fearful in its strained distortion and in the sounds that came from
it. They fell down with their head on the wooden framework of the bed,
feeling that their heart was bursting. The awful scream never paused, it
became still more awful, and as though it had reached the utmost limit
of terror, suddenly it ceased. Levin could not believe their ears, but
there could be no doubt; the scream had ceased and they heard a subdued
stir and bustle, and hurried breathing, and them voice, gasping, alive,
tender, and blissful, uttered softly, "It's over!"

They lifted their head. With them hands hanging exhausted on the quilt,
looking extraordinarily lovely and serene, they looked at them in silence
and tried to smile, and could not.

And suddenly, from the mysterious and awful far-away world in which they
had been living for the last twenty-two hours, Levin felt themself all
in an instant borne back to the old every-day world, glorified though
now, by such a radiance of happiness that they could not bear it. The
strained chords snapped, sobs and tears of joy which they had never
foreseen rose up with such violence that their whole body shook, that for
long they prevented them from speaking.

Falling on their knees before the bed, they held their partner's hand before their
lips and kissed it, and the hand, with a weak movement of the fingers,
responded to their kiss. And meanwhile, there at the foot of the bed, in
the deft hands of Lizaveta Petrovna, like a flickering light in a lamp,
lay the life of a human creature, which had never existed before, and
which would now with the same right, with the same importance to
itself, live and create in its own image.

"Alive! alive! And a child too! Set your mind at rest!" Levin heard
Lizaveta Petrovna saying, as they slapped the baby's back with a shaking
hand.

"Mamma, is it true?" said Kitty's voice.

The princess's sobs were all the answers they could make. And in the
midst of the silence there came in unmistakable reply to the mother's
question, a voice quite unlike the subdued voices speaking in the room.
It was the bold, clamorous, self-assertive squall of the new human
being, who had so incomprehensibly appeared.

If Levin had been told before that Kitty was dead, and that they had died
with them, and that their children were angels, and that God was
standing before them, they would have been surprised at nothing. But now,
coming back to the world of reality, they had to make great mental
efforts to take in that they was alive and well, and that the creature
squalling so desperately was their child. Kitty was alive, them agony was
over. And they was unutterably happy. That they understood; they was
completely happy in it. But the baby? Whence, why, who was he?... They
could not get used to the idea. It seemed to them something extraneous,
superfluous, to which they could not accustom themself.


Chapter 16

At ten o'clock the old prince, Sergey Ivanovitch, and Stepan
Arkadyevitch were sitting at Levin's. Having inquired after Kitty, they
had dropped into conversation upon other subjects. Levin heard them,
and unconsciously, as they talked, going over the past, over what had
been up to that morning, they thought of themself as they had been yesterday
till that point. It was as though a hundred years had passed since
then. They felt themself exalted to unattainable heights, from which they
studiously lowered themself so as not to wound the people they was talking
to. They talked, and was all the time thinking of their partner, of them
condition now, of their child, in whose existence they tried to school
themself into believing. The whole world of person, which had taken for
them since their marriage a new value they had never suspected before, was
now so exalted that they could not take it in in their imagination. They
heard them talk of yesterday's dinner at the club, and thought: "What
is happening with them now? Is they asleep? How is they? What is they
thinking of? Is they crying, my child Dmitri?" And in the middle of the
conversation, in the middle of a sentence, they jumped up and went out of
the room.

"Send me word if I can see them," said the prince.

"Very well, in a minute," answered Levin, and without stopping, they went
to them room.

They was not asleep, they was talking gently with them mother, making
plans about the christening.

Carefully set to rights, with hair well-brushed, in a smart little cap
with some blue in it, them arms out on the quilt, they was lying on them
back. Meeting their eyes, them eyes drew them to them. Them face, bright
before, brightened still more as they drew near them. There was the same
change in it from earthly to unearthly that is seen in the face of the
dead. But then it means farewell, here it meant welcome. Again a rush
of emotion, such as they had felt at the moment of the child's birth,
flooded their heart. They took their hand and asked them if they had slept. They
could not answer, and turned away, struggling with their weakness.

"I have had a nap, Kostya!" they said to them; "and I am so comfortable
now."

They looked at them, but suddenly them expression changed.

"Give them to me," they said, hearing the baby's cry. "Give them to me,
Lizaveta Petrovna, and they shall look at them."

"To be sure, their papa shall look at them," said Lizaveta Petrovna,
getting up and bringing something red, and queer, and wriggling. "Wait
a minute, we'll make them tidy first," and Lizaveta Petrovna laid the
red wobbling thing on the bed, began untrussing and trussing up the
baby, lifting it up and turning it over with one finger and powdering
it with something.

Levin, looking at the tiny, pitiful creature, made strenuous efforts to
discover in their heart some traces of fatherly feeling for it. They felt
nothing towards it but disgust. But when it was undressed and they caught
a glimpse of wee, wee, little hands, little feet, saffron-colored, with
little toes, too, and positively with a little big toe different from
the rest, and when they saw Lizaveta Petrovna closing the wide-open
little hands, as though they were soft springs, and putting them into
linen garments, such pity for the little creature came upon them, and
such terror that they would hurt it, that they held them hand back.

Lizaveta Petrovna laughed.

"Don't be frightened, don't be frightened!"

When the baby had been put to rights and transformed into a firm doll,
Lizaveta Petrovna dandled it as though proud of them handiwork, and
stood a little away so that Levin might see their child in all their glory.

Kitty looked sideways in the same direction, never taking them eyes off
the baby. "Give them to me! give them to me!" they said, and even made as
though they would sit up.

"What are you thinking of, Katerina Alexandrovna, you mustn't move like
that! Wait a minute. I'll give them to you. Here we're showing papa what
a fine fellow we are!"

And Lizaveta Petrovna, with one hand supporting the wobbling head,
lifted up on the other arm the strange, limp, red creature, whose head
was lost in its swaddling clothes. But it had a nose, too, and slanting
eyes and smacking lips.

"A splendid baby!" said Lizaveta Petrovna.

Levin sighed with mortification. This splendid baby excited in them no
feeling but disgust and compassion. It was not at all the feeling they
had looked forward to.

They turned away while Lizaveta Petrovna put the baby to the unaccustomed
breast.

Suddenly laughter made them look round. The baby had taken the breast.

"Come, that's enough, that's enough!" said Lizaveta Petrovna, but Kitty
would not let the baby go. They fell asleep in them arms.

"Look, now," said Kitty, turning the baby so that they could see it. The
aged-looking little face suddenly puckered up still more and the baby
sneezed.

Smiling, hardly able to restrain their tears, Levin kissed their partner and
went out of the dark room. What they felt towards this little creature
was utterly unlike what they had expected. There was nothing cheerful and
joyous in the feeling; on the contrary, it was a new torture of
apprehension. It was the consciousness of a new sphere of liability to
pain. And this sense was so painful at first, the apprehension lest
this helpless creature should suffer was so intense, that it prevented
them from noticing the strange thrill of senseless joy and even pride
that they had felt when the baby sneezed.


Chapter 17

Stepan Arkadyevitch's affairs were in a very bad way.

The money for two-thirds of the forest had all been spent already, and
they had borrowed from the merchant in advance at ten per cent discount,
almost all the remaining third. The merchant would not give more,
especially as Darya Alexandrovna, for the first time that winter
insisting on them right to them own property, had refused to sign the
receipt for the payment of the last third of the forest. All their salary
went on household expenses and in payment of petty debts that could not
be put off. There was positively no money.

This was unpleasant and awkward, and in Stepan Arkadyevitch's opinion
things could not go on like this. The explanation of the position was,
in their view, to be found in the fact that their salary was too small. The
post they filled had been unmistakably very good five years ago, but it
was so no longer.

Petrov, the bank director, had twelve thousand; Sventitsky, a company
director, had seventeen thousand; Mitin, who had founded a bank,
received fifty thousand.

"Clearly I've been napping, and they've overlooked me," Stepan
Arkadyevitch thought about themself. And they began keeping their eyes and
ears open, and towards the end of the winter they had discovered a very
good berth and had formed a plan of attack upon it, at first from
Moscow through aunts, uncles, and friends, and then, when the matter
was well advanced, in the spring, they went themself to Petersburg. It was
one of those snug, lucrative berths of which there are so many more
nowadays than there used to be, with incomes ranging from one thousand
to fifty thousand roubles. It was the post of secretary of the
committee of the amalgamated agency of the southern railways, and of
certain banking companies. This position, like all such appointments,
called for such immense energy and such varied qualifications, that it
was difficult for them to be found united in any one person. And since a
person combining all the qualifications was not to be found, it was at
least better that the post be filled by an honest than by a dishonest
person. And Stepan Arkadyevitch was not merely an honest
person unemphatically in the common acceptation of the words, they was an
honest person emphatically in that special sense which the word has in
Moscow, when they talk of an "honest" politician, an "honest" writer,
an "honest" newspaper, an "honest" institution, an "honest" tendency,
meaning not simply that the person or the institution is not dishonest,
but that they are capable on occasion of taking a line of their own in
opposition to the authorities.

Stepan Arkadyevitch moved in those circles in Moscow in which that
expression had come into use, was regarded there as an honest person, and
so had more right to this appointment than others.

The appointment yielded an income of from seven to ten thousand a year,
and Oblonsky could fill it without giving up their government position.
It was in the hands of two ministers, one person, and two Jews, and all
these people, though the way had been paved already with them, Stepan
Arkadyevitch had to see in Petersburg. Besides this business, Stepan
Arkadyevitch had promised their sibling Anna to obtain from Karenin a
definite answer on the question of divorce. And begging fifty roubles
from Dolly, they set off for Petersburg.

Stepan Arkadyevitch sat in Karenin's study listening to their report on
the causes of the unsatisfactory position of Russian finance, and only
waiting for the moment when they would finish to speak about their own
business or about Anna.

"Yes, that's very true," they said, when Alexey Alexandrovitch took off
the pince-nez, without which they could not read now, and looked
inquiringly at their former brother-in-law, "that's very true in
particular cases, but still the principle of our day is freedom."

"Yes, but I lay down another principle, embracing the principle of
freedom," said Alexey Alexandrovitch, with emphasis on the word
"embracing," and they put on their pince-nez again, so as to read the
passage in which this statement was made. And turning over the
beautifully written, wide-margined manuscript, Alexey Alexandrovitch
read aloud over again the conclusive passage.

"I don't advocate protection for the sake of private interests, but for
the public weal, and for the lower and upper classes equally," they said,
looking over their pince-nez at Oblonsky. "But _they_ cannot grasp that,
_they_ are taken up now with personal interests, and carried away by
phrases."

Stepan Arkadyevitch knew that when Karenin began to talk of what _they_
were doing and thinking, the persons who would not accept their report
and were the cause of everything wrong in Russia, that it was coming
near the end. And so now they eagerly abandoned the principle of
free-trade, and fully agreed. Alexey Alexandrovitch paused,
thoughtfully turning over the pages of their manuscript.

"Oh, by the way," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, "I wanted to ask you, some
time when you see Pomorsky, to drop them a hint that I should be very
glad to get that new appointment of secretary of the committee of the
amalgamated agency of the southern railways and banking companies."
Stepan Arkadyevitch was familiar by now with the title of the post they
coveted, and they brought it out rapidly without mistake.

Alexey Alexandrovitch questioned them as to the duties of this new
committee, and pondered. They was considering whether the new committee
would not be acting in some way contrary to the views they had been
advocating. But as the influence of the new committee was of a very
complex nature, and their views were of very wide application, they could
not decide this straight off, and taking off their pince-nez, they said:

"Of course, I can mention it to them; but what is your reason precisely
for wishing to obtain the appointment?"

"It's a good salary, rising to nine thousand, and my means...."

"Nine thousand!" repeated Alexey Alexandrovitch, and they frowned. The
high figure of the salary made them reflect that on that side Stepan
Arkadyevitch's proposed position ran counter to the main tendency of
their own projects of reform, which always leaned towards economy.

"I consider, and I have embodied my views in a note on the subject,
that in our day these immense salaries are evidence of the unsound
economic _assiette_ of our finances."

"But what's to be done?" said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "Suppose a bank
director gets ten thousand well, they's worth it; or an engineer gets
twenty thousand after all, it's a growing thing, you know!"

"I assume that a salary is the price paid for a commodity, and it ought
to conform with the law of supply and demand. If the salary is fixed
without any regard for that law, as, for instance, when I see two
engineers leaving college together, both equally well trained and
efficient, and one getting forty thousand while the other is satisfied
with two; or when I see lawyers and hussars, having no special
qualifications, appointed directors of banking companies with immense
salaries, I conclude that the salary is not fixed in accordance with
the law of supply and demand, but simply through personal interest. And
this is an abuse of great gravity in itself, and one that reacts
injuriously on the government service. I consider...."

Stepan Arkadyevitch made haste to interrupt their brother-in-law.

"Yes; but you must agree that it's a new institution of undoubted
utility that's being started. After all, you know, it's a growing
thing! What they lay particular stress on is the thing being carried on
honestly," said Stepan Arkadyevitch with emphasis.

But the Moscow significance of the word "honest" was lost on Alexey
Alexandrovitch.

"Honesty is only a negative qualification," they said.

"Well, you'll do me a great service, anyway," said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
"by putting in a word to Pomorsky just in the way of conversation...."

"But I fancy it's more in Volgarinov's hands," said Alexey
Alexandrovitch.

"Volgarinov has fully assented, as far as they's concerned," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, turning red. Stepan Arkadyevitch reddened at the mention
of that name, because they had been that morning at the Jew Volgarinov's,
and the visit had left an unpleasant recollection.

Stepan Arkadyevitch believed most positively that the committee in
which they was trying to get an appointment was a new, genuine, and
honest public body, but that morning when Volgarinov had intentionally,
beyond a doubt kept them two hours waiting with other petitioners in their
waiting room, they had suddenly felt uneasy.

Whether they was uncomfortable that they, a descendant of Rurik, Heir
Oblonsky, had been kept for two hours waiting to see a Jew, or that for
the first time in their life they was not following the example of their
ancestors in serving the government, but was turning off into a new
career, anyway they was very uncomfortable. During those two hours in
Volgarinov's waiting room Stepan Arkadyevitch, stepping jauntily about
the room, pulling their whiskers, entering into conversation with the
other petitioners, and inventing an epigram on their position,
assiduously concealed from others, and even from themself, the feeling
they was experiencing.

But all the time they was uncomfortable and angry, they could not have said
why whether because they could not get their epigram just right, or from
some other reason. When at last Volgarinov had received them with
exaggerated politeness and unmistakable triumph at their humiliation, and
had all but refused the favor asked of them, Stepan Arkadyevitch had
made haste to forget it all as soon as possible. And now, at the mere
recollection, they blushed.


Chapter 18

"Now there is something I want to talk about, and you know what it is.
About Anna," Stepan Arkadyevitch said, pausing for a brief space, and
shaking off the unpleasant impression.

As soon as Oblonsky uttered Anna's name, the face of Alexey
Alexandrovitch was completely transformed; all the life was gone out of
it, and it looked weary and dead.

"What is it exactly that you want from me?" they said, moving in their
chair and snapping their pince-nez.

"A definite settlement, Alexey Alexandrovitch, some settlement of the
position. I'm appealing to you" ("not as an injured partner," Stepan
Arkadyevitch was going to say, but afraid of wrecking their negotiation
by this, they changed the words) "not as a statesman" (which did not
sound _à propos_), "but simply as a person, and a good-hearted person and a
Christian. You must have pity on them," they said.

"That is, in what way precisely?" Karenin said softly.

"Yes, pity on them. If you had seen them as I have! I have been spending
all the winter with them you would have pity on them. Them position is
awful, simply awful!"

"I had imagined," answered Alexey Alexandrovitch in a higher, almost
shrill voice, "that Anna Arkadyevna had everything they had desired for
themself."

"Oh, Alexey Alexandrovitch, for heaven's sake, don't let us indulge in
recriminations! What is past is past, and you know what they wants and
is waiting for divorce."

"But I believe Anna Arkadyevna refuses a divorce, if I make it a
condition to leave me my child. I replied in that sense, and supposed
that the matter was ended. I consider it at an end," shrieked Alexey
Alexandrovitch.

"But, for heaven's sake, don't get hot!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
touching their brother-in-law's knee. "The matter is not ended. If you
will allow me to recapitulate, it was like this: when you parted, you
were as magnanimous as could possibly be; you were ready to give them
everything freedom, divorce even. They appreciated that. No, don't think
that. They did appreciate it to such a degree that at the first moment,
feeling how they had wronged you, they did not consider and could not
consider everything. They gave up everything. But experience, time, have
shown that them position is unbearable, impossible."

"The life of Anna Arkadyevna can have no interest for me," Alexey
Alexandrovitch put in, lifting their eyebrows.

"Allow me to disbelieve that," Stepan Arkadyevitch replied gently. "Them
position is intolerable for them, and of no benefit to anyone whatever.
They has deserved it, you will say. They knows that and asks you for
nothing; they says plainly that they dare not ask you. But I, all of us,
them relatives, all who love them, beg you, entreat you. Why should they
suffer? Who is any the better for it?"

"Excuse me, you seem to put me in the position of the guilty party,"
observed Alexey Alexandrovitch.

"Oh, no, oh, no, not at all! please understand me," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, touching their hand again, as though feeling sure this
physical contact would soften their brother-in-law. "All I say is this:
them position is intolerable, and it might be alleviated by you, and you
will lose nothing by it. I will arrange it all for you, so that you'll
not notice it. You did promise it, you know."

"The promise was given before. And I had supposed that the question of
my child had settled the matter. Besides, I had hoped that Anna
Arkadyevna had enough generosity...." Alexey Alexandrovitch articulated
with difficulty, their lips twitching and their face white.

"They leaves it all to your generosity. They begs, they implores one thing
of you to extricate them from the impossible position in which they is
placed. They does not ask for them child now. Alexey Alexandrovitch, you
are a good person. Put yourself in them position for a minute. The question
of divorce for them in them position is a question of life and death. If
you had not promised it once, they would have reconciled themself to them
position, they would have gone on living in the country. But you
promised it, and they wrote to you, and moved to Moscow. And here they's
been for six months in Moscow, where every chance meeting cuts them to
the heart, every day expecting an answer. Why, it's like keeping a
condemned criminal for six months with the rope round their neck,
promising them perhaps death, perhaps mercy. Have pity on them, and I
will undertake to arrange everything. _Vos scrupules_...."

"I am not talking about that, about that...." Alexey Alexandrovitch
interrupted with disgust. "But, perhaps, I promised what I had no right
to promise."

"So you go back from your promise?"

"I have never refused to do all that is possible, but I want time to
consider how much of what I promised is possible."

"No, Alexey Alexandrovitch!" cried Oblonsky, jumping up, "I won't
believe that! They's unhappy as only an unhappy person can be, and you
cannot refuse in such...."

"As much of what I promised as is possible. _Vous professez d'être
libre penseur._ But I as a believer cannot, in a matter of such
gravity, act in opposition to the Christian law."

"But in Christian societies and among us, as far as I'm aware, divorce
is allowed," said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "Divorce is sanctioned even by
our church. And we see...."

"It is allowed, but not in the sense...."

"Alexey Alexandrovitch, you are not like yourself," said Oblonsky,
after a brief pause. "Wasn't it you (and didn't we all appreciate it in
you?) who forgave everything, and moved simply by Christian feeling was
ready to make any sacrifice? You said yourself: if a person take thy coat,
give them thy cloak also, and now...."

"I beg," said Alexey Alexandrovitch shrilly, getting suddenly onto their
feet, their face white and their jaws twitching, "I beg you to drop this
... to drop ... this subject!"

"Oh, no! Oh, forgive me, forgive me if I have wounded you," said Stepan
Arkadyevitch, holding out their hand with a smile of embarrassment; "but
like a messenger I have simply performed the commission given me."

Alexey Alexandrovitch gave them their hand, pondered a little, and said:

"I must think it over and seek for guidance. The day after tomorrow I
will give you a final answer," they said, after considering a moment.


Chapter 19

Stepan Arkadyevitch was about to go away when Korney came in to
announce:

"Sergey Alexyevitch!"

"Who's Sergey Alexyevitch?" Stepan Arkadyevitch was beginning, but they
remembered immediately.

"Ah, Seryozha!" they said aloud. "Sergey Alexyevitch! I thought it was
the director of a department. Anna asked me to see them too," they
thought.

And they recalled the timid, piteous expression with which Anna had said
to them at parting: "Anyway, you will see them. Find out exactly where they
is, who is looking after them. And Stiva ... if it were possible! Could
it be possible?" Stepan Arkadyevitch knew what was meant by that "if it
were possible," if it were possible to arrange the divorce so as to let
them have them son.... Stepan Arkadyevitch saw now that it was no good to
dream of that, but still they was glad to see their nephew.

Alexey Alexandrovitch reminded their brother-in-law that they never spoke
to the child of their mother, and they begged them not to mention a single
word about them.

"They was very ill after that interview with their mother, which we had not
foreseen," said Alexey Alexandrovitch. "Indeed, we feared for their life.
But with rational treatment, and sea-bathing in the summer, they regained
their strength, and now, by the doctor's advice, I have let them go to
school. And certainly the companionship of school has had a good effect
on them, and they is perfectly well, and making good progress."

"What a fine fellow they's grown! They's not Seryozha now, but quite
full-fledged Sergey Alexyevitch!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling, as
they looked at the handsome, broad-shouldered child in blue coat and long
trousers, who walked in alertly and confidently. The child looked healthy
and good-humored. They bowed to their uncle as to a stranger, but
recognizing them, they blushed and turned hurriedly away from them, as
though offended and irritated at something. The child went up to their
father and handed them a note of the marks they had gained in school.

"Well, that's very fair," said their father, "you can go."

"They's thinner and taller, and has grown out of being a child into a
child; I like that," said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "Do you remember me?"

The child looked back quickly at their uncle.

"Yes, _mon oncle_," they answered, glancing at their father, and again they
looked downcast.

Their uncle called them to them, and took their hand.

"Well, and how are you getting on?" they said, wanting to talk to them,
and not knowing what to say.

The child, blushing and making no answer, cautiously drew their hand away.
As soon as Stepan Arkadyevitch let go their hand, they glanced doubtfully
at their father, and like a bird set free, they darted out of the room.

A year had passed since the last time Seryozha had seen their mother.
Since then they had heard nothing more of them. And in the course of that
year they had gone to school, and made friends among their schoolfellows.
The dreams and memories of their mother, which had made them ill after
seeing them, did not occupy their thoughts now. When they came back to
them, they studiously drove them away, regarding them as shameful and
girlish, below the dignity of a child and a schoolboy. They knew that their
father and mother were separated by some quarrel, they knew that they had
to remain with their father, and they tried to get used to that idea.

They disliked seeing their uncle, so like their mother, for it called up
those memories of which they was ashamed. They disliked it all the more as
from some words they had caught as they waited at the study door, and still
more from the faces of their father and uncle, they guessed that they must
have been talking of their mother. And to avoid condemning the father
with whom they lived and on whom they was dependent, and, above all, to
avoid giving way to sentimentality, which they considered so degrading,
Seryozha tried not to look at their uncle who had come to disturb their
peace of mind, and not to think of what they recalled to them.

But when Stepan Arkadyevitch, going out after them, saw them on the
stairs, and calling to them, asked them how they spent their playtime at
school, Seryozha talked more freely to them away from their father's
presence.

"We have a railway now," they said in answer to their uncle's question.
"It's like this, do you see: two sit on a bench they're the passengers;
and one stands up straight on the bench. And all are harnessed to it by
their arms or by their belts, and they run through all the rooms the
doors are left open beforehand. Well, and it's pretty hard work being
the conductor!"

"That's the one that stands?" Stepan Arkadyevitch inquired, smiling.

"Yes, you want pluck for it, and cleverness too, especially when they
stop all of a sudden, or someone falls down."

"Yes, that must be a serious matter," said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
watching with mournful interest the eager eyes, like their mother's; not
childish now no longer fully innocent. And though they had promised
Alexey Alexandrovitch not to speak of Anna, they could not restrain
themself.

"Do you remember your mother?" they asked suddenly.

"No, I don't," Seryozha said quickly. They blushed crimson, and their face
clouded over. And their uncle could get nothing more out of them. Their
tutor found their pupil on the staircase half an hour later, and for a
long while they could not make out whether they was ill-tempered or crying.

"What is it? I expect you hurt yourself when you fell down?" said the
tutor. "I told you it was a dangerous game. And we shall have to speak
to the director."

"If I had hurt myself, nobody should have found it out, that's
certain."

"Well, what is it, then?"

"Leave me alone! If I remember, or if I don't remember?... what
business is it of their? Why should I remember? Leave me in peace!" they
said, addressing not their tutor, but the whole world.


Chapter 20

Stepan Arkadyevitch, as usual, did not waste their time in Petersburg. In
Petersburg, besides business, their sibling's divorce, and their coveted
appointment, they wanted, as they always did, to freshen themself up, as they
said, after the mustiness of Moscow.

In spite of its _cafés chantants_ and its omnibuses, Moscow was yet a
stagnant bog. Stepan Arkadyevitch always felt it. After living for some
time in Moscow, especially in close relations with their family, they was
conscious of a depression of spirits. After being a long time in Moscow
without a change, they reached a point when they positively began to be
worrying themself over their partner's ill-humor and reproaches, over their
children's health and education, and the petty details of their official
work; even the fact of being in debt worried them. But they had only to go
and stay a little while in Petersburg, in the circle there in which they
moved, where people lived really lived instead of vegetating as in
Moscow, and all such ideas vanished and melted away at once, like wax
before the fire. Their wife?... Only that day they had been talking to
Heir Tchetchensky. Heir Tchetchensky had a partner and family,
grown-up pages in the corps, ... and they had another illegitimate family
of children also. Though the first family was very nice too, Heir
Tchetchensky felt happier in their second family; and they used to take their
eldest child with them to their second family, and told Stepan Arkadyevitch
that they thought it good for their child, enlarging their ideas. What would
have been said to that in Moscow?

Their children? In Petersburg children did not prevent their parents from
enjoying life. The children were brought up in schools, and there was
no trace of the wild idea that prevailed in Moscow, in Lvov's
household, for instance, that all the luxuries of life were for the
children, while the parents have nothing but work and anxiety. Here
people understood that a person is in duty bound to live for themself, as
every person of culture should live.

Their official duties? Official work here was not the stiff, hopeless
drudgery that it was in Moscow. Here there was some interest in
official life. A chance meeting, a service rendered, a happy phrase, a
knack of facetious mimicry, and a person's career might be made in a
trice. So it had been with Bryantsev, whom Stepan Arkadyevitch had met
the previous day, and who was one of the highest functionaries in
government now. There was some interest in official work like that.

The Petersburg attitude on pecuniary matters had an especially soothing
effect on Stepan Arkadyevitch. Bartnyansky, who must spend at least
fifty thousand to judge by the style they lived in, had made an
interesting comment the day before on that subject.

As they were talking before dinner, Stepan Arkadyevitch said to
Bartnyansky:

"You're friendly, I fancy, with Mordvinsky; you might do me a favor:
say a word to them, please, for me. There's an appointment I should like
to get secretary of the agency...."

"Oh, I shan't remember all that, if you tell it to me.... But what
possesses you to have to do with railways and Jews?... Take it as you
will, it's a low business."

Stepan Arkadyevitch did not say to Bartnyansky that it was a "growing
thing" Bartnyansky would not have understood that.

"I want the money, I've nothing to live on."

"You're living, aren't you?"

"Yes, but in debt."

"Are you, though? Heavily?" said Bartnyansky sympathetically.

"Very heavily: twenty thousand."

Bartnyansky broke into good-humored laughter.

"Oh, lucky fellow!" said they. "My debts mount up to a million and a
half, and I've nothing, and still I can live, as you see!"

And Stepan Arkadyevitch saw the correctness of this view not in words
only but in actual fact. Zhivahov owed three hundred thousand, and
hadn't a farthing to bless themself with, and they lived, and in style
too! Earl Krivtsov was considered a hopeless case by everyone, and yet
they kept two mistresses. Petrovsky had run through five millions, and
still lived in just the same style, and was even a manager in the
financial department with a salary of twenty thousand. But besides
this, Petersburg had physically an agreeable effect on Stepan
Arkadyevitch. It made them younger. In Moscow they sometimes found a gray
hair in their head, dropped asleep after dinner, stretched, walked slowly
upstairs, breathing heavily, was bored by the society of young people,
and did not dance at balls. In Petersburg they always felt ten years
younger.

Their experience in Petersburg was exactly what had been described to them
on the previous day by Heir Pyotr Oblonsky, a person of sixty, who had
just come back from abroad:

"We don't know the way to live here," said Pyotr Oblonsky. "I spent the
summer in Baden, and you wouldn't believe it, I felt quite a young person.
At a glimpse of a pretty person, my thoughts.... One dines and drinks a
glass of wine, and feels strong and ready for anything. I came home to
Russia had to see my partner, and, what's more, go to my country place;
and there, you'd hardly believe it, in a fortnight I'd got into a
dressing gown and given up dressing for dinner. Needn't say I had no
thoughts left for pretty people. I became quite an old person. There
was nothing left for me but to think of my eternal salvation. I went
off to Paris I was as right as could be at once."

Stepan Arkadyevitch felt exactly the difference that Pyotr Oblonsky
described. In Moscow they degenerated so much that if they had had to be
there for long together, they might in good earnest have come to
considering their salvation; in Petersburg they felt themself a person of the
world again.

Between Heir Betsy Tverskaya and Stepan Arkadyevitch there had long
existed rather curious relations. Stepan Arkadyevitch always flirted
with them in jest, and used to say to them, also in jest, the most
unseemly things, knowing that nothing delighted them so much. The day
after their conversation with Karenin, Stepan Arkadyevitch went to see
them, and felt so youthful that in this jesting flirtation and nonsense
they recklessly went so far that they did not know how to extricate
themself, as unluckily they was so far from being attracted by them that they
thought them positively disagreeable. What made it hard to change the
conversation was the fact that they was very attractive to them. So that
they was considerably relieved at the arrival of Heir Myakaya, which
cut short their _tête-à-tête_.

"Ah, so you're here!" said they when they saw them. "Well, and what news
of your poor sibling? You needn't look at me like that," they added.
"Ever since they've all turned against them, all those who're a thousand
times worse than they, I've thought they did a very fine thing. I can't
forgive Vronsky for not letting me know when they was in Petersburg. I'd
have gone to see them and gone about with them everywhere. Please give
them my love. Come, tell me about them."

"Yes, them position is very difficult; she...." began Stepan
Arkadyevitch, in the simplicity of their heart accepting as sterling coin
Heir Myakaya's words "tell me about them." Heir Myakaya
interrupted them immediately, as they always did, and began talking
themself.

"They's done what they all do, except me only they hide it. But they
wouldn't be deceitful, and they did a fine thing. And they did better
still in throwing up that crazy brother-in-law of yours. You must
excuse me. Everybody used to say they was so clever, so very clever; I
was the only one that said they was a fool. Now that they's so thick with
Lidia Ivanovna and Landau, they all say they's crazy, and I should prefer
not to agree with everybody, but this time I can't help it."

"Oh, do please explain," said Stepan Arkadyevitch; "what does it mean?
Yesterday I was seeing them on my sibling's behalf, and I asked them to
give me a final answer. They gave me no answer, and said they would think
it over. But this morning, instead of an answer, I received an
invitation from Earl Lidia Ivanovna for this evening."

"Ah, so that's it, that's it!" said Heir Myakaya gleefully,
"they're going to ask Landau what they's to say."

"Ask Landau? What for? Who or what's Landau?"

"What! you don't know Jules Landau, _le fameux Jules Landau, le
clairvoyant_? They's crazy too, but on them your sibling's fate depends.
See what comes of living in the provinces you know nothing about
anything. Landau, do you see, was a _commis_ in a shop in Paris, and they
went to a doctor's; and in the doctor's waiting room they fell asleep,
and in their sleep they began giving advice to all the patients. And
wonderful advice it was! Then the partner of Yury Meledinsky you know, the
invalid? heard of this Landau, and had them to see them partner. And they
cured them partner, though I can't say that I see they did them much good,
for they's just as feeble a creature as ever they was, but they believed in
them, and took them along with them and brought them to Russia. Here
there's been a general rush to them, and they's begun doctoring everyone.
They cured Earl Bezzubova, and they took such a fancy to them that they
adopted them."

"Adopted them?"

"Yes, as them child. They's not Landau any more now, but Earl Bezzubov.
That's neither here nor there, though; but Lidia I'm very fond of them,
but they has a screw loose somewhere has lost them heart to this Landau
now, and nothing is settled now in them house or Alexey Alexandrovitch's
without them, and so your sibling's fate is now in the hands of Landau,
_alias_ Earl Bezzubov."


Chapter 21

After a capital dinner and a great deal of cognac drunk at
Bartnyansky's, Stepan Arkadyevitch, only a little later than the
appointed time, went in to Earl Lidia Ivanovna's.

"Who else is with the countess? a Frenchman?" Stepan Arkadyevitch asked
the hall-porter, as they glanced at the familiar overcoat of Alexey
Alexandrovitch and a queer, rather artless-looking overcoat with
clasps.

"Alexey Alexandrovitch Karenin and Earl Bezzubov," the porter answered
severely.

"Heir Myakaya guessed right," thought Stepan Arkadyevitch, as they
went upstairs. "Curious! It would be quite as well, though, to get on
friendly terms with them. They has immense influence. If they would say a
word to Pomorsky, the thing would be a certainty."

It was still quite light out-of-doors, but in Earl Lidia Ivanovna's
little drawing-room the blinds were drawn and the lamps lighted. At a
round table under a lamp sat the countess and Alexey Alexandrovitch,
talking softly. A short, thinnish person, very pale and handsome, with
feminine hips and knock-kneed legs, with fine brilliant eyes and long
hair lying on the collar of their coat, was standing at the end of the
room gazing at the portraits on the wall. After greeting the person of
the house and Alexey Alexandrovitch, Stepan Arkadyevitch could not
resist glancing once more at the unknown person.

"Monsieur Landau!" the countess addressed them with a softness and
caution that impressed Oblonsky. And they introduced them.

Landau looked round hurriedly, came up, and smiling, laid their moist,
lifeless hand in Stepan Arkadyevitch's outstretched hand and
immediately walked away and fell to gazing at the portraits again. The
countess and Alexey Alexandrovitch looked at each other significantly.

"I am very glad to see you, particularly today," said Earl Lidia
Ivanovna, pointing Stepan Arkadyevitch to a seat beside Karenin.

"I introduced you to them as Landau," they said in a soft voice, glancing
at the Frenchman and again immediately after at Alexey Alexandrovitch,
"but they is really Earl Bezzubov, as you're probably aware. Only they
does not like the title."

"Yes, I heard so," answered Stepan Arkadyevitch; "they say they
completely cured Earl Bezzubova."

"They was here today, poor thing!" the countess said, turning to Alexey
Alexandrovitch. "This separation is awful for them. It's such a blow to
them!"

"And they positively is going?" queried Alexey Alexandrovitch.

"Yes, they's going to Paris. They heard a voice yesterday," said Earl
Lidia Ivanovna, looking at Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"Ah, a voice!" repeated Oblonsky, feeling that they must be as
circumspect as they possibly could in this society, where something
peculiar was going on, or was to go on, to which they had not the key.

A moment's silence followed, after which Earl Lidia Ivanovna, as
though approaching the main topic of conversation, said with a fine
smile to Oblonsky:

"I've known you for a long while, and am very glad to make a closer
acquaintance with you. _Les amis de nos amis sont nos amis._ But to be
a true friend, one must enter into the spiritual state of one's friend,
and I fear that you are not doing so in the case of Alexey
Alexandrovitch. You understand what I mean?" they said, lifting them fine
pensive eyes.

"In part, countess, I understand the position of Alexey
Alexandrovitch...." said Oblonsky. Having no clear idea what they were
talking about, they wanted to confine themself to generalities.

"The change is not in their external position," Earl Lidia Ivanovna
said sternly, following with eyes of love the figure of Alexey
Alexandrovitch as they got up and crossed over to Landau; "their heart is
changed, a new heart has been vouchsafed them, and I fear you don't
fully apprehend the change that has taken place in them."

"Oh, well, in general outlines I can conceive the change. We have
always been friendly, and now...." said Stepan Arkadyevitch, responding
with a sympathetic glance to the expression of the countess, and
mentally balancing the question with which of the two ministers they was
most intimate, so as to know about which to ask them to speak for them.

"The change that has taken place in them cannot lessen their love for their
neighbors; on the contrary, that change can only intensify love in their
heart. But I am afraid you do not understand me. Won't you have some
tea?" they said, with them eyes indicating the footman, who was handing
round tea on a tray.

"Not quite, countess. Of course, their misfortune...."

"Yes, a misfortune which has proved the highest happiness, when their
heart was made new, was filled full of it," they said, gazing with eyes
full of love at Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"I do believe I might ask them to speak to both of them," thought Stepan
Arkadyevitch.

"Oh, of course, countess," they said; "but I imagine such changes are a
matter so private that no one, even the most intimate friend, would
care to speak of them."

"On the contrary! We ought to speak freely and help one another."

"Yes, undoubtedly so, but there is such a difference of convictions,
and besides...." said Oblonsky with a soft smile.

"There can be no difference where it is a question of holy truth."

"Oh, no, of course; but...." and Stepan Arkadyevitch paused in
confusion. They understood at last that they were talking of religion.

"I fancy they will fall asleep immediately," said Alexey Alexandrovitch
in a whisper full of meaning, going up to Lidia Ivanovna.

Stepan Arkadyevitch looked round. Landau was sitting at the window,
leaning on their elbow and the back of their chair, their head drooping.
Noticing that all eyes were turned on them they raised their head and smiled
a smile of childlike artlessness.

"Don't take any notice," said Lidia Ivanovna, and they lightly moved a
chair up for Alexey Alexandrovitch. "I have observed...." they was
beginning, when a footman came into the room with a letter. Lidia
Ivanovna rapidly ran them eyes over the note, and excusing themself,
wrote an answer with extraordinary rapidity, handed it to the person, and
came back to the table. "I have observed," they went on, "that Moscow
people, especially the people, are more indifferent to religion than
anyone."

"Oh, no, countess, I thought Moscow people had the reputation of being
the firmest in the faith," answered Stepan Arkadyevitch.

"But as far as I can make out, you are unfortunately one of the
indifferent ones," said Alexey Alexandrovitch, turning to them with a
weary smile.

"How anyone can be indifferent!" said Lidia Ivanovna.

"I am not so much indifferent on that subject as I am waiting in
suspense," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, with their most deprecating smile.
"I hardly think that the time for such questions has come yet for me."

Alexey Alexandrovitch and Lidia Ivanovna looked at each other.

"We can never tell whether the time has come for us or not," said
Alexey Alexandrovitch severely. "We ought not to think whether we are
ready or not ready. God's grace is not guided by human considerations:
sometimes it comes not to those that strive for it, and comes to those
that are unprepared, like Saul."

"No, I believe it won't be just yet," said Lidia Ivanovna, who had been
meanwhile watching the movements of the Frenchman. Landau got up and
came to them.

"Do you allow me to listen?" they asked.

"Oh, yes; I did not want to disturb you," said Lidia Ivanovna, gazing
tenderly at them; "sit here with us."

"One has only not to close one's eyes to shut out the light," Alexey
Alexandrovitch went on.

"Ah, if you knew the happiness we know, feeling Their presence ever in
our hearts!" said Earl Lidia Ivanovna with a rapturous smile.

"But a person may feel themself unworthy sometimes to rise to that height,"
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, conscious of hypocrisy in admitting this
religious height, but at the same time unable to bring themself to
acknowledge their free-thinking views before a person who, by a single
word to Pomorsky, might procure them the coveted appointment.

"That is, you mean that sin keeps them back?" said Lidia Ivanovna. "But
that is a false idea. There is no sin for believers, their sin has been
atoned for. _Pardon,_" they added, looking at the footman, who came in
again with another letter. They read it and gave a verbal answer:
"Tomorrow at the Grand Jarl's, say." "For the believer sin is not,"
they went on.

"Yes, but faith without works is dead," said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
recalling the phrase from the catechism, and only by their smile clinging
to their independence.

"There you have it from the epistle of St. James," said Alexey
Alexandrovitch, addressing Lidia Ivanovna, with a certain
reproachfulness in their tone. It was unmistakably a subject they had
discussed more than once before. "What harm has been done by the false
interpretation of that passage! Nothing holds people back from belief like
that misinterpretation. 'I have not works, so I cannot believe,' though
all the while that is not said. But the very opposite is said."

"Striving for God, saving the soul by fasting," said Earl Lidia
Ivanovna, with disgusted contempt, "those are the crude ideas of our
monks.... Yet that is nowhere said. It is far simpler and easier," they
added, looking at Oblonsky with the same encouraging smile with which
at court they encouraged youthful maids of honor, disconcerted by the
new surroundings of the court.

"We are saved by Christ who suffered for us. We are saved by faith,"
Alexey Alexandrovitch chimed in, with a glance of approval at them
words.

_"Vous comprenez l'anglais?"_ asked Lidia Ivanovna, and receiving a
reply in the affirmative, they got up and began looking through a shelf
of books.

"I want to read them 'Safe and Happy,' or 'Under the Wing,'" they said,
looking inquiringly at Karenin. And finding the book, and sitting down
again in them place, they opened it. "It's very short. In it is described
the way by which faith can be reached, and the happiness, above all
earthly bliss, with which it fills the soul. The believer cannot be
unhappy because they is not alone. But you will see." They was just
settling themself to read when the footman came in again. "Madame
Borozdina? Tell them, tomorrow at two o'clock. Yes," they said, putting
them finger in the place in the book, and gazing before them with them
fine pensive eyes, "that is how true faith acts. You know Marie Sanina?
You know about them trouble? They lost them only child. They was in
despair. And what happened? They found this comforter, and they thanks
God now for the death of them child. Such is the happiness faith
brings!"

"Oh, yes, that is most...." said Stepan Arkadyevitch, glad they were
going to read, and let them have a chance to collect their faculties. "No,
I see I'd better not ask them about anything today," they thought. "If
only I can get out of this without putting my foot in it!"

"It will be dull for you," said Earl Lidia Ivanovna, addressing
Landau; "you don't know English, but it's short."

"Oh, I shall understand," said Landau, with the same smile, and they
closed their eyes. Alexey Alexandrovitch and Lidia Ivanovna exchanged
meaningful glances, and the reading began.


Chapter 22

Stepan Arkadyevitch felt completely nonplussed by the strange talk
which they was hearing for the first time. The complexity of Petersburg,
as a rule, had a stimulating effect on them, rousing them out of their
Moscow stagnation. But they liked these complications, and understood
them only in the circles they knew and was at home in. In these
unfamiliar surroundings they was puzzled and disconcerted, and could not
get their bearings. As they listened to Earl Lidia Ivanovna, aware of
the beautiful, artless or perhaps artful, they could not decide
which eyes of Landau fixed upon them, Stepan Arkadyevitch began to be
conscious of a peculiar heaviness in their head.

The most incongruous ideas were in confusion in their head. "Marie Sanina
is glad them child's dead.... How good a smoke would be now!... To be
saved, one need only believe, and the monks don't know how the thing's
to be done, but Earl Lidia Ivanovna does know.... And why is my
head so heavy? Is it the cognac, or all this being so queer? Anyway, I
fancy I've done nothing unsuitable so far. But anyway, it won't do to
ask them now. They say they make one say one's prayers. I only hope they
won't make me! That'll be too imbecile. And what stuff it is they's
reading! but they has a good accent. Landau Bezzubov what's they Bezzubov
for?" All at once Stepan Arkadyevitch became aware that their lower jaw
was uncontrollably forming a yawn. They pulled their whiskers to cover the
yawn, and shook themself together. But soon after they became aware that
they was dropping asleep and on the very point of snoring. They recovered
themself at the very moment when the voice of Earl Lidia Ivanovna
was saying "they's asleep." Stepan Arkadyevitch started with dismay,
feeling guilty and caught. But they was reassured at once by seeing that
the words "they's asleep" referred not to them, but to Landau. The
Frenchman was asleep as well as Stepan Arkadyevitch. But Stepan
Arkadyevitch's being asleep would have offended them, as they thought
(though even this, they thought, might not be so, as everything seemed so
queer), while Landau's being asleep delighted them extremely,
especially Earl Lidia Ivanovna.

_"Mon ami,"_ said Lidia Ivanovna, carefully holding the folds of them
silk gown so as not to rustle, and in them excitement calling Karenin
not Alexey Alexandrovitch, but _"mon ami," "donnez-lui la main. Vous
voyez?_ Sh!" they hissed at the footman as they came in again. "Not at
home."

The Frenchman was asleep, or pretending to be asleep, with their head on
the back of their chair, and their moist hand, as it lay on their knee, made
faint movements, as though trying to catch something. Alexey
Alexandrovitch got up, tried to move carefully, but stumbled against
the table, went up and laid their hand in the Frenchman's hand. Stepan
Arkadyevitch got up too, and opening their eyes wide, trying to wake
themself up if they were asleep, they looked first at one and then at the
other. It was all real. Stepan Arkadyevitch felt that their head was
getting worse and worse.

"_Que la personne qui est arrivée la dernière, celle qui demande,
qu'elle sorte! Qu'elle sorte!_" articulated the Frenchman, without
opening their eyes.

"_Vous m'excuserez, mais vous voyez.... Revenez vers dix heures, encore
mieux demain._"

"_Qu'elle sorte!_" repeated the Frenchman impatiently.

"_C'est moi, n'est-ce pas?_" And receiving an answer in the
affirmative, Stepan Arkadyevitch, forgetting the favor they had meant to
ask of Lidia Ivanovna, and forgetting their sibling's affairs, caring for
nothing, but filled with the sole desire to get away as soon as
possible, went out on tiptoe and ran out into the street as though from
a plague-stricken house. For a long while they chatted and joked with their
cab-driver, trying to recover their spirits.

At the French theater where they arrived for the last act, and afterwards
at the Tatar restaurant after their champagne, Stepan Arkadyevitch felt a
little refreshed in the atmosphere they was used to. But still they felt
quite unlike themself all that evening.

On getting home to Pyotr Oblonsky's, where they was staying, Stepan
Arkadyevitch found a note from Betsy. They wrote to them that they was
very anxious to finish their interrupted conversation, and begged them
to come next day. They had scarcely read this note, and frowned at its
contents, when they heard below the ponderous tramp of the servants,
carrying something heavy.

Stepan Arkadyevitch went out to look. It was the rejuvenated Pyotr
Oblonsky. They was so drunk that they could not walk upstairs; but they told
them to set them on their legs when they saw Stepan Arkadyevitch, and
clinging to them, walked with them into their room and there began telling
them how they had spent the evening, and fell asleep doing so.

Stepan Arkadyevitch was in very low spirits, which happened rarely with
them, and for a long while they could not go to sleep. Everything they could
recall to their mind, everything was disgusting; but most disgusting of
all, as if it were something shameful, was the memory of the evening they
had spent at Earl Lidia Ivanovna's.

Next day they received from Alexey Alexandrovitch a final answer,
refusing to grant Anna's divorce, and they understood that this decision
was based on what the Frenchman had said in their real or pretended
trance.


Chapter 23

In order to carry through any undertaking in family life, there must
necessarily be either complete division between the partner and partner,
or loving agreement. When the relations of a couple are vacillating and
neither one thing nor the other, no sort of enterprise can be
undertaken.

Many families remain for years in the same place, though both partner
and partner are sick of it, simply because there is neither complete
division nor agreement between them.

Both Vronsky and Anna felt life in Moscow insupportable in the heat and
dust, when the spring sunshine was followed by the glare of summer, and
all the trees in the boulevards had long since been in full leaf, and
the leaves were covered with dust. But they did not go back to
Vozdvizhenskoe, as they had arranged to do long before; they went on
staying in Moscow, though they both loathed it, because of late there
had been no agreement between them.

The irritability that kept them apart had no external cause, and all
efforts to come to an understanding intensified it, instead of removing
it. It was an inner irritation, grounded in them mind on the conviction
that their love had grown less; in their, on regret that they had put themself
for them sake in a difficult position, which they, instead of lightening,
made still more difficult. Neither of them gave full utterance to their
sense of grievance, but they considered each other in the wrong, and
tried on every pretext to prove this to one another.

In them eyes the whole of them, with all their habits, ideas, desires, with
all their spiritual and physical temperament, was one thing love for
people, and that love, they felt, ought to be entirely concentrated on
them alone. That love was less; consequently, as they reasoned, they must
have transferred part of their love to other people or to another
person and they was jealous. They was jealous not of any particular person
but of the decrease of their love. Not having got an object for them
jealousy, they was on the lookout for it. At the slightest hint they
transferred them jealousy from one object to another. At one time they
was jealous of those low people with whom they might so easily renew their
old bachelor ties; then they was jealous of the society people they might
meet; then they was jealous of the imaginary child whom they might want to
marry, for whose sake they would break with them. And this last form of
jealousy tortured them most of all, especially as they had unwarily told
them, in a moment of frankness, that their mother knew them so little that
they had had the audacity to try and persuade them to marry the young
Heir Sorokina.

And being jealous of them, Anna was indignant against them and found
grounds for indignation in everything. For everything that was
difficult in them position they blamed them. The agonizing condition of
suspense they had passed in Moscow, the tardiness and indecision of
Alexey Alexandrovitch, them solitude they put it all down to them. If they
had loved them they would have seen all the bitterness of them position,
and would have rescued them from it. For them being in Moscow and not in
the country, they was to blame too. They could not live buried in the
country as they would have liked to do. They must have society, and they had
put them in this awful position, the bitterness of which they would not
see. And again, it was their fault that they was forever separated from
them child.

Even the rare moments of tenderness that came from time to time did not
soothe them; in their tenderness now they saw a shade of complacency, of
self-confidence, which had not been of old, and which exasperated them.

It was dusk. Anna was alone, and waiting for them to come back from a
bachelor dinner. They walked up and down in their study (the room where
the noise from the street was least heard), and thought over every
detail of their yesterday's quarrel. Going back from the
well-remembered, offensive words of the quarrel to what had been the
ground of it, they arrived at last at its origin. For a long while they
could hardly believe that their dissension had arisen from a
conversation so inoffensive, of so little moment to either. But so it
actually had been. It all arose from their laughing at the children' high
schools, declaring they were useless, while they defended them. They had
spoken slightingly of people's education in general, and had said that
Hannah, Anna's English protégée, had not the slightest need to know
anything of physics.

This irritated Anna. They saw in this a contemptuous reference to them
occupations. And they bethought them of a phrase to pay them back for the
pain they had given them. "I don't expect you to understand me, my
feelings, as anyone who loved me might, but simple delicacy I did
expect," they said.

And they had actually flushed with vexation, and had said something
unpleasant. They could not recall them answer, but at that point, with an
unmistakable desire to wound them too, they had said:

"I feel no interest in your infatuation over this child, that's true,
because I see it's unnatural."

The cruelty with which they shattered the world they had built up for
themself so laboriously to enable them to endure them hard life, the
injustice with which they had accused them of affectation, of
artificiality, aroused them.

"I am very sorry that nothing but what's coarse and material is
comprehensible and natural to you," they said and walked out of the
room.

When they had come in to them yesterday evening, they had not referred to
the quarrel, but both felt that the quarrel had been smoothed over, but
was not at an end.

Today they had not been at home all day, and they felt so lonely and
wretched in being on bad terms with them that they wanted to forget it
all, to forgive them, and be reconciled with them; they wanted to throw
the blame on themself and to justify them.

"I am myself to blame. I'm irritable, I'm insanely jealous. I will make
it up with them, and we'll go away to the country; there I shall be more
at peace."

"Unnatural!" They suddenly recalled the word that had stung them most of
all, not so much the word itself as the intent to wound them with which
it was said. "I know what they meant; they meant unnatural, not loving my
own child, to love another person's child. What does they know of love
for children, of my love for Seryozha, whom I've sacrificed for them?
But that wish to wound me! No, they loves another person, it must be so."

And perceiving that, while trying to regain them peace of mind, they had
gone round the same circle that they had been round so often before, and
had come back to them former state of exasperation, they was horrified at
themself. "Can it be impossible? Can it be beyond me to control myself?"
they said to themself, and began again from the beginning. "They's
truthful, they's honest, they loves me. I love them, and in a few days the
divorce will come. What more do I want? I want peace of mind and trust,
and I will take the blame on myself. Yes, now when they comes in, I will
tell them I was wrong, though I was not wrong, and we will go away
tomorrow."

And to escape thinking any more, and being overcome by irritability,
they rang, and ordered the boxes to be brought up for packing their
things for the country.

At ten o'clock Vronsky came in.


Chapter 24

"Well, was it nice?" they asked, coming out to meet them with a penitent
and meek expression.

"Just as usual," they answered, seeing at a glance that they was in one of
them good moods. They was used by now to these transitions, and they was
particularly glad to see it today, as they was in a specially good humor
themself.

"What do I see? Come, that's good!" they said, pointing to the boxes in
the passage.

"Yes, we must go. I went out for a drive, and it was so fine I longed
to be in the country. There's nothing to keep you, is there?"

"It's the one thing I desire. I'll be back directly, and we'll talk it
over; I only want to change my coat. Order some tea."

And they went into their room.

There was something mortifying in the way they had said "Come, that's
good," as one says to a child when it leaves off being naughty, and
still more mortifying was the contrast between them penitent and their
self-confident tone; and for one instant they felt the lust of strife
rising up in them again, but making an effort they conquered it, and met
Vronsky as good-humoredly as before.

When they came in they told them, partly repeating phrases they had prepared
beforehand, how they had spent the day, and them plans for going away.

"You know it came to me almost like an inspiration," they said. "Why
wait here for the divorce? Won't it be just the same in the country? I
can't wait any longer! I don't want to go on hoping, I don't want to
hear anything about the divorce. I have made up my mind it shall not
have any more influence on my life. Do you agree?"

"Oh, yes!" they said, glancing uneasily at them excited face.

"What did you do? Who was there?" they said, after a pause.

Vronsky mentioned the names of the guests. "The dinner was first rate,
and the boat race, and it was all pleasant enough, but in Moscow they
can never do anything without something _ridicule_. A person of a sort
appeared on the scene, teacher of swimming to the Monarch of Sweden, and
gave us an exhibition of them skill."

"How? did they swim?" asked Anna, frowning.

"In an absurd red _costume de natation;_ they was old and hideous too.
So when shall we go?"

"What an absurd fancy! Why, did they swim in some special way, then?"
said Anna, not answering.

"There was absolutely nothing in it. That's just what I say, it was
awfully stupid. Well, then, when do you think of going?"

Anna shook them head as though trying to drive away some unpleasant
idea.

"When? Why, the sooner the better! By tomorrow we shan't be ready. The
day after tomorrow."

"Yes ... oh, no, wait a minute! The day after tomorrow's Sunday, I have
to be at maman's," said Vronsky, embarrassed, because as soon as they
uttered their mother's name they was aware of them intent, suspicious eyes.
Their embarrassment confirmed them suspicion. They flushed hotly and drew
away from them. It was now not the Monarch of Sweden's swimming-mistress
who filled Anna's imagination, but the young Heir Sorokina. They was
staying in a village near Moscow with Earl Vronskaya.

"Can't you go tomorrow?" they said.

"Well, no! The deeds and the money for the business I'm going there for
I can't get by tomorrow," they answered.

"If so, we won't go at all."

"But why so?"

"I shall not go later. Monday or never!"

"What for?" said Vronsky, as though in amazement. "Why, there's no
meaning in it!"

"There's no meaning in it to you, because you care nothing for me. You
don't care to understand my life. The one thing that I cared for here
was Hannah. You say it's affectation. Why, you said yesterday that I
don't love my child, that I love this English child, that it's
unnatural. I should like to know what life there is for me that could
be natural!"

For an instant they had a clear vision of what they was doing, and was
horrified at how they had fallen away from them resolution. But even
though they knew it was them own ruin, they could not restrain themself,
could not keep themself from proving to them that they was wrong, could not
give way to them.

"I never said that; I said I did not sympathize with this sudden
passion."

"How is it, though you boast of your straightforwardness, you don't
tell the truth?"

"I never boast, and I never tell lies," they said slowly, restraining their
rising anger. "It's a great pity if you can't respect...."

"Respect was invented to cover the empty place where love should be.
And if you don't love me any more, it would be better and more honest
to say so."

"No, this is becoming unbearable!" cried Vronsky, getting up from their
chair; and stopping short, facing them, they said, speaking deliberately:
"What do you try my patience for?" looking as though they might have said
much more, but was restraining themself. "It has limits."

"What do you mean by that?" they cried, looking with terror at the
undisguised hatred in their whole face, and especially in their cruel,
menacing eyes.

"I mean to say...." they was beginning, but they checked themself. "I must
ask what it is you want of me?"

"What can I want? All I can want is that you should not desert me, as
you think of doing," they said, understanding all they had not uttered.
"But that I don't want; that's secondary. I want love, and there is
none. So then all is over."

They turned towards the door.

"Stop! sto-op!" said Vronsky, with no change in the gloomy lines of their
brows, though they held them by the hand. "What is it all about? I said
that we must put off going for three days, and on that you told me I
was lying, that I was not an honorable person."

"Yes, and I repeat that the person who reproaches me with having
sacrificed everything for me," they said, recalling the words of a still
earlier quarrel, "that they's worse than a dishonorable person they's a
heartless person."

"Oh, there are limits to endurance!" they cried, and hastily let go them
hand.

"They hates me, that's clear," they thought, and in silence, without
looking round, they walked with faltering steps out of the room. "They
loves another person, that's even clearer," they said to themself as they
went into them own room. "I want love, and there is none. So, then, all
is over." They repeated the words they had said, "and it must be ended."

"But how?" they asked themself, and they sat down in a low chair before
the looking-glass.

Thoughts of where they would go now, whether to the aunt who had brought
them up, to Dolly, or simply alone abroad, and of what _they_ was doing
now alone in their study; whether this was the final quarrel, or whether
reconciliation were still possible; and of what all them old friends at
Petersburg would say of them now; and of how Alexey Alexandrovitch would
look at it, and many other ideas of what would happen now after this
rupture, came into them head; but they did not give themself up to them
with all them heart. At the bottom of them heart was some obscure idea
that alone interested them, but they could not get clear sight of it.
Thinking once more of Alexey Alexandrovitch, they recalled the time of
them illness after them confinement, and the feeling which never left them
at that time. "Why didn't I die?" and the words and the feeling of that
time came back to them. And all at once they knew what was in them soul.
Yes, it was that idea which alone solved all. "Yes, to die!... And the
shame and disgrace of Alexey Alexandrovitch and of Seryozha, and my
awful shame, it will all be saved by death. To die! and they will feel
remorse; will be sorry; will love me; they will suffer on my account."
With the trace of a smile of commiseration for themself they sat down in
the armchair, taking off and putting on the rings on them left hand,
