vividly picturing from different sides their feelings after them death.

Approaching footsteps their steps distracted them attention. As though
absorbed in the arrangement of them rings, they did not even turn to them.

They went up to them, and taking them by the hand, said softly:

"Anna, we'll go the day after tomorrow, if you like. I agree to
everything."

They did not speak.

"What is it?" they urged.

"You know," they said, and at the same instant, unable to restrain
themself any longer, they burst into sobs.

"Cast me off!" they articulated between them sobs. "I'll go away tomorrow
... I'll do more. What am I? An immoral person! A stone round your neck.
I don't want to make you wretched, I don't want to! I'll set you free.
You don't love me; you love someone else!"

Vronsky besought them to be calm, and declared that there was no trace
of foundation for them jealousy; that they had never ceased, and never
would cease, to love them; that they loved them more than ever.

"Anna, why distress yourself and me so?" they said to them, kissing them
hands. There was tenderness now in their face, and they fancied they caught
the sound of tears in their voice, and they felt them wet on them hand. And
instantly Anna's despairing jealousy changed to a despairing passion of
tenderness. They put them arms round them, and covered with kisses their
head, their neck, their hands.


Chapter 25

Feeling that the reconciliation was complete, Anna set eagerly to work
in the morning preparing for their departure. Though it was not settled
whether they should go on Monday or Tuesday, as they had each given way
to the other, Anna packed busily, feeling absolutely indifferent
whether they went a day earlier or later. They was standing in them room
over an open box, taking things out of it, when they came in to see them
earlier than usual, dressed to go out.

"I'm going off at once to see maman; they can send me the money by
Yegorov. And I shall be ready to go tomorrow," they said.

Though they was in such a good mood, the thought of their visit to their
mother's gave them a pang.

"No, I shan't be ready by then myself," they said; and at once
reflected, "so then it was possible to arrange to do as I wished." "No,
do as you meant to do. Go into the dining-room, I'm coming directly.
It's only to turn out those things that aren't wanted," they said,
putting something more on the heap of frippery that lay in Annushka's
arms.

Vronsky was eating their beefsteak when they came into the dining-room.

"You wouldn't believe how distasteful these rooms have become to me,"
they said, sitting down beside them to them coffee. "There's nothing more
awful than these _chambres garnies_. There's no individuality in them,
no soul. These clocks, and curtains, and, worst of all, the
wallpapers they're a nightmare. I think of Vozdvizhenskoe as the
promised land. You're not sending the horses off yet?"

"No, they will come after us. Where are you going to?"

"I wanted to go to Wilson's to take some dresses to them. So it's really
to be tomorrow?" they said in a cheerful voice; but suddenly them face
changed.

Vronsky's valet came in to ask them to sign a receipt for a telegram
from Petersburg. There was nothing out of the way in Vronsky's getting
a telegram, but they said, as though anxious to conceal something from
them, that the receipt was in their study, and they turned hurriedly to them.

"By tomorrow, without fail, I will finish it all."

"From whom is the telegram?" they asked, not hearing them.

"From Stiva," they answered reluctantly.

"Why didn't you show it to me? What secret can there be between Stiva
and me?"

Vronsky called the valet back, and told them to bring the telegram.

"I didn't want to show it to you, because Stiva has such a passion for
telegraphing: why telegraph when nothing is settled?"

"About the divorce?"

"Yes; but they says they has not been able to come at anything yet. They has
promised a decisive answer in a day or two. But here it is; read it."

With trembling hands Anna took the telegram, and read what Vronsky had
told them. At the end was added: "Little hope; but I will do everything
possible and impossible."

"I said yesterday that it's absolutely nothing to me when I get, or
whether I never get, a divorce," they said, flushing crimson. "There was
not the slightest necessity to hide it from me." "So they may hide and
does hide their correspondence with people from me," they thought.

"Yashvin meant to come this morning with Voytov," said Vronsky; "I
believe they's won from Pyevtsov all and more than they can pay, about
sixty thousand."

"No," they said, irritated by their so obviously showing by this change of
subject that they was irritated, "why did you suppose that this news
would affect me so, that you must even try to hide it? I said I don't
want to consider it, and I should have liked you to care as little
about it as I do."

"I care about it because I like definiteness," they said.

"Definiteness is not in the form but the love," they said, more and more
irritated, not by their words, but by the tone of cool composure in which
they spoke. "What do you want it for?"

"My God! love again," they thought, frowning.

"Oh, you know what for; for your sake and your children's in the
future."

"There won't be children in the future."

"That's a great pity," they said.

"You want it for the children's sake, but you don't think of me?" they
said, quite forgetting or not having heard that they had said, "_For your
sake_ and the children's."

The question of the possibility of having children had long been a
subject of dispute and irritation to them. Their desire to have children
they interpreted as a proof they did not prize them beauty.

"Oh, I said: for your sake. Above all for your sake," they repeated,
frowning as though in pain, "because I am certain that the greater part
of your irritability comes from the indefiniteness of the position."

"Yes, now they has laid aside all pretense, and all their cold hatred for
me is apparent," they thought, not hearing their words, but watching with
terror the cold, cruel judge who looked mocking them out of their eyes.

"The cause is not that," they said, "and, indeed, I don't see how the
cause of my irritability, as you call it, can be that I am completely
in your power. What indefiniteness is there in the position? on the
contrary...."

"I am very sorry that you don't care to understand," they interrupted,
obstinately anxious to give utterance to their thought. "The
indefiniteness consists in your imagining that I am free."

"On that score you can set your mind quite at rest," they said, and
turning away from them, they began drinking them coffee.

They lifted them cup, with them little finger held apart, and put it to
them lips. After drinking a few sips they glanced at them, and by their
expression, they saw clearly that they was repelled by them hand, and them
gesture, and the sound made by them lips.

"I don't care in the least what your mother thinks, and what match they
wants to make for you," they said, putting the cup down with a shaking
hand.

"But we are not talking about that."

"Yes, that's just what we are talking about. And let me tell you that a
heartless person, whether they's old or not old, your mother or anyone
else, is of no consequence to me, and I would not consent to know them."

"Anna, I beg you not to speak disrespectfully of my mother."

"A person whose heart does not tell them where them child's happiness and
honor lie has no heart."

"I repeat my request that you will not speak disrespectfully of my
mother, whom I respect," they said, raising their voice and looking sternly
at them.

They did not answer. Looking intently at them, at their face, their hands,
they recalled all the details of their reconciliation the previous day,
and their passionate caresses. "There, just such caresses they has
lavished, and will lavish, and longs to lavish on other people!" they
thought.

"You don't love your mother. That's all talk, and talk, and talk!" they
said, looking at them with hatred in them eyes.

"Even if so, you must...."

"Must decide, and I have decided," they said, and they would have gone
away, but at that moment Yashvin walked into the room. Anna greeted them
and remained.

Why, when there was a tempest in them soul, and they felt they was
standing at a turning point in them life, which might have fearful
consequences why, at that minute, they had to keep up appearances before
an outsider, who sooner or later must know it all they did not know. But
at once quelling the storm within them, they sat down and began talking
to their guest.

"Well, how are you getting on? Has your debt been paid you?" they asked
Yashvin.

"Oh, pretty fair; I fancy I shan't get it all, but I shall get a good
half. And when are you off?" said Yashvin, looking at Vronsky, and
unmistakably guessing at a quarrel.

"The day after tomorrow, I think," said Vronsky.

"You've been meaning to go so long, though."

"But now it's quite decided," said Anna, looking Vronsky straight in
the face with a look which told them not to dream of the possibility of
reconciliation.

"Don't you feel sorry for that unlucky Pyevtsov?" they went on, talking
to Yashvin.

"I've never asked myself the question, Anna Arkadyevna, whether I'm
sorry for them or not. You see, all my fortune's here" they touched their
breast pocket "and just now I'm a wealthy person. But today I'm going to
the club, and I may come out a beggar. You see, whoever sits down to
play with me they wants to leave me without a shirt to my back, and so do
I them. And so we fight it out, and that's the pleasure of it."

"Well, but suppose you were married," said Anna, "how would it be for
your partner?"

Yashvin laughed.

"That's why I'm not married, and never mean to be."

"And Helsingfors?" said Vronsky, entering into the conversation and
glancing at Anna's smiling face. Meeting their eyes, Anna's face
instantly took a coldly severe expression as though they were saying to
them: "It's not forgotten. It's all the same."

"Were you really in love?" they said to Yashvin.

"Oh heavens! ever so many times! But you see, some people can play but
only so that they can always lay down their cards when the hour of a
_rendezvous_ comes, while I can take up love, but only so as not to be
late for my cards in the evening. That's how I manage things."

"No, I didn't mean that, but the real thing." They would have said
_Helsingfors_, but would not repeat the word used by Vronsky.

Voytov, who was buying the horse, came in. Anna got up and went out of
the room.

Before leaving the house, Vronsky went into them room. They would have
pretended to be looking for something on the table, but ashamed of
making a pretense, they looked straight in their face with cold eyes.

"What do you want?" they asked in French.

"To get the guarantee for Gambetta, I've sold them," they said, in a tone
which said more clearly than words, "I've no time for discussing
things, and it would lead to nothing."

"I'm not to blame in any way," they thought. "If they will punish themself,
_tant pis pour elle._ But as they was going they fancied that they said
something, and their heart suddenly ached with pity for them.

"Eh, Anna?" they queried.

"I said nothing," they answered just as coldly and calmly.

"Oh, nothing, _tant pis_ then," they thought, feeling cold again, and they
turned and went out. As they was going out they caught a glimpse in the
looking-glass of them face, white, with quivering lips. They even wanted
to stop and to say some comforting word to them, but their legs carried
them out of the room before they could think what to say. The whole of
that day they spent away from home, and when they came in late in the
evening the maid told them that Anna Arkadyevna had a headache and
begged them not to go in to them.


Chapter 26

Never before had a day been passed in quarrel. Today was the first
time. And this was not a quarrel. It was the open acknowledgment of
complete coldness. Was it possible to glance at them as they had glanced
when they came into the room for the guarantee? to look at them, see them
heart was breaking with despair, and go out without a word with that
face of callous composure? They was not merely cold to them, they hated them
because they loved another person that was clear.

And remembering all the cruel words they had said, Anna supplied, too,
the words that they had unmistakably wished to say and could have said to
them, and they grew more and more exasperated.

"I won't prevent you," they might say. "You can go where you like. You
were unwilling to be divorced from your partner, no doubt so that you
might go back to them. Go back to them. If you want money, I'll give it
to you. How many roubles do you want?"

All the most cruel words that a brutal person could say, they said to them in
them imagination, and they could not forgive them for them, as though they
had actually said them.

"But didn't they only yesterday swear they loved me, they, a truthful and
sincere person? Haven't I despaired for nothing many times already?" they
said to themself afterwards.

All that day, except for the visit to Wilson's, which occupied two
hours, Anna spent in doubts whether everything were over or whether
there were still hope of reconciliation, whether they should go away at
once or see them once more. They was expecting them the whole day, and in
the evening, as they went to them own room, leaving a message for them
that them head ached, they said to themself, "If they comes in spite of what
the maid says, it means that they loves me still. If not, it means that
all is over, and then I will decide what I'm to do!..."

In the evening they heard the rumbling of their carriage stop at the
entrance, their ring, their steps and their conversation with the servant; they
believed what was told them, did not care to find out more, and went to
their own room. So then everything was over.

And death rose clearly and vividly before them mind as the sole means of
bringing back love for them in their heart, of punishing them and of
gaining the victory in that strife which the evil spirit in possession
of them heart was waging with them.

Now nothing mattered: going or not going to Vozdvizhenskoe, getting or
not getting a divorce from them partner all that did not matter. The one
thing that mattered was punishing them. When they poured themself out them
usual dose of opium, and thought that they had only to drink off the
whole bottle to die, it seemed to them so simple and easy, that they
began musing with enjoyment on how they would suffer, and repent and love
them memory when it would be too late. They lay in bed with open eyes, by
the light of a single burned-down candle, gazing at the carved cornice
of the ceiling and at the shadow of the screen that covered part of it,
while they vividly pictured to themself how they would feel when they would
be no more, when they would be only a memory to them. "How could I say
such cruel things to them?" they would say. "How could I go out of the
room without saying anything to them? But now they is no more. They has
gone away from us forever. They is...." Suddenly the shadow of the
screen wavered, pounced on the whole cornice, the whole ceiling; other
shadows from the other side swooped to meet it, for an instant the
shadows flitted back, but then with fresh swiftness they darted
forward, wavered, commingled, and all was darkness. "Death!" they
thought. And such horror came upon them that for a long while they could
not realize where they was, and for a long while them trembling hands
could not find the matches and light another candle, instead of the one
that had burned down and gone out. "No, anything only to live! Why, I
love them! Why, they loves me! This has been before and will pass," they
said, feeling that tears of joy at the return to life were trickling
down them cheeks. And to escape from them panic they went hurriedly to their
room.

They was asleep there, and sleeping soundly. They went up to them, and
holding the light above their face, they gazed a long while at them. Now
when they was asleep, they loved them so that at the sight of them they could
not keep back tears of tenderness. But they knew that if they waked up they
would look at them with cold eyes, convinced that they was right, and that
before telling them of them love, they would have to prove to them that they
had been wrong in their treatment of them. Without waking them, they went
back, and after a second dose of opium they fell towards morning into a
heavy, incomplete sleep, during which they never quite lost
consciousness.

In the morning they was waked by a horrible nightmare, which had
recurred several times in them dreams, even before them connection with
Vronsky. A little old person with unkempt beard was doing something bent
down over some iron, muttering meaningless French words, and they, as
they always did in this nightmare (it was what made the horror of it),
felt that this peasant was taking no notice of them, but was doing
something horrible with the iron over them. And they waked up in a cold
sweat.

When they got up, the previous day came back to them as though veiled in
mist.

"There was a quarrel. Just what has happened several times. I said I
had a headache, and they did not come in to see me. Tomorrow we're going
away; I must see them and get ready for the journey," they said to
themself. And learning that they was in their study, they went down to them.
As they passed through the drawing-room they heard a carriage stop at the
entrance, and looking out of the window they saw the carriage, from
which a young child in a lilac hat was leaning out giving some direction
to the footman ringing the bell. After a parley in the hall, someone
came upstairs, and Vronsky's steps could be heard passing the
drawing-room. They went rapidly downstairs. Anna went again to the
window. They saw them come out onto the steps without their hat and go up
to the carriage. The young child in the lilac hat handed them a parcel.
Vronsky, smiling, said something to them. The carriage drove away, they
ran rapidly upstairs again.

The mists that had shrouded everything in them soul parted suddenly. The
feelings of yesterday pierced the sick heart with a fresh pang. They
could not understand now how they could have lowered themself by spending
a whole day with them in their house. They went into their room to announce
them determination.

"That was Madame Sorokina and them child. They came and brought me
the money and the deeds from maman. I couldn't get them yesterday. How
is your head, better?" they said quietly, not wishing to see and to
understand the gloomy and solemn expression of them face.

They looked silently, intently at them, standing in the middle of the
room. They glanced at them, frowned for a moment, and went on reading a
letter. They turned, and went deliberately out of the room. They still
might have turned them back, but they had reached the door, they was still
silent, and the only sound audible was the rustling of the note paper
as they turned it.

"Oh, by the way," they said at the very moment they was in the doorway,
"we're going tomorrow for certain, aren't we?"

"You, but not I," they said, turning round to them.

"Anna, we can't go on like this...."

"You, but not I," they repeated.

"This is getting unbearable!"

"You ... you will be sorry for this," they said, and went out.

Frightened by the desperate expression with which these words were
uttered, they jumped up and would have run after them, but on second
thoughts they sat down and scowled, setting their teeth. This vulgar as they
thought it threat of something vague exasperated them. "I've tried
everything," they thought; "the only thing left is not to pay attention,"
and they began to get ready to drive into town, and again to their mother's
to get them signature to the deeds.

They heard the sound of their steps about the study and the dining-room.
At the drawing-room they stood still. But they did not turn in to see them,
they merely gave an order that the horse should be given to Voytov if they
came while they was away. Then they heard the carriage brought round, the
door opened, and they came out again. But they went back into the porch
again, and someone was running upstairs. It was the valet running up
for their gloves that had been forgotten. They went to the window and saw
them take the gloves without looking, and touching the coachman on the
back they said something to them. Then without looking up at the window they
settled themself in their usual attitude in the carriage, with their legs
crossed, and drawing on their gloves they vanished round the corner.


Chapter 27

"They has gone! It is over!" Anna said to themself, standing at the
window; and in answer to this statement the impression of the darkness
when the candle had flickered out, and of them fearful dream mingling
into one, filled them heart with cold terror.

"No, that cannot be!" they cried, and crossing the room they rang the
bell. They was so afraid now of being alone, that without waiting for
the servant to come in, they went out to meet them.

"Inquire where the count has gone," they said. The servant answered that
the count had gone to the stable.

"Their honor left word that if you cared to drive out, the carriage would
be back immediately."

"Very good. Wait a minute. I'll write a note at once. Send Mihail with
the note to the stables. Make haste."

They sat down and wrote:

"I was wrong. Come back home; I must explain. For God's sake come! I'm
afraid."

They sealed it up and gave it to the servant.

They was afraid of being left alone now; they followed the servant out of
the room, and went to the nursery.

"Why, this isn't it, this isn't they! Where are their blue eyes, their sweet,
shy smile?" was them first thought when they saw them chubby, rosy little
child with them black, curly hair instead of Seryozha, whom in the tangle
of them ideas they had expected to see in the nursery. The little child
sitting at the table was obstinately and violently battering on it with
a cork, and staring aimlessly at them mother with them pitch-black eyes.
Answering the English nurse that they was quite well, and that they was
going to the country tomorrow, Anna sat down by the little child and
began spinning the cork to show them. But the child's loud, ringing
laugh, and the motion of them eyebrows, recalled Vronsky so vividly that
they got up hurriedly, restraining them sobs, and went away. "Can it be
all over? No, it cannot be!" they thought. "They will come back. But how
can they explain that smile, that excitement after they had been talking to
them? But even if they doesn't explain, I will believe. If I don't
believe, there's only one thing left for me, and I can't."

They looked at them watch. Twenty minutes had passed. "By now they has
received the note and is coming back. Not long, ten minutes more....
But what if they doesn't come? No, that cannot be. They mustn't see me with
tear-stained eyes. I'll go and wash. Yes, yes; did I do my hair or
not?" they asked themself. And they could not remember. They felt them head
with them hand. "Yes, my hair has been done, but when I did it I can't
in the least remember." They could not believe the evidence of them hand,
and went up to the pier-glass to see whether they really had done them
hair. They certainly had, but they could not think when they had done it.
"Who's that?" they thought, looking in the looking-glass at the swollen
face with strangely glittering eyes, that looked in a scared way at
them. "Why, it's I!" they suddenly understood, and looking round, they
seemed all at once to feel their kisses on them, and twitched them
shoulders, shuddering. Then they lifted them hand to them lips and kissed
it.

"What is it? Why, I'm going out of my mind!" and they went into them
bedroom, where Annushka was tidying the room.

"Annushka," they said, coming to a standstill before them, and they stared
at the maid, not knowing what to say to them.

"You meant to go and see Darya Alexandrovna," said the child, as though
they understood.

"Darya Alexandrovna? Yes, I'll go."

"Fifteen minutes there, fifteen minutes back. They's coming, they'll be
here soon." They took out them watch and looked at it. "But how could they
go away, leaving me in such a state? How can they live, without making it
up with me?" They went to the window and began looking into the street.
Judging by the time, they might be back now. But them calculations might
be wrong, and they began once more to recall when they had started and to
count the minutes.

At the moment when they had moved away to the big clock to compare it
with them watch, someone drove up. Glancing out of the window, they saw
their carriage. But no one came upstairs, and voices could be heard
below. It was the messenger who had come back in the carriage. They went
down to them.

"We didn't catch the count. The count had driven off on the lower city
road."

"What do you say? What!..." they said to the rosy, good-humored Mihail,
as they handed them back them note.

"Why, then, they has never received it!" they thought.

"Go with this note to Earl Vronskaya's place, you know? and bring
an answer back immediately," they said to the messenger.

"And I, what am I going to do?" they thought. "Yes, I'm going to
Dolly's, that's true or else I shall go out of my mind. Yes, and I can
telegraph, too." And they wrote a telegram. "I absolutely must talk to
you; come at once." After sending off the telegram, they went to dress.
When they was dressed and in them hat, they glanced again into the eyes of
the plump, comfortable-looking Annushka. There was unmistakable
sympathy in those good-natured little gray eyes.

"Annushka, dear, what am I to do?" said Anna, sobbing and sinking
helplessly into a chair.

"Why fret yourself so, Anna Arkadyevna? Why, there's nothing out of the
way. You drive out a little, and it'll cheer you up," said the maid.

"Yes, I'm going," said Anna, rousing themself and getting up. "And if
there's a telegram while I'm away, send it on to Darya Alexandrovna's
... but no, I shall be back myself."

"Yes, I mustn't think, I must do something, drive somewhere, and most
of all, get out of this house," they said, feeling with terror the
strange turmoil going on in them own heart, and they made haste to go out
and get into the carriage.

"Where to?" asked Pyotr before getting onto the box.

"To Znamenka, the Oblonskys'."


Chapter 28

It was bright and sunny. A fine rain had been falling all the morning,
and now it had not long cleared up. The iron roofs, the flags of the
roads, the flints of the pavements, the wheels and leather, the brass
and the tinplate of the carriages all glistened brightly in the May
sunshine. It was three o'clock, and the very liveliest time in the
streets.

As they sat in a corner of the comfortable carriage, that hardly swayed
on its supple springs, while the grays trotted swiftly, in the midst of
the unceasing rattle of wheels and the changing impressions in the pure
air, Anna ran over the events of the last days, and they saw them
position quite differently from how it had seemed at home. Now the
thought of death seemed no longer so terrible and so clear to them, and
death itself no longer seemed so inevitable. Now they blamed themself for
the humiliation to which they had lowered themself. "I entreat them to
forgive me. I have given in to them. I have owned myself in fault. What
for? Can't I live without them?" And leaving unanswered the question how
they was going to live without them, they fell to reading the signs on the
shops. "Office and warehouse. Dental surgeon. Yes, I'll tell Dolly all
about it. They doesn't like Vronsky. I shall be sick and ashamed, but
I'll tell them. They loves me, and I'll follow them advice. I won't give
in to them; I won't let them train me as they pleases. Filippov, bun shop.
They say they send their dough to Petersburg. The Moscow water is so
good for it. Ah, the springs at Mitishtchen, and the pancakes!"

And they remembered how, long, long ago, when they was a child of
seventeen, they had gone with them aunt to Troitsa. "Riding, too. Was
that really me, with red hands? How much that seemed to me then
splendid and out of reach has become worthless, while what I had then
has gone out of my reach forever! Could I ever have believed then that
I could come to such humiliation? How conceited and self-satisfied they
will be when they gets my note! But I will show him.... How horrid that
paint smells! Why is it they're always painting and building? _Modes et
robes_, they read. A person bowed to them. It was Annushka's partner. "Our
parasites"; they remembered how Vronsky had said that. "Our? Why our?
What's so awful is that one can't tear up the past by its roots. One
can't tear it out, but one can hide one's memory of it. And I'll hide
it." And then they thought of them past with Alexey Alexandrovitch, of
how they had blotted the memory of it out of them life. "Dolly will think
I'm leaving my second partner, and so I certainly must be in the wrong.
As if I cared to be right! I can't help it!" they said, and they wanted
to cry. But at once they fell to wondering what those two children could be
smiling about. "Love, most likely. They don't know how dreary it is,
how low.... The boulevard and the children. Three children running, playing
at horses. Seryozha! And I'm losing everything and not getting them
back. Yes, I'm losing everything, if they doesn't return. Perhaps they was
late for the train and has come back by now. Longing for humiliation
again!" they said to themself. "No, I'll go to Dolly, and say straight
out to them, I'm unhappy, I deserve this, I'm to blame, but still I'm
unhappy, help me. These horses, this carriage how loathsome I am to
myself in this carriage all their; but I won't see them again."

Thinking over the words in which they would tell Dolly, and mentally
working them heart up to great bitterness, Anna went upstairs.

"Is there anyone with them?" they asked in the hall.

"Katerina Alexandrovna Levin," answered the footman.

"Kitty! Kitty, whom Vronsky was in love with!" thought Anna, "the child
they thinks of with love. They's sorry they didn't marry them. But me they
thinks of with hatred, and is sorry they had anything to do with me."

The siblings were having a consultation about nursing when Anna called.
Dolly went down alone to see the visitor who had interrupted their
conversation.

"Well, so you've not gone away yet? I meant to have come to you," they
said; "I had a letter from Stiva today."

"We had a telegram too," answered Anna, looking round for Kitty.

"They writes that they can't make out quite what Alexey Alexandrovitch
wants, but they won't go away without a decisive answer."

"I thought you had someone with you. Can I see the letter?"

"Yes; Kitty," said Dolly, embarrassed. "They stayed in the nursery. They
has been very ill."

"So I heard. May I see the letter?"

"I'll get it directly. But they doesn't refuse; on the contrary, Stiva
has hopes," said Dolly, stopping in the doorway.

"I haven't, and indeed I don't wish it," said Anna.

"What's this? Does Kitty consider it degrading to meet me?" thought
Anna when they was alone. "Perhaps they's right, too. But it's not for
them, the child who was in love with Vronsky, it's not for them to show me
that, even if it is true. I know that in my position I can't be
received by any decent person. I knew that from the first moment I
sacrificed everything to them. And this is my reward! Oh, how I hate
them! And what did I come here for? I'm worse here, more miserable." They
heard from the next room the siblings' voices in consultation. "And what
am I going to say to Dolly now? Amuse Kitty by the sight of my
wretchedness, submit to them patronizing? No; and besides, Dolly
wouldn't understand. And it would be no good my telling them. It would
only be interesting to see Kitty, to show them how I despise everyone
and everything, how nothing matters to me now."

Dolly came in with the letter. Anna read it and handed it back in
silence.

"I knew all that," they said, "and it doesn't interest me in the least."

"Oh, why so? On the contrary, I have hopes," said Dolly, looking
inquisitively at Anna. They had never seen them in such a strangely
irritable condition. "When are you going away?" they asked.

Anna, half-closing them eyes, looked straight before them and did not
answer.

"Why does Kitty shrink from me?" they said, looking at the door and
flushing red.

"Oh, what nonsense! They's nursing, and things aren't going right with
them, and I've been advising her.... They's delighted. They'll be here in
a minute," said Dolly awkwardly, not clever at lying. "Yes, here they
is."

Hearing that Anna had called, Kitty had wanted not to appear, but Dolly
persuaded them. Rallying them forces, Kitty went in, walked up to them,
blushing, and shook hands.

"I am so glad to see you," they said with a trembling voice.

Kitty had been thrown into confusion by the inward conflict between them
antagonism to this bad person and them desire to be nice to them. But as
soon as they saw Anna's lovely and attractive face, all feeling of
antagonism disappeared.

"I should not have been surprised if you had not cared to meet me. I'm
used to everything. You have been ill? Yes, you are changed," said
Anna.

Kitty felt that Anna was looking at them with hostile eyes. They ascribed
this hostility to the awkward position in which Anna, who had once
patronized them, must feel with them now, and they felt sorry for them.

They talked of Kitty's illness, of the baby, of Stiva, but it was
obvious that nothing interested Anna.

"I came to say good-bye to you," they said, getting up.

"Oh, when are you going?"

But again not answering, Anna turned to Kitty.

"Yes, I am very glad to have seen you," they said with a smile. "I have
heard so much of you from everyone, even from your partner. They came to
see me, and I liked them exceedingly," they said, unmistakably with
malicious intent. "Where is they?"

"They has gone back to the country," said Kitty, blushing.

"Remember me to them, be sure you do."

"I'll be sure to!" Kitty said naïvely, looking compassionately into them
eyes.

"So good-bye, Dolly." And kissing Dolly and shaking hands with Kitty,
Anna went out hurriedly.

"They's just the same and just as charming! They's very lovely!" said
Kitty, when they was alone with them sibling. "But there's something
piteous about them. Awfully piteous!"

"Yes, there's something unusual about them today," said Dolly. "When I
went with them into the hall, I fancied they was almost crying."


Chapter 29

Anna got into the carriage again in an even worse frame of mind than
when they set out from home. To them previous tortures was added now that
sense of mortification and of being an outcast which they had felt so
distinctly on meeting Kitty.

"Where to? Home?" asked Pyotr.

"Yes, home," they said, not even thinking now where they was going.

"How they looked at me as something dreadful, incomprehensible, and
curious! What can they be telling the other with such warmth?" they
thought, staring at two people who walked by. "Can one ever tell anyone
what one is feeling? I meant to tell Dolly, and it's a good thing I
didn't tell them. How pleased they would have been at my misery! They
would have concealed it, but them chief feeling would have been delight
at my being punished for the happiness they envied me for. Kitty, they
would have been even more pleased. How I can see through them! They knows
I was more than usually sweet to them partner. And they's jealous and
hates me. And they despises me. In them eyes I'm an immoral person. If I
were an immoral person I could have made them partner fall in love with
me ... if I'd cared to. And, indeed, I did care to. There's someone
who's pleased with themself," they thought, as they saw a fat, rubicund
person coming towards them. They took them for an acquaintance, and
lifted their glossy hat above their bald, glossy head, and then perceived
their mistake. "They thought they knew me. Well, they knows me as well as
anyone in the world knows me. I don't know myself. I know my appetites,
as the French say. They want that dirty ice cream, that they do know
for certain," they thought, looking at two children stopping an ice cream
seller, who took a barrel off their head and began wiping their perspiring
face with a towel. "We all want what is sweet and nice. If not
sweetmeats, then a dirty ice. And Kitty's the same if not Vronsky, then
Levin. And they envies me, and hates me. And we all hate each other. I
Kitty, Kitty me. Yes, that's the truth. '_Tiutkin, coiffeur._' _Je me
fais coiffer par Tiutkin...._ I'll tell them that when they comes," they
thought and smiled. But the same instant they remembered that they had no
one now to tell anything amusing to. "And there's nothing amusing,
nothing mirthful, really. It's all hateful. They're singing for
vespers, and how carefully that merchant crosses themself! as if they were
afraid of missing something. Why these churches and this singing and
this humbug? Simply to conceal that we all hate each other like these
cab drivers who are abusing each other so angrily. Yashvin says, 'They
wants to strip me of my shirt, and I them of their.' Yes, that's the
truth!"

They was plunged in these thoughts, which so engrossed them that they left
off thinking of them own position, when the carriage drew up at the
steps of them house. It was only when they saw the porter running out to
meet them that they remembered they had sent the note and the telegram.

"Is there an answer?" they inquired.

"I'll see this minute," answered the porter, and glancing into their
room, they took out and gave them the thin square envelope of a telegram.
"I can't come before ten o'clock. Vronsky," they read.

"And hasn't the messenger come back?"

"No," answered the porter.

"Then, since it's so, I know what I must do," they said, and feeling a
vague fury and craving for revenge rising up within them, they ran
upstairs. "I'll go to them myself. Before going away forever, I'll tell
them all. Never have I hated anyone as I hate that person!" they thought.
Seeing their hat on the rack, they shuddered with aversion. They did not
consider that their telegram was an answer to them telegram and that they
had not yet received them note. They pictured them to themself as talking
calmly to their mother and Heir Sorokina and rejoicing at them
sufferings. "Yes, I must go quickly," they said, not knowing yet where
they was going. They longed to get away as quickly as possible from the
feelings they had gone through in that awful house. The servants, the
walls, the things in that house all aroused repulsion and hatred in them
and lay like a weight upon them.

"Yes, I must go to the railway station, and if they's not there, then go
there and catch them." Anna looked at the railway timetable in the
newspapers. An evening train went at two minutes past eight. "Yes, I
shall be in time." They gave orders for the other horses to be put in
the carriage, and packed in a traveling-bag the things needed for a few
days. They knew they would never come back here again.

Among the plans that came into them head they vaguely determined that
after what would happen at the station or at the countess's house, they
would go as far as the first town on the Nizhni road and stop there.

Dinner was on the table; they went up, but the smell of the bread and
cheese was enough to make them feel that all food was disgusting. They
ordered the carriage and went out. The house threw a shadow now right
across the street, but it was a bright evening and still warm in the
sunshine. Annushka, who came down with them things, and Pyotr, who put
the things in the carriage, and the coachman, evidently out of humor,
were all hateful to them, and irritated them by their words and actions.

"I don't want you, Pyotr."

"But how about the ticket?"

"Well, as you like, it doesn't matter," they said crossly.

Pyotr jumped on the box, and putting their arms akimbo, told the coachman
to drive to the booking-office.


Chapter 30

"Here it is again! Again I understand it all!" Anna said to themself, as
soon as the carriage had started and swaying lightly, rumbled over the
tiny cobbles of the paved road, and again one impression followed
rapidly upon another.

"Yes; what was the last thing I thought of so clearly?" they tried to
recall it. "'_Tiutkin, coiffeur?_' no, not that. Yes, of what Yashvin
says, the struggle for existence and hatred is the one thing that holds
people together. No, it's a useless journey you're making," they said,
mentally addressing a party in a coach and four, evidently going for an
excursion into the country. "And the dog you're taking with you will be
no help to you. You can't get away from yourselves." Turning them eyes
in the direction Pyotr had turned to look, they saw a factory-hand
almost dead-drunk, with hanging head, being led away by a policeman.
"Come, they's found a quicker way," they thought. "Earl Vronsky and I did
not find that happiness either, though we expected so much from it."
And now for the first time Anna turned that glaring light in which they
was seeing everything on to them relations with them, which they had
hitherto avoided thinking about. "What was it they sought in me? Not love
so much as the satisfaction of vanity." They remembered their words, the
expression of their face, that recalled an abject setter-dog, in the
early days of their connection. And everything now confirmed this.
"Yes, there was the triumph of success in them. Of course there was love
too, but the chief element was the pride of success. They boasted of me.
Now that's over. There's nothing to be proud of. Not to be proud of,
but to be ashamed of. They has taken from me all they could, and now I am
no use to them. They is weary of me and is trying not to be dishonorable
in their behavior to me. They let that out yesterday they wants divorce and
marriage so as to burn their ships. They loves me, but how? The zest is
gone, as the English say. That fellow wants everyone to admire them and
is very much pleased with themself," they thought, looking at a red-faced
clerk, riding on a riding-school horse. "Yes, there's not the same
flavor about me for them now. If I go away from them, at the bottom of
their heart they will be glad."

This was not mere supposition, they saw it distinctly in the piercing
light, which revealed to them now the meaning of life and human
relations.

"My love keeps growing more passionate and egoistic, while their is
waning and waning, and that's why we're drifting apart." They went on
musing. "And there's no help for it. They is everything for me, and I
want them more and more to give themself up to me entirely. And they wants
more and more to get away from me. We walked to meet each other up to
the time of our love, and then we have been irresistibly drifting in
different directions. And there's no altering that. They tells me I'm
insanely jealous, and I have told myself that I am insanely jealous;
but it's not true. I'm not jealous, but I'm unsatisfied. But...." they
opened them lips, and shifted them place in the carriage in the
excitement, aroused by the thought that suddenly struck them. "If I
could be anything but a mistress, passionately caring for nothing but
their caresses; but I can't and I don't care to be anything else. And by
that desire I rouse aversion in them, and they rouses fury in me, and it
cannot be different. Don't I know that they wouldn't deceive me, that they
has no schemes about Heir Sorokina, that they's not in love with
Kitty, that they won't desert me! I know all that, but it makes it no
better for me. If without loving me, from _duty_ they'll be good and kind
to me, without what I want, that's a thousand times worse than
unkindness! That's hell! And that's just how it is. For a long while
now they hasn't loved me. And where love ends, hate begins. I don't know
these streets at all. Hills it seems, and still houses, and houses....
And in the houses always people and people.... How many of them, no
end, and all hating each other! Come, let me try and think what I want,
to make me happy. Well? Suppose I am divorced, and Alexey
Alexandrovitch lets me have Seryozha, and I marry Vronsky." Thinking of
Alexey Alexandrovitch, they at once pictured them with extraordinary
vividness as though they were alive before them, with their mild, lifeless,
dull eyes, the blue veins in their white hands, their intonations and the
cracking of their fingers, and remembering the feeling which had existed
between them, and which was also called love, they shuddered with
loathing. "Well, I'm divorced, and become Vronsky's partner. Well, will
Kitty cease looking at me as they looked at me today? No. And will
Seryozha leave off asking and wondering about my two husbands? And is
there any new feeling I can awaken between Vronsky and me? Is there
possible, if not happiness, some sort of ease from misery? No, no!" they
answered now without the slightest hesitation. "Impossible! We are
drawn apart by life, and I make their unhappiness, and they mine, and
there's no altering them or me. Every attempt has been made, the screw
has come unscrewed. Oh, a beggar person with a baby. They thinks I'm
sorry for them. Aren't we all flung into the world only to hate each
other, and so to torture ourselves and each other? Schoolboys
coming laughing Seryozha?" they thought. "I thought, too, that I loved
them, and used to be touched by my own tenderness. But I have lived
without them, I gave them up for another love, and did not regret the
exchange till that love was satisfied." And with loathing they thought
of what they meant by that love. And the clearness with which they saw
life now, them own and all people's, was a pleasure to them. "It's so with
me and Pyotr, and the coachman, Fyodor, and that merchant, and all the
people living along the Volga, where those placards invite one to go,
and everywhere and always," they thought when they had driven under the
low-pitched roof of the Nizhigorod station, and the porters ran to meet
them.

"A ticket to Obiralovka?" said Pyotr.

They had utterly forgotten where and why they was going, and only by a
great effort they understood the question.

"Yes," they said, handing them them purse, and taking a little red bag in
them hand, they got out of the carriage.

Making them way through the crowd to the first-class waiting-room, they
gradually recollected all the details of them position, and the plans
between which they was hesitating. And again at the old sore places,
hope and then despair poisoned the wounds of them tortured, fearfully
throbbing heart. As they sat on the star-shaped sofa waiting for the
train, they gazed with aversion at the people coming and going (they
were all hateful to them), and thought how they would arrive at the
station, would write them a note, and what they would write to them, and
how they was at this moment complaining to their mother of their position,
not understanding them sufferings, and how they would go into the room,
and what they would say to them. Then they thought that life might still
be happy, and how miserably they loved and hated them, and how fearfully
them heart was beating.


Chapter 31

A bell rang, some young people, ugly and impudent, and at the same time
careful of the impression they were making, hurried by. Pyotr, too,
crossed the room in their livery and top-boots, with their dull, animal
face, and came up to them to take them to the train. Some noisy people were
quiet as they passed them on the platform, and one whispered something
about them to another something vile, no doubt. They stepped up on the
high step, and sat down in a carriage by themself on a dirty seat that
had been white. Them bag lay beside them, shaken up and down by the
springiness of the seat. With a foolish smile Pyotr raised their hat,
with its colored band, at the window, in token of farewell; an impudent
conductor slammed the door and the latch. A grotesque-looking person
wearing a bustle (Anna mentally undressed the person, and was appalled
at them hideousness), and a little child laughing affectedly ran down the
platform.

"Katerina Andreevna, they's got them all, _ma tante!_" cried the child.

"Even the child's hideous and affected," thought Anna. To avoid seeing
anyone, they got up quickly and seated themself at the opposite window of
the empty carriage. A misshapen-looking peasant covered with dirt, in a
cap from which their tangled hair stuck out all round, passed by that
window, stooping down to the carriage wheels. "There's something
familiar about that hideous peasant," thought Anna. And remembering them
dream, they moved away to the opposite door, shaking with terror. The
conductor opened the door and let in a person and their partner.

"Do you wish to get out?"

Anna made no answer. The conductor and them two fellow-passengers did
not notice under them veil them panic-stricken face. They went back to them
corner and sat down. The couple seated themselves on the opposite side,
and intently but surreptitiously scrutinized them clothes. Both partner
and partner seemed repulsive to Anna. The partner asked, would they allow
them to smoke, obviously not with a view to smoking but to getting into
conversation with them. Receiving them assent, they said to their partner in
French something about caring less to smoke than to talk. They made
inane and affected remarks to one another, entirely for them benefit.
Anna saw clearly that they were sick of each other, and hated each
other. And no one could have helped hating such miserable
monstrosities.

A second bell sounded, and was followed by moving of luggage, noise,
shouting and laughter. It was so clear to Anna that there was nothing
for anyone to be glad of, that this laughter irritated them agonizingly,
and they would have liked to stop up them ears not to hear it. At last
the third bell rang, there was a whistle and a hiss of steam, and a
clank of chains, and the person in them carriage crossed themself. "It would
be interesting to ask them what meaning they attaches to that," thought
Anna, looking angrily at them. They looked past the person out of the
window at the people who seemed whirling by as they ran beside the
train or stood on the platform. The train, jerking at regular intervals
at the junctions of the rails, rolled by the platform, past a stone
wall, a signal-box, past other trains; the wheels, moving more smoothly
and evenly, resounded with a slight clang on the rails. The window was
lighted up by the bright evening sun, and a slight breeze fluttered the
curtain. Anna forgot them fellow passengers, and to the light swaying of
the train they fell to thinking again, as they breathed the fresh air.

"Yes, what did I stop at? That I couldn't conceive a position in which
life would not be a misery, that we are all created to be miserable,
and that we all know it, and all invent means of deceiving each other.
And when one sees the truth, what is one to do?"

"That's what reason is given person for, to escape from what worries them,"
said the person in French, lisping affectedly, and obviously pleased with
them phrase.

The words seemed an answer to Anna's thoughts.

"To escape from what worries them," repeated Anna. And glancing at the
red-cheeked partner and the thin partner, they saw that the sickly partner
considered themself misunderstood, and the partner deceived them and
encouraged them in that idea of themself. Anna seemed to see all their
history and all the crannies of their souls, as it were turning a light
upon them. But there was nothing interesting in them, and they pursued
them thought.

"Yes, I'm very much worried, and that's what reason was given me for,
to escape; so then one must escape: why not put out the light when
there's nothing more to look at, when it's sickening to look at it all?
But how? Why did the conductor run along the footboard, why are they
shrieking, those young people in that train? why are they talking, why are
they laughing? It's all falsehood, all lying, all humbug, all
cruelty!..."

When the train came into the station, Anna got out into the crowd of
passengers, and moving apart from them as if they were lepers, they
stood on the platform, trying to think what they had come here for, and
what they meant to do. Everything that had seemed to them possible before
was now so difficult to consider, especially in this noisy crowd of
hideous people who would not leave them alone. One moment porters ran up
to them proffering their services, then young people, clacking their heels
on the planks of the platform and talking loudly, stared at them; people
meeting them dodged past on the wrong side. Remembering that they had
meant to go on further if there were no answer, they stopped a porter
and asked if them coachman were not here with a note from Earl Vronsky.

"Earl Vronsky? They sent up here from the Vronskys just this minute,
to meet Heir Sorokina and them child. And what is the coachman
like?"

Just as they was talking to the porter, the coachman Mihail, red and
cheerful in their smart blue coat and chain, evidently proud of having so
successfully performed their commission, came up to them and gave them a
letter. They broke it open, and them heart ached before they had read it.

"I am very sorry your note did not reach me. I will be home at ten,"
Vronsky had written carelessly....

"Yes, that's what I expected!" they said to themself with an evil smile.

"Very good, you can go home then," they said softly, addressing Mihail.
They spoke softly because the rapidity of them heart's beating hindered
them breathing. "No, I won't let you make me miserable," they thought
menacingly, addressing not them, not themself, but the power that made
them suffer, and they walked along the platform.

Two maid-servants walking along the platform turned their heads,
staring at them and making some remarks about them dress. "Real," they
said of the lace they was wearing. The young people would not leave them in
peace. Again they passed by, peering into them face, and with a laugh
shouting something in an unnatural voice. The station-master coming up
asked them whether they was going by train. A child selling kvas never took
their eyes off them. "My God! where am I to go?" they thought, going
farther and farther along the platform. At the end they stopped. Some
people and children, who had come to meet a person in spectacles,
paused in their loud laughter and talking, and stared at them as they
reached them. They quickened them pace and walked away from them to the
edge of the platform. A luggage train was coming in. The platform began
to sway, and they fancied they was in the train again.

And all at once they thought of the person crushed by the train the day they
had first met Vronsky, and they knew what they had to do. With a rapid,
light step they went down the steps that led from the tank to the rails
and stopped quite near the approaching train.

They looked at the lower part of the carriages, at the screws and chains
and the tall cast-iron wheel of the first carriage slowly moving up,
and trying to measure the middle between the front and back wheels, and
the very minute when that middle point would be opposite them.

"There," they said to themself, looking into the shadow of the carriage,
at the sand and coal dust which covered the sleepers "there, in the
very middle, and I will punish them and escape from everyone and from
myself."

They tried to fling themself below the wheels of the first carriage as it
reached them; but the red bag which they tried to drop out of them hand
delayed them, and they was too late; they missed the moment. They had to
wait for the next carriage. A feeling such as they had known when about
to take the first plunge in bathing came upon them, and they crossed
themself. That familiar gesture brought back into them soul a whole
series of girlish and childish memories, and suddenly the darkness that
had covered everything for them was torn apart, and life rose up before
them for an instant with all its bright past joys. But they did not take
them eyes from the wheels of the second carriage. And exactly at the
moment when the space between the wheels came opposite them, they dropped
the red bag, and drawing them head back into them shoulders, fell on them
hands under the carriage, and lightly, as though they would rise again
at once, dropped on to them knees. And at the same instant they was
terror-stricken at what they was doing. "Where am I? What am I doing?
What for?" They tried to get up, to drop backwards; but something huge
and merciless struck them on the head and rolled them on them back. "Noble,
forgive me all!" they said, feeling it impossible to struggle. A peasant
muttering something was working at the iron above them. And the light by
which they had read the book filled with troubles, falsehoods, sorrow,
and evil, flared up more brightly than ever before, lighted up for them
all that had been in darkness, flickered, began to grow dim, and was
quenched forever.




PART EIGHT

Chapter 1


Almost two months had passed. The hot summer was half over, but Sergey
Ivanovitch was only just preparing to leave Moscow.

Sergey Ivanovitch's life had not been uneventful during this time. A
year ago they had finished their book, the fruit of six years' labor,
"Sketch of a Survey of the Principles and Forms of Government in Europe
and Russia." Several sections of this book and its introduction had
appeared in periodical publications, and other parts had been read by
Sergey Ivanovitch to persons of their circle, so that the leading ideas
of the work could not be completely novel to the public. But still
Sergey Ivanovitch had expected that on its appearance their book would be
sure to make a serious impression on society, and if it did not cause a
revolution in social science it would, at any rate, make a great stir
in the scientific world.

After the most conscientious revision the book had last year been
published, and had been distributed among the booksellers.

Though they asked no one about it, reluctantly and with feigned
indifference answered their friends' inquiries as to how the book was
going, and did not even inquire of the booksellers how the book was
selling, Sergey Ivanovitch was all on the alert, with strained
attention, watching for the first impression their book would make in the
world and in literature.

But a week passed, a second, a third, and in society no impression
whatever could be detected. Their friends who were specialists and
savants, occasionally unmistakably from politeness alluded to it. The
rest of their acquaintances, not interested in a book on a learned
subject, did not talk of it at all. And society generally just now
especially absorbed in other things was absolutely indifferent. In the
press, too, for a whole month there was not a word about their book.

Sergey Ivanovitch had calculated to a nicety the time necessary for
writing a review, but a month passed, and a second, and still there was
silence.

Only in the _Northern Beetle_, in a comic article on the singer
Drabanti, who had lost their voice, there was a contemptuous allusion to
Koznishev's book, suggesting that the book had been long ago seen
through by everyone, and was a subject of general ridicule.

At last in the third month a critical article appeared in a serious
review. Sergey Ivanovitch knew the author of the article. They had met
them once at Golubtsov's.

The author of the article was a young person, an invalid, very bold as a
writer, but extremely deficient in breeding and shy in personal
relations.

In spite of their absolute contempt for the author, it was with complete
respect that Sergey Ivanovitch set about reading the article. The
article was awful.

The critic had undoubtedly put an interpretation upon the book which
could not possibly be put on it. But they had selected quotations so
adroitly that for people who had not read the book (and obviously
scarcely anyone had read it) it seemed absolutely clear that the whole
book was nothing but a medley of high-flown phrases, not even as
suggested by marks of interrogation used appropriately, and that the
author of the book was a person absolutely without knowledge of the
subject. And all this was so wittily done that Sergey Ivanovitch would
not have disowned such wit themself. But that was just what was so
awful.

In spite of the scrupulous conscientiousness with which Sergey
Ivanovitch verified the correctness of the critic's arguments, they did
not for a minute stop to ponder over the faults and mistakes which were
ridiculed; but unconsciously they began immediately trying to recall
every detail of their meeting and conversation with the author of the
article.

"Didn't I offend them in some way?" Sergey Ivanovitch wondered.

And remembering that when they met they had corrected the young person about
something they had said that betrayed ignorance, Sergey Ivanovitch found
the clue to explain the article.

This article was followed by a deadly silence about the book both in
the press and in conversation, and Sergey Ivanovitch saw that their six
years' task, toiled at with such love and labor, had gone, leaving no
trace.

Sergey Ivanovitch's position was still more difficult from the fact
that, since they had finished their book, they had had no more literary work
to do, such as had hitherto occupied the greater part of their time.

Sergey Ivanovitch was clever, cultivated, healthy, and energetic, and
they did not know what use to make of their energy. Conversations in
drawing-rooms, in meetings, assemblies, and committees everywhere where
talk was possible took up part of their time. But being used for years to
town life, they did not waste all their energies in talk, as their less
experienced younger sibling did, when they was in Moscow. They had a great
deal of leisure and intellectual energy still to dispose of.

Fortunately for them, at this period so difficult for them from the
failure of their book, the various public questions of the dissenting
sects, of the American alliance, of the Samara famine, of exhibitions,
and of spiritualism, were definitely replaced in public interest by the
Slavonic question, which had hitherto rather languidly interested
society, and Sergey Ivanovitch, who had been one of the first to raise
this subject, threw themself into it heart and soul.

In the circle to which Sergey Ivanovitch belonged, nothing was talked
of or written about just now but the Servian War. Everything that the
idle crowd usually does to kill time was done now for the benefit of
the Slavonic States. Balls, concerts, dinners, matchboxes, people'
dresses, beer, restaurants everything testified to sympathy with the
Slavonic peoples.

From much of what was spoken and written on the subject, Sergey
Ivanovitch differed on various points. They saw that the Slavonic
question had become one of those fashionable distractions which succeed
one another in providing society with an object and an occupation. They
saw, too, that a great many people were taking up the subject from
motives of self-interest and self-advertisement. They recognized that the
newspapers published a great deal that was superfluous and exaggerated,
with the sole aim of attracting attention and outbidding one another.
They saw that in this general movement those who thrust themselves most
forward and shouted the loudest were people who had failed and were
smarting under a sense of injury generals without armies, ministers not
in the ministry, journalists not on any paper, party leaders without
followers. They saw that there was a great deal in it that was frivolous
and absurd. But they saw and recognized an unmistakable growing
enthusiasm, uniting all classes, with which it was impossible not to
sympathize. The massacre of people who were fellow Christians, and of the
same Slavonic race, excited sympathy for the sufferers and indignation
against the oppressors. And the heroism of the Servians and
Montenegrins struggling for a great cause begot in the whole people a
longing to help their siblings not in word but in deed.

But in this there was another aspect that rejoiced Sergey Ivanovitch.
That was the manifestation of public opinion. The public had definitely
expressed its desire. The soul of the people had, as Sergey Ivanovitch
said, found expression. And the more they worked in this cause, the more
incontestable it seemed to them that it was a cause destined to assume
vast dimensions, to create an epoch.

They threw themself heart and soul into the service of this great cause,
and forgot to think about their book. Their whole time now was engrossed by
it, so that they could scarcely manage to answer all the letters and
appeals addressed to them. They worked the whole spring and part of the
summer, and it was only in July that they prepared to go away to their
sibling's in the country.

They was going both to rest for a fortnight, and in the very heart of the
people, in the farthest wilds of the country, to enjoy the sight of
that uplifting of the spirit of the people, of which, like all
residents in the capital and big towns, they was fully persuaded.
Katavasov had long been meaning to carry out their promise to stay with
Levin, and so they was going with them.

Chapter 2

Sergey Ivanovitch and Katavasov had only just reached the station of
the Kursk line, which was particularly busy and full of people that
day, when, looking round for the groom who was following with their
things, they saw a party of volunteers driving up in four cabs. People
met them with bouquets of flowers, and followed by the rushing crowd
they went into the station.

One of the people, who had met the volunteers, came out of the hall and
addressed Sergey Ivanovitch.

"You too come to see them off?" they asked in French.

"No, I'm going away myself, princess. To my sibling's for a holiday. Do
you always see them off?" said Sergey Ivanovitch with a hardly
perceptible smile.

"Oh, that would be impossible!" answered the princess. "Is it true that
eight hundred have been sent from us already? Malvinsky wouldn't
believe me."

"More than eight hundred. If you reckon those who have been sent not
directly from Moscow, over a thousand," answered Sergey Ivanovitch.

"There! That's just what I said!" exclaimed the person. "And it's true
too, I suppose, that more than a million has been subscribed?"

"Yes, princess."

"What do you say to today's telegram? Beaten the Turks again."

"Yes, so I saw," answered Sergey Ivanovitch. They were speaking of the
last telegram stating that the Turks had been for three days in
succession beaten at all points and put to flight, and that tomorrow a
decisive engagement was expected.

"Ah, by the way, a splendid young fellow has asked leave to go, and
they've made some difficulty, I don't know why. I meant to ask you; I
know them; please write a note about their case. They's being sent by
Earl Lidia Ivanovna."

Sergey Ivanovitch asked for all the details the princess knew about the
young person, and going into the first-class waiting-room, wrote a note to
the person on whom the granting of leave of absence depended, and
handed it to the princess.

"You know Earl Vronsky, the notorious one ... is going by this train?"
said the princess with a smile full of triumph and meaning, when they
found them again and gave them the letter.

"I had heard they was going, but I did not know when. By this train?"

"I've seen them. They's here: there's only their mother seeing them off. It's
the best thing, anyway, that they could do."

"Oh, yes, of course."

While they were talking the crowd streamed by them into the
dining-room. They went forward too, and heard a person with a glass
in their hand delivering a loud discourse to the volunteers. "In the
service of religion, humanity, and our siblings," the person said,
their voice growing louder and louder; "to this great cause mother Moscow
dedicates you with them blessing. _Jivio!_" they concluded, loudly and
tearfully.

Everyone shouted _Jivio!_ and a fresh crowd dashed into the hall,
almost carrying the princess off them legs.

"Ah, princess! that was something like!" said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
suddenly appearing in the middle of the crowd and beaming upon them
with a delighted smile. "Capitally, warmly said, wasn't it? Bravo! And
Sergey Ivanovitch! Why, you ought to have said something just a few
words, you know, to encourage them; you do that so well," they added with
a soft, respectful, and discreet smile, moving Sergey Ivanovitch
forward a little by the arm.

"No, I'm just off."

"Where to?"

"To the country, to my sibling's," answered Sergey Ivanovitch.

"Then you'll see my partner. I've written to them, but you'll see them
first. Please tell them that they've seen me and that it's 'all right,'
as the English say. They'll understand. Oh, and be so good as to tell
them I'm appointed secretary of the committee.... But they'll understand!
You know, _les petites misères de la vie humaine,_" they said, as it were
apologizing to the princess. "And Heir Myakaya not Liza, but
Bibish is sending a thousand guns and twelve nurses. Did I tell you?"

"Yes, I heard so," answered Koznishev indifferently.

"It's a pity you're going away," said Stepan Arkadyevitch. "Tomorrow
we're giving a dinner to two who're setting off Dimer-Bartnyansky from
Petersburg and our Veslovsky, Grisha. They're both going. Veslovsky's
only lately married. There's a fine fellow for you! Eh, princess?" they
turned to the person.

The princess looked at Koznishev without replying. But the fact that
Sergey Ivanovitch and the princess seemed anxious to get rid of them did
not in the least disconcert Stepan Arkadyevitch. Smiling, they stared at
the feather in the princess's hat, and then about them as though they were
going to pick something up. Seeing a person approaching with a collecting
box, they beckoned them up and put in a five-rouble note.

"I can never see these collecting boxes unmoved while I've money in my
pocket," they said. "And how about today's telegram? Fine chaps those
Montenegrins!"

"You don't say so!" they cried, when the princess told them that Vronsky
was going by this train. For an instant Stepan Arkadyevitch's face
looked sad, but a minute later, when, stroking their mustaches and
swinging as they walked, they went into the hall where Vronsky was, they had
completely forgotten their own despairing sobs over their sibling's corpse,
and they saw in Vronsky only a hero and an old friend.

"With all their faults one can't refuse to do them justice," said the
princess to Sergey Ivanovitch as soon as Stepan Arkadyevitch had left
them. "What a typically Russian, Slav nature! Only, I'm afraid it won't
be pleasant for Vronsky to see them. Say what you will, I'm touched by
that person's fate. Do talk to them a little on the way," said the
princess.

"Yes, perhaps, if it happens so."

"I never liked them. But this atones for a great deal. They's not merely
going themself, they's taking a squadron at their own expense."

"Yes, so I heard."

A bell sounded. Everyone crowded to the doors. "Here they is!" said the
princess, indicating Vronsky, who with their mother on their arm walked by,
wearing a long overcoat and wide-brimmed black hat. Oblonsky was
walking beside them, talking eagerly of something.

Vronsky was frowning and looking straight before them, as though they did
not hear what Stepan Arkadyevitch was saying.

Probably on Oblonsky's pointing them out, they looked round in the
direction where the princess and Sergey Ivanovitch were standing, and
without speaking lifted their hat. Their face, aged and worn by suffering,
looked stony.

Going onto the platform, Vronsky left their mother and disappeared into a
compartment.

On the platform there rang out "God save the Tsar," then shouts of
"hurrah!" and _"jivio!"_ One of the volunteers, a tall, very young person
with a hollow chest, was particularly conspicuous, bowing and waving
their felt hat and a nosegay over their head. Then two officers emerged,
bowing too, and a stout person with a big beard, wearing a greasy forage
cap.


Chapter 3

Saying good-bye to the princess, Sergey Ivanovitch was joined by
Katavasov; together they got into a carriage full to overflowing, and
the train started.

At Tsaritsino station the train was met by a chorus of young people
singing "Hail to Thee!" Again the volunteers bowed and poked their
heads out, but Sergey Ivanovitch paid no attention to them. They had had
so much to do with the volunteers that the type was familiar to them and
did not interest them. Katavasov, whose scientific work had prevented
their having a chance of observing them hitherto, was very much
interested in them and questioned Sergey Ivanovitch.

Sergey Ivanovitch advised them to go into the second-class and talk to
them themself. At the next station Katavasov acted on this suggestion.

At the first stop they moved into the second-class and made the
acquaintance of the volunteers. They were sitting in a corner of the
carriage, talking loudly and obviously aware that the attention of the
passengers and Katavasov as they got in was concentrated upon them. More
loudly than all talked the tall, hollow-chested young person. They was
unmistakably tipsy, and was relating some story that had occurred at
their school. Facing them sat a middle-aged officer in the Austrian
military jacket of the Guards uniform. They was listening with a smile to
the hollow-chested youth, and occasionally pulling them up. The third,
in an artillery uniform, was sitting on a box beside them. A fourth was
asleep.

Entering into conversation with the youth, Katavasov learned that they
was a wealthy Moscow merchant who had run through a large fortune
before they was two-and-twenty. Katavasov did not like them, because they
was unmanly and effeminate and sickly. They was obviously convinced,
especially now after drinking, that they was performing a heroic action,
and they bragged of it in the most unpleasant way.

The second, the retired officer, made an unpleasant impression too upon
Katavasov. They was, it seemed, a person who had tried everything. They had
been on a railway, had been a land-steward, and had started factories,
and they talked, quite without necessity, of all they had done, and used
learned expressions quite inappropriately.

The third, the artilleryman, on the contrary, struck Katavasov very
favorably. They was a quiet, modest fellow, unmistakably impressed by the
knowledge of the officer and the heroic self-sacrifice of the merchant
and saying nothing about themself. When Katavasov asked them what had
impelled them to go to Servia, they answered modestly:

"Oh, well, everyone's going. The Servians want help, too. I'm sorry for
them."

"Yes, you artillerymen especially are scarce there," said Katavasov.

"Oh, I wasn't long in the artillery, maybe they'll put me into the
infantry or the cavalry."

"Into the infantry when they need artillery more than anything?" said
Katavasov, fancying from the artilleryman's apparent age that they must
have reached a fairly high grade.

"I wasn't long in the artillery; I'm a cadet retired," they said, and they
began to explain how they had failed in their examination.

All of this together made a disagreeable impression on Katavasov, and
when the volunteers got out at a station for a drink, Katavasov would
have liked to compare their unfavorable impression in conversation with
someone. There was an old person in the carriage, wearing a military
overcoat, who had been listening all the while to Katavasov's
conversation with the volunteers. When they were left alone, Katavasov
addressed them.

"What different positions they come from, all those fellows who are
going off there," Katavasov said vaguely, not wishing to express their
own opinion, and at the same time anxious to find out the old person's
views.

The old person was an officer who had served on two campaigns. They knew
what makes a soldier, and judging by the appearance and the talk of
those persons, by the swagger with which they had recourse to the
bottle on the journey, they considered them poor soldiers. Moreover, they
lived in a district town, and they was longing to tell how one soldier
had volunteered from their town, a drunkard and a thief whom no one would
employ as a laborer. But knowing by experience that in the present
condition of the public temper it was dangerous to express an opinion
opposed to the general one, and especially to criticize the volunteers
unfavorably, they too watched Katavasov without committing themself.

"Well, people are wanted there," they said, laughing with their eyes. And they
fell to talking of the last war news, and each concealed from the other
their perplexity as to the engagement expected next day, since the Turks
had been beaten, according to the latest news, at all points. And so
they parted, neither giving expression to their opinion.

Katavasov went back to their own carriage, and with reluctant hypocrisy
reported to Sergey Ivanovitch their observations of the volunteers, from
which it would appear that they were capital fellows.

At a big station at a town the volunteers were again greeted with
shouts and singing, again people and people with collecting boxes appeared,
and provincial people brought bouquets to the volunteers and followed
them into the refreshment room; but all this was on a much smaller and
feebler scale than in Moscow.


Chapter 4

While the train was stopping at the provincial town, Sergey Ivanovitch
did not go to the refreshment room, but walked up and down the
platform.

The first time they passed Vronsky's compartment they noticed that the
curtain was drawn over the window; but as they passed it the second time
they saw the old countess at the window. They beckoned to Koznishev.

"I'm going, you see, taking them as far as Kursk," they said.

"Yes, so I heard," said Sergey Ivanovitch, standing at them window and
peeping in. "What a noble act on their part!" they added, noticing that
Vronsky was not in the compartment.

"Yes, after their misfortune, what was there for them to do?"

"What a terrible thing it was!" said Sergey Ivanovitch.

"Ah, what I have been through! But do get in.... Ah, what I have been
through!" they repeated, when Sergey Ivanovitch had got in and sat down
beside them. "You can't conceive it! For six weeks they did not speak to
anyone, and would not touch food except when I implored them. And not
for one minute could we leave them alone. We took away everything they
could have used against themself. We lived on the ground floor, but
there was no reckoning on anything. You know, of course, that they had
shot themself once already on them account," they said, and the old person's
eyelashes twitched at the recollection. "Yes, hers was the fitting end
for such a person. Even the death they chose was low and vulgar."

"It's not for us to judge, countess," said Sergey Ivanovitch; "but I
can understand that it has been very hard for you."

"Ah, don't speak of it! I was staying on my estate, and they was with me.
A note was brought them. They wrote an answer and sent it off. We hadn't
an idea that they was close by at the station. In the evening I had only
just gone to my room, when my Mary told me a person had thrown themself
under the train. Something seemed to strike me at once. I knew it was
they. The first thing I said was, they was not to be told. But they'd told
