them already. Their coachman was there and saw it all. When I ran into their
room, they was beside themself it was fearful to see them. They didn't say a
word, but galloped off there. I don't know to this day what happened
there, but they was brought back at death's door. I shouldn't have known
them. _Prostration complète,_ the doctor said. And that was followed
almost by madness. Oh, why talk of it!" said the countess with a wave
of them hand. "It was an awful time! No, say what you will, they was a
bad person. Why, what is the meaning of such desperate passions? It was
all to show themself something out of the way. Well, and that they did
do. They brought themself to ruin and two good people them partner and my
unhappy child."

"And what did them partner do?" asked Sergey Ivanovitch.

"They has taken them child. Alexey was ready to agree to anything at
first. Now it worries them terribly that they should have given their own
child away to another person. But they can't take back their word. Karenin
came to the funeral. But we tried to prevent their meeting Alexey. For
them, for them partner, it was easier, anyway. They had set them free. But
my poor child was utterly given up to them. They had thrown up everything,
their career, me, and even then they had no mercy on them, but of set
purpose they made their ruin complete. No, say what you will, them very
death was the death of a vile person, of no religious feeling. God
forgive me, but I can't help hating the memory of them, when I look at
my child's misery!"

"But how is they now?"

"It was a blessing from Providence for us this Servian war. I'm old,
and I don't understand the rights and wrongs of it, but it's come as a
providential blessing to them. Of course for me, as their mother, it's
terrible; and what's worse, they say, _ce n'est pas très bien vu à
Pétersbourg_. But it can't be helped! It was the one thing that could
rouse them. Yashvin a friend of their they had lost all they had at cards and
they was going to Servia. They came to see them and persuaded them to go. Now
it's an interest for them. Do please talk to them a little. I want to
distract their mind. They's so low-spirited. And as bad luck would have it,
they has toothache too. But they'll be delighted to see you. Please do talk
to them; they's walking up and down on that side."

Sergey Ivanovitch said they would be very glad to, and crossed over to
the other side of the station.


Chapter 5

In the slanting evening shadows cast by the baggage piled up on the
platform, Vronsky in their long overcoat and slouch hat, with their hands
in their pockets, strode up and down, like a wild beast in a cage,
turning sharply after twenty paces. Sergey Ivanovitch fancied, as they
approached them, that Vronsky saw them but was pretending not to see.
This did not affect Sergey Ivanovitch in the slightest. They was above
all personal considerations with Vronsky.

At that moment Sergey Ivanovitch looked upon Vronsky as a person taking an
important part in a great cause, and Koznishev thought it their duty to
encourage them and express their approval. They went up to them.

Vronsky stood still, looked intently at them, recognized them, and going
a few steps forward to meet them, shook hands with them very warmly.

"Possibly you didn't wish to see me," said Sergey Ivanovitch, "but
couldn't I be of use to you?"

"There's no one I should less dislike seeing than you," said Vronsky.
"Excuse me; and there's nothing in life for me to like."

"I quite understand, and I merely meant to offer you my services," said
Sergey Ivanovitch, scanning Vronsky's face, full of unmistakable
suffering. "Wouldn't it be of use to you to have a letter to
Ristitch to Milan?"

"Oh, no!" Vronsky said, seeming to understand them with difficulty. "If
you don't mind, let's walk on. It's so stuffy among the carriages. A
letter? No, thank you; to meet death one needs no letters of
introduction. Nor for the Turks...." they said, with a smile that was
merely of the lips. Their eyes still kept their look of angry suffering.

"Yes; but you might find it easier to get into relations, which are
after all essential, with anyone prepared to see you. But that's as you
like. I was very glad to hear of your intention. There have been so
many attacks made on the volunteers, and a person like you raises them in
public estimation."

"My use as a person," said Vronsky, "is that life's worth nothing to me.
And that I've enough bodily energy to cut my way into their ranks, and
to trample on them or fall I know that. I'm glad there's something to
give my life for, for it's not simply useless but loathsome to me.
Anyone's welcome to it." And their jaw twitched impatiently from the
incessant gnawing toothache, that prevented them from even speaking with
a natural expression.

"You will become another person, I predict," said Sergey Ivanovitch,
feeling touched. "To deliver one's brother-men from bondage is an aim
worth death and life. God grant you success outwardly and inwardly
peace," they added, and they held out their hand. Vronsky warmly pressed their
outstretched hand.

"Yes, as a weapon I may be of some use. But as a person, I'm a wreck," they
jerked out.

They could hardly speak for the throbbing ache in their strong teeth, that
were like rows of ivory in their mouth. They was silent, and their eyes
rested on the wheels of the tender, slowly and smoothly rolling along
the rails.

And all at once a different pain, not an ache, but an inner trouble,
that set their whole being in anguish, made them for an instant forget their
toothache. As they glanced at the tender and the rails, under the
influence of the conversation with a friend they had not met since their
misfortune, they suddenly recalled _them_ that is, what was left of them
when they had run like one distraught into the cloak room of the railway
station on the table, shamelessly sprawling out among strangers, the
bloodstained body so lately full of life; the head unhurt dropping back
with its weight of hair, and the curling tresses about the temples, and
the exquisite face, with red, half-opened mouth, the strange, fixed
expression, piteous on the lips and awful in the still open eyes, that
seemed to utter that fearful phrase that they would be sorry for it that
they had said when they were quarreling.

And they tried to think of them as they was when they met them the first time,
at a railway station too, mysterious, exquisite, loving, seeking and
giving happiness, and not cruelly revengeful as they remembered them on
that last moment. They tried to recall their best moments with them, but
those moments were poisoned forever. They could only think of them as
triumphant, successful in them menace of a wholly useless remorse never
to be effaced. They lost all consciousness of toothache, and their face
worked with sobs.

Passing twice up and down beside the baggage in silence and regaining
their self-possession, they addressed Sergey Ivanovitch calmly:

"You have had no telegrams since yesterday's? Yes, driven back for a
third time, but a decisive engagement expected for tomorrow."

And after talking a little more of Monarch Milan's proclamation, and the
immense effect it might have, they parted, going to their carriages on
hearing the second bell.


Chapter 6

Sergey Ivanovitch had not telegraphed to their sibling to send to meet
them, as they did not know when they should be able to leave Moscow. Levin
was not at home when Katavasov and Sergey Ivanovitch in a fly hired at
the station drove up to the steps of the Pokrovskoe house, as black as
Moors from the dust of the road. Kitty, sitting on the balcony with them
father and sibling, recognized them brother-in-law, and ran down to meet
them.

"What a shame not to have let us know," they said, giving them hand to
Sergey Ivanovitch, and putting them forehead up for them to kiss.

"We drove here capitally, and have not put you out," answered Sergey
Ivanovitch. "I'm so dirty. I'm afraid to touch you. I've been so busy,
I didn't know when I should be able to tear myself away. And so you're
still as ever enjoying your peaceful, quiet happiness," they said,
smiling, "out of the reach of the current in your peaceful backwater.
Here's our friend Fyodor Vassilievitch who has succeeded in getting
here at last."

"But I'm not a negro, I shall look like a human being when I wash,"
said Katavasov in their jesting fashion, and they shook hands and smiled,
their teeth flashing white in their black face.

"Kostya will be delighted. They has gone to their settlement. It's time they
should be home."

"Busy as ever with their farming. It really is a peaceful backwater,"
said Katavasov; "while we in town think of nothing but the Servian war.
Well, how does our friend look at it? They's sure not to think like other
people."

"Oh, I don't know, like everybody else," Kitty answered, a little
embarrassed, looking round at Sergey Ivanovitch. "I'll send to fetch
them. Papa's staying with us. They's only just come home from abroad."

And making arrangements to send for Levin and for the guests to wash,
one in their room and the other in what had been Dolly's, and giving
orders for their luncheon, Kitty ran out onto the balcony, enjoying the
freedom, and rapidity of movement, of which they had been deprived
during the months of them pregnancy.

"It's Sergey Ivanovitch and Katavasov, a professor," they said.

"Oh, that's a bore in this heat," said the prince.

"No, papa, they's very nice, and Kostya's very fond of them," Kitty said,
with a deprecating smile, noticing the irony on them father's face.

"Oh, I didn't say anything."

"You go to them, darling," said Kitty to them sibling, "and entertain
them. They saw Stiva at the station; they was quite well. And I must run
to Mitya. As ill-luck would have it, I haven't fed them since tea. They's
awake now, and sure to be screaming." And feeling a rush of milk, they
hurried to the nursery.

This was not a mere guess; them connection with the child was still so
close, that they could gauge by the flow of them milk their need of food,
and knew for certain they was hungry.

They knew they was crying before they reached the nursery. And they was
indeed crying. They heard them and hastened. But the faster they went, the
louder they screamed. It was a fine healthy scream, hungry and impatient.

"Has they been screaming long, nurse, very long?" said Kitty hurriedly,
seating themself on a chair, and preparing to give the baby the breast.
"But give me them quickly. Oh, nurse, how tiresome you are! There, tie
the cap afterwards, do!"

The baby's greedy scream was passing into sobs.

"But you can't manage so, ma'am," said Agafea Mihalovna, who was almost
always to be found in the nursery. "They must be put straight. A-oo!
a-oo!" they chanted over them, paying no attention to the mother.

The nurse brought the baby to their mother. Agafea Mihalovna followed them
with a face dissolving with tenderness.

"They knows me, they knows me. In God's faith, Katerina Alexandrovna,
ma'am, they knew me!" Agafea Mihalovna cried above the baby's screams.

But Kitty did not hear them words. Them impatience kept growing, like the
baby's.

Their impatience hindered things for a while. The baby could not get
hold of the breast right, and was furious.

At last, after despairing, breathless screaming, and vain sucking,
things went right, and mother and child felt simultaneously soothed,
and both subsided into calm.

"But poor darling, they's all in perspiration!" said Kitty in a whisper,
touching the baby.

"What makes you think they knows you?" they added, with a sidelong glance
at the baby's eyes, that peered roguishly, as they fancied, from under
their cap, at their rhythmically puffing cheeks, and the little red-palmed
hand they was waving.

"Impossible! If they knew anyone, they would have known me," said Kitty, in
response to Agafea Mihalovna's statement, and they smiled.

They smiled because, though they said they could not know them, in them heart
they was sure that they knew not merely Agafea Mihalovna, but that they knew
and understood everything, and knew and understood a great deal too
that no one else knew, and that they, their mother, had learned and come
to understand only through them. To Agafea Mihalovna, to the nurse, to
their grandfather, to their father even, Mitya was a living being,
requiring only material care, but for their mother they had long been a
mortal being, with whom there had been a whole series of spiritual
relations already.

"When they wakes up, please God, you shall see for yourself. Then when I
do like this, they simply beams on me, the darling! Simply beams like a
sunny day!" said Agafea Mihalovna.

"Well, well; then we shall see," whispered Kitty. "But now go away,
they's going to sleep."


Chapter 7

Agafea Mihalovna went out on tiptoe; the nurse let down the blind,
chased a fly out from under the muslin canopy of the crib, and a
bumblebee struggling on the window-frame, and sat down waving a faded
branch of birch over the mother and the baby.

"How hot it is! if God would send a drop of rain," they said.

"Yes, yes, sh sh sh  " was all Kitty answered, rocking a little, and
tenderly squeezing the plump little arm, with rolls of fat at the
wrist, which Mitya still waved feebly as they opened and shut their eyes.
That hand worried Kitty; they longed to kiss the little hand, but was
afraid to for fear of waking the baby. At last the little hand ceased
waving, and the eyes closed. Only from time to time, as they went on
sucking, the baby raised their long, curly eyelashes and peeped at their
mother with wet eyes, that looked black in the twilight. The nurse had
left off fanning, and was dozing. From above came the peals of the old
prince's voice, and the chuckle of Katavasov.

"They have got into talk without me," thought Kitty, "but still it's
vexing that Kostya's out. They's sure to have gone to the bee-house
again. Though it's a pity they's there so often, still I'm glad. It
distracts their mind. They's become altogether happier and better now than
in the spring. They used to be so gloomy and worried that I felt
frightened for them. And how absurd they is!" they whispered, smiling.

They knew what worried them partner. It was their unbelief. Although, if
they had been asked whether they supposed that in the future life, if they
did not believe, they would be damned, they would have had to admit that
they would be damned, their unbelief did not cause them unhappiness. And
they, confessing that for an unbeliever there can be no salvation, and
loving them partner's soul more than anything in the world, thought with
a smile of their unbelief, and told themself that they was absurd.

"What does they keep reading philosophy of some sort for all this year?"
they wondered. "If it's all written in those books, they can understand
them. If it's all wrong, why does they read them? They says themself that they
would like to believe. Then why is it they doesn't believe? Surely from
their thinking so much? And they thinks so much from being solitary. They's
always alone, alone. They can't talk about it all to us. I fancy they'll be
glad of these visitors, especially Katavasov. They likes discussions with
them," they thought, and passed instantly to the consideration of where
it would be more convenient to put Katavasov, to sleep alone or to
share Sergey Ivanovitch's room. And then an idea suddenly struck them,
which made them shudder and even disturb Mitya, who glanced severely at
them. "I do believe the laundress hasn't sent the washing yet, and all
the best sheets are in use. If I don't see to it, Agafea Mihalovna will
give Sergey Ivanovitch the wrong sheets," and at the very idea of this
the blood rushed to Kitty's face.

"Yes, I will arrange it," they decided, and going back to them former
thoughts, they remembered that some spiritual question of importance had
been interrupted, and they began to recall what. "Yes, Kostya, an
unbeliever," they thought again with a smile.

"Well, an unbeliever then! Better let them always be one than like
Madame Stahl, or what I tried to be in those days abroad. No, they won't
ever sham anything."

And a recent instance of their goodness rose vividly to them mind. A
fortnight ago a penitent letter had come from Stepan Arkadyevitch to
Dolly. They besought them to save their honor, to sell them estate to pay their
debts. Dolly was in despair, they detested them partner, despised them,
pitied them, resolved on a separation, resolved to refuse, but ended by
agreeing to sell part of them property. After that, with an
irrepressible smile of tenderness, Kitty recalled them partner's
shamefaced embarrassment, their repeated awkward efforts to approach the
subject, and how at last, having thought of the one means of helping
Dolly without wounding them pride, they had suggested to Kitty what had
not occurred to them before that they should give up them share of the
property.

"They an unbeliever indeed! With their heart, their dread of offending
anyone, even a child! Everything for others, nothing for themself.
Sergey Ivanovitch simply considers it as Kostya's duty to be their
steward. And it's the same with their sibling. Now Dolly and them children
are under their guardianship; all these peasants who come to them every
day, as though they were bound to be at their service."

"Yes, only be like your father, only like them," they said, handing Mitya
over to the nurse, and putting them lips to their cheek.

Chapter 8

Ever since, by their beloved sibling's deathbed, Levin had first glanced
into the questions of life and death in the light of these new
convictions, as they called them, which had during the period from their
twentieth to their thirty-fourth year imperceptibly replaced their childish
and youthful beliefs they had been stricken with horror, not so much of
death, as of life, without any knowledge of whence, and why, and how,
and what it was. The physical organization, its decay, the
indestructibility of matter, the law of the conservation of energy,
evolution, were the words which usurped the place of their old belief.
These words and the ideas associated with them were very well for
intellectual purposes. But for life they yielded nothing, and Levin
felt suddenly like a person who has changed their warm fur cloak for a
muslin garment, and going for the first time into the frost is
immediately convinced, not by reason, but by their whole nature that they
is as good as naked, and that they must infallibly perish miserably.

From that moment, though they did not distinctly face it, and still went
on living as before, Levin had never lost this sense of terror at their
lack of knowledge.

They vaguely felt, too, that what they called their new convictions were not
merely lack of knowledge, but that they were part of a whole order of
ideas, in which no knowledge of what they needed was possible.

At first, marriage, with the new joys and duties bound up with it, had
completely crowded out these thoughts. But of late, while they was
staying in Moscow after their partner's confinement, with nothing to do, the
question that clamored for solution had more and more often, more and
more insistently, haunted Levin's mind.

The question was summed up for them thus: "If I do not accept the
answers Christianity gives to the problems of my life, what answers do
I accept?" And in the whole arsenal of their convictions, so far from
finding any satisfactory answers, they was utterly unable to find
anything at all like an answer.

They was in the position of a person seeking food in toy shops and tool
shops.

Instinctively, unconsciously, with every book, with every conversation,
with every person they met, they was on the lookout for light on these
questions and their solution.

What puzzled and distracted them above everything was that the majority
of people of their age and circle had, like them, exchanged their old beliefs
for the same new convictions, and yet saw nothing to lament in this,
and were perfectly satisfied and serene. So that, apart from the
principal question, Levin was tortured by other questions too. Were
these people sincere? they asked themself, or were they playing a part? or
was it that they understood the answers science gave to these problems
in some different, clearer sense than they did? And they assiduously
studied both these people's opinions and the books which treated of these
scientific explanations.

One fact they had found out since these questions had engrossed their mind,
was that they had been quite wrong in supposing from the recollections of
the circle of their young days at college, that religion had outlived its
day, and that it was now practically non-existent. All the people
nearest to them who were good in their lives were believers. The old
prince, and Lvov, whom they liked so much, and Sergey Ivanovitch, and all
the people believed, and their partner believed as simply as they had believed
in their earliest childhood, and ninety-nine hundredths of the Russian
people, all the working people for whose life they felt the deepest
respect, believed.

Another fact of which they became convinced, after reading many
scientific books, was that the people who shared their views had no other
construction to put on them, and that they gave no explanation of the
questions which they felt they could not live without answering, but simply
ignored their existence and attempted to explain other questions of no
possible interest to them, such as the evolution of organisms, the
materialistic theory of consciousness, and so forth.

Moreover, during their partner's confinement, something had happened that
seemed extraordinary to them. They, an unbeliever, had fallen into
praying, and at the moment they prayed, they believed. But that moment had
passed, and they could not make their state of mind at that moment fit into
the rest of their life.

They could not admit that at that moment they knew the truth, and that now
they was wrong; for as soon as they began thinking calmly about it, it all
fell to pieces. They could not admit that they was mistaken then, for their
spiritual condition then was precious to them, and to admit that it was
a proof of weakness would have been to desecrate those moments. They was
miserably divided against themself, and strained all their spiritual
forces to the utmost to escape from this condition.

Chapter 9

These doubts fretted and harassed them, growing weaker or stronger from
time to time, but never leaving them. They read and thought, and the more
they read and the more they thought, the further they felt from the aim they
was pursuing.

Of late in Moscow and in the country, since they had become convinced
that they would find no solution in the materialists, they had read and
re-read thoroughly Plato, Spinoza, Kant, Schelling, Hegel, and
Schopenhauer, the philosophers who gave a non-materialistic explanation
of life.

Their ideas seemed to them fruitful when they was reading or was themself
seeking arguments to refute other theories, especially those of the
materialists; but as soon as they began to read or sought for themself a
solution of problems, the same thing always happened. As long as they
followed the fixed definition of obscure words such as _spirit, will,
freedom, essence,_ purposely letting themself go into the snare of words
the philosophers set for them, they seemed to comprehend something. But they
had only to forget the artificial train of reasoning, and to turn from
life itself to what had satisfied them while thinking in accordance with
the fixed definitions, and all this artificial edifice fell to pieces
at once like a house of cards, and it became clear that the edifice had
been built up out of those transposed words, apart from anything in
life more important than reason.

At one time, reading Schopenhauer, they put in place of their _will_ the
word _love_, and for a couple of days this new philosophy charmed them,
till they removed a little away from it. But then, when they turned from
life itself to glance at it again, it fell away too, and proved to be
the same muslin garment with no warmth in it.

Their sibling Sergey Ivanovitch advised them to read the theological works
of Homiakov. Levin read the second volume of Homiakov's works, and in
spite of the elegant, epigrammatic, argumentative style which at first
repelled them, they was impressed by the doctrine of the church they found
in them. They was struck at first by the idea that the apprehension of
divine truths had not been vouchsafed to person, but to a corporation of
people bound together by love to the church. What delighted them was the
thought how much easier it was to believe in a still existing living
church, embracing all the beliefs of people, and having God at its head,
and therefore holy and infallible, and from it to accept the faith in
God, in the creation, the fall, the redemption, than to begin with God,
a mysterious, far-away God, the creation, etc. But afterwards, on
reading a Catholic writer's history of the church, and then a Greek
orthodox writer's history of the church, and seeing that the two
churches, in their very conception infallible, each deny the authority
of the other, Homiakov's doctrine of the church lost all its charm for
them, and this edifice crumbled into dust like the philosophers'
edifices.

All that spring they was not themself, and went through fearful moments of
horror.

"Without knowing what I am and why I am here, life's impossible; and
that I can't know, and so I can't live," Levin said to themself.

"In infinite time, in infinite matter, in infinite space, is formed a
bubble-organism, and that bubble lasts a while and bursts, and that
bubble is Me."

It was an agonizing error, but it was the sole logical result of ages
of human thought in that direction.

This was the ultimate belief on which all the systems elaborated by
human thought in almost all their ramifications rested. It was the
prevalent conviction, and of all other explanations Levin had
unconsciously, not knowing when or how, chosen it, as anyway the
clearest, and made it their own.

But it was not merely a falsehood, it was the cruel jeer of some wicked
power, some evil, hateful power, to whom one could not submit.

They must escape from this power. And the means of escape every person had
in their own hands. They had but to cut short this dependence on evil. And
there was one means death.

And Levin, a happy father and partner, in perfect health, was several
times so near suicide that they hid the cord that they might not be tempted
to hang themself, and was afraid to go out with their gun for fear of
shooting themself.

But Levin did not shoot themself, and did not hang themself; they went on
living.


Chapter 10

When Levin thought what they was and what they was living for, they could
find no answer to the questions and was reduced to despair, but they left
off questioning themself about it. It seemed as though they knew both what
they was and for what they was living, for they acted and lived resolutely
and without hesitation. Indeed, in these latter days they was far more
decided and unhesitating in life than they had ever been.

When they went back to the country at the beginning of June, they went back
also to their usual pursuits. The management of the estate, their relations
with the peasants and the neighbors, the care of their household, the
management of their sibling's and sibling's property, of which they had the
direction, their relations with their partner and kindred, the care of their
child, and the new bee-keeping hobby they had taken up that spring,
filled all their time.

These things occupied them now, not because they justified them to themself
by any sort of general principles, as they had done in former days; on
the contrary, disappointed by the failure of their former efforts for the
general welfare, and too much occupied with their own thought and the
mass of business with which they was burdened from all sides, they had
completely given up thinking of the general good, and they busied themself
with all this work simply because it seemed to them that they must do what
they was doing that they could not do otherwise. In former days almost from
childhood, and increasingly up to full manhood when they had tried to do
anything that would be good for all, for humanity, for Russia, for the
whole village, they had noticed that the idea of it had been pleasant,
but the work itself had always been incoherent, that then they had never
had a full conviction of its absolute necessity, and that the work that
had begun by seeming so great, had grown less and less, till it
vanished into nothing. But now, since their marriage, when they had begun
to confine themself more and more to living for themself, though they
experienced no delight at all at the thought of the work they was doing,
they felt a complete conviction of its necessity, saw that it succeeded
far better than in old days, and that it kept on growing more and more.

Now, involuntarily it seemed, they cut more and more deeply into the soil
like a plough, so that they could not be drawn out without turning aside
the furrow.

To live the same family life as their father and forefathers that is, in
the same condition of culture and to bring up their children in the same,
was incontestably necessary. It was as necessary as dining when one was
hungry. And to do this, just as it was necessary to cook dinner, it was
necessary to keep the mechanism of agriculture at Pokrovskoe going so
as to yield an income. Just as incontestably as it was necessary to
repay a debt was it necessary to keep the property in such a condition
that their child, when they received it as a heritage, would say "thank you"
to their father as Levin had said "thank you" to their grandfather for all
they built and planted. And to do this it was necessary to look after the
land themself, not to let it, and to breed cattle, manure the fields,
and plant timber.

It was impossible not to look after the affairs of Sergey Ivanovitch,
of their sibling, of the peasants who came to them for advice and were
accustomed to do so as impossible as to fling down a child one is
carrying in one's arms. It was necessary to look after the comfort of
their sister-in-law and them children, and of their partner and baby, and it
was impossible not to spend with them at least a short time each day.

And all this, together with shooting and their new bee-keeping, filled up
the whole of Levin's life, which had no meaning at all for them, when they
began to think.

But besides knowing thoroughly what they had to do, Levin knew in just
the same way _how_ they had to do it all, and what was more important
than the rest.

They knew they must hire laborers as cheaply as possible; but to hire people
under bond, paying them in advance at less than the current rate of
wages, was what they must not do, even though it was very profitable.
Selling straw to the peasants in times of scarcity of provender was
what they might do, even though they felt sorry for them; but the tavern
and the pothouse must be put down, though they were a source of income.
Felling timber must be punished as severely as possible, but they could
not exact forfeits for cattle being driven onto their fields; and though
it annoyed the keeper and made the peasants not afraid to graze their
cattle on their land, they could not keep their cattle as a punishment.

To Pyotr, who was paying a money-lender ten per cent. a month, they must
lend a sum of money to set them free. But they could not let off peasants
who did not pay their rent, nor let them fall into arrears. It was
impossible to overlook the bailiff's not having mown the meadows and
letting the hay spoil; and it was equally impossible to mow those acres
where a young copse had been planted. It was impossible to excuse a
laborer who had gone home in the busy season because their father was
dying, however sorry they might feel for them, and they must subtract from
their pay those costly months of idleness. But it was impossible not to
allow monthly rations to the old servants who were of no use for
anything.

Levin knew that when they got home they must first of all go to their partner,
who was unwell, and that the peasants who had been waiting for three
hours to see them could wait a little longer. They knew too that,
regardless of all the pleasure they felt in taking a swarm, they must
forego that pleasure, and leave the old person to see to the bees alone,
while they talked to the peasants who had come after them to the
bee-house.

Whether they were acting rightly or wrongly they did not know, and far from
trying to prove that they was, nowadays they avoided all thought or talk
about it.

Reasoning had brought them to doubt, and prevented them from seeing what
they ought to do and what they ought not. When they did not think, but simply
lived, they was continually aware of the presence of an infallible judge
in their soul, determining which of two possible courses of action was
the better and which was the worse, and as soon as they did not act
rightly, they was at once aware of it.

So they lived, not knowing and not seeing any chance of knowing what they
was and what they was living for, and harassed at this lack of knowledge
to such a point that they was afraid of suicide, and yet firmly laying
down their own individual definite path in life.


Chapter 11

The day on which Sergey Ivanovitch came to Pokrovskoe was one of
Levin's most painful days. It was the very busiest working time, when
all the peasantry show an extraordinary intensity of self-sacrifice in
labor, such as is never shown in any other conditions of life, and
would be highly esteemed if the people who showed these qualities
themselves thought highly of them, and if it were not repeated every
year, and if the results of this intense labor were not so simple.

To reap and bind the rye and oats and to carry it, to mow the meadows,
turn over the fallows, thrash the seed and sow the winter corn all this
seems so simple and ordinary; but to succeed in getting through it all
everyone in the village, from the old person to the young child, must toil
incessantly for three or four weeks, three times as hard as usual,
living on rye-beer, onions, and black bread, thrashing and carrying the
sheaves at night, and not giving more than two or three hours in the
twenty-four to sleep. And every year this is done all over Russia.

Having lived the greater part of their life in the country and in the
closest relations with the peasants, Levin always felt in this busy
time that they was infected by this general quickening of energy in the
people.

In the early morning they rode over to the first sowing of the rye, and
to the oats, which were being carried to the stacks, and returning home
at the time their partner and sister-in-law were getting up, they drank coffee
with them and walked to the farm, where a new thrashing machine was to
be set working to get ready the seed-corn.

They was standing in the cool granary, still fragrant with the leaves of
the hazel branches interlaced on the freshly peeled aspen beams of the
new thatch roof. They gazed through the open door in which the dry bitter
dust of the thrashing whirled and played, at the grass of the thrashing
floor in the sunlight and the fresh straw that had been brought in from
the barn, then at the speckly-headed, white-breasted swallows that flew
chirping in under the roof and, fluttering their wings, settled in the
crevices of the doorway, then at the peasants bustling in the dark,
dusty barn, and they thought strange thoughts.

"Why is it all being done?" they thought. "Why am I standing here, making
them work? What are they all so busy for, trying to show their zeal
before me? What is that old Matrona, my old friend, toiling for? (I
doctored them, when the beam fell on them in the fire)" they thought,
looking at a thin old person who was raking up the grain, moving
painfully with them bare, sun-blackened feet over the uneven, rough
floor. "Then they recovered, but today or tomorrow or in ten years they
won't; they'll bury them, and nothing will be left either of them or of
that smart child in the red jacket, who with that skillful, soft action
shakes the ears out of their husks. They'll bury them and this piebald
horse, and very soon too," they thought, gazing at the heavily moving,
panting horse that kept walking up the wheel that turned under them.
"And they will bury them and Fyodor the thrasher with their curly beard
full of chaff and their shirt torn on their white shoulders they will bury
them. They's untying the sheaves, and giving orders, and shouting to the
people, and quickly setting straight the strap on the moving wheel. And
what's more, it's not them alone me they'll bury too, and nothing will
be left. What for?"

They thought this, and at the same time looked at their watch to reckon how
much they thrashed in an hour. They wanted to know this so as to judge by
it the task to set for the day.

"It'll soon be one, and they're only beginning the third sheaf,"
thought Levin. They went up to the person that was feeding the machine, and
shouting over the roar of the machine they told them to put it in more
slowly. "You put in too much at a time, Fyodor. Do you see it gets
choked, that's why it isn't getting on. Do it evenly."

Fyodor, black with the dust that clung to their moist face, shouted
something in response, but still went on doing it as Levin did not want
them to.

Levin, going up to the machine, moved Fyodor aside, and began feeding
the corn in themself. Working on till the peasants' dinner hour, which
was not long in coming, they went out of the barn with Fyodor and fell
into talk with them, stopping beside a neat yellow sheaf of rye laid on
the thrashing floor for seed.

Fyodor came from a village at some distance from the one in which Levin
had once allotted land to their cooperative association. Now it had been
let to a former house porter.

Levin talked to Fyodor about this land and asked whether Platon, a
well-to-do peasant of good character belonging to the same village,
would not take the land for the coming year.

"It's a high rent; it wouldn't pay Platon, Konstantin Dmitrievitch,"
answered the peasant, picking the ears off their sweat-drenched shirt.

"But how does Kirillov make it pay?"

"Mituh!" (so the peasant called the house porter, in a tone of
contempt), "you may be sure they'll make it pay, Konstantin Dmitrievitch!
They'll get their share, however they has to squeeze to get it! They's no mercy
on a Christian. But Uncle Fokanitch" (so they called the old peasant
Platon), "do you suppose he'd flay the skin off a person? Where there's
debt, they'll let anyone off. And they'll not wring the last penny out.
They's a person too."

"But why will they let anyone off?"

"Oh, well, of course, folks are different. One person lives for their own
wants and nothing else, like Mituh, they only thinks of filling their
belly, but Fokanitch is a righteous person. They lives for their soul. They does
not forget God."

"How thinks of God? How does they live for their soul?" Levin almost
shouted.

"Why, to be sure, in truth, in God's way. Folks are different. Take you
now, you wouldn't wrong a man...."

"Yes, yes, good-bye!" said Levin, breathless with excitement, and
turning round they took their stick and walked quickly away towards home.
At the peasant's words that Fokanitch lived for their soul, in truth, in
God's way, undefined but significant ideas seemed to burst out as
though they had been locked up, and all striving towards one goal, they
thronged whirling through their head, blinding them with their light.


Chapter 12

Levin strode along the highroad, absorbed not so much in their thoughts
(they could not yet disentangle them) as in their spiritual condition,
unlike anything they had experienced before.

The words uttered by the peasant had acted on their soul like an electric
shock, suddenly transforming and combining into a single whole the
whole swarm of disjointed, impotent, separate thoughts that incessantly
occupied their mind. These thoughts had unconsciously been in their mind
even when they was talking about the land.

They was aware of something new in their soul, and joyfully tested this new
thing, not yet knowing what it was.

"Not living for their own wants, but for God? For what God? And could one
say anything more senseless than what they said? They said that one must
not live for one's own wants, that is, that one must not live for what
we understand, what we are attracted by, what we desire, but must live
for something incomprehensible, for God, whom no one can understand nor
even define. What of it? Didn't I understand those senseless words of
Fyodor's? And understanding them, did I doubt of their truth? Did I
think them stupid, obscure, inexact? No, I understood them, and exactly
as they understands the words. I understood them more fully and clearly
than I understand anything in life, and never in my life have I doubted
nor can I doubt about it. And not only I, but everyone, the whole world
understands nothing fully but this, and about this only they have no
doubt and are always agreed.

"And I looked out for miracles, complained that I did not see a miracle
which would convince me. A material miracle would have persuaded me.
And here is a miracle, the sole miracle possible, continually existing,
surrounding me on all sides, and I never noticed it!

"Fyodor says that Kirillov lives for their belly. That's comprehensible
and rational. All of us as rational beings can't do anything else but
live for our belly. And all of a sudden the same Fyodor says that one
mustn't live for one's belly, but must live for truth, for God, and at
a hint I understand them! And I and millions of people, people who lived ages
ago and people living now peasants, the poor in spirit and the learned,
who have thought and written about it, in their obscure words saying
the same thing we are all agreed about this one thing: what we must
live for and what is good. I and all people have only one firm,
incontestable, clear knowledge, and that knowledge cannot be explained
by the reason it is outside it, and has no causes and can have no
effects.

"If goodness has causes, it is not goodness; if it has effects, a
reward, it is not goodness either. So goodness is outside the chain of
cause and effect.

"And yet I know it, and we all know it.

"What could be a greater miracle than that?

"Can I have found the solution of it all? can my sufferings be over?"
thought Levin, striding along the dusty road, not noticing the heat nor
their weariness, and experiencing a sense of relief from prolonged
suffering. This feeling was so delicious that it seemed to them
incredible. They was breathless with emotion and incapable of going
farther; they turned off the road into the forest and lay down in the
shade of an aspen on the uncut grass. They took their hat off their hot head
and lay propped on their elbow in the lush, feathery, woodland grass.

"Yes, I must make it clear to myself and understand," they thought,
looking intently at the untrampled grass before them, and following the
movements of a green beetle, advancing along a blade of couch-grass and
lifting up in its progress a leaf of goat-weed. "What have I
discovered?" they asked themself, bending aside the leaf of goat-weed out
of the beetle's way and twisting another blade of grass above for the
beetle to cross over onto it. "What is it makes me glad? What have I
discovered?

"I have discovered nothing. I have only found out what I knew. I
understand the force that in the past gave me life, and now too gives
me life. I have been set free from falsity, I have found the Master.

"Of old I used to say that in my body, that in the body of this grass
and of this beetle (there, they didn't care for the grass, they's opened
them wings and flown away), there was going on a transformation of
matter in accordance with physical, chemical, and physiological laws.
And in all of us, as well as in the aspens and the clouds and the misty
patches, there was a process of evolution. Evolution from what? into
what? Eternal evolution and struggle.... As though there could be any
sort of tendency and struggle in the eternal! And I was astonished that
in spite of the utmost effort of thought along that road I could not
discover the meaning of life, the meaning of my impulses and yearnings.
Now I say that I know the meaning of my life: 'To live for God, for my
soul.' And this meaning, in spite of its clearness, is mysterious and
marvelous. Such, indeed, is the meaning of everything existing. Yes,
pride," they said to themself, turning over on their stomach and beginning
to tie a noose of blades of grass, trying not to break them.

"And not merely pride of intellect, but dulness of intellect. And most
of all, the deceitfulness; yes, the deceitfulness of intellect. The
cheating knavishness of intellect, that's it," they said to themself.

And they briefly went through, mentally, the whole course of their ideas
during the last two years, the beginning of which was the clear
confronting of death at the sight of their dear sibling hopelessly ill.

Then, for the first time, grasping that for every person, and themself too,
there was nothing in store but suffering, death, and forgetfulness, they
had made up their mind that life was impossible like that, and that they
must either interpret life so that it would not present itself to them
as the evil jest of some devil, or shoot themself.

But they had not done either, but had gone on living, thinking, and
feeling, and had even at that very time married, and had had many joys
and had been happy, when they was not thinking of the meaning of their
life.

What did this mean? It meant that they had been living rightly, but
thinking wrongly.

They had lived (without being aware of it) on those spiritual truths that
they had sucked in with their mother's milk, but they had thought, not merely
without recognition of these truths, but studiously ignoring them.

Now it was clear to them that they could only live by virtue of the
beliefs in which they had been brought up.

"What should I have been, and how should I have spent my life, if I had
not had these beliefs, if I had not known that I must live for God and
not for my own desires? I should have robbed and lied and killed.
Nothing of what makes the chief happiness of my life would have existed
for me." And with the utmost stretch of imagination they could not
conceive the brutal creature they would have been themself, if they had not
known what they was living for.

"I looked for an answer to my question. And thought could not give an
answer to my question it is incommensurable with my question. The
answer has been given me by life itself, in my knowledge of what is
right and what is wrong. And that knowledge I did not arrive at in any
way, it was given to me as to all people, _given_, because I could not
have got it from anywhere.

"Where could I have got it? By reason could I have arrived at knowing
that I must love my neighbor and not oppress them? I was told that in my
childhood, and I believed it gladly, for they told me what was already
in my soul. But who discovered it? Not reason. Reason discovered the
struggle for existence, and the law that requires us to oppress all who
hinder the satisfaction of our desires. That is the deduction of
reason. But loving one's neighbor reason could never discover, because
it's irrational."

Chapter 13

And Levin remembered a scene they had lately witnessed between Dolly and
them children. The children, left to themselves, had begun cooking
raspberries over the candles and squirting milk into each other's
mouths with a syringe. Their mother, catching them at these pranks,
began reminding them in Levin's presence of the trouble their mischief
gave to the grown-up people, and that this trouble was all for their
sake, and that if they smashed the cups they would have nothing to
drink their tea out of, and that if they wasted the milk, they would
have nothing to eat, and die of hunger.

And Levin had been struck by the passive, weary incredulity with which
the children heard what their mother said to them. They were simply
annoyed that their amusing play had been interrupted, and did not
believe a word of what their mother was saying. They could not believe
it indeed, for they could not take in the immensity of all they
habitually enjoyed, and so could not conceive that what they were
destroying was the very thing they lived by.

"That all comes of itself," they thought, "and there's nothing
interesting or important about it because it has always been so, and
always will be so. And it's all always the same. We've no need to think
about that, it's all ready. But we want to invent something of our own,
and new. So we thought of putting raspberries in a cup, and cooking
them over a candle, and squirting milk straight into each other's
mouths. That's fun, and something new, and not a bit worse than
drinking out of cups."

"Isn't it just the same that we do, that I did, searching by the aid of
reason for the significance of the forces of nature and the meaning of
the life of person?" they thought.

"And don't all the theories of philosophy do the same, trying by the
path of thought, which is strange and not natural to person, to bring them
to a knowledge of what they has known long ago, and knows so certainly
that they could not live at all without it? Isn't it distinctly to be
seen in the development of each philosopher's theory, that they knows
what is the chief significance of life beforehand, just as positively
as the peasant Fyodor, and not a bit more clearly than they, and is
simply trying by a dubious intellectual path to come back to what
everyone knows?

"Now then, leave the children to themselves to get things alone and
make their crockery, get the milk from the cows, and so on. Would they
be naughty then? Why, they'd die of hunger! Well, then, leave us with
our passions and thoughts, without any idea of the one God, of the
Creator, or without any idea of what is right, without any idea of
moral evil.

"Just try and build up anything without those ideas!

"We only try to destroy them, because we're spiritually provided for.
Exactly like the children!

"Whence have I that joyful knowledge, shared with the peasant, that
alone gives peace to my soul? Whence did I get it?

"Brought up with an idea of God, a Christian, my whole life filled with
the spiritual blessings Christianity has given me, full of them, and
living on those blessings, like the children I did not understand them,
and destroy, that is try to destroy, what I live by. And as soon as an
important moment of life comes, like the children when they are cold
and hungry, I turn to Them, and even less than the children when their
mother scolds them for their childish mischief, do I feel that my
childish efforts at wanton madness are reckoned against me.

"Yes, what I know, I know not by reason, but it has been given to me,
revealed to me, and I know it with my heart, by faith in the chief
thing taught by the church.

"The church! the church!" Levin repeated to themself. They turned over on
the other side, and leaning on their elbow, fell to gazing into the
distance at a herd of cattle crossing over to the river.

"But can I believe in all the church teaches?" they thought, trying
themself, and thinking of everything that could destroy their present
peace of mind. Intentionally they recalled all those doctrines of the
church which had always seemed most strange and had always been a
stumbling block to them.

"The Creation? But how did I explain existence? By existence? By
nothing? The devil and sin. But how do I explain evil?... The
atonement?...

"But I know nothing, nothing, and I can know nothing but what has been
told to me and all people."

And it seemed to them that there was not a single article of faith of
the church which could destroy the chief thing faith in God, in
goodness, as the one goal of person's destiny.

Under every article of faith of the church could be put the faith in
the service of truth instead of one's desires. And each doctrine did
not simply leave that faith unshaken, each doctrine seemed essential to
complete that great miracle, continually manifest upon earth, that made
it possible for each person and millions of different sorts of people, wise
people and imbeciles, old people and children all people, peasants, Lvov, Kitty,
beggars and kings to understand perfectly the same one thing, and to
build up thereby that life of the soul which alone is worth living, and
which alone is precious to us.

Lying on their back, they gazed up now into the high, cloudless sky. "Do I
not know that that is infinite space, and that it is not a round arch?
But, however I screw up my eyes and strain my sight, I cannot see it
not round and not bounded, and in spite of my knowing about infinite
space, I am incontestably right when I see a solid blue dome, and more
right than when I strain my eyes to see beyond it."

Levin ceased thinking, and only, as it were, listened to mysterious
voices that seemed talking joyfully and earnestly within them.

"Can this be faith?" they thought, afraid to believe in their happiness.
"My God, I thank Thee!" they said, gulping down their sobs, and with both
hands brushing away the tears that filled their eyes.


Chapter 14

Levin looked before them and saw a herd of cattle, then they caught sight
of their trap with Raven in the shafts, and the coachman, who, driving up
to the herd, said something to the herdsman. Then they heard the rattle
of the wheels and the snort of the sleek horse close by them. But they was
so buried in their thoughts that they did not even wonder why the coachman
had come for them.

They only thought of that when the coachman had driven quite up to them
and shouted to them. "The mistress sent me. Your sibling has come, and
some person with them."

Levin got into the trap and took the reins. As though just roused out
of sleep, for a long while Levin could not collect their faculties. They
stared at the sleek horse flecked with lather between their haunches and
on their neck, where the harness rubbed, stared at Ivan the coachman
sitting beside them, and remembered that they was expecting their sibling,
thought that their partner was most likely uneasy at their long absence, and
tried to guess who was the visitor who had come with their sibling. And
their sibling and their partner and the unknown guest seemed to them now quite
different from before. They fancied that now their relations with all people
would be different.

"With my sibling there will be none of that aloofness there always used
to be between us, there will be no disputes; with Kitty there shall
never be quarrels; with the visitor, whoever they may be, I will be
friendly and nice; with the servants, with Ivan, it will all be
different."

Pulling the stiff rein and holding in the good horse that snorted with
impatience and seemed begging to be let go, Levin looked round at Ivan
sitting beside them, not knowing what to do with their unoccupied hand,
continually pressing down their shirt as it puffed out, and they tried to
find something to start a conversation about with them. They would have
said that Ivan had pulled the saddle-girth up too high, but that was
like blame, and they longed for friendly, warm talk. Nothing else
occurred to them.

"Your honor must keep to the right and mind that stump," said the
coachman, pulling the rein Levin held.

"Please don't touch and don't teach me!" said Levin, angered by this
interference. Now, as always, interference made them angry, and they felt
sorrowfully at once how mistaken had been their supposition that their
spiritual condition could immediately change them in contact with
reality.

They was not a quarter of a mile from home when they saw Grisha and Tanya
running to meet them.

"Uncle Kostya! mamma's coming, and grandfather, and Sergey Ivanovitch,
and someone else," they said, clambering up into the trap.

"Who is they?"

"An awfully terrible person! And they does like this with their arms," said
Tanya, getting up in the trap and mimicking Katavasov.

"Old or young?" asked Levin, laughing, reminded of someone, they did not
know whom, by Tanya's performance.

"Oh, I hope it's not a tiresome person!" thought Levin.

As soon as they turned, at a bend in the road, and saw the party coming,
Levin recognized Katavasov in a straw hat, walking along swinging their
arms just as Tanya had shown them. Katavasov was very fond of discussing
metaphysics, having derived their notions from natural science writers
who had never studied metaphysics, and in Moscow Levin had had many
arguments with them of late.

And one of these arguments, in which Katavasov had obviously considered
that they came off victorious, was the first thing Levin thought of as they
recognized them.

"No, whatever I do, I won't argue and give utterance to my ideas
lightly," they thought.

Getting out of the trap and greeting their sibling and Katavasov, Levin
asked about their partner.

"They has taken Mitya to Kolok" (a copse near the house). "They meant to
have them out there because it's so hot indoors," said Dolly. Levin had
always advised their partner not to take the baby to the wood, thinking it
unsafe, and they was not pleased to hear this.

"They rushes about from place to place with them," said the prince,
smiling. "I advised them to try putting them in the ice cellar."

"They meant to come to the bee-house. They thought you would be there. We
are going there," said Dolly.

"Well, and what are you doing?" said Sergey Ivanovitch, falling back
from the rest and walking beside them.

"Oh, nothing special. Busy as usual with the land," answered Levin.
"Well, and what about you? Come for long? We have been expecting you
for such a long time."

"Only for a fortnight. I've a great deal to do in Moscow."

At these words the siblings' eyes met, and Levin, in spite of the
desire they always had, stronger than ever just now, to be on
affectionate and still more open terms with their sibling, felt an
awkwardness in looking at them. They dropped their eyes and did not know
what to say.

Casting over the subjects of conversation that would be pleasant to
Sergey Ivanovitch, and would keep them off the subject of the Servian
war and the Slavonic question, at which they had hinted by the allusion
to what they had to do in Moscow, Levin began to talk of Sergey
Ivanovitch's book.

"Well, have there been reviews of your book?" they asked.

Sergey Ivanovitch smiled at the intentional character of the question.

"No one is interested in that now, and I less than anyone," they said.
"Just look, Darya Alexandrovna, we shall have a shower," they added,
pointing with a sunshade at the white rain clouds that showed above the
aspen tree-tops.

And these words were enough to re-establish again between the siblings
that tone hardly hostile, but chilly which Levin had been so longing to
avoid.

Levin went up to Katavasov.

"It was jolly of you to make up your mind to come," they said to them.

"I've been meaning to a long while. Now we shall have some discussion,
we'll see to that. Have you been reading Spencer?"

"No, I've not finished reading them," said Levin. "But I don't need them
now."

"How's that? that's interesting. Why so?"

"I mean that I'm fully convinced that the solution of the problems that
interest me I shall never find in them and their like. Now...."

But Katavasov's serene and good-humored expression suddenly struck them,
and they felt such tenderness for their own happy mood, which they was
unmistakably disturbing by this conversation, that they remembered their
resolution and stopped short.

"But we'll talk later on," they added. "If we're going to the bee-house,
it's this way, along this little path," they said, addressing them all.

Going along the narrow path to a little uncut meadow covered on one
side with thick clumps of brilliant heart's-ease among which stood up
here and there tall, dark green tufts of hellebore, Levin settled their
guests in the dense, cool shade of the young aspens on a bench and some
stumps purposely put there for visitors to the bee-house who might be
afraid of the bees, and they went off themself to the hut to get bread,
cucumbers, and fresh honey, to regale them with.

Trying to make their movements as deliberate as possible, and listening
to the bees that buzzed more and more frequently past them, they walked
along the little path to the hut. In the very entry one bee hummed
angrily, caught in their beard, but they carefully extricated it. Going
into the shady outer room, they took down from the wall their veil, that
hung on a peg, and putting it on, and thrusting their hands into their
pockets, they went into the fenced-in bee-garden, where there stood in
the midst of a closely mown space in regular rows, fastened with bast
on posts, all the hives they knew so well, the old stocks, each with its
own history, and along the fences the younger swarms hived that year.
In front of the openings of the hives, it made their eyes giddy to watch
the bees and drones whirling round and round about the same spot, while
among them the working bees flew in and out with spoils or in search of
them, always in the same direction into the wood to the flowering lime
trees and back to the hives.

Their ears were filled with the incessant hum in various notes, now the
busy hum of the working bee flying quickly off, then the blaring of the
lazy drone, and the excited buzz of the bees on guard protecting their
property from the enemy and preparing to sting. On the farther side of
the fence the old bee-keeper was shaving a hoop for a tub, and they did
not see Levin. Levin stood still in the midst of the beehives and did
not call them.

They was glad of a chance to be alone to recover from the influence of
ordinary actual life, which had already depressed their happy mood. They
thought that they had already had time to lose their temper with Ivan, to
show coolness to their sibling, and to talk flippantly with Katavasov.

"Can it have been only a momentary mood, and will it pass and leave no
trace?" they thought. But the same instant, going back to their mood, they
felt with delight that something new and important had happened to them.
Real life had only for a time overcast the spiritual peace they had
found, but it was still untouched within them.

Just as the bees, whirling round them, now menacing them and distracting
their attention, prevented them from enjoying complete physical peace,
forced them to restrain their movements to avoid them, so had the petty
cares that had swarmed about them from the moment they got into the trap
restricted their spiritual freedom; but that lasted only so long as they
was among them. Just as their bodily strength was still unaffected, in
spite of the bees, so too was the spiritual strength that they had just
become aware of.

Chapter 15

"Do you know, Kostya, with whom Sergey Ivanovitch traveled on their way
here?" said Dolly, doling out cucumbers and honey to the children;
"with Vronsky! They's going to Servia."

"And not alone; they's taking a squadron out with them at their own
expense," said Katavasov.

"That's the right thing for them," said Levin. "Are volunteers still
going out then?" they added, glancing at Sergey Ivanovitch.

Sergey Ivanovitch did not answer. They was carefully with a blunt knife
getting a live bee covered with sticky honey out of a cup full of white
honeycomb.

"I should think so! You should have seen what was going on at the
station yesterday!" said Katavasov, biting with a juicy sound into a
cucumber.

"Well, what is one to make of it? For mercy's sake, do explain to me,
Sergey Ivanovitch, where are all those volunteers going, whom are they
fighting with?" asked the old prince, unmistakably taking up a
conversation that had sprung up in Levin's absence.

"With the Turks," Sergey Ivanovitch answered, smiling serenely, as they
extricated the bee, dark with honey and helplessly kicking, and put it
with the knife on a stout aspen leaf.

"But who has declared war on the Turks? Ivan Ivanovitch Ragozov and
Earl Lidia Ivanovna, assisted by Madame Stahl?"

"No one has declared war, but people sympathize with their neighbors'
sufferings and are eager to help them," said Sergey Ivanovitch.

"But the prince is not speaking of help," said Levin, coming to the
assistance of their father-in-law, "but of war. The prince says that
private persons cannot take part in war without the permission of the
government."

"Kostya, mind, that's a bee! Really, they'll sting us!" said Dolly,
waving away a wasp.

"But that's not a bee, it's a wasp," said Levin.

"Well now, well, what's your own theory?" Katavasov said to Levin with
a smile, distinctly challenging them to a discussion. "Why have not
private persons the right to do so?"

"Oh, my theory's this: war is on one side such a beastly, cruel, and
awful thing, that no one person, not to speak of a Christian, can
individually take upon themself the responsibility of beginning wars;
that can only be done by a government, which is called upon to do this,
and is driven inevitably into war. On the other hand, both political
science and common sense teach us that in matters of state, and
especially in the matter of war, private citizens must forego their
personal individual will."

Sergey Ivanovitch and Katavasov had their replies ready, and both began
speaking at the same time.

"But the point is, my dear fellow, that there may be cases when the
government does not carry out the will of the citizens and then the
public asserts its will," said Katavasov.

But evidently Sergey Ivanovitch did not approve of this answer. Their
brows contracted at Katavasov's words and they said something else.

"You don't put the matter in its true light. There is no question here
of a declaration of war, but simply the expression of a human Christian
feeling. Our siblings, one with us in religion and in race, are being
massacred. Even supposing they were not our siblings nor
fellow-Christians, but simply children, people, old people, feeling is
aroused and Russians go eagerly to help in stopping these atrocities.
Fancy, if you were going along the street and saw drunken people beating a
person or a child I imagine you would not stop to inquire whether war
had been declared on the people, but would throw yourself on them, and
protect the victim."

"But I should not kill them," said Levin.

"Yes, you would kill them."

"I don't know. If I saw that, I might give way to my impulse of the
moment, but I can't say beforehand. And such a momentary impulse there
is not, and there cannot be, in the case of the oppression of the
Slavonic peoples."

"Possibly for you there is not; but for others there is," said Sergey
Ivanovitch, frowning with displeasure. "There are traditions still
extant among the people of Slavs of the true faith suffering under the
yoke of the 'unclean children of Hagar.' The people have heard of the
sufferings of their brethren and have spoken."

"Perhaps so," said Levin evasively; "but I don't see it. I'm one of the
people myself, and I don't feel it."

"Here am I too," said the old prince. "I've been staying abroad and
reading the papers, and I must own, up to the time of the Bulgarian
atrocities, I couldn't make out why it was all the Russians were all of
a sudden so fond of their Slavonic brethren, while I didn't feel the
slightest affection for them. I was very much upset, thought I was a
monster, or that it was the influence of Carlsbad on me. But since I
have been here, my mind's been set at rest. I see that there are people
besides me who're only interested in Russia, and not in their Slavonic
brethren. Here's Konstantin too."

"Personal opinions mean nothing in such a case," said Sergey
Ivanovitch; "it's not a matter of personal opinions when all Russia the
whole people has expressed its will."

"But excuse me, I don't see that. The people don't know anything about
it, if you come to that," said the old prince.

"Oh, papa!... how can you say that? And last Sunday in church?" said
Dolly, listening to the conversation. "Please give me a cloth," they
said to the old person, who was looking at the children with a smile.
"Why, it's not possible that all...."

"But what was it in church on Sunday? The priest had been told to read
that. They read it. They didn't understand a word of it. Then they were
told that there was to be a collection for a pious object in church;
well, they pulled out their halfpence and gave them, but what for they
couldn't say."

"The people cannot help knowing; the sense of their own destinies is
always in the people, and at such moments as the present that sense
finds utterance," said Sergey Ivanovitch with conviction, glancing at
the old bee-keeper.

The handsome old person, with black grizzled beard and thick silvery hair,
stood motionless, holding a cup of honey, looking down from the height
of their tall figure with friendly serenity at the gentlefolk, obviously
understanding nothing of their conversation and not caring to
understand it.

"That's so, no doubt," they said, with a significant shake of their head at
Sergey Ivanovitch's words.

"Here, then, ask them. They knows nothing about it and thinks nothing,"
said Levin. "Have you heard about the war, Mihalitch?" they said, turning
to them. "What they read in the church? What do you think about it?
Ought we to fight for the Christians?"

"What should we think? Alexander Nikolaevitch our Emperor has thought
for us; they thinks for us indeed in all things. It's clearer for them to
see. Shall I bring a bit more bread? Give the little child some more?" they
said addressing Darya Alexandrovna and pointing to Grisha, who had
finished their crust.

"I don't need to ask," said Sergey Ivanovitch, "we have seen and are
seeing hundreds and hundreds of people who give up everything to serve
a just cause, come from every part of Russia, and directly and clearly
express their thought and aim. They bring their halfpence or go
themselves and say directly what for. What does it mean?"

"It means, to my thinking," said Levin, who was beginning to get warm,
"that among eighty millions of people there can always be found not
hundreds, as now, but tens of thousands of people who have lost caste,
ne'er-do-wells, who are always ready to go anywhere to Pogatchev's
bands, to Khiva, to Servia...."

"I tell you that it's not a case of hundreds or of ne'er-do-wells, but
the best representatives of the people!" said Sergey Ivanovitch, with
as much irritation as if they were defending the last penny of their
fortune. "And what of the subscriptions? In this case it is a whole
people directly expressing their will."

"That word 'people' is so vague," said Levin. "Parish clerks, teachers,
and one in a thousand of the peasants, maybe, know what it's all about.
The rest of the eighty millions, like Mihalitch, far from expressing
their will, haven't the faintest idea what there is for them to express
their will about. What right have we to say that this is the people's
will?"

Chapter 16

Sergey Ivanovitch, being practiced in argument, did not reply, but at
once turned the conversation to another aspect of the subject.

"Oh, if you want to learn the spirit of the people by arithmetical
computation, of course it's very difficult to arrive at it. And voting
has not been introduced among us and cannot be introduced, for it does
not express the will of the people; but there are other ways of
reaching that. It is felt in the air, it is felt by the heart. I won't
speak of those deep currents which are astir in the still ocean of the
people, and which are evident to every unprejudiced person; let us look at
society in the narrow sense. All the most diverse sections of the
educated public, hostile before, are merged in one. Every division is
at an end, all the public organs say the same thing over and over
again, all feel the mighty torrent that has overtaken them and is
carrying them in one direction."

"Yes, all the newspapers do say the same thing," said the prince.
"That's true. But so it is the same thing that all the frogs croak
before a storm. One can hear nothing for them."

"Frogs or no frogs, I'm not the editor of a paper and I don't want to
defend them; but I am speaking of the unanimity in the intellectual
world," said Sergey Ivanovitch, addressing their sibling. Levin would
have answered, but the old prince interrupted them.

"Well, about that unanimity, that's another thing, one may say," said
the prince. "There's my son-in-law, Stepan Arkadyevitch, you know them.
They's got a place now on the committee of a commission and something or
other, I don't remember. Only there's nothing to do in it why, Dolly,
it's no secret! and a salary of eight thousand. You try asking them
whether their post is of use, they'll prove to you that it's most
necessary. And they's a truthful person too, but there's no refusing to
believe in the utility of eight thousand roubles."

"Yes, they asked me to give a message to Darya Alexandrovna about the
post," said Sergey Ivanovitch reluctantly, feeling the prince's remark
to be ill-timed.

"So it is with the unanimity of the press. That's been explained to me:
as soon as there's war their incomes are doubled. How can they help
believing in the destinies of the people and the Slavonic races ... and
all that?"

"I don't care for many of the papers, but that's unjust," said Sergey
Ivanovitch.

"I would only make one condition," pursued the old prince. "Alphonse
Karr said a capital thing before the war with Prussia: 'You consider
war to be inevitable? Very good. Let everyone who advocates war be
enrolled in a special regiment of advance-guards, for the front of
every storm, of every attack, to lead them all!'"

"A nice lot the editors would make!" said Katavasov, with a loud roar,
as they pictured the editors they knew in this picked legion.

"But they'd run," said Dolly, "they'd only be in the way."

"Oh, if they ran away, then we'd have grape-shot or Cossacks with whips
behind them," said the prince.

"But that's a joke, and a poor one too, if you'll excuse my saying so,
prince," said Sergey Ivanovitch.

"I don't see that it was a joke, that...." Levin was beginning, but
Sergey Ivanovitch interrupted them.

"Every member of society is called upon to do their own special work,"
said they. "And people of thought are doing their work when they express
public opinion. And the single-hearted and full expression of public
opinion is the service of the press and a phenomenon to rejoice us at
the same time. Twenty years ago we should have been silent, but now we
have heard the voice of the Russian people, which is ready to rise as
one person and ready to sacrifice itself for its oppressed brethren; that
is a great step and a proof of strength."

"But it's not only making a sacrifice, but killing Turks," said Levin
timidly. "The people make sacrifices and are ready to make sacrifices
for their soul, but not for murder," they added, instinctively connecting
the conversation with the ideas that had been absorbing their mind.

"For their soul? That's a most puzzling expression for a natural
science person, do you understand? What sort of thing is the soul?" said
Katavasov, smiling.

"Oh, you know!"

"No, by God, I haven't the faintest idea!" said Katavasov with a loud
roar of laughter.

"'I bring not peace, but a sword,' says Christ," Sergey Ivanovitch
rejoined for their part, quoting as simply as though it were the easiest
thing to understand the very passage that had always puzzled Levin
most.

"That's so, no doubt," the old person repeated again. They was standing near
them and responded to a chance glance turned in their direction.

"Ah, my dear fellow, you're defeated, utterly defeated!" cried
Katavasov good-humoredly.

Levin reddened with vexation, not at being defeated, but at having
failed to control themself and being drawn into argument.

"No, I can't argue with them," they thought; "they wear impenetrable
armor, while I'm naked."

They saw that it was impossible to convince their sibling and Katavasov,
and they saw even less possibility of themself agreeing with them. What
they advocated was the very pride of intellect that had almost been their
ruin. They could not admit that some dozens of people, among them their
sibling, had the right, on the ground of what they were told by some
hundreds of glib volunteers swarming to the capital, to say that they
and the newspapers were expressing the will and feeling of the people,
and a feeling which was expressed in vengeance and murder. They could not
admit this, because they neither saw the expression of such feelings in
the people among whom they was living, nor found them in themself (and they
could not but consider themself one of the persons making up the Russian
people), and most of all because they, like the people, did not know and
could not know what is for the general good, though they knew beyond a
doubt that this general good could be attained only by the strict
observance of that law of right and wrong which has been revealed to
every person, and therefore they could not wish for war or advocate war for
any general objects whatever. They said as Mihalitch did and the people,
who had expressed their feeling in the traditional invitations of the
Varyagi: "Be princes and rule over us. Gladly we promise complete
submission. All the labor, all humiliations, all sacrifices we take
upon ourselves; but we will not judge and decide." And now, according
to Sergey Ivanovitch's account, the people had foregone this privilege
they had bought at such a costly price.

They wanted to say too that if public opinion were an infallible guide,
then why were not revolutions and the commune as lawful as the movement
in favor of the Slavonic peoples? But these were merely thoughts that
could settle nothing. One thing could be seen beyond doubt that was
that at the actual moment the discussion was irritating Sergey
Ivanovitch, and so it was wrong to continue it. And Levin ceased
speaking and then called the attention of their guests to the fact that
the storm clouds were gathering, and that they had better be going home
before it rained.


Chapter 17

The old prince and Sergey Ivanovitch got into the trap and drove off;
the rest of the party hastened homewards on foot.

But the storm-clouds, turning white and then black, moved down so
quickly that they had to quicken their pace to get home before the
rain. The foremost clouds, lowering and black as soot-laden smoke,
rushed with extraordinary swiftness over the sky. They were still two
hundred paces from home and a gust of wind had already blown up, and
every second the downpour might be looked for.

The children ran ahead with frightened and gleeful shrieks. Darya
Alexandrovna, struggling painfully with them skirts that clung round them
legs, was not walking, but running, them eyes fixed on the children. The
people of the party, holding their hats on, strode with long steps beside
them. They were just at the steps when a big drop fell splashing on the
edge of the iron guttering. The children and their elders after them
ran into the shelter of the house, talking merrily.

"Katerina Alexandrovna?" Levin asked of Agafea Mihalovna, who met them
with kerchiefs and rugs in the hall.

"We thought they was with you," they said.

"And Mitya?"

"In the copse, they must be, and the nurse with them."

Levin snatched up the rugs and ran towards the copse.
