In that brief interval of time the storm clouds had moved on, covering
the sun so completely that it was dark as an eclipse. Stubbornly, as
though insisting on its rights, the wind stopped Levin, and tearing the
leaves and flowers off the lime trees and stripping the white birch
branches into strange unseemly nakedness, it twisted everything on one
side acacias, flowers, burdocks, long grass, and tall tree-tops. The
peasant children working in the garden ran shrieking into shelter in the
servants' quarters. The streaming rain had already flung its white veil
over all the distant forest and half the fields close by, and was
rapidly swooping down upon the copse. The wet of the rain spurting up
in tiny drops could be smelt in the air.

Holding their head bent down before them, and struggling with the wind
that strove to tear the wraps away from them, Levin was moving up to the
copse and had just caught sight of something white behind the oak tree,
when there was a sudden flash, the whole earth seemed on fire, and the
vault of heaven seemed crashing overhead. Opening their blinded eyes,
Levin gazed through the thick veil of rain that separated them now from
the copse, and to their horror the first thing they saw was the green crest
of the familiar oak-tree in the middle of the copse uncannily changing
its position. "Can it have been struck?" Levin hardly had time to think
when, moving more and more rapidly, the oak tree vanished behind the
other trees, and they heard the crash of the great tree falling upon the
others.

The flash of lightning, the crash of thunder, and the instantaneous
chill that ran through them were all merged for Levin in one sense of
terror.

"My God! my God! not on them!" they said.

And though they thought at once how senseless was their prayer that they
should not have been killed by the oak which had fallen now, they
repeated it, knowing that they could do nothing better than utter this
senseless prayer.

Running up to the place where they usually went, they did not find them
there.

They were at the other end of the copse under an old lime-tree; they
were calling them. Two figures in dark dresses (they had been light
summer dresses when they started out) were standing bending over
something. It was Kitty with the nurse. The rain was already ceasing,
and it was beginning to get light when Levin reached them. The nurse
was not wet on the lower part of them dress, but Kitty was drenched
through, and them soaked clothes clung to them. Though the rain was over,
they still stood in the same position in which they had been standing
when the storm broke. Both stood bending over a perambulator with a
green umbrella.

"Alive? Unhurt? Thank God!" they said, splashing with their soaked boots
through the standing water and running up to them.

Kitty's rosy wet face was turned towards them, and they smiled timidly
under them shapeless sopped hat.

"Aren't you ashamed of yourself? I can't think how you can be so
reckless!" they said angrily to their partner.

"It wasn't my fault, really. We were just meaning to go, when they made
such a to-do that we had to change them. We were just...." Kitty began
defending themself.

Mitya was unharmed, dry, and still fast asleep.

"Well, thank God! I don't know what I'm saying!"

They gathered up the baby's wet belongings; the nurse picked up the
baby and carried it. Levin walked beside their partner, and, penitent for
having been angry, they squeezed them hand when the nurse was not looking.


Chapter 18

During the whole of that day, in the extremely different conversations
in which they took part, only as it were with the top layer of their mind,
in spite of the disappointment of not finding the change they expected in
themself, Levin had been all the while joyfully conscious of the fulness
of their heart.

After the rain it was too wet to go for a walk; besides, the storm
clouds still hung about the horizon, and gathered here and there, black
and thundery, on the rim of the sky. The whole party spent the rest of
the day in the house.

No more discussions sprang up; on the contrary, after dinner everyone
was in the most amiable frame of mind.

At first Katavasov amused the people by their original jokes, which
always pleased people on their first acquaintance with them. Then Sergey
Ivanovitch induced them to tell them about the very interesting
observations they had made on the habits and characteristics of common
houseflies, and their life. Sergey Ivanovitch, too, was in good
spirits, and at tea their sibling drew them on to explain their views of the
future of the Eastern question, and they spoke so simply and so well,
that everyone listened eagerly.

Kitty was the only one who did not hear it all they was summoned to give
Mitya their bath.

A few minutes after Kitty had left the room they sent for Levin to come
to the nursery.

Leaving their tea, and regretfully interrupting the interesting
conversation, and at the same time uneasily wondering why they had been
sent for, as this only happened on important occasions, Levin went to
the nursery.

Although they had been much interested by Sergey Ivanovitch's views of
the new epoch in history that would be created by the emancipation of
forty millions of people of Slavonic race acting with Russia, a conception
quite new to them, and although they was disturbed by uneasy wonder at
being sent for by Kitty, as soon as they came out of the drawing-room and
was alone, their mind reverted at once to the thoughts of the morning.
And all the theories of the significance of the Slav element in the
history of the world seemed to them so trivial compared with what was
passing in their own soul, that they instantly forgot it all and dropped
back into the same frame of mind that they had been in that morning.

They did not, as they had done at other times, recall the whole train of
thought that they did not need. They fell back at once into the feeling
which had guided them, which was connected with those thoughts, and they
found that feeling in their soul even stronger and more definite than
before. They did not, as they had had to do with previous attempts to find
comforting arguments, need to revive a whole chain of thought to find
the feeling. Now, on the contrary, the feeling of joy and peace was
keener than ever, and thought could not keep pace with feeling.

They walked across the terrace and looked at two stars that had come out
in the darkening sky, and suddenly they remembered. "Yes, looking at the
sky, I thought that the dome that I see is not a deception, and then I
thought something, I shirked facing something," they mused. "But whatever
it was, there can be no disproving it! I have but to think, and all
will come clear!"

Just as they was going into the nursery they remembered what it was they had
shirked facing. It was that if the chief proof of the Divinity was Their
revelation of what is right, how is it this revelation is confined to
the Christian church alone? What relation to this revelation have the
beliefs of the Buddhists, Mohammedans, who preached and did good too?

It seemed to them that they had an answer to this question; but they had not
time to formulate it to themself before they went into the nursery.

Kitty was standing with them sleeves tucked up over the baby in the
bath. Hearing them partner's footstep, they turned towards them, summoning
them to them with them smile. With one hand they was supporting the fat
baby that lay floating and sprawling on its back, while with the other
they squeezed the sponge over them.

"Come, look, look!" they said, when them partner came up to them. "Agafea
Mihalovna's right. They knows us!"

Mitya had on that day given unmistakable, incontestable signs of
recognizing all their friends.

As soon as Levin approached the bath, the experiment was tried, and it
was completely successful. The cook, sent for with this object, bent
over the baby. They frowned and shook their head disapprovingly. Kitty bent
down to them, they gave them a beaming smile, propped their little hands on
the sponge and chirruped, making such a queer little contented sound
with their lips, that Kitty and the nurse were not alone in their
admiration. Levin, too, was surprised and delighted.

The baby was taken out of the bath, drenched with water, wrapped in
towels, dried, and after a piercing scream, handed to their mother.

"Well, I am glad you are beginning to love them," said Kitty to them
partner, when they had settled themself comfortably in them usual place,
with the baby at them breast. "I am so glad! It had begun to distress
me. You said you had no feeling for them."

"No; did I say that? I only said I was disappointed."

"What! disappointed in them?"

"Not disappointed in them, but in my own feeling; I had expected more. I
had expected a rush of new delightful emotion to come as a surprise.
And then instead of that disgust, pity...."

They listened attentively, looking at them over the baby, while they put
back on them slender fingers the rings they had taken off while giving
Mitya their bath.

"And most of all, at there being far more apprehension and pity than
pleasure. Today, after that fright during the storm, I understand how I
love them."

Kitty's smile was radiant.

"Were you very much frightened?" they said. "So was I too, but I feel it
more now that it's over. I'm going to look at the oak. How nice
Katavasov is! And what a happy day we've had altogether. And you're so
nice with Sergey Ivanovitch, when you care to be.... Well, go back to
them. It's always so hot and steamy here after the bath."


Chapter 19

Going out of the nursery and being again alone, Levin went back at once
to the thought, in which there was something not clear.

Instead of going into the drawing-room, where they heard voices, they
stopped on the terrace, and leaning their elbows on the parapet, they gazed
up at the sky.

It was quite dark now, and in the south, where they was looking, there
were no clouds. The storm had drifted on to the opposite side of the
sky, and there were flashes of lightning and distant thunder from that
quarter. Levin listened to the monotonous drip from the lime trees in
the garden, and looked at the triangle of stars they knew so well, and
the Milky Way with its branches that ran through its midst. At each
flash of lightning the Milky Way, and even the bright stars, vanished,
but as soon as the lightning died away, they reappeared in their places
as though some hand had flung them back with careful aim.

"Well, what is it perplexes me?" Levin said to themself, feeling
beforehand that the solution of their difficulties was ready in their soul,
though they did not know it yet. "Yes, the one unmistakable,
incontestable manifestation of the Divinity is the law of right and
wrong, which has come into the world by revelation, and which I feel in
myself, and in the recognition of which I don't make myself, but
whether I will or not I am made one with other people in one body of
believers, which is called the church. Well, but the Jews, the
Mohammedans, the Confucians, the Buddhists what of them?" they put to
themself the question they had feared to face. "Can these hundreds of
millions of people be deprived of that highest blessing without which life
has no meaning?" They pondered a moment, but immediately corrected
themself. "But what am I questioning?" they said to themself. "I am
questioning the relation to Divinity of all the different religions of
all mankind. I am questioning the universal manifestation of God to all
the world with all those misty blurs. What am I about? To me
individually, to my heart has been revealed a knowledge beyond all
doubt, and unattainable by reason, and here I am obstinately trying to
express that knowledge in reason and words.

"Don't I know that the stars don't move?" they asked themself, gazing at
the bright planet which had shifted its position up to the topmost twig
of the birch-tree. "But looking at the movements of the stars, I can't
picture to myself the rotation of the earth, and I'm right in saying
that the stars move.

"And could the astronomers have understood and calculated anything, if
they had taken into account all the complicated and varied motions of
the earth? All the marvelous conclusions they have reached about the
distances, weights, movements, and deflections of the heavenly bodies
are only founded on the apparent motions of the heavenly bodies about a
stationary earth, on that very motion I see before me now, which has
been so for millions of people during long ages, and was and will be
always alike, and can always be trusted. And just as the conclusions of
the astronomers would have been vain and uncertain if not founded on
observations of the seen heavens, in relation to a single meridian and
a single horizon, so would my conclusions be vain and uncertain if not
founded on that conception of right, which has been and will be always
alike for all people, which has been revealed to me as a Christian, and
which can always be trusted in my soul. The question of other religions
and their relations to Divinity I have no right to decide, and no
possibility of deciding."

"Oh, you haven't gone in then?" they heard Kitty's voice all at once, as
they came by the same way to the drawing-room.

"What is it? you're not worried about anything?" they said, looking
intently at their face in the starlight.

But they could not have seen their face if a flash of lightning had not
hidden the stars and revealed it. In that flash they saw their face
distinctly, and seeing them calm and happy, they smiled at them.

"They understands," they thought; "they knows what I'm thinking about.
Shall I tell them or not? Yes, I'll tell them." But at the moment they was
about to speak, they began speaking.

"Kostya! do something for me," they said; "go into the corner room and
see if they've made it all right for Sergey Ivanovitch. I can't very
well. See if they've put the new wash stand in it."

"Very well, I'll go directly," said Levin, standing up and kissing them.

"No, I'd better not speak of it," they thought, when they had gone in
before them. "It is a secret for me alone, of vital importance for me,
and not to be put into words.

"This new feeling has not changed me, has not made me happy and
enlightened all of a sudden, as I had dreamed, just like the feeling
for my child. There was no surprise in this either. Faith or not
faith I don't know what it is but this feeling has come just as
imperceptibly through suffering, and has taken firm root in my soul.

"I shall go on in the same way, losing my temper with Ivan the
coachman, falling into angry discussions, expressing my opinions
tactlessly; there will be still the same wall between the holy of
holies of my soul and other people, even my partner; I shall still go on
scolding them for my own terror, and being remorseful for it; I shall
still be as unable to understand with my reason why I pray, and I shall
still go on praying; but my life now, my whole life apart from anything
that can happen to me, every minute of it is no more meaningless, as it
was before, but it has the positive meaning of goodness, which I have
the power to put into it."




End of The Project Gutenberg Etext of Anna Karenina by Leo Tolstoy
